
 
<EOS>
Who
Will
Be
the
New
Bishop
?
 
<EOS>
In
the
latter
days
of
July
in
the
year
185
 
,
a
most
important
question
was
for
ten
days
hourly
asked
in
the
cathedral
city
of
Barchester
,
and
answered
every
hour
in
various
ways
 
Who
was
to
be
the
new
bishop
?
  
<EOS>
The
death
of
old
Dr.
Grantly
,
who
had
for
many
years
filled
that
chair
with
meek
authority
,
took
place
exactly
as
the
ministry
of
Lord
 
---
was
going
to
give
place
to
that
of
Lord
 
---
.
<EOS>
The
illness
of
the
good
old
man
was
long
and
lingering
,
and
it
became
at
last
a
matter
of
intense
interest
to
those
concerned
whether
the
new
appointment
should
be
made
by
a
conservative
or
liberal
government
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
pretty
well
understood
that
the
outgoing
premier
had
made
his
selection
and
that
if
the
question
rested
with
him
,
the
mitre
would
descend
on
the
head
of
Archdeacon
<EOS>
Grantly
,
the
old
bishop
's
son
.
<EOS>
The
archdeacon
had
long
managed
the
affairs
of
the
diocese
,
and
for
some
months
previous
to
the
demise
of
his
father
rumour
had
confidently
assigned
to
him
the
reversion
of
his
father
's
honours
.
  
<EOS>
Bishop
Grantly
died
as
he
had
lived
,
peaceably
,
slowly
,
without
pain
and
without
excitement
.
<EOS>
The
breath
ebbed
from
him
almost
imperceptibly
,
and
for
a
month
before
his
death
it
was
a
question
whether
he
were
alive
or
dead
.
  
<EOS>
A
trying
time
was
this
for
the
archdeacon
,
for
whom
was
designed
the
reversion
of
his
father
's
see
by
those
who
then
had
the
giving
away
of
episcopal
thrones
.
<EOS>
I
would
not
be
understood
to
say
that
the
prime
minister
had
in
so
many
words
promised
the
bishopric
to
Dr.
Grantly
.
<EOS>
He
was
too
discreet
a
man
for
that
.
<EOS>
There
is
a
proverb
with
reference
to
the
killing
of
cats
,
and
those
who
know
anything
either
of
high
or
low
government
places
will
be
well
aware
that
a
promise
may
be
made
without
positive
words
and
that
an
expectant
may
be
put
into
the
highest
state
of
encouragement
,
though
the
great
man
on
whose
breath
<EOS>
he
hangs
may
have
done
no
more
than
whisper
that
"
Mr.
So
-
and
-
So
is
certainly
a
rising
man
.
"
  
<EOS>
Such
a
whisper
had
been
made
,
and
was
known
by
those
who
heard
it
to
signify
that
the
cures
of
the
diocese
of
Barchester
should
not
be
taken
out
of
the
hands
of
the
archdeacon
.
<EOS>
The
then
prime
minister
was
all
in
all
at
Oxford
,
and
had
lately
passed
a
night
at
the
house
of
the
Master
of
Lazarus
.
<EOS>
Now
the
Master
of
Lazarus
 
which
is
,
by
the
by
,
in
many
respects
the
most
comfortable
as
well
as
the
richest
college
at
Oxford
 
was
the
archdeacon
's
most
intimate
friend
and
most
trusted
counsellor
.
<EOS>
On
the
occasion
of
the
prime
minister
's
visit
,
Dr.
Grantly
was
of
course
present
,
and
the
meeting
was
very
gracious
.
<EOS>
On
the
following
morning
Dr.
Gwynne
,
the
master
,
told
the
archdeacon
that
in
his
opinion
the
thing
was
settled
.
  
<EOS>
At
this
time
the
bishop
was
quite
on
his
last
legs
;
but
the
ministry
also
were
tottering
.
<EOS>
Dr.
Grantly
returned
from
Oxford
,
happy
and
elated
,
to
resume
his
place
in
the
palace
and
to
continue
to
perform
for
the
father
the
last
duties
of
a
son
,
which
,
to
give
him
his
due
,
he
performed
with
more
tender
care
than
was
to
be
expected
from
his
usual
somewhat
worldly
manners
.
  
<EOS>
A
month
since
,
the
physicians
had
named
four
weeks
as
the
outside
period
during
which
breath
could
be
supported
within
the
body
of
the
dying
man
.
<EOS>
At
the
end
of
the
month
the
physicians
wondered
,
and
named
another
fortnight
.
<EOS>
The
old
man
lived
on
wine
alone
,
but
at
the
end
of
the
fortnight
he
still
lived
,
and
the
tidings
of
the
fall
of
the
ministry
became
more
frequent
.
<EOS>
Sir
Lamda
Mewnew
and
Sir
Omicron
Pie
,
the
two
great
London
doctors
,
now
came
down
for
the
fifth
time
and
declared
,
shaking
their
learned
heads
,
that
another
week
of
life
was
impossible
;
and
as
they
sat
down
to
lunch
in
the
episcopal

-
room
,
whispered
to
the
archdeacon
their
own
private
knowledge
that
the
ministry
must
fall
within
five
days
.
<EOS>
The
son
returned
to
his
father
's
room
and
,
after
administering
with
his
own
hands
the
sustaining
modicum
of
madeira
,
sat
down
by
the
bedside
to
calculate
his
chances
.
  
<EOS>
The
ministry
were
to
be
out
within
five
days
:
his
father
was
to
be
dead
within
 
<EOS>
no
,
he
rejected
that
view
of
the
subject
.
<EOS>
The
ministry
were
to
be
out
,
and
the
diocese
might
probably
be
vacant
at
the
same
period
.
<EOS>
There
was
much
doubt
as
to
the
names
of
the
men
who
were
to
succeed
to
power
,
and
a
week
must
elapse
before
a
cabinet
was
formed
.
<EOS>
Would
not
vacancies
be
filled
by
the
outgoing
men
during
this
week
?
<EOS>
Dr.
Grantly
had
a
kind
of
idea
that
such
would
be
the
case
but
did
not
know
,
and
then
he
wondered
at
his
own
ignorance
on
such
a

.
  
<EOS>
He
tried
to
keep
his
mind
away
from
the
subject
,
but
he
could
not
.
<EOS>
The
race
was
so
very
close
,
and
the
stakes
were
so
very
high
.
<EOS>
He
then
looked
at
the
dying
man
's
impassive
,
placid
face
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
sign
there
of
death
or

;
it
was
something
thinner
than
of
yore
,
somewhat

,
and
the
deep
lines
of
age
more
marked
;
but
,

far

he

,

might
yet

for
weeks
to

.
<EOS>
Sir
Lamda
Mewnew
and
Sir
Omicron
Pie
had
thrice
been
wrong
,
and
might
yet
be
wrong
thrice
again
.
<EOS>
The
old
bishop
slept
during
twenty
of
the
twenty
-
four
hours
,
but
during
the
short
periods
of
his
waking

,
he
knew
both
his
son
and
his
dear
old
friend
,
Mr.
Harding
,
the
archdeacon
's
father
-
in
-
law
,
and
would
thank
them
tenderly
for
their
care
and

.
<EOS>
Now
he
lay
sleeping
like
a
baby
,
resting
easily
on
his
back
,
his
mouth
just
open
,
and
his
few
gray
hairs
straggling
from
beneath
his
cap
;
his
breath
was
perfectly
noiseless
,
and
his
thin
,
wan
hand
,
which
lay
above
the
coverlid
,
never
moved
.
<EOS>
Nothing
could
be
easier
than
the
old
man
's
passage
from
this
world
to
the
next
.
  
<EOS>
But
by
no
means
easy
were
the
emotions
of
him
who
sat
there
watching
.
<EOS>
He
knew
it
must
be
now
or
never
.
<EOS>
He
was
already
over
fifty
,
and
there
was
little
chance
that
his
friends
who
were
now
leaving
office
would
soon
return
to
it
.
<EOS>
No
probable
British
prime
minister
but
he
who
was
now
in
,
he
who
was
so
soon
to
be
out
,
would
think
of
making
a
bishop
of
Dr.
Grantly
.
<EOS>
Thus
he
thought
long
and
sadly
,
in
deep
silence
,
and
then
gazed
at
that
still
living
face
,
and
then
at
last
dared
to
ask
himself
whether
he
really
longed
for
his
father
's
death
.
  
<EOS>
The
effort
was
a
salutary
one
,
and
the
question
was
answered
in
a
moment
.
<EOS>
The
proud
,
wishful
,
worldly
man
sank
on
his
knees
by
the
bedside
and
,
taking
the
bishop
's
hand
within
his
own
,
prayed
eagerly
that
his
sins
might
be
forgiven
him
.
  
<EOS>
His
face
was
still
buried
in
the
clothes
when
the
door
of
the
bedroom
opened
noiselessly
and
Mr.
Harding
entered
with

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
's

at
that
bedside
had
been
nearly
as

as
that
of
the
archdeacon
,
and
his
ingress
and
egress
was
as

course

that
of
his
son
-
in
-
law
.
<EOS>
He

before

,
and
would

.
<EOS>
Dr.
Grantly
,
however
,

and

.
<EOS>
As

did
so
Mr.
Harding
took

.
<EOS>
There
was
more

between

at

,
and

that
after

greatly

.
<EOS>
As

other
's

,
the

.
  
<EOS>
"
God

,
my
dears
,
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
God
bless
you
 
<EOS>
may
God

,

dear
children
.
"
<EOS>
And

.
  
<EOS>
There

,

,

,

,

<EOS>
Neither

"

<EOS>
The

<EOS>
He

<EOS>
It

dally

useless

"
<EOS>
And

<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
Everything

;

<EOS>
Mr.

<EOS>
Dr.

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

!
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
With

<EOS>
The
_

_
,

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

Sydney

<EOS>
Our

last

<EOS>

;

<EOS>
Hiram
's

<EOS>
According

<EOS>
It

Harding

.

"

,

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
When

from

,

;

the

was
,
that
the

in

paragraphs

"
The
Jupiter
.
"
<EOS>
His

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
Mr.

St.
Cuthbert
's
,
in
Barchester
,
and
so

.
<EOS>
Then
the

took

his
case
,
"
The
Jupiter
"
among
the
rest
,
and
wafted

.
<EOS>
It

that

,
_
Harding
's

_
,
 
and

new

was
spoken

,

,

,
never

.
<EOS>
It

,

,

that

James
's
,

"

,
"

,
and

that

name
of
Harding
would

,
or

.
  
<EOS>
This
was
high

,
and
I
will
not

that
Mr.
Harding
was

by

;
for

,

was

.
<EOS>
But

rested
.
<EOS>
The

,

,
was
never

;
the

disappeared

,

,

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Towers
of
"
The
Jupiter
"
and
his
brethren
occupied

with
other
names
,
and
the
undying
fame
promised
to
our
friend
was
clearly
intended
to
be

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
had
spent
much
of
his
time
with
his
friend
the
bishop
;
much
with
his
daughter
Mrs.
Bold
,
now
,

,

;
and
had

of
his

,
the
few

now
left
at
Hiram
's
Hospital
.
<EOS>
Six
of
them
were
still
living
.
<EOS>
The
number
,
according
to
old
Hiram
's
will
,
should
always
have
been
twelve
.
<EOS>
But
after
the
abdication
of
their
warden
,
the
bishop
had
appointed
no
successor
to
him
,
no
new
occupants
of
the
charity
had
been
nominated
,
and
it
appeared
as
though
the
hospital
at
Barchester
would
fall
into

,
unless
the
powers
that
be
should
take
some
steps
towards
putting
it
once
more
into
working
order
.
  
<EOS>
During
the
past
five
years
,
the
powers
that
be
had
not
overlooked
Barchester
Hospital
,
and
sundry
political
doctors
had
taken
the
matter
in
hand
.
<EOS>
Shortly
after
Mr.
Harding
's
resignation
,
"
The
Jupiter
"
had
very
clearly
shown
what
ought
to
be
done
.
<EOS>
In
about
half
a
column
it
had
distributed
the
income
,
rebuilt
the
buildings
,
put
an
end
to
all
bickerings
,
regenerated

feeling
,
provided

Harding
,
and
placed

which
could

.
<EOS>

"

"

<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
But

"

"

"

"

<EOS>
Poor

Bold
!
<EOS>
How

<EOS>
Poor

!
  
<EOS>
Poor
Eleanor
!
<EOS>
I
can
not
say
that
with
me
John
Bold
was
ever

.
<EOS>
I
never
thought

worthy

the
wife

.
<EOS>
But

her

was

.
<EOS>
Hers
was
one
of
those
feminine

which
cling
to
a

,
not

,
for
worship
can

of

,

.
<EOS>
As

,

and

of
her

.
<EOS>
She
had
once
declared
that
whatever
her
father
did
should
in
her

be
right
.
<EOS>
She
then
transferred
her

,
and
became
ever

to

the

of
her

and

.
  
<EOS>
And
John
Bold
was
a
man
to

a

;
he
was
himself

;
he

;

,

,

.
  
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
She

as

;

world
<EOS>
was

;

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
She

that

.
<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
At

!
<EOS>
To

of
a
poor
infant
,

,

,

<EOS>
There

.
  
<EOS>
By

,

,

,

,

.

,

The

<EOS>
But
,

.
<EOS>
This

.
<EOS>
"

?
"

Mary
Bold

.
  
<EOS>
The
baby
was
really
delightful
;
he
took
his

with

,

,

.
<EOS>
These

the

points
of
baby
perfection
,
and
in

our
baby

.
  
<EOS>
And
thus
the
widow
's
deep
grief
was

,
and

sweet

was

into

she

.
<EOS>
How
much

to

than

!
<EOS>
At

,

.
<EOS>
How

!
<EOS>
How

!
"
<EOS>
Let
me

,

dead
,
"
was

.
<EOS>
Few

,

.
  
<EOS>
I

,

,

Mrs.
Bold

.
<EOS>
She
daily

<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
It

to
press
the
living

to
her

,
and

a
human

who

,

,

;

;

;

;

.
<EOS>
And

Eleanor
's

,

.
  
<EOS>
As

world
,
John
Bold
had
left

widow
in

.
<EOS>
He
had

to

,
and

.
<EOS>
It

;

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
When
John
Bold
died
,

to
come
and

with

,
but
this
Mr.
Harding

,
though

.
<EOS>
He

not

upon

own
,
and
so

in

first

over

's

.
   
<EOS>
Dr.
and
Mrs.
Proudie
 
<EOS>
This
narrative
is
supposed
to
commence
immediately
after
the
installation
of
Dr.
Proudie
.
<EOS>
I
will
not
describe
the
ceremony
,
as
I
do
not
precisely
understand
its
nature
.
<EOS>
I
am
ignorant
whether
a
bishop
be
chaired
like
a
member
of
Parliament
,
or
carried
in
a
gilt
coach
like
a
lord
mayor
,
or
sworn
like
a
justice

peace
,
or

to
the
upper
house
,
or
led

like

knight

garter
;
but
I
do
know
that
everything
was
properly
done
,
and
that
nothing
fit

becoming
to
a
young
bishop
was
omitted
on
the

.
  
<EOS>
Dr.
Proudie
was
not
the
man
to
allow
anything
to
be
omitted
that
might
be
becoming
to
his
new
dignity
.
<EOS>
He
understood
well
the
value
of
forms
,
and
knew
that
the
due
observance
of
rank
could
not
be
maintained
unless

to

were

.
<EOS>
He
was
a
man
born
to
move

high

;
at
least
so
he
thought
himself
,
and
circumstances
had
certainly
sustained
him
in
this
view
.
<EOS>
He
was
the
nephew
of
an
Irish
baron
by
his
mother
's
side
,
and
his
wife
was
the
niece
of
a

earl
.
<EOS>
He
had
for
years
held
some
clerical
office
appertaining
to
courtly
matters
,
which
had
enabled
him
to
live
in
London
,
and
to
entrust
his
parish
to
his
curate
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
preacher
to
the
royal
beefeaters
,
curator
of
theological
manuscripts
in
the
Ecclesiastical
Courts
,
chaplain
to
the
Queen
's
yeomanry
guard
,
and
almoner
to
his
Royal
Highness
the
Prince
of
Rappe
-
Blankenberg
.
  
<EOS>
His
residence
in
the
metropolis
,
rendered
necessary
by
duties
thus
entrusted
to
him
,
his
high
connexions
,
and
the
peculiar
talents
and
nature
of
the
man
,
recommended
him
to
persons
in
power
,
and
Dr.
Proudie
became
known
as
a
useful
and
rising
clergyman
.
  
<EOS>
Some
few
years
since
,
even
within
the
memory
of
many
who
are
not
yet
willing
to
call
themselves
old
,
a
liberal
clergyman
was
a
person
not
frequently
to
be
met
.
<EOS>
Sydney
Smith
was
such
and
was
looked
on
as
little
better
than
an
infidel
;
a
few
others
also
might
be
named
,
but
they
were
_
rarae
aves
_
and
were
regarded
with
doubt
and
distrust
by
their
brethren
.
<EOS>
No
man
was
so
surely
a
Tory
as
a
country
rector
 
nowhere
<EOS>
were
the
powers
that
be
so
cherished
as
at
Oxford
.
  
<EOS>
When
,
however
,
Dr.
Whately
was
made
an
archbishop
,
and
Dr.
Hampden
some
years
afterwards
regius
professor
,
many
wise
divines
saw
that
a
change
was
taking
place
in
men
's
minds
,
and
that
more
liberal
ideas
would
henceforward
be
suitable
to
the
priests
as
well
as
to
the
laity
.
<EOS>
Clergymen
began
to
be
heard
of
who
had
ceased
to
anathematize
papists
on
the
one
hand
,
or
vilify
dissenters
on
the
other
.
<EOS>
It
appeared
clear
that
High
Church
principles
,
as
they
are
called
,
were
no
longer
to
be
surest
claims
to
promotion
with
at
any
rate
one
section
of
statesmen
,
and
Dr.
Proudie
was
one
among
those
who
early
in
life
adapted
himself
to
the
views
held
by
the
Whigs
on
most
theological
and
religious
subjects
.
<EOS>
He
bore
with
the
idolatry
of
Rome
,
tolerated
even
the
infidelity
of
Socinianism
,
and
was
hand
and
glove
with
the
Presbyterian
Synods
of
Scotland
and
Ulster
.
  
<EOS>
Such
a
man
at
such
a
time
was
found
to
be
useful
,
and
Dr.
Proudie
's
name
began
to
appear
in
the
newspapers
.
<EOS>
He
was
made
one
of
a
commission
who
went
over
to
Ireland
to
arrange
matters
preparative
to
the
working
of
the
national
board
;
he
became
honorary
secretary
to
another
commission
nominated
to
inquire
into
the
revenues
of
cathedral
chapters
;
he
had
had
something
to
do
with
both
the
_
regium
donum
_
and
the
Maynooth
grant
.
  
<EOS>
It
must
not
on
this
account
be
taken
as
proved
that
Dr.
Proudie
was
a
man
of
great
mental
powers
,
or
even
of
much
capacity
for
business
,
for
such
qualities
had
not
been
required
in
him
.
<EOS>
In
the
arrangement
of
those
church
reforms
with
which
he
was
connected
,
the
ideas
and
original
conception
of
the
work
to
be
done
were
generally
furnished
by
the
liberal
statesmen
of
the
day
,
and
the
labour
of
the
details
was
borne
by
officials
of
a
lower
rank
.
<EOS>
It
was
,
however
,
thought
expedient
that
the
name
of
some
clergyman
should
appear
in
such
matters
,
and
as
Dr.
Proudie
had
become
known
as
a
tolerating
divine
,
great
use
of
this
sort
was
made
of
his
name
.
<EOS>
If
he
did
not
do
much
active
good
,
he
never
did
any
harm
;
he
was
amenable
to
those
who
were
really
in
authority
and
,
at
the
sittings
of
the
various
boards
to
which
he
belonged
,
maintained
a
kind
of
dignity
which
had
its
value
.
  
<EOS>
He
was
certainly
possessed
of
sufficient
tact
to
answer
the
purpose
for
which
he
was
required
without
making
himself
troublesome
;
but
it
must
not
therefore
be
surmised
that
he
doubted
his
own
power
,
or
failed
to
believe
that
he
could
himself
take
a
high
part
in
high
affairs
when
his
own
turn
came
.
<EOS>
He
was
biding
his
time
,
and
patiently
looking
forward
to
the
days
when
he
himself
would
sit
authoritative
at
some
board
,
and
talk
and
direct
,
and
rule
the
roost
,
while
lesser
stars
sat
round
and
obeyed
,
as
he
had
so
well
accustomed
himself
to
do
.
  
<EOS>
His
reward
and
his
time
had
now
come
.
<EOS>
He
was
selected
for
the
vacant
bishopric
and
,
on
the
next
vacancy
which
might
occur
in
any
diocese
,
would
take
his
place
in
the
House
of
Lords
,
prepared
to
give
not
a
silent
vote
in
all
matters
concerning
the
weal
of
the
church
establishment
.
<EOS>
Toleration
was
to
be
the
basis
on
which
he
was
to
fight
his
battles
,
and
<EOS>
in
the
honest
courage
of
his
heart
he
thought
no
evil
would
come
to
him
in
encountering
even
such
foes
as
his
brethren
of
Exeter
and
Oxford
.
  
<EOS>
Dr.
Proudie
was
an
ambitious
man
,
and
before
he
was
well
consecrated
Bishop
of
Barchester
,
he
had
begun
to
look
up
to
archiepiscopal
splendour
,
and
the
glories
of
Lambeth
,
or
at
any
rate
of
Bishopsthorpe
.
<EOS>
He
was
comparatively
young
,
and
had
,
as
he
fondly
flattered
himself
,
been
selected
as
possessing
such
gifts
,
natural
and
acquired
,
as
must
be
sure
to
recommend
him
to
a
yet
higher
notice
,
now
that
a
higher
sphere
was
opened
to
him
.
<EOS>
Dr.
Proudie
was
,
therefore
,
quite
prepared
to
take
a
conspicuous
part
in
all
theological
affairs
appertaining
to
these
realms
;
and
having
such
views
,
by
no
means
intended
to
bury
himself
at
Barchester
as
his
predecessor
had
done
.
<EOS>
No
!
<EOS>
London
should
still
be
his
ground
:
<EOS>
a
comfortable
mansion
in
a
provincial
city
might
be
well
enough
for
the
dead
months
of
the
year
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
Dr.
Proudie
had
always
felt
it
necessary
to
his
position
to
retire
from
London
when
other
great
and
fashionable
people
did
so
;
but
London
should
still
be
his
fixed
residence
,
and
it
was
in
London
that
he
resolved
to
exercise
that
hospitality
<EOS>
so
peculiarly
recommended
to
all
bishops
by
St.
Paul
.
<EOS>
How
otherwise
could
he
keep
himself
before
the
world
?
<EOS>
How
else
give
to
the
government
,
in
matters
theological
,
the
full
benefit
of
his
weight
and
talents
?
  
<EOS>
This
resolution
was
no
doubt
a
salutary
one
as
regarded
the
world
at
large
,
but
was
not
likely
to
make
him
popular
either
with
the
clergy
or
people
of
Barchester
.
<EOS>
Dr.
Grantly
had
always
lived
there
 
in
truth
,
it
was
hard
for
a
bishop
to
be
popular
after
Dr.
Grantly
.
<EOS>
His
income
had
averaged
£
9,000
a
year
;
his
successor
was
to
be
rigidly
limited
to
£
5,000
.
<EOS>
He
had
but
one
child
on
whom
to
spend
his
money
;
Dr.
Proudie
had
seven
or
eight
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
a
man
of
few
personal
expenses
,
and
they
had
been
confined
to
the
tastes
of
a
moderate
gentleman
;
but
Dr.
Proudie
had
to
maintain
a
position
in
fashionable
society
,
and
had
that
to
do
with
comparatively
small
means
.
<EOS>
Dr.
Grantly
had
certainly
kept
his
carriage
as
became
a
bishop
,
but
his
carriage
,
horses
,
and
coachman
,
though
they
did
very
well
for
Barchester
,
would
have
been
almost
ridiculous
at
Westminster
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Proudie
determined
that
her
husband
's
equipage
should
not
shame
her
,
and
things
on
which
Mrs.
Proudie
resolved
were
generally
accomplished
.
  
<EOS>
From
all
this
it
was
likely
to
result
that
Dr.
Proudie
would
not
spend
much
money
at
Barchester
,
whereas
his
predecessor
had
dealt
with
the
tradesmen
of
the
city
in
a
manner
very
much
to
their
satisfaction
.
<EOS>
The
Grantlys
,
father
and
son
,
had
spent
their
money
like
gentlemen
,
but
it
soon
became
whispered
in
Barchester
that
Dr.
Proudie
was
not
unacquainted
with
those
prudent
devices
by
which
the
utmost
show
of
wealth
is
produced
from
limited
means
.
  
<EOS>
In
person
Dr.
Proudie
is
a
good
-
looking
man
;
spruce
and
dapper
,
and
very
tidy
.
<EOS>
He
is
somewhat
below
middle
height
,
being
about
five
feet
four
;
but
he
makes
up
for
the
inches
which
he
wants
by
the
dignity
with
which
he
carries
those
which
he
has
.
<EOS>
It
is
no
fault
of
his
own
if
he
has
not
a
commanding
eye
,
for
he
studies
hard
to
assume
it
.
<EOS>
His
features
are
well
formed
,
though
perhaps
the
sharpness
of
his
nose
may
give
to
his
face
in
the
eyes
of
some
people
an
air
of
insignificance
.
<EOS>
If
so
,
it
is
greatly
redeemed
by
his
mouth
and
chin
,
of
which
he
is
justly
proud
.
  
<EOS>
Dr.
Proudie
may
well
be
said
to
have
been
a
fortunate
man
,
for
he
was
not
born
to
wealth
,
and
he
is
now
Bishop
of
Barchester
;
nevertheless
,
he
has
his
cares
.
<EOS>
He
has
a
large
family
,
of
whom
the
three
eldest
are
daughters
,
now
all
grown
up
and
fit
for
fashionable
life
;
 
and
he
has
a
wife
.
<EOS>
It
is
not
my
intention
to
breathe
a
word
against
the
character
of
Mrs.
Proudie
,
but
still
I
can
not
think
that
with
all
her
virtues
she
adds
much
to
her
husband
's
happiness
.
<EOS>
The
truth
is
that
in
matters
domestic
she
rules
supreme
over
her
titular
lord
,
and
rules
with
a
rod
of
iron
.
<EOS>
Nor
is
this
all
.
<EOS>
Things
domestic
Dr.
Proudie
might
have
abandoned
to
her
,
if
not
voluntarily
,
yet
willingly
.
<EOS>
But
Mrs.
Proudie
is
not
satisfied
with
such
home
dominion
,
and
stretches
her
power
over
all
his
movements
,
and
will
not
even
abstain
from
things
spiritual
.
<EOS>
In
fact
,
the
bishop
is
hen
-
pecked
.
  
<EOS>
The
archdeacon
's
wife
,
in
her
happy
home
at
Plumstead
,
knows
how
to
assume
the
full
privileges
of
her
rank
and
express
her
own
mind
in
becoming
tone
and
place
.
<EOS>
But
Mrs.
Grantly
's
sway
,
if
sway
<EOS>
she
has
,
is
easy
and
beneficent
.
<EOS>
She
never
shames
her
husband
;
before
the
world
she
is
a
pattern
of
obedience
;
her
voice
is
never
loud
,
nor
her
looks
sharp
:
doubtless
she
values
power
,
and
has
not
unsuccessfully
striven
to
acquire
it
;
but
she
knows
what
should
be
the
limits
of
a
woman
's
rule
.
  
<EOS>
Not
so
Mrs.
Proudie
.
<EOS>
This
lady
is
habitually
authoritative
to
all
,
but
to
her
poor
husband
she
is
despotic
.
<EOS>
Successful
as
has
been
his
career
in
the
eyes
of
the
world
,
it
would
seem
that
in
the
eyes
of
his
wife
he
is
never
right
.
<EOS>
All
hope
of
defending
himself
has
long
passed
from
him
;
indeed
he
rarely
even
attempts
self
-
justification
,
and
is
aware
that
submission
produces
the
nearest
approach
to
peace
which
his
own
house
can
ever
attain
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Proudie
has
not
been
able
to
sit
at
the
boards
and
committees
to
which
her
husband
has
been
called
by
the
State
,
nor
,
as
he
often
reflects
,
can
she
make
her
voice
heard
in
the
House
of
Lords
.
<EOS>
It
may
be
that
she
will
refuse
to
him
permission
to
attend
to
this
branch
of
a
bishop
's
duties
;
it
may
be
that
she
will
insist
on
his
close
attendance
to
his
own
closet
.
<EOS>
He
has
never
whispered
a
word
on
the
subject
to
living
ears
,
but
he
has
already
made
his
fixed
resolve
.
<EOS>
Should
such
attempt
be
made
he
will
rebel
.
<EOS>
Dogs
have
turned
against
their
masters
,
and
even
Neapolitans
against
their
rulers
,
when
oppression
has
been
too
severe
.
<EOS>
And
Dr.
Proudie
feels
within
himself
that
if
the
cord
be
drawn
too
tight
,
he
also
can
muster
courage
and
resist
.
  
<EOS>
The
state
of
vassalage
in
which
our
bishop
has
been
kept
by
his
wife
has
not
tended
to
exalt
his
character
in
the
eyes
of
his
daughters
,
who
assume
in
addressing
their
father
too
much
of
that
authority
which
is
not
properly
belonging
,
at
any
rate
,
to
them
.
<EOS>
They
are
,
on
the
whole
,
fine
engaging
young
ladies
.
<EOS>
They
are
tall
and
robust
like
their
mother
,
whose
high
cheek
-
bones
,
and
 
we
may
say
auburn
hair
they
all
inherit
.
<EOS>
They
think
somewhat
too
much
of
their
grand
-
uncles
,
who
have
not
hitherto
returned
the
compliment
by
thinking
much
of
them
.
<EOS>
But
now
that
their
father
is
a
bishop
,
it
is
probable
that
family
ties
will
be
drawn
closer
.
<EOS>
Considering
their
connexion
with
the
church
,
they
entertain
but
few
prejudices
against
the
pleasures
of
the
world
,
and
have
certainly
not
distressed
their
parents
,
as
too
many
English
girls
have
lately
done
,
by
any
enthusiastic
wish
to
devote
themselves
to
the
seclusion
of
a
Protestant
nunnery
.
<EOS>
Dr.
Proudie
's
sons
are
still
at
school
.
  
<EOS>
One
other
marked
peculiarity
in
the
character
of
the
bishop
's
wife
must
be
mentioned
.
<EOS>
Though
not
averse
to
the
society
and
manners
of
the
world
,
she
is
in
her
own
way
a
religious
woman
;
and
the
form
in
which
this
tendency
shows
itself
in
her
is
by
a
strict
observance
of
Sabbatarian
rule
.
<EOS>
Dissipation
and
low
dresses
during
the
week
are
,
under
her
control
,
atoned
for
by
three
services
,
an
evening
sermon
read
by
herself
,
and
a
perfect
abstinence
from
any
cheering
employment
on
the
Sunday
.
<EOS>
Unfortunately
for
those
under
her
roof
to
whom
the
dissipation
and
low
dresses
are
not
extended
,
her
servants
namely
and
her
husband
,
the
compensating
strictness
of
the
Sabbath
includes
all
.
<EOS>
Woe
betide
the
recreant
housemaid
who
is
found
to
have
been
listening
to
the
honey
of
a
sweetheart
in
the
Regent
's
park
instead
of
the
soul
-
stirring
evening
discourse
of
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
Not
only
is
she
sent
adrift
,
but
she
is
so
sent
with
a
character
which
leaves
her
little
hope
of
a
decent
place
.
<EOS>
Woe
betide
the
six
-
foot
hero
who
escorts
Mrs.
Proudie
to
her
pew
in
red
plush
breeches
,
if
he
slips
away
to
the
neighbouring
beer
-
shop
,
instead
of
falling
into
the
back
seat
appropriated
to
his
use
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Proudie
has
the
eyes
of
Argus
for
such
offenders
.
<EOS>
Occasional
drunkenness
in
the
week
may
be
overlooked
,
for
six
feet
on
low
wages
are
hardly
to
be
procured
if
the
morals
are
always
kept
at
a
high
pitch
,
but
not
even
for
grandeur
or
economy
will
Mrs.
Proudie
forgive
a
desecration
of
the
Sabbath
.
  
<EOS>
In
such
matters
Mrs.
Proudie
allows
herself
to
be
often
guided
by
that
eloquent
preacher
,
the
Rev.
Mr.
Slope
,
and
as
Dr.
Proudie
is
guided
by
his
wife
,
it
necessarily
follows
that
the
eminent
man
we
have
named
has
obtained
a
good
deal
of
control
over
Dr.
Proudie
in
matters
concerning
religion
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
's
only
preferment
has
hitherto
been
that
of
reader
and
preacher
in
a
London
district
church
;
and
on
the

of
his
friend

new

,

readily
gave
this
up
to
undertake
the
onerous
but

of
domestic

to

lordship
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
,
however
,
on
his
first
introduction
must
not
be
brought
before
the
public
at
the
tail
of
a

.
   
<EOS>
The
Bishop
's
Chaplain
 
Of
the
Rev.
Mr.
Slope
's
parentage
<EOS>
I
am
not
able
to
say
much
.
<EOS>
I
have
heard
it
asserted
that
he
is
lineally
descended
from
that
eminent
physician
who
assisted
at
the
birth
of
Mr.
T.
Shandy
,
and
that
in
early
years
he
added
an
"
e
"
to
his
name
,
for
the
sake
of
euphony
,
as
other
great
men
have
done
before
him
.
<EOS>
If
this
be
so
,
I
presume
he
was
christened
Obadiah
,
for
that
is
his
name
,
in
commemoration
of
the
conflict
in
which
his
ancestor
so
distinguished
himself
.
<EOS>
All
my
researches
on
the
subject
have
,
however
,
failed
in
enabling
me
to
fix
the
date
on
which
the
family
changed
its
religion
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
been
a
sizar
at
Cambridge
,
and
had
there
conducted
himself
at
any
rate
successfully
,
for
in
due
process
of
time
<EOS>
he
was
an
M.A.
,
having
university
pupils
under
his
care
.
<EOS>
From
thence
he
was
transferred
to
London
,
and
became
preacher
at
a
new
district
church
built
on
the
confines
of
Baker
Street
.
<EOS>
He
was
in
this
position
when
congenial
ideas
on
religious
subjects
recommended
him
to
Mrs.
Proudie
,
and
the
intercourse
had
become
close
and

.
  
<EOS>
Having
been
thus

thrown
among
the
Misses
Proudie
,
it
was
no
more
than
natural
that
some
softer

than

should
be
engendered
.
<EOS>
There
have
been
some
passages
of
love
between
him
and
the
eldest
hope
,
Olivia
,
but
they
have
hitherto
resulted
in
no

.
<EOS>
In
truth
,
Mr.
Slope
,
having
made

,
afterwards
withdrew
it
on
finding
that
the
doctor
had
no

with

,
and

may

that
Miss
Proudie
,

such

on

,
was
not

to

.
<EOS>
On
the
appointment
of
Dr.
Proudie
to
the

of
Barchester
,
Mr.
Slope
's
views
were
in

.
<EOS>
Bishops
,
even
though
they
be
poor
,
can
provide
for
clerical
children
,
and
Mr.
Slope
began
to
regret
that

had
not

.
<EOS>
He
no

of
the

's

than

his

,
not

,

,
but

,

.
<EOS>
Olivia
Proudie
,
however
,
was
a
girl
of
spirit
:
she
had
the
blood
of
two
peers
in
her

,
and
better
still
she
had
another
lover
on

books
,
so
Mr.
Slope
sighed
in
vain
,
and
the
pair
soon
found
it
convenient
to
establish
a
mutual

of

.
  
<EOS>
It
may
be
thought
singular
that
Mrs.
Proudie
's

for

young

should
remain
firm
after
such
an

,
but
,
to

truth
,
she
had
known

of

.
<EOS>
Though
very
fond
of
Mr.
Slope
herself
,
she
had
never

idea
that
either
of
her

would
become
so
,
and
remembering
their
high
birth

,
expected

matches

a
different

.
<EOS>
Neither
the
gentleman
nor
the

found

to

.
<EOS>
Olivia
's
two
sisters
had
each
known
of
the
affair
,
as

all

,
as

in
the

on
either

,
but
Mrs.
Proudie
had
been
kept

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
soon
comforted
himself
with
the

that
,
as
he
had
been
selected

,

to

in

bishop
's

without
troubling
himself
with
the
bishop
's
daughter
,
and
he
found
himself
able
to

.
<EOS>
As

down
in

,

,

to

.
<EOS>
He
knew
well
his
patron
's

,
but
he
knew
the
weak

as
well
.
<EOS>
He
understood
correctly
enough
to
what
attempts
the
new
bishop
's
high
spirit
would

,
and
he
rightly
guessed
that
public

would
better
suit
the
great
man
's

than

.
  
<EOS>
He
,
therefore
,
 
he
,
Mr.
Slope
,
 
would
in
effect
be
Bishop
of
Barchester
.
<EOS>
Such
was
his
resolve
,
and
to
give
Mr.
Slope
his
due
,
he
had
both
courage
and
spirit
to
bear

out
in

.
<EOS>
He
knew
that
he
should
have
a
hard
battle
to
fight
,
for
the
power
and
patronage
of
the
see
would
be
equally
coveted
by
another
great
mind
 
<EOS>
Mrs.
Proudie
would
also
choose
to
be
Bishop
of
Barchester
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
,
however
,
flattered
himself
that
he
could
outmanoeuvre
the
lady
.
<EOS>
She
must
live
much
in
London
,
while
he
would
always
be
on
the
spot
.
<EOS>
She
would
necessarily
remain
ignorant
of
much
,
while
he
would
know
everything
belonging
to
the
diocese
.
<EOS>
At
first
,
doubtless
,
he
must
flatter
and
cajole
,
perhaps
yield
in
some
things
,
but
he
did
not
doubt
of
ultimate

.
<EOS>
If
all
other
means
failed
,
he
could
join
the
bishop
against
his
wife
,
inspire
courage
into
the
unhappy
man
,
lay
an
axe
to
the
root
of
the
woman
's
power
,
and
emancipate
the
husband
.
  
<EOS>
Such
were
his
thoughts
as
he
sat
looking
at
the
sleeping
pair
in
the
railway
carriage
,
and
Mr.
Slope
is
not
the
man
to
trouble
himself
with
such
thoughts
for
nothing
.
<EOS>
He
is
possessed
of
more
than
average
abilities
,
and
is
of
good
courage
.
<EOS>
Though
he
can
stoop
to
fawn
,
and
stoop
low
indeed
,
if
need
be
,
he
has
still
within
him
the
power
to
assume
the
tyrant
;
 
and
with
the
power
he
has
certainly
the
wish
.
<EOS>
His
acquirements
are
not
of
the
highest
order
,
but
such
as
they
are
,
they
are
completely
under
control
,
and
he
knows
the
use
of
them
.
<EOS>
He
is
gifted
with
a
certain
kind
of
pulpit
eloquence
,
not
likely
indeed
to
be
persuasive
with
men
,
but
powerful
with
the
softer
sex
.
<EOS>
In
his
sermons
he
deals
greatly
in
denunciations
,
excites
the
minds
of
his
weaker
hearers
with
a
not
unpleasant
terror
,
and
leaves
an
impression
on
their
minds
that
all
mankind
are
in
a
perilous
state
,
and
all
womankind
,
too
,
except
those
who
attend
regularly
to
the
evening
lectures
in
Baker
Street
.
<EOS>
His
looks
and
tones
are
extremely
severe
,
so
much
so
<EOS>
that
one
can
not
but
fancy
that
he
regards
the
greater
part
of
the
world
as
being
infinitely
too
bad
for
his
care
.
<EOS>
As
he
walks
through
the
streets
his
very
face
denotes
his
horror
of
the
world
's
wickedness
,
and
there
is
always
an
anathema
lurking
in
the
corner
of
his
eye
.
  
<EOS>
In
doctrine
he
,
like
his
patron
,
is
tolerant
of
dissent
,
if
so
strict
a
mind
can
be
called
tolerant
of
anything
.
<EOS>
With
Wesleyan
-
Methodists
he
has
something
in
common
,
but
his
soul
trembles
in
agony
at
the
iniquities
of
the
Puseyites
.
<EOS>
His
aversion
is
carried
to
things
outward
as
well
as
inward
.
<EOS>
His
gall
rises
at
a
new
church
with
a
high
-
pitched
roof
;
a
full
-
breasted
black
silk
waistcoat
is
with
him
a
symbol
of
Satan
;
and
a
profane
jest
-
book
would
not
,
in
his
view
,
more
foully
desecrate
the
church
seat
of
a
Christian
than
a
book
of
prayer
printed
with
red
letters
and
ornamented
with
a
cross
on
the
back
.
<EOS>
Most
active
clergymen
have
their
hobby
,
and
Sunday
observances
are
his
.
<EOS>
Sunday
,
however
,
is
a
word
which
never
pollutes
his
mouth
 
<EOS>
it
is
always
"
the
Sabbath
.
<EOS>
"
The
"
desecration
of
the
Sabbath
,
"
as
he
delights
to
call
it
,
is
to

meat
and
drink
:
he
thrives
upon
that
as
policemen
do
on
the
general
evil

of
the
community
.
<EOS>
It
is
the
loved
subject
of
all
his
evening

,
the
source
of
all
his
eloquence
,
the
secret
of
all
his
power
over
the
female
heart
.
<EOS>
To
him
the
revelation
of
God
appears
only
in
that
one
law
given
for
Jewish
observance
.
<EOS>
To
him
the
mercies
of
our
Saviour
speak
in
vain
,
to
him
in
vain
has
been
preached
that
sermon
which
fell
from
divine
lips
on
the
mountain
 
<EOS>
"
Blessed
are
the
meek
,
for
they
shall
inherit
the
earth
"
 
<EOS>
"
Blessed
are
the
merciful
,
for
they
shall
obtain
mercy
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
To
him
the
New
Testament
is
comparatively
of
little
moment
,
for
from
it
can
he
draw
no
fresh
authority
for
that
dominion
which
he
loves
to
exercise
over
at
least
a
seventh
part
of
man
's
allotted
time
here
below
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
is
tall
,
and
not
ill
-
made
.
<EOS>
His
feet
and
hands
are
large
,
as
has
ever
been
the
case
with
all
his
family
,
but
he
has
a
broad
chest
and
wide
shoulders
to
carry
off
these
excrescences
,
and
on
the
whole
his
figure
is
good
.
<EOS>
His
countenance
,
however
,
is
not
specially
prepossessing
.
<EOS>
His
hair
is
lank
and
of
a
dull
pale
reddish
hue
.
<EOS>
It
is
always
formed
into
three
straight
,
lumpy
masses
,
each
brushed
with
admirable
precision
and
cemented
with
much
grease
;
two
of
them
adhere
closely
to
the
sides
of
his
face
,
and
the
other
lies
at
right
angles
above
them
.
<EOS>
He
wears
no
whiskers
,
and
is
always
punctiliously
shaven
.
<EOS>
His
face
is
nearly
of
the
same
colour
as
his
hair
,
though
perhaps
a
little
redder
:
it
is
not
unlike
beef
 
beef
,
however
,
one
would
say
,
of
a
bad
quality
.
<EOS>
His
forehead
is
capacious
and
high
,
but
square
and
heavy
and
unpleasantly
shining
.
<EOS>
His
mouth
is
large
,
though
his
lips
are
thin
and
bloodless
;
and
his
big
,
prominent
,
pale
-
brown
eyes
inspire
anything
but
confidence
.
<EOS>
His
nose
,
however
,
is
his
redeeming
feature
:
it
is
pronounced
,
straight
and
well
-
formed
;
though
I
myself
should
have
liked
it
better
did
it
not
possess
a
somewhat
spongy
,
porous
appearance
,
as
though
it
had
been
cleverly
formed
out
of
a
red
-
coloured
cork
.
  
<EOS>
I
never
could
endure
to
shake
hands
with
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
A
cold
,
clammy
perspiration
always
exudes
from
him
,
the
small
drops
are
ever
to
be
seen
standing
on
his
brow
,
and
his
friendly
grasp
is
unpleasant
.
  
<EOS>
Such
is
Mr.
Slope
 
<EOS>
such
is
the
man
who
has
suddenly
fallen
into
the
midst
of
Barchester
Close
,
and
is
destined
there
to
assume
the
station
which
has
heretofore
been
filled
by
the
son
of
the
late
bishop
.
<EOS>
Think
,
<EOS>
oh
,
my
meditative
reader
,
<EOS>
what
an
associate
we
have
here
for
those
comfortable
prebendaries
,
those
gentlemanlike
clerical
doctors
,
those
happy
,
well
-
used
,
well
-
fed
minor
canons
who
have
grown
into
existence
at
Barchester
under
the
kindly
wings
of
Bishop
Grantly
!
  
<EOS>
But
not
as
a
mere
associate
for
these
does
Mr.
Slope
travel
down
to
Barchester
with
the
bishop
and
his
wife
.
<EOS>
He
intends
to
be
,
if
not
their
master
,
at
least
the
chief
among
them
.
<EOS>
He
intends
to
lead
and
to
have
followers
;
he
intends
to
hold
the
purse
-
strings
of
the
diocese
and
draw
round
him
an
obedient
herd
of
his
poor
and
hungry
brethren
.
  
<EOS>
And
here
we
can
hardly
fail
to
draw
a
comparison
between
the
archdeacon
and
our
new
private
chaplain
,
and
despite
the
manifold
faults
of
the
former
,
one
can
hardly
fail
to
make
it
much
to
his
advantage
.
  
<EOS>
Both
men
are
eager
,
much
too
eager
,
to
support
and
increase
the
power
of
their
order
.
<EOS>
Both
are
anxious
that
the
world
should
be
priest
-
governed
,
though
they
have
probably
never
confessed
so
much
,
even
to
themselves
.
<EOS>
Both
begrudge
any
other
kind
of
dominion
held
by
man
over
man
.
<EOS>
Dr.
Grantly
,
if
he
admits
the
Queen
's
supremacy
in
things
spiritual
,
only
admits
it
as
being
due
to
the
quasi
-
priesthood
conveyed
in
the
consecrating
qualities
of
her
coronation
,
and
he
regards
things
temporal
as
being
by
their
nature
subject
to
those
which
are
spiritual
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
's
ideas
of
sacerdotal
rule
are
of
quite
a
different
class
.
<EOS>
He
cares
nothing
,
one
way
or
the
other
,
for
the
Queen
's
supremacy
;
these
to
his
ears
are
empty
words
,
meaning
nothing
.
<EOS>
Forms
he
regards
but
little
,
and
such
titular
expressions
as
supremacy
,
consecration
,
ordination
,
and
the
like
convey
of
themselves
no
significance
to
him
.
<EOS>
Let
him
be
supreme
who
can
.
<EOS>
The
temporal
king
,
judge
,
or
gaoler
can
work
but
on
the
body
.
<EOS>
The
spiritual
master
,
if
he
have
the
necessary
gifts
and
can
duly
use
them
,
has
a
wider
field
of
empire
.
<EOS>
He
works
upon
the
soul
.
<EOS>
If
he
can
make
himself
be
believed
,
he
can
be
all
powerful
over
those
who
listen
.
<EOS>
If
he
be
careful
to
meddle
with
none
who
are
too
strong
in
intellect
,
or
too
weak
in
flesh
,
he
may
indeed
be
supreme
.
<EOS>
And
such
was
the
ambition
of
Mr.
Slope
.
  
<EOS>
Dr.
Grantly
interfered
very
little
with
the
worldly
doings
of
those
who
were
in
any
way
subject
to
him
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
mean
to
say
that
he
omitted
to
notice
misconduct
among
his
clergy
,
immorality
in
his
parish
,
or
omissions
in
his
family
,
but
he
was
not
anxious
to
do
so
where
the
necessity
could
be
avoided
.
<EOS>
He
was
not
troubled
with
a
propensity
to
be
curious
,
and
as
long
as
those
around
him
were
tainted
with
no
heretical
leaning
towards
dissent
,
as
long
as
they
fully
and
freely
admitted
the
efficacy
of
Mother
Church
,
he
was
willing
that
that
mother
should
be
merciful
and
affectionate
,
prone
to
indulgence
,
and
unwilling
to
chastise
.
<EOS>
He
himself
enjoyed
the
good
things
of
this
world
and
liked
to
let
it
be
known
that
he
did
so
.
<EOS>
He
cordially
despised
any
brother
rector
who
thought
harm
of
dinner
-
parties
,
or
dreaded
the
dangers
of
a
moderate
claret
-
jug
;
consequently
,
dinner
-
parties
and
claret
-
jugs
were
common
in
the
diocese
.
<EOS>
He
liked
to
give
laws
and
to
be
obeyed
in
them
implicitly
,
but
he
endeavoured
that
his
ordinances
should
be
within
the
compass
of
the
man
and
not
unpalatable
to
the
gentleman
.
<EOS>
He
had
ruled
among
his
clerical
neighbours
now
for
sundry
years
,
and
as
he
had
maintained
his
power
without
becoming
unpopular
,
it
may
be
presumed
that
he
had
exercised
some
wisdom
.
  
<EOS>
Of
Mr.
Slope
's
conduct
much
can
not
be
said
,
as
his
grand
career
is
yet
to
commence
,
but
it
may
be
premised
that
his
tastes
will
be
very
different
from
those
of
the
archdeacon
.
<EOS>
He
conceives
it
to
be
his
duty
to
know
all
the
private
doings
and
desires
of
the
flock
entrusted
to
his
care
.
<EOS>
From
the
poorer
classes
he
exacts
an
unconditional
obedience
to
set
rules
of
conduct
,
and
if
disobeyed
he
has
recourse
,
like
his
great
ancestor
,
to
the
fulminations
of
an
Ernulfus
:
"
Thou
shalt
be
damned
in
thy
going
in
and
<EOS>
in
thy
coming
out
 
in
thy
eating
and
thy
drinking
,
"
&
c.
&
c.
&
c.
<EOS>
With
the
rich
,
experience
has
already
taught
him
that
a
different
line
of
action
is
necessary
.
<EOS>
Men
in
the
upper
walks
of
life
do
not
mind
being
cursed
,
and
the
women
,
presuming
that
it
be
done
in
delicate
phrase
,
rather
like
it
.
<EOS>
But
he
has
not
,
therefore
,
given
up
so
important
a
portion
of
believing
Christians
.
<EOS>
With
the
men
,
indeed
,
he
is
generally
at
variance
;
they
are
hardened
sinners
,
on
whom
the
voice
of
the
priestly
charmer
too
often
falls
in
vain
;
but
with
the
ladies
,
old
and
young
,
firm
and
frail
,
devout
and
dissipated
,
he
is
,
as
he
conceives
,
all
powerful
.
<EOS>
He
can
reprove
faults
with
so
much
flattery
and
utter
censure
in
so
caressing
a
manner
that
the
female
heart
,
if
it
glow
with
a
spark
of
Low
Church
susceptibility
,
can
not
withstand
him
.
<EOS>
In
many
houses
he
is
thus
an
admired
guest
:
the
husbands
,
for
their
wives
"
sake
,
are
fain
to
admit
him
;
and
when
once
admitted
it
is
not
easy
to
shake
him
off
.
<EOS>
He
has
,
however
,
a
pawing
,
greasy
way
with
him
,
which
does
not
endear
him
to
those
who
do
not
value
him
for
their
souls
"
sake
,
and
he
is
not
a
man
to
make
himself
at
once
popular
in
a
large
circle
such
as
is
now
likely
to
surround
him
at
Barchester
.
   
<EOS>
A
Morning
Visit
 
<EOS>
It
was
known
that
Dr.
Proudie
would
immediately
have
to
reappoint
to
the
wardenship
of
the
hospital
under
the
act
of
Parliament
to
which
allusion
has
been
made
;
no
one
imagined
that
any
choice
was
left
to
him
 
<EOS>
no
one
for
a
moment
thought
that
he
could
appoint
any
other
than
Mr.
Harding
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
himself
,
when
he
heard
how
the
matter
had
been
settled
,
without
troubling
himself
much
on
the
subject
,
considered
it
as
certain
that
he
would
go
back
to
his
pleasant
house
and
garden
.
<EOS>
And
though
there
would
be
much
that
was
melancholy
,
nay
,
almost
heartrending
,
in
such
a
return
,
he
still
was
glad
that
it
was
to
be
so
.
<EOS>
His
daughter
might
probably
be
persuaded
to
return
there
with
him
.
<EOS>
She
had
,
indeed
,
all
but
promised
to
do
so
,
though
she
still
entertained
an
idea
that
that
greatest
of
mortals
,
that
important
atom
of
humanity
,
that
little
god
upon
earth
,
Johnny
Bold
her
baby
,
ought
to
have
a
house
of
his
own
over
his
head
.
  
<EOS>
Such
being
the
state
of
Mr.
Harding
's
mind
in
the
matter
,
he
did
not
feel
any
peculiar
personal
interest
in
the
appointment
of
Dr.
Proudie
to
the
bishopric
.
<EOS>
He
,
as
well
as
others
at
Barchester
,
regretted
that
a
man
should
be
sent
among
them
who
,
they
were
aware
,
was
not
of
their
way
of
thinking
;
but
Mr.
Harding
himself
was
not
a
bigoted
man
on
points
of
church
doctrine
,
and
he
was
quite
prepared
to
welcome
Dr.
Proudie
to
Barchester
in
a
graceful
and
becoming
manner
.
<EOS>
He
had
nothing
to
seek
and
nothing
to
fear
;
he
felt
that
it
behoved
him
to
be
on
good
terms
with
his
bishop
,
and
he
did
not
anticipate
any
obstacle
that
would
prevent
it
.
  
<EOS>
In
such
a
frame
of
mind
he
proceeded
to
pay
his
respects
at
the
palace
the
second
day
after
the
arrival
of
the
bishop
and
his
chaplain
.
<EOS>
But
he
did
not
go
alone
.
<EOS>
Dr.
Grantly
proposed
to
accompany
him
,
and
Mr.
Harding
was
not
sorry
to
have
a
companion
,
who
would
remove
from
his
shoulders
the
burden
of
the
conversation
in
such
an
interview
.
<EOS>
In
the
affair
of
the
consecration
Dr.
Grantly
had
been
introduced
to
the
bishop
,
and
Mr.
Harding
had
also
been
there
.
<EOS>
He
had
,
however
,
kept
himself
in
the
background
,
and
he
was
now
to
be
presented
to
the
great
man
for
the
first
time
.
  
<EOS>
The
archdeacon
's
feelings
were
of
a
much
stronger
nature
.
<EOS>
He
was
not
exactly
the
man
to
overlook
his
own
slighted
claims
,
or
to
forgive
the
preference
shown
to
another
.
<EOS>
Dr.
Proudie
was
playing
Venus
to
his
Juno
,
and
he
was
prepared
to
wage
an
internecine
war
against
the
owner
of
the
wished
-
for
apple
,
and
all
his
satellites
,
private
chaplains
,
and
others
.
  
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,
it
behoved
him
also
to
conduct
himself
towards
the
intruder
as
an
old
archdeacon
should
conduct
himself
to
an
incoming
bishop
;
and
though
he
was
well
aware
of
all
Dr.
Proudie
's
abominable
opinions
as
regarded
dissenters
,
church
reform
,
the
hebdomadal
council
,
and
such
like
;
though
he
disliked
the
man
,
and
hated
the
doctrines
,
still
he
was
prepared
to
show
respect
to
the
station
of
the
bishop
.
<EOS>
So
he
and
Mr.
Harding
called
together
at
the
palace
.
  
<EOS>
His
lordship
was
at
home
,
and
the
two
visitors
were
shown
through
the
accustomed
hall
into
the
well
-
known
room
where
the
good
old
bishop
used
to
sit
.
<EOS>
The
furniture
had
been
bought
at
a
valuation
,
and
every
chair
and
table
,
every
bookshelf
against
the
wall
,
and
every
square
in
the
carpet
was
as
well
known
to
each
of
them
as
their
own
bedrooms
.
<EOS>
Nevertheless
they
at
once
felt
that
they
were
strangers
there
.
<EOS>
The
furniture
was
for
the
most
part
the
same
,
yet
the
place
had
been
metamorphosed
.
<EOS>
A
new
sofa
had
been
introduced
,
a
horrid
chintz
affair
,
most
unprelatical
and
almost
irreligious
;
such
a
sofa
as
never
yet
stood
in
the
study
of
any
decent
High
Church
clergyman
of
the
Church
of
England
.
<EOS>
The
old
curtains
had
also
given
way
.
<EOS>
They
had
,
to
be
sure
,
become
dingy
,
and
that
which
had
been
originally
a
rich
and
goodly
ruby
had
degenerated
into
a
reddish
brown
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
,
however
,
thought
the
old
reddish
-
brown
much
preferable
to
the
gaudy
buff
-
coloured
trumpery
moreen
which
Mrs.
Proudie
had
deemed
good
enough
for
her
husband
's
own
room
in
the
provincial
city
of
Barchester
.
  
<EOS>
Our
friends
found
Dr.
Proudie
sitting
on
the
old
bishop
's
chair
,
looking
very
nice
in
his
new
apron
;
they
found
,
too
,
Mr.
Slope
standing
on
the
hearth
-
rug
,
persuasive
and
eager
,
just
as
the
archdeacon
used
to
stand
;
but
on
the
sofa
they
also
found
Mrs.
Proudie
,
an
innovation
for
which
a
precedent
might
in
vain
be
sought
in
all
the
annals
of
the
Barchester
bishopric
!
  
<EOS>
There
she
was
,
however
,
and
they
could
only
make
the
best
of
her
.
<EOS>
The
introductions
were
gone
through
in
much
form
.
<EOS>
The
archdeacon
shook
hands
with
the
bishop
,
and
named
Mr.
Harding
,
who
received
such
an
amount
of
greeting
as
was
due
from
a
bishop
to
a
precentor
.
<EOS>
His
lordship
then
presented
them
to
his
lady
wife
;
the
archdeacon
first
,
with
archidiaconal
honours
,
and
then
the
precentor
with
diminished
parade
.
<EOS>
After
this
Mr.
Slope
presented
himself
.
<EOS>
The
bishop
,
it
is
true
,
did
mention
his
name
,
and
so
did
Mrs.
Proudie
too
,
in
a
louder
tone
,
but
Mr.
Slope
took
upon
himself
the
chief
burden
of
his
own
introduction
.
<EOS>
He
had
great
pleasure
in
making
himself
acquainted
with
Dr.
Grantly
;
he
had
heard
much
of
the
archdeacon
's
good
works
in
that
part
of
the
diocese
in
which
his
duties
as
archdeacon
had
been
exercised
(
thus
purposely
ignoring
the
archdeacon
's
hitherto
unlimited
dominion
over
the
diocese
at
large
)
.
<EOS>
He
was
aware
that
his
lordship
depended
greatly
on
the
assistance
which
Dr.
Grantly
would
be
able
to
give

in
that

of
his
diocese
.
<EOS>
He
then
thrust
out
his
hand
and
,
grasping
that
of
his
new
foe
,
bedewed
it
unmercifully
.
<EOS>
Dr.
Grantly
in
return
bowed
,
looked
stiff
,
contracted
his
eyebrows
,
and
wiped
his
hand
with
his
pocket
-
handkerchief
.
<EOS>
Nothing
abashed
,
Mr.
Slope
then
noticed
the
precentor
and
descended
to
the
grade
of
the
lower
clergy
.
<EOS>
He
gave
him
a
squeeze
of
the
hand
,
damp
indeed
,
but
affectionate
,
and
was
very
glad
to
make
the
acquaintance
of
Mr.
 
<EOS>
oh
yes
,
Mr.
Harding
;
he
had
not
exactly
caught
the
name
.
<EOS>
"
Precentor
in
the
cathedral
,
"
surmised

Slope
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
confessed
that
such
was
the
humble
sphere
of
his
work
.
<EOS>
"
Some
parish
duty
as
well
,
"
suggested
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
acknowledged
the
diminutive
incumbency
of
St.
Cuthbert
's
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
then
left
him
alone
,
having
condescended
sufficiently
,
and
joined
the
conversation
among
the
higher
powers
.
  
<EOS>
There
were
four
persons
there
,
each
of
whom
considered
himself
the
most
important
personage
in
the
diocese
 
himself
,
indeed
,
or
herself
,
as
Mrs.
Proudie
was
one

them
 
and
with
such

opinion
it
was
not

that

would
get
on

together
.
<EOS>
The
bishop
himself
actually
wore
the
visible
apron
,
and
trusted
mainly
to
that
 
to
that
and
his
title
,
both
being
facts
which
could
not

.
<EOS>
The
archdeacon
knew
his
subject
and
really
understood
the
business
of
bishoping
,
which
the
others
did
not
,
and
this
was
his
strong
ground
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Proudie
had
her
sex
to
back
her
,
and
her
habit
of
command
,
and
was
nothing
daunted
by
the
high
tone
of
Dr.
Grantly
's
face
and
figure
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
had
only
himself
and
his
own
courage
and
tact
to
depend
on
,
but
he
nevertheless
was
perfectly
self
-
assured
,
and
did
not
doubt
but
that
he
should
soon
get
the
better
of
weak
men
who
trusted
so
much
to
externals
,
as
both
bishop
and
archdeacon
appeared
to
do
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
reside
in
Barchester
,
Dr.
Grantly
?
"
asked
the
lady
with
her
sweetest
smile
.
  
<EOS>
Dr.
Grantly
explained
that
he
lived
in
his
own
parish
of
Plumstead
Episcopi
,
a
few
miles
out
of
the
city
.
<EOS>
Whereupon
the
lady
hoped
that
the
distance
was
not
too
great
for
country
visiting
,
as
she
would
be
so
glad
to
make
the
acquaintance
of
Mrs.
Grantly
.
<EOS>
She
would
take
the
earliest
opportunity
,
after
the
arrival
of
her
horses
at
Barchester
;
their
horses
were
at
present
in
London
;
their
horses
were
not
immediately
coming
down
,
as
the
bishop
would
be
obliged
,
in
a
few
days
,
to
return
to
town
.
<EOS>
Dr.
Grantly
was
no
doubt
aware
<EOS>
that
the
bishop
was
at
present
much
called
upon
by
the
"
University
Improvement
Committee
:
"
indeed
,
the
committee
could
not
well
proceed
without
him
,
as
their
final
report
had
now
to
be
drawn
up
.
<EOS>
The
bishop
had
also
to
prepare
a
scheme
for
the
"
Manufacturing
Towns
Morning
and
Evening
Sunday
School
Society
,
"
of
which
he
was
a
patron
,
or
president
,
or
director
,
and
therefore
the
horses
would
not
come
down
to
Barchester
at
present
;
but
whenever
the
horses
did
come
down
,
she
would
take
the
earliest
opportunity
of
calling
at
Plumstead
Episcopi
,
providing
the
distance
was
not
too
great
for
country
visiting
.
  
<EOS>
The
archdeacon
made
his
fifth
bow
 
he
had
made
one
at
each
mention
of
the
horses
 
and
promised
that
Mrs.
Grantly
would
do
herself
the
honour
of
calling
at
the
palace
on
an
early
day
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Proudie
declared
that
she
would
be
delighted
:
she
had
n't
liked
to
ask
,
not
being
quite
sure
whether
Mrs.
Grantly
had
horses
;
besides
,
the
distance
might
have
been
,
&
c.
&
c.
  
<EOS>
Dr.
Grantly
again
bowed
but
said
nothing
.
<EOS>
He
could
have
bought
every
individual
possession
of
the
whole
family
of
the
Proudies
and
have
restored
them
as
a
gift
,
without
much
feeling
the
loss
;
and
had
kept
a
separate
pair
of
horses
for
the
exclusive
use
of
his
wife
since
the
day
of
his
marriage
,
whereas
Mrs.
Proudie
had
been
hitherto
jobbed
about
the
streets
of
London
at
so
much
a
month
,
during
the
season
,
and
at
other
times
had
managed
to
walk
,
or
hire
a
smart
fly
from
the
livery
stables
.
  
<EOS>
"
Are
the
arrangements
with
reference
to
the
Sabbath
-
day
schools
generally
pretty
good
in
your
archdeaconry
?
"
asked
Mr.
Slope
.
  
<EOS>
"
Sabbath
-
day
schools
!
"
repeated
the
archdeacon
with
an
affectation
of
surprise
.
"
<EOS>
Upon
my
word
,
I
ca
n't
tell
;
it
depends
mainly
on
the
parson
's
wife
and
daughters
.
<EOS>
There
is
none
at
Plumstead
.
"
  
<EOS>
This
was
almost
a
fib
on
the
part
of
the
archdeacon
,
for
Mrs.
Grantly
has
a
very
nice
school
.
<EOS>
To
be
sure
it
is
not
a
Sunday
-
school
exclusively
,
and
is
not
so
designated
,
but
that
exemplary
lady
always
attends
there
for
an
hour
before
church
,
and
hears
the
children
say
their
catechism
,
and
sees
that
they
are
clean
and
tidy
for
church
,
with
their
hands
washed
and
their
shoes

;
and
Grisel
and
Florinda
,
her
daughters
,
carry
thither
a
basket
of
large
buns
,
baked
on
the
Saturday

,
and
distribute
them
to
all
the
children
not
especially
under
disgrace
,
which
buns
are
carried
home
after
church
with
considerable
content
,
and
eaten
hot
at
tea
,
being
then
split
and
toasted
.
<EOS>
The
children
of
Plumstead
would
indeed
open
their
eyes
if
they
heard
their
venerated
pastor
declare
that
there
was
no
Sunday
-
school
in
his
parish
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
merely
opened
his
wide
eyes
wider
and
slightly
shrugged
his
shoulders
.
<EOS>
He
was
not
,
however
,
prepared
to
give
up
his
darling
project
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
fear
there
is
a
great
deal
of
Sabbath
travelling
here
,
"
said
he
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
On
looking
at
the
"
Bradshaw
,
"
I
see
that
there
are
three
trains
in
and
three
out
every
Sabbath
.
<EOS>
Could
nothing

to

to

?
<EOS>
Do

you
think
,
<EOS>
Dr.
Grantly
,
that
a

diminish

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not

director
,
I

ca
n't

.
<EOS>
But

,

I
dare

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
It
's
merely

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
But

,
Dr.
Grantly
,
"
said

;
"

.
<EOS>
You

,

,

:

.
<EOS>
Do

,
Mr.
Harding
?
"
<EOS>
and

to
the

,
who
was

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
thought
that
all
porters
and
stokers
,
guards
,

,
and
pointsmen
ought
to

an
opportunity

going
to

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
But
surely
,
surely
,
"
continued

Proudie
,
"
surely

is
not
enough
.
<EOS>
Surely

conceive

<EOS>
;
surely
 
"
  
Come
what

,

not

,
nor

Slope
,
so

upon

to
hope
that
Dr.
Proudie
had
found
that

palace

had
been
such

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
yes
,
"
said
his
lordship
;
upon
the
whole
he
thought
so
 
upon
the
whole
,
he
did
n't

that
there

much

;
the
architect
,
perhaps
,
might
have
 
but
<EOS>
his
double
,
Mr.
Slope
,
who
had
sidled

to
the

's

,
would

to

.
  
<EOS>
"
There

I

,

.
<EOS>
His

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
 
there
's

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

;
"

,

;

,

.
<EOS>
There

's

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Dr.

promised
that
due

"

,

<EOS>
He

.
  
<EOS>
"
And

,

,
"

;
"

,

,

,

.
"
  
"
<EOS>
And

gas
,
"
chimed

;
"
there

gas
through

house
,
<EOS>
none
whatever
,
but
in

.
<EOS>
Surely
the

should
have

,

water

.
<EOS>
There

laid
on
anywhere
above
the
ground
-

;
surely

the

of
getting

in

without

from

.
"
  
<EOS>
The
bishop
had
a
decided
opinion
that
there
should
be
pipes
for
hot
water
.
<EOS>
Hot
water
was
very
essential
for
the
comfort
of
the
palace
.
<EOS>
It
was
,
indeed
,
a
requisite
in
any
decent
gentleman
's
house
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
had
remarked
that
the
coping
on
the
garden
wall
was
in
many
places
imperfect
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Proudie
had
discovered
a
large
hole
,
<EOS>
evidently
the
work
of
rats
,
in
the
servants
"
hall
.
  
<EOS>
The
bishop
expressed
an
utter
detestation
of
rats
.
<EOS>
There
was
nothing
,
he
believed
,
in
this
world
that
he
so
much
hated
as
a
rat
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
had
,
moreover
,
observed
that
the
locks
of
the
outhouses
were
very
imperfect
:
he
might
specify
the
coal
-
cellar
and
the
woodhouse
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Proudie
had
also
seen
that
those
on
the
doors
of
the
servants
'
bedrooms
were
in
an
-
equally
bad
condition
;
indeed
,
the
locks
all
through
the
house
were
old
-
fashioned
and
unserviceable
.
  
<EOS>
The
bishop
thought
that
a
great
deal
depended
on
a
good
lock
and
quite
as
much
on
the
key
.
<EOS>
He
had
observed
that
the
fault
very
often
lay
with
the
key
,
especially
if
the
wards
were
in
any
way
twisted
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
was
going
on
with
his
catalogue
of
grievances
,
when
he
was
somewhat
loudly
interrupted
by
the
archdeacon
,
who
succeeded
in
explaining
that
the
diocesan
architect
,
or
rather
his
foreman
,
was
the
person
to
be
addressed
on
such

,
and
that
he
,
Dr.
Grantly
,
had
inquired
as
to
the
comfort
of
the
palace
merely
as
a
point
of
compliment
.
<EOS>
He
was
sorry
,
however
,
that
so
many
things
had
been
found
amiss
:
<EOS>
and
then
he
rose
from
his
chair
to
escape
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Proudie
,
though
she
had
contrived
to
lend

in

,
had
not
on

given
up
her
hold
of
Mr.
Harding
,
nor
ceased
from
her
cross
-

as
to
the

Sabbatical

.
<EOS>
Over
and
over
again
had
she
thrown
out
her
"
Surely
,
surely
,
"
at
Mr.
Harding
's
devoted
head
,
and
ill
had
that
gentleman
been
able
to
parry
the
attack
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
never
before
found
himself
subjected
to
such
a
nuisance
.
<EOS>
Ladies
hitherto
,
when
they
had
consulted
him
on
religious
subjects
,
had
listened
to
what
he
might
choose
to
say
with
some
deference
,
and
had
differed
,
if
they
differed
,
in
silence
.
<EOS>
But
Mrs.
Proudie
interrogated
him
and
then
lectured
.
"
<EOS>
Neither
thou
,
nor
thy
son
,
nor
thy
daughter
,
thy
manservant
,
nor
thy
maidservant
,
"
said
she
impressively
,
and
more
than
once
,
as
though
Mr.
Harding
had
forgotten
the
words
.
<EOS>
She
shook
her
finger
at
him
as
she
quoted
the
favourite
law
,
as
though
menacing
him
with
punishment
,
and
then
called
upon
him
categorically
to
state
whether
he
did
not
think
that
travelling
on
the
Sabbath
was
an
abomination
and
a
desecration
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
had
never
been
so
hard
pressed
in
his
life
.
<EOS>
He
felt
that
he
ought
to
rebuke
the
lady
for
presuming
so
to
talk
to
a
gentleman
and
a
clergyman
many
years
her
senior
,
but
he
recoiled
from
the
idea
of
scolding
the
bishop
's
wife
,
in
the
bishop
's
presence
,
on
his
first
visit
to
the
palace
;
moreover
,
to
tell
the
truth
,
he
was
somewhat
afraid
of
her
.
<EOS>
She
,
seeing
him
sit
silent
and
absorbed
,
by
no
means
refrained
from
the
attack
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
,
Mr.
Harding
,
"
said
she
,
shaking
her
head
slowly
and
solemnly
,
<EOS>
"
I
hope
you
will
not
leave
me
to
think
that
you
approve
of
Sabbath
travelling
,
"
and
she
looked
a
look
of
unutterable
meaning
into
his
eyes
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
no
standing
this
,
for
Mr.
Slope
was
now
looking
at
him
,
and
so
was
the
bishop
,
and
so
was
the
archdeacon
,
who
had
completed
his
adieux
on
that
side
of
the
room
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
therefore
got
up
also
and
,
putting
out
his
hand
to
Mrs.
Proudie
,
said
:
"
If
you
will
come
to
St.
Cuthbert
's
<EOS>
some
Sunday
,
I
will
preach
you
a
sermon
on
that
subject
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
And
so
the
archdeacon
and
the
precentor
took
their
departure
,
bowing
low
to
the
lady
,
shaking
hands
with
the
lord
,
and
escaping
from
Mr.
Slope
in
the
best
manner
each
could
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
was
again
maltreated
,
but
Dr.
Grantly
swore
deeply
in
the
bottom
of
his
heart
,
that
no
earthly
consideration
should
ever
again
induce
him
to
touch
the
paw
of
that
impure
and
filthy
animal
.
  
<EOS>
And
now
,
had
I
the
pen
of
a
mighty
poet
,
would
I
sing
in
epic
verse
the
noble
wrath
of
the
archdeacon
.
<EOS>
The
palace
steps
descend
to
a
broad
gravel
sweep
,
from
whence
a
small
gate
opens
out
into
the
street
,
very
near
the
covered
gateway
leading
into
the
close
.
<EOS>
The
road
from
the
palace
door
turns
to
the
left
,
through
the
spacious
gardens
,
and
terminates
on
the
London
road
,
half
a
mile
from
the
cathedral
.
  
<EOS>
Till
they
had
both
passed
this
small
gate
and
entered
the
close
,
neither
of
them
spoke
a
word
,
but
the
precentor
clearly
saw
from
his
companion
's
face
that
a
tornado
was
to
be
expected
,
nor
was
he
himself
inclined
to
stop
it
.
<EOS>
Though
by
nature
far
less
irritable
than
the
archdeacon
,
even
he
was
angry
:
<EOS>
he
<EOS>
even
 
that
mild
and
courteous
man
 
was
inclined
to
express
himself
in
anything
but
courteous
terms
.
   
<EOS>
War
 
<EOS>
"
Good
heavens
!
"
exclaimed
the
archdeacon
,
as
he
placed
his
foot
on
the
gravel
walk
of
the
close
,
and
raising
his
hat
with
one
hand
,
passed
the
other
somewhat
violently
over
his
now
grizzled
locks
;
smoke
issued
forth
from
the
uplifted
beaver
as
it
were
a
cloud
of
wrath
,
and
the
safety
valve
of
his
anger
opened
,
and
emitted
a
visible
steam
,
preventing
positive
explosion
and
probable
apoplexy
.
"
<EOS>
Good
heavens
!
"
 
<EOS>
and
the
archdeacon
looked
up
to
the
gray
pinnacles
of
the
cathedral
tower
,
making
a
mute
appeal
to
that
still
living
witness
which
had
looked
down
on
the
doings
of
so
many
bishops
of
Barchester
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
I
shall
ever
like
that
Mr.
Slope
,
"
said
Mr.
Harding
.
  
<EOS>
"
Like
him
!
"
<EOS>
roared
the
archdeacon
,
standing
still
for
a
moment
to
give
more
force
to

voice
;
"
like
him
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
All
the
ravens
of
the
close
cawed
their
assent
.
<EOS>
The
old
bells
of
the
tower
,
in
chiming
the
hour
,
echoed
the
words
,
and
the
swallows
flying
out
from
their
nests
mutely
expressed
a
similar
opinion
.
<EOS>
Like
Mr.
Slope
!
<EOS>
Why
no
,
it
was
not
very
probable
that
any
Barchester
-
bred
living
thing
should
like
Mr.
Slope
!
  
<EOS>
"
Nor
Mrs.
Proudie
either
,
"
said
Mr.
Harding
.
  
<EOS>
The
archdeacon
hereupon
forgot
himself
.
<EOS>
I
will
not
follow
his
example
,
nor
shock
my
readers
by
transcribing
the
term
in
which
he
expressed
his

as
to
the
lady
who
had
been
named
.
<EOS>
The
ravens
and
the
last

of
the
clock

were
less

and
repeated
in

the
very
improper

.
<EOS>
The
archdeacon
again
raised
his
hat
,
and
another
salutary
escape
of
steam
was
effected
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
a
pause
,
during
which
the

tried
to

that
the
wife
of
a
Bishop
of
Barchester
had
been
thus
designated
,
in
the
close
of
the
cathedral
,
by
the
lips
of
its
own

;
but
he
could
not
do

.
  
<EOS>
"
The
bishop
seems
to
be
a
quiet
man
enough
,
"
suggested
Mr.
Harding
,
having
acknowledged
to

his
own
failure
.
  
<EOS>
"
Idiot
!
"
exclaimed
the
doctor
,
who
for
the
nonce
was
not
capable
of
more
than
such
spasmodic

at
utterance
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
he
did
not
seem
very
bright
,
"
said
Mr.
Harding
,
"
and
yet
he
has
always
had
the
reputation
of
a
clever
man
.
<EOS>
I
suppose
he
's
cautious
and
not
inclined
to
express
himself
very
freely
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
new
Bishop
of
Barchester
was
already
so
contemptible
a
creature
in
Dr.
Grantly
's
eyes
that
he
could
not
condescend
to
discuss
his
character
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
puppet
to
be
played
by
others
;
a
mere
wax
doll
,
done
up
in
an
apron
and
a

hat
,
to
be
stuck
on
a
throne
or
elsewhere
,
and
pulled
about
by
wires
as
others
chose
.
<EOS>
Dr.
Grantly
did
not
choose
to
let
himself
down
low
enough
to
talk
about
Dr.
Proudie
,
but
he
saw
that
he
would
have
to
talk
about
the
other

his

,
the
coadjutor
bishops
,
who
had
brought
his
lordship
down
,
as
it
were
,
in
a
box
,
and
were
about
to
handle
the
wires
as
they
willed
.
<EOS>
This
in
itself
was
a
terrible

to
the
archdeacon
.
<EOS>
Could
he
have
ignored
the
chaplain
and

the
bishop
,
there
would
have
been
,
at
any
rate
,
nothing

in

.
<EOS>
Let
the
Queen
make
whom

would
Bishop

Barchester
;
a
man
,
or
even
an
ape
,
when

,
would

,

,
himself
.
<EOS>
But
what

to

Mr.
Slope

?
  
<EOS>
If

,

,

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
If

.
<EOS>
He

Slope
,
to
 
Bah
!
<EOS>
the

.
<EOS>
He

.
  
<EOS>

He

"

.

Who

?
"

<EOS>

!
<EOS>
no

!
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

!
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
I

,

,

Bishop

Barchester
!
"
<EOS>
And
again

Grantly
raised

hat
and

and

.
  
<EOS>
"
Impudent

!
"
<EOS>
he
continued
after

.
"
<EOS>
To
dare
to
cross
-
examine
me
about
the
Sunday
-
schools
in
the
diocese
,
and
Sunday
travelling
too
:
I
never
in
my
life
met
his
equal
for
sheer
