.
<EOS>
Why
,
he
must
have
thought
we
were
two
candidates
for
ordination
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
declare
I
thought
Mrs.
Proudie
was
the
worst
of
the
two
,
"
said
Mr.
Harding
.
  
<EOS>
"
When
a
woman
is
impertinent
,
one
must
only
put
up
with
it
,
and
keep
out
of
her
way
in
future
,
but
I
am
not
inclined
to
put
up
with
Mr.
Slope
.
"
<EOS>
Sabbath
travelling
!
"
<EOS>
"
and
the
doctor
attempted
to
imitate
the
peculiar
drawl
of
the
man
he
so
much
disliked
:
"
"
Sabbath
travelling
!
<EOS>
"
Those
are
the
sort
of
men
who
will
ruin
the
Church
of
England
and
make
the
profession
of
a
clergyman
disreputable
.
<EOS>
It
is
not
the
dissenters
or
the
papists
that
we
should
fear
,
but
the
set
of
canting
,
low
-
bred
hypocrites
who
are
wriggling
their
way
in
among
us
;
men
who
have
no
fixed
principle
,
no
standard
ideas
of
religion
or
doctrine
,
but
who
take
up
some
popular
cry
,
as
this
fellow
has
done
about
"
Sabbath
travelling
.
"
<EOS>
"
  
Dr.
Grantly
did
not
again
repeat
the
question
aloud
,
but
he
did
so
constantly
to
himself
:
<EOS>
What
were
they
to
do
with
Mr.
Slope
?
<EOS>
How
was
he
openly
,
before
the
world
,
to
show
that
he
utterly
disapproved
of
and
abhorred
such
a
man
?
  
<EOS>
Hitherto
Barchester
had
escaped
the
taint
of
any
extreme
rigour
of
church
doctrine
.
<EOS>
The
clergymen
of
the
city
and
neighbourhood
,
though
very
well
inclined
to
promote
High
Church
principles
,
privileges
,
and
prerogatives
,
had
never
committed
themselves
to
tendencies
which
are
somewhat
too
loosely
called
Puseyite
practices
.
<EOS>
They
all
preached
in
their
black
gowns
,
as
their
fathers
had
done
before
them
;
they
wore
ordinary
black
cloth
waistcoats
;
they
had
no
candles
on
their
altars
,
either
lighted
or
unlighted
;
they
made
no
private
genuflexions
,
and
were
contented
to
confine
themselves
to
such
ceremonial
observances
as
had
been
in
vogue
for
the
last
hundred
years
.
<EOS>
The
services
were
decently
and
demurely
read
in
their
parish
churches
,
chanting
was
confined
to
the
cathedral
,
and
the
science
of
intoning
was
unknown
.
<EOS>
One
young
man
who
had
come
direct
from
Oxford
as
a
curate
to
Plumstead
had
,
after
the
lapse
of
two
or
three
Sundays
,
made
a
faint
attempt
,
much
to
the
bewilderment
of
the
poorer
part
of
the
congregation
.
<EOS>
Dr.
Grantly
had
not
been
present
on
the
occasion
,
but
<EOS>
Mrs.
Grantly
,
who
had
her
own
opinion
on
the
subject
,
immediately
after
the
service
expressed
a
hope
that
the
young
gentleman
had
not
been
taken
ill
,
and
offered
to
send
him
all
kinds
of
condiments
supposed
to
be
good
for
a
sore
throat
.
<EOS>
After
that
there
had
been
no
more
intoning
at
Plumstead
Episcopi
.
  
<EOS>
But
now
the
archdeacon
began
to
meditate
on
some
strong
measures
of
absolute
opposition
.
<EOS>
Dr.
Proudie
and
his
crew
were
of
the
lowest
possible
order
of
Church
of
England
clergymen
,
and
therefore
it
behoved
him
,
<EOS>
Dr.
Grantly
,
to
be
of
the
very
highest
.
<EOS>
Dr.
Proudie
would
abolish
all
forms
and
ceremonies
,
and
therefore
Dr.
Grantly
felt
the
sudden
necessity
of
multiplying
them
.
<EOS>
Dr.
Proudie
would
consent
to
deprive
the
church
of
all
collective
authority
and
rule
,
and
therefore
Dr.
Grantly
would
stand
up
for
the
full
power
of
convocation
and
the
renewal
of
all
its
ancient
privileges
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
true
that
he
could
not
himself
intone
the
service
,
but
he
could
procure
the
co
-
operation
of
any
number
of
gentlemanlike
curates
well
trained
in
the
mystery
of
doing
so
.
<EOS>
He
would
not
willingly
alter
his
own
fashion
of
dress
,
but
he
could
people
Barchester
with
young
clergymen
dressed
in
the
longest
frocks
and
in
the
highest
-
breasted
silk
waistcoats
.
<EOS>
He
certainly
was
not
prepared
to
cross
himself
,
or
to
advocate
the
real
presence
,
but
without
going
this
length
there
were
various
observances
,
by
adopting
which
he
could
plainly
show
his
antipathy
to
such
men
as
Dr.
Proudie
and
Mr.
Slope
.
  
<EOS>
All
these
things
passed
through
his
mind
as
he
paced
up
and
down
the
close
with
Mr.
Harding
.
<EOS>
War
,
war
,
internecine
war
was
in
his
heart
.
<EOS>
He
felt
that
,
as
regarded
himself
and
Mr.
Slope
,
one
of
the
two
must
be
annihilated
as
far
as
the
city
of
Barchester
was
concerned
,
and
he
did
not
intend
to
give
way
until
there
was
not
left
to
him
an
inch
of
ground
on
which
he
could
stand
.
<EOS>
He
still
flattered
himself
that
he
could
make
Barchester
too
hot
to
hold
Mr.
Slope
,
and
he
had
no
weakness
of
spirit
to
prevent
his
bringing
about
such
a
consummation
if
it
were
in
his
power
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
Susan
must
call
at
the
palace
,
"
said
Mr.
Harding
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
she
shall
call
there
,
but
it
shall
be
once
and
once
only
.
<EOS>
I
dare
say
"
the
horses
"
wo
n't
find
it
convenient
to
come
out
to
Plumstead
very
soon
,
and
when
that
once
is
done
the
matter
may
drop
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
suppose
Eleanor
need
call
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
think
Eleanor
would
get
on
at
all
well
with
Mrs.
Proudie
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Not
the
least
necessity
in
life
,
"
replied
the
archdeacon
,
not
without
the
reflexion
that
a
ceremony
which
was
necessary
for
his
wife
might
not
be
at
all
binding
on
the
widow
of
John
Bold
.
"
<EOS>
Not
the
slightest
reason
on
earth
why
she
should
do
so
,
if
she
does
n't
like
it
.
<EOS>
For
myself
,
I
do
n't
think
that
any
decent
young
woman
should
be
subjected
to
the
nuisance
of
being
in
the
same
room
with
that
man
.
"
  
<EOS>
And
so
the
two
clergymen
parted
<EOS>
,
Mr.
Harding
going
to
his
daughter
's
house
,
and
the
archdeacon
seeking
the
seclusion
of
his
brougham
.
  
<EOS>
The
new
inhabitants
of
the
palace
did
not
express
any
higher
opinion
of
their
visitors
than
their
visitors
had
expressed
of
them
.
<EOS>
Though
they
did
not
use
quite
such
strong
language
as
Dr.
Grantly
had
done
,
they
felt
as
much
personal
aversion
,
and
were
quite
as
well
aware
as
he
was
that
there
would
be
a
battle
to
be
fought
,
and
that
there
was
hardly
room
for
Proudieism
in
Barchester
as
long
as
Grantlyism
was
predominant
.
  
<EOS>
Indeed
,
it
may
be
doubted
whether
Mr.
Slope
had
not
already
within
his
breast
a
better
prepared
system
of
strategy
,
a
more
accurately
defined
line
of
hostile
conduct
than
the
archdeacon
.
<EOS>
Dr.
Grantly
was
going
to
fight
because
he
found
that
he
hated
the
man
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
had
predetermined
to
hate
the
man
because
he
foresaw
the
necessity
of
fighting
him
.
<EOS>
When
he
had
first
reviewed
the
_
carte
du
pays
_
previous
to
his
entry
into
Barchester
,
the
idea
had
occurred
to
him
of
conciliating
the
archdeacon
,
of
cajoling
and
flattering
him
into
submission
,
and
of
obtaining
the
upper
hand
by
cunning
instead
of
courage
.
<EOS>
A
little
inquiry
,
however
,
sufficed
to
convince
him
that
all
his
cunning
would
fail
to
win
over
such
a
man
as
Dr.
Grantly
to
such
a
mode
of
action
as
that
to
be
adopted
by
Mr.
Slope
,
and
then
he
determined
to
fall
back
upon
his
courage
.
<EOS>
He
at
once
saw
that
open
battle
against
Dr.
Grantly
and
<EOS>
all
Dr.
Grantly
's
adherents
was
a
necessity
of
his
position
,
and
he
deliberately
planned
the
most
expedient
methods
of
giving
offence
.
  
<EOS>
Soon
after
his
arrival
the
bishop
had
intimated
to
the
dean
that
,
with
the
permission
of
the
canon
then
in
residence
,
his
chaplain
would
preach
in
the
cathedral
on
the
next
Sunday
.
<EOS>
The
canon
in
residence
happened
to
be
the
Hon
.
<EOS>
and
Rev.
Dr.
Vesey
Stanhope
,
who
at
this
time
was
very
busy
on
the
shores
of
the
Lake
of
Como
,
adding
to
that
unique
collection
of
butterflies
for
which
he
is
so
famous
.
<EOS>
Or
rather
,
he
would
have
been
in
residence
but
for
the
butterflies
and
other
such
summer
-
day
considerations
;
and
the
vicar
-
choral
,
who
was
to
take
his
place
in
the
pulpit
,
by
no
means
objected
to
having
his
work
done
for
him
by
Mr.
Slope
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
accordingly
preached
,
and
if
a
preacher
can
have
satisfaction
in
being
listened
to
,
Mr.
Slope
ought
to
have
been
gratified
.
<EOS>
I
have
reason
to
think
that
he
was
gratified
,
and
that
he
left
the
pulpit
with
the
conviction
that
he
had
done
what
he
intended
to
do
when
he
entered
it
.
  
<EOS>
On
this
occasion
the
new
bishop
took
his
seat
for
the
first
time
in
the
throne
alloted
to
him
.
<EOS>
New
scarlet
cushions
and
drapery
had
been
prepared
,
with
new
gilt
binding
and
new
fringe
.
<EOS>
The
old
carved
oak
-
wood
of
the
throne
,
ascending
with
its
numerous
grotesque
pinnacles
half
-
way
up
to
the
roof
of
the
choir
,
had
been
washed
,
and
dusted
,
and
rubbed
,
and
it
all
looked
very
smart
.
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
how
often
sitting
there
,
in
happy
early
days
,
on
those
lowly
benches
in
front
of
the
altar
,
have
I
whiled
away
the
tedium
of
a
sermon
in
considering
how
best
I
might
thread
my
way
up
amidst
those
wooden
towers
and
climb
safely
to
the
topmost
pinnacle
!
  
<EOS>
All
Barchester
went
to
hear
Mr.
Slope
;
either
for
that
or
to
gaze
at
the
new
bishop
.
<EOS>
All
the
best
bonnets
of
the
city
were
there
,
and
moreover
all
the
best
glossy
clerical
hats
.
<EOS>
Not
a
stall
but
had
its
fitting
occupant
,
for
though
some
of
the
prebendaries
might
be
away
in
Italy
or
elsewhere
,
their
places
were
filled
by
brethren
who
flocked
into
Barchester
on
the
occasion
.
<EOS>
The
dean
was
there
,
a
heavy
old
man
,
now
too
old
,
indeed
,
to
attend
frequently
in
his
place
,
and
so
was
the
archdeacon
.
<EOS>
So
also
were
the
chancellor
,
the
treasurer
,
the
precentor
,
sundry
canons
and
minor
canons
,
and
every
lay
member
of
the
choir
,
prepared
to
sing
the
new
bishop
in
with
due
melody
and
harmonious
expression
of
sacred
welcome
.
  
<EOS>
The
service
was
certainly
very
well
performed
.
<EOS>
Such
was
always
the
case
at
Barchester
,
as
the
musical
education
of
the
choir
had
been
good
,
and
the
voices
had
been
carefully
selected
.
<EOS>
The
psalms
were
beautifully
chanted
;
the
Te
Deum
was
magnificently
sung
;
and
the
litany
was
given
in
a
manner
which
is
still
to
be
found
at
Barchester
,
but
,
if
my
taste
be
correct
,
is
to
be
found
nowhere
else
.
<EOS>
The
litany
in
Barchester
cathedral
has
long
been
the
special
task
to
which
Mr.
Harding
's
skill
and
voice
have
been
devoted
.
<EOS>
Crowded
audiences
generally
make
good
performers
,
and
though
Mr.
Harding
was
not
aware
of
any
extraordinary
exertion
on
his
part
,
yet
probably
he
rather
exceeded
his
usual
mark
.
<EOS>
Others
were
doing
their
best
,
and
it
was
natural
that
he
should
emulate
his
brethren
.
<EOS>
So
the
service
went
on
,
and
at
last
Mr.
Slope
got
into
the
pulpit
.
  
<EOS>
He
chose
for
his
text
a
verse
from
the
precepts
addressed
by
St.
Paul
to
Timothy
,
as
to
the
conduct
necessary
in
a
spiritual
pastor
and
guide
,
and
it
was
immediately
evident
that
the
good
clergy
of
Barchester
were
to
have
a
lesson
.
  
<EOS>
"
Study
to
show
thyself
approved
unto
God
,
a
workman
that
needeth
not
to
be
ashamed
,
rightly
dividing
the
word
of
truth
.
<EOS>
"
These
were
the
words
of
his
text
,
and
with
such
a
subject
in
such
a
place
,
it
may
be
supposed
that
such
a
preacher
would
be
listened
to
by
such
an
audience
.
<EOS>
He
was
listened
to
with
breathless
attention
and
not
without
considerable
surprise
.
<EOS>
Whatever
opinion
of
Mr.
Slope
might
have
been
held
in
Barchester
before
he
commenced
his
discourse
,
none
of
his
hearers
,
when
it
was
over
,
could
mistake
him
either
for
a
fool
or
a
coward
.
  
<EOS>
It
would
not
be
becoming
<EOS>
were
I
to
travesty
a
sermon
,
or
even
to
repeat
the
language
of
it
in
the
pages
of
a
novel
.
<EOS>
In
endeavouring
to
depict
the
characters
of
the
persons
of
whom
I
write
,
I
am
to
a
certain
extent
forced
to
speak
of
sacred
things
.
<EOS>
I
trust
,
however
,
that
I
shall
not
be
thought
to
scoff
at
the
pulpit
,
though
some
may
imagine
that
I
do
not
feel
all
the
reverence
that
is
due
to
the
cloth
.
<EOS>
I
may
question
the
infallibility
of
the
teachers
,
but
I
hope
that
I
shall
not
therefore
be
accused
of
doubt
as
to
the
thing
to
be
taught
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
,
in
commencing
his
sermon
,
showed
no
slight
tact
in
his
ambiguous
manner
of
hinting
that
,
humble
as
he
was
himself
,
he
stood
there
as
the
mouth
-
piece
of
the
illustrious
divine
who
sat
opposite
to
him
;
and
having
premised
so
much
,
he
gave
forth
a
very
accurate
definition
of
the
conduct
which
that
prelate
would
rejoice
to
see
in
the
clergymen
now
brought
under
his
jurisdiction
.
<EOS>
It
is
only
necessary
to
say
that
the
peculiar
points
insisted
upon
were
exactly
those
which
were
most
distasteful
to
the
clergy
of
the
diocese
,
and
most
averse
to
their
practice
and
opinions
,
and
that
all
those
peculiar
habits
and
privileges
which
have
always
been
dear
to
High
Church
priests
,
to
that
party
which
is
now
scandalously
called
the
"
high
and
dry
church
,
"
were
ridiculed
,
abused
,
and
anathematized
.
<EOS>
Now
,
the
clergymen
of
the
diocese
of
Barchester
are
all
of
the
high
and
dry
church
.
  
<EOS>
Having
thus
,
according
to
his
own
opinion
,
explained
how
a
clergyman
should
show
himself
approved
unto
God
,
as
a
workman
that
needeth
not
to
be
ashamed
,
he
went
on
to
explain
how
the
word
of
truth
should
be
divided
;
and
here
he
took
a
rather
narrow
view
of
the
question
and
fetched
his
arguments
from
afar
.
<EOS>
His
object
was
to
express
his
abomination
of
all
ceremonious
modes
of
utterance
,
to
cry
down
any
religious
feeling
which
might
be
excited
,
not
by
the
sense
,
but
by
the
sound
of
words
,
and
in
fact
to
insult
cathedral
practices
.
<EOS>
Had
St.
Paul
spoken
of
rightly
pronouncing
,
instead
of
rightly
dividing
the
word
of
truth
,
this
part
of
his
sermon
would
have
been
more
to
the
purpose
,
but
the
preacher
's
immediate
object
was
to
preach
Mr.
Slope
's
doctrine
,
and
not
St.
Paul
's
,
and
he
contrived
to
give
the
necessary
twist
to
the
text
with
some
skill
.
  
<EOS>
He
could
not
exactly
say
,
preaching
from
a
cathedral
pulpit
,
that
chanting
should
be
abandoned
in
cathedral
services
.
<EOS>
By
such
an
assertion
he
would
have
overshot
his
mark
and
rendered
himself
absurd
,
to
the
delight
of
his
hearers
.
<EOS>
He
could
,
however
,
and
did
,
allude
with
heavy
denunciations
to
the
practice
of
intoning
in
parish
churches
,
although
the
practice
was
all
but
unknown
in
the
diocese
;
and
from
thence
he
came
round
to
the
undue
preponderance
which
,
he
asserted
,
music
had
over
meaning
in
the
beautiful
service
which
they
had
just
heard
.
<EOS>
He
was
aware
,
he
said
,
that
the
practices
of
our
ancestors
could
not
be
abandoned
at
a
moment
's
notice
;
the
feelings
of
the
aged
would
be
outraged
,
and
the
minds
of
respectable
men
would
be
shocked
.
<EOS>
There
were
many
,
he
was
aware
,
of
not
sufficient
calibre
of
thought
to
perceive
,
of
not
sufficient
education
to
know
,
that
a
mode
of
service
which
was
effective
when
outward
ceremonies
were
of
more
moment
than
inward
feelings
,
had
become
all
but
barbarous
at
a
time
when
inward
conviction
was
everything
,
when
each
word
of
the
minister
's
lips
should
fall
intelligibly
into
the
listener
's
heart
.
<EOS>
Formerly
the
religion
of
the
multitude
had
been
an
affair
of
the
imagination
:
now
,
in
these
latter
days
,
it
had
become
necessary
that
a
Christian
should
have
a
reason
for
his
faith
 
should
not
only
believe
,
but
digest
 
not
only
hear
,
but
understand
.
<EOS>
The
words
of
our
morning
service
,
how
beautiful
,
how
apposite
,
how
intelligible
they
were
,
when
read
with
simple
and
distinct
decorum
!
<EOS>
But
how
much
of
the
meaning
of
the
words
was
lost
when
they
were
produced
with
all
the
meretricious
charms
of
melody
!
&
c.
&
c.
  
<EOS>
Here
was
a
sermon
to
be
preached
before
Mr.
Archdeacon
<EOS>
Grantly
,
Mr.
Precentor
Harding
,
and
the
rest
of
them
!
<EOS>
Before
a
whole
dean
and
chapter
assembled
in
their
own
cathedral
!
<EOS>
Before
men
who
had
grown
old
in
the
exercise
of
their
peculiar
services
,
with
a
full
conviction
of
their
excellence
for
all
intended
purposes
!
<EOS>
This
too
from
such
a
man
,
a
clerical
_
parvenu
_
,
a
man
without
a
cure
,
a
mere
chaplain
,
an
intruder
among
them
;
a
fellow
raked
up
,
so
said
Dr.
Grantly
,
from
the
gutters
of
Marylebone
!
<EOS>
They
had
to
sit
through
it
!
<EOS>
None
of
them
,
not
even
Dr.
Grantly
,
could
close
his
ears
,
nor
leave
the
house
of
God
during
the
hours
of
service
.
<EOS>
They
were
under
an
obligation
of
listening
,
and
that
too
without
any
immediate
power
of
reply
.
  
<EOS>
There
is
,
perhaps
,
no
greater
hardship
at
present
inflicted
on
mankind
in
civilized
and
free
countries
than
the
necessity
of
listening
to
sermons
.
<EOS>
No
one
but
a
preaching
clergyman
has
,
in
these
realms
,
the
power
of
compelling
an
audience
to
sit
silent
and
be
tormented
.
<EOS>
No
one
but
a
preaching
clergyman
can
revel
in
platitudes
,
truisms
,
and
untruisms
,
and
yet
receive
,
as
his
undisputed
privilege
,
the
same
respectful
demeanour
as
though
words
of
impassioned
eloquence
,
or
persuasive
logic
,
fell
from
his
lips
.
<EOS>
Let
a
professor
of
law
or
physics
find
his
place
in
a
lecture
-
room
,
and
there
pour
forth
jejune
words
and
useless
empty
phrases
,
and
he
will
pour
them
forth
to
empty
benches
.
<EOS>
Let
a
barrister
attempt
to
talk
without
talking
well
,
and
he
will
talk
but
seldom
.
<EOS>
A
judge
's
charge
need
be
listened
to
perforce
by
none
but
the
jury
,
prisoner
,
and
gaoler
.
<EOS>
A
member
of
Parliament
can
be
coughed
down
or
counted
out
.
<EOS>
Town
-
councillors
can
be
tabooed
.
<EOS>
But
no
one
can
rid
himself
of
the
preaching
clergyman
.
<EOS>
He
is
the
bore
of
the
age
,
the
old
man
whom
we
Sindbads
can
not
shake
off
,
the
nightmare
that
disturbs
our
Sunday
's
rest
,
the
incubus
that
overloads
our
religion
and
makes
God
's
service
distasteful
.
<EOS>
We
are
not
forced
into
church
!
<EOS>
No
:
<EOS>
but
we
desire
more
than
that
.
<EOS>
We
desire
not
to
be
forced
to
stay
away
.
<EOS>
We
desire
,
nay
,
we
are
resolute
,
to
enjoy
the
comfort
of
public
worship
,
but
we
desire
also
that
we
may
do
so
without
an
amount
of
tedium
which
ordinary
human
nature
can
not
endure
with
patience
;
that
we
may
be
able
to
leave
the
house
of
God
without
that
anxious
longing
for
escape
which
is
the
common
consequence
of
common
sermons
.
  
<EOS>
With
what
complacency
will
a
young
parson
deduce
false
conclusions
from
misunderstood
texts
,
and
then
threaten
us
with
all
the
penalties
of
Hades
if
we
neglect
to
comply
with
the
injunctions
he
has
given
us
!
<EOS>
Yes
,
my
too
self
-
confident
juvenile
friend
,
I
do
believe
in
those
mysteries
which
are
so
common
in
your
mouth
;
I
do
believe
in
the
unadulterated
word
which
you
hold
there
in
your
hand
;
but
you
must
pardon
me
if
,
in
some
things
,
I
doubt
your
interpretation
.
<EOS>
The
Bible
is
good
,
the
prayer
-
book
is
good
,
nay
,
you
yourself
would
be
acceptable
,
if
you
would
read
to
me
some
portion
of
those
time
-
honoured
discourses
which
our
great
divines
have
elaborated
in
the
full
maturity
of
their
powers
.
<EOS>
But
you
must
excuse
me
,
my
insufficient
young
lecturer
,
if
I
yawn
over
your
imperfect
sentences
,
your
repeated
phrases
,
your
false
pathos
,
your
drawlings
and
denouncings
,
your
humming
and
hawing
,
your
oh
-
ing
and
ah
-
ing
,
your
black
gloves
and
your
white

.
<EOS>
To
me
,
it
all
means
nothing
;
and
hours
are
too
precious
to
be
so
wasted
 
if
one
could
only
avoid
it
.
  
<EOS>
And
here
I
must
make
a
protest
against
the
pretence
,
so
often
put
forward
by
the
working
clergy
,
that
they
are
overburdened
by
the
multitude
of
sermons
to
be
preached
.
<EOS>
We
are
all
too
fond
of
our
own
voices
,
and
a
preacher
is
encouraged
in
the
vanity
of
making
his
heard
by
the
privilege
of
a
compelled

.
<EOS>
His
sermon
is
the
pleasant
morsel
of
his
life
,
his
delicious
moment
of
self
-
exaltation
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
preached
nine

this
week
,
"
said
a
young
friend
to

the
other

,
with
hand

,
the
picture
of

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Nine
this
week
,
seven

,
four

.
<EOS>
I
have
preached
twenty
-
three
sermons
this
month
.
<EOS>
It
is
really
too
much
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Too

,

,
"
said

"
too

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

"

;

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Would
,
"
said

,
"
you
could
feel
it
 
would
that
you

be

to

.
"
<EOS>
But
he
never

that
my

was
wrung
for
the
poor

.
  
<EOS>
There
was
,
at
any
rate
,
no

felt
in

Mr.
Slope
on
the

.
<EOS>
His
subject
came
too
home
to
his

to
be
dull
,
and
,

,
Mr.
Slope
had

.
<EOS>
He
was

through

with

and

,
but
with

,

,

from

,

,

,
and

not
at
peace
with
all
the
world
.
  
<EOS>
At
last

bishop
,
who
,

,

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
The
Dean
and
Chapter
Take
Counsel
 
<EOS>
All
Barchester
was
in
a

.
<EOS>
Dr.
Grantly
could
hardly
get
himself
out
of
the
cathedral
porch
before
he
exploded
in
his

.
<EOS>
The
old
dean
betook
himself
silently
to
his
deanery
,
afraid
to
speak
,
and
there

,
half

,

many

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
crept
forth
solitary

;
and
,

,

Barchester

.
<EOS>
Was

to

?
<EOS>
Was

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
It

not
,

,
the

<EOS>
Yes
!
<EOS>
All

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
The

<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
They
had

and

;

;
the

;
and
the

was

to

.
<EOS>
Yet
there
were
those
who
had

Mr.
Slope
with

.
  
<EOS>
It
is
so
pleasant
to
receive
a
fillip
of
excitement
when
suffering
from
the
dull

of
everyday

!
<EOS>
The
anthems
and
Te

were
in

,
but
they
had

so
often
!
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
was
certainly

,
but
he
was
new
,
and
,
moreover
,
clever
.
<EOS>
They
had
long

slow
,

,

,

none

which
were

.
<EOS>
People
in

of
the
age
now
had
new

,
and
it

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
might

.
<EOS>
Sunday

,

.
<EOS>
Indeed

.
<EOS>
Then
,

!
<EOS>
Really

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
(

that

,

<EOS>

;

,

Wilkes

.
  
<EOS>
There

.

<EOS>
Cunning

,

,

.

,

,

,

!
"

but

.
<EOS>
Why

?
<EOS>

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

matters
may
be
different
from
ours
 
with
that
one
would
not
quarrel
.
<EOS>
It
is
because
he
has
purposely
insulted
us
.
<EOS>
When
he
went
up
into
that
pulpit
last
Sunday
,
his
studied
object
was
to
give
offence
to
men
who
had
grown
old
in
reverence
of
those
things
of
which
he
dared
to
speak
so
slightingly
.
<EOS>
What
!
<EOS>
To
come
here
a
stranger
,
a
young
,
unknown
,
and
unfriended
stranger
,
and
tell
us
,
in
the
name
of
the
bishop
his
master
,
that
we
are
ignorant
of
our
duties
,
old
-
fashioned
,
and
useless
!
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
whether
most
to
admire
his
courage
or
his
impudence
!
<EOS>
And
one
thing
I
will
tell
you
:
that
sermon
originated
solely
with
the
man
himself
.
<EOS>
The
bishop
was
no
more
a
party
to
it
than
was
the
dean
here
.
<EOS>
You
all
know
how
grieved
I
am
to
see
a
bishop
in
this
diocese
holding
the
latitudinarian
ideas
by
which
Dr.
Proudie
has
made
himself
conspicuous
.
<EOS>
You
all
know
how
greatly
I
should
distrust
the
opinion
of
such
a
man
.
<EOS>
But
in
this
matter
I
hold
him
to
be
blameless
.
<EOS>
I
believe
Dr.
Proudie
has
lived
too
long
among
gentlemen
to
be
guilty
,
or
to
instigate
another
to
be
guilty
,
of
so
gross
an
outrage
.
<EOS>
No
!
<EOS>
That
man
uttered
what
was
untrue
when
he
hinted
that
he
was
speaking
as
the
mouthpiece
of
the
bishop
.
<EOS>
It
suited
his
ambitious
views
at
once
to
throw
down
the
gauntlet
to
us
 
at
once
to
defy
us
here
in
the
quiet
of
our
own
religious
duties
 
here
within
the
walls
of
our
own
loved
cathedral
 
here
where
we
have
for
so
many
years
exercised
our
ministry
without
schism
and
with
good
repute
.
<EOS>
Such
an
attack
upon
us
,
coming
from
such
a
quarter
,
is
abominable
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Abominable
,
"
groaned
the
dean
.
"
<EOS>
Abominable
,
"
muttered
the
meagre
doctor
.
"
<EOS>
Abominable
,
"
re
-
echoed
the
chancellor
,
uttering
the
sound
from
the
bottom
of
his
deep
chest
.
<EOS>
"
I
really
think
it
was
,
"
said
Mr.
Harding
.
  
<EOS>
"
Most
abominable
and
most
unjustifiable
,
"
continued
the
archdeacon
.
"
<EOS>
But
,
Mr.
Dean
,
thank
God
,
that
pulpit
is
still
our
own
:
<EOS>
your
own
,
I
should
say
.
<EOS>
That

belongs
solely
to
the
dean
and
chapter
of
Barchester
Cathedral
,
and
as
yet
Mr.
Slope
is
no

that

.
<EOS>
You
,
Mr.
Dean
,
have

that

man
on

;
but

?
<EOS>
In

matter
is
in

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
can
not

there

,
and

.
<EOS>
Let

.
<EOS>
Then
,

bishop
choose

,

know

make

bishop
.
<EOS>
My
friend
here
has
suggested
that
this
man
may
again

by

,
but

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
you
may
,
"
said

chancellor
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
much
more
discussion
among
the
learned
conclave
,
all
of
which
,
of
course
,
ended
in
obedience
to
the
archdeacon
's
commands
.
<EOS>
They
had
too
long
been
accustomed
to
his
rule
to
shake
it
off
so
soon
,
and
in
this

they
had
none
of
them
a
wish
to
abet
the
man
whom
he
was
so

to
put

.
  
<EOS>
Such
a
meeting
as
that
we
have
just
recorded
is
not
held
in
such

city
as
Barchester
unknown
and
untold
of
.
<EOS>
Not

the

the

talked

in
every

house
,

the

,
but
the

of
the
dean
,

,
and
chancellor
were

;
not
without
many

and
imaginary

,
according

and

.
  
<EOS>
All
,
however
,
agreed
in
saying
that
Mr.
Slope
was

from

in
the
cathedral
of
Barchester
;
many
believed
that
the

were

;
and
some

for

measures
declared

was
looked

as
an

,
and
that

were
to
be
taken
against

for

.
  
<EOS>
The
party
who
were
inclined
to
defend
him
 
the
enthusiastically
religious
young
ladies
and
the
middle
-
aged
spinsters
desirous
of
a
move
 
<EOS>
of
course
took
up
his
defence
the
more
warmly
on
account
of
this
attack
.
<EOS>
If
they
could
not
hear
Mr.
Slope
in
the
cathedral
,
they
would

elsewhere
;
they
would
leave
the
dull
dean
,
the

,
and

less
dull

to

;

,
make

,
and

up
in
some

Sion
or
Bethesda
,
and
put
the
cathedral
quite
out
of
fashion
.
  
<EOS>
Dr.
and
Mrs.
Proudie
at
once
returned
to
London
.
<EOS>
They
thought
it
expedient
not
to
have

from
the
dean
and
chapter
respecting
the
sermon
till
the

of
the
storm
had
expended

;
but
they
left
Mr.
Slope
behind
them
nothing
daunted
,
and
he
went
about
his
work
zealously
,
flattering
such
as
would
listen
to
his
flattery
,
whispering
religious
twaddle
into
the
ears
of
foolish
women
,
ingratiating
himself
with
the
few
clergy
who
would
receive
him
,
visiting
the
houses
of
the
poor
,
inquiring
into
all
people
,
prying
into
everything
,
and
searching
with
his
minutest
eye
into
all
palatial

.
<EOS>
He
did
not
,
however
,
make
any
immediate
attempt
to
preach
again
in
the
cathedral
.
  
<EOS>
And
so
all
Barchester
was
by
the
ears
.
   
<EOS>
The
Ex
-
warden
Rejoices
in
His
Probable
Return
to
the
Hospital
 
<EOS>
Among
the
ladies
in
Barchester
who
have
hitherto
acknowledged
Mr.
Slope
as
their
spiritual
director
must
not
be
reckoned
either
the
Widow
Bold
or
her
sister
-
in
-
law
.
<EOS>
On
the
first
outbreak
of
the
wrath
of
the
denizens
of
the
close
,
none
had
been
more
animated
against
the
intruder
than
these
two
ladies
.
<EOS>
And
this
was
natural
.
<EOS>
Who
could
be
so
proud
of
the
musical
distinction
of
their
own
cathedral
as
the
favourite
daughter
of
the
precentor
?
<EOS>
Who
would
be
so
likely
to
resent
an
insult
offered
to
the
old
choir
?
<EOS>
And
in
such
matters
Miss
Bold
and
her
sister
-
in
-
law
had
but
one
opinion
.
  
<EOS>
This
wrath
,
however
,
has
in
some
degree
been
mitigated
,
and
I
regret
to
say
that
these
ladies
allowed
Mr.
Slope
to
be
his
own
apologist
.
<EOS>
About
a
fortnight
after
the
sermon
had
been
preached
,
they
were
both
of
them
not
a
little
surprised
by
hearing
Mr.
Slope
announced
,
as
the
page
in
buttons
opened
Mrs.
Bold
's
drawing
-
room
door
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
what
living
man
could
,
by
a
mere
morning
visit
,
have
surprised
them
more
?
<EOS>
Here
was
the
great
enemy
of
all
that
was
good
in
Barchester
coming
into
their
own
drawing
-
room
,
and
they
had
no
strong
arm
,
no
ready
tongue
,
near
at
hand
for
their
protection
.
<EOS>
The
widow
snatched
her
baby
out
of
its
cradle
into
her
lap
,
and
Mary
Bold
stood
up
ready
to
die
manfully
in
that
baby
's
behalf
,
should
,
under
any
circumstances
,
such
a
sacrifice
become
necessary
.
  
<EOS>
In
this
manner
was
Mr.
Slope
received
.
<EOS>
But
when
he
left
,
he
was
allowed
by
each
lady
to
take
her
hand
and
to
make
his
adieux
as
gentlemen
do
who
have
been
graciously
entertained
!
<EOS>
Yes
,
he
shook
hands
with
them
,
and
was
curtseyed
out
courteously
,
the
buttoned
page
opening
the
door
as
he
would
have
done
for
the
best
canon
of
them
all
.
<EOS>
He
had
touched
the
baby
's
little
hand
and
blessed
him
with
a
fervid
blessing
;
he
had
spoken
to
the
widow
of
her
early
sorrows
,
and
Eleanor
's
silent
tears
had
not
rebuked
him
;
he
had
told
Mary
Bold
that
her
devotion
would
be
rewarded
,
and
Mary
Bold
had
heard
the
praise
without
disgust
.
<EOS>
And
how
had
he
done
all
this
?
<EOS>
How
had
he
so
quickly
turned
aversion
into
,
at
any
rate
,
acquaintance
?
<EOS>
How
had
he
over
-
come
the
enmity
with
which
these
ladies
had
been
ready
to
receive
him
,
and
made
his
peace
with
them
so
easily
?
  
<EOS>
My
readers
will
guess
from
what
I
have
written
that
I
myself
do
not
like
Mr.
Slope
,
but
I
am
constrained
to
admit
that
he
is
a
man
of
parts
.
<EOS>
He
knows
how
to
say
a
soft
word
in
the
proper
place
;
he
knows
how
to
adapt
his
flattery
to
the
ears
of
his
hearers
;
he
knows
the
wiles
of
the
serpent
,
and
he
uses
them
.
<EOS>
Could
Mr.
Slope
have
adapted
his
manners
to
men
as
well
as
to
women
,
could
he
ever
have
learnt
the
ways
of
a
gentleman
,
he
might
have
risen
to
great
things
.
  
<EOS>
He
commenced
his
acquaintance
with
Eleanor
by
praising
her
father
.
<EOS>
He
had
,
he
said
,
become
aware
that
he
had
unfortunately
offended
the
feelings
of
a
man
of
whom
he
could
not
speak
too
highly
;
he
would
not
now
allude
to
a
subject
which
was
probably
too
serious
for
drawing
-
room
conversation
,
but
he
would
say
that
it
had
been
very
far
from
him
to
utter
a
word
in
disparagement
of
a
man
of
whom
<EOS>
all
the
world
,
at
least
the
clerical
world
,
spoke
so
highly
as
it
did
of
Mr.
Harding
.
<EOS>
And
so
he
went
on
,
unsaying
a
great
deal
of
his
sermon
,
expressing
his
highest
admiration
for
the
precentor
's

,
eulogizing
the
father
and
the
daughter
and
the
sister
-
in
-
law
,
speaking
in
that
low
silky
whisper
which
he
always
had
specially
prepared
for
feminine
ears
,
and
,
ultimately
,
gaining
his
object
.
<EOS>
When
he
left
,
he
expressed
a
hope
that
he
might
again
be
allowed
to
call
;
and
though
Eleanor
gave
no
verbal

to
this
,
she
did
not
express
dissent
:
and
so
Mr.
Slope
's
right
to
visit
at
the
widow
's
house
was
established
.
  
<EOS>
The
day
after
this
visit
Eleanor
told
her
father
of
it
and
expressed
an
opinion
that
Mr.
Slope
was
not
quite
so
black
as
he
had
been
painted
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
opened
his
eyes
rather
wider
than
usual
when
he
heard
what
had
occurred
,
but
he
said
little
;
he
could
not
agree
in
any
praise
of
Mr.
Slope
,
and
it
was
not
his
practice
to
say
much
evil
of
anyone
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
,
however
,
like
the
visit
,
and
simple
-
minded
as
he
was
,
he
felt
sure
that
Mr.
Slope
had
some
deeper
motive
than
the
mere
pleasure
of
making
soft
speeches
to
two
ladies
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
,
however
,
had
come
to
see
his
daughter
with
other
purpose
than
that
of
speaking
either
good
or
evil
of
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
He
had
come
to
tell
her
that
the
place
of
warden
in
Hiram
's
Hospital
was
again
to
be
filled
up
,
and
that
in
all
probability
he
would
once
more
return
to
his
old
home
and
his
twelve
bedesmen
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
,
"
said
he
,
laughing
,
"
I
shall
be
greatly
shorn
of
my
ancient
glory
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
so
,
Papa
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
This
new
act
of
Parliament
that
is
to
put
us
all
on
our
feet
again
,
"
continued
he
,
"
settles
my
income
at
four
hundred
and
fifty
pounds
per
annum
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Four
hundred
and
fifty
,
"
said
she
,
"
instead
of
eight
hundred
!
<EOS>
Well
,
that
is
rather
shabby
.
<EOS>
But
still
,
Papa
,
you
'll
have
the
dear
old
house
and
the
garden
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
,
"
said
he
,
"
it
's
worth
twice
the
money
;
"
and
as
he
spoke
he
showed
a
jaunty
kind
of
satisfaction
in
his
tone
and
manner
and
in
the
quick
,
pleasant
way
in
which
he
paced
Eleanor
's
drawing
-
room
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
worth
twice
the
money
.
<EOS>
I
shall
have
the
house
and
the
garden
and
a
larger
income
than
I
can
possibly
want
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
At
any
rate
,
you
'll
have
no
extravagant
daughter
to
provide
for
;
"
and
as

,
the
young
widow
put
her
arm
within
his
,
and
made
him
sit
on
the
sofa
beside
her
;
"
at
any
rate
,
you
'll
not
have
that
expense
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
my
dear
,
and
I
shall
be
rather
lonely
without
her
;
but
we
wo
n't
think
of
that
now
.
<EOS>
As
regards
income
,
I
shall
have
plenty
for
all
I
want
.
<EOS>
I
shall
have
my
old
house
,
and
I
do
n't
mind
owning
now
that
I
have
felt
sometimes

of

.
<EOS>
Lodgings
are

,

my

there
is
a
want
of
 
I

,

"
  
"
Oh
,
Papa
!
<EOS>
I
'm

's

.
<EOS>
Nobody

;

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
explained
that
he
thought
there

no

;
that
the

had
declared
as

,

that
the

his

between

had

else
,

,

.
<EOS>
The

was
of

that
,

Harding
had

,

had

,
he

as

,
now
that
the

had
been

on
a

by

of

.
<EOS>
Such
was
the
archdeacon
's
opinion
,
and
his
father
-
in
-
law
received
it
without
a
shadow

.
  
<EOS>
Dr.
Grantly
had
always
been
strongly
opposed
to
Mr.
Harding
's
resignation
of
the
place
.
<EOS>
He
had
done
all
in
his
power
to
dissuade
him
from
it
.
<EOS>
He
had
considered
that
Mr.
Harding
was
bound
to

the
popular

with

he
was
attacked
for
receiving
so
large
an

as
eight
hundred
a
year
from
such
a
charity
,
and
was
not
even
yet
satisfied
that
his
father
-
in
-
law
's

had
not
been

and

.
<EOS>
He
looked
also
on
this
reduction
of
the
warden
's

as
a
shabby
,
paltry
scheme
on
the
part
of
government
for
escaping
from
a
difficulty
into
which

had
been

by
the
public

.
<EOS>
Dr.
Grantly
observed
that
the
government
had
no
more
right
to
dispose
of
a
sum
of
four
hundred
and

a

out
of

of
Hiram
's

than

nine

;
whereas
,

,
the

,

,
and
chapter
clearly
had
a
right
to
settle
what

.
<EOS>
He
also
declared
that
the
government
had
no
more
right
to
saddle
the
charity
with
twelve
old
women
than
with
twelve
hundred
;
and
he
was
,
therefore
,
very
indignant
on

matter
.
<EOS>
He
probably
forgot
when
so
talking
that
government
had
done
nothing
of
the
kind
,
and
had
never
assumed
any

might
or
any

.
<EOS>
He
made
the
common

of
attributing
to
the
government
,
which
in
such

is
powerless
,
the
doings
of
Parliament
,
which
in

.
  
<EOS>
But

Hospital

;

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
had
,

,

that

,

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
The

,

.

<EOS>
"
And

?

"
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

's

.
<EOS>
She

.
  
<EOS>
"
Papa
,
"

,

I

somewhat

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
Papa
.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
But

's

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
Courtesy

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nor

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Believe

,

,
that

's

to

,

,

that

.
<EOS>
I

Slope
's

.
<EOS>
But

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Now
I
think

can

.
"
  
<EOS>
Eleanor
rang

bell
and
gave
a
variety
of
imperative

as
to

of
the

,
whom
,
all
but

,
she

for
an
hour
or
so
,
and
then
sauntered
forth
with
her
father
to
revisit

old
hospital
.
<EOS>
It
had
been
forbidden
ground
to
her
as
well
as
to
him
since
the
day
on
which
they
had
walked
forth

from

.
   
<EOS>
The
Stanhope
Family
 
<EOS>
It
is
now
three
months
since
Dr.
Proudie
began
his
reign
,
and
changes
have
already
been
effected
in
the
diocese
which
show
at
least
the
energy
of
an
active
mind
.
<EOS>
Among
other
things
absentee
clergymen
have
been
favoured
with
hints
much
too
strong
to
be
overlooked
.
<EOS>
Poor
dear
old
Bishop
<EOS>
Grantly
had
on
this
matter
been
too
lenient
,
and
the
archdeacon
had
never
been
inclined
to
be
severe
with
those
who
were
absent
on
reputable
pretences
,
and
who
provided
for
their
duties
in
a
liberal
way
.
  
<EOS>
Among
the
greatest
of
the
diocesan
sinners
in
this
respect
was
Dr.
Vesey
Stanhope
.
<EOS>
Years
had
now
passed
since
he
had
done
a
day
's
duty
,
and
yet
there
was
no
reason
against
his
doing
duty
except
a
want
of
inclination
on
his
own
part
.
<EOS>
He
held
a
prebendal
stall
in
the
diocese
,
one
of
the
best
residences
in
the
close
,
and
the
two
large
rectories
of
Crabtree
Canonicorum
and
Stogpingum
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
he
had
the
cure
of
three
parishes
,
for
that
of
Eiderdown
was
joined
to
Stogpingum
.
<EOS>
He
had
resided
in
Italy
for
twelve
years
.
<EOS>
His
first
going
there
had
been
attributed
to
a
sore
throat
,
and
that
sore
throat
,
though
never
repeated
in
any
violent
manner
,
had
stood
him
in
such
stead
that
it
had
enabled
him
to
live
in
easy
idleness
ever
since
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
now
been
summoned
home
 
not
,
indeed
,
with
rough
violence
,
or
by
any
peremptory
command
,
but
by
a
mandate
which
he
found
himself
unable
to
disregard
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
had
written
to
him
by
the
bishop
's
desire
.
<EOS>
In
the
first
place
,
the
bishop
much
wanted
the
valuable
co
-
operation
of
Dr.
Vesey
Stanhope
in
the
diocese
;
in
the
next
,
the
bishop
thought
it
his
imperative
duty
to
become
personally
acquainted
with
the
most
conspicuous
of
his
diocesan
clergy
;
then
the
bishop
thought
it
essentially
necessary
for
Dr.
Stanhope
's
own
interests
that
Dr.
Stanhope
should
,
at
any
rate
for
a
time
,
return
to
Barchester
;
and
lastly
,
it
was
said
that
so
strong
a
feeling
was
at
the
present
moment
evinced
by
the
hierarchs
of
the
church
with
reference
to
the
absence
of
its
clerical
members
,
that
it
behoved
Dr.
Vesey
Stanhope
not
to
allow
his
name
to
stand
among
those
which
would
probably
in
a
few
months
be
submitted
to
the
councils
of
the
nation
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
something
so
ambiguously
frightful
in
this
last
threat
that
Dr.
Stanhope
determined
to
spend
two
or
three
summer
months
at
his
residence
in
Barchester
.
<EOS>
His
rectories
were
inhabited
by
his
curates
,
and
he
felt
himself
from
disuse
to
be
unfit
for
parochial
duty
;
but
his
prebendal
home
was
kept
empty
for
him
,
and
he
thought
it
probable
that
he
might
be
able
now
and
again
to
preach
a
prebendal
sermon
.
<EOS>
He
arrived
,
therefore
,
with
all
his
family
at
Barchester
,
and
he
and
they
must
be
introduced
to
my
readers
.
  
<EOS>
The
great
family
characteristic
of
the
Stanhopes
might
probably
be
said
to
be
heartlessness
,
but
this
want
of
feeling
was
,
in
most
of
them
,
accompanied
by
so
great
an
amount
of
good
nature
as
to
make
itself
but
little
noticeable
to
the
world
.
<EOS>
They
were
so
prone
to
oblige
their
neighbours
that
their
neighbours
failed
to
perceive
how
indifferent
to
them
was
the
happiness
and
well
-
being
of
those
around
them
.
<EOS>
The
Stanhopes
would
visit
you
in
your
sickness
(
provided
it
were
not
contagious
)
,
would
bring
you
oranges
,
French
novels
,
and
the
last
new
bit
of
scandal
,
and
then
hear
of
your
death
or
your
recovery
with
an
equally
indifferent
composure
.
<EOS>
Their
conduct
to
each
other
was
the
same
as
to
the
world
;
they
bore
and
forbore
;
and
there
was
sometimes
,
as
will
be
seen
,
much
necessity
for
forbearing
;
but
their
love
among
themselves
rarely
reached
above
this
.
<EOS>
It
is
astonishing
how
much
each
of
the
family
was
able
to
do
,
and
how
much
each
did
,
to
prevent
the
well
-
being
of
the
other
four
.
  
<EOS>
For
there
were
five
in
all
;
the
doctor
,
namely
,
and
Mrs.
Stanhope
,
two
daughters
,
and
one
son
.
<EOS>
The
doctor
,
perhaps
,
was
the
least
singular
and
most
estimable
of
them
all
,
and
yet
such
good
qualities
as
he
possessed
were
all
negative
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
good
-
looking
rather
plethoric
gentleman
of
about
sixty
years
of
age
.
<EOS>
His
hair
was
snow
-
white
,
very
plentiful
,
and
somewhat
like
wool
of
the
finest
description
.
<EOS>
His
whiskers
were
very
large
and
very
white
,
and
gave
to
his
face
the
appearance
of
a
benevolent
,
sleepy
old
lion
.
<EOS>
His
dress
was
always
unexceptionable
.
<EOS>
Although
he
had
lived
so
many
years
in
Italy
it
was
invariably
of
a
decent
clerical
hue
,
but
it
never
was
hyperclerical
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
man
not
given
to
much
talking
,
but
what
little
he
did
say
was
generally
well
said
.
<EOS>
His
reading
seldom
went
beyond
romances
and
poetry
of
the
lightest
and
not
always
most
moral
description
.
<EOS>
He
was
thoroughly
a
_
bon
vivant
_
;
an
accomplished
judge
of
wine
,
though
he
never
drank
to
excess
;
and
a
most
inexorable
critic
in
all
affairs
touching
the
kitchen
.
<EOS>
He
had
had
much
to
forgive
in
his
own
family
,
since
a
family
had
grown
up
around
him
,
and
had
forgiven
everything
 
except
inattention
to
his
dinner
.
<EOS>
His
weakness
in
that
respect
was
now
fully
understood
,
and
his
temper
but
seldom
tried
.
<EOS>
As
Dr.
Stanhope
was
a
clergyman
,
it
may
be
supposed
that
his
religious
convictions
made
up
a
considerable
part
of
his
character
,
but
this
was
not
so
.
<EOS>
That
he
had
religious
convictions
must
be
believed
,
but
he
rarely
obtruded
them
,
even
on
his
children
.
<EOS>
This
abstinence
on
his
part
was
not
systematic
,
but
very
characteristic
of
the
man
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
that
he
had
predetermined
never
to
influence
their
thoughts
,
but
he
was
so
habitually
idle
that
his
time
for
doing
so
had
never
come
till
the
opportunity
for
doing
so
was
gone
forever
.
<EOS>
Whatever
conviction
the
father
may
have
had
,
the
children
were
at
any
rate
but
indifferent
members
of
the
church
from
which
he
drew
his
income
.
  
<EOS>
Such
was
Dr.
Stanhope
.
<EOS>
The
features
of
Mrs.
Stanhope
's
character
were
even
less
plainly
marked
than
those
of
her
lord
.
<EOS>
The
_
far
niente
_
of
her
Italian
life
had
entered
into
her
very
soul
,
and
brought
her
to
regard
a
state
of
inactivity
as
the
only
earthly
good
.
<EOS>
In
manner
and
appearance
she
was
exceedingly
prepossessing
.
<EOS>
She
had
been
a
beauty
,
and
even
now
,
at
fifty
-
five
,
she
was
a
handsome
woman
.
<EOS>
Her
dress
was
always
perfect
:
<EOS>
she
never
dressed
but
once
in
the
day
,
and
never
appeared
till
between
three
and
four
;
but
when
she
did
appear
,
she
appeared
at
her
best
.
<EOS>
Whether
the
toil
rested
partly
with
her
,
or
wholly
with
her
handmaid
,
it
is
not
for
such
a
one
as
the
author
even
to
imagine
.
<EOS>
The
structure
of
her
attire
was
always
elaborate
and
yet
never
over
-
laboured
.
<EOS>
She
was
rich
in
apparel
but
not
bedizened
with
finery
;
her
ornaments
were
costly
,
rare
,
and
such
as
could
not
fail
to
attract
notice
,
but
they
did
not
look
as
though
worn
with
that
purpose
.
<EOS>
She
well
knew
the
great
architectural
secret
of
decorating
her
constructions
,
and
never
descended
to
construct
a
decoration
.
<EOS>
But
when
we
have
said
that
Mrs.
Stanhope
knew
how
to
dress
and
used
her
knowledge
daily
,
we
have
said
all
.
<EOS>
Other
purpose
in
life
<EOS>
she
had
none
.
<EOS>
It
was
something
,
indeed
,
that
she
did
not
interfere
with
the
purposes
of
others
.
<EOS>
In
early
life
she
had
undergone
great
trials
with
reference
to
the
doctor
's
dinners
,
but
for
the
last
ten
or
twelve
years
her
elder
daughter
Charlotte
had
taken
that
labour
off
her
hands
,
and
she
had
had
little
to
trouble
her
 
little
,
that
is
,
till
the
edict
for
this
terrible
English
journey
had
gone
forth
:
since
then
,
indeed
,
her
life
had
been
laborious
enough
.
<EOS>
For
such
a
one
,
the
toil
of
being
carried
from
the
shores
of
Como
to
the
city
of
Barchester
is
more
than
labour
enough
,
let
the
care
of
the
carriers
be
ever
so
vigilant
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Stanhope
had
been
obliged
to
have
every
one
of
her
dresses
taken
in
from
the
effects
of
the
journey
.
  
<EOS>
Charlotte
Stanhope
was
at
this
time
about
thirty
-
five
years
old
,
and
whatever
may
have
been
her
faults
,
she
had
none
of
those
which
belong
particularly
to
old
young
ladies
.
<EOS>
She
neither
dressed
young
,
nor
talked
young
,
nor
indeed
looked
young
.
<EOS>
She
appeared
to
be
perfectly
content
with
her
time
of
life
,
and
in
no
way
affected
the
graces
of
youth
.
<EOS>
She
was
a
fine
young
woman
,
and
had
she
been
a
man
,
would
have
been
a
very
fine
young
man
.
<EOS>
All
that
was
done
in
the
house
,
and
that
was
not
done
by
servants
,
was
done
by
her
.
<EOS>
She
gave
the
orders
,
paid
the
bills
,
hired
and
dismissed
the
domestics
,
made
the
tea
,
carved
the
meat
,
and
managed
everything
in
the
Stanhope
household
.
<EOS>
She
,
and
she
alone
,
could
ever
induce
her
father
to
look
into
the
state
of
his
worldly
concerns
.
<EOS>
She
,
and
she
alone
,
could
in
any
degree
control
the
absurdities
of
her
sister
.
<EOS>
She
,
and
she
alone
,
prevented
the
whole
family
from
falling
into
utter
disrepute
and
beggary
.
<EOS>
It
was
by
her
advice
that
they
now
found
themselves
very
unpleasantly
situated
in
Barchester
.
  
<EOS>
So
far
,
the
character
of
Charlotte
Stanhope
is
not
unprepossessing
.
<EOS>
But
it
remains
to
be
said
that
the
influence
which
she
had
in
her
family
,
though
it
had
been
used
to
a
certain
extent
for
their
worldly
well
-
being
,
had
not
been
used
to
their
real
benefit
,
as
it
might
have
been
.
<EOS>
She
had
aided
her
father
in
his
indifference
to
his
professional
duties
,
counselling
him
that
his
livings
were
as
much
his
individual
property
as
the
estates
of
his
elder
brother
were
the
property
of
that
worthy
peer
.
<EOS>
She
had
for
years
past
stifled
every
little
rising
wish
for
a
return
to
England
which
the
doctor
had
from
time
to
time
expressed
.
<EOS>
She
had
encouraged
her
mother
in
her
idleness
,
in
order
that
she
herself
might
be
mistress
and
manager
of
the
Stanhope
household
.
<EOS>
She
had
encouraged
and
fostered
the
follies
of
her
sister
,
though
she
was
always
willing
,
and
often
able
,
to
protect
her
from
their
probable
result
.
<EOS>
She
had
done
her
best
,
and
had
thoroughly
succeeded
in
spoiling
her
brother
,
and
turning
him
loose
upon
the
world
an
idle
man
without
a
profession
and
without
a
shilling
that
he
could
call
his
own
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Stanhope
was
a
clever
woman
,
able
to
talk
on
most
subjects
,
and
quite
indifferent
as
to
what
the
subject
was
.
<EOS>
She
prided
herself
on
her
freedom
from
English
prejudice
,
and
,
she
might
have
added
,
from
feminine
delicacy
.
<EOS>
On
religion
she
was
a
pure
free
-
thinker
,
and
with
much
want
of
true
affection
,
delighted
to
throw
out
her
own
views
before
the
troubled
mind
of
her
father
.
<EOS>
To
have
shaken
what
remained
of
his
Church
of
England
faith
would
have
gratified
her
much
,
but
the
idea
of
his
abandoning
his
preferment
in
the
church
had
never
once
presented
itself
to
her
mind
.
<EOS>
How
could
he
indeed
,
when
he
had
no
income
from
any
other
source
?
  
<EOS>
But
the
two
most
prominent
members
of
the
family
still
remain
to
be
described
.
<EOS>
The
second
child
had
been
christened
Madeline
and
had
been
a
great
beauty
.
<EOS>
We
need
not
say
had
been
,
for
she
was
never
more
beautiful
than
at
the
time
of
which
we
write
,
though
her
person
for
many
years
had
been
disfigured
by
an
accident
.
<EOS>
It
is
unnecessary
that
we
should
give
in
detail
the
early
history
of
Madeline
Stanhope
.
<EOS>
She
had
gone
to
Italy
when
about
seventeen
years
of
age
,
and
had
been
allowed
to
make
the
most
of
her
surpassing
beauty
in
the
salons
of
Milan
and
among
the
crowded
villas
along
the
shores
of
the
Lake
of
Como
.
<EOS>
She
had
become
famous
for
adventures
in
which
her
character
was
just
not
lost
,
and
had
destroyed
the
hearts
of
a
dozen
cavaliers
without
once
being
touched
in
her
own
.
<EOS>
Blood
had
flowed
in
quarrels
about
her
charms
,
and
she
had
heard
of
these
encounters
with
pleasurable
excitement
.
<EOS>
It
had
been
told
of
her
that
on
one
occasion
she
had
stood
by
in
the
disguise
of
a
page
and
had
seen
her
lover
fall
.
  
<EOS>
As
is
so
often
the
case
,
she
had
married
the
very
worst
of
those
who
sought
her
hand
.
<EOS>
Why
she
had
chosen
Paulo
Neroni
,
a
man
of
no
birth
and
no
property
,
a
mere
captain
in
the
Pope
's
guard
,
one
who
had
come
up
to
Milan
either
simply
as
an
adventurer
or
else
as
a
spy
,
a
man
of
harsh
temper
and
oily
manners
,
<EOS>
mean
in
figure
,
swarthy
in
face
,
and
so
false
in
words
as
to
be
hourly
detected
,
<EOS>
need
not
now
be
told
.
<EOS>
When
the
moment
for
doing
so
came
,
she
had
probably
no
alternative
.
<EOS>
He
,
at
any
rate
,
had
become
her
husband
,
and
after
a
prolonged
honeymoon
among
the
lakes
,
they
had
gone
together
to
Rome
,
the
papal
captain
having
vainly
endeavoured
to
induce
his
wife
to
remain
behind
him
.
  
<EOS>
Six
months
afterwards
she
arrived
at
her
father
's
house
a
cripple
,
and
a
mother
.
<EOS>
She
had
arrived
without
even
notice
,
with
hardly
clothes
to
cover
her
,
and
without
one
of
those
many
ornaments
which
had
graced
her
bridal
trousseau
.
<EOS>
Her
baby
was
in
the
arms
of
a
poor
girl
from
Milan
,
whom
she
had
taken
in
exchange
for
the
Roman
maid
who
had
accompanied
her
thus
far
,
and
who
had
then
,
as
her
mistress
said
,
become
homesick
and
had
returned
.
<EOS>
It
was
clear
that
the
lady
had
determined
that
there
should
be
no
witness
to
tell
stories
of
her
life
in
Rome
.
  
<EOS>
She
had
fallen
,
she
said
,
in
ascending
a
ruin
,
and
had
fatally
injured
the
sinews
of
her
knee
;
so
fatally
that
when
she
stood
,
she
lost
eight
inches
of
her
accustomed
height
;
so
fatally
that
when
she
essayed
to
move
,
she
could
only
drag
herself
painfully
along
,
with
protruded
hip
and
extended
foot
,
in
a
manner
less
graceful
than
that
of
a
hunchback
.
<EOS>
She
had
consequently
made
up
her
mind
,
once
and
forever
,
that
she
would
never
stand
and
never
attempt
to
move
herself
.
  
<EOS>
Stories
were
not
slow
to
follow
her
,
averring
that
she
had
been
cruelly
ill
-
used
by
Neroni
,
and
that
to
his
violence
had
she
owed
her
accident
.
<EOS>
Be
that
as
it
may
,
little
had
been
said
about
her
husband
,
but
that
little
had
made
it
clearly
intelligible
to
the
family
that
Signor
Neroni
was
to
be
seen
and
heard
of
no
more
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
question
as
to
readmitting
the
poor
,
ill
-
used
beauty
to
her
old
family
rights
,
no
question
as
to
adopting
her
infant
daughter
beneath
the
Stanhope
roof
-
tree
.
<EOS>
Though
heartless
,
the
Stanhopes
were
not
selfish
.
<EOS>
The
two
were
taken
in
,
petted
,
made
much
of
,
for
a
time
all
but
adored
,
and
then
felt
by
the
two
parents
to
be
great
nuisances
in
the
house
.
<EOS>
But
in
the
house
the
lady
was
,
and
there
she
remained
,
having
her
own
way
,
though
that
way
was
not
very
conformable
with
the
customary
usages
of
an
English
clergyman
.
  
<EOS>
Madame
Neroni
,
though
forced
to
give
up
all
motion
in
the
world
,
had
no
intention
whatever
of
giving
up
the
world
itself
.
<EOS>
The
beauty
of
her
face
was
uninjured
,
and
that
beauty
was
of
a
peculiar
kind
.
<EOS>
Her
copious
rich
brown
hair
was
worn
in
Grecian
bandeaux
<EOS>
round
her
head
,
displaying
as
much
as
possible
of
her
forehead
and
cheeks
.
<EOS>
Her
forehead
,
though
rather
low
,
was
very
beautiful
from
its
perfect
contour
and
pearly
whiteness
.
<EOS>
Her
eyes
were
long
and
large
,
and
marvellously
bright
;
might
I
venture
to
say
bright
as
Lucifer
's
,
I
should
perhaps
best
express
the
depth
of
their
brilliancy
.
<EOS>
They
were
dreadful
eyes
to
look
at
,
such
as
would
absolutely
deter
any
man
of
quiet
mind
and
easy
spirit
from
attempting
a
passage
of
arms
with
such
foes
.
<EOS>
There
was
talent
in
them
,
and
the
fire
of
passion
and
the
play
of
wit
,
but
there
was
no
love
.
<EOS>
Cruelty
was
there
instead
,
and
courage
,
a
desire
of
masterhood
,
cunning
,
and
a
wish
for
mischief
.
<EOS>
And
yet
,
as
eyes
,
they
were
very
beautiful
.
<EOS>
The
eyelashes
were
long
and
perfect
,
and
the
long
,
steady
,
unabashed
gaze
with
which
she
would
look
into
the
face
of
her
admirer
fascinated
while
it
frightened
him
.
<EOS>
She
was
a
basilisk
from
whom
an
ardent
lover
of
beauty
could
make
no
escape
.
<EOS>
Her
nose
and
mouth
and
teeth
and
chin
and
neck
and
bust
were
perfect
,
much
more
so
at
twenty
-
eight
than
they
had
been
at
eighteen
.
<EOS>
What
wonder
that
with
such
charms
still
glowing
in
her
face
,
and
with
such
deformity
destroying
her
figure
,
she
should
resolve
to
be
seen
,
but
only
to
be
seen
reclining
on
a
sofa
.
  
<EOS>
Her
resolve
had
not
been
carried
out
without
difficulty
.
<EOS>
She
had
still
frequented
the
opera
at
Milan
;
she
had
still
been
seen
occasionally
in
the
salons
of
the
noblesse
;
she
had
caused
herself
to
be
carried
in
and
out
from
her
carriage
,
and
that
in
such
a
manner
as
in
no
wise
to
disturb
her
charms
,
disarrange
her
dress
,
or
expose
her
deformities
.
<EOS>
Her
sister
always
accompanied
her
and
a
maid
,
a
manservant
also
,
and
on
state
occasions
,
two
.
<EOS>
It
was
impossible
that
her
purpose
could
have
been
achieved
with
less
;
and
yet
,
poor
as
she
was
,
she
had
achieved
her
purpose
.
<EOS>
And
then
again
the
more
dissolute
Italian
youths
of
Milan
frequented
the
Stanhope
villa
and
surrounded
her
couch
,
not
greatly
to
her
father
's
satisfaction
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
his
spirit
would
rise
,
a
dark
spot
would
show
itself
on
his
cheek
,
and
he
would
rebel
,
but
Charlotte
would
assuage
him
with
some
peculiar
triumph
of
her
culinary
art
and
all
again
would
be
smooth
for
awhile
.
  
<EOS>
Madeline
affected
all
manner
of
rich
and
quaint
devices
in
the
garniture
of
her
room
,
her
person
,
and
her
feminine
belongings
.
<EOS>
In
nothing
was
this
more
apparent
than
in
the
visiting
card
which
she
had
prepared
for
her
use
.
<EOS>
For
such
an
article
one
would
say
that
she
,
in
her
present
state
,
could
have
but
small
need
,
seeing
how
improbable
it
was
that
she
should
make
a
morning
call
:
but
not
such
was
her
own
opinion
.
<EOS>
Her
card
was
surrounded
by
a
deep
border
of
gilding
;
on
this
she
had
imprinted
,
in
three
lines
  
La
Signora
Madeline
Vesey
Neroni
.
 
<EOS>
Nata
Stanhope
.
  
<EOS>
And
over
the
name
she
had
a
bright
gilt
coronet
,
which
certainly
looked
very
magnificent
.
<EOS>
How
she
had
come
to
concoct
such
a
name
for
herself
it
would
be
difficult
to
explain
.
<EOS>
Her
father
had
been
christened
Vesey
as
another
man
is
christened
Thomas
,
and
she
had
no
more
right
to
assume
it
than
would
have
the
daughter
of
a
Mr.
Josiah
Jones
to
call
herself
Mrs.
Josiah
Smith
,
on
marrying
a
man
of
the
latter
name
.
<EOS>
The
gold
coronet
was
equally
out
of
place
,
and
perhaps
inserted
with
even
less
excuse
.
<EOS>
Paulo
Neroni
had
had
not
the
faintest
title
to
call
himself
a
scion
of
even
Italian
nobility
.
<EOS>
Had
the
pair
met
in
England
<EOS>
Neroni
would
probably
have
been
a
count
,
but
they
had
met
in
Italy
,
and
any
such
pretence
on
his
part
would
have
been
simply
ridiculous
.
<EOS>
A
coronet
,
however
,
was
a
pretty
ornament
,
and
if
it
could
solace
a
poor
cripple
to
have
such
on
her
card
,
who
would
begrudge
it
to
her
?
  
<EOS>
Of
her
husband
,
or
of
his
individual
family
,
she
never
spoke
,
but
with
her
admirers
she
would
often
allude
in
a
mysterious
way
to
her
married
life
and
isolated
state
,
and
,
pointing
to
her
daughter
,
would
call
her
the
last
of
the
blood
of
the
emperors
,
thus
referring
Neroni
's
extraction
to
the
old
Roman
family
from
which
the
worst
of
the
Caesars
sprang
.
  
<EOS>
The
"
signora
"
was
not
without
talent
and
not
without
a
certain
sort
of
industry
;
she
was
an
indomitable
letter
-
writer
,
and
her
letters
were
worth
the
postage
:
they
were
full
of
wit
,
mischief
,
satire
,
love
,
latitudinarian
philosophy
,
free
religion
,
and
,
sometimes
,
alas
,
loose
ribaldry
.
<EOS>
The
subject
,
however
,
depended
entirely
on
the
recipient
,
and
she
was
prepared
to
correspond
with
anyone
but
moral
young
ladies
or
stiff
old
women
.
<EOS>
She
wrote
also
a
kind
of
poetry
,
generally
in
Italian
,
and
short
romances
,
generally
in
French
.
<EOS>
She
read
much
of
a
desultory
sort
of
literature
,
and
as
a
modern
linguist
had
really
made
great
proficiency
.
<EOS>
Such
was
the
lady
who
had
now
come
to
wound
the
hearts
of
the
men
of
Barchester
.
  
<EOS>
Ethelbert
Stanhope
was
in
some
respects
like
his
younger
sister
,
but
he
was
less
inestimable
as
a
man
than
she
as
a
woman
.
<EOS>
His
great
fault
was
an
entire
absence
of
that
principle
which
should
have
induced
him
,
as
the
son
of
a
man
without
fortune
,
to
earn
his
own
bread
.
<EOS>
Many
attempts
had
been
made
to
get
him
to
do
so
,
but
these
had
all
been
frustrated
,
not
so
much
by
idleness
on
his
part
as
by
a
disinclination
to
exert
himself
in
any
way
not
to
his
taste
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
educated
at
Eton
and
had
been
intended
for
the
Church
,
but
he
had
left
Cambridge
in
disgust
after
a
single
term
,
and
notified
to
his
father
his
intention
to
study
for
the
bar
.
<EOS>
Preparatory
to
that
,
he
thought
it
well
that
he
should
attend
a
German
university
,
and
consequently
went
to
Leipzig
.
<EOS>
There
he
remained
two
years
and
brought
away
a
knowledge
of
German
and
a
taste
for
the
fine
arts
.
<EOS>
He
still
,
however
,
intended
himself
for
the
bar
,
took
chambers
,
engaged
himself
to
sit
at
the
feet
of
a
learned
pundit
,
and
spent
a
season
in
London
.
<EOS>
He
there
found
that
all
his
aptitudes
inclined
him
to
the
life
of
an
artist
,
and
he
determined
to
live
by
painting
.
<EOS>
With
this
object
he
returned
to
Milan
,
and
had
himself
rigged
out
for
Rome
.
<EOS>
As
a
painter
he
might
have
earned
his
bread
,
for
he
wanted
only
diligence
to
excel
,
but
when
at
Rome
his
mind
was
carried
away
by
other
things
:
he
soon
wrote
home
for
money
,
saying
that
he
had
been
converted
to
the
Mother
Church
,
that
he
was
already
an
acolyte
of
the
Jesuits
,
and
that
he
was
about
to
start
with
others
to
Palestine
on
a
mission
for
converting
Jews
.
<EOS>
He
did
go
to
Judea
,
but
being
unable
to
convert
the
Jews
,
was
converted
by
them
.
<EOS>
He
again
wrote
home
,
to
say
that
Moses
was
the
only
giver
of
perfect
laws
to
the
world
,
that
the
coming
of
the
true
Messiah
was
at
hand
,
that
great
things
were
doing
in
Palestine
,
and
that
he
had
met
one
of
the
family
of
Sidonia
,
a
most
remarkable
man
,
who
was
now
on
his
way
to
western
Europe
,
and
whom
he
had
induced
to
deviate
from
his
route
with
the
object
of
calling
at
the
Stanhope
villa
.
<EOS>
Ethelbert
then
expressed
his
hope
that
his
mother
and
sisters
would
listen
to
this
wonderful
prophet
.
<EOS>
His
father
he
knew
could
not
do
so
from
pecuniary
considerations
.
<EOS>
This
Sidonia
,
however
,
did
not
take
so
strong
a
fancy
to
him
as
another
of
that
family
once
did
to
a
young
English
nobleman
.
<EOS>
At
least
he
provided
him
with
no
heaps
of
gold
as
large
as
lions
,
so
that
the
Judaized
Ethelbert
was
again
obliged
to
draw
on
the
revenues
of
the
Christian
Church
.
  
<EOS>
It
is
needless
to
tell
how
the
father
swore
that
he
would
send
no
more
money
and
receive
no
Jew
,
nor
how
Charlotte
declared
that
Ethelbert
could
not
be
left

in
Jerusalem
,
and
how
"
La
Signora
Neroni
"
resolved
to
have
Sidonia
at
her
feet
.
<EOS>
The
money
was
sent
,
and
the
Jew
did
come
.
<EOS>
The
Jew
did
come
,
but
he
was
not
at
all
to
the
taste
of
"
La
Signora
.
<EOS>
"
He
was
a
dirty
little
old
man
,
and
though
he
had
provided
no
golden
lions
<EOS>
,
he
had
,
it
seems
,
relieved
young
Stanhope
's
necessities
.
<EOS>
He
positively
refused
to
leave
the
villa
till
he
had
got
a
bill
from
the
doctor
on
his
London
bankers
.
  
<EOS>
Ethelbert
did
not
long
remain
a
Jew
.
<EOS>
He
soon
reappeared
at
the
villa
without
prejudices
on
the
subject
of
his
religion
,
and
with
a
firm
resolve
to
achieve
fame
and
fortune
as
a
sculptor
.
<EOS>
He
brought
with
him
some
models
which
he
had
originated
at
Rome
and
which
really
gave
such
fair
promise
that
his
father
was
induced
to
go
to
further
expense
in
furthering
these
views
.
<EOS>
Ethelbert
opened
an
establishment
,
or
rather
took
lodgings
and
a
workshop
,
at
Carrara
,
and
there
spoilt
much
marble
and
made
some
few
pretty
images
.
<EOS>
Since
that
period
,
now
four
years
ago
,
he
had
alternated
between
Carrara
and
the
villa
,
but
his
sojourns
at
the
workshop
became
shorter
and
shorter
and
those
at
the
villa
longer
and
longer
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Twas
no
wonder
,
for
Carrara
is
not
a
spot
in
which
an
Englishman
would
like
to
dwell
.
  
<EOS>
When
the
family
started
for
England
,
he
had
resolved
not
to
be
left
behind
,
and
,
with
the
assistance
of
his
elder
sister
,
had
carried
his
point
against
his
father
's
wishes
.
<EOS>
It
was
necessary
,
he
said
,
that
he
should
come
to
England
for
orders
.
<EOS>
How
otherwise
was
he
to
bring
his
profession
to
account
?
  
<EOS>
In
personal
appearance
Ethelbert
Stanhope
was
the
most
singular
of
beings
.
<EOS>
He
was
certainly
very
handsome
.
<EOS>
He
had
his
sister
Madeline
's
eyes
,
without
their
stare
and
without
their
hard
,
cunning
,
cruel
firmness
.
<EOS>
They
were
also
very
much
lighter
,
and
of
so
light
and
clear
a
blue
as
to
make
his
face
remarkable
,
if
nothing
else
did
so
.
<EOS>
On
entering
a
room
with
him
,
Ethelbert
's
blue
eyes
would
be
the
first
thing
you
would
see
,
and
on
leaving
it
almost
the
last
you
would
forget
.
<EOS>
His
light
hair
was
very
long
and
silky
,
coming
down
over
his
coat
.
<EOS>
His
beard
had
been
prepared
in
holy
land
,
and
was
patriarchal
.
<EOS>
He
never
shaved
and
rarely
trimmed
it
.
<EOS>
It
was
glossy
,
soft
,
clean
,
and
altogether
not
unprepossessing
.
<EOS>
It
was
such
that
ladies
might
desire
to
reel
it
off
and
work
it
into
their
patterns
in
lieu
of
floss
silk
.
<EOS>
His
complexion
was
fair
and
almost
pink
;
he
was
small
in
height
and
slender
in
limb
,
but
well
-
made
;
and
his
voice
was
of
peculiar
sweetness
.
  
<EOS>
In
manner
and
dress
he
was
equally
remarkable
.
<EOS>
He
had
none
of
the
_
mauvaise
honte
_
of
an
Englishman
.
<EOS>
He
required
no
introduction
to
make
himself
agreeable
to
any
person
.
<EOS>
He
habitually
addressed
strangers
,
ladies
as
well
as
men
,
without
any
such
formality
,
and
in
doing
so
never
seemed
to
meet
with
rebuke
.
<EOS>
His
costume
can
not
be
described
because
it
was
so
various
,
but
it
was
always
totally
opposed
in
every
principle
of
colour
and
construction
to
the
dress
of
those
with
whom
he
for
the
time
consorted
.
  
<EOS>
He
was
habitually
addicted
to
making
love
to
ladies
,
and
did
so
without
any
scruples
of
conscience
,
or
any
idea
that
such
a
practice
was
amiss
.
<EOS>
He
had
no
heart
to
touch
himself
,
and
was
literally
unaware
that
humanity
was
subject
to
such
an
infliction
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
thought
much
about
it
,
but
,
had
he
been
asked
,
would
have
said
that
ill
-
treating
a
lady
's
heart
meant
injuring
her
promotion
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
His
principles
therefore
forbade
him
to
pay
attention
to
a
girl
if
he
thought
any
man
was
present
whom
it
might
suit
her
to
marry
.
<EOS>
In
this
manner
his
good
nature
frequently
interfered
with
his
amusement
,
but
he
had
no
other
motive
in
abstaining
from
the
fullest
declarations
of
love
to
every
girl
that
pleased
his
eye
.
  
<EOS>
Bertie
Stanhope
,
as
he
was
generally
called
,
was
,
however
,
popular
with
both
sexes
 
and
with
Italians
as
well
as
English
.
<EOS>
His
circle
of
acquaintance
was
very
large
and
embraced
people
of
all
sorts
.
<EOS>
He
had
no
respect
for
rank
,
and
no
aversion
to
those
below
him
.
<EOS>
He
had
lived
on
familiar
terms
with
English
peers
,
German
shopkeepers
,
and
Roman
priests
.
<EOS>
All
people
were
nearly
alike
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
was
above
,
or
rather
below
,
all
prejudices
.
<EOS>
No
virtue
could
charm
him
,
no
vice
shock
him
.
<EOS>
He
had
about
him
a
natural
good
manner
,
which
seemed
to
qualify
him
for
the
highest
circles
,
and
yet
he
was
never
out
of
place
in
the
lowest
.
<EOS>
He
had
no
principle
,
no
regard
for
others
,
no
self
-
respect
,
no
desire
to
be
other
than
a
drone
in
the
hive
,
if
only
he
could
,
as
a
drone
,
get
what
honey
was
sufficient
for
him
.
<EOS>
Of
honey
,
in
his
latter
days
,
it
may
probably
be
presaged
,
that
he
will
have
but
short
allowance
.
  
<EOS>
Such
was
the
family
of
the
Stanhopes
,
who
,
at
this
period
,
suddenly
joined
themselves
to
the
ecclesiastical
circle
of
Barchester
close
.
<EOS>
Any
stranger
union
it
would
be
impossible
perhaps
to
conceive
.
<EOS>
And
it
was
not
as
though
they
all
fell
down
into
the
cathedral
precincts
hitherto
unknown
and
untalked
of
.
<EOS>
In
such
case
,
no
amalgamation
would
have
been
at
all
probable
between
the
new
-
comers
and
either
the
Proudie
set
or
the
Grantly
set
.
<EOS>
But
such
was
far
from
being
the
case
.
<EOS>
The
Stanhopes
were
all
known
by
name
in
Barchester
,
and
Barchester
was
prepared
to
receive
them
with
open
arms
.
<EOS>
The
doctor
was
one
of
her
prebendaries
,
one
of
her
rectors
,
one
of
her
pillars
of
strength
;
and
was
,
moreover
,
counted
on
as
a
sure
ally
both
by
Proudies
and
Grantlys
.
  
<EOS>
He
himself
was
the
brother
of
one
peer
,
and
his
wife
was
the
sister
of
another
 
and
both
these
peers
were
lords
of
Whiggish
tendency
,
with
whom
the
new
bishop
had
some
sort
of
alliance
.
<EOS>
This
was
sufficient
to
give
to
Mr.
Slope
high
hope
that
he
might
enlist
Dr.
Stanhope
on
his
side
,
before
his
enemies
could
outmanoeuvre
him
.
<EOS>
On
the
other
hand
,
the
old
dean
had
many
many
years
ago
,
in
the
days
of
the
doctor
's
clerical
energies
,
been
instrumental
in
assisting
him
in
his
views
as
to
preferment
;
and
many
many
years
ago
also
,
the
two
doctors
,
Stanhope
and
Grantly
,
had
,
as
young
parsons
,
been
joyous
together
in
the
common
-
rooms
of
Oxford
.
<EOS>
Dr.
Grantly
,
consequently
,
did
not
doubt
but
that
the
newcomer
would
range
himself
under
his
banners
.
  
<EOS>
Little
did
any
of
them
dream
of
what
ingredients
the
Stanhope
family
was
now
composed
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs.
Proudie
's
Reception
 
Commenced
 
<EOS>
The
bishop
and
his
wife
had
spent
only
three
or
four
days
in
Barchester
on
the
occasion
of
their
first
visit
.
<EOS>
His
lordship
had
,
as
we
have
seen
,
taken
his
seat
on
his
throne
,
but
his
demeanour
there
,
into
which
it
had
been
his
intention
to
infuse
much
hierarchal
dignity
,
had
been
a
good
deal
disarranged
by
the
audacity
of
his
chaplain
's
sermon
.
<EOS>
He
had
hardly
dared
to
look
his
clergy
in
the
face
,
and
to
declare
by
the
severity
of
his
countenance
that
in
truth
he
meant
all
that
his
factotum
was
saying
on
his
behalf
;
nor
yet
did
he
dare
to
throw
Mr.
Slope
over
,
and
show
to
those
around
him
that
he
was
no
party
to
the
sermon
,
and
would
resent
it
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
accordingly
blessed
his
people
in
a

manner
,
not
at
all
to
his
own
satisfaction
,
and
had
walked
back
to
his
palace
with
his
mind
very
doubtful
as
to
what
he
would
say
to
his
chaplain
on
the
subject
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
remain
long
in
doubt
.
<EOS>
He
had
hardly
doffed
his
lawn
when
the
partner
of
all
his
toils
entered
his
study
and
exclaimed
even
before
she
had
seated
herself
<EOS>
:
  
"
Bishop
,
did
you
ever
hear
a
more

,
more
spirit
-

,
more

than
that
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
my
love
;
ha
 
hum
 
he
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
bishop
did
not
know
what
to
say
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
,
my
lord
,
you
do
n't

disapprove
?
"
  
<EOS>
There

look
about
the
lady
's

which
did
not
admit
of
my
lord
's
disapproving
at
that

.
<EOS>
He
felt
that
if
he
intended
to
disapprove
,
it
must
be
now
or

;
but
he
also
felt
that
it
could
not

now
.
<EOS>
It
was
not

him
to
say
to
the
wife
of
his

that
Mr.
Slope
's
sermon
was
ill
-

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
"
replied

bishop
.
"
<EOS>
No
,
I
ca
n't
say
I
disapprove
 
a
very
clever

and
very
well

,
and
I
dare
say
will
do

great

.
<EOS>
"
This

,

what

no

Mrs.

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

will
,
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
I

.
<EOS>
Did

,
bishop
,

-

Harding

?
<EOS>
I

Slope
to

.
<EOS>
We

,

.
<EOS>
There

play
-
acting
here
now
;
"
and

for

.
  
<EOS>
The
bishop
knew
more
about

and

than
his
wife

,
and

of

's

.
<EOS>
But

.
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
,
"
said

,
"
I
think
we
must
go
back
to
London
on
Tuesday
.
<EOS>
I
find
my
staying
here
will
be
very
inconvenient
to
the
Government
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
bishop
knew
that
to
this

his
wife
would
not
object
,
and
he
also
felt
that
by
thus
retreating
from
the
ground
of
battle
the
heat

the
fight
might
be
got
over
in

.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Slope
will
remain

,

course
?
"
said
the

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
of
course
,
"
said
the
bishop
.
  
<EOS>
Thus
,
after
less
than
a
week
's
sojourn
in
his

,
did
the
bishop
fly
from
Barchester
;
nor
did
he
return
to
it
for
two
months
,
the
London
season
being
then
over
.
<EOS>
During
that
time
Mr.
Slope
was
not
idle
,
but
he
did
not
again
essay
to
preach
in
the
cathedral
.
<EOS>
In
answer
to
Mrs.
Proudie
's

advising

,
he
had
pleaded
that
he
would
at
any
rate
wish
to
put
off
such
an
undertaking
till
she
was
there
to
hear
them
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
employed
his
time
in
consolidating
a
Proudie
and
Slope
party
 
or
rather
a
Slope
and
Proudie
party
,
and
he
had
not
employed
his
time
in
vain
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
meddle
with
the
dean
and
chapter
,
except
by
giving
them
little
teasing
intimations
of
the
bishop
's
wishes
about
this
and
the
bishop
's
feelings
about
that
,
in
a
manner
which
was
to
them
sufficiently
annoying
,
but
which
they
could
not
resent
.
<EOS>
He
preached
once
or
twice
in
a
distant
church
in
the
suburbs
of
the
city
,
but
made
no
allusion
to
the
cathedral
service
.
<EOS>
He
commenced
the
establishment
of
two
"
Bishop
's
Barchester
Sabbath
-
day
schools
,
"
gave
notice
of
a

"
Bishop
's
Barchester
Young
Men
's
Sabbath
Evening
Lecture
Room
,
"
and
wrote

or

to

Barchester
branch
railway
,
informing
him
how
anxious
the
bishop
was
that
the
Sunday

should

.
  
<EOS>
At
the
end
of
two
months
,
however
,
the
bishop
and
the
lady

,
and
as
a
happy

of
their

,
heralded
their

by
the

of
an
evening

on
the
largest

.
<EOS>
The
tickets
of
invitation
were
sent
out
from
London
 
<EOS>
they
were
dated
from
Bruton
Street
,
and
were
dispatched
by
the
odious
Sabbath
-
breaking
railway
,
in
a
huge
brown

to
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
Everybody
calling
himself
a
gentleman
,
or
herself

,
within
the
city
of
Barchester
,
and
a

two

,

.
<EOS>
Tickets
were

to
all

,
and

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
It

,

,
to
be
a

and

,

were

for

.
  
<EOS>
And
now
there
arose
considerable
agitation
among
the
Grantlyites
<EOS>
whether
or
no
they
would
attend
the
episcopal

.
<EOS>
The
first
feeling
with
them
all
was
to
send

briefest

both
for

and
their
wives
and

.
<EOS>
But
by
degrees
policy
prevailed
over

.
<EOS>
The
archdeacon
perceived
that
he

be

if

to

.
<EOS>
They
all
met
in

and
agreed
to
go
.
<EOS>
They
would
show
that
they
were
willing
to
respect
the
office
,
much
as
they
might
dislike
the
man
.
<EOS>
They
agreed
to
go
.
<EOS>
The
old
dean
would
crawl
in
,
if
it
were
but

.
<EOS>
The

,

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
was

,

to

Proudie
.
<EOS>
And

Bold

,

.
<EOS>
When

,

.
<EOS>
Had

?
<EOS>
And

,

,

?
  
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
Even

.
<EOS>
They

.
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
No

.
<EOS>
What

?
<EOS>
Some

,

_

_

.
  
<EOS>
The

's

,

.
<EOS>
If

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

parsons

"

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
You

Papa

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Papa

,

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
Such

,

it
;
as
he
had
sown
his
seed
,
so
must
he
reap
his
corn
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
indeed
utter
such
reflexions
in
such
language
,
but
such
was
the
gist
of
his
thought
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
because
Madeline
was
a
cripple
that
he
shrank
from
seeing
her
made
one
of
the
bishop
's
guests
,
but
because
he
knew
that
she
would
practise
her
accustomed
lures
,
and
behave
herself
in
a
way
that
could
not
fail
of
being
distasteful
to
the
propriety
of
Englishwomen
.
<EOS>
These
things
had
annoyed
but
not
shocked
him
in
Italy
.
<EOS>
There
they
had
shocked
no
one
;
but
here
in
Barchester
,
here
among
his
fellow
parsons
,
he
was
ashamed
that
they
should
be
seen
.
<EOS>
Such
had
been
his
feelings
,
but
he
repressed
them
.
<EOS>
What
if
his
brother
clergymen
were
shocked
!
<EOS>
They
could
not
take
from
him
his
preferment
because
the
manners
of
his
married
daughter
were
too
free
.
  
<EOS>
La
Signora
Neroni
had
,
at
any
rate
,
<EOS>
no
fear
that
she
would
shock
anybody
.
<EOS>
Her
ambition
was
to
create
a
sensation
,
to
have
parsons
at
her
feet
,
seeing
that
the
manhood
of
Barchester
consisted
mainly
of
parsons
,
and
to
send
,
if
possible
,
every
parson
's
wife
home
with
a
green

of
jealousy
.
<EOS>
None
could
be
too
old
for
her
,
and
hardly
any
too
young
.
<EOS>
None
too
sanctified
,
and
none
too
worldly
.
<EOS>
She
was
quite
prepared
to
entrap
the
bishop
himself
,
and
then
to
turn
up
her
nose
at
the
bishop
's
wife
.
<EOS>
She
did
not
doubt
of
success
,
for
she
had
always
succeeded
;
but
one
thing
was
absolutely
necessary
;
she
must
secure
the
entire
use
of
a
sofa
.
  
<EOS>
The
card
sent
to
Dr.
and
Mrs.
Stanhope
and
family
had
been
so
sent
in
an
envelope
having
on
the
cover
Mr.
Slope
's
name
.
<EOS>
The
signora
soon
learnt
that
Mrs.
Proudie
was
not
yet
at
the
palace
and
that
the
chaplain
was
managing
everything
.
<EOS>
It
was
much
more
in
her
line
to
apply
to
him
than
to
the
lady
,
and
she
accordingly
wrote
him
the
prettiest
little
billet
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
In
five
lines
she
explained
everything
,
declared
how
impossible
it
was
for
her
not
to
be
desirous
to
make
the
acquaintance
of
such

as
the
Bishop
of
Barchester
and
his
wife
,
and
she
might
add
also
of
Mr.
Slope
,
depicted
her
own

state
,
and
concluded
by
being
assured
that
Mrs.
Proudie
would
forgive
her

in
petitioning
to
be

to
be
carried
to
a
sofa
.
<EOS>
She
then
enclosed
one
of
her
beautiful
cards
.
<EOS>
In
return
she
received
as
polite
an
answer
from
Mr.
Slope
 
<EOS>
a
sofa
should
be
kept
in
the
large
drawing

,
immediately
at
the
top
of
the
grand
stairs
,
especially
for
her
use
.
  
<EOS>
And
now
the
day
of
the
party
had
arrived
.
<EOS>
The
bishop
and
his
wife
came
down
from
town
only
on
the
morning
of
the
eventful
day
,
as
behoved
such
great
people
to
do
,
but
Mr.
Slope
had
toiled
day
and
night
to
see
that
everything
should
be
in

order
.
<EOS>
There
had
been
much
to
do
.
<EOS>
No
company
had
been
seen
in
the
palace
since
heaven
knows
when
.
<EOS>
New
furniture
had
been
required
,
new
pots
and
pans
,
new

and

,
new

and

.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Proudie
had
at
first
declared
that
she
would
condescend
to
nothing
so

as
eating
and

,
but
Mr.
Slope
had
talked
,

.
<EOS>
Bishops
should
be
given
to
hospitality
,
and
hospitality
meant
eating
and
drinking
.
<EOS>
So
the
supper
was
conceded
;
the
guests
,
however
,
were
to
stand

.
  
<EOS>
There
were
four
rooms
opening
into

on

,
which
were

the

,

,

's

.
<EOS>
In

one

had
been
Bishop
Grantly
's

,
and
another
his
common

and

.
<EOS>
The
present
bishop
,

,

,

.
<EOS>
He
had
been

,
but

.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Proudie
's
heart
beat
high
as
she
inspected
her
suite
of
rooms
.
<EOS>
They
were
really
very
magnificent
,
or
at
least
would
be
so
by

,
and
they
had
nevertheless
been
got
up
with
commendable

.
<EOS>
Large
rooms
when
full
of
people
and
full
of
light
look
well
,
because
they
are
large
,
and
are
full
,
and
are
light
.
<EOS>
Small
rooms
are
those
which
require
costly
fittings
and
rich
furniture
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Proudie
knew
this
,
and
made
the
most

;
she
had
therefore
a
huge
gas

with
a
dozen

.
  
<EOS>
People
were
to
arrive
at
ten
,
supper
was
to
last
from
twelve
till
one
,
and
at
half
-
past
one
everybody
was
to

gone
.
<EOS>
Carriages
were
to
come
in
at
the
gate

and

.
<EOS>
They

a

before
one
.
<EOS>
It
was

,
and
Mr.
Slope
was

.
  
<EOS>
At

nine
the

,

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
was
downstairs
giving

about

.
<EOS>
He
well
understood
that
curates
and
country

with

not

.
<EOS>
There

,
and
Marsala
at
20s
.
<EOS>
a
dozen
did
very

for

.
  
<EOS>
"
Bishop
,
"

,

,
"

,

;

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The

"
<EOS>
A

?
"

"

<EOS>
"
  
"

,

<EOS>
"

,

"

<EOS>
"
No

!
<EOS>
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Nonsense
,
Netta
,

,
"

<EOS>
"
She

,

.
<EOS>
She

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Laws
,

!
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Always

!
<EOS>
I

n't

.
<EOS>

,

?
<EOS>
I

;
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

!
<EOS>
To

,
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

?
"
  
<EOS>
A

<EOS>
Mrs.

<EOS>

"

,

?
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
La

!
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
La

,

<EOS>
Who

?
<EOS>
He

<EOS>
They

<EOS>
The

all

for

's

,

.
<EOS>
Mr.

.
<EOS>
The

,

,

.
<EOS>
The

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
And

:
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
Mr.

.
<EOS>
The

,

,
a

very

,

.
<EOS>
A

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Finnie
,
the

,
with

,

,
much

.
<EOS>
The

were
all
there
,

old
Scalpen
,

,

's

.
<EOS>
Then

,

,

who

,

,
one

much

when

should

.
  
<EOS>
And
so
the
rooms
became
full
,
and

were
formed
,
and
every

paid
his
respects
to
my
lord
and

,

's

.
<EOS>
The

shook

Stanhope
,
and
Mrs.
Grantly
seated

by
the
doctor
's
wife
.
<EOS>
And
Mrs.
Proudie
moved
about
with

,

to

.
<EOS>
But

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
does

?
"

bishop

.
<EOS>
His

to
behave

_
en

_
.
  
<EOS>
At

.
<EOS>
A

.
<EOS>
The

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Proudie
perked

up
,
feeling
that
some

was
in

.
<EOS>
The
bishop
was
instinctively

that
La
Signora
Vicinironi
was
come

,
and
Mr.
Slope

.
  
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
He

,

.
<EOS>
The
signora
was

,
her
head
being
the
care
of
her
brother
and
an
Italian
manservant
who
was
accustomed
to
the
work
;
her
feet
were
in
the
care
of
the
lady
's
maid
and
the
lady
's
Italian
page
;
and
Charlotte
Stanhope
followed
to
see
that
all
was
done
with
due
grace
and
decorum
.
<EOS>
In
this
manner
they
climbed
easily
into
the
drawing
-
room
,
and
a
broad
way
through
the
crowd
having
been
opened
,
the
signora
rested
safely
on
her
couch
.
<EOS>
She
had
sent
a
servant
beforehand
to
learn
whether
it
was
a
right-
or
a
left
-
hand
sofa
,
for
it
required
that
she
should
dress
accordingly
,
particularly
as
regarded
her
bracelets
.
  
<EOS>
And
very
becoming
her
dress
was
.
<EOS>
It
was
white
velvet
,
without
any
other

than
rich
white
lace
worked
with

across
her

,
and
the
same
round
the
armlets
of
her
dress
.
<EOS>
Across

brow
she
wore
a
band
of
red

,
on
the
centre
of
which
shone
a
magnificent
Cupid
in
mosaic
,
the
tints
of
whose
wings
were
of
the
most
lovely
azure
,
and
the
colour
of
his
chubby

the
clearest
pink
.
<EOS>
On
the
one
arm
which
her
position
required
her
to
expose
<EOS>
she
wore
three
magnificent

,

.
<EOS>
Beneath

on

sofa
,
and

,
which
went

and

.
<EOS>
Dressed

,
with

her
white

,

head
,

,

.
  
<EOS>
Neither

.
  
<EOS>
Her

too

worthy

.
<EOS>
The
three

were
Italian
,

in

.
<EOS>
The

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
The

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
His

.
  
<EOS>
The

<EOS>

So

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

loud
,
indeed
,
but
yet

.
<EOS>
And

will

.
  
<EOS>
"
Madam
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
 
and
it
is
beyond

prose
to
tell
of
the

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

means
so
good
as
his
wine
,
my
lord
,
"
said
a
witty
minor
canon
.
  
<EOS>
"
Nor
so
generally
used
,
"
said
another
;
"
<EOS>
that
is
,
for
inward
application
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ha
,
ha
,
ha
!
"
laughed
the
bishop
,
"
a
good
cellar
of
wine
is
a
very
comfortable
thing
in
a
house
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Your
German
professors
,
Sir
,
prefer
beer
,
I
believe
,
"
said
the
sarcastic
little
meagre
prebendary
.
  
<EOS>
"
They
do
n't
think
much
of
either
,
"
said
Ethelbert
,
"
and
that
perhaps
accounts
for
their

.
<EOS>
Now
the
Jewish
professor
 
"
  
The
insult
was
becoming
too
deep
for
the
spirit
of
Oxford
to
endure
,
so
the
archdeacon
walked
off
one
way
and
the
chancellor
another
,
followed
by
their
disciples
,
and
the
bishop
and
the
young

were
left
together
on
the
hearth
-
rug
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
was
a
Jew
once
myself
,
"
began

.
  
<EOS>
The
bishop
was
determined
not
to
stand
another
examination
,
or
be
led
on
any
terms
into
Palestine
,
so
he
again
remembered
that
he
had
to
do
something
very

,
and
left
young
Stanhope
with

.
<EOS>
The

did
not

it
for
Ethelbert
<EOS>
gave

a
true

his

in

Land
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Mr.
Harding
,
"
said

,

_
ci
-
devant
_

;
"
I
wanted
to

one

about

hospital
.
<EOS>
You

,

,
that

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
's

beat
a

,
and
he
said
that
he
had
heard

.
  
<EOS>
"
Of

,
"
continued

;
"
there

.
<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>
"
  
"
They

,
my

,
"

;
"
to

,

of
it

.
"
  
<EOS>
The
bishop
professed

delighted
to
hear

;
Mr.
Harding
might
be
quite
sure
that
no
other
man
would
get

.
<EOS>
There
were
some
few
circumstances
which
would
in

change
the

of
the

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
was
probably
aware
of
this
,
and
would
,
perhaps
,
not

to
discuss
the
matter
with
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
subject
to
which
Mr.
Slope
had
given
a

deal

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
felt
,
he
knew

why
,
oppressed
and

.
<EOS>
What
could
Mr.
Slope
do
to
him
?
<EOS>
He
knew
that
there

to
be
changes
.
<EOS>
The

must

communicated
to
the
warden
through

,
and
through

so

as
the
bishop
's

?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Twas
thus
he
tried

argue

back

,
but

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
in
the
meantime
had
taken
the
seat
which
the
bishop
had
vacated
on
the
signora
's
sofa
,
and
remained
with
that
lady
till
it
was
time
to
marshal

folk
to
supper
.
<EOS>
Not
with
contented
eyes
had
Mrs.
Proudie
seen
this
.
<EOS>
Had
not
this
woman
laughed
at
her

,
and
had
not
Mr.
Slope
heard
it
?
<EOS>
Was
she
not
an
intriguing
Italian
woman
,
half
wife
and
half

,
full
of

,
airs
,
and

?
<EOS>
Was

not
horribly
bedizened
with
velvet
and

,
with
velvet
and
pearls
,
too
,
which
had
not
been

off
her
back
?
<EOS>
Above
all
,
did
she
not
pretend
to
be
more

?
<EOS>
To

Mrs.
Proudie
was

would
give
a

her

.
<EOS>
She
had
not
the
slightest
desire
that
Mr.
Slope
should

.
<EOS>
But
she
desired
the

of
Mr.
Slope
's

,
and
did
not

Signora
Neroni
.
<EOS>
She

that
Mr.

ought

to
hate
the
signora
,
and
it
appeared
from
his

that
he
was

.
  
<EOS>
"
Come
,
Mr.
Slope
,
"
she

,
