and

all
that

,
"
ca

?
<EOS>
Do

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.

heard

.
<EOS>
The

hardly
out
of
Mrs.
Proudie
's

before

intended

had
stuck
her

's

saved

.
<EOS>
What

?
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
heard

,
but
was
by

means
<EOS>
so
obedient
as
was
expected
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
the

of
Mr.
Slope
's

to

was

.
<EOS>
He
did
not

,

,

.
<EOS>
But

,
and
as

it

.
  
<EOS>
Before

the

he
arranged

and

to
know
what
he
should

.
<EOS>
She
was
quite
indifferent
,
she
said
 
nothing
 
anything
.
<EOS>
It
was
now
she
felt
the
misery
of
her
position
,
now
that
she
must

left
alone
.
<EOS>
Well
,
a
little
chicken
,
some

,
and
a

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
had
to
explain
,
not

for
his

,
that
there
was
no
champagne
.
  
<EOS>
Sherry
would
do
just

.
<EOS>
And
then
Mr.
Slope
descended
with
the
learned
Miss
Trefoil
on

.
<EOS>
Could
she
tell

,
he

,

?
<EOS>
His

was
for
ferns
 
<EOS>
and
before

him
<EOS>
he

.
<EOS>
It

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
You

,

,
"

,
with

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.

that

in

.
  
<EOS>
"
Pray
,
Mr.
Slope
,

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
It

.
<EOS>
Pray

,

<EOS>
;

"
  
<EOS>
Ethelbert

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

;
"
I

.
"
  
<EOS>
The

,

that

,

off

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Such

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
I

;
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
When

room

,

,

.
<EOS>
The

was

to

,

.
<EOS>
They

,

,

in

.
  
<EOS>
"
And
when

,

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.

.
<EOS>
She

,

.
"
<EOS>
And

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
muttered
something
in

,

.
<EOS>
As

the
bishop
's
wanting
him
,
he

to

;

.
  
<EOS>
"
Is

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes

,
"

,

;
"
<EOS>
always

same
 
always

;
"
and

,

.
  
<EOS>
The
signora
could
n't

,
or

.
<EOS>
But

,

.
<EOS>
Had

as

as
Grimaldi
<EOS>
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.

,
"

,

the
door
<EOS>
,
"
I
am

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

's

,

,

.
<EOS>
Somebody

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Lame
,
"

;
"
I
'd

if

.
<EOS>
What

had

here

all
?
 
<EOS>
such

such

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
In

hall
and

rooms
all
manner
of

and

was
going
on
,
and
the
Barchester
folk
were

.
<EOS>
Mrs.

did

best

,
but

.
<EOS>
Her

had
been
tried
fearfully
.
<EOS>
By

.
  
<EOS>
"
Send

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
The

were
left
to
the

last
,
and
an
uncomfortable
party
they
made
with

's

.
<EOS>
They

went
into

,

bishop

that
"
the
lady
"
was
alone

,

.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Proudie
kept
Mr.
Slope
and
her
daughters
in
close

,
resolving
that
he
should
not

indulged
,
nor
they

.
<EOS>
The
bishop
,
in
mortal
dread
of
Bertie
and
the
Jews
,
tried
to
converse
with
Charlotte
Stanhope
about
the
climate
of
Italy
.
<EOS>
Bertie
and
the
signora
had
no
resource
but
in
each
other
.
  
<EOS>
"
Did
you
get
your
supper
at
last
,
Madeline
?
"
said
the
impudent
or
else
mischievous
young
man
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
yes
,
"
said

;
"
Mr.
Slope
was
so
very
kind
as
to
bring

me
.
<EOS>
I
fear
,

,
he
put

to

than
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Proudie
looked
at
her
but
said
nothing
.
<EOS>
The
meaning
of
her
look
might
have
been
thus
translated
;
"
If
ever
you
find
yourself
within
these

again
,
I
'll

leave
to
be
as

and

.
"
  
<EOS>
At
last
the
carriage
returned
with
the
three
Italian
servants
,
and
La
Signora
Madeline
Vesey
Neroni
was
carried
out
,
as
she
had
been
carried
in
.
  
<EOS>
The
lady
of
the
palace
retired
to
her
chamber
by
no
means
contented
with
the
result
of
her
first
grand
party
at
Barchester
.
   
<EOS>
Slope
versus
Harding
 
<EOS>
Two
or
three
days
after
the
party
,
Mr.
Harding
received
a
note
begging
him
to
call
on
Mr.
Slope
,
at
the
palace
,
at
an
early
hour
on
the
following
morning
.
<EOS>
There
was
nothing
uncivil
in
the
communication
,
and
yet
the
tone
of
it
was
thoroughly
displeasing
.
<EOS>
It
was
as
follows
:
  
MY
DEAR
MR
.
<EOS>
HARDING
,
  
<EOS>
Will
you
favour
me
by
calling
on
me
at
the
palace
to
-
morrow
morning
at
9:30
A.M.
<EOS>
The
bishop
wishes
me
to
speak
to
you
touching
the
hospital
.
<EOS>
I
hope
you
will
excuse
my
naming
so
early
an
hour
.
<EOS>
I
do
so
as
my
time
is
greatly
occupied
.
<EOS>
If
,
however
,
it
is
positively
inconvenient
to
you
,
I
will
change
it
to
10
.
<EOS>
You
will
,
perhaps
,
be
kind
enough
to
let
me
have
a
note
in
reply
.
  
<EOS>
Believe
me
to
be
,
<EOS>
My
dear
Mr.
Harding
,
Your
assured
friend
,
OBH
.
<EOS>
SLOPE
  
<EOS>
The
Palace
,
Monday
morning
,
20th
August
,
185
    
Mr.
Harding
neither
could
nor
would
believe
anything
of
the
sort
,
and
he
thought
,
moreover
,
that
Mr.
Slope
was
rather
impertinent
to
call
himself
by
such
a
name
.
<EOS>
His
assured
friend
,
indeed
!
<EOS>
How
many
assured
friends
generally
fall
to
the
lot
of
a
man
in
this
world
?
<EOS>
And
by
what
process
are
they
made
?
<EOS>
And
how
much
of
such
process
had
taken
place
as
yet
between
Mr.
Harding
and
Mr.
Slope
?
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
could
not
help
asking
himself
these
questions
as
he
read
and
re
-
read
the
note
before
him
.
<EOS>
He
answered
it
,
however
,
as
follows
:
  
<EOS>
DEAR
SIR
,
  
I
will
call
at
the
palace
to
-
morrow
at
9:30
A.M.
as
you
desire
.
  
<EOS>
Truly
yours
,
  
S.
HARDING
  
High
Street
,
Barchester
,
Monday
  
<EOS>
And
on
the
following
morning
,
punctually
at
half
-
past
nine
,
he
knocked
at
the
palace
door
and
asked
for
Mr.
Slope
.
  
<EOS>
The
bishop
had
one
small
room
allotted
to
him
on
the
ground
-
floor
,
and
Mr.
Slope
had
another
.
<EOS>
Into
this
latter
Mr.
Harding
was
shown
and
asked
to
sit
down
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
was
not
yet
there
.
<EOS>
The
ex
-
warden
stood
up
at
the
window
looking
into
the
garden
,
and
could
not
help
thinking
how
very
short
a
time
had
passed
since
the
whole
of
that
house
had
been
open
to
him
,
as
though
he
had
been
a
child
of
the
family
,
born
and
bred
in
it
.
<EOS>
He
remembered
how
the
old
servants
used
to
smile
as
they
opened
the
door
to
him
;
how
the
familiar
butler
would
say
,
when
he
had
been
absent
a
few
hours
longer
than
usual
,
"
A
sight
of
you
,
Mr.
Harding
,
is
good
for
sore
eyes
;
"
how
the
fussy
housekeeper
would
swear
that
he
could
n't
have
dined
,
or
could
n't
have
breakfasted
,
or
could
n't
have
lunched
.
<EOS>
And
then
,
above
all
,
he
remembered
the
pleasant
gleam
of
inward
satisfaction
which
always
spread
itself
over
the
old
bishop
's
face
whenever
his
friend
entered
his
room
.
  
<EOS>
A
tear
came
into
each
eye
as
he
reflected
that
all
this
was
gone
.
<EOS>
What
use
would
the
hospital
be
to
him
now
?
<EOS>
He
was
alone
in
the
world
,
and
getting
old
;
he
would
soon
,
very
soon
have
to
go
and
leave
it
all
,
as
his
dear
old
friend
had
gone
;
go
,
and
leave
the
hospital
,
and
his
accustomed
place
in
the
cathedral
,
and
his
haunts
and
pleasures
,
to
younger
and
perhaps
wiser
men
.
<EOS>
That
chanting
of
his
!
<EOS>
Perhaps
,
in
truth
,
the
time
for
it
was
gone
by
.
<EOS>
He
felt
as
though
the
world
were
sinking
from
his
feet
;
as
though
this
,
this
was
the
time
for
him
to
turn
with
confidence
to
those
hopes
which
he
had
preached
with
confidence
to
others
.
<EOS>
"
What
,
"
said
he
to
himself
,
"
can
a
man
's
religion
be
worth
if
it
does
not
support
him
against
the
natural
melancholy
of
declining
years
?
"
<EOS>
And
as
he
looked
out
through
his
dimmed
eyes
into
the
bright
parterres
of
the
bishop
's
garden
,
he
felt
that
he
had
the
support
which
he
wanted
.
  
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,
he
did
not
like
to
be
thus
kept
waiting
.
<EOS>
If
Mr.
Slope
did
not
really
wish
to
see
him
at
half
-
past
nine
o'clock
,
why
force
him
to
come
away
from
his
lodgings
with
his
breakfast
in
his
throat
?
<EOS>
To
tell
the
truth
,
it
was
policy
on
the
part
of
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
had
made
up
his
mind
that
Mr.
Harding
should
either
accept
the
hospital
with
abject
submission
,
or
else
refuse
it
altogether
,
and
had
calculated
that
he
would
probably
be
more
quick
to
do
the
latter
,
if
he
could
be
got
to
enter
upon
the
subject
in
an
ill
-
humour
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
Mr.
Slope
was
not
altogether
wrong
in
his
calculation
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
nearly
ten
when
Mr.
Slope
hurried
into
the
room
and
,
muttering
something
about
the
bishop
and
diocesan
duties
,
shook
Mr.
Harding
's
hand
ruthlessly
and
begged
him
to
be
seated
.
  
<EOS>
Now
the
air
of
superiority
which
this
man
assumed
did
go
against
the
grain
with
Mr.
Harding
,
and
yet
he
did
not
know
how
to
resent
it
.
<EOS>
The
whole
tendency
of
his
mind
and
disposition
was
opposed
to
any
contra
-
assumption
of
grandeur
on
his
own
part
,
and
he
had
n't
the
worldly
spirit
or
quickness
necessary
to
put
down
insolent
pretensions
by
downright
and
open
rebuke
,
as
the
archdeacon
would
have
done
.
<EOS>
There
was
nothing
for
Mr.
Harding
but
to
submit
,
and
he
accordingly
did
so
.
  
<EOS>
"
About
the
hospital
,
Mr.
Harding
?
"
began
Mr.
Slope
,
speaking
of
it
as
the
head
of
a
college
at
Cambridge
might
speak
of
some
sizarship
which
had
to
be
disposed
of
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
crossed
one
leg
over
another
,
and
then
one
hand
over
the
other
on
the
top
of
them
,
and
looked
Mr.
Slope
in
the
face
;
but
he
said
nothing
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
to
be
filled
up
again
,
"
said
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
said
that
he
had
understood
so
.
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
,
you
know
,
the
income
will
be
very
much
reduced
,
"
continued
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
"
The
bishop
wished
to
be
liberal
,
and
he
therefore
told
the
government
that
he
thought
it
ought
to
be
put
at
not
less
than
£
450
.
<EOS>
I
think
on
the
whole
the
bishop
was
right
,
for
though
the
services
required
will
not
be
of
a
very
onerous
nature
,
they
will
be
more
so
than
they
were
before
.
<EOS>
And
it
is
,
perhaps
,
well
that
the
clergy
immediately
attached
to
the
cathedral
town
should
be
made
as
comfortable
as
the
extent
of
the
ecclesiastical
means
at
our
disposal
will
allow
.
<EOS>
Those
are
the
bishop
's
ideas
,
and
I
must
say
mine
also
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
sat
rubbing
one
hand
on
the
other
,
but
said
not
a
word
.
  
<EOS>
"
So
much
for
the
income
,
Mr.
Harding
.
<EOS>
The
house
will
,
of
course
,
remain
to
the
warden
,
as
before
.
<EOS>
It
should
,
however
,
I
think
,
be
stipulated
that
he
should
paint
inside
every
seven
years
,
and
outside
every
three
years
,
and
be
subject
to
dilapidations
,
in
the
event
of
vacating
,
either
by
death
or
otherwise
.
<EOS>
But
this
is
a
matter
on
which
the
bishop
must
yet
be
consulted
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
still
rubbed
his
hands
and
still
sat
silent
,
gazing
up
into
Mr.
Slope
's
unprepossessing
face
.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
,
as
to
the
duties
,
"
continued
he
,
"
I
believe
,
if
I
am
rightly
informed
,
there
can
hardly
be
said
to
have
been
any
duties
hitherto
,
"
and
he
gave
a
sort
of
half
-
laugh
,
as
though
to
pass
off
the
accusation
in
the
guise
of
a
pleasantry
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
thought
of
the
happy
,
easy
years
he
had
passed
in
his
old
home
;
of
the
worn
-
out
,
aged
men
whom
he
had
succoured
;
of
his
good
intentions
;
and
of
his
work
,
which
had
certainly
been
of
the
lightest
.
<EOS>
He
thought
of
these
things
,
doubting
for
a
moment
whether
he
did
or
did
not
deserve
the
sarcasm
.
<EOS>
He
gave
his
enemy
the
benefit
of
the
doubt
,
and
did
not
rebuke
him
.
<EOS>
He
merely
observed
,
very
tranquilly
,
and
perhaps
with
too
much
humility
,
that
the
duties
of
the
situation
,
such
as
they
were
,
had
,
he
believed
,
been
done
to
the
satisfaction
of
the
late
bishop
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
again
smiled
,
and
this
time
the
smile
was
intended
to
operate
against
the
memory
of
the
late
bishop
rather
than
against
the
energy
of
the
ex
-
warden
;
so
it
was
understood
by
Mr.
Harding
.
<EOS>
The
colour
rose
to
his
cheeks
,
and
he
began
to
feel
very
angry
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
must
be
aware
,
Mr.
Harding
,
that
things
are
a
good
deal
changed
in
Barchester
,
"
said
Mr.
Slope
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
said
that
he
was
aware
of
it
.
"
<EOS>
And
not
only
in
Barchester
,
Mr.
Harding
,
but
in
the
world
at
large
.
<EOS>
It
is
not
only
in
Barchester
that
a
new
man
is
carrying
out
new
measures
and
casting
away
the
useless
rubbish
of
past
centuries
.
<EOS>
The
same
thing
is
going
on
throughout
the
country
.
<EOS>
Work
is
now
required
from
every
man
who
receives
wages
,
and
they
who
have
to
superintend
the
doing
of
work
,
and
the
paying
of
wages
,
are
bound
to
see
that
this
rule
is
carried
out
.
<EOS>
New
men
,
Mr.
Harding
,
are
now
needed
and
are
now
forthcoming
in
the
church
,
as
well
as
in
other
professions
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
All
this
was
wormwood
to
our
old
friend
.
<EOS>
He
had
never
rated
very
high
his
own
abilities
or
activity
,
but
all
the
feelings
of
his
heart
were
with
the
old
clergy
,
and
any
antipathies
of
which
his
heart
was
susceptible
were
directed
against
those
new
,
busy
,
uncharitable
,
self
-
lauding
men
,
of
whom
Mr.
Slope
was
so
good
an
example
.
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
,
"
said
he
,
"
the
bishop
will
prefer
a
new
man
at
the
hospital
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
By
no
means
,
"
said
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
"
The
bishop
is
very
anxious
that
you
should
accept
the
appointment
,
but
he
wishes
you
should
understand
beforehand
what
will
be
the
required
duties
.
<EOS>
In
the
first
place
,
a
Sabbath
-
day
school
will
be
attached
to
the
hospital
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
!
<EOS>
For
the
old
men
?
"
asked
Mr.
Harding
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
Mr.
Harding
,
not
for
the
old
men
,
but
for
the
benefit
of
the
children
of
such
of
the
poor
of
Barchester
as
it
may
suit
.
<EOS>
The
bishop
will
expect
that
you
shall
attend
this
school
,
and
that
the
teachers
shall
be
under
your
inspection
and
care
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
slipped
his
topmost
hand
off
the
other
and
began
to
rub
the
calf
of
the
leg
which
was
supported
.
  
<EOS>
"
As
to
the
old
men
,
"
continued
Mr.
Slope
,
"
and
the
old
women
who
are
to
form
a
part
of
the
hospital
,
the
bishop
is
desirous
that
you
shall
have
morning
and
evening
service
on
the
premises
every
Sabbath
,
and
one
weekday
service
;
that
you
shall
preach
to
them
once
at
least
on
Sundays
;
and
that
the
whole
hospital
be
always
collected
for
morning
and
evening
prayer
.
<EOS>
The
bishop
thinks
that
this
will
render
it
unnecessary
that
any
separate
seats
in
the
cathedral
should
be
reserved
for
the
hospital
inmates
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
paused
,
but
Mr.
Harding
still
said
nothing
.
  
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,
it
would
be
difficult
to
find
seats
for
the
women
;
on
the
whole
,
Mr.
Harding
,
I
may
as
well
say
at
once
,
that
for
people
of
that
class
the
cathedral
service
does
not
appear
to
me
the
most
useful
 
even
if
it
be
so
for
any
class
of
people
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
will
not
discuss
that
,
if
you
please
,
"
said
Mr.
Harding
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
desirous
of
doing
so
;
at
least
,
not
at
the
present
moment
.
<EOS>
I
hope
,
however
,
you
fully
understand
the
bishop
's
wishes
about
the
new
establishment
of
the
hospital
;
and
if
,
as
I
do
not
doubt
,
I
shall
receive
from
you
an
assurance
that
you
accord
with
his
lordship
's
views
,
it
will
give
me
very
great
pleasure
to
be
the
bearer
from
his
lordship
to
you
of
the
presentation
to
the
appointment
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
if
I
disagree
with
his
lordship
's
views
?
"
asked
Mr.
Harding
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
hope
you
do
not
,
"
said
Mr.
Slope
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
if
I
do
?
"
again
asked
the
other
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
such
unfortunately
should
be
the
case
,
which
I
can
hardly
conceive
,
I
presume
your
own
feelings
will
dictate
to
you
the
propriety
of
declining
the
appointment
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
if
I
accept
the
appointment
and
yet
disagree
with
the
bishop
,
what
then
?
"
  
<EOS>
This
question
rather
bothered
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
It
was
true
that
he
had
talked
the
matter
over
with
the
bishop
and
had
received
a
sort
of
authority
for
suggesting
to
Mr.
Harding
the
propriety
of
a
Sunday
school
and
certain
hospital
services
,
but
he
had
no
authority
for
saying
that
these
propositions
were
to
be
made
peremptory
conditions
attached
to
the
appointment
.
<EOS>
The
bishop
's
idea
had
been
that
Mr.
Harding
would
of
course
consent
and
that
the
school
would
become
,
like
the
rest
of
those
new
establishments
in
the
city
,
under
the
control
of
his
wife
and
his
chaplain
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
's
idea
had
been
more
correct
.
<EOS>
He
intended
that
Mr.
Harding
should
refuse
the
situation
,
and
that
an
ally
of
his
own
should
get
it
,
but
he
had
not
conceived
the
possibility
of
Mr.
Harding
openly
accepting
the
appointment
and
as
openly
rejecting
the
conditions
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
,
I
presume
,
probable
,
"
said
he
,
"
that
you
will
accept
from
the
hands
of
the
bishop
a
piece
of
preferment
with
a
fixed
predetermination
to
disacknowledge
the
duties
attached
to
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
become
warden
,
"
said
Mr.
Harding
,
"
and
neglect
my
duty
,
the
bishop
has
means
by
which
he
can
remedy
the
grievance
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hardly
expected
such
an
argument
from
you
,
or
I
may
say
the
suggestion
of
such
a
line
of
conduct
,
"
said
Mr.
Slope
with
a
great
look
of
injured
virtue
.
  
<EOS>
"
Nor
did
I
expect
such
a
proposition
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
glad
at
any
rate
to
know
what
answer
I
am
to
make
to
his
lordship
,
"
said
Mr.
Slope
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
take
an
early
opportunity
of
seeing
his
lordship
myself
,
"
said
Mr.
Harding
.
  
<EOS>
"
Such
an
arrangement
,
"
said
Mr.
Slope
,
"
will
hardly
give
his
lordship
satisfaction
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
it
is
impossible
that
the
bishop
should
himself
see
every
clergyman
in
the
diocese
on
every
subject
of
patronage
that
may
arise
.
<EOS>
The
bishop
,
I
believe
,
did
see
you
on
the
matter
,
and
I
really
can
not
see
why
he
should
be
troubled
to
do
so
again
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
,
Mr.
Slope
,
how
long
I
have
been
officiating
as
a
clergyman
in
this
city
?
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
's
wish
was
now
nearly
fulfilled
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
had
become
angry
,
and
it
was
probable
that
he
might
commit
himself
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
really
do
not
see
what
that
has
to
do
with
the
question
.
<EOS>
You
can
not
think
the
bishop
would
be
justified
in
allowing
you
to
regard
as
a
sinecure
a
situation
that
requires
an
active
,
man
merely
because
you
have
been
employed
for
many
years
in
the
cathedral
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
it
might
induce
the
bishop
to
see
me
,
if
I
asked
him
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
I
shall
consult
my
friends
in
this
matter
,
Mr.
Slope
;
but
I
mean
to
be
guilty
of
no
subterfuge
 
<EOS>
you
may
tell
the
bishop
that
as
I
altogether
disagree
with
his
views
about
the
hospital
,
I
shall
decline
the
situation
if
I
find
that
any
such
conditions
are
attached
to
it
as
those
you
have
suggested
;
"
and
so
saying
,
Mr.
Harding
took
his
hat
and
went
his
way
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
was
contented
.
<EOS>
He
considered
himself
at
liberty
to
accept
Mr.
Harding
's
last
speech
as
an
absolute
refusal
of
the
appointment
.
<EOS>
At
least
,
he
so
represented
it
to
the
bishop
and
to
Mrs.
Proudie
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
very
surprising
,
"
said
the
bishop
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
at
all
,
"
said
Mrs.
Proudie
;
"
you
little
know
how
determined
the
whole
set
of
them
are
to
withstand
your
authority
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
But
Mr.
Harding
was
so
anxious
for
it
,
"
said
the
bishop
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
Mr.
Slope
,
"
if
he
can
hold
it
without
the
slightest
acknowledgement
of
your
lordship
's
jurisdiction
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
out
of
the
question
,
"
said
the
bishop
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
imagine
it
to
be
quite
so
,
"
said
the
chaplain
.
  
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,
I
should
think
so
,
"
said
the
lady
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
really
am
sorry
for
it
,
"
said
the
bishop
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
that
there
is
much
cause
for
sorrow
,
"
said
the
lady
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Quiverful
is
a
much
more
deserving
man
,
more
in
need
of
it
,
and
one
who
will
make
himself
much
more
useful
in
the
close
neighbourhood
of
the
palace
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
I
had
better
see
Quiverful
?
"
said
the
chaplain
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
you
had
,
"
said
the
bishop
.
   
<EOS>
The
Rubbish
Cart
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
was
not
a
happy
man
as
he
walked
down
the
palace
pathway
and
stepped
out
into
the
close
.
<EOS>
His
preferment
and
pleasant
house
were
a
second
time
gone
from
him
,
but
that
he
could
endure
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
schooled
and
insulted
by
a
man
young
enough
to
be
his
son
,
but
that
he
could
put
up
with
.
<EOS>
He
could
even
draw
from
the
very
injuries
which
had
been
inflicted
on
him
some
of
that
consolation
which
we
may
believe
martyrs
always
receive
from
the
injustice
of
their
own
sufferings
,
and
which
is
generally
proportioned
in
its
strength
to
the
extent
of
cruelty
with
which
martyrs
are
treated
.
<EOS>
He
had
admitted
to
his
daughter
that
he
wanted
the
comfort
of
his
old
home
,
and
yet
he
could
have
returned
to
his
lodgings
in
the
High
Street
,
if
not
with
exaltation
,
at
least
with
satisfaction
,
had
that
been
all
.
<EOS>
But
the
venom
of
the
chaplain
's
harangue
had
worked
into
his
blood
,
and
sapped
the
life
of
his
sweet
contentment
.
  
<EOS>
"
New
men
are
carrying
out
new
measures
and
are
carting
away
the
useless
rubbish
of
past
centuries
!
"
<EOS>
What
cruel
words
these
had
been
;
and
how
often
are
they
now
used
with
all
the
heartless
cruelty
of
a
Slope
!
<EOS>
A
man
is
sufficiently
condemned
if
it
can
only
be
shown
that
either
in
politics
or
religion
he
does
not
belong
to
some
new
school
established
within
the
last
score
of
years
.
<EOS>
He
may
then
regard
himself
as
rubbish
and
expect
to
be
carted
away
.
<EOS>
A
man
is
nothing
now
unless
he
has
within
him
a
full
appreciation
of
the
new
era
,
an
era
in
which
it
would
seem
that
neither
honesty
nor
truth
is
very
desirable
,
but
in
which
success
is
the
only
touchstone
of
merit
.
<EOS>
We
must
laugh
at
everything
that
is
established
.
<EOS>
Let
the
joke
be
ever
so
bad
,
ever
so
untrue
to
the
real
principles
of
joking
;
nevertheless
we
must
laugh
 
or
else
beware
the
cart
.
<EOS>
We
must
talk
,
think
,
and
live
up
to
the
spirit
of
the
times
,
and
write
up
to
it
too
,
if
that
cacoethes
be
upon
us
,
or
else
we
are
nought
.
<EOS>
New
men
and
new
measures
,
long
credit
and
few
scruples
,
great
success
or
wonderful
ruin
,
such
are
now
the
tastes
of
Englishmen
who
know
how
to
live
.
<EOS>
Alas
,
alas
!
<EOS>
Under
such
circumstances
Mr.
Harding
could
not
but
feel
that
he
was
an
Englishman
who
did
not
know
how
to
live
.
<EOS>
This
new
doctrine
of
Mr.
Slope
and
the
rubbish
cart
,
new
at
least
at
Barchester
,
sadly
disturbed
his
equanimity
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
same
thing
is
going
on
throughout
the
whole
country
!
<EOS>
Work
is
now
required
from
every
man
who
receives
wages
!
"
<EOS>
And
had
he
been
living
all
his
life
receiving
wages
and
doing
no
work
?
<EOS>
Had
he
in
truth
so
lived
as
to
be
now
in
his
old
age
justly
reckoned
as
rubbish
fit
only
to
be
hidden
away
in
some
huge
dust
-
hole
?
<EOS>
The
school
of
men
to
whom
he
professes
to
belong
,
the
Grantlys
,
the
Gwynnes
,
and
the
old
high
set
of
Oxford
divines
,
are
afflicted
with
no
such
self
-
accusations
as
these
which
troubled
Mr.
Harding
.
<EOS>
They
,
as
a
rule
,
are
as
satisfied
with
the
wisdom
and
propriety
of
their
own
conduct
as
can
be
any
Mr.
Slope
,
or
any
Dr.
Proudie
,
with
his
own
.
<EOS>
But
unfortunately
for
himself
Mr.
Harding
had
little
of
this
self
-
reliance
.
<EOS>
When
he
heard
himself
designated
as
rubbish
by
the
Slopes
of
the
world
,
he
had
no
other
resource
than
to
make
inquiry
within
his
own
bosom
as
to
the
truth
of
the
designation
.
<EOS>
Alas
,
alas
!
<EOS>
The
evidence
seemed
generally
to
go
against
him
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
professed
to
himself
in
the
bishop
's
parlour
that
in
these
coming
sources
of
the
sorrow
of
age
,
in
these
fits
of
sad
regret
from
which
the
latter
years
of
few
reflecting
men
can
be
free
,
religion
would
suffice
to
comfort
him
.
<EOS>
Yes
,
religion
could
console
him
for
the
loss
of
any
worldly
good
,
but
was
his
religion
of
that
active
sort
which
would
enable
him
so
to
repent
of
misspent
years
as
to
pass
those
that
were
left
to
him
in
a
spirit
of
hope
for
the
future
?
<EOS>
And
such
repentance
itself
,
is
it
not
a
work
of
agony
and
of
tears
?
<EOS>
It
is
very
easy
to
talk
of
repentance
,
but
a
man
has
to
walk
over
hot
ploughshares
before
he
can
complete
it
;
to
be
skinned
alive
as
was
St.
Bartholomew
;
to
be
stuck
full
of
arrows
as
was
St.
Sebastian
;
to
lie
broiling
on
a
gridiron
like
St.
Lorenzo
!
<EOS>
How
if
his
past
life
required
such
repentance
as
this
?
<EOS>
Had
he
the
energy
to
go
through
with
it
?
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
,
after
leaving
the
palace
,
walked
slowly
for
an
hour
or
so
beneath
the
shady
elms
of
the
close
and
then
betook
himself
to
his
daughter
's
house
.
<EOS>
He
had
at
any
rate
made
up
his
mind
that
he
would
go
out
to
Plumstead
to
consult
Dr.
Grantly
,
and
that
he
would
in
the
first
instance
tell
Eleanor
what
had
occurred
.
  
<EOS>
And
now
he
was
doomed
to
undergo
another
misery
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
had
forestalled
him
at
the
widow
's
house
.
<EOS>
He
had
called
there
on
the
preceding
afternoon
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
,
he
had
said
,
deny
himself
the
pleasure
of
telling
Mrs.
Bold
that
her
father
was
about
to
return
to
the
pretty
house
at
Hiram
's
Hospital
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
instructed
by
the
bishop
to
inform
Mr.
Harding
that
the
appointment
would
now
be
made
at
once
.
<EOS>
The
bishop
was
of
course
only
too
happy
to
be
able
to
be
the
means
of
restoring
to
Mr.
Harding
the
preferment
which
he
had
so
long
adorned
.
<EOS>
And
then
by
degrees
Mr.
Slope
had
introduced
the
subject
of
the
pretty
school
which
he
hoped
before
long
to
see
attached
to
the
hospital
.
<EOS>
He
had
quite
fascinated
Mrs.
Bold
by
his
description
of
this
picturesque
,
useful
,
and
charitable
appendage
,
and
she
had
gone
so
far
as
to
say
that
she
had
no
doubt
her
father
would
approve
,
and
that
she
herself
would
gladly
undertake
a
class
.
  
<EOS>
Anyone
who
had
heard
the
entirely
different
tone
and
seen
the
entirely
different
manner
in
which
Mr.
Slope
had
spoken
of
this
projected
institution
to
the
daughter
and
to
the
father
could
not
have
failed
to
own
that
Mr.
Slope
was
a
man
of
genius
.
<EOS>
He
said
nothing
to
Mrs.
Bold
about
the
hospital
sermons
and
services
,
nothing
about
the
exclusion
of
the
old
men
from
the
cathedral
,
nothing
about
dilapidation
and
painting
,
nothing
about
carting
away
the
rubbish
.
<EOS>
Eleanor
had
said
to
herself
that
certainly
she
did
not
like
Mr.
Slope
personally
,
but
that
he
was
a
very
active
,
zealous
clergyman
and
would
no
doubt
be
useful
in
Barchester
.
<EOS>
All
this
paved
the
way
for
much
additional
misery
to
Mr.
Harding
.
  
<EOS>
Eleanor
put
on
her
happiest
face
as
she
heard
her
father
on
the
stairs
,
for
she
thought
she
had
only
to
congratulate
him
;
but
directly
she
saw
his
face
she
knew
that
there
was
but
little
matter
for
congratulation
.
<EOS>
She
had
seen
him
with
the
same
weary
look
of
sorrow
on
one
or
two
occasions
before
,
and
remembered
it
well
.
<EOS>
She
had
seen
him
when
he
first
read
that
attack
upon
himself
in
"
The
Jupiter
"
which
had
ultimately
caused
him
to
resign
the
hospital
,
and
she
had
seen
him
also
when
the
archdeacon
had
persuaded
him
to
remain
there
against
his
own
sense
of
propriety
and
honour
.
<EOS>
She
knew
at
a
glance
that
his
spirit
was
in
deep
trouble
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Papa
,
what
is
it
?
<EOS>
"
said
she
,
putting
down
her
boy
to
crawl
upon
the
floor
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
came
to
tell
you
,
my
dear
,
"
said
he
,
"
that
I
am
going
out
to
Plumstead
<EOS>
:
you
wo
n't
come
with
me
,
I
suppose
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
To
Plumstead
,
Papa
?
<EOS>
Shall
you
stay
there
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
I
shall
,
to
-
night
:
I
must
consult
the
archdeacon
about
this
weary
hospital
.
<EOS>
Ah
me
!
<EOS>
I
wish
I
had
never
thought
of
it
again
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
Papa
,
what
is
the
matter
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
've
been
with
Mr.
Slope
,
my
dear
,
and
he
is
n't
the
pleasantest
companion
in
the
world
,
at
least
not
to
me
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Eleanor
gave
a
sort
of
half
-
blush
,
but
she
was
wrong
if
she
imagined
that
her
father
in
any
way
alluded
to
her
acquaintance
with
Mr.
Slope
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Papa
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
wants
to
turn

hospital
into
a
Sunday

,

I

.
<EOS>
I

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What

,
Papa
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
The

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

Slope

.
<EOS>
But

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Papa
!
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
does

.
<EOS>
He
was

,

what
he
intends
 
"
  
"
He

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

.
"
  
"
And

?
"

<EOS>

;

I

<EOS>

,

.

!
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
Everyone

.

<EOS>
Poor

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

"
  
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

I

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>

-

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So

,

,

Eleanor
in
as

as

.
  
<EOS>
All
this
was
a
great
aggravation
to
his
misery
.
<EOS>
He
had
so
few
with
whom
to
sympathize
that
he
could
not
afford
to
be
cut
off
from
the
one
whose
sympathy
was
of
the
most
value
to
him
.
<EOS>
And
yet
it
seemed
probable
that
this
would
be
the
case
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
own
to
himself
that
he
wished
his
daughter
to
hate
Mr.
Slope
,
yet
had
she
expressed
such
a
feeling
there
would
have
been
very
little
bitterness
in
the
rebuke
he
would

given
her
for
so
uncharitable

state
of

.
<EOS>
The
fact
,
however
,
was
that
she
was
on
friendly
terms
with
Mr.
Slope
,
that
she
coincided
with
his
views
,
adhered
at
once
to
his
plans
,
and
listened
with
delight
to
his

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
hardly
wished
his
daughter
to
hate
the
man
,
but
he
would
have
preferred
that
to
her
loving
him
.
  
<EOS>
He
walked
away
to
the
inn
to
order
a
fly
,
went
home
to
put
up
his
carpet
-
bag
,
and
then
started
for
Plumstead
.
<EOS>
There
was
,
at
any
rate
,
no
danger
that
the
archdeacon
would
fraternize
with
Mr.
Slope
;
but
then
he
would
recommend
internecine
war
,
public

,
loud

,
and
all
the
paraphernalia
of
open
battle
.
<EOS>
Now
that
alternative
was
hardly
more
to
Mr.
Harding
's
taste
than
the
other
.
  
<EOS>
When
Mr.
Harding
reached
the
parsonage
,
he
found
that
the
archdeacon
was
out
,
and
would
not
be
home
till
dinnertime
,
so
he
began
his
complaint
to
his
elder
daughter
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Grantly
entertained
quite
as
strong
an
antagonism
to
Mr.
Slope
as
did
her
husband
;
she
was
also
quite
as
alive
to
the
necessity
of
combating
the
Proudie
faction
,
of
supporting
the
old
church
interest
of
the
close
,
of
keeping
in
her
own
set
such
of
the
loaves
and
fishes
as
duly

to
it
;
and
was
quite
as
well
prepared
as
her
lord
to
carry
on
the
battle
without
giving
or
taking
quarter
.
<EOS>
Not
that
she
was
a
woman
prone
to
quarrelling
,
or
ill
-
inclined
to
live
at
peace
with
her
clerical
neighbours
;
but
she
felt
,
as
did
the
archdeacon
,
that
the
presence
of
Mr.
Slope
in
Barchester
was
an
insult
to
everyone
connected
with
the
late
bishop
,
and
that
his
assumed
dominion
in
the
diocese
was
a
spiritual
injury
to
her
husband
.
<EOS>
Hitherto
people
had
little
guessed
how
bitter
Mrs.
Grantly
could
be
.
<EOS>
She
lived
on
the
best
of
terms
with
all
the
rectors
"
wives
around
her
.
<EOS>
She
had
been
popular
with
all
the
ladies
connected
with
the
close
.
<EOS>
Though
much
the
wealthiest
of
the
ecclesiastical
matrons
of
the
county
,
she
had
so
managed
her
affairs
that
her
carriage
and
horses
had
given
umbrage
to
none
.
<EOS>
She
had
never
thrown
herself
among
the
county
grandees
so
as
to
excite
the
envy
of
other
clergymen
's
wives
.
<EOS>
She
never
talked
too
loudly
of
earls
and
countesses
,
or
boasted
that
she
gave
her
governess
sixty
pounds
a
year
,
or
her
cook
seventy
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Grantly
had
lived
the
life
of
a
wise
,
discreet
,
peace
-
making
woman
,
and
the
people
of
Barchester
were
surprised
at
the
amount
of
military

she
displayed
as

of
the
feminine
Grantlyite

.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Grantly
soon
learned
that
her
sister
Eleanor
had
promised
to

Mr.
Slope
in
the

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
How
can

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
He
is

,
"

,
"
and
his
craft
has

Eleanor

that

.
<EOS>
God

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

"

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
I
only

he
wo

.

"
  
"

?
<EOS>
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
What
is

so
improbable

?
<EOS>
Of

would
be
his
own

if

.
<EOS>
Eleanor
has

entirely
at

,

Mr.
Slope
's

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

ca

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

?
"

.
<EOS>
"
Why

?
<EOS>
He

,

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Look

!
"
said

;
"
do

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
Papa
,
how

!
<EOS>
Of

<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

Slope
?
<EOS>
Why
,

Bold

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Eighteen
months
,
"

.
<EOS>
"
But
I
do
n't

Eleanor
has

.
<EOS>
It
is
very

,

,
that
he

;
and
that

will

;
and
that
he
will
succeed
too
,
if
we
do
n't
take
care
what
we
are
about
.
"
  
<EOS>
This
was
quite
a
new
phase
of
the
affair
to
poor
Mr.
Harding
.
<EOS>
To
have
thrust
upon
him
as
his
son
-
in
-
law
,
as
the
husband
of
his
favourite
child
,
the
only
man
in
the
world
whom
he
really
positively
disliked
,
would
be
a
misfortune
which
he
felt
he
would
not
know
how
to
endure
patiently
.
<EOS>
But
then
,
could
there
be
any
ground
for
so
dreadful
a
surmise
?
<EOS>
In
all
worldly
matters
he
was
apt
to
look
upon
the
opinion
of
his
eldest
daughter
as
one
generally
sound
and
trustworthy
.
<EOS>
In
her
appreciation
of
character
,
of
motives
,
and
the
probable
conduct
both
of
men
and
women
,
she
was
usually
not
far
wrong
.
<EOS>
She
had
early
foreseen
the
marriage
of
Eleanor
and
John
Bold
;
she
had
at
a
glance
deciphered
the
character
of
the
new
bishop
and
his
chaplain
;
could
it
possibly
be
that
her
present
surmise
should
ever
come
forth
as
true
?
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
do
n't
think
that
she
likes
him
?
"
said
Mr.
Harding
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Papa
,
I
ca
n't
say
that
I
think
she
dislikes
him
as
she
ought
to
do
.
<EOS>
Why
is
he
visiting
there
as
a
confidential
friend
,
when
he
never
ought
to
have
been
admitted
inside
the
house
?
<EOS>
Why
is
it
that
she
speaks
to
him
about
your
welfare
and
your
position
,
as
she
clearly
has
done
?
<EOS>
At
the
bishop
's
party
the
other
night
I
saw
her
talking
to
him
for
half
an
hour
at
the
stretch
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
thought
Mr.
Slope
seemed
to
talk
to
nobody
there
but
that
daughter
of
Stanhope
's
,
"
said
Mr.
Harding
,
wishing
to
defend
his
child
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Mr.
Slope
is
a
cleverer
man
than
you
think
of
,
Papa
,
and
keeps
more
than
one
iron
in
the
fire
.
"
  
<EOS>
To
give
Eleanor
her
due
,
any
suspicion
as
to
the
slightest
inclination
on
her
part
towards
Mr.
Slope
was
a
wrong
to
her
.
<EOS>
She
had
no
more
idea
of
marrying
Mr.
Slope
than
she
had
of
marrying
the
bishop
,
and
the
idea
that
Mr.
Slope
would
present
himself
as
a
suitor
had
never
occurred
to
her
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
to
give
her
her
due
again
,
she
had
never
thought
about
suitors
since
her
husband
's
death
.
<EOS>
But
nevertheless
it
was
true
that
she
had
overcome
all
that
repugnance
to
the
man
which
was
so
strongly
felt
for
him
by
the
rest
of
the
Grantly
faction
.
<EOS>
She
had
forgiven
him
his
sermon
.
<EOS>
She
had
forgiven
him
his
Low
Church
tendencies
,
his
Sabbath
-
schools
,
and
puritanical
observances
.
<EOS>
She
had
forgiven
his
pharisaical
arrogance
,
and
even
his
greasy
face
and
oily
,
vulgar
manners
.
<EOS>
Having
agreed
to
overlook
such
offences
as
these
,
why
should
she
not
in
time
be
taught
to
regard
Mr.
Slope
as
a
suitor
?
  
<EOS>
And
as
to
him
,
it
must
also
be
affirmed
that
he
was
hitherto
equally
innocent
of
the
crime
imputed
to
him
.
<EOS>
How
it
had
come
to
pass
that
a
man
whose
eyes
were
generally
so
widely
open
to
everything
around
him
had
not
perceived
that
this
young
widow
was
rich
as
well
as
beautiful
,
can
not
probably
now
be
explained
.
<EOS>
But
such
was
the
fact
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
had
ingratiated
himself
with
Mrs.
Bold
,
merely
as
he
had
done
with
other
ladies
,
in
order
to
strengthen
his
party
in
the
city
.
<EOS>
He
subsequently
amended
his
error
,
but
it
was
not
till
after
the
interview
between
him
and
Mr.
Harding
.
   
<EOS>
The
New
Champion
 
<EOS>
The
archdeacon
did
not
return
to
the
parsonage
till
close
upon
the
hour
of
dinner
,
and
there
was
therefore
no
time
to
discuss
matters
before
that
important
ceremony
.
<EOS>
He
seemed
to
be
in
an
especial
good
humour
,
and
welcomed
his
father
-
in
-
law
with
a
sort
of
jovial

that
was
usual
with
him
when
things
on
which
he
was
intent
were
going
on
as
he
would
have
them
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
all
settled
,
my

,
"

to

wife

in

dressing

,
while
she
,
according
to
her
wo

,
sat

;
"
Arabin
has
agreed
to
accept

living
.
<EOS>
He
'll
be
here
next
week
.
"
<EOS>
And
the

his

and

with
a

,
which
showed
that
Arabin
's
coming
was
a
great
point
gained
.
  
<EOS>
"
Will
he
come
here
to

?
"

wife
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
has

,
"

,
"
so

.
<EOS>
You
'll

.
<EOS>
He
's

,
and
full

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
's

,

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
 
he

,

you
wo

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
I
really
do
n't

what

Arabin
.
<EOS>
It
's

to

so
near

,
and
if
anything
can
put
Slope
down
,
Arabin
will
do

.
"
  
<EOS>
The
Reverend
Francis
Arabin
was
a
fellow
of
Lazarus
,
the
favoured
disciple
of
the
great
Dr.
Gwynne
,
a
High
Churchman
at
all
points
 
so
high
,
indeed
,
that
at
one
period
of
his
career
he
had
all
but
toppled
over
into
the
cesspool
of
Rome
 
a
poet
and
also
a
polemical
writer
,
a
great
pet
in
the
common
-
rooms
at
Oxford
,
an
eloquent
clergyman
,
a
droll
,
odd
,
humorous
,
energetic
,
conscientious
man
,
and
,
as
the
archdeacon
had
boasted
of
him
,
a
thorough
gentleman
.
<EOS>
As
he
will
hereafter
be
brought
more
closely
to
our
notice
,
it
is
now
only
necessary
to
add
that
he
had
just
been
presented
to
the
vicarage
of
St.
Ewold
by
Dr.
Grantly
,
in
whose
gift
as
archdeacon
the
living
lay
.
<EOS>
St.
Ewold
is
a
parish
lying
just
without
the
city
of
Barchester
.
<EOS>
The
suburbs
of
the
new
town
,
indeed
,
are
partly
within
its
precincts
,
and
the
pretty
church
and
parsonage
are
not
much
above
a
mile
distant
from
the
city
gate
.
  
<EOS>
St.
Ewold
is
not
a
rich
piece
of
preferment
 
<EOS>
it
is
worth
some
three
or
four
hundred
a
year
at
most
,
and
has
generally
been
held
by
a
clergyman
attached
to
the
cathedral
choir
.
<EOS>
The
archdeacon
,
however
,
felt
,
when
the
living
on
this
occasion
became
vacant
,
that
it
imperatively
behoved
him
to
aid
the
force
of
his
party
with
some
tower
of
strength
,
if
any
such
tower
could
be
got
to
occupy
St.
Ewold
's
.
<EOS>
He
had
discussed
the
matter
with
his
brethren
in
Barchester
,
not
in
any
weak
spirit
as
the
holder
of
patronage
to
be
used
for
his
own
or
his
family
's
benefit
,
but
as
one
to
whom
was
committed
a
trust
on
the
due
administration
of
which
much
of
the
church
's
welfare
might
depend
.
<EOS>
He
had
submitted
to
them
the
name
of
Mr.
Arabin
,
as
though
the
choice
had
rested
with
them
all
in

,
and
they
had
unanimously

that
,
if
Mr.
Arabin
would
accept
St.
Ewold
's
,
no
better
choice
could
possibly
be
made
.
  
<EOS>
If
Mr.
Arabin
would
accept
St.
Ewold
's
!
<EOS>
There
lay
the
difficulty
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
was
a
man
standing
somewhat
prominently
before
the
world
,
that
is
,
before
the
Church
of
England
world
.
<EOS>
He
was
not
a
rich
man
,
it
is
true
,
for
he
held
no
preferment
but
his
fellowship
;
but
he
was
a
man
not
over
-
anxious
for
riches
,
not
married
of
course
,
and
one
whose
time
was
greatly
taken
up
in
discussing
,
both
in
print
and
on
platforms
,
the
privileges
and
practices
of
the
church
to
which
he
belonged
.
<EOS>
As
the
archdeacon
had
done
battle
for
its
temporalities
,
so
did
Mr.
Arabin
do
battle
for
its
spiritualities
,
and
both
had
done
so
conscientiously
;
that
is
,
not
so
much
each
for
his
own
benefit
as
for
that
of
others
.
  
<EOS>
Holding
such
a
position
as
Mr.
Arabin
did
,
there
was
much
reason
to
doubt
whether
he
would
consent
to
become
the
parson
of
St.
Ewold
's
,
and
Dr.
Grantly
had
taken
the
trouble
to
go
himself
to
Oxford
on
the
matter
.
<EOS>
Dr.
Gwynne
and
Dr.
Grantly
together
had
succeeded
in
persuading
this
eminent
divine
that
duty
required
him
to
go
to
Barchester
.
<EOS>
There
were
wheels
within
wheels
in
this
affair
.
<EOS>
For
some
time
past
Mr.
Arabin
had
been
engaged
in
a
tremendous
controversy
with
no
less
a
person
than
Mr.
Slope
,
respecting
the
apostolic
succession
.
<EOS>
These
two
gentlemen
had
never
seen
each
other
,
but
they
had
been
extremely
bitter
in
print
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
had
endeavoured
to
strengthen
his
cause
by
calling
Mr.
Arabin
an
owl
,
and
Mr.
Arabin
had
retaliated
by
hinting
that
Mr.
Slope
was
an
infidel
.
<EOS>
This
battle
had
been
commenced
in
the
columns
of
"
The
Jupiter
,
"
a
powerful
newspaper
,
the
manager
of
which
was
very
friendly
to
Mr.
Slope
's
view
of
the
case
.
<EOS>
The
matter
,
however
,
had
become
too
tedious
for
the
readers
of
"
The
Jupiter
,
"
and
a
little
note
had
therefore
been
appended
to
one
of
Mr.
Slope
's
most
telling
rejoinders
,
in
which
it
had
been
stated
that
no
further
letters
from
the
reverend
gentlemen
could
be
inserted
except
as

.
  
<EOS>
Other
methods
of
publication
were
,
however
,
found
,
less
expensive
than
advertisements
in
"
The
Jupiter
,
"
and
the
war
went
on
merrily
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
declared
that
the
main
part
of
the
consecration
of
a
clergyman
was
the
self
-
devotion
of
the
inner
man
to
the
duties
of
the
ministry
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
contended
that
a
man
was
not
consecrated
at
all
,
had
,
indeed
,
no
single
attribute
of
a
clergyman
,
unless
he
became
so
through
the

of
some
bishop
's
hands
,
who
had
become
a
bishop
through
the
imposition
of
other
hands
,
and
so
on
in
a
direct
line
to
one
of
the
apostles
.
<EOS>
Each
had
repeatedly
hung
the
other
on
the
horns
of
a
dilemma
,
but
neither
seemed
to
be
a
whit
the
worse
for
the
hanging
;
and
so
the
war
went
on

.
  
<EOS>
Whether
or
no
the
near

of
the
foe
may

as

Mr.
Arabin

living

Ewold
,

;

,

,

,

,
or
,

,

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
intended
to
keep

St.

,

,

from

great
a
man
<EOS>
Dr.

.
<EOS>
It

into

under

the

.
  
<EOS>
All

the

's

shone

.
<EOS>
He
ate
of

,

,

,

-
in

that

ought

Gwynne
at

,

.

"
Is

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

,

"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"

.
<EOS>
Had

eighty
,

.
  
<EOS>
When

,

.
<EOS>
But

,

,

's

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
He
ca
n't

,
"

over

,

-

-

;
"
he
ca

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
He
ca
n't

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

ca

?
"

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
"

"
  
"

;

.
<EOS>
Let

,

.
<EOS>
For

.
<EOS>
But

,
ass

,

's

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
winced
at
the
idea
of
the
press
.
<EOS>
He
had
had
enough
of
that
sort

,
and
was

.
<EOS>
He
gently

that

hoped

would

again
,
and

.
<EOS>
"
I
am

,
"

,
"
and

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
New
duties
?
<EOS>
"

;
"
do

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Or

duties

,
"

Harding
;
"
I

I

.
"
<EOS>
The
picture
of
Mr.
Slope
carting
away

was
still

to

.
  
<EOS>
The
archdeacon
drank

his

of

and
prepared
himself
to
be

.
<EOS>
"
I
do
hope
,
"
said
he
,
"
that
you

Slope
to

.
<EOS>
You

at

hospital
now

so

the

as

.
<EOS>
You

,

now

,
your

hereafter

,
"
and

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Your

will

,
"
he

.
<EOS>
"
You
resigned

place
from

,

,

I

.
<EOS>
All

friends

,

.
<EOS>
It
is

.
<EOS>
Dr.
Gwynne
was

only
the
other
day
 
<EOS>
"
  
"
Dr.
Gwynne
does

I

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Old
 
nonsense
,
"

;
"
you

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

-

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

,

ten

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
And

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
Your

old
age
is
a
pretence
.
<EOS>
But
you
're

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
The

,

"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nor
I
neither
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
This

,

"
  
<EOS>
Mr.

.

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
No

"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
And

<EOS>
Mr.

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
How

.
<EOS>
He

,

.
<EOS>
Arabin

,

.
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
And

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>
Poor

!
<EOS>
But

.

<EOS>
The
Widow
's

<EOS>
Mr.

,

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.

,
with

four

,

,

,

<EOS>

?
<EOS>
But

,

,

;

,

<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>

"
<EOS>

.

!
"

.
<EOS>
"

!
"
said

as

.
<EOS>
If

were

Mrs.

of
her
own
,
what
a

would
he

her
father
's

to

.
<EOS>
The
train
of
Mr.
Slope
's
ideas
will
probably

plain
to
all
my
readers
.
<EOS>
Why
should
he
not

twelve

a

his

?
<EOS>
And

,

to

father
-
in
-
law
comfortably

?
<EOS>
Would

,
moreover
,

daughter
if

all

forward

's
views
?
  
<EOS>
These

presented
themselves
to
him
in
a
very
forcible

,
and
yet

were
many
points
of

.
<EOS>
If

Harding
his

,

for

;

,

Proudie
,

not

,
and

know
that

as
to

's

.
<EOS>
That

he

not

,

.
<EOS>
He

daughter
.
<EOS>
He

not

to

before

another
.
  
<EOS>
And
thus
he
rode
home
,
meditating
many
things
in
his

.
<EOS>
It
occurred
to
him
that
Mrs.
Bold
was
sister
-
in
-
law
to
the
archdeacon
,
and
that
not
even
for
twelve
hundred
a
year
would

submit
to
that
imperious
man
.
<EOS>
A
rich
wife
was
a
great
desideratum
to
him
,
but
success
in
his

was
still
greater
;
there

,
moreover
,
other
rich

who
might

;
and

,
this
twelve

year
might
,
when
inquired
into
,
melt
away

some

utterly

.
<EOS>
Then
also
he
remembered
that
Mrs.
Bold
had
a
son
.
  
<EOS>
Another
circumstance
also
much
influenced
him
,
though
it
was
one
which
may
almost
be
said
to
have

him
against
his
will
.
<EOS>
The
vision
of
the
Signora
Neroni
was
perpetually
before
his
eyes
.
<EOS>
It
would
be
too
much
to
say
that
Mr.
Slope
was
lost
in
love
,
but
yet
he
thought
,
and
kept
continually
thinking
,
that
he
had
never
seen
so
beautiful
a
woman
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
man
whose
nature
was
open
to
such
impulses
,
and
the
wiles
of
the
Italianized
charmer
had
been
thoroughly
successful
in
imposing
upon
his
thoughts
.
<EOS>
We
will
not
talk
about
his
heart
:
not
that
he
had
no
heart
,
but
because
his
heart
had
little
to
do
with
his
present
feelings
.
<EOS>
His
taste
had
been
pleased
,
his
eyes
charmed
,
and
his
vanity
gratified
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
dazzled
by
a
sort
of
loveliness
which
he
had
never
before
seen
,
and
had
been
caught
by
an
easy
,
free
,
voluptuous
manner
which
was
perfectly
new
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
had
never
been
so
tempted
before
,
and
the
temptation
was
now
irresistible
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
owned
to
himself
that
he
cared
for
this
woman
more
than
for
others
around
him
,
but
yet
he
thought
often
of
the
time
when
he
might
see
her
next
,
and
made
,
almost
unconsciously
,
little
cunning
plans
for
seeing
her
frequently
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
called
at
Dr.
Stanhope
's
house
the
day
after
the
bishop
's
party
,
and
then
the
warmth
of
his
admiration
had
been
fed
with
fresh
fuel
.
<EOS>
If
the
signora
had
been
kind
in
her
manner
and
flattering
in
her
speech
when
lying
upon
the
bishop
's
sofa
,
with
the
eyes
of
so
many
on
her
,
she
had
been
much
more
so
in
her
mother
's
drawing
-
room
,
with
no
one
present
but
her
sister
to
repress
either
her
nature
or
her
art
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
had
thus
left
her
quite
bewildered
,
and
could
not
willingly
admit
into
his
brain
any
scheme
a
part
of
which
would
be
the
necessity
of
his
abandoning
all
further
special
friendship
with
this
lady
.
  
<EOS>
And
so
he
slowly
rode
along
,
very
meditative
.
  
<EOS>
And
here
the
author
must
beg
it
to
be
remembered
that
Mr.
Slope
was
not
in
all
things
a
bad
man
.
<EOS>
His
motives
,
like
those
of
most
men
,
were
mixed
,
and
though
his
conduct
was
generally
very
different
from
that
which
we
would
wish
to
praise
,
it
was
actuated
perhaps
as
often
as
that
of
the
majority
of
the
world
by
a
desire
to
do
his
duty
.
<EOS>
He
believed
in
the
religion
which
he
taught
,
harsh
,
unpalatable
,
uncharitable
as
that
religion
was
.
<EOS>
He
believed
those
whom
he
wished
to
get
under
his
hoof
,
the
Grantlys
and
Gwynnes
of
the
church
,
to
be
the
enemies
of
that
religion
.
<EOS>
He
believed
himself
to
be
a
pillar
of
strength
,
destined
to
do
great
things
,
and
with
that
subtle
,
selfish
,
ambiguous
sophistry
to
which
the
minds
of
all
men
are
so
subject
,
he
had
taught
himself
to
think
that
in
doing
much
for
the
promotion
of
his
own
interests
,
he
was
doing
much
also
for
the
promotion
of
religion
.
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Slope
had
never
been
an
immoral
man
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
he
had
resisted
temptations
to
immorality
with
a
strength
of
purpose
that
was
creditable
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
had
early
in
life
devoted
himself
to
works
which
were
not
compatible
with
the
ordinary
pleasures
of
youth
,
and
he
had
abandoned
such
pleasures
not
without
a
struggle
.
<EOS>
It
must
therefore
be
conceived
that
he
did
not
admit
to
himself
that
he
warmly
admired
the
beauty
of
a
married
woman
without
heart
-
felt
stings
of
conscience
;
and
to
pacify
that
conscience
he
had
to
teach
himself
that
the
nature
of
his
admiration
was
innocent
.
  
<EOS>
And
thus
he
rode
along
meditative
and
ill
at
ease
.
<EOS>
His
conscience
had
not
a
word
to
say
against
his
choosing
the
widow
and
her
fortune
.
<EOS>
That
he
looked
upon
as
a
godly
work
rather
than
otherwise
;
as
a
deed
which
,
if
carried
through
,
would
redound
to
his
credit
as
a
Christian
.
<EOS>
On
that
side
lay
no
future
remorse
,
no
conduct
which
he
might
probably
have
to
forget
,
no
inward
stings
.
<EOS>
If
it
should
turn
out
to
be
really
the
fact
that
Mrs.
Bold
had
twelve
hundred
a
year
at
her
own
disposal
,
Mr.
Slope
would
rather
look
upon
it
as
a
duty
which
he
owed
his
religion
to
make
himself
the
master
of
the
wife
and
the
money
;
as
a
duty
too
,
in
which
some
amount
of
self
-
sacrifice
would
be
necessary
.
<EOS>
He
would
have
to
give
up
his
friendship
with
the
signora
,
his
resistance
to
Mr.
Harding
,
his
antipathy
 
<EOS>
no
,
he
found
on
mature
self
-
examination
that
he
could
not
bring
himself
to
give
up
his
antipathy
to
Dr.
Grantly
.
<EOS>
He
would
marry
the
lady
as
the
enemy
of
her
brother
-
in
-
law
if
such
an
arrangement
suited
her
;
if
not
,
she
must
look
elsewhere
for
a
husband
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
with
such
resolve
as
this
that
he
reached
Barchester
.
<EOS>
He
would
at
once
ascertain
what
the
truth
might
be
as
to
the
lady
's
wealth
,
and
having
done
this
he
would
be
ruled
by
circumstances
in
his
conduct
respecting
the
hospital
.
<EOS>
If
he
found
that
he
could
turn
round
and
secure
the
place
for
Mr.
Harding
without
much
self
-
sacrifice
,
he
would
do
so
;
but
if
not
,
he
would
woo
the
daughter
in
opposition
to
the
father
.
<EOS>
But
in
no
case
would
he
succumb
to
the
archdeacon
.
  
<EOS>
He
saw
his
horse
taken
round
to
the
stable
,
and
immediately
went
forth
to
commence
his
inquiries
.
<EOS>
To
give
Mr.
Slope
his
due
,
he
was
not
a
man
who
ever
let
much
grass
grow
under
his
feet
.
  
<EOS>
Poor
Eleanor
!
<EOS>
She
was
doomed
to
be
the
intended
victim
of
more
schemes
than
one
.
  
<EOS>
About
the
time
that
Mr.
Slope
was
visiting
the
vicar
of
Puddingdale
,
a
discussion
took
place
respecting
her
charms
and
wealth
at
Dr.
Stanhope
's
house
in
the
close
.
<EOS>
There
had
been
morning
callers
there
,
and
people
had
told
some
truth
and
also
some
falsehood
respecting
the
property
which
John
Bold
had
left
behind
him
.
<EOS>
By
degrees
the
visitors
went
,
and
as
the
doctor
went
with
them
,
and
as
the
doctor
's
wife
had
not
made
her
appearance
,
Charlotte
Stanhope
and
her
brother
were
left
together
.
<EOS>
He
was
sitting
idly
at
the
table
,
scrawling
caricatures
of
Barchester
notables
,
then
yawning
,
then
turning
over
a
book
or
two
,
and
evidently
at
a
loss
how
to
kill
his
time
without
much
labour
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
n't
done
much
,
Bertie
,
about
getting
any
orders
,
"
said
his
sister
.
  
<EOS>
"
Orders
!
"
said
he
;
"
who
on
earth
is
there
at
Barchester
to
give
one
orders
?
<EOS>
Who
among
the
people
here
could
possibly
think
it
worth
his
while
to
have
his
head
done
into
marble
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
you
mean
to
give
up
your
profession
,
"
said
she
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
do
n't
,
"
said
he
,
going
on
with
some
absurd
portrait
of
the
bishop
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Look
at
that
,
Lotte
;
is
n't
it
the
little
man
all
over
,
apron
and
all
?
<EOS>
I
'd
go
on
with
my
profession
at
once
,
as
you
call
it
,
if
the
governor
would
set
me
up
with
a
studio
in
London
;
but
as
to
sculpture
at
Barchester
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
half
the
people
here
do
n't
know
what
a
torso
means
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
governor
will
not
give
you
a
shilling
to
start
you
in
London
,
"
said
Lotte
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Indeed
,
he
ca
n't
give
you
what
would
be
sufficient
,
for
he
has
not
got
it
.
<EOS>
But
you
might
start
yourself
very
well
,
if
you
pleased
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
the
deuce
am
I
to
do
it
?
"
said
he
.
  
<EOS>
"
To
tell
you
the
truth
,
Bertie
,
you
'll
never
make
a
penny
by
any
profession
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
what
I
often
think
myself
,
"
said
he
,
not
in
the
least

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Some
men
have
a
great
gift
of
making
money
,
but
they
ca
n't
spend
it
.
<EOS>
Others
ca
n't
put
two
shillings
together
,
but
they
have
a
great
talent
for
all
sorts
of
outlay
.
<EOS>
I
begin
to
think
that
my
genius
is
wholly
in
the
latter
line
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
mean
to
live
then
?
"
asked
the
sister
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
I
must
regard
myself
as
a
young
raven
and
look
for
heavenly
manna
;
besides
,
we
have
all
got
something
when
the
governor
goes
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
 
you
'll
have
enough
to
supply
yourself
with
gloves
and

;
that
is
,
if
the
Jews
have
not

.
<EOS>
I
believe
they
have
the
most
of
it
already
.
<EOS>
I
wonder
,
Bertie
,
at
your
indifference
;
that
you
,
with
your
talents
and
personal
advantages
,
should
never
try
to
settle
yourself
in
life
.
<EOS>
I
look
forward
with
dread
to
the
time
when
the
governor
must
go
.
<EOS>
Mother
,
and
Madeline
,
and
I
 
<EOS>
we
shall
be
poor
enough
,
but
you
will
have
absolutely
nothing
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Sufficient
for
the
day
is
the
evil
thereof
,
"
said
Bertie
.
  
<EOS>
"
Will
you
take
my
advice
?
"
said
his
sister
.
  
<EOS>
"
_
Cela
dépend
_
,
"
said
the
brother
.
  
<EOS>
"
Will
you
marry
a
wife
with
money
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
At
any
rate
,
"
said
he
,
"
I
wo
n't
marry
one
without
;
wives
with
money
a'nt
so
easy
to
get
now
-
a
-
days
;
the
parsons
pick
them
all
up
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
a
parson
will
pick
up
the
wife
I
mean

,
if
you
do
not
look
quickly
about

;
the
wife
I

Mrs.
Bold
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Whew
-
w
-
w
-
w
!
"
whistled

,
"
a
widow
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
is
very
beautiful
,
"
said
Charlotte
.
  
<EOS>
"
With
a
son
and
heir
all
ready
to
my
hand
,
"
said
Bertie
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
baby
that
will
very
likely
die
,
"
said
Charlotte
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
see
that
,
"
said
Bertie
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
however
,
he
may
live
for
me
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
wish
to
kill
him
;
only
,
it
must
be
owned
that
a
ready
-
made
family
is
a

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
is
only
one
after

,
"

Charlotte
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
that
a
very
little
one
,

the
maidservant

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Beggars
must
n't
be
choosers
,
Bertie
;
you
ca
n't
have
everything
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
God
knows
I
am
not
unreasonable
,
"
said
he
,
"
nor
yet
opinionated
,
and
if
you
'll

all
for

,
Lotte
,
I
'll

.
<EOS>
Only

:
the
money
must

sure
,
and
the
income
at
my
own
disposal
,
at
any
rate
for
the
lady
's
life
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Charlotte
was
explaining
to
her
brother
that
he
must
make
love
for
himself
if
he
meant
to
carry
on
the
matter
,
and
was

to

on
Eleanor
's

,
when
the
signora
was

into

-

.
<EOS>
When
at
home
,
and
subject
to
the

of
none
but
her
own
family
,
she
allowed
herself
to
be
dragged
about
by
two
persons
,
and
her
two
bearers
now
deposited
her
on
her

.
<EOS>
She
was
not
quite
so
grand
in
her

as
she
had

at
the
bishop
's
party
,
but
yet
she
was
dressed
with
much
care
,
and
though

was
a
look
of
care
and
pain
about
her
eyes
,
she
was
,
even
by

,
extremely

.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Madeline
,
so
I
'm
going
to
be
married
,
"
Bertie
began
as
soon
as
the
servants
had
withdrawn
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
's
no
other
foolish
thing
left
that
you
have
n't
done
,
"
said
Madeline
,
"
and
therefore

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
you

it
's

,

?
"
said
he
.
<EOS>
"
There
's
Lotte
advising
me
to
marry
by

.
<EOS>
But
on
such

your
opinion
ought
to

;
you

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I

,
"

Madeline
with

in

,

<EOS>
"
What

I

?
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Bertie
was
sorry

he

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
Come
,

,
I

;

.
<EOS>
But
in

,
Lotte
is

.
<EOS>
She
wants

Mrs.
Bold
.
<EOS>
She
's

with

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
By

,

,

,

-
house

<EOS>
it
's
just
the
life

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
,
"

,
"

,

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The

.
  
<EOS>
"
Instead

,
"

,
"
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
She

rooms
the

;

,

.

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Every

,
"

"

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do

of

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
It

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
People

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Exactly
,
"

.
<EOS>
"
She

a
little
rebellion
on
the
part
of
the
bishop
.
<EOS>
He
thought
that
such
a
state
of
things
would
be
advisable
,
not
only
in
respect
to
Messrs.
Harding
and
Quiverful
,
but
also
in
the
affairs
of
the
diocese
generally
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
was
by
no
means
of
opinion
that
Dr.
Proudie
was
fit
to
rule
,
but
he
conscientiously
thought
it
wrong
that
his
brother
clergy
should
be
subjected
to
petticoat
government
.
<EOS>
He
therefore
made
up
his
mind
to
infuse
a
little
of
his
spirit
into
the
bishop
,
sufficient
to
induce
him
to
oppose
his
wife
,
though
not
enough
to
make
him
altogether
insubordinate
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
therefore
taken
an
opportunity
of
again
speaking
to
his
lordship
about
the
hospital
,
and
had
endeavoured
to
make
it
appear
that
after
all
it
would
be
unwise
to
exclude
Mr.
Harding
from
the
appointment
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
,
however
,
had
a
harder
task
than
he
had
imagined
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Proudie
,
anxious
to
assume
to
herself
as
much
as
possible
of
the
merit
of
patronage
,
had
written
to
Mrs.
Quiverful
,
requesting
her
to
call
at
the
palace
,
and
had
then
explained
to
that
matron
,
with
much
mystery
,
condescension
,
and
dignity
,
the
good
that
was
in
store
for
her
and
her
progeny
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
Mrs.
Proudie
had
been
so
engaged
at
the
very
time
that
Mr.
Slope
had
been
doing
the
same
with
the
husband
at
Puddingdale
Vicarage
,
and
had
thus
in
a
measure
committed
herself
.
<EOS>
The
thanks
,
the
humility
,
the
gratitude
,
the
surprise
of
Mrs.
Quiverful
had
been
very
overpowering
;
she
had
all
but
embraced
the
knees
of
her
patroness
,
and
had
promised
that
the
prayers
of
fourteen
unprovided
babes
(
so
Mrs.
Quiverful
had
described
her
own
family
,
the
eldest
of
which
was
a
stout
young
woman
of
three
-
and
-
twenty
)
should
be
put
up
to
heaven
morning
and
evening
for
the
munificent
friend
whom
God
had
sent
to
them
.
<EOS>
Such
incense
as
this
was
not
unpleasing
to
Mrs.
Proudie
,
and
she
made
the
most
of
it
.
<EOS>
She
offered
her
general
assistance
to
the
fourteen
unprovided
babes
,
if
,
as
she
had
no
doubt
,
she
should
find
them
worthy
;
expressed
a
hope
that
the
eldest
of
them
would
be
fit
to
undertake
tuition
in
her
Sabbath
-
schools
;
and
altogether
made
herself
a
very
great
lady
in
the
estimation
of
Mrs.
Quiverful
.
  
<EOS>
Having
done
this
,
she
thought
it
prudent
to
drop
a
few
words
before
the
bishop
,
letting
him
know
that
she
had
acquainted
the
Puddingdale
family
with
their
good
fortune
;
so
that
he
might
perceive
that
he
stood
committed
to
the
appointment
.
<EOS>
The
husband
well
understood
the
ruse
of
his
wife
,
but
he
did
not
resent
it
.
<EOS>
He
knew
that
she
was
taking
the
patronage
out
of
his
hands
;
he
was
resolved
to
put
an
end
to
her
interference
and
reassume
his
powers
.
<EOS>
But
then
he
thought
this
was
not
the
best
time
to
do
it
.
<EOS>
He
put
off
the
evil
hour
,
as
many
a
man
in
similar
circumstances
has
done
before
him
.
  
<EOS>
Such
having
been
the
case
,
Mr.
Slope
naturally
encountered
a
difficulty
in
talking
over
the
bishop
,
a
difficulty
indeed
which
he
found
could
not
be
overcome
except
at
the
cost
of
a
general
outbreak
at
the
palace
.
<EOS>
A
general
outbreak
at
the
present
moment
might
be
good
policy
,
but
it
also
might
not
.
<EOS>
It
was
at
any
rate
not
a
step
to
be
lightly
taken
.
<EOS>
He
began
by
whispering
to
the
bishop
that
he
feared
that
public
opinion
would
be
against
him
if
Mr.
Harding
did
not
reappear
at
the
hospital
.
<EOS>
The
bishop
answered
with
some
warmth
that
Mr.
Quiverful
had
been
promised
the
appointment
on
Mr.
Slope
's
advice
.
"
<EOS>
Not
promised
?
"
said
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
promised
,
"
replied
the
bishop
,
"
and
Mrs.
Proudie
has
seen
Mrs.
Quiverful
on
the
subject
.
<EOS>
"
This
was
quite
unexpected
on
the
part
of
Mr.
Slope
,
but
his
presence
of
mind
did
not
fail
him
,
and
he
turned
the
statement
to
his
own
account
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
my
lord
,
"
said
he
,
"
we
shall
all
be
in
scrapes
if
the
ladies
interfere
.
"
  
<EOS>
This
was
too
much
in
unison
with
my
lord
's
feelings
to
be
altogether
unpalatable
,
and
yet
such
an
allusion
to
interference
demanded
a
rebuke
.
<EOS>
My
lord
was
somewhat
astounded
also
,
though
not
altogether
made
miserable
,
by
finding
that
there
was
a
point
of
difference
between
his
wife
and
his
chaplain
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
what
you
mean
by
interference
,
"
said
the
bishop
mildly
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
When
Mrs.
Proudie
heard
that
Mr.
Quiverful
was
to
be
appointed
,
it
was
not
unnatural
that
she
should
wish
to
see
Mrs.
Quiverful
about
the
schools
.
<EOS>
I
really
can
not
say
that
I
see
any
interference
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
only
speak
,
my
lord
,
for
your
own
comfort
,
"
said
Slope
;
"
for
your
own
comfort
and
dignity
in
the
diocese
.
<EOS>
I
can
have
no
other
motive
.
<EOS>
As
far
as
personal
feelings
go
,
Mrs.
Proudie
is
the
best
friend
I
have
.
<EOS>
I
must
always
remember
that
.
<EOS>
But
still
,
in
my
present
position
,
my
first
duty
is
to
your
lordship
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
sure
of
that
,
Mr.
Slope
;
I
am
quite
sure
of
that
;
"
said
the
bishop
,
mollified
:
"
and
you
really
think
that
Mr.
Harding
should
have
the
hospital
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Upon
my
word
,
I
'm
inclined
to
think
so
.
<EOS>
I
am
quite
prepared
to
take
upon
myself
the
blame
of
first
suggesting
Mr.
Quiverful
's
name
.
<EOS>
But
since
doing
so
,
I
have
found
that
there
is
so
strong
a
feeling
in
the
diocese
in
favour
of
Mr.
Harding
that
I
think
your
lordship
should
give
way
.
<EOS>
I
hear
also
that
Mr.
Harding
has
modified
the
objections
he
first
felt
to
your
lordship
's
propositions
.
<EOS>
And
as
to
what
has
passed
between
Mrs.
Proudie
and
Mrs.
Quiverful
,
the
circumstance
may
be
a
little
inconvenient
,
but
I
really
do
not
think
that
that
should
weigh
in
a
matter
of
so
much
moment
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
And
thus
the
poor
bishop
was
left
in
a
dreadfully
undecided
step
as
to
what
he
should
do
.
<EOS>
His
mind
,
however
,
slightly
inclined
itself
to
the
appointment
of
Mr.
Harding
,
seeing
that
by
such
a
step
he
should
have
the
assistance
of
Mr.
Slope
in
opposing
Mrs.
Proudie
.
  
<EOS>
Such
was
the
state
of
affairs
at
the
palace
,
when
Mr.
Slope
called
at
Mrs.
Bold
's
house
and
found
her
playing
with
her
baby
.
<EOS>
When
she
ran
out
of
the
room
,
Mr.
Slope
began
praising
the
weather
to
Mary
Bold
,
then
he
praised
the
baby
and
kissed
him
,
and
then
he
praised
the
mother
,
and
then
he
praised
Miss
Bold
herself
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Bold
,
however
,
was
not
long
before
she
came
back
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
to
apologize
for
calling
at
so
very
early
an
hour
,
"
began
Mr.
Slope
,
"
but
I
was
really
so
anxious
to
speak
to
you
that
I
hope
you
and
Miss
Bold
will
excuse
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
Eleanor
muttered
something
in
which
the
words
"
certainly
,
"
and
"
of
course
,
"
and
"
not
early
at
all
,
"
were
just
audible
,
and
then
apologized
for
her
own
appearance
,
declaring
,
with
a
smile
,
that
her
baby
was
becoming
such
a
big
boy
that
he
was
quite
unmanageable
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
's
a
great
big
naughty
boy
,
"
said
she
to
the
child
,
"
and
we
must
send
him
away
to
a
great
big
rough
romping
school
,
where
they
have
great
big
rods
and
do
terrible
things
to
naughty
boys
who
do
n't
do
what
their
own
mammas
tell
them
;
"
and
she
then
commenced
another
course
of
kissing
,
being
actuated
thereto
by
the
terrible
idea
of
sending
her
child
away
which
her
own
imagination
had
depicted
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
where
the
masters
do
n't
have
such
beautiful
long
hair
to
be
dishevelled
,
"
said
Mr.
Slope
,
taking
up
the
joke
and
paying
a
compliment
at
the
same
time
.
  
<EOS>
Eleanor
thought
he
might
as
well
have
left
the
compliment
alone
,
but
she
said
nothing
and
looked
nothing
,
being
occupied
as
she
was
with
the
baby
.
  
<EOS>
"
Let
me
take
him
,
"
said
Mary
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
His
clothes
are
nearly
off
his
back
with
his
romping
,
"
and
so
saying
she
left
the
room
with
the
child
.
<EOS>
Miss
Bold
had
heard
Mr.
Slope
say
he
had
something
pressing
to
say
to
Eleanor
,
and
thinking
that
she
might
be
_
de
trop
_
,
<EOS>
took
this
opportunity
of
getting
herself
out
of
the
room
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
be
long
,
Mary
,
"
said
Eleanor
as
Miss
Bold
shut
the
door
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
,
Mrs.
Bold
,
to
have
the
opportunity
of
having
ten
minutes
'
conversation
with
you
alone
,
"
began
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
"
Will
you
let
me
openly
ask
you
a
plain
question
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
"
said
she
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
I
am
sure
you
will
give
me
a
plain
and
open
answer
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Either
that
,
or
none
at
all
,
"
said
she
,
laughing
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
question
is
this
,
Mrs.
Bold
:
is
your
father
really
anxious
to
go
back
to
the
hospital
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
do
you
ask
me
?
"
said
she
.
<EOS>
"
Why
do
n't
you
ask
himself
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Mrs.
Bold
,
I
'll
tell
you
why
.
<EOS>
There
are
wheels
within
wheels
,
all
of
which
I
would
explain
to
you
,
only
I
fear
that
there
is
not
time
.
<EOS>
It
is
essentially
necessary
that
I
should
have
an
answer
to
this
question
,
otherwise
I
can
not
know
how
to
advance
your
father
's
wishes
;
and
it
is
quite
impossible
that
I
should
ask
himself
.
<EOS>
No
one
can
esteem
your
father
more
than
I
do
,
but
I
doubt
if
this
feeling
is
reciprocal
.
<EOS>
"
It
certainly
was
not
.
<EOS>
"
I
must
be
candid
with
you
as
the
only
means
of
avoiding
ultimate
consequences
,
which
may
be
most
injurious
to
Mr.
Harding
.
<EOS>
I
fear
there
is
a
feeling
 
I
will
not
even
call
it
a
prejudice
 
with
regard
to
myself
in
Barchester
,
which
is
not
in
my
favour
.
<EOS>
You
remember
that
sermon
 
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Mr.
Slope
,
we
need
not
go
back
to
that
,
"
said
Eleanor
.
  
<EOS>
"
For
one
moment
,
Mrs.
Bold
.
<EOS>
It
is
not
that
I
may
talk
of
myself
,
but
because
it
is
so
essential
that
you
should
understand
how
matters
stand
.
<EOS>
That
sermon
may
have
been
ill
-
judged
 
<EOS>
it
was
certainly
misunderstood
;
but
I
will
say
nothing
about
that
now
;
only
this
,
that
it
did
give
rise
to
a
feeling
against
myself
which
your
father
shares
with
others
.
<EOS>
It
may
be
that
he
has
proper
cause
,
but
the
result
is
that
he
is
not
inclined
to
meet
me
on
friendly
terms
.
<EOS>
I
put
it
to
yourself
whether
you
do
not
know
this
to
be
the
case
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Eleanor
made
no
answer
,
and
Mr.
Slope
,
in
the
eagerness
of
his
address
,
edged
his
chair
a
little
nearer
to
the
widow
's
seat
,
unperceived
by
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
Such
being
so
,
"
continued
Mr.
Slope
,
"
I
can
not
ask
him
this
question
as
I
can
ask
it
of
you
.
<EOS>
In
spite
of
my
delinquencies
since
I
came
to
Barchester
you
have
allowed
me
to
regard
you
as
a
friend
.
<EOS>
"
Eleanor
made
a
little
motion
with
her
head
which
was
hardly
confirmatory
,
but
Mr.
Slope
if
he
noticed
it
,
did
not
appear
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
"
To
you
I
can
speak
openly
and
explain
the
feelings
of
my
heart
.
<EOS>
This
your
father
would
not
allow
.
<EOS>
Unfortunately
,
the
bishop
has
thought
it
right
that
this
matter
of
the
hospital
should
pass
through
my
hands
.
<EOS>
There
have
been
some
details
to
get
up
with
which
he
would
not
trouble
himself
,
and
thus
it
has
come
to
pass
that
I
was
forced
to
have
an
interview
with
your
father
on
the
matter
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
aware
of
that
,
"
said
Eleanor
.
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
,
"
said
he
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
In
that
interview
Mr.
Harding
left
the
impression
on
my
mind
that
he
did
not
wish
to
return
to
the
hospital
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
could
that
be
?
"
said
Eleanor
,
<EOS>
at
last
stirred
up
to
forget
the
cold
propriety
of
demeanour
which
she
had
determined
to
maintain
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Mrs.
Bold
,
I
give
you
my
word
that
such
was
the
case
,
"
said
he
,
again
getting
a
little
nearer
to
her
.
"
<EOS>
And
what
is
more
than
that
,
before
my
interview
with
Mr.
Harding
,
certain
persons
at
the
palace
 
<EOS>
I
do
not
mean
the
bishop
 
had
told
me
that
such
was
the
fact
.
<EOS>
I
own
,
I
hardly
believed
it
;
I
own
,
I
thought
that
your
father
would
wish
on

,
for
conscience
"

,

,

"

.

"

;

.
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
and

this
of

,
that
I

's

for

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
widow
hardly
knew
what

.
<EOS>
She
was
quite
aware
that
her
father
would
not

Mr.
Slope
;
she

father
's

;
and
yet
she
could
not
but

that
Mr.
Slope
was
very
kind
.
<EOS>
Her
father
,
who
was
generally
so

to
all

,
who
seldom
spoke
ill
of
anyone
,
had
warned
her
against
Mr.
Slope
,
and
yet
she
did
not

how
to

from
thanking

.
<EOS>
What

could
he
have
in
the

but

which

?
<EOS>
Nevertheless

was
that

which
even

.
<EOS>
She
felt
,
she
did
not

,
that

something
about

which
ought
to

on

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
read
all
this
in
her
hesitating

just

had

to

.
<EOS>
It
was
the
talent
of
the
man
that
he
could
so
read
the
inward
feelings
of
women
with

he

.
<EOS>
He
knew
that
Eleanor
was
doubting

,
and
that
,
if
she

him
,
she
would
only
do
so
because
she
could
not

,
but
yet
this
did
not

him

.
<EOS>
Rome
was
not
built
in

day
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
not
come

thanks
,
"
continued

,

,
"
and
do

at
any

.
<EOS>
But

I

,

Bold
,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm

,
"

,
"
you

soon

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
She
felt

.
  
<EOS>
"
That
will
be
nothing
unless

;

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
In

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
I
'm

,
Mr.
Slope
.
"
<EOS>
Eleanor
meant

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

;

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
May

<EOS>
And

.
"
  
<EOS>
And

,

's

.
<EOS>
Circumstances
,
however
,
seemed
just
then

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
not

,
"

Bold

.
<EOS>
"
I

is
a

man
or

bad
man
 
whether

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then

,
"

,
"
and

best
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
On

,
I

do
,
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
do
believe
that
he
means
well
 
<EOS>
and
if

,
it
is
a
shame
that
we
should

and

while
he

.
<EOS>
But
,
oh
,
Mary
,
I
fear
Papa
will
be
disappointed
in
the
hospital
.
"
   
<EOS>
Who
Shall
Be
Cock
of
the
Walk
?
 
<EOS>
All
this
time
things
were
going
somewhat
uneasily
at
the
palace
.
<EOS>
The
hint
or
two
which
Mr.
Slope
had
given
was
by
no
means
thrown
away
upon
the
bishop
.
<EOS>
He
had
a
feeling
that
if
he
ever
meant
to
oppose
the
now
almost
unendurable
despotism
of
his
wife
,
he
must
lose
no
further
time
in
doing
so
;
that
if
he
ever
meant
to
be
himself
master
in
his
own
diocese
,
let
alone
his
own
house
,
he
should
begin
at
once
.
<EOS>
It
would
have
been
easier
to
have
done
so
from
the
day
of
his
consecration
than
now
,
but
easier
now
than
when
Mrs.
Proudie
should
have
succeeded
in
thoroughly
mastering
the
diocesan
details
.
<EOS>
Then
the
proffered
assistance
of
Mr.
Slope
was
a
great
thing
for
him
,
a
most
unexpected
and
invaluable
aid
.
<EOS>
Hitherto
he
had
looked
on
the
two
as
allied
forces
and
had
considered
that
,
as
allies
,
they
were
impregnable
.
<EOS>
He
had
begun
to
believe
that
his
only
chance
of
escape
would
be
by
the
advancement
of
Mr.
Slope
to
some
distant
and
rich
preferment
.
<EOS>
But
now
it
seemed
that
one
of
his
enemies
,
certainly
the
least
potent
of
them
,
but
nevertheless
one
very
important
,
was
willing
to
desert
his
own
camp
.
<EOS>
Assisted
by
Mr.
Slope
what
might
he
not
do
?
<EOS>
He
walked
up
and
down
his
little
study
,
almost
thinking
that
the
time
might
come
when
he
would
be
able
to
appropriate
to
his
own
use
the
big
room
upstairs
in
which
his
predecessor
had
always
sat
.
  
<EOS>
As
he
revolved
these
things
in
his
mind
a
note
was
brought
to
him
from
Archdeacon
<EOS>
Grantly
,
in
which
that
divine
begged
his
lordship
to
do
him
the
honour
of
seeing
him
on
the
morrow
 
<EOS>
would
his
lordship
have
the
kindness
to
name
an
hour
?
<EOS>
Dr.
Grantly
's
proposed
visit
would
have
reference
to
the
reappointment
of
Mr.
Harding
to
the
wardenship
of
Barchester
Hospital
.
<EOS>
The
bishop
having
read
his
note
was
informed
that
the
archdeacon
's
servant
was
waiting
for
an
answer
.
  
<EOS>
Here
at
once
a
great
opportunity
offered
itself
to
the
bishop
of
acting
on
his
own
responsibility
.
<EOS>
He
bethought
himself
however
of
his
new
ally
and
rang
the
bell
for
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
It
turned
out
that
Mr.
Slope
was
not
in
the
house
,
and
then
,
greatly
daring
,
the
bishop
with
his
own
unassisted
spirit
wrote
a
note
to
the
archdeacon
saying
that
he
would
see
him
,
and
naming
an
hour
for
doing
so
.
<EOS>
Having
watched
from
his
study
-
window
that
the
messenger
got
safely
off
from
the
premises
with
this
dispatch
,
he
began
to
turn
over
in
his
mind
<EOS>
what
step
he
should
next
take
.
  
<EOS>
To
-
morrow
he
would
have
to
declare
to
the
archdeacon
either
that
Mr.
Harding
should
have
the
appointment
,
or
that
he
should
not
have
it
.
<EOS>
The
bishop
felt
that
he
could
not
honestly
throw
over
the
Quiverfuls
without
informing
Mrs.
Proudie
,
and
he
resolved
at
last
to
brave
the
lioness
in
her
den
and
tell
her
that
circumstances
were
such
that
it
behoved
him
to
reappoint
Mr.
Harding
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
feel
that
he
should
at
all
derogate
from
his
new
courage
by
promising
Mrs.
Proudie
that
the
very
first
piece
of
available
preferment
at
his
disposal
should
be
given
to
Quiverful
to
atone
for
the
injury
done
to
him
.
<EOS>
If
he
could
mollify
the
lioness
with
such
a
sop
,
how
happy
would
he
think
his
first
efforts
to
have
been
!
  
<EOS>
Not
without
many
misgivings
did
he
find
himself
in
Mrs.
Proudie
's
boudoir
.
<EOS>
He
had
at
first
thought
of
sending
for
her
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
not
at
all
impossible
that
she
might
choose
to
take
such
a
message
amiss
,
and
then
also
it
might
be
some
protection
to
him
to
have
his
daughters
present
at
the

.
<EOS>
He
found
her
sitting
with
her
account
-
books
before
her
,
nibbling
the
end
of
her
pencil
,
evidently
immersed
in
pecuniary
difficulties
,
and
harassed
in
mind
by
the
multiplicity
of
palatial
expenses
and
the
heavy
cost
of
episcopal
grandeur
.
<EOS>
Her
daughters
were
around
her
.
<EOS>
Olivia
was
reading
a
novel
,
Augusta
was
crossing
a
note
to
her
bosom
friend
in
Baker
Street
,
and
Netta
was
working
diminutive
coach
wheels
for
the
bottom
of
a
petticoat
.
<EOS>
If
the
bishop
could
get
the
better
of
his
wife
in
her
present
mood
,
he
would
be
a
man
indeed
.
<EOS>
He
might
then
consider
the
victory
his
own
forever
.
<EOS>
After
all
,
in
such
cases
the
matter
between
husband
and
wife
stands
much
the
same
as
it
does
between
two
boys
at
the
same
school
,
two
cocks
in
the
same
yard
,
or
two
armies
on
the
same
continent
.
<EOS>
The
conqueror
once
is
generally
the
conqueror
forever
after
.
<EOS>
The
prestige
of
victory
is
everything
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ahem
 
<EOS>
my
dear
<EOS>
,
"
began
the
bishop
,
"
if
you
are
disengaged
,
I
wished
to
speak
to
you
.
"
<EOS>
Mrs.
Proudie
put
her
pencil
down
carefully
at
the
point
to
which
she
had
totted
her
figures
,
marked
down
in
her
memory
<EOS>
the
sum
she
had
arrived
at
,
and
then
looked
up
,
sourly
enough
,
into
her
helpmate
's
face
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
are
busy
,
another

will

,
"
continued
the
bishop
,
whose
courage
,
like
Bob
Acres
"
,

now
that

found

on
the
ground

.
  
<EOS>
"
What
is

about
,
Bishop
?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
 
it
was
about
those
Quiverfuls
 
<EOS>
but
I
see
you
are
engaged
.
<EOS>
Another
time
will
do

as

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
about

Quiverfuls
?
<EOS>
It

quite

,

,
that

to

.
<EOS>
There
is
to
be

,
is
there
?
"
<EOS>
and
as

she
kept
her

sternly
and

fixed
on
the
column
of
figures
before

.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
my
dear
,
there
is
a
difficulty
,
"
said

bishop
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
difficulty
!
<EOS>
"
said
Mrs.
Proudie
,
"
what
difficulty
?
<EOS>
The
place
has
been
promised
to
Mr.
Quiverful
,
and
of
course
he
must
have
it
.
<EOS>
He
has
made
all
his
arrangements
.
<EOS>
He
has
written
for
a
curate
for
Puddingdale
,
he
has
spoken
to
the
auctioneer
about
selling
his
farm
,
horses
,
and
cows
,
and
in
all
respects
considers
the
place
as
his
own
.
<EOS>
Of
course
he
must
have
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
Now
,
Bishop
,
look
well
to
thyself
and
call
up
all
the
manhood
that
is
in
thee
.
<EOS>
Think
how
much
is
at
stake
.
<EOS>
If
now
thou
art
not
true
to
thy
guns
,
no
Slope
can
hereafter
aid
thee
.
<EOS>
How
can
he
who
deserts
his
own
colours
at
the
first
smell
of
gunpowder
expect
faith
in
any
ally
?
<EOS>
Thou
thyself
hast
sought
the
battle
-
field
:
fight
out
the
battle
manfully
now
thou
art
there
.
<EOS>
Courage
,
Bishop
,
courage
!
<EOS>
Frowns
can
not
kill
,
nor
can
sharp
words
break
any
bones
.
<EOS>
After
all
,
the
apron
is
thine
own
.
<EOS>
She
can
appoint
no
wardens
,
give

no
benefices
,
nominate
no

,
an
'
thou
art
but
true
to
thyself
.
<EOS>
Up
,
man
,
and
at
her
with
a
constant
heart
.
  
<EOS>
Some
little
monitor
within
the
bishop
's

so

.
<EOS>
But

was
another
monitor
there
which
advised

differently
,
and
as
follows
.
<EOS>
Remember
,
Bishop
,
she
is
a
woman
,
and
such

woman
too
as
thou
<EOS>
well

:
<EOS>
a
battle
of
words
with
such
a
woman
is
the
very
mischief
.
<EOS>
Were
it
not
better
for
thee
to
carry
on
this
war
,
if
it
must

,
from
behind
thine
own

in

own

?
<EOS>
Does
not
every
cock
fight
best
on
his
own
dunghill
?
<EOS>
Thy
daughters
also
are
here
,
the
pledges
of

love
,
the

of

:

that

should
see
thee
in
the

thy
victory
over

?
<EOS>
Nay
,
is

well
that
they
should
see
thee
in
the
possible

of
thy
defeat
?
<EOS>
Besides
,
hast
thou
not
chosen

with
wonderful
little

,
indeed
with
no

that

?
<EOS>
Will

not

that

art

in

;
that

hast

in

,

turn

because

?
<EOS>
Art

not

Christian

,
and

thy

to
be
held
sacred
<EOS>
whatever

?
<EOS>
Return
,

,

for
some

in

at

against

less

against
thee
.
  
<EOS>
All

passed
within

bishop
's

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
£
4
17s
.
<EOS>
7d
.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
Of

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Slope

!
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.
"
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"
Certainly

,

.
<EOS>
Nothing

.
<EOS>
But

,

Slope

,

"

,
"

;
"

anything

,

,

.
<EOS>
If

is

,

.
<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>
It

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

,

,

,
"

,

room
<EOS>
,

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
He

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Slope
,

!
<EOS>
I

Slope

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

Slope
.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He

,
"

;
"
I

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

,

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There

're

,
"

;
"
he
's

;

,

,

;

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He

's

,
"

;
"

,

's

;

all
the
currant
pie
he
ate
yesterday
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
When
Mr.
Slope
got

he
soon
learnt
from

bishop
,
as

,

's

.
<EOS>
Dr.
Proudie
let

something
as

"
this

only
"
and
"
keeping
all

about

exclusively
in
his
own
hands
.
"
<EOS>
But
he
was
quite
decided
about
Mr.
Harding
;
and
as
Mr.
Slope
did
not

to

and
the

against
him
,
he
did

anything
but

.
  
<EOS>
He
merely
remarked
that
he
would
of
course
carry
out
the
bishop
's
views
and
that
he
was
quite
sure
that
if
the
bishop
trusted
to
his
own
