things
in
the
diocese
would
certainly
be
well
ordered
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
knew
that
if
you
hit
a
nail
on
the
head
often
enough
,
it
will
penetrate
at
last
.
  
<EOS>
He
was
sitting
alone
in
his
room
on
the
same
evening
when
a
light
knock
was
made
on
his
door
,
and
before
he
could
answer
it
<EOS>
the
door
was
opened
,
and
his
patroness
appeared
.
<EOS>
He
was
all
smiles
in
a
moment
,
but
so
was
not
she
also
.
<EOS>
She
took
,
however
,
the
chair
that
was
offered
to
her
,
and
thus
began
her
expostulation
:
  
"
Mr.
Slope
,
I
did
not
at
all
approve
your
conduct
the
other
night
with
that
Italian
woman
.
<EOS>
Anyone
would
have
thought
that
you
were
her
lover
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Good
gracious
,
my
dear
madam
,
"
said
Mr.
Slope
with
a
look
of
horror
.
<EOS>
"
Why
,
she
is
a
married
woman
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
more
than
I
know
,
"
said
Mrs.
Proudie
;
"
however
she
chooses
to
pass
for
such
.
<EOS>
But
married
or
not
married
,
such
attention
as
you
paid
to
her
was
improper
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
believe
that
you
would
wish
to
give
offence
in
my
drawing
-
room
,
Mr.
Slope
,
but
I
owe
it
to
myself
and
my
daughters
to
tell
you
that
I
disapprove
of
your
conduct
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
opened
wide
his
huge
protruding
eyes
and
stared
out
of
them
with
a
look
of
well
-
feigned
surprise
.
<EOS>
"
Why
,
Mrs.
Proudie
,
"
said
he
,
"
I
did
but
fetch
her
something
to
eat
when
she
said
she
was
hungry
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
have
called
on
her
since
,
"
continued
she
,
looking
at
the
culprit
with
the
stern
look
of
a
detective
policeman
in
the
act
of
declaring
himself
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
turned
over
in
his
mind
whether
it
would
be
well
for
him
to
tell
this
termagant
at
once
that
he
should
call
on
whom
he
liked
and
do
what
he
liked
,
but
he
remembered
that
his
footing
in
Barchester
was
not
yet
sufficiently
firm
,
and
that
it
would
be
better
for
him
to
pacify
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
certainly
called
since
at
Dr.
Stanhope
's
house
,
and
certainly
saw
Madame
Neroni
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
and
you
saw
her
alone
,
"
said
the
episcopal
Argus
.
  
<EOS>
"
Undoubtedly
,
I
did
,
"
said
Mr.
Slope
,
"
but
that
was
because
nobody
else
happened
to
be
in
the
room
.
<EOS>
Surely
it
was
no
fault
of
mine
if
the
rest
of
the
family
were
out
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
not
,
but
I
assure
you
,
Mr.
Slope
,
you
will
fall
greatly
in
my
estimation
if
I
find
that
you
allow
yourself
to
be
caught
by
the
lures
of
that
woman
.
<EOS>
I
know
women
better
than
you
do
,
Mr.
Slope
,
and
you
may
believe
me
that
that
signora
,
as
she
calls
herself
,
is
not
a
fitting
companion
for
a
strict
evangelical
unmarried
young
clergyman
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
How
Mr.
Slope
would
have
liked
to
laugh
at
her
,
had
he
dared
!
<EOS>
But
he
did
not
dare
.
<EOS>
So
he
merely
said
,
"
I
can
assure
you
,
Mrs.
Proudie
,
the
lady
in
question
is
nothing
to
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
hope
not
,
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
But
I
have
considered
it
my
duty
to
give
you
this
caution
.
<EOS>
And
now
there
is
another
thing
I
feel
myself
called
on
to
speak
about
:
it
is
your
conduct
to
the
bishop
,
Mr.
Slope
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
conduct
to
the
bishop
,
"
said
he
,
now
truly
surprised
and
ignorant
what
the
lady
alluded
to
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Mr.
Slope
,
your
conduct
to
the
bishop
.
<EOS>
It
is
by
no
means
what
I
would
wish
to
see
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Has
the
bishop
said
anything
,
Mrs.
Proudie
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
the
bishop
has
said
nothing
.
<EOS>
He
probably
thinks
that
any
remarks
on
the
matter
will
come
better
from
me
,
who
first
introduced
you
to
his
lordship
's
notice
.
<EOS>
The
fact
is
,
Mr.
Slope
,
you
are
a
little
inclined
to
take
too
much
upon
yourself
.
"
  
<EOS>
An
angry
spot
showed
itself
on
Mr.
Slope
's
cheeks
,
and
it
was
with
difficulty
that
he
controlled
himself
.
<EOS>
But
he
did
do
so
,
and
sat
quite
silent
while
the
lady
went
on
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
the
fault
of
many
young
men
in
your
position
,
and
therefore
the
bishop
is
not
inclined
at
present
to
resent
it
.
<EOS>
You
will
,
no
doubt
,
soon
learn
what
is
required
from
you
and
what
is
not
.
<EOS>
If
you
will
take
my
advice
,
however
,
you
will
be
careful
not
to
obtrude
advice
upon
the
bishop
in
any
matter
touching
patronage
.
<EOS>
If
his
lordship
wants
advice
,
he
knows
where
to
look
for
it
.
"
<EOS>
And
then
having
added
to
her
counsel
a
string
of
platitudes
as
to
what
was
desirable
and
what
not
desirable
in
the
conduct
of
a
strictly
evangelical
unmarried
young
clergyman
,
Mrs.
Proudie
retreated
,
leaving
the
chaplain
to
his
thoughts
.
  
<EOS>
The
upshot
of
his
thoughts
was
this
,
that
there
certainly
was
not
room
in
the
diocese
for
the
energies
of
both
himself
and
Mrs.
Proudie
,
and
that
it
behoved
him
quickly
to
ascertain
whether
his
energies
or
hers
were
to
prevail
.
   
<EOS>
The
Widow
's
Persecution
 
Early
on
the
following
morning
Mr.
Slope
was
summoned
to
the
bishop
's
dressing
-
room
,
and
went
there
fully
expecting
that
he
should
find
his
lordship
very
indignant
and
spirited
up
by
his
wife
to
repeat
the
rebuke
which
she
had
administered
on
the
previous
day
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
had
resolved
that
at
any
rate
from
him
he
would
not
stand
it
,
and
entered
the
dressing
-
room
in
rather
a
combative
disposition
;
but
he
found
the
bishop
in
the
most
placid
and
gentlest
of
humours
.
<EOS>
His
lordship
complained
of
being
rather
unwell
,
had
a
slight
headache
,
and
was
not
quite
the
thing
in
his
stomach
;
but
there
was
nothing
the
matter
with
his
temper
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Slope
,
"
said
he
,
taking
the
chaplain
's
proffered
hand
,
"
Archdeacon
Grantly
is
to
call
on
me
this
morning
,
and
I
really
am
not
fit
to
see
him
.
<EOS>
I
fear
I
must
trouble
you
to
see
him
for
me
;
"
and
then
Dr.
Proudie
proceeded
to
explain
what
it
was
that
must
be
said
to
Dr.
Grantly
.
<EOS>
He
was
to
be
told
in
fact
,
in
the
civilest
words
in
which
the
tidings
could
be
conveyed
,
that
Mr.
Harding
having
refused
the
wardenship
,
the
appointment
had
been
offered
to
Mr.
Quiverful
and
accepted
by
him
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
again
pointed
out
to
his
patron
that
he
thought
he
was
perhaps
not
quite
wise
in
his
decision
,
and
this
<EOS>
he
did
_
sotto
<EOS>
voce
_
.
<EOS>
But
even
with
this
precaution
it
was
not
safe
to
say
much
,
and
during
the
little
that
he
did
say
,
the
bishop
made
a
very
slight
,
but
still
a
very
ominous
gesture
with
his
thumb
towards
the
door
which
opened
from
his
dressing
-
room
to
some
inner
sanctuary
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
at
once
took
the
hint
and
said
no
more
,
but
he
perceived
that
there
was
to
be
confidence
between
him
and
his
patron
,
that
the
league
desired
by
him
was
to
be
made
,
and
that
this
appointment
of
Mr.
Quiverful
was
to
be
the
last
sacrifice
offered
on
the
altar
of
conjugal
obedience
.
<EOS>
All
this
Mr.
Slope
read
in
the
slight
motion
of
the
bishop
's
thumb
,
and
he
read
it
correctly
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
need
of
parchments
and
seals
,
of
attestations
,
explanations
,
and
professions
.
<EOS>
The
bargain
was
understood
between
them
,
and
Mr.
Slope
gave
the
bishop
his
hand
upon
it
.
<EOS>
The
bishop
understood
the
little
extra
squeeze
,
and
an
intelligible
gleam
of
assent
twinkled
in
his
eye
.
  
<EOS>
"
Pray
be
civil
to
the
archdeacon
,
Mr.
Slope
,
"
said
he
out
loud
,
"
but
make
him
quite
understand
that
in
this
matter
Mr.
Harding
has
put
it
out
of
my
power
to
oblige
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
would
be
a
calumny
on
Mrs.
Proudie
to
suggest
that
she
was
sitting
in
her
bedroom
with
her
ear
at
the
keyhole
during
this
interview
.
<EOS>
She
had
within
her
a
spirit
of
decorum
which
prevented
her
from
descending
to
such
baseness
.
<EOS>
To
put
her
ear
to
a
keyhole
,
or
to
listen
at
a
chink
,
was
a
trick
for
a
housemaid
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Proudie
knew
this
,
and
therefore
did
not
do
it
;
but
she
stationed
herself
as
near
to
the
door
as
she
well
could
,
that
she
might
,
if
possible
,
get
the
advantage
which
the
housemaid
would
have
had
,
without
descending
to
the
housemaid
's
artifice
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
little
,
however
,
that
she
heard
,
and
that
little
was
only
sufficient
to
deceive
her
.
<EOS>
She
saw
nothing
of
that
friendly
pressure
,
perceived
nothing
of
that
concluded
bargain
;
she
did
not
even
dream
of
the
treacherous
resolves
which
those
two
false
men
had
made
together
to
upset
her
in
the
pride
of
her
station
,
to
dash
the
cup
from
her
lip
before
she
had
drunk
of
it
,
to
sweep
away
all
her
power
before
she
had
tasted
its
sweets
!
<EOS>
Traitors
that
they
were
,
the
husband
of
her
bosom
and
the
outcast
whom
she
had
fostered
and
brought
to
the
warmth
of
the
world
's
brightest
fireside
!
<EOS>
But
neither
of
them
had
the
magnanimity
of
this
woman
.
<EOS>
Though
two
men
have
thus
leagued
themselves
together
against
her
,
even
yet
the
battle
is
not
lost
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
felt
pretty
sure
that
Dr.
Grantly
would
decline
the
honour
of
seeing
him
,
and
such
turned
out
to
be
the
case
.
<EOS>
The
archdeacon
,
when
the
palace
door
was
opened
to
him
,
was
greeted
by
a
note
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
presented
his
compliments
,
&
c.
&
<EOS>
c.
The
bishop
was
ill
in
his
room
and
very
greatly
regretted
,
&
c.
&
<EOS>
c.
Mr.
Slope
had
been
charged
with
the
bishop
's
views
,
and
if
agreeable
to
the
archdeacon
,
would
do
himself
the
honour
,
&
c.
&
c.
<EOS>
The
archdeacon
,
however
,
was
not
agreeable
,
and
having
read
his
note
in
the
hall
,
crumpled
it
up
in
his
hand
,
and
muttering
something
about
sorrow
for
his
lordship
's
illness
,
took
his
leave
,
without
sending
as
much
as
a
verbal
message
in
answer
to
Mr.
Slope
's
note
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ill
!
"
said
the
archdeacon
to
himself
as
he
flung
himself
into
his
brougham
.
<EOS>
"
The
man
is
absolutely
a
coward
.
<EOS>
He
is
afraid
to
see
me
.
<EOS>
Ill
,
indeed
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
archdeacon
was
never
ill
himself
,
and
did
not
therefore
understand
that
anyone
else
could
in
truth
be
prevented
by
illness
from
keeping
an
appointment
.
<EOS>
He
regarded
all
such
excuses
as
subterfuges
,
and
in
the
present
instance
he
was
not
far
wrong
.
  
<EOS>
Dr.
Grantly
desired
to
be
driven
to
his
father
-
in
-
law
's
lodgings
in
the
High
Street
,
and
hearing
from
the
servant
that
Mr.
Harding
was
at
his
daughter
's
,
followed
him
to
Mrs.
Bold
's
house
,
and
there
found
him
.
<EOS>
The
archdeacon
was
fuming
with
rage
when
he
got
into
the
drawing
-
room
,
and
had
by
this
time
nearly
forgotten
the
pusillanimity
of
the
bishop
in
the
villainy
of
the
chaplain
.
  
<EOS>
"
Look
at
that
,
"
said
he
,
throwing
Mr.
Slope
's
crumpled
note
to
Mr.
Harding
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
to
be
told
that
if
I
choose
I
may
have
the
honour
of
seeing
Mr.
Slope
,
and
that
too
after
a
positive
engagement
with
the
bishop
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
he
says
the
bishop
is
ill
,
"
said
Mr.
Harding
.
  
<EOS>
"
Pshaw
!
<EOS>
You
do
n't
mean
to
say
that
you
are
deceived
by
such
an
excuse
as
that
.
<EOS>
He
was
well
enough
yesterday
.
<EOS>
Now
I
tell
you
what
,
I
will
see
the
bishop
,
and
I
will
tell
him
also
very
plainly
what
I
think
of
his
conduct
.
<EOS>
I
will
see
him
,
or
else
Barchester
will
soon
be
too
hot
to
hold
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
Eleanor
was
sitting
in
the
room
,
but
Dr.
Grantly
had
hardly
noticed
her
in
his
anger
.
<EOS>
Eleanor
now
said
to
him
with
the
greatest
innocence
,
"
I
wish
you
had
seen
Mr.
Slope
,
<EOS>
Dr.
Grantly
,
because
I
think
perhaps
it
might
have
done
good
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
archdeacon
turned
on
her
with
almost
brutal
wrath
.
<EOS>
Had
she
at
once
owned
that
she
had
accepted
Mr.
Slope
for
her
second
husband
<EOS>
,
he
could
hardly
have
felt
more
convinced
of
her
belonging
body
and
soul
to
the
Slope
and
Proudie
party
than
he
now
did
on
hearing
her
express
such
a
wish
as
this
.
<EOS>
Poor
Eleanor
!
  
<EOS>
"
See
him
!
"
said
the
archdeacon
glaring
at
her
.
"
<EOS>
And
why
am
I
to
be
called
on
to
lower
myself
in
the
world
's
esteem
and
my
own
by
coming
in
contact
with
such
a
man
as
that
?
<EOS>
I
have
hitherto
lived
among
gentlemen
,
and
do
not
mean
to
be
dragged
into
other
company
by
anybody
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Poor
Mr.
Harding
well
knew
what
the
archdeacon
meant
,
but
Eleanor
was
as
innocent
as
her
own
baby
.
<EOS>
She
could
not
understand
how
the
archdeacon
could
consider
himself
to
be
dragged
into
bad
company
by
condescending
to

to
Mr.
Slope
for
a
few
minutes
when
the
interests
of
her
father
might
be
served
by
his
doing
so
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
was
talking
for
a
full
hour
yesterday
to
Mr.
Slope
,
"
said
she
with
some
little
assumption
of
dignity
,
"
and
I
did
not
find
myself
lowered
by
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Perhaps
not
,
"
said
he
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
if
you
'll
be
good

to
allow

,
I

judge
for

.
<EOS>
And
I
tell

what
,
Eleanor
;
it

if
you
will
allow

be
guided

of

your

.
<EOS>
If

do

,
you
will

apt
to

that
you
have
no
friends
left
who
can
advise

.
"
  
<EOS>
Eleanor
blushed
up
to
the
roots

.
<EOS>
But
even
now
she
had
not
the

what
was

in

's

.
<EOS>
No

of
love
-
making
or
love
-

had
yet

to
her

since
the
death
of
poor
John
Bold
,
and
if

that
such

should
spring
there
,
the
man
must
be
far
different
from
Mr.
Slope
that
could
give
it
birth
.
  
<EOS>
Nevertheless
Eleanor
blushed
deeply
,
for
she
felt
she
was
charged
with
improper
conduct
,
and
she
did
so
with
the
more
inward
pain
because
her
father
did
not
instantly
rally
to
her
side
 
<EOS>
that
father
for
whose

and
love
she
had
submitted
to

of
Mr.
Slope
's
confidence
.
<EOS>
She
had
given
a
detailed
account
of
all
that
had
passed
to
her
father
,
and
though

had
not

about
Mr.
Slope
's

touching
the
hospital
,
yet
he
had
said
nothing
to
make

that
she
had
been
wrong
in
talking
to
him
.
  
<EOS>
She
was
far
too
angry
to
humble

before
her
brother
-
in
-
law
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
she
had
never
accustomed

to

,
and
they
had
never

.
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
the
least

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
called

Papa
's

about
the

,

as

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Friendly

!
"

.
  
<EOS>

wrong

,
"

,
"

I

;

,

,

Papa
together
;
"
<EOS>
so

,

.
  
<EOS>
All
this
made
Mr.
Harding
very
unhappy
.
<EOS>
It
was
quite
clear
that
the
archdeacon
and
his
wife
had
made
up
their
minds
that
Eleanor
was
going
to
marry
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
could
not
really
bring
himself
to
think
that
she
would
do
so
,
but
yet
he
could
not
deny
that
circumstances

that
the
man
's
company
was
not

to

.
<EOS>
She
was
now
constantly
seeing
him
,
and
yet
she
received
visits
from
no
other
unmarried
gentleman
.
<EOS>
She
always
took
his
part
when
his
conduct
was
canvassed
,
although
she
was
aware
how
personally

to

.
<EOS>
Then
,
again
,
Mr.
Harding
felt
that

Slope
,

nothing

.
<EOS>
She
had
full

,
and

,
as

,

not

by

a

who
stood
so
well

Slope
did
.
<EOS>
As
for

,
and

from

,
that
,

,
would

out

.
<EOS>
If
she
should

this
man
,

as

.
<EOS>
His
Eleanor
,
his
own
old

in
their
old

,
must
still
be
the
friend
of

,
the

.
<EOS>
Let

off
,
he

not
.
<EOS>
If

that

,

.
<EOS>
Anything

.
  
<EOS>
Such

,

against

,

.
<EOS>
It

.
 
<EOS>
Alas
!
<EOS>
he
never

.
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Harding
was
by

.
<EOS>
In

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
And

that

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
He

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
He

some

,

as

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
She
'll

that
man

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

,
"

.
<EOS>

,

?
<EOS>

.

.

<EOS>

.

<EOS>
The

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

the

.
<EOS>
Here

.
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
Of

.
<EOS>
It

,

"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
wo

.
"
  
<EOS>
Eleanor

.
<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
She

,

.

,

;

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

;

.
  
<EOS>
"
The

!
"

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"

,

.

"

.

"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
is
certainly
becoming
of
some

in
Barchester
.
   
<EOS>
Barchester
by
Moonlight
 
<EOS>
There
was
much
cause
for
grief
and
occasional
perturbation
of
spirits
in
the
Stanhope
family
,
but
yet
they
rarely
seemed
to
be
grieved
or
to
be
disturbed
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
peculiar
gift
of
each
of
them
that
each
was
able
to
bear
his
or
her
own
burden
without
complaint
,
and
perhaps
without
sympathy
.
<EOS>
They
habitually
looked
on
the
sunny
side
of
the
wall
,
if
there
was
a
gleam
on
either
side
for
them
to
look
at
;
if
there
was
none
,
they
endured
the
shade
with
an
indifference
which
,
if
not
stoical
,
answered
the
end
at
which
the
Stoics
aimed
.
<EOS>
Old
Stanhope
could
not
but
feel
that
he
had
ill
-
performed
his
duties
as
a
father
and
a
clergyman
,
and
could
hardly
look
forward
to
his
own
death
without
grief
at
the
position
in
which
he
would
leave
his
family
.
<EOS>
His
income
for
many
years
had
been
as
high
as
£
3,000
a
year
,
and
yet
they
had
among
them
no
other
provision
than
their
mother
's
fortune
of
£
10,000
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
only
spent
his
income
,
but
was
in
debt
.
<EOS>
Yet
with
all
this
he
seldom
showed
much
outward
sign
of
trouble
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
the
same
with
the
mother
.
<EOS>
If
she
added
little
to
the
pleasures
of
her
children
,
she
detracted
still
less
:
she
neither
grumbled
at
her
lot
,
nor
spoke
much
of
her
past
or
future
sufferings
;
as
long
as
she
had
a
maid
to
adjust
her
dress
,
and
had
those
dresses
well
made
,
nature
with
her
was
satisfied
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
same
with
the
children
.
<EOS>
Charlotte
never
rebuked
her
father
with
the
prospect
of
their
future
poverty
,
nor
did
it
seem
to
grieve
her
that
she
was
becoming
an
old
maid
so
quickly
;
her
temper
was
rarely
ruffled
,
and
,
if
we
might
judge
by
her
appearance
,
she
was
always
happy
.
<EOS>
The
signora
was
not
so
sweet
-
tempered
,
but
she
possessed
much
enduring
courage
;
she
seldom
complained
 
never
,
indeed
,
to
her
family
.
<EOS>
Though
she
had
a
cause
for
affliction
which
would
have
utterly
broken
down
the
heart
of
most
women
as
beautiful
as
she
and
as
devoid
of
all
religious
support
,
yet
she
bore
her
suffering
in
silence
,
or
alluded
to
it
only
to
elicit
the
sympathy
and
stimulate
the
admiration
of
the
men
with
whom
she
flirted
.
<EOS>
As
to
Bertie
,
one
would
have
imagined
from
the
sound
of
his
voice
and
the
gleam
of
his
eye
that
he
had
not
a
sorrow
nor
a
care
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
Nor
had
he
.
<EOS>
He
was
incapable
of
anticipating
to
-
morrow
's
griefs
.
<EOS>
The
prospect
of
future
want
no
more
disturbed
his
appetite
<EOS>
than
does
that
of
the
butcher
's
knife
disturb
the
appetite
of
the
sheep
.
  
<EOS>
Such
was
the
usual
tenor
of
their
way
;
but
there
were
rare
exceptions
.
<EOS>
Occasionally
the
father
would
allow
an
angry
glance
to
fall
from
his
eye
,
and
the
lion
would
send
forth
a
low
dangerous
roar
as
though
he
meditated
some
deed
of
blood
.
<EOS>
Occasionally
also
Madame
Neroni
would
become
bitter
against
mankind
,
more
than
usually
antagonistic
to
the
world
's
decencies
,
and
would
seem
as
though
she
was
about
to
break
from
her
moorings
and
allow
herself
to
be
carried
forth
by
the
tide
of
her
feelings
to
utter
ruin
and
shipwreck
.
<EOS>
She
,
however
,
like
the
rest
of
them
,
had
no
real
feelings
,
could
feel
no
true
passion
.
<EOS>
In
that
was
her
security
.
<EOS>
Before
she
resolved
on
any
contemplated
escapade
she
would
make
a
small
calculation
,
and
generally
summed
up
that
the
Stanhope
villa
or
even
Barchester
close
was
better
than
the
world
at
large
.
  
<EOS>
They
were
most
irregular
in
their
hours
.
<EOS>
The
father
was
generally
the
earliest
in
the
breakfast
-
parlour
,
and
Charlotte
would
soon
follow
and
give
him
his
coffee
,
but
the
others
breakfasted
anywhere
,
anyhow
,
and
at
any
time
.
<EOS>
On
the
morning
after
the
archdeacon
's
futile
visit
to
the
palace
,
Dr.
Stanhope
came
downstairs
with
an
ominously
dark
look
about
his
eyebrows
;
his
white
locks
were
rougher
than
usual
,
and
he
breathed
thickly
and
loudly
as
he
took
his
seat
in
his
armchair
.
<EOS>
He
had
open
letters
in
his
hand
,
and
when
Charlotte
came
into
the
room
,
he
was
still
reading
them
.
<EOS>
She
went
up
and
kissed
him
as
was
her
wo
nt
,
but
he
hardly
noticed
her
as
she
did
so
,
and
she
knew
at
once
that
something
was
the
matter
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
meaning
of
that
?
"
<EOS>
said
he
,
throwing
over
the
table
a
letter
with
a
Milan
postmark
.
<EOS>
Charlotte
was
a
little
frightened
as
she
took
it
up
,
but
her
mind
was
relieved
when
she
saw
that
it
was
merely
the
bill
of
their
Italian
milliner
.
<EOS>
The
sum
total
was
certainly
large
,
but
not
so
large
as
to
create
an
important
row
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
for
our
clothes
,
Papa
,
for
six
months
before
we
came
here
.
<EOS>
The
three
of
us
ca
n't
dress
for
nothing
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
indeed
!
"
said
he
,
looking
at
the
figures
which
,
in
Milanese
denominations
,
were
certainly
monstrous
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
man
should
have
sent
it
to
me
,
"
said
Charlotte
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
wish
he
had
with
all
my
heart
 
if
you
would
have
paid
it
.
<EOS>
I
see
enough
in
it
to
know
that
three
quarters
of
it
are
for
Madeline
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
has
little
else
to
amuse
her
,
sir
,
"
said
Charlotte
with
true
good
nature
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
I
suppose
he
has
nothing
else
to
amuse
him
,
"
said
the
doctor
,
throwing
over
another
letter
to
his
daughter
.
<EOS>
It
was
from
some
member
of
the
family
of
Sidonia
,
and
politely
requested
the
father
to
pay
a
small
trifle
of
£
700
,
being
the
amount
of
a
bill
discounted
in
favour
of
Mr.
Ethelbert
Stanhope
and
now
overdue
for
a
period
of
nine
months
.
  
<EOS>
Charlotte
read
the
letter
,
slowly
folded
it
up
,
and
put
it
under
the
edge
of
the
tea
-
tray
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
he
has
nothing
to
amuse
him
but
discounting
bills
with
Jews
.
<EOS>
Does
he
think
I
'll
pay
that
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
he
thinks
no
such
thing
,
"
said
she
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
who
does
he
think
will
pay
it
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
As
far
as
honesty
goes
I
suppose
it
wo
n't
much
matter
if
it
is
never
paid
,
"
said
she
.
<EOS>
"
I
dare
say
he
got
very
little
of
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
it
wo
n't
much
matter
either
,
"
said
the
father
,
"
if
he
goes
to
prison
and
rots
there
.
<EOS>
It
seems
to
me
that
that
's
the
other
alternative
.
"
  
<EOS>
Dr.
Stanhope
spoke
of
the
custom
of
his
youth
.
<EOS>
But
his
daughter
,
though
she
had
lived
so
long
abroad
,
was
much
more
completely
versed
in
the
ways
of
the
English
world
.
<EOS>
"
If
the
man
arrests
him
,
"
said
she
,
"
he
must
go
through
the
court
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
is
thus
,
thou
great
family
of
Sidonia
 
<EOS>
it
is
thus
that
we
Gentiles
treat
thee
,
when
,
in
our
extremest
need
,
thou
and
thine
have
aided
us
with
mountains
of
gold
as
big
as
lions
 
and
occasionally
with
wine
-
warrants
and
orders
for
dozens
of
dressing
-
cases
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
,
and
become
an
insolvent
?
"
said
the
doctor
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
's
that
already
,
"
said
Charlotte
,
wishing
always
to
get
over
a
difficulty
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
a
condition
,
"
said
the
doctor
,
"
for
the
son
of
a
clergyman
of
the
Church
of
England
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
see
why
clergymen
's
sons
should
pay
their
debts
more
than
other
young
men
,
"
said
Charlotte
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
's
had
as
much
from
me
since
he
left
school
as
is
held
sufficient
for
the
eldest
son
of
many
a
nobleman
,
"
said
the
angry
father
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
,
"
said
Charlotte
,
"
give
him
another
chance
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
!
"
said
the
doctor
,
"
do
you
mean
that
I
am
to
pay
that
Jew
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
no
!
<EOS>
I
would
n't
pay
him
,
he
must
take
his
chance
;
and
if
the
worst
comes
to
the
worst
,
Bertie
must
go
abroad
.
<EOS>
But
I
want
you
to
be
civil
to
Bertie
and
let
him
remain
here
as
long
as
we
stop
.
<EOS>
He
has
a
plan
in
his
head
that
may
put
him
on
his
feet
after
all
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Has
he
any
plan
for
following
up
his
profession
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
he
'll
do
that
too
;
but
that
must
follow
.
<EOS>
He
's
thinking
of
getting
married
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Just
at
that
moment
the
door
opened
,
and
Bertie
came
in
whistling
.
<EOS>
The
doctor
immediately
devoted
himself
to
his
egg
and
allowed
Bertie
to
whistle
himself
round
to
his
sister
's
side
without
noticing
him
.
  
<EOS>
Charlotte
gave
a
sign
to
him
with
her
eye
,
first
glancing
at
her
father
,
and
then
at
the
letter
,
the
corner
of
which
peeped
out
from
under
the
tea
-
tray
.
<EOS>
Bertie
saw
and
understood
,
and
with
the
quiet
motion
of
a
cat
he
abstracted
the
letter
and
made
himself
acquainted
with
its
contents
.
<EOS>
The
doctor
,
however
,
had
seen
him
,
deep
as
he
appeared
to
be
mersed
in
his
egg
-
shell
,
and
said
in
his
harshest
voice
,
"
Well
,
sir
,
do
you
know
that
gentleman
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
"
said
Bertie
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
a
sort
of
acquaintance
with
him
,
but
none
that
can
justify
him
in
troubling
you
.
<EOS>
If
you
will
allow
me
,
sir
,
I
will
answer
this
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
At
any
rate
I
sha
n't
,
"
said
the
father
,
and
then
he
added
,
after
a
pause
,
"
Is
it
true
,
sir
,
that
you
owe
the
man
£
700
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
said
Bertie
,
"
I
think
I
should
be
inclined
to
dispute
the
amount
,
if
I
were
in
a
condition
to
pay
him
such
of
it
as
I
really
do
owe
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Has
he
your
bill
for
£
700
?
"
said
the
father
,
speaking
very
loudly
and
very
angrily
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
believe
he
has
,
"
said
Bertie
,
"
but
all
the
money
I
ever
got
from
him
was
£
150
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
what
became
of
the
£
550
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
sir
,
the
commission
was
£
100
or
so
,
and
I
took
the
remainder
in
paving
-

and
rocking
-

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Paving
-
stones
and
rocking
-
horses
!
"
said
the
doctor
.
<EOS>
"
Where
are
they
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
sir
,
I
suppose
they
are
in
London
somewhere
 
<EOS>
but
I
'll
inquire
if
you
wish
for

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
's
an
idiot
,
"
said
the
doctor
,
"
and
it
's
sheer
folly
to
waste
more
money
on
him
.
<EOS>
Nothing
can
save
him
from
ruin
,
"
and
so
saying
,
the
unhappy
father
walked
out
of
the
room
.
  
<EOS>
"
Would
the
governor
like
to
have
the
paving
-
stones
?
"
said
Bertie
to
his
sister
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
tell
you
what
,
"
said
she
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
do
n't
take
care
,
you
will
find
yourself
loose
upon
the
world
without
even
a
house
over
your
head
;
you
do
n't
know
him
as
well
as
I
do
.
<EOS>
He
's
very
angry
.
"
  
<EOS>
Bertie
stroked
his
big
beard
,
sipped
his
tea
,
chatted
over
his
misfortunes
in
a
half
-
comic
,
half
-
serious
tone
,
and
ended
by
promising
his
sister
that
he
would
do
his
very
best
to
make
himself
agreeable
to
the
Widow
Bold
.
<EOS>
Then
Charlotte
followed
her
father
to
his
own
room
,
softened
down
his
wrath
,
and
persuaded
him
to
say
nothing
more
about
the
Jew
bill
discounter
,
at
any
rate
for
a
few
weeks
.
<EOS>
He
even
went
so
far
as
to
say
he
would
pay
the
£
700
,
or
at
any
rate
settle
the
bill
,
if
he
saw
a
certainty
of
his
son
's
securing
for
himself
anything
like
a
decent
provision
in
life
.
<EOS>
Nothing
was
said
openly
between
them
about
poor
Eleanor
,
but
the
father
and
the
daughter
understood
each
other
.
  
<EOS>
They
all
met
together
in
the
drawing
-
room
at
nine
o'clock
,
in
perfect
good
humour
with
each
other
,
and
about
that
hour
Mrs.
Bold
was
announced
.
<EOS>
She
had
never
been
in
the
house
before
,
though
she
had
of
course
called
,
and
now
she
felt
it
strange
to
find
herself
there
in
her
usual
evening
dress
,
entering
the
drawing
-
room
of
these
strangers
in
this
friendly
,
unceremonious
way
,
as
though
she
had
known
them
all
her
life
.
<EOS>
But
in
three
minutes
they
made
her
at
home
.
<EOS>
Charlotte
tripped
downstairs
and
took
her
bonnet
from
her
,
and
Bertie
came
to
relieve
her
from
her
shawl
,
and
the
signora
smiled
on
her
as
she
could
smile
when
she
chose
to
be
gracious
,
and
the
old
doctor
shook
hands
with
her
in
a
kind
benedictory
manner
that
went
to
her
heart
at
once
and
made
her
feel
that
he
must
be
a
good
man
.
  
<EOS>
She
had
not
been
seated
for
above
five
minutes
when
the
door
again
opened
and
Mr.
Slope
was
announced
.
<EOS>
She
felt
rather
surprised
,
because
she
was
told
that
nobody
was
to
be
there
,
and
it
was
very
evident
from
the
manner
of
some
of
them
that
Mr.
Slope
was
not
unexpected
.
<EOS>
But
still
there
was
not
much
in
it
.
<EOS>
In
such
invitations
a
bachelor
or
two
more
or
less
are
always
spoken
of
as
nobodies
,
and
there
was
no
reason
why
Mr.
Slope
should
not
drink
tea
at
Dr.
Stanhope
's
as
well
as
Eleanor
herself
.
<EOS>
He
,
however
,
was
very
much
surprised
and
not
very
much
gratified
at
finding
that
his
own
embryo
spouse
made
one
of
the
party
.
<EOS>
He
had
come
there
to
gratify
himself
by
gazing
on
Madame
Neroni
's
beauty
and
listening
to
and
returning
her
flattery
:
and
though
he
had
not
owned
as
much
to
himself
,
he
still
felt
that
if
he
spent
the
evening
as
he
had
intended
to
do
,
he
might
probably
not
thereby
advance
his
suit
with
Mrs.
Bold
.
  
<EOS>
The
signora
,
who
had
no
idea
of
a
rival
,
received
Mr.
Slope
with
her
usual
marks
of
distinction
.
<EOS>
As
he
took
her
hand
,
she
made
some
confidential
communication
to
him
in
a
low
voice
,
declaring
that
she
had
a
plan
to
communicate
to
him
after
tea
,
and
was
evidently
prepared
to
go
on
with
her
work
of
reducing
the
chaplain
to
a
state
of
captivity
.
<EOS>
Poor
Mr.
Slope
was
rather
beside
himself
.
<EOS>
He
thought
that
Eleanor
could
not
but
have
learnt
from
his
demeanour
that
he
was
an
admirer
of
her
own
,
and
he
had
also
flattered
himself
that
the
idea
was
not
unacceptable
to
her
.
<EOS>
What
would
she
think
of
him
if
he
now
devoted
himself
to
a
married
woman
!
  
<EOS>
But
Eleanor
was
not
inclined
to
be
severe
in
her
criticisms
on
him
in
this
respect
,
and
felt
no
annoyance
of
any
kind
,
when
she
found
herself
seated
between
Bertie
and
Charlotte
Stanhope
.
<EOS>
She
had
no
suspicion
of
Mr.
Slope
's
intentions
;
she
had
no
suspicion
even
of
the
suspicion
of
other
people
;
but
still
she
felt
well
-
pleased
not
to
have
Mr.
Slope
too
near
to
her
.
  
<EOS>
And
she
was
not
ill
-
pleased
to
have
Bertie
Stanhope
near
her
.
<EOS>
It
was
rarely
indeed
that
he
failed
to
make
an
agreeable
impression
on
strangers
.
<EOS>
With
a
bishop
indeed
who
thought
much
of
his
own
dignity
it
was
possible
that
he
might
fail
,
but
hardly
with
a
young
and
pretty
woman
.
<EOS>
He
possessed
the
tact
of
becoming
instantly
intimate
with
women
without
giving
rise
to
any
fear
of
impertinence
.
<EOS>
He
had
about
him
somewhat
of
the
propensities
of
a
tame
cat
.
<EOS>
It
seemed
quite
natural
that
he
should
be
petted
,
caressed
,
and
treated
with
familiar
good
nature
,
and
that
in
return
he
should
purr
,
and
be
sleek
and
graceful
,
and
above
all
never
show
his
claws
.
<EOS>
Like
other
tame
cats
,
however
,
he
had
his
claws
,
and
sometimes
made
them
dangerous
.
  
<EOS>
When
tea
was
over
,
Charlotte
went
to
the
open
window
and
declared
loudly
that
the
full
harvest
moon
was
much
too
beautiful
to
be
disregarded
,
and
called
them
all
to
look
at
it
.
<EOS>
To
tell
the
truth
there
was
but
one
there
who
cared
much
about
the
moon
's
beauty
,
and
that
one
was
not
Charlotte
,
but
she
knew
how
valuable
an
aid
to
her
purpose
the
chaste
goddess
might
become
,
and
could
easily
create
a
little
enthusiasm
for
the
purpose
of
the
moment
.
<EOS>
Eleanor
and
Bertie
were
soon
with
her
.
<EOS>
The
doctor
was
now
quiet
in
his
armchair
,
and
Mrs.
Stanhope
in
hers
,
both
prepared
for
slumber
.
  
<EOS>
"
Are
you
a
Whewellite
or
a
Brewsterite
,
or
a
t'othermanite
,
Mrs.
Bold
?
"
said
Charlotte
,
who
knew
a
little
about
everything
,
and
had
read
about
a
third
of
each
of
the
books
to
which
she
alluded
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
said
Eleanor
;
"
I
have
not
read
any
of
the
books
,
but
I
feel
sure
that
there
is
one
man
in
the
moon
at
least
,
if
not
more
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
believe
in
the
pulpy
gelatinous
matter
?
"
said
Bertie
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
heard
about
that
,
"
said
Eleanor
,
"
and
<EOS>
I
really
think
it
's
almost
wicked
to
talk
in
such
a
manner
.
<EOS>
How
can
we
argue
about
God
's
power
in
the
other
stars
from
the
laws
which
he
has
given
for
our
rule
in
this
one
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
indeed
!
"
said
Bertie
.
<EOS>
"
Why
should
n't
there
be
a
race
of
salamanders
in
Venus
?
<EOS>
And
even
if
there
be
nothing
but
fish
in
Jupiter
,
why
should
n't
the
fish
there
be
as
wide
awake
as
the
men
and
women
here
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
would
be
saying
very
little
for
them
,
"
said
Charlotte
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
for
Dr.
Whewell
myself
,
for
I
do
not
think
that
men
and
women
are
worth
being
repeated
in
such
countless
worlds
.
<EOS>
There
may
be
souls
in
other
stars
,
but
I
doubt
their
having
any
bodies
attached
to
them
.
<EOS>
But
come
,
Mrs.
Bold
,
let
us
put
our
bonnets
on
and
walk
round
the
close
.
<EOS>
If
we
are
to
discuss
sidereal
questions
,
we
shall
do
so
much
better
under
the
towers
of
the
cathedral
than
stuck
in
this
narrow
window
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Bold
made
no
objection
,
and
a
party
was
made
to
walk
out
.
<EOS>
Charlotte
Stanhope
well
knew
the
rule
as
to
three
being
no
company
,
and
she
had
therefore
to
induce
her
sister
to
allow
Mr.
Slope
to
accompany
them
.
  
<EOS>
"
Come
,
Mr.
Slope
<EOS>
,
"
she
said
,
"
I
'm
sure
you
'll
join
us
.
<EOS>
We
shall
be
in
again
in
a
quarter
of
an
hour
,
Madeline
.
"
  
<EOS>
Madeline
read
in
her
eye
all
that
she
had
to
say
,
knew
her
object
,
and
as
she
had
to
depend
on
her
sister
for
so
many
of
her
amusements
,
she
felt
that
she
must
yield
.
<EOS>
It
was
hard
to
be
left
alone
while
others
of
her
own
age
walked
out
to
feel
the
soft
influence
of
the
bright
night
,
but
it
would
be
harder
still
to
be
without
the
sort
of
sanction
which
Charlotte
gave
to
all
her
flirtations
and
intrigues
.
<EOS>
Charlotte
's
eye
told
her
that
she
must
give
up
just
at
present
for
the
good
of
the
family
,
and
so
Madeline
obeyed
.
  
<EOS>
But
Charlotte
's
eyes
said
nothing
of
the
sort
to
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
He
had
no
objection
at
all
to
the
_
tête
-
à
-
tête
_
with
the
signora
which
the
departure
of
the
other
three
would
allow
him
,
and
gently
whispered
to
her
,
"
I
shall
not
leave
you
alone
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
yes
,
"
said
she
;
"
go
 
pray
go
,
pray
go
,
for
my
sake
.
<EOS>
Do
not
think
that
I
am
so
selfish
.
<EOS>
It
is
understood
that
nobody
is
kept
within
for
me
.
<EOS>
You
will
understand
this
too
when
you
know
me
better
.
<EOS>
Pray
join
them
,
Mr.
Slope
,
but
when
you
come
in
speak
to
me
for
five
minutes
before
you
leave
us
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
understood
that
he
was
to
go
,
and
he
therefore
joined
the
party
in
the
hall
.
<EOS>
He
would
have
had
no
objection
at
all
to
this
arrangement
,
if
he
could
have
secured
Mrs.
Bold
's
arm
;
but
this
of
course
was
out
of
the
question
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
his
fate
was
very
soon
settled
,
for
no
sooner
had
he
reached
the
hall
-
door
than
Miss
Stanhope
put
her
hand
within
his
arm
,
and
Bertie
walked
off
with
Eleanor
just
as
naturally
as
though
she
were
already
his
own
property
.
  
<EOS>
And
so
they
sauntered
forth
<EOS>
:
first
they
walked
round
the
close
,
according
to
their
avowed
intent
;
then
they
went
under
the
old
arched
gateway
below
St.
Cuthbert
's
little
church
,
and
then
they
turned
behind
the
grounds
of
the
bishop
's
palace
,
and
so
on
till
they
came
to
the
bridge
just
at
the
edge
of
the
town
,
from
which
passers
-
by
can
look
down
into
the
gardens
of
Hiram
's
Hospital
;
and
here
Charlotte
and
Mr.
Slope
,
who
were
in
advance
,
stopped
till
the
other
two
came
up
to
them
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
knew
that
the
gable
-
ends
and
old
brick
chimneys
which
stood
up
so
prettily
in
the
moonlight
were
those
of
Mr.
Harding
's
late
abode
,
and
would
not
have
stopped
on
such
a
spot
,
in
such
company
,
if
he
could
have
avoided
it
;
but
Miss
Stanhope
would
not
take
the
hint
which
he
tried
to
give
.
  
<EOS>
"
This
is
a
very
pretty
place
,
Mrs.
Bold
,
"
said
Charlotte
;
"
by
far
the
prettiest
place
near
Barchester
.
<EOS>
I
wonder
your
father
gave
it
up
.
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
very
pretty
place
,
and
now
by
the
deceitful
light
of
the
moon
looked
twice
larger
,
twice
prettier
,
twice
more
antiquely
picturesque
than
it
would
have
done
in
truth
-
telling
daylight
.
<EOS>
Who
does
not
know
the
air
of
complex
multiplicity
and
the
mysterious
interesting
grace
which
the
moon
always
lends
to
old
gabled
buildings
half
-
surrounded
,
as
was
the
hospital
,
by
fine
trees
!
<EOS>
As
seen
from
the
bridge
on
the
night
of
which
we
are
speaking
,
Mr.
Harding
's
late
abode
did
look
very
lovely
,
and
though
Eleanor
did
not
grieve
at
her
father
's
having
left
it
,
she
felt
at
the
moment
an
intense
wish
that
he
might
be
allowed
to
return
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
going
to
return
to
it
almost
immediately
,
is
he
not
?
"
asked
Bertie
.
  
<EOS>
Eleanor
made
no
immediate
reply
.
<EOS>
Many
such
a
question
passes
unanswered
without
the
notice
of
the
questioner
,
but
such
was
not
now
the
case
.
<EOS>
They
all
remained
silent
as
though
expecting
her
to
reply
,
and
after
a
moment
or
two
,
Charlotte
said
,
"
I
believe
it
is
settled
that
Mr.
Harding
returns
to
the
hospital
,
is
it
not
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
anything
about
it
is
settled
yet
,
"
said
Eleanor
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
it
must
be
a
matter
of
course
,
"
said
Bertie
;
"
that
is
,
if
your
father
wishes
it
.
<EOS>
Who
else
on
earth
could
hold
it
after
what
has
occurred
?
"
  
<EOS>
Eleanor
quietly
made
her
companion
understand
that
the
matter
was
one
which
she
could
not
discuss
in
the
present
company
,
and
then
they
passed
on
.
<EOS>
Charlotte
said
she
would
go
a
short
way
up
the
hill
out
of
the
town
so
as
to
look
back
upon
the
towers
of
the
cathedral
,
and
as
Eleanor
leant
upon
Bertie
's
arm
for
assistance
in
the
walk
,
she
told
him
how
the
matter
stood
between
her
father
and
the
bishop
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
,
he
,
"
said
Bertie
,
pointing
on
to
Mr.
Slope
,
"
what
part
does
he
take
in
it
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Eleanor
explained
how
Mr.
Slope
had
at
first
endeavoured
to
tyrannize
over
her
father
,
but
how
he
had
latterly
come
round
and
done
all
he
could
to
talk
the
bishop
over
in
Mr.
Harding
's
favour
.
"
<EOS>
But
my
father
,
"
she
said
,
"
is
hardly
inclined
to
trust
him
;
they
all
say
he
is
so
arrogant
to
the
old
clergymen
of
the
city
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Take
my
word
for
it
,
"
said
Bertie
,
"
your
father
is
right
.
<EOS>
If
I
am
not
very
much
mistaken
,
that
man
is
both
arrogant
and
false
.
"
  
<EOS>
They
strolled
up
to
the
top
of
the
hill
and
then
returned
through
the
fields
by
a
foot
-
path
which
leads
by
a
small
wooden
bridge
,
or
rather
a
plank
with
a
rustic
rail
to
it
,
over
the
river
to
the
other
side
of
the
cathedral
from
that
at
which
they
had
started
.
<EOS>
They
had
thus
walked
round
the
bishop
's
grounds
,
through
which
the
river
runs
,
and
round
the
cathedral
and
adjacent
fields
,
and
it
was
past
eleven
before
they
reached
the
doctor
's
door
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
very
late
,
"
said
Eleanor
;
"
it
will
be
a
shame
to
disturb
your
mother
again
at
such
an
hour
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
"
"
said
Charlotte
,
laughing
,
"
you
wo
n't
disturb
Mamma
<EOS>
;
I
dare
say
she
is
in
bed
by
this
time
,
and
Madeline
would
be
furious
if
you
did
not
come
in
and
see
her
.
<EOS>
Come
,
Bertie
,
take
Mrs.
Bold
's
bonnet
from
her
.
"
  
<EOS>
They
went
upstairs
and
found
the
signora
alone
,
reading
.
<EOS>
She
looked
somewhat
sad
and
melancholy
,
but
not
more
so
perhaps
than
was
sufficient
to
excite
additional
interest
in
the
bosom
of
Mr.
Slope
;
and
she
was
soon
deep
in
whispered
intercourse
with
that
happy
gentleman
,
who
was
allowed
to
find
a
resting
-
place
on
her
sofa
.
<EOS>
The
signora
had
a
way
of
whispering
that
was
peculiarly
her
own
,
and
was
exactly
the
reverse
of
that
which
prevails
among
great
tragedians
.
<EOS>
The
great
tragedian
hisses
out
a
positive
whisper
,
made
with
bated
breath
,
and
produced
by
inarticulated
tongue
-
formed
sounds
,
but
yet
he
is
audible
through
the
whole
house
.
<EOS>
The
signora
,
however
,
used
no
hisses
and
produced
all
her
words
in
a
clear
,
silver
tone
,
but
they
could
only
be
heard
by
the
ear
into
which
they
were
poured
.
  
<EOS>
Charlotte
hurried
and
scurried
about
the
room
hither
and
thither
,
doing
,
or
pretending
to
do
many
things
;
then
,
saying
something
about
seeing
her
mother
,
ran
upstairs
.
<EOS>
Eleanor
was
thus
left
alone
with
Bertie
,
and
she
hardly
felt
an
hour
fly
by
her
.
<EOS>
To
give
Bertie
his
due
credit
,
he
could
not
have
played
his
cards
better
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
make
love
to
her
,
nor
sigh
,
nor
look
languishing
,
but
he
was
amusing
and
familiar
,
yet
respectful
;
and
when
he
left
Eleanor
at
her
own
door
at
one
o'clock
,
which
he
did
by
the
by
with
the
assistance
of
the
now
jealous
Slope
,
she
thought
that
he
was
one
of
the
most
agreeable
men
and
the
Stanhopes
decidedly
the
most
agreeable
family
that
she
had
ever
met
.
   
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
 
<EOS>
The
Rev.
Francis
Arabin
,
fellow
of
Lazarus
,
late
professor
of
poetry
at
Oxford
,
and
present
vicar
of
St.
Ewold
,
in
the
diocese
of
Barchester
,
must
now
be
introduced
personally
to
the
reader
.
<EOS>
He
is
worthy
of
a
new
volume
,
and
as
he
will
fill
a
conspicuous
place
in
it
,
it
is
desirable
that
he
should
be
made
to
stand
before
the
reader
's
eye
by
the
aid
of
such
portraiture
as
the
author
is
able
to
produce
.
  
<EOS>
It
is
to
be
regretted
that
no
mental
method
of
daguerreotype
or
photography
has
yet
been
discovered
by
which
the
characters
of
men
can
be
reduced
to
writing
and
put
into
grammatical
language
with
an
unerring
precision
of
truthful
description
.
<EOS>
How
often
does
the
novelist
feel
,
ay
,
and
the
historian
also
and
the
biographer
,
that
he
has
conceived
within
his
mind
and
accurately
depicted
on
the
tablet
of
his
brain
the
full
character
and
personage
of
a
man
,
and
that
nevertheless
,
when
he
flies
to
pen
and
ink
to
perpetuate
the
portrait
,
his
words
forsake
,
elude
,
disappoint
,
and
play
the
deuce
with
him
,
till
at
the
end
of
a
dozen
pages
the
man
described
has
no
more
resemblance
to
the
man
conceived
than
the
sign
-
board
at
the
corner
of
the
street
has
to
the
Duke
of
Cambridge
.
  
<EOS>
And
yet
such
mechanical
descriptive
skill
would
hardly
give
more
satisfaction
to
the
reader
than
the
skill
of
the
photographer
<EOS>
does
to
the
anxious
mother
desirous
to
possess
an
absolute
duplicate
of
her
beloved
child
.
<EOS>
The
likeness
is
indeed
true
,
but
it
is
a
dull
,
dead
,
unfeeling
,
inauspicious
likeness
.
<EOS>
The
face
is
indeed
there
,
and
those
looking
at
it
will
know
at
once
whose
image
it
is
,
but
the
owner
of
the
face
will
not
be
proud
of
the
resemblance
.
  
<EOS>
There
is
no
royal
road
to
learning
,
no
short
cut
to
the
acquirement
of
any
valuable
art
.
<EOS>
Let
photographers
and
daguerreotypers
do
what
they
will
,
and
improve
as
they
may
with
further
skill
on
that
which
skill
has
already
done
,
they
will
never
achieve
a
portrait
of
the
human
face
divine
.
<EOS>
Let
biographers
,
novelists
,
and
the
rest
of
us
groan
as
we
may
under
the
burdens
which
we
so
often
feel
too
heavy
for
our
shoulders
;
we
must
either
bear
them
up
like
men
,
or
own
ourselves
too
weak
for
the
work
we
have
undertaken
.
<EOS>
There
is
no
way
of
writing
well
and
also
of
writing
easily
.
  
<EOS>
_
Labor
omnia
vincit
improbus
_
.
<EOS>
Such
should
be
the
chosen
motto
of
every
labourer
,
and
it
may
be
that
labour
,
if
adequately
enduring
,
may
suffice
at
last
to
produce
even
some
not
untrue
resemblance
of
the
Rev.
Francis
Arabin
.
  
<EOS>
Of
his
doings
in
the
world
,
and
of
the
sort
of
fame
which
he
has
achieved
,
enough
has
been
already
said
.
<EOS>
It
has
also
been
said
that
he
is
forty
years
of
age
,
and
still
unmarried
.
<EOS>
He
was
the
younger
son
of
a
country
gentleman
of
small
fortune
in
the
north
of
England
.
<EOS>
At
an
early
age
he
went
to
Winchester
,
and
was
intended
by
his
father
for
New
College
;
but
though
studious
as
a
boy
,
he
was
not
studious
within
the
prescribed
limits
,
and
at
the
age
of
eighteen
he
left
school
with
a
character
for
talent
,
but
without
a
scholarship
.
<EOS>
All
that
he
had
obtained
,
over
and
above
the
advantage
of
his
character
,
was
a
gold
medal
for
English
verse
,
and
hence
was
derived
a
strong
presumption
on
the
part
of
his
friends
that
he
was
destined
to
add
another
name
to
the
imperishable
list
of
English
poets
.
  
<EOS>
From
Winchester
he
went
to
Oxford
,
and
was
entered
as
a
commoner
at
Balliol
.
<EOS>
Here
his
special
career
very
soon
commenced
.
<EOS>
He
utterly
eschewed
the
society
of
fast
men
,
gave
no
wine
-
parties
,
kept
no
horses
,
rowed
no
boats
,
joined
no
rows
,
and
was
the
pride
of
his
college
tutor
.
<EOS>
Such
at
least
was
his
career
till
he
had
taken
his
little
go
,
and
then
he
commenced
a
course
of
action
which
,
though
not
less
creditable
to
himself
as
a
man
,
was
hardly
so
much
to
the
taste
of
the
tutor
.
<EOS>
He
became
a
member
of
a
vigorous
debating
society
,
and
rendered
himself
remarkable
there
for
humorous
energy
.
<EOS>
Though
always
in
earnest
,
yet
his
earnestness
was
always
droll
.
<EOS>
To
be
true
in
his
ideas
,
unanswerable
in
his
syllogisms
,
and
just
in
his
aspirations
was
not
enough
for
him
.
<EOS>
He
had
failed
,
failed
in
his
own
opinion
as
well
as
that
of
others
when
others
came
to
know
him
,
if
he
could
not
reduce
the
arguments
of
his
opponents
to
an
absurdity
and
conquer
both
by
wit
and
reason
.
<EOS>
To
say
that
his
object
was
ever
to
raise
a
laugh
would
be
most
untrue
.
<EOS>
He
hated
such
common
and
unnecessary
evidence
of
satisfaction
on
the
part
of
his
hearers
.
<EOS>
A
joke
that
required
to
be
laughed
at
was
,
with
him
,
not
worth
uttering
.
<EOS>
He
could
appreciate
by
a
keener
sense
than
that
of
his
ears
the
success
of
his
wit
,
and
would
see
in
the
eyes
of
his
auditors
whether
or
no
he
was
understood
and
appreciated
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
been
a
religious
lad
before
he
left
school
.
<EOS>
That
is
,
he
had
addicted
himself
to
a
party
in
religion
,
and
having
done
so
had
received
that
benefit
which
most
men
do
who
become
partisans
in
such
a
cause
.
<EOS>
We
are
much
too
apt
to
look
at
schism
in
our
church
as
an
unmitigated
evil
.
<EOS>
Moderate
schism
,
if
there
may
be
such
a
thing
,
at
any
rate
calls
attention
to
the
subject
,
draws
in
supporters
who
would
otherwise
have
been
inattentive
to
the
matter
,
and
teaches
men
to
think
upon
religion
.
<EOS>
How
great
an
amount
of
good
of
this
description
has
followed
that
movement
in
the
Church
of
England
which
commenced
with
the
publication
of
Froude
's
Remains
!
  
<EOS>
As
a
boy
young
Arabin
took
up
the
cudgels
on
the
side
of
the
Tractarians
,
and
at
Oxford
he
sat
for
a
while
at
the
feet
of
the
great
Newman
.
<EOS>
To
this
cause
he
lent
all
his
faculties
.
<EOS>
For
it
he
concocted
verses
,
for
it
he
made
speeches
,
for
it
he
scintillated
the
brightest
sparks
of
his
quiet
wit
.
<EOS>
For
it
he
ate
and
drank
and
dressed
and
had
his
being
.
<EOS>
In
due
process
of
time
he
took
his
degree
and
wrote
himself
B.A.
,
but
he
did
not
do
so
with
any
remarkable
amount
of
academical
éclat
.
<EOS>
He
had
occupied
himself
too
much
with
High
Church
matters
and
the
polemics
,
politics
,
and
outward
demonstrations
usually
concurrent
with
High
Churchmanship
to
devote
himself
with
sufficient
vigour
to
the
acquisition
of
a
double
first
.
<EOS>
He
was
not
a
double
first
,
nor
even
a
first
class
man
,
but
he
revenged
himself
on
the
university
by
putting
firsts
and
double
firsts
out
of
fashion
for
the
year
and
laughing
down
a
species
of
pedantry
which
,
at
the
age
of
twenty
-
three
,
leaves
no
room
in
a
man
's
mind
for
graver
subjects
than
conic
sections
or
Greek
accents
.
  
<EOS>
Greek
accents
,
however
,
and
conic
sections
were
esteemed
necessaries
at
Balliol
,
and
there
was
no
admittance
there
for
Mr.
Arabin
within
the
list
of
its
fellows
.
<EOS>
Lazarus
,
however
,
the
richest
and
most
comfortable
abode
of
Oxford
dons
,
opened
its
bosom
to
the
young
champion
of
a
church
militant
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
was
ordained
,
and
became
a
fellow
soon
after
taking
his
degree
,
and
shortly
after
that
was
chosen
professor
of
poetry
.
  
<EOS>
And
now
came
the
moment
of
his
great
danger
.
<EOS>
After
many
mental
struggles
,
and
an
agony
of
doubt
which
may
be
well
surmised
,
the
great
prophet
of
the
Tractarians
confessed
himself
a
Roman
Catholic
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Newman
left
the
Church
of
England
and
with
him
carried
many
a
waverer
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
carry
off
Mr.
Arabin
,
but
the
escape
which
that
gentleman
had
was
a
very
narrow
one
.
<EOS>
He
left
Oxford
for
awhile
that
he
might
meditate
in
complete
peace
on
the
step
which
appeared
to
him
to
be
all
but
unavoidable
,
and
shut
himself
up
in
a
little
village
on
the
sea
-
shore
of
one
of
our
remotest
counties
,
that
he
might
learn
by
communing
with
his
own
soul
<EOS>
whether
or
no
he
could
with
a
safe
conscience
remain
within
the
pale
of
his
mother
church
.
  
<EOS>
Things
would
have
gone
badly
with
him
there
had
he
been
left
entirely
to
himself
.
<EOS>
Everything
was
against
him
:
all
his
worldly
interests
required
him
to
remain
a
Protestant
,
and
he
looked
on
his
worldly
interests
as
a
legion
of
foes
,
to
get
the
better
of
whom
was
a
point
of
extremest
honour
.
<EOS>
In
his
then
state
of
ecstatic
agony
such
a
conquest
would
have
cost
him
little
;
he
could
easily
have
thrown
away
all
his
livelihood
;
but
it
cost
him
much
to
get
over
the
idea
that
by
choosing
the
Church
of
England
he
should
be
open
in
his
own
mind
to
the
charge
that
he
had
been
led
to
such
a
choice
by
unworthy
motives
.
<EOS>
Then
his
heart
was
against
him
:
he
loved
with
a
strong
and
eager
love
the
man
who
had
hitherto
been
his
guide
,
and
yearned
to
follow
his
footsteps
.
<EOS>
His
tastes
were
against
him
:
the
ceremonies
and
pomps
of
the
Church
of
Rome
,
their
august
feasts
and
solemn
fasts
,
invited
his
imagination
and
pleased
his
eye
.
<EOS>
His
flesh
was
against
him
:
<EOS>
how
great
an
aid
would
it
be
to
a
poor
,
weak
,
wavering
man
to
be
constrained
to
high
moral
duties
,
self
-
denial
,
obedience
,
and
chastity
by
laws
which
were
certain
in
their
enactments
,
and
not
to
be
broken
without
loud
,
palpable
,
unmistakable
sin
!
<EOS>
Then
his
faith
was
against
him
:
he
required
to
believe
so
much
;
panted
so
eagerly
to
give
signs
of
his
belief
;
deemed
it
so
insufficient
to
wash
himself
simply
in
the
waters
of
Jordan
;
that
some
great
deed
,
such
as
that
of
forsaking
everything
for
a
true
Church
,
had
for
him
allurements
almost
past
withstanding
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
was
at
this
time
a
very
young
man
,
and
when
he
left
Oxford
for
his
far
retreat
was
much
too
confident
in
his
powers
of
fence
,
and
too
apt
to
look
down
on
the
ordinary
sense
of
ordinary
people
,
to
expect
aid
in
the
battle
that
he
had
to
fight
from
any
chance
inhabitants
of
the
spot
which
he
had
selected
.
<EOS>
But
Providence
was
good
to
him
;
there
,
in
that
all
but
desolate
place
,
on
the
storm
-
beat
shore
of
that
distant
sea
,
he
met
one
who
gradually
calmed
his
mind
,
quieted
his
imagination
,
and
taught
him
something
of
a
Christian
's
duty
.
<EOS>
When
Mr.
Arabin
left
Oxford
,
he
was
inclined
to
look
upon
the
rural
clergymen
of
most
English
parishes
almost
with
contempt
.
<EOS>
It
was
his
ambition
,
should
he
remain
within
the
fold
of
their
church
,
to
do
somewhat
towards
redeeming
and
rectifying
their
inferiority
and
to
assist
in
infusing
energy
and
faith
into
the
hearts
of
Christian
ministers
,
who
were
,
as
he
thought
,
too
often
satisfied
to
go
through
life
without
much
show
of
either
.
  
<EOS>
And
yet
it
was
from
such
a
one
that
Mr.
Arabin
in
his
extremest
need
received
that
aid
which
he
so
much
required
.
<EOS>
It
was
from
the
poor
curate
of
a
small
Cornish
parish
that
he
first
learnt
to
know
that
the
highest
laws
for
the
governance
of
a
Christian
's
duty
must
act
from
within
and
not
from
without
;
that
no
man
can
become
a
serviceable
servant
solely
by
obedience
to
written
edicts
;
and
that
the
safety
which
he
was
about
to
seek
within
the
gates
of
Rome
was
no
other
than
the
selfish
freedom
from
personal
danger
which
the
bad
soldier
attempts
to
gain
who
counterfeits
illness
on
the
eve
of
battle
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
returned
to
Oxford
a
humbler
but
a
better
and
a
happier
man
,
and
from
that
time
forth
he
put
his
shoulder
to
the
wheel
as
a
clergyman
of
the
Church
for
which
he
had
been
educated
.
<EOS>
The
intercourse
of
those
among
whom
he
familiarly
lived
kept
him
staunch
to
the
principles
of
that
system
of
the
Church
to
which
he
had
always
belonged
.
<EOS>
Since
his
severance
from
Mr.
Newman
,
no
one
had
had
so
strong
an
influence
over
him
as
the
head
of
his
college
.
<EOS>
During
the
time
of
his
expected
apostasy
Dr.
Gwynne
had
not
felt
much
predisposition
in
favour
of
the
young
fellow
.
<EOS>
Though
a
High
Churchman
himself
within
moderate
limits
,
Dr.
Gwynne
felt
no
sympathy
with
men
who
could
not
satisfy
their
faiths
with
the
Thirty
-
nine
Articles
.
<EOS>
He
regarded
the
enthusiasm
of
such
as
Newman
as
a
state
of
mind
more
nearly
allied
to
madness
than
to
religion
,
and
when
he
saw
it
evinced
by
very
young
men
,
he
was
inclined
to
attribute
a
good
deal
of
it
to
vanity
.
<EOS>
Dr.
Gwynne
himself
,
though
a
religious
man
,
was
also
a
thoroughly
practical
man
of
the
world
,
and
he
regarded
with
no
favourable
eye
the
tenets
of
anyone
who
looked
on
the
two
things
as
incompatible
.
<EOS>
When
he
found
that
Mr.
Arabin
was
a
half
Roman
,
he
began
to
regret
all
he
had
done
towards
bestowing
a
fellowship
on
so
unworthy
a
recipient
;
and
when
again
he
learnt
that
Mr.
Arabin
would
probably
complete
his
journey
to
Rome
,
he
regarded
with
some
satisfaction
the
fact
that
in
such
case
the
fellowship
would
be
again
vacant
.
  
<EOS>
When
,
however
,
Mr.
Arabin
returned
and
professed
himself
a
confirmed
Protestant
,
the
Master
of
Lazarus
again
opened
his
arms
to
him
,
and
gradually
he
became
the
pet
of
the
college
.
<EOS>
For
some
little
time
he
was
saturnine
,
silent
,
and
unwilling
to
take
any
prominent
part
in
university
broils
,
but
gradually
his
mind
recovered
,
or
rather
made
its
tone
,
and
he
became
known
as
a
man
always
ready
at
a
moment
's
notice
to
take
up
the
cudgels
in
opposition
to
anything
that
savoured
of
an
evangelical
bearing
.
<EOS>
He
was
great
in
sermons
,
great
on
platforms
,
great
at
after
-
dinner
conversations
,
and
always
pleasant
as
well
as
great
.
<EOS>
He
took
delight
in
elections
,
served
on
committees
,
opposed
tooth
and
nail
all
projects
of
university
reform
,
and
talked
jovially
over
his
glass
of
port
of
the
ruin
to
be
anticipated
by
the
Church
and
of
the
sacrilege
daily
committed
by
the
Whigs
.
<EOS>
The
ordeal
through
which
he
had
gone
in
resisting
the
blandishments
of
the
lady
of
Rome
had
certainly
done
much
towards
the
strengthening
of
his
character
.
<EOS>
Although
in
small
and
outward
matters
he
was
self
-
confident
enough
,
nevertheless
in
things
affecting
the
inner
man
he
aimed
at
a
humility
of
spirit
which
would
never
have
been
attractive
to
him
but
for
that
visit
to
the
coast
of
Cornwall
.
<EOS>
This
visit
he
now
repeated
every
year
.
  
<EOS>
Such
is
an
interior
view
of
Mr.
Arabin
at
the
time
when
he
accepted
the
living
of
St.
Ewold
.
<EOS>
Exteriorly
,
he
was
not
a
remarkable
person
.
<EOS>
He
was
above
the
middle
height
,
well
-
made
,
and
very
active
.
<EOS>
His
hair
,
which
had
been
jet
black
,
was
now
tinged
with
gray
,
but
his
face
bore
no
sign
of
years
.
<EOS>
It
would
perhaps
be
wrong
to
say
that
he
was
handsome
,
but
his
face
was
nevertheless
pleasant
to
look
upon
.
<EOS>
The
cheek
-
bones
were
rather
too
high
for
beauty
,
and
the
formation
of
the
forehead
too
massive
and
heavy
:
but
the
eyes
,
nose
,
and
mouth
were
perfect
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
continual
play
of
lambent
fire
about
his
eyes
,
which
gave
promise
of
either
pathos
or
humour
whenever
he
essayed
to
speak
,
and
that
promise
was
rarely
broken
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
gentle
play
about
his
mouth
which
declared
that
his
wit
never
descended
to
sarcasm
,
and
that
there
was
no
ill
-
nature
in
his
repartee
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
was
a
popular
man
among
women
,
but
more
so
as
a
general
than
a
special
favourite
.
<EOS>
Living
as
a
fellow
at
Oxford
,
marriage
with
him
had
been
out
of
the
question
,
and
it
may
be
doubted
whether
he
had
ever
allowed
his
heart
to
be
touched
.
<EOS>
Though
belonging
to
a
church
in
which
celibacy
is
not
the
required
lot
of
its
ministers
,
he
had
come
to
regard
himself
as
one
of
those
clergymen
to
whom
to
be
a
bachelor
is
almost
a
necessity
.
<EOS>
He
had
never
looked
for
parochial
duty
,
and
his
career
at
Oxford
was
utterly
incompatible
with
such
domestic
joys
as
a
wife
and
nursery
.
<EOS>
He
looked
on
women
,
therefore
,
in
the
same
light
that
one
sees
them
regarded
by
many
Romish
priests
.
<EOS>
He
liked
to
have
near
him
that
which
was
pretty
and
amusing
,
but
women
generally
were
little
more
to
him
than
children
.
<EOS>
He
talked
to
them
without
putting
out
all
his
powers
,
and
listened
to
them
without
any
idea
that
what
he
should
hear
from
them
could
either
actuate
his
conduct
or
influence
his
opinion
.
  
<EOS>
Such
was
Mr.
Arabin
,
the
new
vicar
of
St.
Ewold
,
who
is
going
to
stay
with
the
Grantlys
at
Plumstead
Episcopi
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
reached
Plumstead
the
day
before
Mr.
Harding
and
Eleanor
,
and
the
Grantly
family
were
thus
enabled
to
make
his
acquaintance
and
discuss
his
qualifications
before
the
arrival
of
the
other
guests
.
<EOS>
Griselda
was
surprised
to
find
that
he
looked
so
young
,
but
she
told
Florinda
her
younger
sister
,
when
they
had
retired
for
the
night
,
that
he
did
not
talk
at
all
like
a
young
man
:
and
she
decided
with
the
authority
that
seventeen
has
over
sixteen
that
he
was
not
at
all
nice
,
although
his
eyes
were
lovely
.
<EOS>
As
usual
,
sixteen
implicitly
acceded
to
the
dictum
of
seventeen
in
such
a
matter
,
and
said
that
he
certainly
was
not
nice
.
<EOS>
They
then
branched
off
on
the
relative
merits
of
other
clerical
bachelors
in
the
vicinity
,
and
both
determined
without
any
feeling
of
jealousy
between
them
that
a
certain
Rev.
Augustus
Green
was
by
many
degrees
the
most
estimable
of
the
lot
.
<EOS>
The
gentleman
in
question
had
certainly
much
in
his
favour
,
as
,
having
a
comfortable
allowance
from
his
father
,
he
could
devote
the
whole
proceeds
of
his
curacy
to
violet
gloves
and
unexceptionable
neck
ties
.
<EOS>
Having
thus
fixedly
resolved
that
the
new
-
comer
had
nothing
about
him
to
shake
the
pre
-
eminence
of
the
exalted
Green
,
the
two
girls
went
to
sleep
in
each
other
's
arms
,
contented
with
themselves
and
the
world
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Grantly
at
first
sight
came
to
much
the
same
conclusion
about
her
husband
's
favourite
as
her
daughters
had
done
,
though
,
in
seeking
to
measure
his
relative
value
,
she
did
not
compare
him
to
Mr.
Green
;
indeed
,
she
made
no
comparison
by
name
between
him
and
anyone
else
;
but
she
remarked
to
her
husband
that
one
person
's
swans
were
very
often
another
person
's
geese
,
thereby
clearly
showing
that
Mr.
Arabin
had
not
yet
proved
his
qualifications
in
swanhood
to
her
satisfaction
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Susan
,
"
said
he
,
rather
offended
at
hearing
his
friend
spoken
of
so
disrespectfully
,
"
if
you
take
Mr.
Arabin
for
a
goose
,
I
can
not
say
that
I
think
very
highly
of
your
discrimination
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
goose
!
<EOS>
No
,
of
course
,
he
's
not
a
goose
.
<EOS>
I
've
no
doubt
he
's
a
very
clever
man
.
<EOS>
But
you
're
so
matter
-
of
-
fact
,
<EOS>
Archdeacon
,
when
it
suits
your
purpose
,
that
one
ca
n't
trust
oneself
to
any
_
façon
de
parler
_
.
<EOS>
I
've
no
doubt
Mr.
Arabin
is
a
very
valuable
man
 
at
Oxford
 
and
that
he
'll
be
a
good
vicar
at
St.
Ewold
.
<EOS>
All
I
mean
is
that
,
having
passed
one
evening
with
him
,
I
do
n't
find
him
to
be
absolutely
a
paragon
.
<EOS>
In
the
first
place
,
if
I
am
not
mistaken
,
he
is
a
little
inclined
to
be
conceited
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
all
the
men
that
I
know
intimately
,
"
said
the
archdeacon
,
<EOS>
"
Arabin
is
,
in
my
opinion
,
the
most
free
from
any
taint
of
self
-
conceit
.
<EOS>
His
fault
is
that
he
's
too
diffident
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
so
,
"
said
the
lady
;
"
only
I
must
own
<EOS>
I
did
not
find
it
out
this
evening
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Nothing
further
was
said
about
him
.
<EOS>
Dr.
Grantly
thought
that
his
wife
was
abusing
Mr.
Arabin
merely
because
he
had
praised
him
,
and
Mrs.
Grantly
knew
that
it
was
useless
arguing
for
or
against
any
person
in
favour
of
or
in
opposition
to
whom
the
archdeacon
had
already
pronounced
a
strong
opinion
.
  
<EOS>
In
truth
,
they
were
both
right
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
was
a
diffident
man
in
social
intercourse
with
those
whom
he
did
not
intimately
know
;
when
placed
in
situations
which
it
was
his
business
to
fill
,
and
discussing
matters
with
which
it
was
his
duty
to
be
conversant
,
Mr.
Arabin
was
from
habit
brazen
-
faced
enough
.
<EOS>
When
standing
on
a
platform
in
Exeter
Hall
,
no
man
would
be
less
mazed
than
he
by
the
eyes
of
the
crowd
before
him
,
for
such
was
the
work
which
his
profession
had
called
on
him
to
perform
;
but
he
shrank
from
a
strong
expression
of
opinion
in
general
society
,
and
his
doing
so
not
uncommonly
made
it
appear
that
he
considered
the
company
not
worth
the
trouble
of
his
energy
.
<EOS>
He
was
averse
to
dictate
when
the
place
did
not
seem
to
him
to
justify
dictation
,
and
as
those
subjects
on
which
people
wished
to
hear
him
speak
were
such
as
he
was
accustomed
to
treat
with
decision
,
he
generally
shunned
the
traps
there
were
laid
to
allure
him
into
discussion
,
and
,
by
doing
so
,
not
infrequently
subjected
himself
to
such
charges
as
those
brought
against
him
by
Mrs.
Grantly
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
,
as
he
sat
at
his
open
window
,
enjoying
the
delicious
moonlight
and
gazing
at
the
gray
towers
of
the
church
,
which
stood
almost
within
the
rectory
grounds
,
little
dreamed
that
he
was
the
subject
of
so
many
friendly
or
unfriendly
criticisms
.
<EOS>
Considering
how
much
we
are
all
given
to
discuss
the
characters
of
others
,
and
discuss
them
often
not
in
the
strictest
spirit
of
charity
,
it
is
singular
how
little
we
are
inclined
to
think
that
others
can
speak
ill
-
naturedly
of
us
,
and
how
angry
and
hurt
we
are
when
proof
reaches
us
that
they
have
done
so
.
<EOS>
It
is
hardly
too
much
to
say
that
we
all
of
us
occasionally
speak
of
our
dearest
friends
in
a
manner
in
which
those
dearest
friends
would
very
little
like
to
hear
themselves
mentioned
,
and
that
we
nevertheless
expect
that
our
dearest
friends
shall
invariably
speak
of
us
as
though
they
were
blind
to
all
our
faults
,
but
keenly
alive
to
every
shade
of
our
virtues
.
  
<EOS>
It
did
not
occur
to
Mr.
Arabin
that
he
was
spoken
of
at
all
.
<EOS>
It
seemed
to
him
,
when
he
compared
himself
with
his
host
,
that
he
was
a
person
of
so
little
consequence
to
any
,
that
he
was
worth
no
one
's
words
or
thoughts
.
<EOS>
He
was
utterly
alone
in
the
world
as
regarded
domestic
ties
and
those
inner
familiar
relations
which
are
hardly
possible
between
others
than
husbands
and
wives
,
parents
and
children
,
or
brothers
and
sisters
.
<EOS>
He
had
often
discussed
with
himself
the
necessity
of
such
bonds
for
a
man
's
happiness
in
this
world
,
and
had
generally
satisfied
himself
with
the
answer
that
happiness
in
this
world
is
not
a
necessity
.
<EOS>
Herein
he
deceived
himself
,
or
rather
tried
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
He
,
like
others
,
yearned
for
the
enjoyment
of
whatever
he
saw
enjoyable
,
and
though
he
attempted
,
with
the
modern
stoicism
of
so
many
Christians
,
to
make
himself
believe
that
joy
and
sorrow
were
matters
which
here
should
be
held
as
perfectly
indifferent
,
these
things
were
not
indifferent
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
was
tired
of
his
Oxford
rooms
and
his
college
life
.
<EOS>
He
regarded
the
wife
and
children
of
his
friend
with
something
like
envy
;
<EOS>
he
all
but
coveted
the
pleasant
drawing
-
room
,
with
its
pretty
windows
opening
on
to
lawns
and
flower
-
beds
,
the
apparel
of
the
comfortable
house
,
and
 
above
all
 
the
air
of
home
which
encompassed
it
all
.
  
<EOS>
It
will
be
said
that
no
time
can
have
been
so
fitted
for
such
desires
on
his
part
as
this
,
when
he
had
just
possessed
himself
of
a
country
parish
,
of
a
living
among
fields
and
gardens
,
of
a
house
which
a
wife
would
grace
.
<EOS>
It
is
true
there
was
a
difference
between
the
opulence
of
Plumstead
and
the
modest
economy
of
St.
Ewold
,
but
surely
Mr.
Arabin
was
not
a
man
to
sigh
after
wealth
!
<EOS>
Of
all
men
,
his
friends
would
have
unanimously
declared
he
was
the
last
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
But
how
little
our
friends
know
us
!
<EOS>
In
his
period
of
stoical
rejection
of
this
world
's
happiness
,
he
had
cast
from
him
as
utter
dross
all
anxiety
as
to
fortune
.
<EOS>
He
had
,
as
it
were
,
proclaimed
himself
to
be
indifferent
to
promotion
,
and
those
who
chiefly
admired
his
talents
,
and
would
mainly
have
exerted
themselves
to
secure
to
them
their
deserved
reward
,
had
taken
him
at
his
word
.
<EOS>
And
now
,
if
the
truth
must
out
,
he
felt
himself
disappointed
 
<EOS>
disappointed
not
by

but

.
<EOS>
The
daydream
of
his
youth
was
over
,
and

the
age

forty
he
felt
that
he
was
not

.
<EOS>
He
had
mistaken

,

.
<EOS>
He

,

,
and

to

good

of
other

,

.
  
<EOS>
Not

,

,

;
not

rich

<EOS>
had

;

<EOS>

a

,

,

him
<EOS>
,

.
  
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>

would

some
£
300

<EOS>
should

,

.
<EOS>
Such

,

.
<EOS>
The
world
also
thought
that
Mr.
Arabin
was
,

,

.
<EOS>
Alas
!
<EOS>
Alas
!
<EOS>
The
world
was
mistaken
,
and
Mr.
Arabin
was
beginning
to
ascertain
that
such
was
the
case
.
  
<EOS>
And
here
may
I
beg
the
reader
not

hard

his

upon
this
man
.
<EOS>
Is
not

state

he
has
arrived
the
natural

of

to
reach
that
which

?
<EOS>
Is

modern

,

on

,

?
<EOS>
The

of
Zeno
was
built
on

,
but

misunderstood
and
therefore

.
<EOS>
It
is

same
with

Stoics
here
,
who

that

.
<EOS>
Alas
,
for
a
doctrine
which
can
find
no

and
no

!
  
<EOS>
The
case
of
Mr.
Arabin
was
the
more
singular
,
as
he
belonged
to
a
branch
of
the
Church
of
England
well
inclined
to
regard
its
temporalities
with
avowed
favour
,
and
had
habitually
lived
with
men
who
were
accustomed
to
much
worldly
comfort
.
<EOS>
But
such
was
his
idiosyncrasy
that
these
very
facts
had
produced
within
him
,
in
early

,

state

mind
that
was
not
natural

.
<EOS>
He
was
content
to
be
a
High
Churchman
,
if
he
could

so
on

of
his
own
and
could
strike

showing

with

.
<EOS>
He
was
ready

as

was
allowed
to
have
a
course
of
action
and

thought
unlike
that
of

.
<EOS>
His
party
had
indulged

,
and
he
began
to
feel
that
his
party
was
right
and
himself
wrong
,
just
when
such
a
conviction
was
too
late
to

.
<EOS>
He
discovered
,
when
such

was
no

,
that

to
have
worked
for

usual

to

world
and
have

,

to
have

pleasant

,
in

his
friends
could

,
and
the
power
of

,
with

that
all

.
<EOS>
Other
men

at

in

and
so

up
to
them
.
<EOS>
To
him
they
had
come
when
they
were
too
late
to
be

use
.
  
<EOS>
It
has
been
said
that
Mr.
Arabin
was
a
man
of
pleasantry
,
and
it
may
be
thought
that
such

mind
as
that
described
would
be
antagonistic
to

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
Wit
is

outward
mental
casing
of
the
man
,
and
has
no
more

do
with
the
inner

of

than
have

rich

of

,

.
<EOS>
Nay
,

such

often

in

rich
show
of

?
<EOS>
Will

not

that

?
<EOS>
So
it
is
with
the

.
<EOS>
Those
which
they
show
forth
daily
to
the
world
are
often

inner

.
  
<EOS>
In

's

,

had

<EOS>
Truly

.
   
<EOS>
St.
Ewold
's
Parsonage
 
<EOS>

,

's
.
<EOS>
They

that

,

.
<EOS>
Mr.

,

wo

,

;

about
Barchester
.
  
<EOS>
There

not

confidence

.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Grantly
was
ten

Eleanor
,

had

yet

.
<EOS>
They

never
,

,

;

.
<EOS>
They

much

;

.
<EOS>
Mrs.

,

,

;

in

Mr.
Slope

.
  
<EOS>
It

to

.
<EOS>
That

,

<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
She

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

.

"

!
"

.
"
<EOS>

?
"
  
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Mrs.

<EOS>

ugh
!
<EOS>
"

"

,

Now

.
<EOS>
Poor

!
  
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Eleanor
also
knew

,
but

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
did
not

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
She

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
The

,

,

,

had
,

,

.
<EOS>
It

,

,

should
not

_
savoir
vivre
_
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
,
as
we
have
said
,
did
not

of
her
,
but
yet
he
did
not
go

;

,

,

when

.
  
<EOS>
Before
they
all

that

the

to

at

Ewold
.
<EOS>
The

,

.
  
<EOS>
Accordingly
,

the

.
<EOS>
There

only

for

inside
,
and

.
<EOS>
Eleanor
found

Mr.
Arabin
,
and
was
,
therefore
,
in
a
manner
forced
into
conversation
with
him
.
<EOS>
They
were
soon
on
comfortable
terms
together
,
and
had
she
thought
about
it
,
she
would
have
thought
that
,
in
spite
of
his
black
cloth
,
Mr.
Arabin
would
not
have
been
a
bad
addition
to
the
Stanhope
family
party
.
  
<EOS>
Now
that
the
archdeacon
was
away
they
could
all
trifle
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
began
by
telling
them
in
the
most
innocent
manner
imaginable
an
old
legend
about
Mr.
Arabin
's
new
parish
.
<EOS>
There
was
,
he
said
,
in
days
of
yore
an
illustrious
priestess
of
St.
Ewold
,
famed
through
the
whole
country
for
curing
all
manner
of
diseases
.
<EOS>
She
had
a
well
,
as
all
priestesses
have
ever
had
,
which
well
was
extant
to
this
day
,
and
shared
in
the
minds
of
many
of
the
people
the
sanctity
which
belonged
to
the
consecrated
ground
of
the
parish
church
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
declared
that
he
should
look
on
such
tenets
on
the
part
of
his
parishioners
as
anything
but
orthodox
.
<EOS>
And
Mrs.
Grantly
replied
that
she
so
entirely
disagreed
with
him
as
to
think
that
no
parish
was
in
a
proper
state
that
had
not
its
priestess
as
well
as
its
priest
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
duties
are
never
well
done
,
"
said
she
,
"
unless
they
are
so
divided
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
,
Papa
,
"
said
Eleanor
,
"
that
in
the
olden
times
the
priestess
bore
all
the
sway
herself
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
,
perhaps
,
thinks
that
such
might
be
too
much
the
case
now
if
a
sacred
lady
were
admitted
within
the
parish
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
,
at
any
rate
,
"
said
he
,
"
that
it
is
safer
to
run
no
such
risk
.
<EOS>
No
priestly
pride
has
ever
exceeded
that
of
sacerdotal
females
.
<EOS>
A
very
lowly
curate
I
might
,
perhaps
,
essay
to
rule
,
but
a
curatess
would
be
sure
to
get
the
better

me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
are
certainly
examples
of
such
accidents
happening
,
"
said
Mrs.
Grantly
.
<EOS>
"
They
do
say
that
there
is
a
priestess
at
Barchester
who
is
very
imperious
in
all
things
touching
the
altar
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
the
fear
of
such
a
fate
as
that
is
before
your
eyes
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
When
they
were
joined
by
the
archdeacon
on
the
gravel
before
the
vicarage
,
they
descended
again
to
grave

.
<EOS>
Not
that
Archdeacon
Grantly
was
a
dull
man
,
but
his
frolic
humours
were
of
a
cumbrous
kind
,
and
his
wit
,
when
he
was

,
did
not
generally
extend
itself
to
his

.
<EOS>
On
the
present
occasion
he
was
soon
making
speeches
about
wounded
roofs
and
walls
,
which
he
declared
to
be
in
want
of
some
surgeon
's
art
.
<EOS>
There
was
not
a
partition
that
he
did
not
tap
,
nor
a

that
he
did

narrowly
examine
;
all
water
-
pipes
,
flues
,
cisterns
,
and
sewers
underwent
an
investigation
;
he
even
descended
,
in
the
care
of
his
friend
,
so
far
as
to
bore
sundry
boards
in
the
floors
with
a

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
accompanied
him
through
the
rooms
,
trying
to
look
wise
in
such
domestic
matters
,
and
the
other
three
also
followed
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Grantly
showed
that
she
had
not
herself
been
priestess
of
a
parish
twenty
years
for
nothing
,
and
examined
the
bells
and
window
-
panes
in
a
very
knowing
way
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
will
,
at
any
rate
,
have
a
beautiful
prospect
out
of
your
own
window
,
if
this
is
to
be
your
private
sanctum
,
"
said
Eleanor
.
<EOS>
She
was
standing
at
the
lattice
of
a
little
room
upstairs
,
from
which
the
view
certainly
was
very
lovely
.
<EOS>
It
was
from
the
back
of
the
vicarage
,
and
there
was
nothing
to
interrupt
the
eye
between
the
house
and
the
glorious
gray
pile
of
the
cathedral
.
<EOS>
The
intermediate
ground
,
however
,
was
beautifully
studded
with
timber
.
<EOS>
In
the
immediate
foreground
ran
the
little
river
which
afterwards
skirted
the
city
,
and
,
just
to
the
right
of
the

,
the
pointed

and

of
Hiram
's
Hospital
peeped
out
of
the
elms
which

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
he
,
joining
her
.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
have
a
beautifully
complete
view
of
my
adversaries
.
<EOS>
I
shall
sit
down
before
the
hostile
town
and
fire
away
at
them
at
a
very
pleasant
distance
.
<EOS>
I
shall
just
be
able
to
lodge
a
shot
in
the
hospital
,
should
the
enemy
ever
get
possession

it
,
and
as

the
palace
,
I
have

within
full

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
never
saw
anything
like
you
clergymen
,
"
said
Eleanor
;
"
You
are
always
thinking
of
fighting
each
other
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Either
that
,
"
said
he
,
"
or
else
supporting
each
other
.
<EOS>
The
pity
is
that
we
can
not
do
the
one
without
the
other
.
<EOS>
But
are
we
not
here
to
fight
?
<EOS>
Is
not
ours
a
church
militant
?
<EOS>
What
is
all
our
work
but
fighting
,
and
hard
fighting
,
if
it
be
well
done
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
not
with
each
other
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
as
it
may
be
.
<EOS>
The
same
complaint
which
you
make
of
me
for
battling
with
another
clergyman
of
our
own
church
,
the
Mohammedan
would
make
against
me
for
battling
with
the
error
of
a
