of
Rome
.
<EOS>
Yet
,
surely
,
you
would
not
be
inclined
to
say
that
I
should
be
wrong
to
do
battle
with
such
as
him
.
<EOS>
A
pagan
,
too
,
with
his
multiplicity
of
gods
,
would
think
it
equally
odd
that
the
Christian
and
the
Mohammedan
should
disagree
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
But
you
wage
your
wars
about
trifles
so
bitterly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Wars
about
trifles
,
"
said
he
,
"
are
always
bitter
,
especially
among
neighbours
.
<EOS>
When
the
differences
are
great
,
and
the
parties
comparative
strangers
,
men
quarrel
with
courtesy
.
<EOS>
What
combatants
are
ever
so
eager
as
two
brothers
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
But
do
not
such
contentions
bring
scandal
on
the
church
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
More
scandal
would
fall
on
the
church
if
there
were
no
such
contentions
.
<EOS>
We
have
but
one
way
to
avoid
them
 
by
that
of
acknowledging
a
common
head
of
our
church
,
whose
word
on
all
points
of
doctrine
shall
be
authoritative
.
<EOS>
Such
a
termination
of
our
difficulties
is
alluring
enough
.
<EOS>
It
has
charms
which
are
irresistible
to
many
,
and
all
but
irresistible
,
I
own
,
to
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
speak
now
of
the
Church
of
Rome
?
"
said
Eleanor
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
he
,
"
not
necessarily
of
the
Church
of
Rome
;
but
of
a
church
with
a
head
.
<EOS>
Had
it
pleased
God
to
vouchsafe
to
us
such
a
church
our
path
would
have
been
easy
.
<EOS>
But
easy
paths
have
not
been
thought
good
for
us
.
"
<EOS>
He
paused
and
stood
silent
for
awhile
,
thinking
of
the
time
when
he
had
so
nearly
sacrificed
all
he
had
,
his
powers
of
mind
,
his
free
agency
,
the
fresh
running
waters
of
his
mind
's
fountain
,
his
very
inner
self
,
for
an
easy
path
in
which
no
fighting
would
be
needed
;
and
then
he
continued
:
"
What
you
say
is
partly
true
:
our
contentions
do
bring
on
us
some
scandal
.
<EOS>
The
outer
world
,
though
it
constantly
reviles
us
for
our
human
infirmities
and
throws
in
our
teeth
the
fact
that
being
clergymen
we
are
still
no
more
than
men
,
demands
of
us
that
we
should
do
our
work
with
godlike
perfection
.
<EOS>
There
is
nothing
god
-
like
about
us
:
we
differ
from
each
other
with
the
acerbity
common
to
man
;
we
triumph
over
each
other
with
human
frailty
;
we
allow
differences
on
subjects
of
divine
origin
to
produce
among
us
antipathies
and
enmities
which
are
anything
but
divine
.
<EOS>
This
is
all
true
.
<EOS>
But
what
would
you
have
in
place
of
it
?
<EOS>
There
is
no
infallible
head
for
a
church
on
earth
.
<EOS>
This
dream
of
believing
man
has
been
tried
,
and
we
see
in
Italy
and
in
Spain
what
has
come
of
it
.
<EOS>
Grant
that
there
are
and
have
been
no
bickerings
within
the
pale
of
the
Pope
's
Church
.
<EOS>
Such
an
assumption
would
be
utterly
untrue
,
but
let
us
grant
it
,
and
then
let
us
say
which
church
has
incurred
the
heavier
scandals
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
a
quiet
earnestness
about
Mr.
Arabin
,
as
he
half
-
acknowledged
and
half
-
defended
himself
from
the
charge
brought
against
him
,
which
surprised
Eleanor
.
<EOS>
She
had
been
used
all
her
life
to
listen
to
clerical
discussion
,
but
the
points
at
issue
between
the
disputants
had
so
seldom
been
of
more
than
temporal
significance
as
to
have
left
on
her
mind
no
feeling
of
reverence
for
such
subjects
.
<EOS>
There
had
always
been
a
hard
worldly
leaven
of
the
love
either
of
income
or
of
power
in
the
strains
she
had
heard
;
there
had
been
no
panting
for
the
truth
;
no
aspirations
after
religious
purity
.
<EOS>
It
had
always
been
taken
for
granted
by
those
around
her
that
they
were
indubitably
right
;
that
there
was
no
ground
for
doubt
;
that
the
hard
uphill
work
of
ascertaining
what
the
duty
of
a
clergyman
should
be
had
been
already
accomplished
in
full
;
and
that
what
remained
for
an
active
militant
parson
to
do
was
to
hold
his
own
against
all
comers
.
<EOS>
Her
father
,
it
is
true
,
was
an
exception
to
this
,
but
then
he
was
so
essentially
anti
-
militant
in
all
things
that
she
classed
him
in
her
own
mind
apart
from
all
others
.
<EOS>
She
had
never
argued
the
matter
within
herself
,
or
considered
whether
this
common
tone
was
or
was
not
faulty
;
but
she
was
sick
of
it
without
knowing
that
she
was
so
.
<EOS>
And
now
she
found
to
her
surprise
,
and
not
without
a
certain
pleasurable
excitement
,
that
this
new
-
comer
among
them
spoke
in
a
manner
very
different
from
that
to
which
she
was
accustomed
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
so
easy
to
condemn
,
"
said
he
,
continuing
the
thread
of
his
thoughts
.
<EOS>
"
I
know
no
life
that
must
be
so
delicious
as
that
of
a
writer
for
newspapers
,
or
a
leading
member
of
the
opposition
 
to
thunder
forth
accusations
against
men
in
power
;
to
show
up
the
worst
side
of
everything
that
is
produced
;
to
pick
holes
in
every
coat
;
to
be
indignant
,
sarcastic
,
jocose
,
moral
,
or
supercilious
;
to
damn
with
faint
praise
,
or
crush
with
open
calumny
!
<EOS>
What
can
be
so
easy
as
this
when
the
critic
has
to
be
responsible
for
nothing
?
<EOS>
You
condemn
what
I
do
,
but
put
yourself
in
my
position
and
do
the
reverse
,
and
then
see
if
I
can
not
condemn
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Mr.
Arabin
,
I
do
not
condemn
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Pardon
me
,
you
do
,
<EOS>
Mrs.
Bold
 
you
as
one
of
the
world
;
you
are
now
the
opposition
member
;
you
are
now
composing
your
leading
article
,
and
well
and
bitterly
you
do
it
.
<EOS>
"
Let
dogs
delight
to
bark
and
bite
"
 
you
fitly
begin
with
an
elegant
quotation
 
"
but
if
we
are
to
have
a
church
at
all
,
in
heaven
's
name
let
the
pastors
who
preside
over
it
keep
their
hands
from
each
other
's
throats
.
<EOS>
Lawyers
can
live
without
befouling
each
other
's
names
;
doctors
do
not
fight
duels
.
<EOS>
Why
is
it
that
clergymen
alone
should
indulge
themselves
in
such
unrestrained
liberty
of
abuse
against
each
other
?
"
<EOS>
and
so
you
go
on
reviling
us
for
our
ungodly
quarrels
,
our
sectarian
propensities
,
and
scandalous
differences
.
<EOS>
It
will
,
however
,
give
you
no
trouble
to
write
another
article
next
week
in
which
we
,
or
some
of
us
,
shall
be
twitted
with
an
unseemly
apathy
in
matters
of
our
vocation
.
<EOS>
It
will
not
fall
on
you
to
reconcile
the
discrepancy
;
your
readers
will
never
ask
you
how
the
poor
parson
is
to
be
urgent
in
season
and
out
of
season
and
yet
never
come
in
contact
with
men
who
think
widely
differently
from
him
.
<EOS>
You
,
when
you
condemn
this
foreign
treaty
,
or
that
official
arrangement
,
will
have
to
incur
no
blame
for
the
graver
faults
of
any
different
measure
.
<EOS>
It
is
so
easy
to
condemn
 
and
so
pleasant
too
,
for
eulogy
charms
<EOS>
no
listeners
as
detraction
does
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Eleanor
only
half
-
followed
him
in
his
raillery
,
but
she
caught
his
meaning
.
<EOS>
"
I
know
I
ought
to
apologize
for
presuming
to
criticize
you
,
"
she
said
,
"
but
I
was
thinking
with
sorrow
of
the
ill
-
will
that
has
lately
come
among
us
at
Barchester
,
and
I
spoke
more
freely
than
I
should
have
done
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Peace
on
earth
and
goodwill
among
men
,
are
,
like
heaven
,
promises
for
the
future
;
"
said
he
,
following
rather
his
own
thoughts
than
hers
.
<EOS>
"
When
that
prophecy
is
accomplished
,
there
will
no
longer
be
any
need
for
clergymen
.
"
  
<EOS>
Here
they
were
interrupted
by
the
archdeacon
,
whose
voice
was
heard
from
the
cellar
shouting
to
the
vicar
.
  
<EOS>
"
Arabin
,
Arabin
,
"
 
and
then
,
turning
to
his
wife
,
who
was
apparently
at
his
elbow
 
<EOS>
"
where
has
he
gone
to
?
<EOS>
This
cellar
is
perfectly
abominable
.
<EOS>
It
would
be
murder
to
put
a
bottle
of
wine
into
it
till
it
has
been
roofed
,
walled
,
and
floored
.
<EOS>
How
on
earth
old
Goodenough
ever
got
on
with
it
<EOS>
I
can
not
guess
.
<EOS>
But
then
Goodenough
never
had
a
glass
of
wine
that
any
man
could
drink
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
it
,
Archdeacon
?
"
said
the
vicar
,
running
downstairs
and
leaving
Eleanor
above
to
her
meditations
.
  
<EOS>
"
This
cellar
must
be
roofed
,
walled
,
and
floored
,
"
repeated
the
archdeacon
.
"
<EOS>
Now
mind
what
I
say
,
and
do
n't
let
the
architect
persuade
you
that
it
will
do
;
half
of
these
fellows
know
nothing
about
wine
.
<EOS>
This
place
as
it
is
now
would
be
damp
and
cold
in
winter
and
hot
and
muggy
in
summer
.
<EOS>
I
would
n't
give
a
straw
for
the
best
wine
that
ever
was
vinted
,
after
it
had
lain
here
a
couple
of
years
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
assented
and
promised
that
the
cellar
should
be
reconstructed
according
to
the
archdeacon
's
receipt
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
,
Arabin
,
look
here
;
was
such
an
attempt
at
a
kitchen
grate
ever
seen
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
grate
is
really
very
bad
,
"
said
Mrs.
Grantly
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
the
priestess
wo
n't
approve
of
it
,
when
she
is
brought
home
to
the
scene
of
her
future
duties
.
<EOS>
Really
,
Mr.
Arabin
,
no
priestess
accustomed
to
such
an
excellent
well
as
that
above
could
put
up
with
such
a
grate
as
this
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
there
must
be
a
priestess
at
St.
Ewold
's
at
all
,
Mrs.
Grantly
,
I
think
we
will
leave
her
to
her
well
and
not
call
down
her
divine
wrath
on
any
of
the
imperfections
rising
from
our
human
poverty
.
<EOS>
However
,
I
own
I
am
amenable
to
the
attractions
of
a
well
-
cooked
dinner
,
and
the
grate
shall
certainly
be
changed
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
By
this
time
the
archdeacon
had
again
ascended
,
and
was
now
in
the
dining
-
room
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Arabin
,
"
said
he
,
speaking
in
his
usual
loud
,
clear
voice
and
with
that
tone
of
dictation
which
was
so
common
to
him
,
"
you
must
positively
alter
this
dining
-
room
 
that
is
,
remodel
it
altogether
.
<EOS>
Look
here
,
it
is
just
sixteen
feet
by
fifteen
;
did
any
man
ever
hear
of
a
dining
-
room
of
such
proportions
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
archdeacon
stepped
the
room
long
-
ways
and
cross
-
ways
with
ponderous
steps
,
as
though
a
certain
amount
of
ecclesiastical
dignity
could
be
imparted
even
to
such
an
occupation
as
that
by
the
manner
of
doing
it
.
"
<EOS>
Barely
sixteen
;
you
may
call
it
a
square
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
would
do
very
well
for
a
round
table
,
"
suggested
the
ex
-
warden
.
  
<EOS>
Now
there
was
something
peculiarly
unorthodox
,
in
the
archdeacon
's
estimation
,
in
the
idea
of
a
round
table
.
<EOS>
He
had
always
been
accustomed
to
a
goodly
board
of
decent
length
,
comfortably
elongating
itself
according
to
the
number
of
the
guests
,
nearly
black
with
perpetual
rubbing
,
and
as
bright
as
a
mirror
.
<EOS>
Now
round
dinner
-
tables
are
generally
of
oak
,
or
else
of
such
new
construction
as
not
to
have
acquired
the
peculiar
hue
which
was
so
pleasing
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
connected
them
with
what
he
called
the
nasty
newfangled
method
of
leaving
a
cloth
on
the
table
,
as
though
to
warn
people
that
they
were
not
to
sit
long
.
<EOS>
In
his
eyes
there
was
something
democratic
and
parvenu
in
a
round
table
.
<EOS>
He
imagined
that
dissenters
and
calico
-
printers
chiefly
used
them
,
and
perhaps
a
few
literary
lions
more
conspicuous
for
their
wit
than
their
gentility
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
little
flurried
at
the
idea
of
such
an
article
being
introduced
into
the
diocese
by
a
protégé
of
his
own
,
and
at
the
instigation
of
his
father
-
in
-
law
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
round
dinner
-
table
,
"
said
he
with
some
heat
,
"
is
the
most
abominable
article
of
furniture
that
ever
was
invented
.
<EOS>
I
hope
that
Arabin
has
more
taste
than
to
allow
such
a
thing
in
his
house
.
"
  
<EOS>
Poor
Mr.
Harding
felt
himself
completely
snubbed
,
and
of
course
said
nothing
further
;
but
Mr.
Arabin
,
who
had
yielded
submissively
in
the
small
matters
of
the
cellar
and
kitchen
grate
,
found
himself
obliged
to
oppose
reforms
which
might
be
of
a
nature
too
expensive
for
his
pocket
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
it
seems
to
me
,
Archdeacon
,
that
I
ca
n't
very
well
lengthen
the
room
without
pulling
down
the
wall
,
and
if
I
pull
down
the
wall
,
I
must
build
it
up
again
;
then
if
I
throw
out
a
bow
on
this
side
,
I
must
do
the
same
on
the
other
,
and
if
I
do
it
for
the
ground
floor
,
I
must
carry
it
up
to
the
floor
above
.
<EOS>
That
will
be
putting
a
new
front
to
the
house
and
will
cost
,
I
suppose
,
a
couple
of
hundred
pounds
.
<EOS>
The
ecclesiastical
commissioners
will
hardly
assist
me
when
they
hear
that
my
grievance
consists
in
having
a
dining
-
room
only
sixteen
feet
long
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
archdeacon
proceeded
to
explain
that
nothing
would
be
easier
than
adding
six
feet
to
the
front
of
the
dining
-
room
without
touching
any
other
room
in
the
house
.
<EOS>
Such
irregularities
of
construction
in
small
country
-
houses
were
,
he
said
,
rather
graceful
than
otherwise
,
and
he
offered
to
pay
for
the
whole
thing
out
of
his
own
pocket
if
it
cost
more
than
forty
pounds
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
,
however
,
was
firm
,
and
,
although
the
archdeacon
fussed
and
fumed
about
it
,
would
not
give
way
.
<EOS>
Forty
pounds
,
he
said
,
was
a
matter
of
serious
moment
to
him
,
and
his
friends
,
if
under
such
circumstances
they
would
be
good
-
natured
enough
to
come
to
him
at
all
,
must
put
up
with
the
misery
of
a
square
room
.
<EOS>
He
was
willing
to
compromise
matters
by
disclaiming
any
intention
of
having
a
round
table
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
,
"
said
Mrs.
Grantly
,
"
what
if
the
priestess
insists
on
having
both
the
rooms
enlarged
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
priestess
in
that
case
must
do
it
for
herself
,
Mrs.
Grantly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
doubt
she
will
be
well
able
to
do
so
,
"
replied
the
lady
;
"
to
do
that
and
many
more
wonderful
things
.
<EOS>
I
am
quite
sure
that
the
priestess
of
St.
Ewold
,
when
she
does
come
,
wo
n't
come
empty
-
handed
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
,
however
,
did
not
appear
well
inclined
to
enter
into
speculative
expenses
on
such
a
chance
as
this
,
and
therefore
any
material
alterations
in
the
house
,
the
cost
of
which
could
not
fairly
be
made
to
lie
at
the
door
either
of
the
ecclesiastical
commissioners
or
of
the
estate
of
the
late
incumbent
,
were
tabooed
.
<EOS>
With
this
essential
exception
,
the
archdeacon
ordered
,
suggested
,
and
carried
all
points
before
him
in
a
manner
very
much
to
his
own
satisfaction
.
<EOS>
A
close
observer
,
had
there
been
one
there
,
might
have
seen
that
his
wife
had
been
quite
as
useful
in
the
matter
as
himself
.
<EOS>
No
one
knew
better
than
Mrs.
Grantly
the
appurtenances
necessary
to
a
comfortable
house
.
<EOS>
She
did
not
,
however
,
think
it
necessary
to
lay
claim
to
any
of
the
glory
which
her
lord
and
master
was
so
ready
to
appropriate
as
his
own
.
  
<EOS>
Having
gone
through
their
work
effectually
and
systematically
,
the
party
returned
to
Plumstead
well
satisfied
with
their
expedition
.
   
<EOS>
The
Thornes
of
Ullathorne
 
<EOS>
On
the
following
Sunday
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
was
to
read
himself
in
at
his
new
church
.
<EOS>
It
was
agreed
at
the
rectory
that
the
archdeacon
should
go
over
with
him
and
assist
at
the
reading
desk
,
and
that
Mr.
Harding
should
take
the
archdeacon
's
duty
at
Plumstead
Church
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Grantly
had
her
school
and
her
buns
to
attend
to
,
and
professed
that
she
could
not
be
spared
,
but
Mrs.
Bold
was
to
accompany
them
.
<EOS>
It
was
further
agreed
also
that
they
would
lunch
at
the
squire
's
house
and
return
home
after
the
afternoon
service
.
  
<EOS>
Wilfred
Thorne
,
Esq
.
,
of
Ullathorne
,
was
the
squire
of
St.
Ewold
's
 
or
,
rather
,
the
squire
of
Ullathorne
,
for
the
domain
of
the
modern
landlord
was
of
wider
notoriety
than
the
fame
of
the
ancient
saint
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
fair
specimen
of
what
that
race
has
come
to
in
our
days
which
,
a
century
ago
,
was
,
as
we
are
told
,
fairly
represented
by
Squire
Western
.
<EOS>
If
that
representation
be
a
true
one
,
few
classes
of
men
can
have
made
faster
strides
in
improvement
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Thorne
,
however
,
was
a
man
possessed
of
quite
a
sufficient
number
of
foibles
to
lay
him
open
to
much
ridicule
.
<EOS>
He
was
still
a
bachelor
,
being
about
fifty
,
and
was
not
a
little
proud
of
his
person
.
<EOS>
When
living
at
home
at
Ullathorne
,
there
was
not
much
room
for
such
pride
,
and
there
therefore
he
always
looked
like
a
gentleman
and
like
that
which
he
certainly
was
,
the
first
man
in
his
parish
.
<EOS>
But
during
the
month
or
six
weeks
which
he
annually
spent
in
London
,
he
tried
so
hard
to
look
like
a
great
man
there
also
,
which
he
certainly
was
not
,
that
he
was
put
down
as
a
fool
by
many
at
his
club
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
man
of
considerable
literary
attainment
in
a
certain
way
and
on
certain
subjects
.
<EOS>
His
favourite
authors
were
Montaigne
and
Burton
,
and
he
knew
more
perhaps
than
any
other
man
in
his
own
county
and
the
next
to
it
of
the
English
essayists
of
the
two
last
centuries
.
<EOS>
He
possessed
complete
sets
of
the
Idler
,
the
Spectator
,
the
Tatler
,
the
Guardian
,
and
the
Rambler
,
and
would
discourse
by
hours
together
on
the
superiority
of
such
publications
to
anything
which
has
since
been
produced
in
our
Edinburghs
and
Quarterlies
.
<EOS>
He
was
proficient
in
all
questions
of
genealogy
,
and
knew
enough
of
almost
every
gentleman
's
family
in
England
to
say
of
what
blood
and
lineage
were
descended
all
those
who
had
any
claim
to
be
considered
as
possessors
of
any
such
luxuries
.
<EOS>
For
blood
and
lineage
he
himself
had
a
most
profound
respect
.
<EOS>
He
counted
back
his
own
ancestors
to
some
period
long
antecedent
to
the
Conquest
,
and
could
tell
you
,
if
you
would
listen
to
him
,
how
it
had
come
to
pass
that
they
,
like
Cedric
the
Saxon
,
had
been
permitted
to
hold
their
own
among
the
Norman
barons
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
,
according
to
his
showing
,
on
account
of
any
weak
complaisance
on
the
part
of
his
family
towards
their
Norman
neighbours
.
<EOS>
Some
Ealfried
of
Ullathorne
once
fortified
his
own
castle
and
held
out
,
not
only
that
,
but
the
then
existing
cathedral
of
Barchester
also
,
against
one
Geoffrey
De
Burgh
,
in
the
time
of
King
John
;
and
Mr.
Thorne
possessed
the
whole
history
of
the
siege
written
on
vellum
and
illuminated
in
a
most
costly
manner
.
<EOS>
It
little
signified
that
no
one
could
read
the
writing
,
as
,
had
that
been
possible
,
no
one
could
have
understood
the
language
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Thorne
could
,
however
,
give
you
all
the
particulars
in
good
English
,
and
had
no
objection
to
do
so
.
  
<EOS>
It
would
be
unjust
to
say
that
he
looked
down
on
men
whose
families
were
of
recent
date
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
do
so
.
<EOS>
He
frequently
consorted
with
such
,
and
had
chosen
many
of
his
friends
from
among
them
.
<EOS>
But
he
looked
on
them
as
great
millionaires
are
apt
to
look
on
those
who
have
small
incomes
;
as
men
who
have
Sophocles
at
their
fingers
"
ends
regard
those
who
know
nothing
of
Greek
.
<EOS>
They
might
doubtless
be
good
sort
of
people
,
entitled
to
much
praise
for
virtue
,
very
admirable
for
talent
,
highly
respectable
in
every
way
,
but
they
were
without
the
one
great
good
gift
.
<EOS>
Such
was
Mr.
Thorne
's
way
of
thinking
on
this
matter
<EOS>
;
nothing
could
atone
for
the
loss
of
good
blood
;
nothing
could
neutralize
its
good
effects
.
<EOS>
Few
indeed
were
now
possessed
of
it
,
but
the
possession
was
on
that
account
the
more
precious
.
<EOS>
It
was
very
pleasant
to
hear
Mr.
Thorne
descant
on
this
matter
.
<EOS>
Were
you
in
your
ignorance
to
surmise
that
such
a
one
was
of
a
good
family
because
the
head
of
his
family
was
a
baronet
of
an
old
date
,
he
would
open
his
eyes
with
a
delightful
look
of
affected
surprise
,
and
modestly
remind
you
that
baronetcies
only
dated
from
James
I.
<EOS>
He
would
gently
sigh
if
you
spoke
of
the
blood
of
the
Fitzgeralds
and
De
Burghs
;
would
hardly
allow
the
claims
of
the
Howards
and
Lowthers
;
and
has
before
now
alluded
to
the
Talbots
as
a
family
who
had
hardly
yet
achieved
the
full
honours
of
a
pedigree
.
  
<EOS>
In
speaking
once
of
a
wide
-
spread
race
whose
name
had
received
the
honours
of
three
coronets
,
scions
from
which
sat
for
various
constituencies
,
some
one
of
whose
members
had
been
in
almost
every
cabinet
formed
during
the
present
century
,
a
brilliant
race
such
as
there
are
few
in
England
,
Mr.
Thorne
had
called
them
all
"
dirt
.
"
<EOS>
He
had
not
intended
any
disrespect
to
these
men
.
<EOS>
He
admired
them
in
many
senses
,
and
allowed
them
their
privileges
without
envy
.
<EOS>
He
had
merely
meant
to
express
his
feeling
that
the
streams
which
ran
through
their
veins
were
not
yet
purified
by
time
to
that
perfection
,
had
not
become
so
genuine
an
ichor
,
as
to
be
worthy
of
being
called
blood
in
the
genealogical
sense
.
  
<EOS>
When
Mr.
Arabin
was
first
introduced
to
him
,
Mr.
Thorne
had
immediately
suggested
that
he
was
one
of
the
Arabins
of
Uphill
Stanton
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
replied
that
he
was
a
very
distant
relative
of
the
family
alluded
to
.
<EOS>
To
this
Mr.
Thorne
surmised
that
the
relationship
could
not
be
very
distant
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
assured
him
that
it
was
so
distant
that
the
families
knew
nothing
of
each
other
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Thorne
laughed
his
gentle
laugh
at
this
and
told
Mr.
Arabin
that
there
was
now
existing
no
branch
of
his
family
separated
from
the
parent
stock
at
an
earlier
date
than
the
reign
of
Elizabeth
,
and
that
therefore
Mr.
Arabin
could
not
call
himself
distant
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
himself
was
quite
clearly
an
Arabin
of
Uphill
Stanton
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
,
"
said
the
vicar
,
"
Uphill
Stanton
has
been
sold
to
the
De
Greys
and
has
been
in
their
hands
for
the
last
fifty
years
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
when
it
has
been
there
one
hundred
and
fifty
,
if
it
unluckily
remain
there
so
long
,
"
said
Mr.
Thorne
,
"
your
descendants
will
not
be
a
whit
the
less
entitled
to
describe
themselves
as
being
of
the
family
of
Uphill
Stanton
.
<EOS>
Thank
God
no
De
Grey
can
buy
that
 
and
thank
God
no
Arabin
,
and
no
Thorne
,
can
sell
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
In
politics
<EOS>
Mr.
Thorne
was
an
unflinching
conservative
.
<EOS>
He
looked
on
those
fifty
-
three
Trojans
who
,
as
Mr.
Dod
tells
us
,
censured
free
trade
in
November
,
1852
,
as
the
only
patriots
left
among
the
public
men
of
England
.
<EOS>
When
that
terrible
crisis
of
free
trade
had
arrived
,
when
the
repeal
of
the
Corn
Laws
was
carried
by
those
very
men
whom
Mr.
Thorne
had
hitherto
regarded
as
the
only
possible
saviours
of
his
country
,
he
was
for
a
time
paralysed
.
<EOS>
His
country
was
lost
;
but
that
was
comparatively
a
small
thing
.
<EOS>
Other
countries
had
flourished
and
fallen
,
and
the
human
race
still
went
on
improving
under
God
's
providence
.
<EOS>
But
now
all
trust
in
human
faith
must
forever
be
at
an
end
.
<EOS>
Not
only
must
ruin
come
,
but
it
must
come
through
the
apostasy
of
those
who
had
been
regarded
as
the
truest
of
true
believers
.
<EOS>
Politics
in
England
,
as
a
pursuit
for
gentlemen
,
must
be
at
an
end
.
<EOS>
Had
Mr.
Thorne
been
trodden
under
foot
by
a
Whig
,
he
could
have
borne
it
as
a
Tory
and
a
martyr
,
but
to
be
so
utterly
thrown
over
and
deceived
by
those
he
had
so
earnestly
supported
,
so
thoroughly
trusted
,
was
more
than
he
could
endure
and
live
.
<EOS>
He
therefore
ceased
to
live
as
a
politician
,
and
refused
to
hold
any
converse
with
the
world
at
large
on
the
state
of
the
country
.
  
<EOS>
Such
were
Mr.
Thorne
's
impressions
for
the
first
two
or
three
years
after
Sir
Robert
Peel
's
apostasy
,
but
by
degrees
his
temper
,
as
did
that
of
others
,
cooled
down
.
<EOS>
He
began
once
more
to
move
about
,
to
frequent
the
bench
and
the
market
,
and
to
be
seen
at
dinners
shoulder
to
shoulder
with
some
of
those
who
had
so
cruelly
betrayed
him
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
necessity
for
him
to
live
,
and
that
plan
of
his
for
avoiding
the
world
did
not
answer
.
<EOS>
He
,
however
,
and
others
around
him
who
still
maintained
the
same
staunch
principles
of
protection
 
men
like
himself
who
were
too
true
to
flinch
at
the
cry
of
a
mob
 
had
their
own
way
of
consoling
themselves
.
<EOS>
They
were
,
and
felt
themselves
to
be
,
the
only
true
depositaries
left
of
certain
Eleusinian
mysteries
,
of
certain
deep
and
wondrous
services
of
worship
by
which
alone
the
gods
could
be
rightly
approached
.
<EOS>
To
them
and
them
only
was
it
now
given
to
know
these
things
and
to
perpetuate
them
,
if
that
might
still
be
done
,
by
the
careful
and
secret
education
of
their
children
.
  
<EOS>
We
have
read
how
private
and
peculiar
forms
of
worship
have
been
carried
on
from
age
to
age
in
families
which
,
to
the
outer
world
,
have
apparently
adhered
to
the
services
of
some
ordinary
church
.
<EOS>
And
so
by
degrees
it
was
with
Mr.
Thorne
.
<EOS>
He
learnt
at
length
to
listen
calmly
while
protection
was
talked
of
as
a
thing
dead
,
although
he
knew
within
himself
that
it
was
still
quick
with
a
mystic
life
.
<EOS>
Nor
was
he
without
a
certain
pleasure
that
such
knowledge
,
though
given
to
him
,
should
be
debarred
from
the
multitude
.
<EOS>
He
became
accustomed
to
hear
even
among
country
gentlemen
that
free
trade
was
after
all
not
so
bad
,
and
to
hear
this
without
dispute
,
although
conscious
within
himself
that
everything
good
in
England
had
gone
with
his
old
palladium
.
<EOS>
He
had
within
him
something
of
the
feeling
of
Cato
,
who
gloried
that
he
could
kill
himself
because
Romans
were
no
longer
worthy
of
their
name
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Thorne
had
no
thought
of
killing
himself
,
being
a
Christian
and
still
possessing
his
£
4000
a
year
,
but
the
feeling
was
not
on
that
account
the
less
comfortable
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Thorne
was
a
sportsman
,
and
had
been
active
though
not
outrageous
in
his
sports
.
<EOS>
Previous
to
the
great
downfall
of
politics
in
his
county
,
he
had
supported
the
hunt
by
every
means
in
his
power
.
<EOS>
He
had
preserved
game
till
no
goose
or
turkey
could
show
a
tail
in
the
parish
of
St.
Ewold
's
.
<EOS>
He
had
planted
gorse
covers
with
more
care
than
oaks
and
larches
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
more
anxious
for
the
comfort
of
his
foxes
than
of
his
ewes
and
lambs
.
<EOS>
No
meet
had
been
more
popular
than
Ullathorne
;
no
man
's
stables
had
been
more
liberally
open
to
the
horses
of
distant
men
than
Mr.
Thorne
's
;
no
man
had
said
more
,
written
more
,
or
done
more
to
keep
the
club
up
.
<EOS>
The
theory
of
protection
could
expand
itself
so
thoroughly
in
the
practices
of
a
county
hunt
!
<EOS>
But
when
the
great
ruin
came
;
when
the
noble
master
of
the
Barsetshire
hounds
supported
the
recreant
minister
in
the
House
of
Lords
and
basely
surrendered
his
truth
,
his
manhood
,
his
friends
,
and
his
honour
for
the
hope
of
a
garter
,
then
Mr.
Thorne
gave
up
the
hunt
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
cut
his
covers
,
for
that
would
not
have
been
the
act
of
a
gentleman
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
kill
his
foxes
,
for
that
according
to
his
light
would
have
been
murder
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
say
that
his
covers
should
not
be
drawn
,
or
his
earths
stopped
,
for
that
would
have
been
illegal
according
to
the
by
-
laws
prevailing
among
country
gentlemen
.
<EOS>
But
he
absented
himself
from
home
on
the
occasion
of
every
meet
at
Ullathorne
,
left
the
covers
to
their
fate
,
and
could
not
be
persuaded
to
take
his
pink
coat
out
of
his
press
,
or
his
hunters
out
of
his
stable
.
<EOS>
This
lasted
for
two
years
,
and
then
by
degrees
he
came
round
.
<EOS>
He
first
appeared
at
a
neighbouring
meet
on
a
pony
,
dressed
in
his
shooting
-
coat
,
as
though
he
had
trotted
in
by
accident
;
then
he
walked
up
one
morning
on
foot
to
see
his
favourite
gorse
drawn
,
and
when
his
groom
brought
his
mare
out
by
chance
,
he
did
not
refuse
to
mount
her
.
<EOS>
He
was
next
persuaded
,
by
one
of
the
immortal
fifty
-
three
,
to
bring
his
hunting
materials
over
to
the
other
side
of
the
county
and
take
a
fortnight
with
the
hounds
there
;
and
so
gradually
he
returned
to
his
old
life
.
<EOS>
But
in
hunting
as
in
other
things
he
was
only
supported
by
an
inward
feeling
of
mystic
superiority
to
those
with
whom
he
shared
the
common
breath
of
outer
life
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Thorne
did
not
live
in
solitude
at
Ullathorne
.
<EOS>
He
had
a
sister
,
who
was
ten
years
older
than
himself
and
who
participated
in
his
prejudices
and
feelings
so
strongly
that
she
was
a
living
caricature
of
all
his
foibles
.
<EOS>
She
would
not
open
a
modern
quarterly
,
did
not
choose
to
see
a
magazine
in
her
drawing
-
room
,
and
would
not
have
polluted
her
fingers
with
a
shred
of
the
Times
for
any
consideration
.
<EOS>
She
spoke
of
Addison
,
Swift
,
and
Steele
as
though
they
were
still
living
,
regarded
Defoe
as
the
best
known
novelist
of
his
country
,
and
thought
of
Fielding
as
a
young
but
meritorious
novice
in
the
fields
of
romance
.
<EOS>
In
poetry
,
she
was
familiar
with
names
as
late
as
Dryden
,
and
had
once
been
seduced
into
reading
"
The
Rape
of
the
Lock
;
"
but
she
regarded
Spenser
as
the
purest
type
of
her
country
's
literature
in
this
line
.
<EOS>
Genealogy
was
her
favourite
insanity
.
<EOS>
Those
things
which
are
the
pride
of
most
genealogists
were
to
her
contemptible
.
<EOS>
Arms
and
mottoes
set
her
beside
herself
.
<EOS>
Ealfried
of
Ullathorne
had
wanted
no
motto
to
assist
him
in
cleaving
to
the
brisket
Geoffrey
De
Burgh
,
and
Ealfried
's
great
grandfather
,
the
gigantic
Ullafrid
,
had
required
no
other
arms
than
those
which
nature
gave
him
to
hurl
from
the
top
of
his
own
castle
a
cousin
of
the
base
invading
Norman
.
<EOS>
To
her
all
modern
English
names
were
equally
insignificant
:
<EOS>
Hengist
,
Horsa
,
and
such
like
had
for
her
ears
the
only
true
savour
of
nobility
.
<EOS>
She
was
not
contented
unless
she
could
go
beyond
the
Saxons
,
and
would
certainly
have
christened
her
children
,
had
she
had
children
,
by
the
names
of
the
ancient
Britons
.
<EOS>
In
some
respects
she
was
not
unlike
Scott
's
Ulrica
,
and
had
she
been
given
to
cursing
,
she
would
certainly
have
done
so
in
the
names
of
Mista
,
Skogula
,
and
Zernebock
.
<EOS>
Not
having
submitted
to
the
embraces
of
any
polluting
Norman
,
as
poor
Ulrica
had
done
,
and
having
assisted
no
parricide
,
the
milk
of
human
kindness
was
not
curdled
in
her
bosom
.
<EOS>
She
never
cursed
therefore
,
but
blessed
rather
.
<EOS>
This
,
however
,
she
did
in
a
strange
uncouth
Saxon
manner
that
would
have
been
unintelligible
to
any
peasants
but
her
own
.
  
<EOS>
As
a
politician
,
Miss
Thorne
had
been
so
thoroughly
disgusted
with
public
life
by
base
deeds
long
antecedent
to
the
Corn
Law
question
that
that
had
but
little
moved
her
.
<EOS>
In
her
estimation
her
brother
had
been
a
fast
young
man
,
hurried
away
by
a
too
ardent
temperament
into
democratic
tendencies
.
<EOS>
Now
happily
he
was
brought
to
sounder
views
by
seeing
the
iniquity
of
the
world
.
<EOS>
She
had
not
yet
reconciled
herself
to
the
Reform
Bill
,
and
still
groaned
in
spirit
over
the
defalcations
of
the
Duke
as
touching
the
Catholic
Emancipation
.
<EOS>
If
asked
whom
she
thought
the
Queen
should
take
as
her
counsellor
,
she
would
probably
have
named
Lord
Eldon
,
and
when
reminded
that
that
venerable
man
was
no
longer
present
in
the
flesh
to
assist
us
,
she
would
probably
have
answered
with
a
sigh
that
none
now
could
help
us
but
the
dead
.
  
<EOS>
In
religion
Miss
Thorne
was
a
pure
Druidess
.
<EOS>
We
would
not
have
it
understood
by
that
<EOS>
that
she
did
actually
in
these
latter
days
assist
at
any
human
sacrifices
,
or
that
she
was
in
fact
hostile
to
the
Church
of
Christ
.
<EOS>
She
had
adopted
the
Christian
religion
as
a
milder
form
of
the
worship
of
her
ancestors
,
and
always
appealed
to
her
doing
so
as
evidence
that
she
had
no
prejudices
against
reform
,
when
it
could
be
shown
that
reform
was
salutary
.
<EOS>
This
reform
was
the
most
modern
of
any
to
which
she
had
as
yet
acceded
,
it
being
presumed
that
British
ladies
had
given
up
their
paint
and
taken
to
some
sort
of
petticoats
before
the
days
of
St.
Augustine
.
<EOS>
That
further
feminine
step
in
advance
which
combines
paint
and
petticoats
together
had
not
found
a
votary
in
Miss
Thorne
.
  
<EOS>
But
she
was
a
Druidess
in
this
,
that
she
regretted
she
knew
not
what
in
the
usages
and
practices
of
her
Church
.
<EOS>
She
sometimes
talked
and
constantly
thought
of
good
things
gone
by
,
though
she
had
but
the
faintest
idea
of
what
those
good
things
had
been
.
<EOS>
She
imagined
that
a
purity
had
existed
which
was
now
gone
,
that
a
piety
had
adorned
our
pastors
and
a
simple
docility
our
people
,
for
which
it
may
be
feared
history
gave
her
but
little
true
warrant
.
<EOS>
She
was
accustomed
to
speak
of
Cranmer
as
though
he
had
been
the
firmest
and
most
simple
-
minded
of
martyrs
,
and
of
Elizabeth
as
though
the
pure
Protestant
faith
of
her
people
had
been
the
one
anxiety
of
her
life
.
<EOS>
It
would
have
been
cruel
to
undeceive
her
,
had
it
been
possible
;
but
it
would
have
been
impossible
to
make
her
believe
that
the
one
was
a
time
-
serving
priest
,
willing
to
go
any
length
to
keep
his
place
,
and
that
the
other
was
in
heart
a
papist
,
with
this
sole
proviso
,
that
she
should
be
her
own
pope
.
  
<EOS>
And
so
Miss
Thorne
went
on
sighing
and
regretting
,
looking
back
to
the
divine
right
of
kings
as
the
ruling
axiom
of
a
golden
age
,
and
cherishing
,
low
down
in
the
bottom
of
her
heart
of
hearts
,
a
dear
unmentioned
wish
for
the
restoration
of
some
exiled
Stuart
.
<EOS>
Who
would
deny
her
the
luxury
of
her
sighs
,
or
the
sweetness
of
her
soft
regrets
!
  
<EOS>
In
her
person
and
her
dress
she
was
perfect
,
and
well
she
knew
her
own
perfection
.
<EOS>
She
was
a
small
,
elegantly
made
old
woman
,
with
a
face
from
which
the
glow
of
her
youth
had
not
departed
without
leaving
some
streaks
of
a
roseate
hue
.
<EOS>
She
was
proud
of
her
colour
,
proud
of
her
grey
hair
which
she
wore
in
short
crisp
curls
peering
out
all
around
her
face
from
her
dainty
white
lace
cap
.
<EOS>
To
think
of
all
the
money
that
she
spent
in
lace
used
to
break
the
heart
of
poor
Mrs.
Quiverful
with
her
seven
daughters
.
<EOS>
She
was
proud
of
her
teeth
,
which
were
still
white
and
numerous
,
proud
of
her
bright
cheery
eye
,
proud
of
her
short
jaunty
step
;
and
very
proud
of
the
neat
,
precise
,
small
feet
with
which
those
steps
were
taken
.
<EOS>
She
was
proud
also
,
ay
,
very
proud
,
of
the
rich
brocaded
silk
in
which
it
was
her
custom
to
ruffle
through
her
drawing
-
room
.
  
<EOS>
We
know
what
was
the
custom
of
the
lady
of
Branksome
    
Nine
-
and
-
twenty
knights
of
fame
Hung
their
shields
in
Branksome
Hall
.
  
<EOS>
The
lady
of
Ullathorne
was
not
so
martial
in
her
habits
,
but
hardly
less
costly
.
<EOS>
She
might
have
boasted
that
nine
-
and
-
twenty
silken
skirts
might
have
been
produced
in
her
chamber
,
each
fit
to
stand
alone
.
<EOS>
The
nine
-
and
-
twenty
shields
of
the
Scottish
heroes
were
less
independent
and
hardly
more
potent
to
withstand
any
attack
that
might
be
made
on
them
.
<EOS>
Miss
Thorne
when
fully
dressed
might
be
said
to
have
been
armed
cap
-
a
-
pie
,
and
she
was
always
fully
dressed
,
as
far
as
was
ever
known
to
mortal
man
.
  
<EOS>
For
all
this
rich
attire
Miss
Thorne
was
not
indebted
to
the
generosity
of
her
brother
.
<EOS>
She
had
a
very
comfortable
independence
of
her
own
,
which
she
divided
among
juvenile
relatives
,
the
milliners
,
and
the
poor
,
giving
much
the
largest
share
to
the
latter
.
<EOS>
It
may
be
imagined
,
therefore
,
that
with
all
her
little
follies
she
was
not
unpopular
.
<EOS>
All
her
follies
have
,
we
believe
,
been
told
.
<EOS>
Her
virtues
were
too
numerous
to
describe
,
and
not
sufficiently
interesting
to
deserve
description
.
  
<EOS>
While
we
are
on
the
subject
of
the
Thornes
,
one
word
must
be
said
of
the
house
they
lived
in
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
a
large
house
,
nor
a
fine
house
,
nor
perhaps
to
modern
ideas
a
very
commodious
house
,
but
by
those
who
love
the
peculiar
colour
and
peculiar
ornaments
of
genuine
Tudor
architecture
it
was
considered
a
perfect
gem
.
<EOS>
We
beg
to
own
ourselves
among
the
number
,
and
therefore
take
this
opportunity
to
express
our
surprise
that
so
little
is
known
by
English
men
and
women
of
the
beauties
of
English
architecture
.
<EOS>
The
ruins
of
the
Colosseum
,
the
Campanile
at
Florence
,
<EOS>
St.
Mark
's
,
Cologne
,
the
Bourse
and
Notre
Dame
are
with
our
tourists
as
familiar
as
household
words
;
but
they
know
nothing
of
the
glories
of
Wiltshire
,
Dorsetshire
,
and
Somersetshire
.
<EOS>
Nay
,
we
much
question
whether
many
noted
travellers
,
men
who
have
pitched
their
tents
perhaps
under
Mount
Sinai
,
are
not
still
ignorant
that
there
are
glories
in
Wiltshire
,
Dorsetshire
,
and
Somersetshire
.
<EOS>
We
beg
that
they
will
go
and
see
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Thorne
's
house
was
called
Ullathorne
Court
 
and
was
properly
so
called
,
for
the
house
itself
formed
two
sides
of
a
quadrangle
,
which
was
completed
on
the
other
two
sides
by
a
wall
about
twenty
feet
high
.
<EOS>
This
wall
was
built
of
cut
stone
,
rudely
cut
indeed
,
and
now
much
worn
,
but
of
a
beautiful
,
rich
,
tawny
yellow
colour
,
the
effect
of
that
stonecrop
of
minute
growth
which
it
had
taken
three
centuries
to
produce
.
<EOS>
The
top
of
this
wall
was
ornamented
by
huge
,
round
stone
balls
of
the
same
colour
as
the
wall
itself
.
<EOS>
Entrance
into
the
court
was
had
through
a
pair
of
iron
gates
so
massive
that
no
one
could
comfortably
open
or
close
them
 
consequently
,
they
were
rarely
disturbed
.
<EOS>
From
the
gateway
two
paths
led
obliquely
across
the
court
:
<EOS>
that
to
the
left
reaching
the
hall
-
door
,
which
was
in
the
corner
made
by
the
angle
of
the
house
,
and
that
to
the
right
leading
to
the
back
entrance
,
which
was
at
the
further
end
of
the
longer
portion
of
the
building
.
  
<EOS>
With
those
who
are
now
adepts
in
contriving
house
accommodation
,
it
will
militate
much
against
Ullathorne
Court
that
no
carriage
could
be
brought
to
the
hall
-
door
.
<EOS>
If
you
enter
Ullathorne
at
all
,
you
must
do
so
,
fair
reader
,
on
foot
,
or
at
least
in
a
bath
-
chair
.
<EOS>
No
vehicle
drawn
by
horses
ever
comes
within
that
iron
gate
.
<EOS>
But
this
is
nothing
to
the
next
horror
that
will
encounter
you
.
<EOS>
On
entering
the
front
door
,
which
you
do
by
no
very
grand
portal
,
you
find
yourself
immediately
in
the
dining
-
room
.
<EOS>
What
,
no
hall
?
<EOS>
exclaims
my
luxurious
friend
,
accustomed
to
all
the
comfortable
appurtenances
of
modern
life
.
<EOS>
Yes
,
kind
sir
,
a
noble
hall
,
if
you
will
but
observe
it
;
a
true
old
English
hall
of
excellent
dimensions
for
a
country
gentleman
's
family
;
but
,
if
you
please
,
no
dining
-
parlour
.
  
<EOS>
Both
Mr.
and
Miss
Thorne
were
proud
of
this
peculiarity
of
their
dwelling
,
though
the
brother
was
once
all
but
tempted
by
his
friends
to
alter
it
.
<EOS>
They
delighted
in
the
knowledge
that
they
,
like
Cedric
,
positively
dined
in
their
true
hall
,
even
though
they
so
dined
_
tête
-
à
-
tête
_
.
<EOS>
But
though
they
had
never
owned
,
they
had
felt
and
endeavoured
to
remedy
the
discomfort
of
such
an
arrangement
.
<EOS>
A
huge
screen
partitioned
off
the
front
door
and
a
portion
of
the
hall
,
and
from
the
angle
so
screened
off
a
second
door
led
into
a
passage
which
ran
along
the
larger
side
of
the
house
next
to
the
courtyard
.
<EOS>
Either
my
reader
or
I
must
be
a
bad
hand
at
topography
,
if
it
be
not
clear
that
the
great
hall
forms
the
ground
-
floor
of
the
smaller
portion
of
the
mansion
,
that
which
was
to
your
left
as
you
entered
the
iron
gate
,
and
that
it
occupies
the
whole
of
this
wing
of
the
building
.
<EOS>
It
must
be
equally
clear
that
it
looks
out
on
a
trim
mown
lawn
,
through
three
quadrangular
windows
with
stone
mullions
,
each
window
divided
into
a
larger
portion
at
the
bottom
,
and
a
smaller
portion
at
the
top
,
and
each
portion
again
divided
into
five
by
perpendicular
stone
supporters
.
<EOS>
There
may
be
windows
which
give
a
better
light
than
such
as
these
,
and
it
may
be
,
as
my
utilitarian
friend
observes
,
that
the
giving
of
light
is
the
desired
object
of
a
window
.
<EOS>
I
will
not
argue
the
point
with
him
.
<EOS>
Indeed
I
can
not
.
<EOS>
But
I
shall
not
the
less
die
in
the
assured
conviction
that
no
sort
or
description
of
window
is
capable
of
imparting
half
so
much
happiness
to
mankind
as
that
which
had
been
adopted
at
Ullathorne
Court
.
<EOS>
What
,
not
an
oriel
?
<EOS>
says
Miss
Diana
de
Midellage
.
<EOS>
No
,
Miss
Diana
,
not
even
an
oriel
,
beautiful
as
is
an
oriel
window
.
<EOS>
It
has
not
about
it
<EOS>
so
perfect
a
feeling
of
quiet
English
homely
comfort
.
<EOS>
Let
oriel
windows
grace
a
college
,
or
the
half
-
public
mansion
of
a
potent
peer
,
but
for
the
sitting
room
of
quiet
country
ladies
,
of
ordinary
homely
folk
,
nothing
can
equal
the
square
,
mullioned
windows
of
the
Tudor
architects
.
  
<EOS>
The
hall
was
hung
round
with
family
female
insipidities
by
Lely
and
unprepossessing
male
Thornes
in
red
coats
by
Kneller
,
each
Thorne
having
been
let
into
a
panel
in
the
wainscoting
,
in
the
proper
manner
.
<EOS>
At
the
further
end
of
the
room
was
a
huge
fire
-
place
,
which
afforded
much
ground
of
difference
between
the
brother
and
sister
.
<EOS>
An
antiquated
grate
that
would
hold
about
a
hundredweight
of
coal
,
had
been
stuck
on
to
the
hearth
by
Mr.
Thorne
's
father
.
<EOS>
This
hearth
had
of
course
been
intended
for
the
consumption
of
wood
faggots
,
and
the
iron
dogs
for
the
purpose
were
still
standing
,
though
half
-
buried
in
the
masonry
of
the
grate
.
<EOS>
Miss
Thorne
was
very
anxious
to
revert
to
the
dogs
.
<EOS>
The
dear
good
old
creature
was
always
glad
to
revert
to
anything
,
and
had
she
been
systematically
indulged
,
would
doubtless
in
time
have
reflected
that
fingers
were
made
before
forks
and
have
reverted
accordingly
.
<EOS>
But
in
the
affairs
of
the
fire
-
place
Mr.
Thorne
would
not
revert
.
<EOS>
Country
gentlemen
around
him
all
had
comfortable
grates
in
their
dining
-
rooms
.
<EOS>
He
was
not
exactly
the
man
to
have
suggested
a
modern
usage
,
but
he
was
not
so
far
prejudiced
as
to
banish
those
which
his
father
had
prepared
for
his
use
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Thorne
had
indeed
once
suggested
that
with
very
little
contrivance
the
front
door
might
have
been
so
altered
as
to
open
at
least
into
the
passage
,
but
on
hearing
this
,
his
sister
Monica
 
such
was
Miss
Thorne
's
name
 
had
been
taken
ill
and
had
remained
so
for
a
week
.
<EOS>
Before
she
came
downstairs
she
received
a
pledge
from
her
brother
that
the
entrance
should
never
be
changed
in
her
lifetime
.
  
<EOS>
At
the
end
of
the
hall
opposite
to
the
fire
-
place
a
door
led
into
the
drawing
-
room
,
which
was
of
equal
size
,
and
lighted
with
precisely
similar
windows
.
<EOS>
But
yet
the
aspect
of
the
room
was
very
different
.
<EOS>
It
was
papered
,
and
the
ceiling
,
which
in
the
hall
showed
the
old
rafters
,
was
whitened
and
finished
with
a
modern
cornice
.
<EOS>
Miss
Thorne
's
drawing
-
room
,
or
,
as
she
always
called
it
,
withdrawing
-
room
,
was
a
beautiful
apartment
.
<EOS>
The
windows
opened
on
to
the
full
extent
of
the
lovely
trim
garden
;
immediately
before
the
windows
were
plots
of
flowers
in
stiff
,
stately
,
stubborn
little
beds
,
each
bed
surrounded
by
a
stone
coping
of
its
own
;
beyond
,
there
was
a
low
parapet
wall
on
which
stood
urns
and
images
,
fawns
,
nymphs
,
satyrs
,
and
a
whole
tribe
of
Pan
's
followers
;
and
then
again
,
beyond
that
,
a
beautiful
lawn
sloped
away
to
a
sunk
fence
which
divided
the
garden
from
the
park
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Thorne
's
study
was
at
the
end
of
the
drawing
-
room
,
and
beyond
that
were
the
kitchen
and
the
offices
.
<EOS>
Doors
opened
into
both
Miss
Thorne
's
withdrawing
-
room
and
Mr.
Thorne
's
sanctum
from
the
passage
above
alluded
to
,
which
,
as
it
came
to
the
latter
room
,
widened
itself
so
as
to
make
space
for
the
huge
black
oak
stairs
which
led
to
the
upper
regions
.
  
<EOS>
Such
was
the
interior
of
Ullathorne
Court
.
<EOS>
But
having
thus
described
it
,
perhaps
somewhat
too
tediously
,
we
beg
to
say
that
it
is
not
the
interior
to
which
we
wish
to
call
the
English
tourist
's
attention
,
though
we
advise
him
to
lose
no
legitimate
opportunity
of
becoming
acquainted
with
it
in

friendly

.
<EOS>
It
is
the
outside
of
Ullathorne
that
is
so
lovely
.
<EOS>
Let
the
tourist
get
admission
at
least
into
the
garden
and
fling
himself
on
that
soft
sward
just
opposite
to
the
exterior
angle
of
the
house
.
<EOS>
He
will
there
get
the
double
frontage
and
enjoy
that
which
is
so
lovely
 
<EOS>
the
expanse
of
architectural
beauty
without
the
formal
dullness
of
one
long
line
.
  
<EOS>
It
is
the
colour
of
Ullathorne
that
is
so
remarkable
.
<EOS>
It
is
of
that
delicious
tawny
hue
which
no
stone
can
give
,
unless
it
has
on
it
the
vegetable
richness
of
centuries
.
<EOS>
Strike
the
wall
with
your
hand
,
and
you
will
think
that
the
stone
has
on
it
no
covering
,
but
rub
it
carefully
,
and
you
will
find
that
the
colour
comes
off
upon
your
finger
.
<EOS>
No
colourist
that
ever
yet
worked
from
a
palette
has
been
able
to
come
up
to
this
rich
colouring
of
years
crowding
themselves
on
years
.
  
<EOS>
Ullathorne
is
a
high
building
for
a
country
-
house
,
for
it
possesses
three
stories
,
and
in
each
story
the
windows
are
of
the
same
sort
as
that
described
,
though
varying
in
size
and
varying
also
in
their
lines
athwart
the
house
.
<EOS>
Those
of
the
ground
floor
are
all
uniform
in
size
and
position
.
<EOS>
But
those
above
are
irregular
both
in
size
and
place
,
and
this
irregularity
gives
a
bizarre
and
not
unpicturesque
appearance
to
the
building
.
<EOS>
Along
the
top
,
on
every
side
,
runs
a
low
parapet
,
which
nearly
hides
the
roof
,
and
at
the
corners
are
more
figures
of
fawns
and
satyrs
.
  
<EOS>
Such
is
Ullathorne
House
.
<EOS>
But
we
must
say
one
word
of
the
approach
to
it
,
which
shall
include
all
the
description
which
we
mean
to
give
of
the
church
also
.
<EOS>
The
picturesque
old
church
of
St.
Ewold
's
stands
immediately
opposite
to
the
iron
gates
which
open
into
the
court
,
and
is
all
but
surrounded
by
the
branches
of
the
lime
-
trees
which
form
the
avenue
leading
up
to
the
house
from
both
sides
.
<EOS>
This
avenue
is
magnificent
,
but
it
would
lose
much
of
its
value
in
the
eyes
of
many
proprietors
by
the
fact
that
the
road
through
it
is
not
private
property
.
<EOS>
It
is
a
public
lane
between
hedgerows
,
with
a
broad
grass
margin
on
each
side
of
the
road
,
from
which
the
lime
-
trees
spring
.
<EOS>
Ullathorne
Court
,
therefore
,
does
not
stand
absolutely
surrounded
by
its
own
grounds
,
though
Mr.
Thorne
is
owner
of
all
the
adjacent
land
.
<EOS>
This
,
however
,
is
the
source
of
very
little
annoyance
to
him
.
<EOS>
Men
,
when
they
are
acquiring
property
,
think
much
of
such
things
,
but
they
who
live
where
their
ancestors
have
lived
for
years
do
not
feel
the
misfortune
.
<EOS>
It
never
occurred
either
to
Mr.
or
Miss
Thorne
that
they
were
not
sufficiently
private
because
the
world
at
large
might
,
if
it
so
wished
,
walk
or
drive
by
their
iron
gates
.
<EOS>
That
part
of
the
world
which
availed
itself
of
the
privilege
was
however
very
small
.
  
<EOS>
Such
a
year
or
two
since
were
the
Thornes
of
Ullathorne
.
<EOS>
Such
,
we
believe
,
are
the
inhabitants
of
many
an
English
country
-
home
.
<EOS>
May
it
be
long
before
their
number
diminishes
.
   
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
Reads
Himself
in
at
St.
Ewold
's
 
<EOS>
On
the
Sunday
morning
the
archdeacon
with
his
sister
-
in
-
law
and
Mr.
Arabin
drove
over
to
Ullathorne
,
as
had
been
arranged
.
<EOS>
On
their
way
thither
the
new
vicar
declared
himself
to
be
considerably
disturbed
in
his
mind
at
the
idea
of
thus
facing
his
parishioners
for
the
first
time
.
<EOS>
He
had
,
he
said
,
been
always
subject
to
_
mauvaise
honte
_
and
an
annoying
degree
of
bashfulness
,
which
often
unfitted
him
for
any
work
of
a
novel
description
;
and
now
he
felt
this
so
strongly
that
he
feared
he
should
acquit
himself
badly
in
St.
Ewold
's
reading
-
desk
.
<EOS>
He
knew
,
he
said
,
that
those
sharp
little
eyes
of
Miss
Thorne
would
be
on
him
,
and
that
they
would
not
approve
.
<EOS>
All
this
the
archdeacon
greatly
ridiculed
.
<EOS>
He
himself
knew
not
,
and
had
never
known
,
what
it
was
to
be
shy
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
conceive
that
Miss
Thorne
,
surrounded
as
she
would
be
by
the
peasants
of
Ullathorne
and
a
few
of
the
poorer
inhabitants
of
the
suburbs
of
Barchester
,
could
in
any
way
affect
the
composure
of
a
man
well
accustomed
to
address
the
learned
congregation
of
St.
Mary
's
at
Oxford
,
and
he
laughed
accordingly
at
the
idea
of
Mr.
Arabin
's
modesty
.
  
<EOS>
Thereupon
Mr.
Arabin
commenced
to
subtilize
.
<EOS>
The
change
,
he
said
,
from
St.
Mary
's
to
St.
Ewold
's
was
quite
as
powerful
on
the
spirits
as
would
be
that
from
St.
Ewold
's
to
St.
Mary
's
.
<EOS>
Would
not
a
peer
who
,
by
chance
of
fortune
,
might
suddenly
be
driven
to
herd
among
navvies
be
as
afraid
of
the
jeers
of
his
companions
as
would
any
navvy
suddenly
exalted
to
a
seat
among
the
peers
?
<EOS>
Whereupon
the
archdeacon
declared
with
a
loud
laugh
that
he
would
tell
Miss
Thorne
that
her
new
minister
had
likened
her
to
a
navvy
.
<EOS>
Eleanor
,
however
,
pronounced
such
a
conclusion
to
be
unfair
;
a
comparison
might
be
very
just
in
its
proportions
which
did
not
at
all
assimilate
the
things
compared
.
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Arabin
went
on
subtilizing
,
regarding
neither
the
archdeacon
's
raillery
nor
Eleanor
's
defence
.
<EOS>
A
young
lady
,
he
said
,
would
execute
with
most
perfect
self
-
possession
a
difficult
piece
of
music
in
a
room
crowded
with
strangers
,
who
would
not
be
able
to
express
herself
in
intelligible
language
,
even
on
any
ordinary
subject
and
among
her
most
intimate
friends
,
if
she
were
required
to
do
so
standing
on
a
box
somewhat
elevated
among
them
.
<EOS>
It
was
all
an
affair
of
education
,
and
he
at
forty
found
it
difficult
to
educate
himself
anew
.
  
<EOS>
Eleanor
dissented
on
the
matter
of
the
box
,
and
averred
she
could
speak
very
well
about
dresses
,
or
babies
,
or
legs
of
mutton
from
any
box
,
<EOS>
provided
it
were
big
enough
for
her
to
stand
upon
without
fear
,
even
though
all
her
friends
were
listening
to
her
.
<EOS>
The
archdeacon
was
sure
she
would
not
be
able
to
say
a
word
,
but
this
proved
nothing
in
favour
of
Mr.
Arabin
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
said
that
he
would
try
the
question
out
with
Mrs.
Bold
,
and
get
her
on
a
box
some
day
when
the
rectory
might
be
full
of
visitors
.
<EOS>
To
this
Eleanor
assented
,
making
condition
that
the
visitors
should
be
of
their
own
set
,
and
the
archdeacon
cogitated
in
his
mind
whether
by
such
a
condition
it
was
intended
that
Mr.
Slope
should
be
included
,
resolving
also
that
,
if
so
,
the
trial
would
certainly
never
take
place
in
the
rectory
drawing
-
room
at
Plumstead
.
  
<EOS>
And
so
arguing
,
they
drove
up
to
the
iron
gates
of
Ullathorne
Court
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
and
Miss
Thorne
were
standing
ready
dressed
for
church
in
the
hall
,
and
greeted
their
clerical
visitors
with
cordiality
.
<EOS>
The
archdeacon
was
an
old
favourite
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
clergyman
of
the
old
school
,
and
this
recommended
him
to
the
lady
.
<EOS>
He
had
always
been
an
opponent
of
free
trade
as
long
as
free
trade
was
an
open
question
,
and
now
that
it
was
no
longer
so
,
he
,
being
a
clergyman
,
had
not
been
obliged
,
like
most
of
his
lay
Tory
companions
,
to
read
his
recantation
.
<EOS>
He
could
therefore
be
regarded
as
a
supporter
of
the
immaculate
fifty
-
three
,
and
was
on
this
account
a
favourite
with
Mr.
Thorne
.
<EOS>
The
little
bell
was
tinkling
,
and
the
rural
population
of
the
parish
were
standing
about
the
lane
,
leaning
on
the
church
-
stile
and
against
the
walls
of
the
old
court
,
anxious
to
get
a
look
at
their
new
minister
as
he
passed
from
the
house
to
the
rectory
.
<EOS>
The
archdeacon
's
servant
had
already
preceded
them
thither
with
the
vestments
.
  
<EOS>
They
all
went
forth
together
,
and
when
the
ladies
passed
into
the
church
,
the
three
gentlemen
tarried
a
moment
in
the
lane
,
that
Mr.
Thorne
might
name
to
the
vicar
with
some
kind
of
one
-
sided
introduction
the
most
leading
among
his
parishioners
.
  
<EOS>
"
Here
are
our
churchwardens
,
Mr.
Arabin
 
Farmer
Greenacre
and
Mr.
Stiles
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Stiles
has
the
mill
as
you
go
into
Barchester
;
and
very
good
churchwardens
they
are
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
Not
very
severe
,
I
hope
,
"
said
Mr.
Arabin
.
<EOS>
The
two
ecclesiastical
officers
touched
their
hats
,
and
each
made
a
leg
in
the
approved
rural
fashion
,
assuring
the
vicar
that
they
were
very
glad
to
have
the
honour
of
seeing
him
,
and
adding
that
the
weather
was
very
good
for
the
harvest
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Stiles
,
being
a
man
somewhat
versed
in
town
life
,
had
an
impression
of
his
own
dignity
,
and
did
not
quite
like
leaving
his
pastor
under
the
erroneous
idea
that
he
being
a
churchwarden
kept
the
children
in
order
during
church
time
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Twas
thus
he
understood
Mr.
Arabin
's
allusion
to
his
severity
and
hastened
to
put
matters
right
by
observing
that
"
Sexton
Clodheve
looked
to
the
younguns
,
and
perhaps
sometimes
there
may
be
a
thought
too
much
stick
going
on
during
sermon
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
's
bright
eye
twinkled
as
he
caught
that
of
the
archdeacon
,
and
he
smiled
to
himself
as
he
observed
how
ignorant
his
officers
were
of
the
nature
of
their
authority
and
of
the
surveillance
which
it
was
their
duty
to
keep
even
over
himself
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
read
the
lessons
and
preached
.
<EOS>
It
was
enough
to
put
a
man
a
little
out
,
let
him
have
been
ever
so
used
to
pulpit
reading
,
to
see
the
knowing
way
in
which
the
farmers
cocked
their
ears
and
set
about
a
mental
criticism
as
to
whether
their
new
minister
did
or
did
not
fall
short
of
the
excellence
of
him
who
had
lately
departed
from
them
.
<EOS>
A
mental
and
silent
criticism
it
was
for
the
existing
moment
,
but
soon
to
be
made
public
among
the
elders
of
St.
Ewold
's
over
the
green
graves
of
their
children
and
forefathers
.
<EOS>
The
excellence
,
however
,
of
poor
old
Mr.
Goodenough
had
not
been
wonderful
,
and
there
were
few
there
who
did
not
deem
that
Mr.
Arabin
did
his
work
sufficiently
well
,
in
spite
of
the
slightly
nervous
affliction
which
at
first
impeded
him
,
and
which
nearly
drove
the
archdeacon
beside
himself
.
  
<EOS>
But
the
sermon
was
the
thing
to
try
the
man
.
<EOS>
It
often
surprises
us
that
very
young
men
can
muster
courage
to
preach
for
the
first
time
to
a
strange
congregation
.
<EOS>
Men
who
are
as
yet
but
little
more
than
boys
,
who
have
but
just
left
what
indeed
we
may
not
call
a
school
,
but
a
seminary
intended
for
their
tuition
as
scholars
,
whose
thoughts
have
been
mostly
of
boating
,
cricketing
,
and
wine
-
parties
,
ascend
a
rostrum
high
above
the
heads
of
the
submissive
crowd
,
not
that
they
may
read
God
's
word
to
those
below
,
but
that
they
may
preach
their
own
word
for
the
edification
of
their
hearers
.
<EOS>
It
seems
strange
to
us
that
they
are
not
stricken
dumb
by
the
new
and
awful
solemnity
of
their
position
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
How
am
I
,
just
turned
twenty
-
three
,
who
have
never
yet
passed
ten
thoughtful
days
since
the
power
of
thought
first
came
to
me
,
how
am
I
to
instruct
these
greybeards
who
,
with
the
weary
thinking
of
so
many
years
,
have
approached
so
near
the
grave
?
<EOS>
Can
I
teach
them
their
duty
?
<EOS>
Can
I
explain
to
them
that
which
I
so
imperfectly
understand
,
that
which
years
of
study
may
have
made
so
plain
to
them
?
<EOS>
Has
my
newly
acquired
privilege
as
one
of
God
's
ministers
imparted
to
me
as
yet
any
fitness
for
the
wonderful
work
of
a
preacher
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
must
be
supposed
that
such
ideas
do
occur
to
young
clergymen
,
and
yet
they
overcome
,
apparently
with
ease
,
this
difficulty
which
to
us
appears
to
be
all
but
insurmountable
.
<EOS>
We
have
never
been
subjected
in
the
way
of
ordination
to
the
power
of
a
bishop
's
hands
.
<EOS>
It
may
be
that
there
is
in
them
something
that
sustains
the
spirit
and
banishes
the
natural
modesty
of
youth
.
<EOS>
But
for
ourselves
we
must
own
that
the
deep
affection
which
Dominie
Sampson
felt
for
his
young
pupils
has
not
more
endeared
him
to
us
than
the
bashful
spirit
which
sent
him
mute
and
inglorious
from
the
pulpit
when
he
rose
there
with
the
futile
attempt
to
preach
God
's
gospel
.
  
<EOS>
There
is
a
rule
in
our
church
which
forbids
the
younger
order
of
our
clergymen
to
perform
a
certain
portion
of
the
service
.
<EOS>
The
absolution
must
be
read
by
a
minister
in
priest
's
orders
.
<EOS>
If
there
be
no
such
minister
present
,
the
congregation
can
have
the
benefit
of
no
absolution
but
that
which
each
may
succeed
in
administering
to
himself
.
<EOS>
The
rule
may
be
a
good
one
,
though
the
necessity
for
it
hardly
comes
home
to
the
general
understanding
.
<EOS>
But
this
forbearance
on
the
part
of
youth
would
be
much
more
appreciated
if
it
were
extended
likewise
to
sermons
.
<EOS>
The
only
danger
would
be
that
congregations
would
be
too
anxious
to
prevent
their
young
clergymen
from
advancing
themselves
in
the
ranks
of
the
ministry
.
<EOS>
Clergymen
who
could
not
preach
would
be
such
blessings
that
they
would
be
bribed
to
adhere
to
their
incompetence
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
,
however
,
had
not
the
modesty
of
youth
to
impede
him
,
and
he
succeeded
with
his
sermon
even
better
than
with
the
lessons
.
<EOS>
He
took
for
his
text
two
verses
out
of
the
second
epistle
of
St.
John
,
"
Whosoever
transgresseth
,
and
abideth
not
in
the
doctrine
of
Christ
,
hath
not
God
.
<EOS>
He
that
abideth
in
the
doctrine
of
Christ
,
he
hath
both
the
Father
and
the
Son
.
<EOS>
If
there
come
any
unto
you
,
and
bring
not
this
doctrine
,
receive
him
not
into
your
house
,
neither
bid
him
God
-
speed
.
"
<EOS>
He
told
them
that
the
house
of
theirs
to
which
he
alluded
was
this
their
church
,
in
which
he
now
addressed
them
for
the
first
time
;
that
their
most
welcome
and
proper
manner
of
bidding
him
God
-
speed
would
be
their
patient
obedience
to
his
teaching
of
the
gospel
;
but
that
he
could
put
forward
no
claim
to
such
conduct
on
their
part
unless
he
taught
them
the
great
Christian
doctrine
of
works
and
faith
combined
.
<EOS>
On
this
he
enlarged
,
but
not
very
amply
,
and
after
twenty
minutes
succeeded
in
sending
his
new
friends
home
to
their
baked
mutton
and
pudding
well
pleased
with
their
new
minister
.
  
<EOS>
Then
came
the
lunch
at
Ullathorne
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
they
were
in
the
hall
Miss
Thorne
took
Mr.
Arabin
's
hand
and
assured
him
that
she
received
him
into
her
house
,
into
the
temple
,
she
said
,
in
which
she
worshipped
,
and
bade
him
God
-
speed
with
all
her
heart
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
was
touched
and
squeezed
the
spinster
's
hand
without
uttering
a
word
in
reply
.
<EOS>
Then
Mr.
Thorne
expressed
a
hope
that
Mr.
Arabin
found
the
church
well
adapted
for
articulation
,
and
Mr.
Arabin
having
replied
that
he
had
no
doubt
he
should
as
soon
as
he
had
learnt
to
pitch
his
voice
to
the
building
,
they
all
sat
down
to
the
good
things
before
them
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Thorne
took
special
care
of
Mrs.
Bold
.
<EOS>
Eleanor
still
wore
her
widow
's
weeds
,
and
therefore
had
about
her
that
air
of
grave
and
sad
maternity
which
is
the
lot
of
recent
widows
.
<EOS>
This
opened
the
soft
heart
of
Miss
Thorne
,
and
made
her
look
on
her
young
guest
as
though
too
much
could
not
be
done
for
her
.
<EOS>
She
heaped
chicken
and
ham
upon
her
plate
and
poured
out
for
her
a
full
bumper
of
port
wine
.
<EOS>
When
Eleanor
,
who
was
not
sorry
to
get
it
,
had
drunk
a
little
of
it
,
Miss
Thorne
at
once
essayed
to
fill
it
again
.
<EOS>
To
this
Eleanor
objected
,
but
in
vain
.
<EOS>
Miss
Thorne
winked
and
nodded
and
whispered
,
saying
that
it
was
the
proper
thing
and
must
be
done
,
and
that
she
knew
all
about
it
;
and
so
she
desired
Mrs.
Bold
to
drink
it
up
and
not
mind
anybody
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
your
duty
,
you
know
,
to
support
yourself
,
"
she
said
into
the
ear
of
the
young
mother
;
"
there
's
more
than
yourself
depending
on
it
;
"
and
thus
she
coshered
up
Eleanor
with
cold
fowl
and
port
wine
.
<EOS>
How
it
is
that
poor
men
's
wives
,
who
have
no
cold
fowl
and
port
wine
on
which
to
be
coshered
up
,
nurse
their
children
without
difficulty
,
whereas
the
wives
of
rich
men
,
who
eat
and
drink
everything
that
is
good
,
can
not
do
so
,
we
will
for
the
present
leave
to
the
doctors
and
the
mothers
to
settle
between
them
.
  
<EOS>
And
then
Miss
Thorne
was
great
about
teeth
.
<EOS>
Little
Johnny
Bold
had
been
troubled
for
the
last
few
days
with
his
first
incipient
masticator
,
and
with
that
freemasonry
which
exists
among
ladies
,
Miss
Thorne
became
aware
of
the
fact
before
Eleanor
had
half
-
finished
her
wing
.
<EOS>
The
old
lady
prescribed
at
once
a
receipt
which
had
been
much
in
vogue
in
the
young
days
of
her
grandmother
,
and
warned
Eleanor
with
solemn
voice
against
the
fallacies
of
modern
medicine
.
  
<EOS>
"
Take
his
coral
,
my
dear
,
"
said
she
,
"
and
rub
it
well
with
carrot
-
juice
;
rub
it
till
the
juice
dries
on
it
,
and
then
give
it
him
to
play
with
 
"
  
"
<EOS>
But
he
has
n't
got
a
coral
,
"
said
Eleanor
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
got
a
coral
!
"
said
Miss
Thorne
with
almost
angry

.
<EOS>
"
Not
got
a
coral
 
<EOS>
how
can
you
expect
that
he
should
cut
his
teeth
?
<EOS>
Have
you
got
Daffy
's
Elixir
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Eleanor
explained
that
she
had
not
.
<EOS>
It
had
not
been
ordered
by
Mr.
Rerechild
,
the
Barchester
doctor
whom
she
employed
;
and
then
the
young
mother
mentioned
some
shockingly
modern
succedaneum
which
Mr.
Rerechild
's
new
lights
had
taught
him
to
recommend
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Thorne
looked
awfully
severe
.
"
<EOS>
Take
care
,
my
dear
,
"
said
she
,
"
that
the
man
knows
what
he
's
about
<EOS>
;
take
care
he
does
n't
destroy
your
little
boy
.
<EOS>
But
"
 
and
she
softened
into
sorrow
,
as
she
said
it
,
and
spoke
more
in
pity
than
in
anger
 
"
<EOS>
but
I
do
n't
know
who
there
is
in
Barchester
now
that
you
can
trust
.
<EOS>
Poor
dear
old
Doctor
Bumpwell
,
indeed
 
"
  
"
Why
,
Miss
Thorne
,
he
died
when
I
was
a
little
girl
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
my
dear
,
he
did
,
and
an
unfortunate
day
it
was
for
Barchester
.
<EOS>
As
to
those
young
men
that
have
come
up
since
"
 
Mr.
Rerechild
,
by
the
by
,
was
quite
as
old
as
Miss
Thorne
herself
 
"
one
does
n't
know
where
they
came
from
or
who
they
are
,
or
whether
they
know
anything
about
their
business
or
not
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
there
are
very
clever
men
in
Barchester
,
"
said
Eleanor
.
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
there
may
be
;
only
I
do
n't
know
them
:
and
it
's
admitted
on
all
sides
that
medical
men
are
n't
now
what
they
used
to
be
.
<EOS>
They
used
to
be
talented
,
observing
,
educated
men
.
<EOS>
But
now
any
whipper
-
snapper
out
of
an
apothecary
's
shop
can
call
himself
a
doctor
.
<EOS>
I
believe
no
kind
of
education
is
now
thought
necessary
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Eleanor
was
herself
the
widow
of
a
medical
man
and
felt
a
little
inclined
to
resent
all
these
hard
sayings
.
<EOS>
But
Miss
Thorne
was
so
essentially
good
-
natured
that
it
was
impossible
to
resent
anything
she
said
.
<EOS>
She
therefore
sipped
her
wine
and
finished
her
chicken
.
  
<EOS>
"
At
any
rate
,
my
dear
,
do
n't
forget
the
carrot
-
juice
,
and
by
all
means
get
him
a
coral
at
once
.
<EOS>
My
grandmother
Thorne
had
the
best
teeth
in
the
county
and
carried
them
to
the
grave
with
her
at
eighty
.
<EOS>
I
have
heard
her
say
it
was
all
the
carrot
-
juice
.
<EOS>
She
could
n't
bear
the
Barchester
doctors
.
<EOS>
Even
poor
old
Dr.
Bumpwell
did
n't
please
her
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
It
clearly
never
occurred
to
Miss
Thorne
that
some
fifty
years
ago
Dr.
Bumpwell
was
only
a
rising
man
and
therefore
as
much
in
need
of
character
in
the
eyes
of
the
then
ladies
of
Ullathorne
as
the
present
doctors
were
in
her
own
.
  
<EOS>
The
archdeacon
made
a
very
good
lunch
,
and
talked
to
his
host
about
turnip
-
drillers
and
new
machines
for
reaping
,
while
the
host
,
thinking
it
only
polite
to
attend
to
a
stranger
,
and
fearing
that
perhaps
he
might
not
care
about
turnip
crops
on
a
Sunday
,
mooted
all
manner
of
ecclesiastical
subjects
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
never
saw
a
heavier
lot
of
wheat
,
Thorne
,
than
you
've
got
there
in
that
field
beyond
the
copse
.
<EOS>
I
suppose
that
's
guano
,
"
said
the
archdeacon
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
guano
.
<EOS>
I
get
it
from
Bristol
myself
.
<EOS>
You
'll
find
you
often
have
a
tolerable
congregation
of
Barchester
people
out
here
,
Mr.
Arabin
.
<EOS>
They
are
very
fond
of
St.
Ewold
's
,
particularly
of
an
afternoon
when
the
weather
is
not
too
hot
for
the
walk
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
under
an
obligation
to
them
for
staying
away
to
-
day
,
at
any
rate
,
"
said
the
vicar
.
<EOS>
"
The
congregation
can
never
be
too
small
for
a
maiden
sermon
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
got
a
ton
and
a
half
at
Bradley
's
in
High
Street
,
"
said
the
archdeacon
,
"
and
it
was
a
complete
take
in
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
believe
there
was
five
hundredweight
of
guano
in

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
That
Bradley
never
has
anything
good
,
"
said
Miss
Thorne
,
who
had
just
caught

name
during

.
"
<EOS>
And
such
a
nice
shop
as
there
used

in

house
before
he
came
.
<EOS>
Wilfred
<EOS>
,
do
n't
you
remember
what
good
things
<EOS>
old
Ambleoff
used
to
have
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
have
been
three
men
since
Ambleoff
's

,
"
said

archdeacon
,
"
and
each
as

as

other
.
<EOS>
But
who
gets

for
you
at
Bristol
,
Thorne
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
ran
up

this
year
and
bought

out

the
ship
.
<EOS>
I
am
afraid
as
the
evenings
get

,
Mr.
Arabin
,
you
'll
find
the
reading
-

too

.
<EOS>
I
must
send
a
fellow
with

and

lop

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
declared
that
the
morning
light
at
any
rate
was
perfect
,
and
deprecated
any
interference
with
the
lime
-

.
<EOS>
And
then
they
took
a
stroll
out
among
the
trim

,
and
Mr.
Arabin
explained
to
Mrs.
Bold
the
difference
between
a
naiad
and
a
dryad
,
and
dilated
on
vases
and
the

of
urns
.
<EOS>
Miss
Thorne
busied
herself
among
her
pansies
,
and
her
brother
,
finding
it
quite
impracticable
to
give
anything
of

tone
to
the
conversation
,
abandoned
the

and
had
it
out
with
the

about
the
Bristol
guano
.
  
<EOS>
At
three
o'clock
they
again
went
into
church
,
and
now
Mr.
Arabin
read
the
service
and
the
archdeacon
preached
.
<EOS>
Nearly
the
same
congregation
was
present
,
with
some
adventurous

from
the
city
,
who
had
not
thought
the

of
the
midday
August
sun
too
great
to

.
<EOS>
The
archdeacon
took
his
text
from
the
epistle
to
Philemon
.
<EOS>
"
I
beseech
thee
for
my
son
Onesimus
,
whom
I
have
begotten
in
my
bonds
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
From
such
a
text
it
may
be
imagined
the
kind
of
sermon
which
Dr.
Grantly
preached
,
and
on
the
whole
it
was
neither
dull
,
nor
bad
,
nor
out
of
place
.
  
<EOS>
He
told
them
that
it
had
become
his
duty
to
look
about
for
a
pastor
for
them
,
to
supply
the
place
of
one
who
had
been
long
among
them
,
and
that
in
this
manner
he
regarded
as

son
him
whom
he
had
selected
,
as
St.
Paul
had
regarded
the
young
disciple
whom
he
sent
forth
.
<EOS>
Then
he
took
a
little
merit
to
himself
for
having
studiously
provided
the
best
man
he
could
without
reference
to
patronage
or

;
but
he
did
not

that
the
best
man
according

was
he
who
was
best
able
to
subdue
Mr.
Slope
,
and
make
that

's
situation
in
Barchester
too
hot
to
be

.
<EOS>
As
to
the
bonds
,
they
had
consisted
in
the
exceeding
struggle
which
he
had
made
to
get
a
good
clergyman
for

.
<EOS>
He
deprecated
any
comparison
between
himself
and
St.
Paul
,
but
said
that
he
was

to
beseech

for

Mr.
Arabin
,
in
the
same

that
the

had
besought

with

.
  
<EOS>
The
archdeacon
's
sermon
 
text
,
blessing
,
and
all
 
was
concluded
within
the
half
-
hour
.
<EOS>
Then
they
shook
hands
with
their
Ullathorne
friends
and
returned
to
Plumstead
.
"
<EOS>
Twas
thus
that
Mr.
Arabin
read
himself
in
at
St.
Ewold
's
.
   
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
Manages
Matters
Very
Cleverly
at
Puddingdale
 
<EOS>
The
next
two
weeks
passed
pleasantly
enough
at
Plumstead
.
<EOS>
The
whole
party
there
assembled
seemed
to
get
on
well
together
.
<EOS>
Eleanor
made
the
house
agreeable
,
and
the
archdeacon
and
Mr.
Grantly
seemed
to
have
forgotten
her
iniquity
as
regarded
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
had
his
violoncello
,
and
played
to
them
while
his
daughters
accompanied
him
.
<EOS>
Johnny
Bold
,
by
the
help
either
of
Mr.
Rerechild
or
else
by
that
of
his
coral
and
carrot
-
juice
,
got
through
his
teething
troubles
.
<EOS>
There
had
been
gaieties
,
too
,
of
all
sorts
.
<EOS>
They
had
dined
at
Ullathorne
,
and
the
Thornes
had
dined
at
the
rectory
.
<EOS>
Eleanor
had
been
duly
put
to
stand
on
her
box
,
and
in
that
position
had
found
herself
quite
unable
to
express
her
opinion
on
the
merits
of
flounces
,
such
having
been
the
subject
given
to
try
her
elocution
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
had
of
course
been
much
in
his
own
parish
,
looking
to
the
doings
at
his
vicarage
,
calling
on
his
parishioners
,
and
taking
on
himself
the
duties
of
his
new
calling
.
<EOS>
But
still
he
had
been
every
evening
at
Plumstead
,
and
Mrs.
Grantly
was
partly
willing
to
agree
with
her
husband
that
he
was
a
pleasant
inmate
in
a
house
.
  
<EOS>
They
had
also
been
at
a
dinner
-
party
at
Dr.
Stanhope
's
,
of
which
Mr.
Arabin
had
made
one
.
<EOS>
He
also
,
mothlike
,
burnt
his
wings
in
the
flames
of
the
signora
's
candle
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Bold
,
too
,
had
been
there
,
and
had
felt
somewhat
displeased
with
the
taste
 
want
of
taste
she
called
it
 
shown
by
Mr.
Arabin
in
paying
so
much
attention
to
Madame
Neroni
.
<EOS>
It
was
as
infallible
that
Madeline
should
displease
and
irritate
the
women
as
that
she
should
charm
and
captivate
the
men
.
<EOS>
The
one
result
followed
naturally
on
the
other
.
<EOS>
It
was
quite
true
that
Mr.
Arabin
had
been
charmed
.
<EOS>
He
thought
her
a
very
clever
and
a
very
handsome
woman
;
he
thought
also
that
her
peculiar
affliction
entitled
her
to
the
sympathy
of
all
.
<EOS>
He
had
never
,
he
said
,
met
so
much
suffering
joined
to
such
perfect
beauty
and
so
clear
a
mind
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Twas
thus
he
spoke
of
the
signora
,
coming
home
in
the
archdeacon
's
carriage
,
and
Eleanor
by
no
means
liked
to
hear
the
praise
.
<EOS>
It
was
,
however
,
exceedingly
unjust
of
her
to
be
angry
with
Mr.
Arabin
,
as
she
had
herself
spent
a
very
pleasant
evening
with
Bertie
Stanhope
,
who
had
taken
her
down
to
dinner
and
had
not
left
her
side
for
one
moment
after
the
gentlemen
came
out
of
the
dining
-
room
.
<EOS>
It
was
unfair
that
she
should
amuse
herself
with
Bertie
and
yet
begrudge
her
new
friend
his
license
of
amusing
himself
with
Bertie
's
sister
.
<EOS>
And
yet
she
did
so
.
<EOS>
She
was
half
-
angry
with
him
in
the
carriage
,
and
said
something
about
meretricious
manners
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
did
not
understand
the
ways
of
women
very
well
,
or
else
he
might
have
flattered
himself
that
Eleanor
was
in
love
with
him
.
  
<EOS>
But
Eleanor
was
not
in
love
with
him
.
<EOS>
How
many
shades
there
are
between
love
and
indifference
,
and
how
little
the
graduated
scale
is
understood
!
<EOS>
She
had
now
been
nearly
three
weeks
in
the
same
house
with
Mr.
Arabin
,
and
had
received
much
of
his
attention
and
listened
daily
to
his
conversation
.
<EOS>
He
had
usually
devoted
at
least
some
portion
of
his
evening
to
her
exclusively
.
<EOS>
At
Dr.
Stanhope
's
he
had
devoted
himself
exclusively
to
another
.
<EOS>
It
does
not
require
that
a
woman
should
be
in
love
to
be
irritated
at
this
;
it
does
not
require
that
she
should
even
acknowledge
to

that
it
is
unpleasant
to
her
.
<EOS>
Eleanor
had
no
such
self
-
knowledge
.
<EOS>
She
thought
in
her
own
heart
that
it
was
only
on
Mr.
Arabin
's
account
that
she
regretted
that
he
could
condescend
to
be
amused
by
the
signora
.
<EOS>
"
I
thought
he
had
more
mind
,
"
she
said
to

as
she
sat
watching
her

's

on

the
party
.
"
<EOS>
After
all
,
I
believe
Mr.
Stanhope
is
the
pleasanter
man
of
the
two
.
"
<EOS>
Alas
for
the
memory
of
poor
John
Bold
!
<EOS>
Eleanor
was
not
in
love
with
Bertie
Stanhope
,
nor
was
she
in
love
with
Mr.
Arabin
.
<EOS>
But
her
devotion
to
her
late
husband
was
fast
fading
when
she
could
revolve
in
her
mind
,
over
the
cradle
of
his
infant
,
the
faults
and
failings
of
other
aspirants
to
her

.
  
<EOS>
Will
anyone
blame
my
heroine
for
this
?
<EOS>
Let
him
or
her
rather
thank
God
for
all
His
goodness
 
for
His
mercy
endureth
forever
.
  
<EOS>
Eleanor
,
in
truth
,
was
not
in
love
;
neither
was
Mr.
Arabin
.
<EOS>
Neither
indeed
was
Bertie
Stanhope
,
though
he
had
already
found
occasion
to
say
nearly
as
much
as
that
he
was
.
<EOS>
The
widow
's
cap
had
prevented
him
from
making
a
positive
declaration
,
when
otherwise
he
would
have
considered
himself
entitled
to
do
so
on
a
third
or
fourth
interview
.
<EOS>
It
was
,
after
all
,
but
a
small
cap
now
,
and
had
but
little
of
the
weeping
willow
left
in
its
construction
.
<EOS>
It
is
singular
how
these
emblems
of
grief
fade
away
by
unseen
gradations
.
<EOS>
Each
pretends
to
be
the
counterpart
of
the
forerunner
,
and
yet
the
last
little
bit
of
crimped
white
crape
that
sits
so
jauntily
on
the
back
of
the
head
is
as
dissimilar
to
the
first
huge

of
woe
which
disfigured

face
of
the
weeper
as
the
state
of
the
Hindu
is
to
the
jointure
of
the
English
dowager
.
  
<EOS>
But
let
it
be
clearly
understood
that
Eleanor
was
in
love
with
no
one
,
and
that
no
one
was
in
love
with
Eleanor
.
<EOS>
Under
these
circumstances
her
anger
against
Mr.
Arabin
did
not
last
long
,
and
before
two
days
were
over
they
were
both
as
good
friends
as
ever
.
<EOS>
She
could
not
but
like
him
,
for
every
hour
spent
in
his
company
was
spent
pleasantly
.
<EOS>
And
yet
she
could
not
quite
like
him
,
for
there
was
always
apparent
in
his
conversation
<EOS>
a
certain
feeling
on
his
part
that
he
hardly
thought
it
worth
his
while
to
be
in
earnest
.
<EOS>
It
was
almost
as
though
he
were
playing
with
a
child
.
<EOS>
She
knew
well
enough
that
he
was
in
truth
a
sober
,
thoughtful
man
who
,
in
some

and
on
some

,
could
endure
an
agony
of
earnestness
.
<EOS>
And
yet
to
her
he
was
always
gently
playful
.
<EOS>
Could
she
have
seen
his
brow
once
clouded
,
she
might
have
learnt
to
love
him
.
  
<EOS>
So
things
went
on
at
Plumstead
,
and
on
the
whole
not
unpleasantly
,
till
a
huge
storm
darkened
the
horizon
and
came
down
upon
the
inhabitants
of
the
rectory
with
all
the

of
a
water
-
spout
.
<EOS>
It
was
astonishing
how
in
a
few
minutes
the
whole
face
of
the
heavens
was
changed
.
<EOS>
The
party
broke
up
from
breakfast
in
perfect
harmony
,
but
fierce
passions
had
arisen
before
the
evening
which
did
not
admit
of
their
sitting
at
the
same
board
for
dinner
.
<EOS>
To
explain
this
it
will
be
necessary
to
go
back
a
little
.
  
<EOS>
It
will
be
remembered
that
the
bishop
expressed
to
Mr.
Slope
in
his
dressing
-
room
his
determination
that
Mr.
Quiverful
should
be
confirmed
in
his

to
the
hospital
,
and
that
his
lordship
requested
Mr.
Slope
to

to
the
archdeacon
.
<EOS>
It
will
also
be
remembered
that
the
archdeacon
had
indignantly
declined
seeing
Mr.
Slope
,
and
had
instead
written
a
strong
letter
to
the
bishop
in
which
he
all
but
demanded
the
situation
of
warden
for
Mr.
Harding
.
<EOS>
To
this
letter
the
archdeacon
received
an
immediate
formal
reply
from
Mr.
Slope
,
in
which
it
was
stated
that
the
bishop
had
received
and
would
give
his
best

to
the
archdeacon
's

.
  
<EOS>
The
archdeacon
felt
himself
somewhat
checkmated
by
this
reply
.
<EOS>
What
could
he
do
with
a
man
who
would
neither
see
him
,
nor
argue
with
him
by
letter
,
and
who
had
undoubtedly
the
power
of
appointing
any
clergyman
he
pleased
?
<EOS>
He
had
consulted
with
Mr.
Arabin
,
who
had
suggested
the
propriety
of
calling
in
the
aid
of
the
Master
of
Lazarus
.
<EOS>
"
If
,
"
said
he
,
"
you
and
Dr.
Gwynne
formally
declare

of
waiting

bishop
,
the
bishop

not
dare

;

as
you
are
see
him

,
you
will
probably
not

without

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The

did
not
quite
like

the
necessity
of
his
being
backed
by
the
Master
of
Lazarus
before
he
could
obtain

into
the
episcopal
palace
of
Barchester
,
but
still
he
felt
that
the
advice
was
good
,
and
he
resolved
to
take

.
<EOS>
He
wrote
again
to
the
bishop
,
expressing
a
hope
that
nothing

would
be
done
in
the
matter
of
the
hospital
till
the

promised
by
his
lordship
had
been
given
,
and
then
sent
off
a
warm

to
his
friend

master
,
imploring
him
to
come
to
Plumstead
and

in
driving

bishop
into

.
<EOS>
The
master
had
rejoined
,
raising
some
difficulty
,
but
not
declining
,
and
the
archdeacon
had
again
pressed
his
point
,
insisting
on
the

for
immediate
