.
<EOS>
Dr.
Gwynne
unfortunately
had
the
gout
,
and
could
therefore
name
no
immediate
day
,
but
still
agreed
to
come
,
if
it
should
be
finally
found
necessary
.
<EOS>
So
the
matter
stood
,
as
regarded
the
party
at
Plumstead
.
  
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Harding
had
another
friend
fighting
his
battle
for
him
,
quite
as
powerful
as
the
Master
of
Lazarus
,
and
this
was
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
Though
the
bishop
had
so
pertinaciously
insisted
on
giving
way
to
his
wife
in
the
matter
of
the
hospital
,
Mr.
Slope
did
not
think
it
necessary
to
abandon
his
object
.
<EOS>
He
had
,
he
thought
,
daily
more
and
more
reason
to
imagine
that
the
widow
would
receive
his
overtures
favourably
,
and
he
could
not
but
feel
that
Mr.
Harding
at
the
hospital
,
and
placed
there
by
his
means
,
would
be
more
likely
to
receive
him
as
a
son
-
in
-
law
than
Mr.
Harding
growling
in
opposition
and
disappointment
under
the
archdeacon
's
wing
at
Plumstead
.
<EOS>
Moreover
,
to
give
Mr.
Slope
due
credit
,
he
was
actuated
by
greater
motives
even
than
these
.
<EOS>
He
wanted
a
wife
,
and
he
wanted
money
,
but
he
wanted
power
more
than
either
.
<EOS>
He
had
fully
realized
the
fact
that
he
must
come
to
blows
with
Mrs.
Proudie
.
<EOS>
He
had
no
desire
to
remain
in
Barchester
as
her
chaplain
.
<EOS>
Sooner
than
do
so
,
he
would
risk
the
loss
of
his
whole
connexion
with
the
diocese
.
<EOS>
What
!
<EOS>
Was
he
to
feel
within
him
<EOS>
the
possession
of
no
ordinary
talents
 
was
he
to
know
himself
to
be
courageous
,
firm
,
and
,
in
matters
where
his
conscience
did
not
interfere
,
unscrupulous
 
<EOS>
and
yet
he
contented
to
be
the
working
factotum
of
a
woman
prelate
?
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
had
higher
ideas
of
his
own
destiny
.
<EOS>
Either
he
or
Mrs.
Proudie
must
go
to
the
wall
,
and
now
had
come
the
time
when
he
would
try
which
it
should
be
.
  
<EOS>
The
bishop
had
declared
that
Mr.
Quiverful
should
be
the
new
warden
.
<EOS>
As
Mr.
Slope
went
downstairs
,
prepared
to
see
the
archdeacon
,
if
necessary
,
but
fully
satisfied
that
no
such
necessity
would
arise
,
he
declared
to
himself
that
Mr.
Harding
should
be
warden
.
<EOS>
With
the
object
of
carrying
this
point
,
he
rode
over
to
Puddingdale
and
had
a
further
interview
with
the
worthy
expectant
of
clerical
good
things
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Quiverful
was
on
the
whole
a
worthy
man
.
<EOS>
The
impossible
task
of
bringing
up
as
ladies
and
gentlemen
fourteen
children
on
an
income
which
was
insufficient
to
give
them
with
decency
the
common
necessaries
of
life
,
had
had
an
effect
upon
him
not
beneficial
either
to
his
spirit
or
his
keen
sense
of
honour
.
<EOS>
Who
can
boast
that
he
would
have
supported
such
a
burden
with
a
different
result
?
<EOS>
Mr.
Quiverful
was
an
honest
,
painstaking
,
drudging
man
,
anxious
indeed
for
bread
and
meat
,
anxious
for
means
to
quiet
his
butcher
and
cover
with
returning
smiles
the
now
sour
countenance
of
the
baker
's
wife
;
but
anxious
also
to
be
right
with
his
own
conscience
.
<EOS>
He
was
not
careful
,
as
another
might
be
who
sat
on
an
easier
worldly
seat
,
to
stand
well
with
those
around
him
,
to
shun
a
breath
which
might
sully
his
name
or
a
rumour
which
might
affect
his
honour
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
afford
such
niceties
of
conduct
,
such
moral
luxuries
.
<EOS>
It
must
suffice
for
him
to
be
ordinarily
honest
according
to
the
ordinary
honesty
of
the
world
's
ways
,
and
to
let
men
's
tongues
wag
as
they
would
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
felt
that
his
brother
clergymen
,
men
whom
he
had
known
for
the
last
twenty
years
,
looked
coldly
on
him
from
the
first
moment
that
he
had
shown
himself
willing
to
sit
at
the
feet
of
Mr.
Slope
;
he
had
seen
that
their
looks
grew
colder
still
when
it
became
bruited
about
that
he
was
to
be
the
bishop
's
new
warden
at
Hiram
's
Hospital
.
<EOS>
This
was
painful
enough
,
but
it
was
the
cross
which
he
was
doomed
to
bear
.
<EOS>
He
thought
of
his
wife
,
whose
last
new
silk
dress
was
six
years
in
wear
.
<EOS>
He
thought
of
all
his
young
flock
,
whom
he
could
hardly
take
to
church
with
him
on
Sundays
,
for
there
were
not
decent
shoes
and
stockings
for
them
all
to
wear
.
<EOS>
He
thought
of
the
well
-
worn
sleeves
of
his
own
black
coat
and
of
the
stern
face
of
the
draper
,
from
whom
he
would
fain
ask
for
cloth
to
make
another
,
did
he
not
know
that
the
credit
would
be
refused
him
.
<EOS>
Then
he
thought
of
the
comfortable
house
in
Barchester
,
of
the
comfortable
income
,
of
his
boys
sent
to
school
,
of
his
girls
with
books
in
their
hands
instead
of
darning
needles
,
of
his
wife
's
face
again
covered
with
smiles
,
and
of
his
daily
board
again
covered
with
plenty
.
<EOS>
He
thought
of
these
things
;
and
do
thou
also
,
reader
,
think
of
them
,
and
then
wonder
,
if
thou
canst
,
that
Mr.
Slope
had
appeared
to
him
to
possess
all
those
good
gifts
which
could
grace
a
bishop
's
chaplain
.
<EOS>
"
How
beautiful
upon
the
mountains
are
the
feet
of
him
that
bringeth
good
tidings
.
"
  
<EOS>
Why
,
moreover
,
should
the
Barchester
clergy
have
looked
coldly
on
Mr.
Quiverful
?
<EOS>
Had
they
not
all
shown
that
they
regarded
with
complacency
the
loaves
and
fishes
of
their
mother
church
?
<EOS>
Had
they
not
all
,
by
some
hook
or
crook
,
done
better
for
themselves
than
he
had
done
?
<EOS>
They
were
not
burdened
as
he
was
burdened
.
<EOS>
Dr.
Grantly
had
five
children
and
nearly
as
many
thousands
a
year
on
which
to
feed
them
.
<EOS>
It
was
very
well
for
him
to
turn
up
his
nose
at
a
new
bishop
who
could
do
nothing
for
him
,
and
a
chaplain
who
was
beneath
his
notice
;
but
it
was
cruel
in
a
man
so
circumstanced
to
set
the
world
against
the
father
of
fourteen
children
because
he
was
anxious
to
obtain
for
them
an
honourable
support
!
<EOS>
He
,
Mr.
Quiverful
,
had
not
asked
for
the
wardenship
;
he
had
not
even
accepted
it
till
he
had
been
assured
that
Mr.
Harding
had
refused
it
.
<EOS>
How
hard
then
that
he
should
be
blamed
for
doing
that
which
not
to
have
done
would
have
argued
a
most
insane
imprudence
!
  
<EOS>
Thus
in
this
matter
of
the
hospital
poor
Mr.
Quiverful
had
his
trials
,
and
he
had
also
his
consolations
.
<EOS>
On
the
whole
the
consolations
were
the
more
vivid
of
the
two
.
<EOS>
The
stern
draper
heard
of
the
coming
promotion
,
and
the
wealth
of
his
warehouse
was
at
Mr.
Quiverful
's
disposal
.
<EOS>
Coming
events
cast
their
shadows
before
,
and
the
coming
event
of
Mr.
Quiverful
's
transference
to
Barchester
produced
a
delicious
shadow
in
the
shape
of
a
new
outfit
for
Mrs.
Quiverful
and
her
three
elder
daughters
.
<EOS>
Such
consolations
come
home
to
the
heart
of
a
man
,
and
quite
home
to
the
heart
of
a
woman
.
<EOS>
Whatever
the
husband
might
feel
,
the
wife
cared
nothing
for
frowns
of
dean
,
archdeacon
,
or
prebendary
.
<EOS>
To
her
the
outsides
and
insides
of
her
husband
and
fourteen
children
were
everything
.
<EOS>
In
her
bosom
every
other
ambition
had
been
swallowed
up
in
that
maternal
ambition
of
seeing
them
and
him
and
herself
duly
clad
and
properly
fed
.
<EOS>
It
had
come
to
that
with
her
that
life
had
now
no
other
purpose
.
<EOS>
She
recked
nothing
of
the
imaginary
rights
of
others
.
<EOS>
She
had
no
patience
with
her
husband
when
he
declared
to
her
that
he
could
not
accept
the
hospital
unless
he
knew
that
Mr.
Harding
had
refused
it
.
<EOS>
Her
husband
had
no
right
to
be
quixotic
at
the
expense
of
fourteen
children
.
<EOS>
The
narrow
escape
of
throwing
away
his
good
fortune
which
her
lord
had
had
,
almost
paralysed
her
.
<EOS>
Now
,
indeed
,
they
had
received
a
full
promise
,
not
only
from
Mr.
Slope
,
but
also
from
Mrs.
Proudie
.
<EOS>
Now
,
indeed
,
they
might
reckon
with
safety
on
their
good
fortune
.
<EOS>
But
what
if
all
had
been
lost
?
<EOS>
What
if
her
fourteen
bairns
had
been
resteeped
to
the
hips
in
poverty
by
the
morbid
sentimentality
of
their
father
?
<EOS>
Mrs.
Quiverful
was
just
at
present
a
happy
woman
,
but
yet
it
nearly
took
her
breath
away
when
she
thought
of
the
risk
they
had
run
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
what
your
father
means
when
he
talks
so
much
of
what
is
due
to
Mr.
Harding
,
"
she
said
to
her
eldest
daughter
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Does
he
think
that
Mr.
Harding
would
give
him
£
450
a
year
out
of
fine
feeling
?
<EOS>
And
what
signifies
it
whom
he
offends
,
as
long
as
he
gets
the
place
?
<EOS>
He
does
not
expect
anything
better
.
<EOS>
It
passes
me
to
think
how
your
father
can
be
so
soft
,
while
everybody
around
him
is
so
griping
.
"
  
<EOS>
Thus
,
while
the
outer
world
was
accusing
Mr.
Quiverful
of
rapacity
for
promotion
and
of
disregard
to
his
honour
,
the
inner
world
of
his
own
household
was
falling
foul
of
him
,
with
equal
vehemence
,
for
his
willingness
to
sacrifice
their
interests
to
a
false
feeling
of
sentimental
pride
.
<EOS>
It
is
astonishing
how
much
difference
the
point
of
view
makes
in
the
aspect
of
all
that
we
look
at
!
  
<EOS>
Such
were
the
feelings
of
the
different
members
of
the
family
at
Puddingdale
on
the
occasion
of
Mr.
Slope
's
second
visit
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Quiverful
,
as
soon
as
she
saw
his
horse
coming
up
the
avenue
from
the
vicarage
gate
,
hastily
packed
up
her
huge
basket
of
needlework
and
hurried
herself
and
her
daughter
out
of
the
room
in
which
she
was
sitting
with
her
husband
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
Mr.
Slope
,
"
she
said
.
<EOS>
"
He
's
come
to
settle
with
you
about
the
hospital
.
<EOS>
I
do
hope
we
shall
now
be
able
to
move
at
once
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
she
hastened
to
bid
the
maid
of
all
work
go
to
the
door
,
so
that
the
welcome
great
man
might
not
be
kept
waiting
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
thus
found
Mr.
Quiverful
alone
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Quiverful
went
off
to
her
kitchen
and
back
settlements
with
anxious
beating
heart
,
almost
dreading
that
there
might
be
some
slip
between
the
cup
of
her
happiness
and
the
lip
of
her
fruition
,
but
yet
comforting
herself
with
the
reflexion
that
after
what
had
taken
place
,
any
such
slip
could
hardly
be
possible
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
was
all
smiles
as
he
shook
his
brother
clergyman
's
hand
and
said
that
he
had
ridden
over
because
he
thought
it
right
at
once
to
put
Mr.
Quiverful
in
possession
of
the
facts
of
the
matter
regarding
the
wardenship
of
the
hospital
.
<EOS>
As
he
spoke
,
the
poor
expectant
husband
and
father
saw
at
a
glance
that
his
brilliant
hopes
were
to
be
dashed
to
the
ground
,
and
that
his
visitor
was
now
there
for
the
purpose
of
unsaying
what
on
his
former
visit
he
had
said
.
<EOS>
There
was
something
in
the
tone
of
the
voice
,
something
in
the
glance
of
the
eye
,
which
told
the
tale
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Quiverful
knew
it
all
at
once
.
<EOS>
He
maintained
his
self
-
possession
,
however
,
smiled
with
a
slight
unmeaning
smile
,
and
merely
said
that
he
was
obliged
to
Mr.
Slope
for
the
trouble
he
was
taking
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
has
been
a
troublesome
matter
from
first
to
last
,
"
said
Mr.
Slope
,
"
and
the
bishop
has
hardly
known
how
to
act
.
<EOS>
Between
ourselves
 
<EOS>
but
mind
this
of
course
must
go
no
further
,
Mr.
Quiverful
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Quiverful
said
that
of
course
it
should
not
.
"
<EOS>
The
truth
is
that
poor
Mr.
Harding
has
hardly
known
his
own
mind
.
<EOS>
You
remember
our
last
conversation
,
no
doubt
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Quiverful
assured
him
that
he
remembered
it
very
well
indeed
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
will
remember
that
I
told
you
that
Mr.
Harding
had
refused
to
return
to
the
hospital
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Quiverful
declared
that
nothing
could
be
more
distinct
on
his
memory
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
acting
on
this
refusal
,
I
suggested
that
you
should
take
the
hospital
,
"
continued
Mr.
Slope
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
understood
you
to
say
that
the
bishop
had
authorised
you
to
offer
it
to
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Did
I
?
<EOS>
Did
I
go
so
far
as
that
?
<EOS>
Well
,
perhaps
it
may
be
that
in
my
anxiety
in
your
behalf
I
did
commit
myself
further
than
I
should
have
done
.
<EOS>
So
far
as
my
own
memory
serves
me
,
I
do
n't
think
I
did
go
quite
so
far
as
that
.
<EOS>
But
I
own
I
was
very
anxious
that
you
should
get
it
,
and
<EOS>
I
may
have
said
more
than
was
quite
prudent
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
,
"
said
Mr.
Quiverful
in
his
deep
anxiety
to
prove
his
case
,
"
my
wife
received
as
distinct
a
promise
from
Mrs.
Proudie
as
one
human
being
could
give
to
another
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
smiled
and
gently
shook
his
head
.
<EOS>
He
meant
the
smile
for
a
pleasant
smile
,
but
it
was
diabolical
in
the
eyes
of
the
man
he
was
speaking
to
.
"
<EOS>
Mrs.
Proudie
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
If
we
are
to
go
to
what
passes
between
the
ladies
in
these
matters
,
we
shall
really
be
in
a
nest
of
troubles
from
which
we
shall
never
extricate
ourselves
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Proudie
is
a
most
excellent
lady
,
kind
-
hearted
,
charitable
,
pious
,
and
in
every
way
estimable
.
<EOS>
But
,
my
dear
Mr.
Quiverful
,
the
patronage
of
the
diocese
is
not
in
her
hands
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Quiverful
for
a
moment
sat
panic
-

and
silent
.
"
<EOS>
Am
I
to
understand
,
then
,
that
I
have
received
no
promise
?
"
<EOS>
he
said
as
soon
as
he
had
sufficiently
collected

.
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
will
allow
me
,
I
will
tell
you
exactly
how
the
matter
rests
.
<EOS>
You
certainly
did
receive
a
promise
conditional
on
Mr.
Harding
's
refusal
.
<EOS>
I
am
sure
you
will
do
me
the
justice
to
remember
that
you
yourself
declared
that
you
could
accept
the
appointment
on
no
other

than
the
knowledge
that
Mr.
Harding
had
declined
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
Mr.
Quiverful
;
"
I
did
say
that
,
certainly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
it
now
appears
that
he
did
not

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
surely
you
told
me
,
and
repeated

more
than
once
,
that
he
had
done
so
in
your

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
So
I
understood
him
.
<EOS>
But
it
seems
I
was
in
error
.
<EOS>
But
do
n't
for
a
moment
,
Mr.
Quiverful
,
suppose
that
I

to
throw
you
over
.
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
Having
held

hand
to
a
man
in

position
,
with
your
large
family
and
pressing

,
I
am
not
now
going

draw

back
again
.
<EOS>
I
only
want
you
to
act
with
me
fairly
and

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Whatever
I
do
I
shall
endeavour
at
any
rate
to
act
fairly
,
"
said
the
poor
man
,
feeling
that
he
had
to
fall
back
for
support
on
the
spirit
of
martyrdom
within

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
you
will
,
"
said
the
other
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
you
have
no

to

an

which

.
<EOS>
No
man
knows

you

Mr.
Harding
's

,
or
can
better

his
character
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
is
very
desirous
of
returning
to
his
old
position
,
and
the
bishop
feels
that
he
is

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
said
Mr.
Quiverful
,
dreadfully
doubtful
as
to
what
his
conduct
under
such

should
be
,
and
fruitlessly
striving
to
harden
his

with
some

that

of
self
-
preservation
which
made
his
wife
so

.
  
<EOS>
"
The
wardenship
of
this
little

is

the
bishop
's

,
Mr.
Quiverful
,

by
many

the

.
<EOS>
And
his
lordship
is
not
the
man
to
forget
anyone
whom

once

with

.
<EOS>
If
you
would

me
to

you
as
a
friend
 
"
  
"
Indeed
,
I
shall
be
most

to

,
"
said
the

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
should

you
to

Mr.
Harding
's
claims
.
<EOS>
If
you

in

,
I

ultimately

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
has
all
but
a
positive
right
to
the
place
.
<EOS>
But
if
you
will
allow
me
to
inform
the
bishop
that
you
decline
to
stand
in
Mr.
Harding
's

,
I
think
I
may
promise
you
 
though
,
by
the
by
,
it

that
the
bishop

not
allow
you
to

man
than
you
would

had
you

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Quiverful
sat
in
his
armchair
,
silent
,
gazing
at
vacancy
.
<EOS>
What
was
he
to
say
?
<EOS>
All
this
that
came
from
Mr.
Slope
was
so
true
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
had
a
right
to
the
hospital
.
<EOS>
The
bishop
had
a
great
many
good
things
to
give
away
.
<EOS>
Both
the
bishop
and
Mr.
Slope
would
be
excellent
friends
and

to
a
man
in
his
position
.
<EOS>
And
then
he
had
no
proof
of
any
promise
;
he
could
not
force
the
bishop
to
appoint
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Mr.
Quiverful
,
what
do

say
about

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
of
course
,
whatever
you
think
fit
,
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
It
's
a
great
disappointment
,
a
very
great
disappointment
.
<EOS>
I
wo
n't
deny
that
I
am
a
very
poor
man
,
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
In
the
end
,
Mr.
Quiverful
,
you
will
find
that
it
will
have
been
better
for
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
interview
ended
in
Mr.
Slope
receiving
a
full
renunciation
from
Mr.
Quiverful
of
any
claim
he
might
have
to
the
appointment
in
question
.
<EOS>
It
was
only
given
verbally
and
without
witnesses
,
but
then
the
original
promise
was
made
in
the
same
way
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
again
assured
him
that
he
should
not
be
forgotten
,
and
then
rode
back
to
Barchester
,
satisfied
that
he
would
now
be
able
to
mould
the
bishop
to
his
wishes
.
   
<EOS>
Fourteen
Arguments
in
Favour
of
Mr.
Quiverful
's
Claims
 
<EOS>
We
have
most
of
us
heard
of
the
terrible
anger
of
a
lioness
<EOS>
when
,
surrounded
by
her
cubs
,
she
guards
her
prey
.
<EOS>
Few
of
us
wish
to
disturb
the
mother
of
a
litter
of
puppies
when
mouthing
a
bone
in
the
midst
of
her
young
family
.
<EOS>
Medea
and
her
children
are
familiar
to
us
,
and
so
is
the
grief
of
Constance
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Quiverful
,
when
she
first
heard
from
her
husband
the
news
which
he
had
to
impart
,
felt
within
her
bosom
all
the
rage
of
the
lioness
,
the
rapacity
of
the
hound
,
the
fury
of
the
tragic
queen
,
and
the
deep
despair
of
the
bereaved
mother
.
  
<EOS>
Doubting
,
but
yet
hardly
fearing
,
what
might
have
been
the
tenor
of
Mr.
Slope
's
discourse
,
she
rushed
back
to
her
husband
as
soon
as
the
front
door
was
closed
behind
the
visitor
.
<EOS>
It
was
well
for
Mr.
Slope
that
he
so
escaped
 
the
anger
of
such
a
woman
,
at
such
a
moment
,
would
have
cowed
even
him
.
<EOS>
As
a
general
rule
,
it
is
highly
desirable
that
ladies
should
keep
their
temper
:
a
woman
when
she
storms
always
makes
herself
ugly
,
and
usually
ridiculous
also
.
<EOS>
There
is
nothing
so
odious
to
man
as
a
virago
.
<EOS>
Though
Theseus
loved
an
Amazon
,
he
showed
his
love
but
roughly
,
and
from
the
time
of
Theseus
downward
,
no
man
ever
wished
to
have
his
wife
remarkable
rather
for
forward
prowess
than
retiring
gentleness
.
<EOS>
A
low
voice
"
is
an
excellent
thing
in
woman
.
"
  
<EOS>
Such
may
be
laid
down
as
a
very
general
rule
;
and
few
women
should
allow
themselves
to
deviate
from
it
,
and
then
only
on
rare
occasions
.
<EOS>
But
if
there
be
a
time
when
a
woman
may
let
her
hair
to
the
winds
,
when
she
may
loose
her
arms
,
and
scream
out
trumpet
-
tongued
to
the
ears
of
men
,
it
is
when
nature
calls
out
within
her
not
for
her
own
wants
,
but
for
the
wants
of
those
whom
her
womb
has
borne
,
whom
her
breasts
have
suckled
,
for
those
who
look
to
her
for
their
daily
bread
as
naturally
as
man
looks
to
his
Creator
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
nothing
poetic
in
the
nature
of
Mrs.
Quiverful
.
<EOS>
She
was
neither
a
Medea
nor
a
Constance
.
<EOS>
When
angry
,
she
spoke
out
her
anger
in
plain
words
,
and
in
a
tone
which
might
have
been
modulated
with
advantage
;
but
she
did
so
,
at
any
rate
,
without
affectation
.
<EOS>
Now
,
without
knowing
it
,
she
rose
to
a
tragic
vein
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
my
dear
,
we
are
not
to
have
it
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Such
were
the
words
with
which
her
ears
were
greeted
when
she
entered
the
parlour
,
still
hot
from
the
kitchen

.
<EOS>
And
the
face
of
her
husband
spoke
even
more
plainly
than
his
words
:
    
E'en
<EOS>
such
a
man
,
so
faint
,
<EOS>
so
spiritless
,
<EOS>
So
dull
,
so
dead

,
so

-

,
<EOS>
Drew

's

in
the
dead
of

.
  
<EOS>
"
What
!
"
said
she
 
and
Mrs.
Siddons
could
not
have
put
more
passion
into

single

<EOS>
"
What
!
<EOS>
Not
have
it
?
<EOS>
Who
says
so
?
"
<EOS>
And
she
sat
opposite

her
husband
,
with
her

,

,
and
her

,

.
  
<EOS>
She
sat
as

as
death
while
he
told
his
story
,
and
very
dreadful
to
him
<EOS>
her

was
.
<EOS>
He

very

and

but
still
in

that
she

the

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
so
you
have

?
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
had
no

of

,
"
he

.
<EOS>
"
I
had
no
witnesses

Slope
's

,

.
<EOS>
It

,

,

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Witnesses
!
<EOS>
"
she
screamed
,
rising

and

.
<EOS>
"
Do
clergymen
require
witnesses
to
their
words
?
<EOS>
He
made
the
promise
in
the
bishop
's
name
,
and

to

,
I

.
<EOS>
Did
he
not

say
that
the
bishop

sent

to

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
did
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
But

is
now
nothing
to
the
purpose
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
everything

,
Mr.
Quiverful
.
<EOS>
Witnesses

!
<EOS>
And
then
to

of
your
honour
being

because
you
wish

provide

fourteen

.
<EOS>
It

everything
to
the
purpose
;
and
so

,
if
I
scream
it
into
their

from

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
forget
,
Letitia
,
that
the
bishop
has
so
many

in
his

.
<EOS>
We
must
wait
a
little

.
<EOS>
That
is
all
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Wait
!
<EOS>
Shall
we
feed
the
children
by
waiting
?
<EOS>
Will
waiting
put
George
,
and
Tom
,
and
Sam
out

?
<EOS>
Will

?
<EOS>
Will

make

and
Jane

?
<EOS>
Will
waiting
pay

things

last

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
all
we
can

,
my

.
<EOS>
The
disappointment
is
as
much

to

;
and
yet
,
God

,
I
feel

more

than
my
own
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Quiverful
was
looking
full
into
her
husband
's
face
,
and
saw
a
small

appear
on
each
of
those

.
<EOS>
This
was
too
much
for
her
woman
's
heart
.
<EOS>
He
also
had
risen
,
and
was
standing
with
his
back
to
the
empty
grate
.
<EOS>
She
rushed
towards
him
and
,
seizing
him
in

,
sobbed
aloud
upon

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
too
good
,
too
soft
,
too
yielding
,
"
she
said
at
last
.
"
<EOS>
These
men
,

,
they

like

's

;
and
when

no

,
they
throw

aside

old

.
<EOS>
This
is
twice
they
have

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
In
one

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
It

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
At
any
rate

shall
hear

,
"
said

lady
,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
At
any
rate
he
shall
hear

,

that
loudly
;
and
so

.
<EOS>
She
little
knows
Letitia
Quiverful
,
if
she

I
will

with
the
loss

that

.
<EOS>
If

within
her
,
I
'll

her
ashamed
of
herself
,
"
 
and
she
paced

,
stamping

as

with

fat
,

.
"
<EOS>
Good

!
<EOS>
What

she
must

her
to
treat
in
such

as
this
the

unprovided

!
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Quiverful
proceeded
to
explain
that
he
did
n't

Mrs.
Proudie
had

do

.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't

,
"
said
Mrs.
Quiverful
;
"
I

about

than

.
<EOS>
Does

Mrs.
Proudie

Slope

?
<EOS>
Was

that

,

?
<EOS>
I

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My

,

're
wrong
 
<EOS>
"
  
"
Now
,
Q.
,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
Take

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Jemima

the

.
"
<EOS>
And

'll

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
Soft
,
however
,
as
Mr.
Quiverful
might
be
,
he
would

on
this

,
and

the

Mr.
Slope
had
spoken
of
Mrs.
Proudie
's

in

.
<EOS>
As
he
did
so
,
a
new

gradually
instilled
itself
into
the
matron
's

,
and
a
new
course
of
conduct
presented
itself
to
her

.
<EOS>
What
if
,
after
all
,
Mrs.
Proudie
knew

this

of
Mr.
Slope
's
?
<EOS>
In
that

,
might

not

that
that

still

her
in
this

,
still
stand
her

,
and
,

,

through
in

Mr.
Slope
?
<EOS>
Mrs.
Quiverful
said
nothing
as
this
vague
hope
occurred
to
her
,
but
listened
with
more
than
ordinary

to
what
her
husband
had
to

.
<EOS>
While
he
was
still
explaining
that
in
all

the
world
was
wrong
in
its
estimation
of
Mrs.
Proudie
's
power
and
authority
,
she
had
fully
made
up
her
mind
as
to
her
course
of
action
.
<EOS>
She
did
not
,
however
,
proclaim
her
intention
.
<EOS>
She
shook
her
head

as
he
continued
his
narration
,
and
when
he
had
completed
,
she
rose
to
go
,
merely
observing
that
it
was
cruel
,
cruel
treatment
.
<EOS>
She
then
asked
him
if
he
would
mind
waiting
for
a
late
dinner
instead
of
dining
at
their
usual

of
three
;
and
,
having
received
from
him
a

on
this
point
,
she
proceeded
to
carry
her
purpose
into
execution
.
  
<EOS>
She
determined
that
she
would
at
once
go
to
the
palace
,
that
she
would
do
so
,
if
possible
,
before
Mrs.
Proudie
could
have
had
an
interview
with
Mr.
Slope
,
and
that
she
would
be
either
submissive
,
piteous
,
and
pathetic
,
or
else
indignant
,
violent
,
and
exacting
,
according
to
the
manner
in
which
she
was
received
.
  
<EOS>
She
was
quite
confident
in
her
own
power
.
<EOS>
Strengthened
as
she
was
by
the
pressing
wants
of
fourteen
children
,
she
felt
that
she
could
make
her
way
through
legions
of
episcopal
servants
and
force
herself
,
if
need
be
,
into
the
presence
of
the
lady
who
had
so
wronged
her
.
<EOS>
She
had
no
shame
about
it
,
no
_
mauvaise
honte
_
,
no
dread
of
archdeacons
.
<EOS>
She
would
,
as
she
declared
to
her
husband
,
make
her
wail
heard
in
the
market
-
place
if
she
did
not
get
redress
and
justice
.
<EOS>
It
might
be
very
well
for
an
unmarried
young
curate
to
be
shamefaced
in
such
matters
;
it
might
be
all
right
that
a
snug
rector
,
really
in
want
of
nothing
,
but
still
looking
for
better
preferment
,
should
carry
on
his
affairs
decently
under
the
rose
.
<EOS>
But
Mrs.
Quiverful
,
with
fourteen
children
,
had
given
over
being
shamefaced
and
,
in
some
things
,
had
given
over
being
decent
.
<EOS>
If
it
were
intended
that
she
should
be
ill
-
used
in
the
manner
proposed
by
Mr.
Slope
,
it
should
not
be
done
under
the
rose
.
<EOS>
All
the
world
should
know
of
it
.
  
<EOS>
In
her
present
mood
,
Mrs.
Quiverful
was
not
over
-
careful
about
her
attire
.
<EOS>
She
tied
her
bonnet
under
her
chin
,
threw
her
shawl
over
her
shoulders
,
armed
herself
with
the
old
family
cotton
umbrella
,
and
started
for
Barchester
.
<EOS>
A
journey
to
the
palace
was
not
quite
so
easy
a
thing
for
Mrs.
Quiverful
as
for
our
friend
at
Plumstead
.
<EOS>
Plumstead
is
nine
miles
from
Barchester
,
and
Puddingdale
is
but
four
.
<EOS>
But
the
archdeacon
could
order
round
his
brougham
,
and
his
high
-
trotting
fast
bay
gelding
would
take
him
into
the
city
within
the
hour
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
brougham
in
the

-
house
of
Puddingdale
Vicarage
,
no
bay

in

.
<EOS>
There
was
no
method
of

for
its

but
that
which
nature
has
assigned
to

.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Quiverful
was
a
broad
,
heavy
woman
,
not

,
nor

.
<EOS>
In

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
There

,

next

.
<EOS>
To

Quiverful

before

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
Those

Mrs.

"

Harding
's
claims
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Mr.
Harding
should
have
known
his
own
mind
,
"
said
the
lady
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
Mr.
Harding
be
not
replaced
at
the
hospital
,
his
lordship
will
have
to
encounter
much
ill
-
will
,
not
only
in
the
diocese
,
but
in
the
world
at
large
.
<EOS>
Besides
,
taking
a
higher
ground
,
his
lordship
,
as
I
understand
,
feels
it
to
be
his
duty
to
gratify
,
in
this
matter
,
so
very
worthy
a
man
<EOS>
and
so
good
a
clergyman
as
Mr.
Harding
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
what
is
to
become
of
the
Sabbath
-
day
school
and
of
the
Sunday
services
in
the
hospital
?
"
said
Mrs.
Proudie
,
with
something
very
nearly
approaching
to
a
sneer
on
her
face
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
understand
that
Mr.
Harding
makes
no
objection
to
the
Sabbath
-
day
school
,
"
said
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
as
to
the
hospital
services
,
that
matter
will
be
best
discussed
after
his
appointment
.
<EOS>
If
he
has
any
permanent
objection
,
then
,
I
fear
,
the
matter
must
rest
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
a
very
easy
conscience
in
such
matters
,
Mr.
Slope
,
"
said
she
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
not
have
an
easy
conscience
,
"
he
rejoined
,
"
but
a
conscience
very
far
from
being
easy
,
if
anything
said
or
done
by
me
should
lead
the
bishop
to
act
unadvisedly
in
this
matter
.
<EOS>
It
is
clear
that
in
the
interview
<EOS>
I
had
with
Mr.
Harding
<EOS>
I
misunderstood
him
 
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
it
is
equally
clear
that
you
have
misunderstood
Mr.
Quiverful
,
"
said
she
,
now
at
the
top
of
her
wrath
.
<EOS>
"
What
business
have
you
at
all
with
these
interviews
?
<EOS>
Who
desired
you
to
go
to
Mr.
Quiverful
this
morning
?
<EOS>
Who
commissioned
you
to
manage
this
affair
?
<EOS>
Will
you
answer
me
,
sir
?
<EOS>
Who
sent
you
to
Mr.
Quiverful
this
morning
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
a
dead
pause
in
the
room
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
had
risen
from
his
chair
,
and
was
standing
with
his
hand
on
the
back
of
it
,
looking
at
first
very
solemn
and
now
very
black
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Proudie
was
standing
as
she
had
at
first
placed
herself
,
at
the
end
of
the
table
,
and
as
she
interrogated
her
foe
<EOS>
she
struck
her
hand
upon
it
with
almost
more
than
feminine
vigour
.
<EOS>
The
bishop
was
sitting
in
his
easy
chair
twiddling
his
thumbs
,
turning
his
eyes
now
to
his
wife
,
and
now
to
his
chaplain
,
as
each
took
up
the
cudgels
.
<EOS>
How
comfortable
it
would
be
if
they
could
fight
it
out
between
them
without
the
necessity
of
any
interference
on
his
part
;
fight
it
out
so
that
one
should
kill
the
other
utterly
,
as
far
as
diocesan
life
was
concerned
,
so
that
he
,
the
bishop
,
might
know
clearly
by
whom
it
behoved
him
to
be
led
.
<EOS>
There
would
be
the
comfort
of
quiet
in
either
case
;
but
if
the
bishop
had
a
wish
as
to
which
might
prove
the
victor
,
that
wish
was
certainly
not
antagonistic
to
Mr.
Slope
.
  
<EOS>
"
Better
the
d
 
---
you
know
than
the
d
 
---
you
do
n't
know
,
"
is
an
old
saying
,
and
perhaps
a
true
one
;
but
the
bishop
had
not
yet
realized
the
truth
of
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
Will
you
answer
me
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
she
repeated
.
<EOS>
"
Who
instructed
you
to
call
on
Mr.
Quiverful
this
morning
?
<EOS>
"
There
was
another
pause
.
<EOS>
"
Do
you
intend
to
answer
me
,
sir
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
,
Mrs.
Proudie
,
that
under
all
the
circumstances
it
will
be
better
for
me
not
to
answer
such
a
question
,
"
said
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
had
many
tones
in
his
voice
,
all
duly
under
his
command
;
among
them
was
a
sanctified
low
tone
and
a
sanctified
loud
tone
 
<EOS>
he
now
used
the
former
.
  
<EOS>
"
Did
anyone
send
you
,
sir
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mrs.
Proudie
,
"
said
Mr.
Slope
,
"
I
am
quite
aware
how
much
I
owe
to
your
kindness
.
<EOS>
I
am
aware
also
what
is
due
by
courtesy
from
a
gentleman
to
a
lady
.
<EOS>
But
there
are
higher
considerations
than
either
of
those
,
and
I
hope
I
shall
be
forgiven
if
I
now
allow
myself
to
be
actuated
solely
by
them
.
<EOS>
My
duty
in
this
matter
is
to
his
lordship
,
and
I
can
admit
of
no
questioning
but
from
him
.
<EOS>
He
has
approved
of
what
I
have
done
,
and
you
must
excuse
me
if
I
say
that
,
having
that
approval
and
my
own
,
I
want
none
other
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
What
horrid
words
were
these
which
greeted
the
ear
of
Mrs.
Proudie
?
<EOS>
The
matter
was
indeed
too
clear
.
<EOS>
There
was
premeditated
mutiny
in
the
camp
.
<EOS>
Not
only
had
ill
-
conditioned
minds
become
insubordinate
by
the
fruition
of
a
little
power
,
but
sedition
had
been
overtly
taught
and
preached
.
<EOS>
The
bishop
had
not
yet
been
twelve
months
in
his
chair
,
and
rebellion
had
already
reared
her
hideous
head
within
the
palace
.
<EOS>
Anarchy
and
misrule
would
quickly
follow
unless
she
took
immediate
and
strong
measures
to
put
down
the
conspiracy
which
she
had
detected
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Slope
,
"
she
said
with
slow
and
dignified
voice
,
differing
much
from
that
which
she
had
hitherto
used
,
"
Mr.
Slope
,
I
will
trouble
you
,
if
you
please
,
to
leave
the
apartment
.
<EOS>
I
wish
to
speak
to
my
lord
alone
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
also
felt
that
everything
depended
on
the
present
interview
.
<EOS>
Should
the
bishop
now
be
re
-
petticoated
,
his
thraldom
would
be
complete
and
forever
.
<EOS>
The
present
moment
was
peculiarly
propitious
for
rebellion
.
<EOS>
The
bishop
had
clearly
committed
himself
by
breaking
the
seal
of
the
answer
to
the
archbishop
;
he
had
therefore
fear
to
influence
him
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
had
told
him
that
no
consideration
ought
to
induce
him
to
refuse
the
archbishop
's
invitation
;
he
had
therefore
hope
to
influence
him
.
<EOS>
He
had
accepted
Mr.
Quiverful
's
resignation
and
therefore
dreaded
having
to
renew
that
matter
with
his
wife
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
screwed
up
to
the
pitch
of
asserting
a
will
of
his
own
,
and
might
possibly
be
carried
on
till
by
an
absolute
success
he
should
have
been
taught
how
possible
it
was
to
succeed
.
<EOS>
Now
was
the
moment
for
victory
or
rout
.
<EOS>
It
was
now
that
Mr.
Slope
must
make
himself
master
of
the
diocese
,
or
else
resign
his
place
and
begin
his
search
for
fortune
again
.
<EOS>
He
saw
all
this
plainly
.
<EOS>
After
what
had
taken
place
any
compromise
between
him
and
the
lady
was
impossible
.
<EOS>
Let
him
once
leave
the
room
at
her
bidding
and
leave
the
bishop
in
her
hands
,
and
he
might
at
once
pack
up
his
portmanteau
and
bid
adieu
to
episcopal
honours
,
Mrs.
Bold
,
and
the
Signora
Neroni
.
  
<EOS>
And
yet
it
was
not
so
easy
to
keep
his
ground
when
he
was
bidden
by
a
lady
to
go
,
or
to
continue
to
make
a
third
in
a
party
between
a
husband
and
wife
when
the
wife
expressed
a
wish
for
a
_
tête
-
à
-
tête
_
with
her
husband
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Slope
,
"
she
repeated
,
"
I
wish
to
be
alone
with
my
lord
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
His
lordship
has
summoned
me
on
most
important
diocesan
business
,
"
said
Mr.
Slope
,
glancing
with
uneasy
eye
at
Dr.
Proudie
.
<EOS>
He
felt
that
he
must
trust
something
to
the
bishop
,
and
yet
that
that
trust
was
so
woefully
ill
-
placed
.
<EOS>
"
My
leaving
him
at
the
present
moment
is
,
I
fear
,
impossible
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
bandy
words
with
me
,
you
ungrateful
man
?
"
said
she
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
lord
,
will
you
do
me
the
favour
to
beg
Mr.
Slope
to
leave
the
room
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
My
lord
scratched
his
head
,
but
for
the
moment
said
nothing
.
<EOS>
This
was
as
much
as
Mr.
Slope
expected
from
him
,
and
was
on
the
whole
,
for
him
,
an
active
exercise
of
marital
rights
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
lord
,
"
said
the
lady
,
"
is
Mr.
Slope
to
leave
this
room
,
or
am
I
?
"
  
<EOS>
Here
Mrs.
Proudie
made
a
false
step
.
<EOS>
She
should
not
have
alluded
to
the
possibility
of
retreat
on
her
part
.
<EOS>
She
should
not
have
expressed
the
idea
that
her
order
for
Mr.
Slope
's
expulsion
could
be
treated
otherwise
than
by
immediate
obedience
.
<EOS>
In
answer
to
such
a
question
the
bishop
naturally
said
in
his
own
mind
that
,
as
it
was
necessary
that
one
should
leave
the
room
,
perhaps
it
might
be
as
well
that
Mrs.
Proudie
did
so
.
<EOS>
He
did
say
so
in
his
own
mind
,
but
externally
he
again
scratched
his
head
and
again
twiddled
his
thumbs
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Proudie
was
boiling
over
with
wrath
.
<EOS>
Alas
,
alas
!
<EOS>
Could
<EOS>
she
but
have
kept
her
temper
as
her
enemy
did
,
she
would
have
conquered
as
she
had
ever
conquered
.
<EOS>
But
divine
anger
got
the
better
of
her
,
as
it
has
done
of
other
heroines
,
and
she
fell
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
lord
,
"
said
she
,
"
am
I
to
be
vouchsafed
an
answer
or
am
I
not
?
"
  
<EOS>
At
last
he
broke
his
deep
silence
and
proclaimed
himself
a
Slopeite
.
<EOS>
"
Why
,
my
dear
,
"
said
he
,
"
Mr.
Slope
and
I
are
very
busy
.
"
  
<EOS>
That
was
all
.
<EOS>
There
was
nothing
more
necessary
.
<EOS>
He
had
gone
to
the
battlefield
,
stood
the
dust
and
heat
of
the
day
,
encountered
the
fury
of
the
foe
,
and
won
the
victory
.
<EOS>
How
easy
is
success
to
those
who
will
only
be
true
to
themselves
!
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
saw
at
once
the
full
amount
of
his
gain
,
and
turned
on
the
vanquished
lady
a
look
of
triumph
which
she
never
forgot
and
never
forgave
.
<EOS>
Here
he
was
wrong
.
<EOS>
He
should
have
looked
humbly
at
her
and
,
with
meek
entreating
eye
,
have
deprecated
her
anger
.
<EOS>
He
should
have
said
by
his
glance
that
he
asked
pardon
for
his
success
,
and
that
he
hoped
forgiveness
for
the
stand
which
he
had
been
forced
to
make
in
the
cause
of
duty
.
<EOS>
So
might
he
perchance
have
somewhat
mollified
that
imperious
bosom
and
prepared
the
way
for
future
terms
.
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Slope
meant
to
rule
without
terms
.
<EOS>
Ah
,
forgetful
,
inexperienced
man
!
<EOS>
Can
you
cause
that
little
trembling
victim
to
be
divorced
from
the
woman
that
possesses
him
?
<EOS>
Can
you
provide
that
they
shall
be
separated
at
bed
and
board
?
<EOS>
Is
he
not
flesh
of
her
flesh
and
bone
of
her
bone
,
and
must
he
not
so
continue
?
<EOS>
It
is
very
well
now
for
you
to
stand
your
ground
and
triumph
as
she
is
driven
ignominiously
from
the
room
,
but
can
you
be
present
when
those
curtains
are
drawn
,
when
that
awful
helmet
of
proof
has
been
tied
beneath
the
chin
,
when
the
small
remnants
of
the
bishop
's
prowess
shall
be
cowed
by
the
tassel
above
his
head
?
<EOS>
Can
you
then
intrude
yourself
when
the
wife
wishes
"
to
speak
to
my
lord
alone
?
"
  
<EOS>
But
for
the
moment
Mr.
Slope
's
triumph
was
complete
,
for
Mrs.
Proudie
without
further
parley
<EOS>
left
the
room
and
did
not
forget
to
shut
the
door
after
her
.
<EOS>
Then
followed
a
close
conference
between
the
new
allies
,
in
which
was
said
much
which
it
astonished
Mr.
Slope
to
say
and
the
bishop
to
hear
.
<EOS>
And
yet
the
one
said
it
and
the
other
heard
it
without
ill
-
will
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
mincing
of
matters
now
.
<EOS>
The
chaplain
plainly
told
the
bishop
that
the
world
gave
him
credit
for
being
under
the
governance
of
his
wife
;
that
his
credit
and
character
in
the
diocese
were
suffering
;
that
he
would
surely
get
himself
in
hot
water
if
he
allowed
Mrs.
Proudie
to
interfere
in
matters
which
were
not
suitable
for
a
woman
's
powers
;
and
in
fact
that
he
would
become
contemptible
if
he
did
not
throw
off
the
yoke
under
which
he
groaned
.
<EOS>
The
bishop
at
first
hummed
and
hawed
and
affected
to
deny
the
truth
of
what
was
said
.
<EOS>
But
his
denial
was
not
stout
and
quickly
broke
down
.
<EOS>
He
soon
admitted
by
silence
his
state
of
vassalage
and
pledged
himself
,
with
Mr.
Slope
's
assistance
,
to
change
his
courses
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
also
did
not
make
out
a
bad
case
for
himself
.
<EOS>
He
explained
how
it
grieved
him
to
run
counter
to
a
lady
who
had
always
been
his
patroness
,
who
had
befriended
him
in
so
many
ways
,
who
had
,
in
fact
,
recommended
him
to
the
bishop
's
notice
;
but
,
as
he
stated
,
his
duty
was
now
imperative
;
he
held
a
situation
of
peculiar
confidence
,
and
was
immediately
and
especially
attached
to
the
bishop
's
person
.
<EOS>
In
such
a
situation
his
conscience
required
that
he
should
regard
solely
the
bishop
's
interests
,
and
therefore
he
had
ventured
to
speak
out
.
  
<EOS>
The
bishop
took
this
for
what
it
was
worth
,
and
Mr.
Slope
only
intended
that
he
should
do
so
.
<EOS>
It
gilded
the
pill
which
Mr.
Slope
had
to
administer
,
and
which
the
bishop
thought
would
be
less
bitter
than
that
other
pill
which
he
had
so
long
been
taking
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
lord
,
"
had
his
immediate
reward
,
like
a
good
child
.
<EOS>
He
was
instructed
to
write
and
at
once
did
write
another
note
to
the
archbishop
accepting
his
grace
's

.
<EOS>
This
note
Mr.
Slope
,
more
prudent
than
the
lady
,
himself
took
away
and
posted
with
his
own
hands
.
<EOS>
Thus
he
made
sure
that
this
act
of
self
-
jurisdiction
should
be
as
nearly
as
possible
a
_
fait

_
.
<EOS>
He
begged
,
and
coaxed
,
and
threatened
the
bishop
with
a

of

him
also
write
at

to
Mr.
Harding
,
but

bishop
,
though

from
his
wife
,
was
not
yet

to
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
He
said
,
and
probably
said
truly
,
that
such

offer
must
be
made
in
some
official

;
that

was

to

;
and
that
he
should

Mr.
Harding
before

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
might
,
however
,
beg
Mr.
Harding
to
call
upon
him
.
<EOS>
Not
disappointed
with
his
achievement
Mr.
Slope
went
his
way
.
<EOS>
He
first
posted
the
precious
note
which
he
had
in
his
pocket
,
and
then
pursued
other
enterprises
in
which
we
must
follow
him
in
other
chapters
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Proudie
,
having
received
such
satisfaction
as
was
to
be

from
slamming
her
husband
's
door
,
did
not

betake
herself
to
Mrs.
Quiverful
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,

the
first

she
felt
that
she
could
not
again
see
that
lady
.
<EOS>
She
would
have
to
own
that

,
to

had
passed
from

,

!
<EOS>
No
,

would

a

the
next
day
or

day

.
<EOS>
Thus
resolving
,
she
betook

to

,
but
here
she
again
changed
her
mind
.
<EOS>
The
air
of
that
sacred
enclosure
somewhat
restored
her

and
gave
her

.
<EOS>
As
Achilles
warmed
at

,

Don

's

when

,

Proudie
look
forward
to
fresh

,
as
her

on
her
husband
's

.
<EOS>
She
would
not
despair
.
<EOS>
Having
so
resolved
,
she

with

and

to
Mrs.
Quiverful
.
  
<EOS>
This
scene
in
the
bishop
's
study
took
longer
in

acting

in

telling
.
<EOS>
We
have
not
,

,

the

.
<EOS>
At
any
rate
Mrs.
Quiverful
was
beginning
to
be
very

,
and
was
thinking
that
Farmer
Subsoil
would

.
<EOS>
Oh
,
who
can

of
that

,
as

the
great

to
see
written
there
<EOS>
either

,

the

continued

!
<EOS>
Poor
mother
!
<EOS>
Poor
wife
!
<EOS>
There
was
little
there
to
comfort
you
!
  
<EOS>
"
Mrs.
Quiverful
,
"
thus
spoke
the
lady
with
considerable

,
and
without
sitting
down
herself
,
"
I
find
that
your
husband
has
behaved
in
this
matter
in
a
very
weak
and
foolish
manner
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Quiverful
immediately
rose
upon
her
feet
,
thinking
it
disrespectful
to
remain
sitting
while
the
wife
of
the
bishop
stood
.
<EOS>
But
she
was
desired
to
sit
down
again
,
and
made
to
do
so
,
so
that
Mrs.
Proudie
might
stand
and
preach
over
her
.
<EOS>
It
is
generally
considered
an
offensive
thing
for
a
gentleman
to
keep
his
seat
while
another
is
kept
standing
before
him
,
and
we
presume
the
same
law
holds
with
regard
to
ladies
.
<EOS>
It
often
is
so
felt
,
but
we
are
inclined
to
say
that
it
never
produces
half
the
discomfort
or
half
the
feeling
of
implied
inferiority
that
is
shown
by
a
great
man
who
desires
his
visitor
to
be
seated
while
he
himself
speaks
from
his
legs
.
<EOS>
Such
a
solecism
in
good
breeding
,
when
construed
into
English
,
means
this
:
"
The
accepted
rules
of
courtesy
in
the
world
require
that
I
should
offer
you
a
seat
;
if
I
did
not
do
so
,
you
would
bring
a
charge
against
me
in
the
world
of
being
arrogant
and
ill
-
mannered
;
I
will
obey
the
world
,
but
,
nevertheless
,
I
will
not
put
myself
on
an
equality
with
you
.
<EOS>
You
may
sit
down
,
but
I
wo
n't
sit
with
you
.
<EOS>
Sit
,
therefore
,
at
my
bidding
,
and
I
'll
stand
and
talk
at
you
!
"
  
<EOS>
This
was
just
what
Mrs.
Proudie
meant

,
and
Mrs.
Quiverful
,
though

,

.
<EOS>
She

,
and
a

.
  
<EOS>
"
Pray

,
Mrs.
Quiverful
,

.
<EOS>
Your

,
I

,

.
<EOS>
It

,
Mrs.
Quiverful
,

.
<EOS>
I
much

I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

Proudie
,

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
_
Pray
_
be

,
Mrs.
Quiverful
.
<EOS>
I
must

I

.
<EOS>
Your

,

.
<EOS>
As

,

know

own

.
<EOS>
What

may
ultimately

what

doing
 
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Knowing

<EOS>
"
  
"
Fourteen

,

Proudie
,
fourteen

!
<EOS>
And
barely
bread
 
<EOS>
barely
bread
?
<EOS>
It
's

for
the
children
of
a

,
it
's
hard
for
one
who
has
always
done

!
"
<EOS>
Not
a

fell
from
her
about
herself
,
but
the

came

down

big
,
coarse

,
on
which
the
dust
of
the
August
road
had
left

.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Proudie
has
not
been
portrayed
in
these
pages
as
an
agreeable
or
an
amiable
lady
.
<EOS>
There
has
been
no
intention
to
impress
the
reader
much
in

.
<EOS>
It
is
ordained
that
all
novels
should
have
a
male
and

and
a
male

.
<EOS>
If

Proudie
.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
There

a
heart
inside
that
stiff
-
ribbed
bodice
,
though
not
,

,
of
large

,
and

.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Quiverful
,

,

,
and
Mrs.

.
<EOS>
Whether

,
we

.
<EOS>
But
Mrs.
Proudie
was

.
  
<EOS>
She
did

show
it
as
other

.
<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Quiverful
,

,

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
Instead

,
Mrs.
Proudie
slapped

and
declared
 
not

,

,

"

.
"
  
<EOS>
The

Quiverful
's

Mr.
Slope

.
<EOS>
This

she
very

.
  
<EOS>
"
Why

such

,
"

,

,
"
as

?
<EOS>
If

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Poor

was
ready

in

to
his

<EOS>

Thus

"

"

<EOS>
Oh

,

_

<EOS>
Mrs.

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
A
Love
Scene
 
Mr.
Slope
,
as
we
have
said
,
left
the
palace
with
a
feeling
of
considerable
triumph
.
<EOS>
Not
that
he
thought
that
his
difficulties
were
all
over
 
he
did
not
so
deceive
himself
 
<EOS>
but
he
felt
that
he
had
played
his
first
move
well
,
as
well
as
the
pieces
on
the
board
would
allow
,
and
that
he
had
nothing
with
which
to
reproach
himself
.
<EOS>
He
first
of
all
posted
the
letter
to
the
archbishop
and
,
having
made
that
sure
,
proceeded
to
push
the
advantage
which
he
had
gained
.
<EOS>
Had
Mrs.
Bold
been
at
home
,
he
would
have
called
on
her
,
but
he
knew
that
she
was
at
Plumstead
,
so
he
wrote
the
following
note
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
beginning
of
what
,
he
trusted
,
might
be
a
long
and
tender

of

.
  
<EOS>
MY
DEAR
MRS
.
<EOS>
BOLD
,
  
<EOS>
You
will
understand
perfectly
that
I
can
not
at
present
correspond
with
your
father
.
<EOS>
I
heartily
wish
that
I
could
,
and
hope
the
day
may
be
not
long
distant
when
mists
shall
have
been
cleared
away
,
and
we
may
know
each
other
.
<EOS>
But
I
can
not
preclude
myself
from
the
pleasure
of
sending
you
these
few
lines
to
say
that
Mr.
Q.
has
to
-
day
,
in
my

,

any
title
that
he

to

,
and
that
the
bishop

offer

to
your

.
  
<EOS>
Will

,
with
my

,

him
,
who
I

now
a
fellow
-
visitor
with

,
to

the
bishop
either
on
Wednesday

,
between

and

.
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
This
is
by
the
bishop
's
desire
<EOS>
_
.
<EOS>
If

so
far

as

,

Harding
,

.
<EOS>
Perhaps
I
should
say
no
more
 
<EOS>
but

I
wish

make

father
understand
that
no

will

him
which

duty
.
<EOS>
I
for
one
am

that
no
clergyman
could
perform
it
more
satisfactorily
than
he
did
,
or

he

.
  
<EOS>
On
a
former
occasion
I
was
indiscreet
and
much
too
impatient
,
considering
your
father
's
age
and
my
own
.
<EOS>
I
hope
he
will
not
now
refuse
my
apology
.
<EOS>
I
still
hope
also
that
with
your
aid
and
sweet
pious
labours
we
may
live
to
attach
such
a
Sabbath
-
school
to
the
old
endowment
as
may
,
by
God
's
grace
and
furtherance
,
be
a
blessing
to
the
poor
of
this
city
.
  
<EOS>
You
will
see
at
once
that
this
letter
is
confidential
.
<EOS>
The
subject
,
of
course
,
makes
it
so
.
<EOS>
But
,
equally
,
of
course
,
it
is
for
your
parent
's
eye
as
well
as
for
your
own
,
should
you
think
proper
to
show
it
to
him
.
  
<EOS>
I
hope
my
darling
little
friend
Johnny
is
as
strong
as
ever
 
dear
little
fellow
.
<EOS>
Does
he
still
continue
his
rude
assaults
on
those
beautiful
long
silken
tresses
?
  
<EOS>
I
can
assure
you
your
friends
miss
you
from
Barchester
sorely
,
but
it
would
be
cruel
to
begrudge
you
your
sojourn
among
flowers
and
fields
during
this
truly
sultry
weather
.
  
<EOS>
Pray
believe
me
,
my
dear
Mrs.
Bold
,
Yours
most
sincerely
,
OBADIAH
SLOPE
  
Barchester
,
Friday
.
  
<EOS>
Now
this
letter
,
taken
as
a
whole
,
and
with
the
consideration
that
Mr.
Slope
wished
to
assume
a
great
degree
of
intimacy
with
Eleanor
,
would
not
have
been
bad
but
for
the
allusion
to
the
tresses
.
<EOS>
Gentlemen
do
not
write
to
ladies
about
their
tresses
unless
they
are
on
very
intimate
terms
indeed
.
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Slope
could
not
be
expected
to
be
aware
of
this
.
<EOS>
He
longed
to
put
a
little
affection
into
his
epistle
,
and
yet
he
thought
it
injudicious
,
as
the
letter
would
,
he
knew
,
be
shown
to
Mr.
Harding
.
<EOS>
He
would
have
insisted
that
the
letter
should
be
strictly
private
and
seen
by
no
eyes
but
Eleanor
's
own
,
had
he
not
felt
that
such
an
injunction
would
have
been
disobeyed
.
<EOS>
He
therefore
restrained
his
passion
,
did
not
sign
himself
"
yours
affectionately
,
"
and
contented
himself
instead
with
the
compliment
to
the
tresses
.
  
<EOS>
Having
finished
his
letter
,
he
took

to
Mrs.
Bold
's
house
and
,
learning
there
,
from
the
servant
,
that
things
were
to
be
sent
out
to
Plumstead
that

,
left
it
,
with
many
injunctions
,
in
her
hands
.
  
<EOS>
We
will
now
follow
Mr.
Slope
so
as
to
complete
the
day
with
him
and
then
return
to
his
letter
and
its
momentous
fate
in
the
next
chapter
.
  
<EOS>
There
is
an
old
song
which
gives
us
some
very
good
advice
about
courting
:
    
<EOS>
It
's
gude
to
be
off
with
the
auld
luve
Before
ye
be
on
wi
'
the
new
.
  
<EOS>
Of
the
wisdom
of
this
maxim
Mr.
Slope
was
ignorant
,
and
accordingly
,
having
written
his
letter
to
Mrs.
Bold
,
he
proceeded
to
call
upon
the
Signora
Neroni
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
it
was
hard
to
say
which
was
the
old
love
and
which
the
new
,
Mr.
Slope
having
been
smitten
with
both
so
nearly
at
the
same
time
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
he
thought
it
not
amiss
to
have
two
strings
to
his
bow
.
<EOS>
But
two
strings
to
Cupid
's
bow
are
always
dangerous
to
him
on
whose
behalf
they
are
to
be
used
.
<EOS>
A
man
should
remember
that
between
two
stools
he
may
fall
to
the
ground
.
  
<EOS>
But
in
sooth
Mr.
Slope
was
pursuing
Mrs.
Bold
in
obedience
to
his
better
instincts
,
and
the
signora
in
obedience
to
his
worser
.
<EOS>
Had
he
won
the
widow
and
worn
her
,
no
one
could
have
blamed
him
.
<EOS>
You
,
O
reader
,
and
I
,
and
Eleanor
's
other
friends
would
have
received
the
story
of
such
a
winning
with
much
disgust
and
disappointment
,
but
we
should
have
been
angry
with
Eleanor
,
not

Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
Bishop
,
male
and

,

and

in
full

could
have
found

.
<EOS>
Convocation
itself
,
that
mysterious
and
mighty
synod
,
could
in
no
wise
have
fallen
foul
of
it
.
<EOS>
The
possession
of
£
1000
a
year
and
a
beautiful
wife
would
not
at
all
have
hurt
the
voice
of
the
pulpit

,
or
lessened

grace
and
piety
of
the

.
  
<EOS>
But
not
of
such

were
likely
to
be
his

with

Signora
Neroni
.
<EOS>
In
the
first
place
he
knew
that
her
husband
was
living
,
and
therefore
he
could
not
woo
her
honestly
.
<EOS>
Then
again
she
had
nothing
to
recommend
her
to
his
honest

,
had
such
been
possible
.
<EOS>
She
was
not
only
portionless
,
but
also
from
misfortune
unfitted
to
be
chosen
as
the
wife
of
any
man
who
wanted
a

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
was
aware
that
she
was
a
helpless
,

.
  
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Slope
could
not
help
himself
.
<EOS>
He
knew
that
he
was
wrong
in
devoting

to
the
back

room
in
Dr.
Stanhope
's

.
<EOS>
He

would
,

,
utterly

with
Mrs.
Bold
.
<EOS>
He
knew
that
scandal
would
soon
come
upon

and
spread
abroad
among
the
black
coats
of
Barchester
some
tidings
,
exaggerated

,
of
the
sighs
which
he
poured
into
the
lady
's
ears
.
<EOS>
He
knew
that
he
was
acting
against
the
recognized
principles
of
his
life
,
against
those
laws
of
conduct
by
which
he
hoped
to
achieve
much
higher
success
.
<EOS>
But
,
as
we
have
said
,
he
could
not
help
himself
.
<EOS>
Passion
,
for
the
first
time
in
his
life
,
passion
was
too
strong
for
him
.
  
<EOS>
As
for
the
signora
,
no
such
plea
can
be
put
forward
for
her
,
for
in
truth
she
cared
no
more
for
Mr.
Slope
than
she
did
for
twenty
others
who
had
been
at
her
feet
before
him
.
<EOS>
She
willingly
,
nay
greedily
,
accepted
his
homage
.
<EOS>
He
was
the
finest
fly
that
Barchester
had
hitherto
afforded
to
her
web
,
and
the
signora
was
a
powerful
spider
that
made
wondrous
webs
,
and
could
in
no
way
live
without
catching
flies
.
<EOS>
Her
taste
in
this
respect
was
abominable
,
for
she
had
no
use
for
the
victims
when
caught
.
<EOS>
She
could
not
eat
them
matrimonially
,
as
young
lady
flies
do
whose
webs
are
most
frequently
of
their
mothers
"
weaving
.
<EOS>
Nor
could
she
devour
them
by
any
escapade
of
a
less

description
.
<EOS>
Her
unfortunate
affliction
precluded
her
from
all
hope
of
levanting
with
a
lover
.
<EOS>
It
would
be
impossible
to
run
away
with
a
lady
who
required
three
servants
to
move
her
from
a
sofa
.
  
<EOS>
The
signora
was
subdued
by
no
passion
.
<EOS>
Her
time
for
love
was
gone
.
<EOS>
She
had
lived
out
her
heart
,
such
heart
as
she
had
ever
had
,
in
her
early

,
at
an
age
when
Mr.
Slope
was
thinking
of
the
second
book
of
Euclid
and
his
unpaid
bill
at
the
buttery
hatch
.
<EOS>
In
age
the
lady
was
younger
than
the
gentleman
,
but
in
feelings
,
in
knowledge
of
the
affairs
of
love
,
in

,
he
was
immeasurably
her
junior
.
<EOS>
It
was
necessary
to
her
to
have
some
man
at
her
feet
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
one
customary
excitement
of
her
life
.
<EOS>
She
delighted
in
the
exercise
of
power
which
this
gave
her
;
it
was
now
nearly
the
only

for
her

;
she
would
boast
to
her
sister
that
she
could
make
a
fool
of

man
,
and
the
sister
,
as
little
imbued

as
herself
,
good
-
naturedly
thought
it
but
fair
that
such

be

to
a
poor
invalid
who
was
debarred
from
the
ordinary

of
life
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
was
madly
in
love
but
hardly
knew
it
.
<EOS>
The
Signora
spitted
him
,
as
a
boy
does
a
cockchafer
on

,
that
she
might

of

.
<EOS>
And
she
knew
very
well
what

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
having
added

all

as

making

such

_

_
of

called
about

.
<EOS>
At

this

the
signora
was
almost

.
<EOS>
The

had

.
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
Bertie

out
,
and
Charlotte
at

left

if
anyone
called
whose

specially
with

.
<EOS>
Such

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
,
as

,

Stanhope
,

,
as

,

.
<EOS>
Upstairs

.
<EOS>
He

,
as

.
<EOS>
At

.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,

friend
,
"

to

and

"
  
Mr.

,

in

and

was
 
<EOS>
bowed

red

.
<EOS>
It

,

,

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
was
big
,

,

,
and
,

heart

,

ill

.
<EOS>
The
lady
was
fair
,
as
we
have
said
,
and
delicate
;
everything

was
fine

;
her

in

looked
like

rose
lying
among

,
and

,

as

.
<EOS>
She
was

and
,

,

self

Venus

.
  
<EOS>
Oh
,
that

!
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,
"
but

"

<EOS>
"

"

"
<EOS>
Nothing

,

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Gracious
me
!
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
,
"

,
"
I
hope

do

.
<EOS>
Half

,

,
I

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
At

,
I
do

.
<EOS>
If

,
they
perish

,
and

,
as
Dido

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
With

steel

,

,
"
said

,
"
to

.
<EOS>
Of

my

I
think
Lady
Dido
was
the
most
absurd
.
<EOS>
Why
did
she
not
do
as
Cleopatra
did
?
<EOS>
Why
did
she
not
take
out
her
ships
and
insist

?
<EOS>
She
could
not
bear

the
land
she
had
got
by
a

,
and
then
she
could
not

the

her
lover
.
<EOS>
So
she
fell
between
two
stools
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
,
whatever
you
do
,
never
mingle
love
and
business
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
blushed
up
to
his
eyes
and
over
his
mottled
forehead
to
the
very
roots
of
his
hair
.
<EOS>
He
felt
sure
that
the
signora
knew
all
about
his
intentions
with
reference
to
Mrs
Bold
.
<EOS>
His
conscience
told
him
that
he
was
detected
.
<EOS>
His
doom
was
to
be
spoken
;
he
was
to
be
punished
for
his
duplicity
,
and
rejected
by
the
beautiful
creature
before
him
.
<EOS>
Poor
man
.
<EOS>
He
little
dreamt
that
had
all
his
intentions
with
reference
to
Mrs.
Bold
been
known
to
the
signora
,
it
would
only
have
added
zest
to
that
lady
's
amusement
.
<EOS>
It
was
all
very
well
to
have
Mr.
Slope
at
her
feet
,
to
show
her
power
by
making
an
utter
fool
of
a
clergyman
,
to
gratify
her
own
infidelity
by
thus
proving
the
little
strength
which
religion
had
in
controlling
the
passions
even
of
a
religious
man
;
but
it
would
be
an
increased
gratification
if
she
could
be
made
to
understand
that
she
was
at
the
same
time
alluring
her
victim
away
from
another
,
whose
love
if
secured
would
be
in
every
way
beneficent
and
salutary
.
  
<EOS>
The
Signora
had
indeed
discovered
,
with
the
keen
instinct
of
such
a
woman
,
that
Mr.
Slope
was
bent
on
matrimony
with
Mrs.
Bold
,
but
in
alluding
to
Dido
she
had
not
thought
of
it
.
<EOS>
She
instantly
perceived
,
however
,
from
her
lover
's
blushes
,
what
was
on
his
mind
and
was
not
slow
in
taking
advantage
of
it
.
  
<EOS>
She
looked
him
full
in
the
face
,
not
angrily
,
nor
yet
with
a
smile
,
but
with
an
intense
and
overpowering
gaze
;
then
,
holding
up
her
forefinger
and
slightly
shaking
her
head
,
she
said
:
    
<EOS>
"
Whatever
you
do
,
my
friend
,
do
not
mingle
love
and
business
.
<EOS>
Either
stick
to
your
treasure
and
your
city
of
wealth
,
or
else
follow
your
love
like
a
true
man
.
<EOS>
But
never
attempt
both
.
<EOS>
If
you
do
,
you
'll
have
to
die
with
a
broken
heart
as
did
poor
Dido
.
<EOS>
Which
is
it
to
be
with
you
,
Mr.
Slope
,
love
or
money
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
was
not
so
ready
with
a
pathetic
answer
as
he
usually
was
with
touching
episodes
in
his
extempore
sermons
.
<EOS>
He
felt
that
he
ought
to
say
something
pretty
,
something
also
that
should
remove
the
impression
on
the
mind
of
his
lady
-
love
.
<EOS>
But
he
was
rather
put
about
how
to
do
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
Love
,
"
said
he
,
"
true
overpowering
love
,
must
be
the
strongest
passion
a
man
can
feel
;
it
must
control
every
other
wish
,
and
put
aside
every
other
pursuit
.
<EOS>
But
with
me
love
will
never
act
in
that
way
unless
it
be
returned
;
"
and
he
threw
upon
the
signora
a
look
of
tenderness
which
was
intended
to
make
up
for
all
the
deficiencies
of
his
speech
.
  
<EOS>
"
Take
my
advice
,
"
said
she
.
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
love
.
<EOS>
After
all
,
what
is
it
?
<EOS>
The
dream
of
a
few
weeks
.
<EOS>
That
is
all
its
joy
.
<EOS>
The
disappointment
of
a
life
is
its
Nemesis
.
<EOS>
Who
was
ever
successful
in
true
love
?
<EOS>
Success
in
love
argues
that
the
love
is
false
.
<EOS>
True
love
is
always
despondent
or
tragical
.
<EOS>
Juliet
loved
,
Haidee
loved
,
Dido
loved
,
and
what
came
of
it
?
<EOS>
Troilus
loved
and
ceased
to
be
a
man
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Troilus
loved
and
was
fooled
,
"
said
the
more
manly
chaplain
.
<EOS>
"
A
man
may
love
and
yet
not
be
a
Troilus
.
<EOS>
All
women
are
not
Cressidas
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
all
women
are
not
Cressidas
.
<EOS>
The
falsehood
is
not
always
on
the
woman
's
side
.
<EOS>
Imogen
was
true
,
but
how
was
she
rewarded
?
<EOS>
Her
lord
believed
her
to
be
the
paramour
of
the
first
he
who
came
near
her
in
his
absence
.
<EOS>
Desdemona
was
true
and
was
smothered
.
<EOS>
Ophelia
was
true
and
went
mad
.
<EOS>
There
is
no
happiness
in
love
,
except
at
the
end
of
an
English
novel
.
<EOS>
But
in
wealth
,
money
,
houses
,
lands
,
goods
,
and
chattels
,
in
the
good
things
of
this
world
,
yes
,
in
them
there
is
something
tangible
,
something
that
can
be
retained
and
enjoyed
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
no
,
"
said
Mr.
Slope
,
feeling
himself
bound
to
enter
some
protest
against
so
very
unorthodox
a
doctrine
,
"
this
world
's
wealth
will
make
no
one
happy
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
what
will
make
you
happy
 
<EOS>
you
 
you
?
<EOS>
"
said
she
,
raising
herself
up
and
speaking
to
him
with
energy
across
the
table
.
<EOS>
"
From
what
source
do
you
look
for
happiness
?
<EOS>
Do
not
say
that
you
look
for
none
.
<EOS>
I
shall
not
believe
you
.
<EOS>
It
is
a
search
in
which
every
human
being
spends
an
existence
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
the
search
is
always
in
vain
,
"
said
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
"
We
look
for
happiness
on
earth
,
while
we
ought
to
be
content
to
hope
for
it
in
heaven
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Pshaw
!
<EOS>
You
preach
a
doctrine
which
you
know
you
do
n't
believe
.
<EOS>
It
is
the
way
with
you
all
.
<EOS>
If
you
know
that
there
is
no
earthly
happiness
,
why
do
you
long
to
be
a
bishop
or
a
dean
?
<EOS>
Why
do
you
want
lands
and
income
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
the
natural
ambition
of
a
man
,
"
said
he
.
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
you
have
,
and
the
natural
passions
;
and
therefore
I
say
that
you
do
n't
believe
the
doctrine
you
preach
.
<EOS>
St.
Paul
was
an
enthusiast
.
<EOS>
He
believed
so
that
his
ambition
and
passions
did
not
war
against
his
creed
.
<EOS>
So
does
the
Eastern
fanatic
who
passes
half
his
life
erect
upon
a
pillar
.
<EOS>
As
for
me
,
I
will
believe
in
no
belief
that
does
not
make
itself
manifest
by
outward
signs
.
<EOS>
I
will
think
no
preaching
sincere
that
is
not
recommended
by
the
practice
of
the
preacher
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
was
startled
and
horrified
,
but
he
felt
that
he
could
not
answer
.
<EOS>
How
could
he
stand
up
and
preach
the
lessons
of
his
Master
,
being
there
,
as
he
was
,
on
the
devil
's
business
?
<EOS>
He
was
a
true
believer
,
otherwise
this
would
have
been
nothing
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
had
audacity
for
most
things
,
but
he
had
not
audacity
to
make
a
plaything
of
the
Lord
's
word
.
<EOS>
All
this
the
signora
understood
,
and
felt
much
interest
as
she
saw
her
cockchafer
whirl
round
upon
her
pin
.
  
<EOS>
"
Your
wit
delights
in
such
arguments
,
"
said
he
,
"
but
your
heart
and
your
reason
do
not
go
along
with
them
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
heart
!
<EOS>
"
said
she
;
"
you
quite
mistake
the
principles
of
my
composition
if
you
imagine
that
there
is
such
a
thing
about
me
.
<EOS>
"
After
all
,
there
was
very
little
that
was
false
in
anything
that
the
signora
said
.
<EOS>
If
Mr.
Slope
allowed
himself
to
be
deceived
,
it
was
his
own
fault
.
<EOS>
Nothing
could
have
been
more
open
than
her
declarations
about
herself
.
  
<EOS>
The
little
writing
-
table
with
her
desk
was
still
standing
before
her
,
a
barrier
,
as
it
were
,
against
the
enemy
.
<EOS>
She
was
sitting
as
nearly
upright
as
she
ever
did
,
and
he
had
brought
a
chair
close
to
the
sofa
,
so
that
there
was
only
the
corner
of
the
table
between
him
and
her
.
<EOS>
It
so
happened
that
as
she
spoke
her
hand
lay
upon
the
table
,
and
as
Mr.
Slope
answered
her
he
put
his
hand
upon
hers
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
heart
!
"
said
he
.
<EOS>
"
That
is
a
heavy
charge
which
you
bring
against
yourself
,
and
one
of
which
I
can
not
find
you
guilty
 
<EOS>
"
  
She
withdrew
her
hand
,
not
quickly
and
angrily
,
as
though
insulted
by
his
touch
,
but
gently
and
slowly
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
in
no
condition
to
give
a
verdict
on
the
matter
,
"
said
she
,
"
as
you
have
not
tried
me
.
<EOS>
No
,
do
n't
say
that
you
intend
doing
so
,
for
you
know
you
have
no
intention
of
the
kind
;
nor
indeed
have
I
,
either
.
<EOS>
As
for
you
,
you
will
take
your
vows
where
they
will
result
in
something
more
substantial
than
the
pursuit
of
such
a
ghostlike
,
ghastly
love
as
mine
 
<EOS>
"
  
"
Your
love
should
be
sufficient
to
satisfy
the
dream
of
a
monarch
,
"
said
Mr.
Slope
,
not
quite
clear
as
to
the
meaning
of
his
words
.
  
<EOS>
"
Say
an
archbishop
,
Mr.
Slope
,
"
said
she
.
<EOS>
Poor
fellow
!
<EOS>
She
was
very
cruel
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
went
round
again
upon
his
cork
on
this
allusion
to
his
profession
.
<EOS>
He
tried
,
however
,
to
smile
and
gently
accused
her
of
joking
on
a
matter
,
which
was
,
he
said
,
to
him
of
such
vital
moment
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
 
what
gulls
do
you
men
make
of
us
,
"
she
replied
.
<EOS>
"
How
you
fool
us
to
the
top
of
our
bent
;
and
of
all
men
you
clergymen
are
the
most
fluent
of
your
honeyed
,
caressing
words
.
<EOS>
Now
look
me
in
the
face
,
Mr.
Slope
,
boldly
and
openly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
did
look
at
her
with
a
languishing
loving
eye
,
and
as
he
did
so
he
again
put
forth
his
hand
to
get
hold
of
hers
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
told
you
to
look
at
me
boldly
,
Mr.
Slope
,
but
confine
your
boldness
to
your
eyes
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Madeline
!
"
<EOS>
he
sighed
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
my
name
is
Madeline
,
"
said
she
,
"
but
none
except
my
own
family
usually
call
me
so
.
<EOS>
Now
look
me
in
the
face
,
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
Am
I
to
understand
that
you
say
you
love
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
never
had
said
so
.
<EOS>
If
he
had
come
there
with
any
formed
plan
at
all
,
his
intention
was
to
make
love
to
the
lady
without
uttering
any
such
declaration
.
<EOS>
It
was
,
however
,
quite
impossible
that
he
should
now
deny
his
love
.
<EOS>
He
had
,
therefore
,
nothing
for
it
<EOS>
but
to
go
down
on
his
knees
distractedly
against
the
sofa
and
swear
that
he
did
love
her
with
a
love
passing
the
love
of
man
.
  
<EOS>
The
signora
received
the
assurance
with
very
little
palpitation
or
appearance
of
surprise
.
"
<EOS>
And
now
answer
me
another
question
,
"
said
she
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
When
are
you
to
be
married
to
my
dear
friend
Eleanor
Bold
?
"
  
<EOS>
Poor
Mr.
Slope
went
round
and
round
in
mortal
agony
.
<EOS>
In
such
a
condition
as
his
it
was
really
very
hard
for
him
to
know
what
answer
to
give
.
<EOS>
And
yet
no
answer
would
be
his
surest
condemnation
.
<EOS>
He
might
as
well
at
once
plead
guilty
to
the
charge
brought
against
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
why
do
you
accuse
me
of
such
dissimulation
?
"
said
he
.
  
<EOS>
"
Dissimulation
!
<EOS>
I
said
nothing
of
dissimulation
.
<EOS>
I
made
no
charge
against
you
,
and
make
none
.
<EOS>
Pray
do
n't
defend
yourself
to
me
.
<EOS>
You
swear
that
you
are
devoted
to
my
beauty
,
and
yet
you
are
on
the
eve
of
matrimony
with
another
.
<EOS>
I
feel
this
to
be
rather
a
compliment
.
<EOS>
It
is
to
Mrs.
Bold
that
you
must
defend
yourself
.
<EOS>
That
you
may
find
difficult
;
unless
,
indeed
,
you
can
keep
her
in
the
dark
.
<EOS>
You
clergymen
are
cleverer
than
other
men
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Signora
,
I
have
told
you
that
I
loved
you
,
and
now
you
rail
at
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Rail
at
you
.
<EOS>
God
bless
the
man
;
what
would
he
have
?
<EOS>
Come
,
answer
me
this
at
your
leisure
 
not
without
thinking
now
,
but
leisurely
and
with
consideration
 
are
you
not
going
to
be
married
to
Mrs.
Bold
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
,
"
said
he
.
<EOS>
And
as
he
said
it
he
almost
hated
,
with
an
exquisite
hatred
,
the
woman
whom
he
could
not
help
loving
with
an
exquisite
love
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
surely
you
are
a
worshipper
of
hers
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
,
"
said
Mr.
Slope
,
to
whom
the
word
worshipper
was
peculiarly
distasteful
.
<EOS>
The
signora
had
conceived
that
it
would
be
so
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
wonder
at
that
,
"
said
she
.
<EOS>
"
Do
you
not
admire
her
?
<EOS>
To
my
eye
she
is
the
perfection
of
English
beauty
.
<EOS>
And
then
she
is
rich
,
too
.
<EOS>
I
should
have
thought
she
was
just
the
person
to
attract
you
.
<EOS>
Come
,
Mr.
Slope
,
let
me
give
you
advice
on
this
matter
.
<EOS>
Marry
the
charming
widow
;
she
will
be
a
good
mother
to
your
children
and
an
excellent
mistress
of
a
clergyman
's
household
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
signora
,
how
can
you
be
so
cruel
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Cruel
,
"
said
she
,
changing
the
voice
of
banter
which
she
had
been
using
for
one
which
was
expressively
earnest
in
its
tone
;
"
is
that
cruelty
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
can
I
love
another
while
my
heart
is
entirely
your
own
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
that
were
cruelty
,
Mr.
Slope
,
what
might
you
say
of
me
if
I
were
to
declare
that
I
returned
your
passion
?
<EOS>
What
would
you
think
if
I
bound
you
even
by
a
lover
's
oath
to
do
daily
penance
at
this
couch
of
mine
?
<EOS>
What
can
I
give
in
return
for
a

love
?
<EOS>
Ah
,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope

not

.
<EOS>
After

,
he
had

,
and

.
<EOS>
This

on
the

of
the

,

,

,
and
already

.
  
<EOS>
"
And

?
"
<EOS>

,
now

.
  
<EOS>
"
Sympathy
is

!
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
If

,

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
Now

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
"
Signor

!
<EOS>
"

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
No

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My

!
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
Mr.

<EOS>
He

<EOS>

<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
He

,

already

.
<EOS>
He

,
so

,

.
<EOS>
He

put

to

,
and

had
turned
to
ashes

.
<EOS>
Yet

.
<EOS>
He

,

,

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
He

,

.
<EOS>
He

,
that

.
<EOS>
All

.
<EOS>

,

,

,
how

.
<EOS>
But

,

.
<EOS>
What
chance

dead
knowledge
with

in

man
?
<EOS>
What
possible
chance
between
man
and
woman
?
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
loved

,
insanely

,

never

.
<EOS>
The

did
not
love
at

,
but
she
was
up
to
every

.
<EOS>
It
was

.
  
<EOS>
And

continued
to

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Sacrifice

world
for

!
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"

,

"
<EOS>

"

?
<EOS>

,
false

.

<EOS>
The
wretch

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
Mrs.
Bold

Grantly

.

-
in
-
law
.
<EOS>
But
that
was
now
impossible
.
<EOS>
There
it
was
in
his
hand
,
and
he
looked
as
thoroughly
disgusted
as
though
he
were
quite
sure
that
it
contained
all
the
rhapsodies
of
a
favoured
lover
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
very
hard
on
me
,
"
said
he
after
awhile
,
"
that
this
should
go
on
under
my
roof
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Now
here
the
archdeacon
was
certainly
most
unreasonable
.
<EOS>
Having
invited
his
sister
-
in
-
law
to
his
house
,
it
was
a
natural
consequence
that
she
should
receive
her
letters
there
.
<EOS>
And
if
Mr.
Slope
chose
to
write
to
her
,
his
letter
would
,
as
a
matter
of
course
,
be
sent
after
her
.
<EOS>
Moreover
,
the
very
fact
of
an
invitation
to
one
's
house
implies
confidence
on
the
part
of
the
inviter
.
<EOS>
He
had
shown
that
he
thought
Mrs.
Bold
to
be
a
fit
person
to
stay
with
him
by
his
asking
her
to
do
so
,
and
it
was
most
cruel
to
her
that
he
should
complain
of
her
violating
the
sanctity
of
his
roof
-
tree
,
when
the
laches
committed
were
none
of
her
committing
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
felt
this
,
and
felt
also
that
when
the
archdeacon
talked
thus
about
his
roof
,
what
he
said
was
most
offensive
to
himself
as
Eleanor
's
father
.
<EOS>
If
Eleanor
did
receive
a
letter
from
Mr.
Slope
,
what
was
there
in
that
to
pollute
the
purity
of
Dr.
Grantly
's
household
?
<EOS>
He
was
indignant
that
his
daughter
should
be
so
judged
and
so
spoken
of
,
and
he
made
up
his
mind
that
even
as
Mrs.
Slope
she
must
be
dearer
to
him
than
any
other
creature
on
God
's
earth
.
<EOS>
He
almost
broke
out
and
said
as
much
,
but
for
the
moment
he
restrained
himself
.
  
<EOS>
"
Here
,
"
said
the
archdeacon
,
handing
the
offensive
missile
to
his
father
-
in
-
law
,
"
I
am
not
going
to
be
the
bearer
of
his
love
-
letters
.
<EOS>
You
are
her
father
and
may
do
as
you
think
fit
with
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
By
doing
as
he
thought
fit
with
it
,
the
archdeacon
certainly
meant
that
Mr.
Harding
would
be
justified
in
opening
and
reading
the
letter
,
and
taking
any
steps
which
might
in
consequence
be
necessary
.
<EOS>
To
tell
the
truth
,
Dr.
Grantly
did
feel
rather
a
stronger
curiosity
than
was
justified
by
his
outraged
virtue
to
see
the
contents
of
the
letter
.
<EOS>
Of
course
he
could
not
open
it
himself
,
but
he
wished
to
make
Mr.
Harding
understand
that
he
,
as
Eleanor
's
father
,
would
be
fully
justified
in
doing
so
.
<EOS>
The
idea
of
such
a
proceeding
never
occurred
to
Mr.
Harding
.
<EOS>
His
authority
over
Eleanor
ceased
when
she
became
the
wife
of
John
Bold
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
the
slightest
wish
to
pry
into
her
correspondence
.
<EOS>
He
consequently
put
the
letter
into
his
pocket
,
and
only
wished
that
he
had
been
able
to
do
so
without
the
archdeacon
's
knowledge
.
<EOS>
They
both
sat
silent
during
half
the
journey
home
,
and
then
Dr.
Grantly
said
,
"
Perhaps
Susan
had
better
give
it
to
her
.
<EOS>
She
can
explain
to
her
sister
better
than
either
you
or
I
can
do
how
deep
is
the
disgrace
of
such
an
acquaintance
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
you
are
very
hard
upon
Eleanor
,
"
replied
Mr.
Harding
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
allow
that
she
has
disgraced
herself
,
nor
do
I
think
it
likely
that
she
will
do
so
.
<EOS>
She
has
a
right
to
correspond
with
whom
she
pleases
,
and
I
shall
not
take
upon
myself
to
blame
her
because
she
gets
a
letter
from
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
,
"
said
Dr.
Grantly
,
"
you
do
n't
wish
her
to
marry
the
man
.
<EOS>
I
suppose
you
'll
admit
that
she
would
disgrace
herself
if
she
did
do
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
wish
her
to
marry
him
,
"
said
the
perplexed
father
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
like
him
,
and
do
not
think
he
would
make
a
good
husband
.
<EOS>
But
if
Eleanor
chooses
to
do
so
,
I
shall
certainly
not
think
that
she
disgraces
herself
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Good
heavens
!
"
exclaimed
Dr.
Grantly
and
threw
himself
back
into
the
corner
of
his
brougham
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
said
nothing
more
,
but
commenced
playing
a
dirge
with
an
imaginary
fiddle
bow
upon
an
imaginary
violoncello
,
for
which
there
did
not
appear
to
be
quite
room
enough
in
the
carriage
;
he
continued
the
tune
,
with
sundry
variations
,
till
he
arrived
at
the
rectory
door
.
  
<EOS>
The
archdeacon
had
been
meditating
sad
things
in
his
mind
.
<EOS>
Hitherto
he
had
always
looked
on
his
father
-
in
-
law
as
a
true
partisan
,
though
he
knew
him
to
be
a
man
devoid
of
all
the
combative
qualifications
for
that
character
.
<EOS>
He
had
felt
no
fear
that
Mr.
Harding
would
go
over
to
the
enemy
,
though
he
had
never
counted
much
on
the
ex
-
warden
's
prowess
in
breaking
the
hostile
ranks
.
<EOS>
Now
,
however
,
it
seemed
that
Eleanor
,
with
her
wiles
,
had
completely
trepanned
and
bewildered
her
father
,
cheated
him
out
of
his
judgement
,
robbed
him
of
the
predilections
and
tastes
of
his
life
,
and
caused
him
to
be
tolerant
of
a
man
whose
arrogance
and
vulgarity
would
,
a
few
years
since
,
have
been
unendurable
to
him
.
<EOS>
That
the
whole
thing
was
as
good
as
arranged
between
Eleanor
and
Mr.
Slope
<EOS>
there
was
no
longer
any
room
to
doubt
.
<EOS>
That
Mr.
Harding
knew
that
such
was
the
case
,
even
this
could
hardly
be
doubted
.
<EOS>
It
was
too
manifest
that
he
at
any
rate
suspected
it
and
was
prepared
to
sanction
it
.
  
<EOS>
And
to
tell
the
truth
,
such
was
the
case
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
disliked
Mr.
Slope
as
much
as
it
was
in
his
nature
to
dislike
any
man
.
<EOS>
Had
his
daughter
wished
to
do
her
worst
to
displease
him
by
a
second
marriage
,
she
could
hardly
have
succeeded
better
than
by
marrying
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
But
,
as
he
said
to
himself
now
very
often
,
what
right
had
he
to
condemn
her
if
she
did
nothing
that
was
really
wrong
?
<EOS>
If
she
liked
Mr.
Slope
,
it
was
her
affair
.
<EOS>
It
was
indeed
miraculous
to
him
that
a
woman
with
such
a
mind
,
so
educated
,
so
refined
,
so
nice
in
her
tastes
,
should
like
such
a
man
.
<EOS>
Then
he
asked
himself
whether
it
was
possible
that
she
did
so
.
  
<EOS>
Ah
,
thou
weak
man
;
most
charitable
,
most
Christian
,
but
weakest
of
men
!
<EOS>
Why
could
n't
thou
not
have
asked
herself
?
<EOS>
Was
she
not
the
daughter
of
thy
loins
,
the
child
of
thy
heart
,
the
best
beloved
to
thee
of
all
humanity
?
<EOS>
Had
she
not
proved
to
thee
,
by
years
of
closest
affection
,
her
truth
and
goodness
and
filial
obedience
?
<EOS>
And
yet
,
knowing
and
feeling
all
this
,
thou
couldst
endure
to
go
groping
in
darkness
,
hearing
her
named
in
strains
which
wounded
thy
loving
heart
,
and
being
unable
to
defend
her
as
thou
shouldst
have
done
!
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
had
not
believed
,
did
not
believe
,
that
his
daughter
meant
to
marry
this
man
,
but
he
feared
to
commit
himself
to
such
an
opinion
.
<EOS>
If
she
did
do
it
there
would
be
then
no
means
of
retreat
.
<EOS>
The
wishes
of
his
heart
were
:
first
,
that
there
should
be
no
truth
in
the
archdeacon
's
surmises
;
and
in
this
wish
he
would
have
fain
trusted
entirely
,
had
he
dared
so
to
do
;
secondly
,
that
the
match
might
be
prevented
,
if
unfortunately
,
it
had
been
contemplated
by
Eleanor
;
thirdly
,
that
should
she
be
so
infatuated
as
to
marry
this
man
,
he
might
justify
his
conduct
and
declare
that
no
cause
existed
for
his
separating
himself
from
her
.
  
<EOS>
He
wanted
to
believe
her
incapable
of
such
a
marriage
;
he
wanted
to
show
that
he
so
believed
of
her
;
but
he
wanted
also
to
be
able
to
say
hereafter
that
she
had
done
nothing
amiss
,
if
she
should
unfortunately
prove
herself
to
be
different
from
what
he
thought
her
to
be
.
  
<EOS>
Nothing
but
affection
could
justify
such
fickleness
,
but
affection
did
justify
it
.
<EOS>
There
was
but
little
of
the
Roman
about
Mr.
Harding
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
sacrifice
his
Lucretia
even
though
she
should
be
polluted
by
the
accepted
addresses
of
the
clerical
Tarquin
at
the
palace
.
<EOS>
If
Tarquin
could
be
prevented
,
well
and
good
,
but
if
not
,
the
father
would
still
open
his
heart
to
his
daughter
and
accept
her
as
she
presented
herself
,
Tarquin
and
all
.
  
<EOS>
Dr.
Grantly
's
mind
was
of
a
stronger
calibre
,
and
he
was
by
no
means
deficient
in
heart
.
<EOS>
He
loved
with
an
honest
genuine
love
his
wife
and
children
and
friends
.
<EOS>
He
loved
his
father
-
in
-
law
,
and
was
quite
prepared
to
love
Eleanor
too
,
if
she
would
be
one
of
his
party
,
if
she
would
be
on
his
side
,
if
she
would
regard
the
Slopes
and
the
Proudies
as
the
enemies
of
mankind
and
acknowledge
and
feel
the
comfortable
merits
of
the
Gwynnes
and
Arabins
.
<EOS>
He
wished
to
be
what
he
called
"
safe
"
with
all
those
whom
he
had
admitted
to
the
penetralia
of
his
house
and
heart
.
<EOS>
He
could
luxuriate
in
no
society
that
was
deficient
in
a
certain
feeling
of
faithful
,
staunch
High
Churchism
,
which
to
him
was
tantamount
to
freemasonry
.
<EOS>
He
was
not
strict
in
his
lines
of
definition
.
<EOS>
He
endured
without
impatience
many
different
shades
of
Anglo
-
church
conservatism
;
but
with
the
Slopes
and
Proudies
he
could
not
go
on
all
fours
.
  
<EOS>
He
was
wanting
in
,
moreover
,
or
perhaps
it
would
be
more
correct
to
say
,
he
was
not
troubled
by
that
womanly
tenderness
which
was
so
peculiar
to
Mr.
Harding
.
<EOS>
His
feelings
towards
his
friends
were
that
while
they
stuck
to
him
,
he
would
stick
to
them
;
that
he
would
work
with
them
shoulder
and
shoulder
;
that
he
would
be
faithful
to
the
faithful
.
<EOS>
He
knew
nothing
of
that
beautiful
love
which
can
be
true
to
a
false
friend
.
  
<EOS>
And
thus
these
two
men
,
each
miserable
enough
in
his
own
way
,
returned
to
Plumstead
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
getting
late
when
they
arrived
there
,
and
the
ladies
had
already
gone
up
to
dress
.
<EOS>
Nothing
more
was
said
as
the
two
parted
in
the
hall
.
<EOS>
As
Mr.
Harding
passed
to
his
own
room
he
knocked
at
Eleanor
's
door
and
handed
in
the
letter
.
<EOS>
The
archdeacon
hurried
to
his
own
territory
,
there
to
unburden
his
heart
to
his
faithful
partner
.
  
<EOS>
What
colloquy
took
place
between
the
marital
chamber
and
the
adjoining
dressing
-
room
shall
not
be
detailed
.
<EOS>
The
reader
,
now
intimate
with
the
persons
concerned
,
can
well
imagine
it
.
<EOS>
The
whole
tenor
of
it
also
might
be
read
in
Mrs.
Grantly
's
brow
as
she
came
down
to
dinner
.
  
<EOS>
Eleanor
,
when
she
received
the
letter
from
her
father
's
hand
,
had
no
idea
from
whom
it
came
.
<EOS>
She
had
never
seen
Mr.
Slope
's
handwriting
,
or
if
so
had
forgotten
it
,
and
did
not
think
of
him
as
she
twisted
the
letter
as
people
do
twist
letters
when
they
do
not
immediately
recognize
their
correspondents
either
by
the
writing
or
the
seal
.
<EOS>
She
was
sitting
at
her
glass
,
brushing
her
hair
and
rising
every
other
minute
to
play
with
her
boy
,
who
was
sprawling
on
the
bed
and
who
engaged
pretty
nearly
the
whole
attention
of
the
maid
as
well
as
of
his
mother
.
  
<EOS>
At
last
,
sitting
before
her
toilet
-
table
,
she
broke
the
seal
and
,
turning
over
the
leaf
,
saw
Mr.
Slope
's
name
.
<EOS>
She
first
felt
surprised
,
and
then
annoyed
,
and
then
anxious
.
<EOS>
As
she
read
it
she
became
interested
.
<EOS>
She
was
so
delighted
to
find
that
all
obstacles
to
her
father
's
return
to
the
hospital
were
apparently
removed
that
she
did
not
observe
the
fulsome
language
in
which
the
tidings
were
conveyed
.
<EOS>
She
merely
perceived
that
she
was
commissioned
to
tell
her
father
that
such
was
the
case
,
and
she
did
not
realize
the
fact
that
such
a
communication
should
not
have
been
made
,
in
the
first
instance
,
to
her
by
an
unmarried
young
clergyman
.
<EOS>
She
felt
,
on
the
whole
,
grateful
to
Mr.
Slope
and
anxious
to
get
on
her
dress
that
she
might
run
with
the
news
to
her
father
.
<EOS>
Then
she
came
to
the
allusion
to
her
own
pious
labours
,
and
she
said
in
her
heart
that
Mr.
Slope
was
an
affected
ass
.
<EOS>
Then
she
went
on
again
and
was
offended
by
her
boy
being
called
Mr.
Slope
's
darling
 
<EOS>
he
was
nobody
's
darling
but
her
own
,
or
at
any
rate
not
the
darling
of
a
disagreeable
stranger
like
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
Lastly
she
arrived
at
the
tresses
and
felt
a
qualm
of
disgust
.
<EOS>
She
looked
up
in
the
glass
,
and
there
they
were
before
her
,
long
and
silken
,
certainly
,
and
very
beautiful
.
<EOS>
I
will
not
say
but
that
she
knew
them
to
be
so
,
but
she
felt
angry
with
them
and
brushed

roughly
and
carelessly
.
<EOS>
She
crumpled
the
letter
up
with
angry

,
and
resolved
,
almost
without
thinking
of
it
,
that
she
would
not

to
her
father
.
<EOS>
She
would
merely
tell
him
the
contents
of

.
<EOS>
She
then
comforted
herself
again
with
her
boy
,
had
her

,
and
went
down
to

.
  
<EOS>
As

she
began
to
ascertain
that
there
was
some
difficulty
in
her
situation
.
<EOS>
She
could
not

her

,
nor

Slope
before

.
<EOS>
Her
father
had
already
gone
down
.
<EOS>
She
had
heard

.
<EOS>
She
resolved
therefore
to
take

her
little

of
news
.
<EOS>
Poor
girl
!
<EOS>
She
had
no
idea
how
severely
the
unfortunate
letter
had
already

discussed
.
  
<EOS>
When

the

,
the

were

,

Mr.
Arabin
,

.
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
Even

Arabin
was
solemn

.
<EOS>
Eleanor
had
not
seen

since

.
<EOS>
He
had
been
the

at
St.
Ewold
's
,
and

,

.
<EOS>
He
did

,
however
,
but
remained

.
<EOS>
They

all

.
<EOS>
Eleanor

.
<EOS>
At

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
With

<EOS>

<EOS>
Mrs.

,

,

.
<EOS>
She

,

.
<EOS>

;

"

.
<EOS>
She

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
They

.
<EOS>
The

<EOS>

He

"
Mr.
Slope
!
"
<EOS>

"
had

.
<EOS>
"
I

,

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
We

<EOS>

<EOS>
He

<EOS>

<EOS>
When

had

,

.
  
<EOS>
Thus

,

<EOS>
So

.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.

,

<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
Mrs.

,

The

.
<EOS>
Perhaps

.
<EOS>
Of

.
<EOS>
But

;

,

,

.
<EOS>
So

,

,

,

,
her

that

.
<EOS>
And

.
  
<EOS>
As

,

.
<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
Their

,

,

.
<EOS>
They

.
<EOS>
Eleanor
had
,

,

,

,

"

.
  
<EOS>
Eleanor

.
<EOS>

"

?
"

<EOS>
"

"
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
She

,

what

<EOS>

,

Mr.

a

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
But

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
He

,

<EOS>
"
In

?
"

.
<EOS>
"
Upon

I

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
We

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

.
<EOS>
That

.
<EOS>
I

Slope
's

,

man

.
<EOS>
He

,

's

.
<EOS>
If

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
,

,

,
"
and

,
"

is

,
and

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Eleanor
's

flashed

as

answered

,

as

.
<EOS>
"
You
may

that

.
<EOS>
And

,
"
if
Dr.

used

of

,

,
"
and

.
<EOS>
"
When
Papa
comes

-

I

.
<EOS>
I

's

,

.
"
<EOS>
And

,
she

to

.
  
<EOS>
She
had
no
conception
of
the

with

she
was

.
<EOS>
The

she
could
be
thought

to

Slope
as

lover
had
never

upon

.
<EOS>
She
conceived
that
they
were
all

and

in
their

of

,
and
therefore
she
would
not

the

,
even
though
she
greatly

the
man
.
  
<EOS>
Eleanor
was
very
angry
as
she
seated

in

her

at

's

.
"
<EOS>
To
dare
to

I
have

,
"
she

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
How
Papa
can

up

that
man
's

!
<EOS>
I
will

down

dinner

his

he

.
"
<EOS>
And
then
a
thought
struck
her
that
Mr.
Arabin
might
perchance
hear
of
her
"
disgraceful
"
correspondence
with
Mr.
Slope
,
and
she
turned
crimson
with
pure
vexation
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
if
she
had
known
the
truth
!
<EOS>
If
she
could
have
conceived
that
Mr.
Arabin
had
been
informed

fact
that

Mr.
Slope
!
  
<EOS>
She
had
not
