long
in
her
room
before
her
father
joined
her
.
<EOS>
As
he
left
the
drawing
-
room
Mrs.
Grantly
took
her
husband
into
the
recess
of
the

and
told

how
signally
she
had
failed
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
speak
to

before

to
bed
,
"
said

archdeacon
.
  
<EOS>
"
Pray

no

,
"
said

;
"
you
can
do
no

and
will

in

.
<EOS>
You
have
no

.
"
  
<EOS>
The
archdeacon
declared
that
as
to
that
he
was
quite
indifferent
.
<EOS>
He
knew
his
duty
and
would
do

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
was
weak

.
<EOS>
He
would
not

it
hereafter
on

that
he

that

.
<EOS>
It

that

angrily
would

and
render

,

.
<EOS>
He
was
angry
,
self

,
and

.
<EOS>
The

a

of

had
received
a
letter
from
Mr.
Slope
had
wounded
his
pride
in
the
sorest
place
,
and
nothing
could
control

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
looked
worn
and
woe
-

as

entered

daughter
's
room
.
<EOS>
These

.
<EOS>
He
felt
that

continued
,
he
must
go

the

in

.
<EOS>
He

daughter
's

,

and

.
  
<EOS>
Eleanor
's

was

,
not

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
Papa
,
"

"

.
<EOS>
They

downstairs

-
night
 
<EOS>
do

have
,
Papa
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding

that
the

had
been

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

Dr.
Grantly
soon
 
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
my
dear
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
shall
.
<EOS>
I
can

.
<EOS>
He
is

,

,

:
<EOS>
and

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
There

Slope

.
<EOS>
It

<EOS>
There

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
It

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
And

Susan

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
took
his
arm
from
his
daughter
's

and

read

.
<EOS>
She
expected

but

,

<EOS>
His

.
<EOS>
He

been

,
but

to
Mr.

's

.
<EOS>
Then

's

;
it

unctuous
,

,

,
like
the
man
.
<EOS>
He

,

had
failed

,
that

.
<EOS>
The

to
Eleanor
's

as

grated

against
his

as
a

.
<EOS>
And

,

to
the
"
darling
boy
"
and

"

,
"

.
<EOS>
It
was
impossible

Mr.
Slope
should
so

unless

.
<EOS>
It

impossible
Eleanor
should

,

,
unless

.
<EOS>
So

Mr.
Harding
argued
to

.
  
<EOS>
How
hard

is
to
judge

of

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
,
as

came
to
the

,
in

condemned
his
daughter
for

,

.
<EOS>
She
was
not
responsible
for
what
Mr.
Slope
might
write
.
<EOS>
True
.
<EOS>
But
then
she
expressed
no
disgust
at

.
<EOS>
She
had
rather
expressed
approval
of
the
letter
as
a
whole
.
<EOS>
She
had
given
it
to
him
to
read
,
as
a

for
herself
and
also
for
him
.
<EOS>
The
father
's
spirits
sank
within
him
as
he
felt
that
he
could
not
acquit
her
.
  
<EOS>
And
yet
it
was
the
true
feminine
delicacy
of
Eleanor
's
mind
which
brought
on
her
this
condemnation
.
<EOS>
Listen
to
me
,
ladies
,
and
I
beseech
you
to
acquit
her
.
<EOS>
She
thought
of
this
man
,
this
lover
of
whom
she
was
so
unconscious
,
exactly
as
her
father
did
,
exactly

the
Grantlys
did
.
<EOS>
At
least
she
esteemed

personally

they
did
.
<EOS>
But
she
believed
him
to
be
in
the
main
an

man
,
and
one

inclined
to

.
<EOS>
She
felt
herself
bound
,
after
what
had
passed
,
to
show
this

to
Mr.
Harding
.
<EOS>
She
thought
it
necessary
that
he
should
know
what
Mr.
Slope
had
to
say
.
<EOS>
But
she
did
not
think

to
apologize
for
,
or

,
or

to

of
the
man
's

,
which
arose
,
as

,
from

.
<EOS>
It
was
nauseous
to
her
to
have
a
man
like
Mr.
Slope
commenting
on
her

attractions
,
and
she
did
not

it
necessary
to
dilate
with
her
father
upon
what
was
nauseous
.
<EOS>
She
never
supposed
they
could
disagree
on
such

subject
.
<EOS>
It
would
have
been
painful
for
her
to
point

,
painful

her
to
speak
strongly
against
a
man
of
whom
,
on
the
whole
,
she
was
anxious
to
think
and

.
<EOS>
In
encountering
such
a
man
she
had
encountered
what
was
disagreeable
,
as
she
might
do
in

.
<EOS>
But
in
such
encounters
she
never
thought

necessary

dwell

.
  
<EOS>
And
he
,
foolish
,
weak
,

,
would
not

,
though
one

would
have
cleared

.
<EOS>
There

been

,
and
in

everyone
in
the
house
would
have
understood
how

really
were
.
<EOS>
The
father
would
have
been
delighted
.
<EOS>
The
sister
would
have
kissed
her
sister
and
begged
a

pardons
.
<EOS>
The
archdeacon
would
have
apologized
and
wondered
,
and
raised

,
and
gone
to
bed
a
happy
man
.
<EOS>
And
Mr.
Arabin
 
Mr.
Arabin
would
have
dreamt
of
Eleanor
,
have
awoke
in
the
morning
with
ideas

love
,
and
retired

.
<EOS>
But
,
alas
,
all

was
not

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
slowly
folded
the
letter
,
handed

to

,
kissed
her

,
and
bade
God

.
<EOS>
He
then

slowly
away
to
his
own
room
.
  
<EOS>
As
soon

he
had
left
the
passage
,
another

's

,
and
<EOS>
Mrs.
Grantly
's
very
demure
own
maid
,

,
wanted

Mrs.
Bold

,

.
<EOS>
The

's

,

.
  
<EOS>
Eleanor
thought

very

;
she

;
her

anything

.
<EOS>
She
was
,

,
no

,
and
therefore

in

.
<EOS>
So
she
arranged
her

,
tied
on
her
cap
,
and
went
down
with
a

.
   
<EOS>
A
Serious
Interview
 
<EOS>
There
are
people
who
delight
in
serious
interviews
,
especially
when
to
them
appertains
the
part
of
offering
advice
or
administering
rebuke
,
and
perhaps
the
archdeacon
was
one
of
these
.
<EOS>
Yet
on
this
occasion
he
did
not
prepare
himself
for
the
coming
conversation
with
much
anticipation
of
pleasure
.
<EOS>
Whatever
might
be
his
faults
he
was
not
an
inhospitable
man
,
and
he
almost
felt
that
he
was
sinning
against
hospitality
in
upbraiding
Eleanor
in
his
own
house
.
<EOS>
Then
,
also
,
he
was
not
quite
sure
that
he
would
get
the
best
of
it
.
<EOS>
His
wife
had
told
him
that
he
decidedly
would
not
,
and
he
usually
gave
credit
to
what
his
wife
said
.
<EOS>
He
was
,
however
,
so
convinced
of
what
he
considered
to
be
the
impropriety
of
Eleanor
's
conduct
,
and
so
assured
also
of
his
own
duty
in
trying
to
check
it
,
that
his
conscience
would
not
allow
him
to
take
his
wife
's
advice
and
go
to
bed
quietly
.
  
<EOS>
Eleanor
's
face
as
she
entered
the
room
was
not
such
as
to
reassure
him
.
<EOS>
As
a
rule
she
was
always
mild
in
manner
and
gentle
in
conduct
;
but
there
was
that
in
her
eye
which
made
it
not
an
easy
task
to
scold
her
.
<EOS>
In
truth
she
had
been
little
used
to
scolding
.
<EOS>
No
one
since
her
childhood
had
tried
it
but
the
archdeacon
,
and
he
had
generally
failed
when
he
did
try
it
.
<EOS>
He
had
never
done
so
since
her
marriage
;
and
now
,
when
he
saw
her
quiet
,
easy
step
as
she
entered
his
room
,
he
almost
wished
that
he
had
taken
his
wife
's
advice
.
  
<EOS>
He
began
by
apologizing
for
the
trouble
he
was
giving
her
.
<EOS>
She
begged
him
not
to
mention
it
,
assured
him
that
walking
downstairs
was
no
trouble
to
her
at
all
,
and
then
took
a
seat
and
waited
patiently
for
him
to
begin
his
attack
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Eleanor
,
"
he
said
,
"
I
hope
you
believe
me
when
I
assure
you
that
you
have
no
sincerer
friend
than
I
am
.
"
<EOS>
To
this
Eleanor
answered
nothing
,
and
therefore
he
proceeded
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
had
a
brother
of
your
own
,
I
should
not
probably
trouble
you
with
what
I
am
going
to
say
.
<EOS>
But
as
it
is
I
can
not
but
think
that
it
must
be
a
comfort
to
you
to
know
that
you
have
near
you
one
who
is
as
anxious
for
your
welfare
as
any
brother
of
your
own
could
be
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
never
had
a
brother
,
"
said
she
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
you
never
had
,
and
it
is
therefore
that
I
speak
to
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
never
had
a
brother
,
"
she
repeated
,
"
but
I
have
hardly
felt
the
want
.
<EOS>
Papa
has
been
to
me
both
father
and
brother
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Your
father
is
the
fondest
and
most
affectionate
of
men
.
<EOS>
But
 
"
  
"
He
is
 
the
fondest
and
most
affectionate
of
men
,
and
the
best
of
counsellors
.
<EOS>
While
he
lives
I
can
never
want
advice
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
This
rather
put
the
archdeacon
out
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
exactly
contradict
what
his
sister
-
in
-
law
said
about
her
father
,
and
yet
he
did
not
at
all
agree
with
her
.
<EOS>
He
wanted
her
to
understand
that
he
tendered
his
assistance
because
her
father
was
a
soft
,
good
-
natured
gentleman
not
sufficiently
knowing
in
the
ways
of
the
world
;
but
he
could
not
say
this
to
her
.
<EOS>
So
he
had
to
rush
into
the
subject
-
matter
of
his
proffered
counsel
without
any
acknowledgement
on
her
part
that
she
could
need
it
,
or
would
be
grateful
for
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
Susan
tells
me
that
you
received
a
letter
this
evening
from
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
Papa
brought
it
in
the
brougham
.
<EOS>
Did
he
not
tell
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
Susan
says
that
you
objected
to

her
know
what
it
was
about
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't

she
asked
me
.
<EOS>
But
had
she
done
so
,
I
should
not

.
<EOS>
I
do

to

's

.
<EOS>
If

show

,

does

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
True
.
<EOS>
Quite

.
<EOS>
What

.
<EOS>
But

,

some
 
some

<EOS>
some

<EOS>
"
  
"
Suspicion
!
"
<EOS>
said

,
not

,
speaking

<EOS>
"
Suspicion
!
<EOS>
And

,

?
"
<EOS>
And

,
for
the
archdeacon
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>

"

.
  
<EOS>
This

an

which

,

rather

in

.
<EOS>
However
,

,

,

then

,

under

.
<EOS>
To

appeared

be
in

the
letter

declared

;

;

's

.
<EOS>
He

,

on

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll

to

,
if

please
,
Dr.
Grantly
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
took

in

held

up
,
but

.
"
<EOS>
And

Harding
has

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

;
"
it

.
<EOS>
It

to
his
business
 
of
course

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Quite
a
proper
letter
,
"
said

,
speaking
,
perhaps
,
a

out

,
probably

the
objectionable

of

.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
,
Eleanor
,
it
is
my
duty
to
tell

that
I
wholly

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
So
I
suppose
,
"
said
she
,
instigated

and

.
<EOS>
"
You
think
Mr.
Slope
is
a

.
<EOS>
I

he

,

.
<EOS>
It

we

.
<EOS>
But
,

we
do
differ
,
we

probably

not

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Here
Eleanor
undoubtedly
put
herself
in
the
wrong
.
<EOS>
She
might
probably
have
refused
to
talk
to
Dr.
Grantly
on
the
matter
in
dispute
without
any

,
but
,
having
consented
to
listen
to
him
,
she
had
no
business
to
tell
him
that
he
regarded
Mr.
Slope
as

emissary
from
the
evil

;
nor
was

justified
in
praising
Mr.
Slope
,
seeing
that
in
her
heart
of
hearts
she
did
not
think

.
<EOS>
She
was
,
however
,
wounded
in
spirit
,
and
angry
,
and

.
<EOS>
She
had
been
subjected
to
contumely
and
cross
-
questioning
and
ill
-
usage
through
the
whole

.
<EOS>
No

,
not

Mr.
Arabin
,
not

,
had

.
<EOS>
All

she
attributed
to
the
prejudice
and

of
the
archdeacon
,
and
therefore
she
resolved
to
set
no

to
her
antagonism
to
him
.
<EOS>
She
would
neither
give
nor
take

.
<EOS>
He
had
greatly
presumed
in
daring
to
question
her
about
her
correspondence
,
and
she
was
determined
to
show
that
she

.
  
<EOS>
"
Eleanor
,
you
are

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Otherwise
you
would
never

I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

,

;
"
and

.
"
<EOS>
He

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

,

his
,

,

.
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

night
 
I

very

.
"
  
<EOS>
Dr.
Grantly
had
,

thought
,

best
to

-

law
.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
But

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
You

<EOS>
Susan

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
he

.
<EOS>

"
  
"
You

Arabin

!
"
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Eleanor
,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Agrees

?
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
I

.
"
  
<EOS>
"

that

as
Mrs.
Slope
.
"
  
<EOS>
Not
being
favourites
with
the
tragic

,
we
do
not

any
description
of
Eleanor
's

when

of
Mrs.
Slope
pronounced
as
that
which
would
or
should
or
might

some

to
herself
.
<EOS>
The
look
,
such
as
it
was
,
Dr.
Grantly
did
not
soon
forget
.
<EOS>
For
a
moment
or
two
she
could
find
no
words
to
express
her
deep
anger
and
deep
disgust
;
indeed
,
at
this
conjuncture
,
words
did
not
come
to

very
freely
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
dare
you
be
so
impertinent
?
<EOS>
"
at
last
she
said
,
and
then
she
hurried
out
of
the
room
without
giving
the
archdeacon
the
opportunity
of
uttering
another
word
.
<EOS>
It
was
with
difficulty
she
contained
herself
till
she
reached
her
own
room
;
and
then
,
locking
the
door
,
she
threw
herself
on
her
bed
and
sobbed
as
though
her
heart
would
break
.
  
<EOS>
But
even
yet
she
had
no
conception
of
the
truth
.
<EOS>
She
had
no
idea
that
her
father
and
her
sister
had
for
days
past
conceived
in
sober
earnest
the
idea
that
she
was
going
to
marry
this
man
.
<EOS>
She
did
not
even
then
believe
that
the
archdeacon
thought
that
she
would
do
so
.
<EOS>
By
some
manoeuvre
of
her
brain
she
attributed
the
origin
of
the
accusation
to
Mr.
Arabin
,
and
as
she
did
so
her
anger
against
him
was
excessive
,
and
the
vexation
of
her
spirit
almost
unendurable
.
<EOS>
She
could
not
bring
herself
to
think
that
the
charge
was
made
seriously
.
<EOS>
It
appeared
to
her
most
probable
that
the
archdeacon
and
Mr.
Arabin
had
talked
over
her
objectionable
acquaintance
with
Mr.
Slope
;
that
Mr.
Arabin
in
his
jeering
,
sarcastic
way
had
suggested
the
odious
match
as
being
the
severest
way
of
treating
with
contumely
her
acquaintance
with
his
enemy
;
and
that
the
archdeacon
,
taking
the
idea
from
him
,
thought
proper
to
punish
her
by
the
allusion
.
<EOS>
The
whole
night
she
lay
awake
thinking
of
what
had
been
said
,
and
this
appeared
to
be
the
most
probable
solution
.
  
<EOS>
But
the
reflexion
that
Mr.
Arabin
should
have
in
any
way
mentioned
her
name
in
connexion
with
that
of
Mr.
Slope
was
overpowering
;
and
the
spiteful
ill
-
nature
of
the
archdeacon
in
repeating
the
charge
to
her
made
her
wish
to
leave
his
house
almost
before
the
day
had
broken
.
<EOS>
One
thing
was
certain
:
nothing
should
make
her
stay
there
beyond
the
following
morning
,
and
nothing
should
make
her
sit
down
to
breakfast
in
company
with
Dr.
Grantly
.
<EOS>
When
she
thought
of
the
man
whose
name
had
been
linked
with
her
own
,
she
cried
from
sheer
disgust
.
<EOS>
It
was
only
because
she
would
be
thus
disgusted
,
thus
pained
and
shocked
and
cut
to
the
quick
,
that
the
archdeacon
had
spoken
the
horrid
word
.
<EOS>
He
wanted
to
make
her
quarrel
with
Mr.
Slope
,
and
therefore
he
had
outraged
her
by
his
abominable
vulgarity
.
<EOS>
She
determined
that
at
any
rate
he
should
know
that
she
appreciated
it
.
  
<EOS>
Nor
was
the
archdeacon
a
bit
better
satisfied
with
the
result
of
his
serious
interview
than
was
Eleanor
.
<EOS>
He
gathered
from
it
,
as
indeed
he
could
hardly
fail
to
do
,
that
she
was
very
angry
with
him
,
but
he
thought
that
she
was
thus
angry
,
not
because
she
was
suspected
of
an
intention
to
marry
Mr.
Slope
,
but
because
such
an
intention
was
imputed
to
her
as
a
crime
.
<EOS>
Dr.
Grantly
regarded
this
supposed
union
with
disgust
,
but
it
never
occurred
to
him
that
Eleanor
was
outraged
because
she
looked
at
it
exactly
in
the
same
light
.
  
<EOS>
He
returned
to
his
wife
,
vexed
and
somewhat
disconsolate
,
but
nevertheless
confirmed
in
his
wrath
against
his
sister
-

law
.
"
<EOS>
Her

,
"

,
"
has

.
<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>

"

"
<EOS>

<EOS>
Another
Love
Scene
 
<EOS>

And

In

.
<EOS>

And

<EOS>
Eleanor
had
not

.
<EOS>
She

,

.
<EOS>
She

,

<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>
He

,

,

Mr.
Slope
's
name
.
<EOS>
There
was
yet
a
chance
that
they
were
all
wrong
in
their
surmise
,
and
being
thus
in
doubt
,
he
could
not
bring
himself
to
speak
openly
to
her
on
the
subject
.
  
<EOS>
He
was
sitting
with
her
in
the
drawing
-
room
,
with
his
arm
round
her
waist
,
saying
every
now
<EOS>
and
then
some
little
soft
words
of
affection
and
working
hard
with
his
imaginary
fiddle
-
bow
,
when
Mr.
Arabin
entered
the
room
.
<EOS>
He
immediately
got
up
,
and
the
two
made
some
trite
remarks
to
each
other
,
neither
thinking
of
what
he
was
saying
,
while
Eleanor
kept
her
seat
on
the
sofa
,
mute
and
moody
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
was
included
in
the
list
of
those
against
whom
her
anger
was
excited
.
<EOS>
He
,
too
,
had
dared
to
talk
about
her
acquaintance
with
Mr.
Slope
;
he
,
too
,
had
dared
to
blame
her
for
not
making
an
enemy
of
his
enemy
.
<EOS>
She
had
not
intended
to
see
him
before
her
departure
,
and
was
now
but
little
inclined
to
be
gracious
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
a
feeling
through
the
whole
house
that
something
was
wrong
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
,
when
he
saw
Eleanor
,
could
not
succeed
in
looking
or
in
speaking
as
though
he
knew
nothing
of
all
this
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
be
cheerful
and
positive
and
contradictory
with
her
,
as
was
his
wo
nt
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
been
two
minutes
in
the
room
before
he
felt
that
he
had
done
wrong
to
return
;
and
the
moment
he
heard
her
voice
,
he
thoroughly
wished
himself
back
at
St.
Ewold
's
.
<EOS>
Why
,
indeed
,
should
he
have
wished
to
have
aught
further
to
say
to
the
future
wife
of
Mr.
Slope
?
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
to
hear
that
you
are
to
leave
us
so
soon
,
"
said
he
,
striving
in
vain
to
use
his
ordinary
voice
.
<EOS>
In
answer
to
this
she
muttered
something
about
the
necessity
of
her
being
in
Barchester
,
and
betook
herself
most
industriously
to
her
crochet
work
.
  
<EOS>
Then
there
was
a
little
more
trite
conversation
between
Mr.
Arabin
and
Mr.
Harding
 
trite
,
and
hard
,
and
vapid
,
and
senseless
.
<EOS>
Neither
of
them
had
anything
to
say
to
the
other
,
and
yet
neither
at
such
a
moment
liked
to
remain
silent
.
<EOS>
At
last
Mr.
Harding
,
taking
advantage
of
a
pause
,
escaped
out
of
the
room
,
and
Eleanor
and
Mr.
Arabin
were
left
together
.
  
<EOS>
"
Your
going
will
be
a
great
break
-
up
to
our
party
,
"
said
he
.
  
<EOS>
She
again
muttered
something
which
was
all
but
inaudible
,
but
kept
her
eyes
fixed
upon
her
work
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
have
had
a
very
pleasant
month
here
,
"
said
he
;
"
at
least
I
have
;
and
I
am
sorry
it
should
be
so
soon
over
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
already
been
from
home
longer
than
I
intended
,
"
said
she
,
"
and
it
is
time
that
I
should
return
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
pleasant
hours
and
pleasant
days
must
come
to
an
end
.
<EOS>
It
is
a
pity
that
so
few
of
them
are
pleasant
;
or
perhaps
,
rather
 
"
  
"
It
is
a
pity
,
certainly
,
that
men
and
women
do
so
much
to
destroy
the
pleasantness
of
their
days
,
"
said
she
,
interrupting
him
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
pity
that
there
should
be
so
little
charity
abroad
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Charity
should
begin
at
home
,
"
said
he
,
and
he
was
proceeding
to
explain
that
he
as
a
clergyman
could
not
be
what
she
would
call
charitable
at
the
expense
of
those
principles
<EOS>
which
he
considered
it
his
duty
to
teach
,
when
he
remembered
that
it
would
be
worse
than
vain
to
argue
on
such

matter
with
the
future
wife
of
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
"
But
you
are
just
leaving
us
,
"
he
continued
,
"
and
I
will
not
weary
your
last
hour
with
another
lecture
.
<EOS>
As
it
is
,
I
fear
I
have
given
you
too
many
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
should
practise
as
well
as
preach
,
Mr.
Arabin
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Undoubtedly
I
should
.
<EOS>
So
should
we
all
.
<EOS>
All
of
us
who
presume
to
teach
are
bound
to
do
our
utmost
towards
fulfilling
our
own

.
<EOS>
I
thoroughly
allow
my
deficiency
in
doing
so
,
but
I
do
not
quite
know
now
to
what
you
allude
.
<EOS>
Have
you
any
special
reason
for
telling
me
now
that
I
should
practise
as
well
as
preach
?
"
  
<EOS>
Eleanor
made
no
answer
.
<EOS>
She
longed
to
let
him
know
the
cause
of
her
anger
,
to
upbraid
him
for
speaking
of
her
disrespectfully
,
and
then
at
last
to
forgive
him
,
and
so
part
friends
.
<EOS>
She
felt
that
she
would
be
unhappy
to
leave
him
in
her
present
frame
of
mind
,
but
yet
she
could
hardly
bring
herself
to
speak
to
him
of
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
And
how
could
she
allude
to
the
innuendo
thrown
out
by
the
archdeacon
,
and
thrown
out
,
as
she
believed
,
at
the
instigation
of
Mr.
Arabin
?
<EOS>
She
wanted
to
make
him
know
that
he
was
wrong
,
to
make
him
aware
that
he
had
ill
-
treated
her
,
in
order
that
the
sweetness
of
her
forgiveness
might
be
enhanced
.
<EOS>
She
felt
that
she
liked
him
too
well
to
be
contented
to
part
with
him
in
displeasure
,
yet
she
could
not
get
over
her
deep
displeasure
without
some
explanation
,
some
acknowledgement
on
his
part
,
some
assurance
that
he
would
never
again
so
sin
against
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
do
you
tell
me
that
I
should
practise
what
I
preach
?
<EOS>
"
continued
he
.
  
<EOS>
"
All
men
should
do

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Certainly
.
<EOS>
That
is
as
it
were
understood
and
acknowledged
.
<EOS>
But
you
do
not
say
so
to
all
men
,
or
to
all
clergymen
.
<EOS>
The
advice
,
good
as
it
is
,
is
not
given
except
in
allusion
to
some
special
deficiency
.
<EOS>
If
you
will
tell
me
my
special
deficiency
,
I
will
endeavour
to
profit
by
the
advice
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
paused
for
awhile
and
then
,
looking
full
in
his
face
,
she
said
,
"
You
are
not
bold
enough
,
Mr.
Arabin
,
to
speak

me
openly
and
plainly
,
and
yet
you
expect
me
,
a
woman
,
to

openly
to
you
.
<EOS>
Why
did
you
speak
calumny
of
me
to
Dr.
Grantly
behind

back
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Calumny
!
"
said
he
,
and
his
whole
face
became

with
blood
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
calumny
?
<EOS>
If
I
have
spoken
calumny
of
you
,
I
will
beg
your
pardon
,
and
his
to
whom
I
spoke

,
and
God
's

also
.
<EOS>
But
what
calumny
have
I
spoken
of
you
to
Dr.
Grantly
?
"
  
<EOS>
She
also
blushed
deeply
.
<EOS>
She
could
not
bring
herself
to
ask
him
whether
he
had
not
spoken
of
her
as
another
man
's
wife
.
<EOS>
"
You
know
that
best
yourself
,
"
said
she
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
I
ask
you
as
a
man

,
if
you
have
not
spoken
of
me
as
you
would
not
have
spoken
of
your
own
sister
 
or
<EOS>
rather
I
will
not
ask
you
,
"
she
continued
,
finding
that
he
did
not
immediately
answer

.
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
put
you
to
the
necessity
of
answering
such

question
.
<EOS>
Dr.
Grantly
has
told

you

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Dr.
Grantly
certainly
asked
me
for
my
advice
,
and
I
gave

.
<EOS>
He
asked
me
 
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
he
did
,
Mr.
Arabin
.
<EOS>
He
asked
you
whether
he
would

to

if
I
continued

with
a
gentleman
who
happens

to

and

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
mistaken
,
Mrs.
Bold
.
<EOS>
I
have
no
personal
knowledge
of
Mr.
Slope
;
I
never

in

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
not
the
less

to

.
<EOS>
It

not
for

to
question
the

of
your

,
but
I
had

expect

my

should
not

.
<EOS>
This
has
been
done
,
and
been

you
in
a

the
most
injurious
and
the
most
distressing
to

as

woman
.
<EOS>
I
must
confess
,
Mr.
Arabin
,
that
from
you
I
expected
a
different
sort
of
usage
.
"
  
<EOS>
As
she
spoke
she
with
difficulty
restrained
her
tears
 
<EOS>
but
she
did
restrain
them
.
<EOS>
Had
she
given
way
and
sobbed
aloud
,
as
in
such
cases
a
woman
should
do
,
he
would
have
melted
at
once
,
implored
her
pardon
,
perhaps
knelt
at
her
feet
and
declared
his
love
.
<EOS>
Everything
would
have
been
explained
,
and
Eleanor
would
have
gone
back
to
Barchester
with
a
contented
mind
.
<EOS>
How
easily
would
she

forgiven
and

's
suspicions
had
she
but
heard
the
whole
truth
from
Mr.
Arabin
.
<EOS>
But
then
where
would
have
been
my
novel
?
<EOS>
She
did
not
cry
,
and
Mr.
Arabin
did
not
melt
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
do
me
an
injustice
,
"
said
he
.
<EOS>
"
My
advice
was
asked
by
Dr.
Grantly
,
and
I
was

to
give
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Dr.
Grantly
has
been
most
officious
,
most

.
<EOS>
I
have
as
complete
a
right
to
form
my

as
he
has
to

.
<EOS>
What
would

had
I

you
as

the

of
my
banishing
Dr.
Grantly
from

because

Lord
Tattenham
Corner
?
<EOS>
I

Lord
Tattenham
is

as

an

for

as
Mr.
Slope
is

's
daughter
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
know
Lord
Tattenham
Corner
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
but
Dr.
Grantly
does
.
<EOS>
It
is
nothing
to
me
if
he
knows
all
the
young
lords
on
every
race
-
course
in
England
.
<EOS>
I
shall
not
interfere
with
him
,
nor

with

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
to
differ
with
you
,
Mrs.
Bold
,
but
as
you
have
spoken
to
me
on
this
matter
,
and
especially
as
you
blame
me
for
what
little
I
said
on
the
subject
,
I
must
tell
you
that
I
do
differ
from
you
.
<EOS>
Dr.
Grantly
's
position
as
a
man
in
the
world
gives
him
a
right
to
choose
his
own
acquaintances
,
subject
to
certain

.
<EOS>
If
he
chooses
them
badly
,
those

will

used
.
<EOS>
If
he
consorts
with

,
his

.
<EOS>
What
the
bishop
is
to

Grantly
,
Dr.
Grantly
is
to

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
deny
it
.
<EOS>
I
utterly
deny
it
,
"
said
Eleanor
,
jumping
from
her
seat
and
literally
flashing
before
Mr.
Arabin
,
as
she
stood
on
the
drawing
-
room
floor
.
<EOS>
He
had
never
seen
her
so
excited
<EOS>
,
he
had
never
seen
her
look
half
so
beautiful
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
utterly
deny
it
,
"
said
she
.
"
<EOS>
Dr.
Grantly
has
no
sort
of
jurisdiction
over

whatsoever
.
<EOS>
Do
you
and
he
forget
that
I
am
not

alone

the
world
?
<EOS>
Do
you
forget
that
I
have
a
father
?
<EOS>
Dr.
Grantly
,
I
believe
,
always
has
forgotten
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
From
you
,
Mr.
Arabin
,
"
she
continued
,
"
I
would
have
listened
to
advice
because
I
should
have
expected

to
have
been
given
as
one
friend
may
advise
another
 
not
as
a

gives
an

.
<EOS>
I
might
have
differed
from
you
 
on
this
matter
<EOS>
I
should
have
done
so
 
but
had
you
spoken
to
me
in
your
usual
manner
and

your
usual

,
I
should
not

.
<EOS>
But
now
 
was

manly

you
,
Mr.
Arabin
,
to

in

<EOS>
so

<EOS>
so
 
?
<EOS>
I
can
not

to

.
<EOS>
You
must

feel
.
<EOS>
Was

to

's

because
I
chose

man

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
no

left
to

,
Mrs.
Bold
,
"
said

,
standing

,

,
and
speaking

slow

measured

,
"
but
to

what
did

Grantly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
said
she
,
finding
that

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am

that
what
I
may
say
may
pain

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
can
not
well
do
so
more
than

you

already
done
,
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
"
Dr.
Grantly

would

prudent
for
him
to
receive
you
in

as

,

I

that
I
thought

be
imprudent
.
<EOS>
Believing
it
to
be

that
Mr.
Slope
and
 
"
  
"
Thank
you
,
Mr.
Arabin
,
that
is
sufficient
.
<EOS>
I
do
not

know
your
reasons
,
"

,
speaking
with

voice
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
shown
to
this

commonplace

;

because

<EOS>
so
 
no

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
As

,

walked
to
the
drawing

room
window
and
stepped

the

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
was
left
in
the

,
still

in

the
pattern

.
<EOS>
He
had
,
however
,
distinctly
heard
and
accurately
marked
every

that
she

spoken
.
<EOS>
Was
it
not
clear
from
what
she
had
said
that
the

wrong
in

to

Slope
?
<EOS>
Was

not

Eleanor
was
still

?
<EOS>
It
may

,

.
<EOS>
She
had
not

;

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
understood
little
of

's

,
or

known

.
<EOS>
Few

's

,

.
<EOS>
And
it
is
well
that

,

men

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
stood

,

,

,
at

.
<EOS>
As

he

be

that
he
was
himself
in

.
<EOS>
Forty

had
passed
over
his

,
and
as
yet
woman
's
beauty
had
never
given
him
an

.
<EOS>
His
present
hour
was
very
uneasy
.
  
<EOS>
Not
that
he
remained
there
for
half

a

.
<EOS>
In

what
Eleanor

said
,
Mr.
Arabin
was

,

.
<EOS>
Having

that
he

this
woman
,
and

she

to

,

,

into

to

such

as

.
  
<EOS>
He
was
not
long
in

.
<EOS>
She
was

to

fro
beneath
the

of
elms
that

in
the

's

,

.
<EOS>
What

between

had
not
,

.
<EOS>
She
was
very
angry
 
more
angry
with

than

.
<EOS>
How
could
he
have
so
misunderstood
her
?
<EOS>
She
had
been
so

with

,
had
allowed

such

,

,

,

!
<EOS>
She

,

been

<EOS>
he
had
regarded

as

.
  
<EOS>
As

sward
with
very
spite

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
was
very
near
to

,
and

,

<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
He

.
  
<EOS>
He
had
not

he

;

.
<EOS>
He

,

that

.
<EOS>
And
yet

not

by

.
<EOS>
He
had

no

.
<EOS>
He
had
not

,

,

.
<EOS>
He
could
not

.
<EOS>
He

and

to

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
There

,
"

;
"
I

.
<EOS>
It

,

.
<EOS>
People

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
And

<EOS>
I

;

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thought

!
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
In

"
<EOS>
He

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

!
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Speak

!
<EOS>
Insult

!
<EOS>
Wilfully

!
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Calumny
!
<EOS>
Ah
me
!
"
<EOS>
Twere

that

.
<EOS>
Better

;
sinful

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
me
!
"

"
<EOS>
Ah

!
<EOS>
These

and

<EOS>

<EOS>
A

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

,

?
"
  
"
Yes
 
yes
,

;
"
Lead

not

but

.
"
<EOS>
But

?
<EOS>
What
is

?
<EOS>
Is
this
evil
 
<EOS>
is
this
temptation
?
"
  
<EOS>
Poor
Mr.
Arabin
!
<EOS>
It
would
not
come
out
of
him
,
that
deep
,
true
love
of
his
.
<EOS>
He
could
not

to

.
<EOS>
He

"
Since

,

,

?
<EOS>
"
These

which
were
in

,
but
with

he
could
not

to

.
<EOS>
He
would

given
anything
,
everything
for

to

,
but
glib
as
was
his

in

,
now

not

a

plain

his
heart
.
  
<EOS>
And
yet
Eleanor
understood
him
as

as
though
he
had
declared
his

with

.
<EOS>
With
a
woman
's

,
she
followed
every

mind
as

spoke
of
the

of
Plumstead
and

Oxford
,

he

the

of

and

.
<EOS>
She
knew
that
it
all
meant
love
.
<EOS>
She

that
this
man
at

,
this

,
this

,

,

to

that

was
no

.
  
<EOS>
She
knew

,
and
felt

sort

joy
in

;
yet
she
would
not

.
<EOS>
He
had

,
had

,
the

that
he

,
and
Eleanor

.
<EOS>
She

not

whether

no

.
<EOS>
She
did
not
even

to

that
she
now

with

.
<EOS>
At

present

it
did
not

her

;
it
merely

her

and
flattered

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
had
dared
to
associate
her
name
with
that
of
Mr.
Slope
,
and
now
her
spirit
was
soothed
by
finding
that
he
would
fain
associate

with
his
own
.
<EOS>
And
so
she
walked
on

him
,
inhaling

but
giving
out
no
sweetness
in
return
.
  
<EOS>
"
Answer
me
this
,
"
said
Mr.
Arabin
,

that

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Answer
me
this

.
<EOS>
You
do

Mr.
Slope
?
<EOS>
You
do

his
wife
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
certainly
did
not
go
the
right

to
win
such
a
woman
as
Eleanor
Bold
.
<EOS>
Just

her

was

,
as

the
true

of
his

.
<EOS>
Had

was

,
he

never

Mr.
Slope
's

before
Eleanor
Bold
,
till
he
had
made

.
<EOS>
Then
,

not
till

,
he
might
have
talked
of
Mr.
Slope
with

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
answer
no
such

,
"
said

;
"
and
what

more
,
I

that
nothing

.
<EOS>
Good

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
And

,
she

the

and
,

through

window
,

her

.
<EOS>
Half
an
hour
afterwards
she
was
in
the

,
and
so
she
left
Plumstead
without
again
seeing
Mr.
Arabin
.
  
<EOS>
His

was
long
and

among
the
sombre
trees
that

.
<EOS>
He
left
the
archdeacon
's
grounds
that
he
might
escape
attention
,
and
sauntered
among
the
green
hillocks
under
which
lay
at
rest
<EOS>
so
many
of
the
once

.
<EOS>
To

Eleanor

last

like
a

never

.
<EOS>
He
could
not

.
<EOS>
He

whether

no

Slope

in

favoured
rival
.
<EOS>
If

,
why

not

?
  
<EOS>
Poor
Mr.
Arabin
 
untaught
,
illiterate
,
boorish
,
ignorant
man
!
<EOS>
That
at
forty
years
of
age
you
should

the

woman
's

!
   
<EOS>
The
Bishop
's
Library
 
<EOS>
And
thus
the
pleasant
party
at
Plumstead
was
broken
up
.
<EOS>
It
had
been
a
very
pleasant
party
as

as
they
had
all
remained
in

with

.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Grantly
had
felt

house
to
be

and

,

passed

.
<EOS>
Within

,

<EOS>
During

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
Mrs.

<EOS>
The

<EOS>

been
done
.
"
  
<EOS>
Just
at
this
period
Mrs.
Grantly
's
carriage
drove
into
the
close
,
and
the
archdeacon
went
down
to
confirm
the
news
which
she
had
heard
before
.
  
<EOS>
By
the
9.15
P.M.
train
Sir
Omicron
Pie
did
arrive
.
<EOS>
And
in
the
course
of
the
night
a
sort
of
consciousness
returned
to
the
poor
old
dean
.
<EOS>
Whether
this
was
due
to
Sir
Omicron
Pie
is
a
question
on
which
it
may
be
well
not
to
offer
an
opinion
.
<EOS>
Dr.
Fillgrave
was
very
clear
in
his
own
mind
,
but
Sir
Omicron
himself
is
thought
to
have
differed
from
that
learned
doctor
.
<EOS>
At
any
rate
Sir
Omicron
expressed
an
opinion
that
the
dean
had
yet
some
days
to
live
.
  
<EOS>
For
the
eight
or
ten
next
days
,
accordingly
,
the
poor
dean
remained
in
the
same
state
,
half
-
conscious
and
half
-
comatose
;
and
the
attendant
clergy
began
to
think
that
no
new
appointment
would
be
necessary
for
some
few
months
to
come
.
   
<EOS>
A
New
Candidate
for
Ecclesiastical
Honours
 
<EOS>
The
dean
's
illness
occasioned
much
mental
turmoil
in
other
places
besides
the
deanery
and
adjoining
library
,
and
the
idea
which
occurred
to
the
meagre
little
prebendary
about
Mr.
Slope
did
not
occur
to
him
alone
.
  
<EOS>
The
bishop
was
sitting
listlessly
in
his
study
when
the
news
reached
him
of
the
dean
's
illness
.
<EOS>
It
was
brought
to
him
by
Mr.
Slope
,
who
of
course
was
not
the
last
person
in
Barchester
to
hear
it
.
<EOS>
It
was
also
not
slow
in
finding
its
way
to
Mrs.
Proudie
's
ears
.
<EOS>
It
may
be
presumed
that
there
was
not
just
then
much
friendly
intercourse
between
these
two
rival
claimants
for
his
lordship
's
obedience
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
though
living
in
the
same
house
,
they
had
not
met
since
the
stormy
interview
between
them
in
the
bishop
's
study
on
the
preceding
day
.
  
<EOS>
On
that
occasion
Mrs.
Proudie
had
been
defeated
.
<EOS>
That
the
prestige
of
continual
victory
should
have
been
torn
from
her
standards
<EOS>
was
a
subject
of
great
sorrow
to
that
militant
lady
;
but
,
though
defeated
,
she
was
not
overcome
.
<EOS>
She
felt
that
she
might
yet
recover
her
lost
ground
,
that
she
might
yet
hurl
Mr.
Slope
down
to
the
dust
from
which
she
had
picked
him
,
and
force
her
sinning
lord
to
sue
for
pardon
in
sackcloth
and
ashes
.
  
<EOS>
On
that
memorable
day
,
memorable
for
his
mutiny
and
rebellion
against
her
high
behests
,
he
had
carried
his
way
with
a
high
hand
,
and
had
really
begun
to
think
it
possible
that
the
days
of
his
slavery
were
counted
.
<EOS>
He
had
begun
to
hope
that
he
was
now
about
to
enter
into
a
free
land
,
a
land
delicious
with
milk
which
he
himself
might
quaff
and
honey
which
would
not
tantalize
him
by
being
only
honey
to
the
eye
.
<EOS>
When
Mrs.
Proudie
banged
the
door
as
she
left
his
room
,
he
felt
himself
every
inch
a
bishop
.
<EOS>
To
be
sure
,
his
spirit
had
been
a
little
cowed
by
his
chaplain
's
subsequent
lecture
,
but
on
the
whole
he
was
highly
pleased
with
himself
,
and
he
flattered
himself
that
the
worst
was
over
.
"
<EOS>
_
Ce
n'est
que
le
premier
pas
qui
coûte
_
,
"
he
reflected
,
and
now
that
the
first
step
had
been
so
magnanimously
taken
,
all
the
rest
would
follow
easily
.
  
<EOS>
He
met
his
wife
as
a
matter
of
course
at
dinner
,
where
little
or
nothing
was
said
that
could
ruffle
the
bishop
's
happiness
.
<EOS>
His
daughters
and
the
servants
were
present
and
protected
him
.
  
<EOS>
He
made
one
or
two
trifling
remarks
on
the
subject
of
his
projected
visit
to
the
archbishop
,
in
order
to
show
to
all
concerned
that
he
intended
to
have
his
own
way
;
the
very
servants
,
perceiving
the
change
,
transferred
a
little
of
their
reverence
from
their
mistress
to
their
master
.
<EOS>
All
which
the
master
perceived
,
and
so
also
did
the
mistress
.
<EOS>
But
Mrs.
Proudie
bided
her
time
.
  
<EOS>
After
dinner
he
returned
to
his
study
,
where
Mr.
Slope
soon
found
him
,
and
there
they
had
tea
together
and
planned
many
things
.
<EOS>
For
some
few
minutes
the
bishop
was
really
happy
;
but
as
the
clock
on
the
chimney
-
piece
warned
him
that
the
stilly
hours
of
night
were
drawing
on
,
as
he
looked
at
his
chamber
candlestick
and
knew
that
he
must
use
it
,
his
heart
sank
within
him
again
.
<EOS>
He
was
as
a
ghost
,
all
whose
power
of
wandering
free
through
these
upper
regions
ceases
at
cock
-
crow
;
or
,
rather
,
he
was
the
opposite
of
the
ghost
,
for
till
cock
-
crow
he
must
again
be
a
serf
.
<EOS>
And
would
that
be
all
?
<EOS>
Could
he
trust
himself
to
come
down
to
breakfast
a
free
man
in
the
morning
?
  
<EOS>
He
was
nearly
an
hour
later
than
usual
when
he
betook
himself
to
his
rest
.
<EOS>
Rest
!
<EOS>
What
rest
?
<EOS>
However
,
he
took
a
couple
of
glasses
of
sherry
and
mounted
the
stairs
.
<EOS>
Far
be
it
from
us
to
follow
him
thither
.
<EOS>
There
are
some
things
which
no
novelist
,
no
historian
,
should
attempt
;
some
few
scenes
in
life
's
drama
which
even
no
poet
should
dare
to
paint
.
<EOS>
Let
that
which
passed
between
Dr.
Proudie
and
his
wife
on
this
night
be
understood
to
be
among
them
.
  
<EOS>
He
came
down
the
following
morning
a
sad
and
thoughtful
man
.
<EOS>
He
was
attenuated
in
appearance
 
one
might
almost
say
emaciated
.
<EOS>
I
doubt
whether
his
now
grizzled
locks
had
not
palpably
become
more
grey
than
on
the
preceding
evening
.
<EOS>
At
any
rate
he
had
aged
materially
.
<EOS>
Years
do
not
make
a
man
old
gradually
and
at
an
even
pace
.
<EOS>
Look
through
the
world
and
see
if
this
is
not
so
always
,
except
in
those
rare
cases
in
which
the
human
being
lives
and
dies
without
joys
and
without
sorrows
,
like
a
vegetable
.
<EOS>
A
man
shall
be
possessed
of
florid
,
youthful
blooming
health
till
<EOS>
,
it
matters
not
what
age
 
<EOS>
thirty
;
forty
;
<EOS>
fifty
 
then
comes
some
nipping
frost
,
some
period
of
agony
,
that
robs
the
fibres
of
the
body
of
their
succulence
,
and
the
hale
and
hearty
man
is
counted
among
the
old
.
  
<EOS>
He
came
down
and
breakfasted
alone
;
Mrs.
Proudie
,
being
indisposed
,
took
her
coffee
in
her
bedroom
,
and
her
daughters
waited
upon
her
there
.
<EOS>
He
ate
his
breakfast
alone
,
and
then
,
hardly
knowing
what
he
did
,
he
betook
himself
to
his
usual
seat
in
his
study
.
<EOS>
He
tried
to
solace
himself
with
his
coming
visit
to
the
archbishop
.
<EOS>
That
effort
of
his
own
free
will
at
any
rate
remained
to
him
as
an
enduring
triumph
.
<EOS>
But
somehow
,
now
that
he
had
achieved
it
,
he
did
not
seem
to
care
so
much
about
it
.
<EOS>
It
was
his
ambition
that
had
prompted
him
to
take
his
place
at
the
archiepiscopal
table
,
and
his
ambition
was
now
quite
dead
within
him
.
  
<EOS>
He
was
thus
seated
when
Mr.
Slope
made
his
appearance
,
with
breathless
impatience
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
lord
,
the
dean
is
dead
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Good
heavens
!
"
exclaimed
the
bishop
,
startled
out
of
his
apathy
by
an
announcement
so
sad
and
so
sudden
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
either
dead
or
now
dying
.
<EOS>
He
has
had
an
apoplectic
fit
,
and
I
am
told
that
there
is
not
the
slightest
hope
;
indeed
,
I
do
not
doubt
that
by
this
time
he
is
no
more
.
"
  
<EOS>
Bells
were
rung
,
and
servants
were
immediately
sent
to
inquire
.
<EOS>
In
the
course
of
the
morning
the
bishop
,
leaning
on
his
chaplain
's
arm
,
himself
called
at
the
deanery
door
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Proudie
sent
to
Miss
Trefoil
all
manner
of
offers
of
assistance
.
<EOS>
The
Misses
Proudie
sent
also
,
and
there
was
immense
sympathy
between
the
palace
and
the
deanery
.
<EOS>
The
answer
to
all
inquiries
was
unvaried
.
<EOS>
The
dean
was
just
the
same
,
and
Sir
Omicron
Pie
was
expected
down
by
the
9.15
P.M.
train
.
  
<EOS>
And
then
Mr.
Slope
began
to
meditate
,
as
others
also
had
done
,
as
to
who
might
possibly
be
the
new
dean
,
and
it
occurred
to
him
,
as
it
had
also
occurred
to
others
,
that
it
might
be
possible
that
he
should
be
the
new
dean
himself
.
<EOS>
And
then
the
question
as
to
the
twelve
hundred
,
or
fifteen
hundred
,
or
two
thousand
ran
in
his
mind
,
as
it
had
run
through
those
of
the
other
clergymen
in
the
cathedral
library
.
  
<EOS>
Whether
it
might
be
two
thousand
,
or
fifteen
,
or
twelve
hundred
,
it
would
in
any
case
undoubtedly
be
a
great
thing
for
him
,
if
he
could
get
it
.
<EOS>
The
gratification
to
his
ambition
would
be
greater
even
than
that
of
his
covetousness
.
<EOS>
How
glorious
to
out
-
top
the
archdeacon
in
his
own
cathedral
city
;
to
sit
above
prebendaries
and
canons
and
have
the
cathedral
pulpit
and
all
the
cathedral
services
altogether
at
his
own
disposal
!
  
<EOS>
But
it
might
be
easier
to
wish
for
this
than
to
obtain
it
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
,
however
,
was
not
without
some
means
of
forwarding
his
views
,
and
he
at
any
rate
did
not
let
the
grass
grow
under
his
feet
.
<EOS>
In
the
first
place
,
he
thought
 
and
not
vainly
 
that
he
could
count
upon
what
assistance
the
bishop
could
give
him
.
<EOS>
He
immediately
changed
his
views
with
regard
to
his
patron
;
he
made
up
his
mind
that
if
he
became
dean
,
he
would
hand
his
lordship
back
again
to
his
wife
's
vassalage
;
and
he
thought
it
possible
that
his
lordship
might
not
be
sorry
to
rid
himself
of
one
of
his
mentors
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
had
also
taken
some
steps
towards
making
his
name
known
to
other
men
in
power
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
certain
chief
-
commissioner
of
national
schools
,
who
at
the
present
moment
was
presumed
to
stand
especially
high
in
the
good
graces
of
the
government
bigwigs
,
and
with
him
Mr.
Slope
had
contrived
to
establish
a
sort
of
epistolary
intimacy
.
<EOS>
He
thought
that
he
might
safely
apply
to
Sir
Nicholas
Fitzwhiggin
,
and
he
felt
sure
that
if
Sir
Nicholas
chose
to
exert
himself
,
the
promise
of
such
a
piece
of
preferment
would
be
had
for
the
asking
.
  
<EOS>
Then
he
also
had
the
press
at
his
bidding
,
or
flattered
himself
that
he
had
so
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
Daily
Jupiter
"
had
taken
his
part
in
a
very
thorough
manner
in
those
polemical
contests
of
his
with
Mr.
Arabin
;
he
had
on
more
than
one
occasion
absolutely
had
an
interview
with
a
gentleman
on
the
staff
of
that
paper
who
,
if
not
the
editor
,
was
as
good
as
the
editor
;
and
he
had
long
been
in
the
habit
of
writing
telling
letters
on
all
manner
of
ecclesiastical
abuses
,
which
he
signed
with
his
initials
,
and
sent
to
his
editorial
friend
with
private
notes
signed
in
his
own
name
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
he
and
Mr.
Towers
 
such
was
the
name
of
the
powerful
gentleman
of
the
press
with
whom
he
was
connected
 
were
generally
very
amiable
with
each
other
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
's
little
productions
were
always
printed
and
occasionally
commented
upon
;
and
thus
,
in
a
small
sort
of
way
,
he
had
become
a
literary
celebrity
.
<EOS>
This
public
life
had
great
charms
for
him
,
though
it
certainly
also
had
its
drawbacks
.
<EOS>
On
one
occasion
,
when
speaking
in
the
presence
of
reporters
,
he
had
failed
to
uphold
and
praise
and
swear
by
that
special
line
of
conduct
which
had
been
upheld
and
praised
and
sworn
by
in
"
The
Jupiter
,
"
and
then
he
had
been
much
surprised
and
at
the
moment
not
a
little
irritated
to
find
himself
lacerated
most
unmercifully
by
his
old
ally
.
<EOS>
He
was
quizzed
and
bespattered
and
made
a
fool
of
,
just
as
though
,
or
rather
worse
than
if
,
he
had
been
a
constant
enemy
instead
of
a
constant
friend
.
<EOS>
He
had
hitherto
not
learnt
that
a
man
who
aspires
to
be
on
the
staff
of
"
The
Jupiter
"
must
surrender
all
individuality
.
<EOS>
But
ultimately
this
little
castigation
had
broken
no
bones
between
him
and
his
friend
Mr.
Towers
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
was
one
of
those
who
understood
the
world
too
well
to
show
himself
angry
with
such
a
potentate
as
"
The
Jupiter
.
<EOS>
"
He
had
kissed
the
rod
that
scourged
him
,
and
now
thought
that
he
might
fairly
look
for
his
reward
.
<EOS>
He
determined
that
he
would
at
once
let
Mr.
Towers
know
that
he
was
a
candidate
for
the
place
which
was
about
to
become
vacant
.
<EOS>
More
than
one
piece
of
preferment
had
lately
been
given
away
much
in
accordance
with
advice
tendered
to
the
government
in
the
columns
of
"
The
Jupiter
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But
it
was
incumbent
on
Mr.
Slope
first
to
secure
the
bishop
.
<EOS>
He
specially
felt
that
it
behoved
him
to
do
this
before
the
visit
to
the
archbishop
was
made
.
<EOS>
It
was
really
quite
providential
that
the
dean
should
have
fallen
ill
just
at
the
very
nick
of
time
.
<EOS>
If
Dr.
Proudie
could
be
instigated
to
take
the
matter
up
warmly
,
he
might

at

's

.
<EOS>
Feeling

,

sound

.
<EOS>
He
was
to

on

to
London
,
and
therefore

.
  
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
It

<EOS>

<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
Dean
of
Barchester
!
<EOS>
The

.

But
 
.
<EOS>

that

might

without

,

,

,

<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
had
now

.
<EOS>
He

.

.

.
  
<EOS>
Touching
Mrs.
Bold
his

now

high
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
was
one
of
that
numerous

of
swains
who
think
that
all
is
fair
in

,
and

's

.
<EOS>

not

,
for
"
<EOS>
the
own
maid
"
had

,

.

"

;

"

positively
refused
to
give
the
letter
up
;
that
she
had
received
from
the
archdeacon
the
option
of
giving
up
either
Mr.
Slope
and
his
letter
,
or
else
the
society
of
Plumstead
Rectory
;
and
that
"
missus
"
had
declared
,
with
much
indignation
,
that
"
she
did
n't
care
a
straw
for
the
society
of
Plumstead
Rectory
,
"
and
that
she
would
n't
give
up
Mr.
Slope
for
any
of
them
.
  
<EOS>
Considering
the
source
from
whence
this
came
,
it
was
not
quite
so
untrue
as
might
have
been
expected
.
<EOS>
It
showed
pretty
plainly
what
had
been
the
nature
of
the
conversation
in
the
servants
"
hall
;
and
,
coupled
as
it
was
with
the
certainty
of
Eleanor
's
sudden
return
,
it
appeared
to
Mr.
Slope
to
be
so
far
worthy
of
credit
as
to
justify
him
in
thinking
that
the
fair
widow
would
in
all
human
probability
accept
his
offer
.
  
<EOS>
All
this
work
was
therefore
to
be
done
.
<EOS>
It
was
desirable
,
he
thought
,
that
he
should
make
his
offer
before
it
was
known
that
Mr.
Quiverful
was
finally
appointed
to
the
hospital
.
<EOS>
In
his
letter
to
Eleanor
he
had
plainly
declared
that
Mr.
Harding
was
to
have
the
appointment
.
<EOS>
It
would
be
very
difficult
to
explain
this
away
,
and
were
he
to
write
another
letter
to
Eleanor
,
telling
the
truth
and
throwing
the
blame
on
the
bishop
,
it
would
naturally
injure
him
in
her
estimation
.
<EOS>
He
determined
therefore
to
let
that
matter
disclose
itself
as
it
would
,
and
to
lose
no
time
in
throwing
himself
at
her
feet
.
  
<EOS>
Then
he
had
to
solicit
the
assistance
of
Sir
Nicholas
Fitzwhiggin
and
Mr.
Towers
,
and
he
went
directly
from
the
bishop
's
presence
to
compose
his
letters
to
those
gentlemen
.
<EOS>
As
Mr.
Slope
was
esteemed
an
adept
at
letter
writing
,
they
shall
be
given
in
full
.
  
<EOS>
(
Private
)
Palace
,
Barchester
,
Sept.
185
    
MY
DEAR
SIR
NICHOLAS
,
  
<EOS>
I
hope
that
the
intercourse
which
has
been
between
us
will
preclude
you
from
regarding
my
present
application
as
an
intrusion
.
<EOS>
You
can
not
,
I
imagine
,
have
yet
heard
that
poor
old
Dr.
Trefoil
has
been
seized
with
apoplexy
.
<EOS>
It
is
a
subject
of
profound
grief
to
everyone
in
Barchester
,
for
he
has
always
been
an
excellent
man
 
excellent
as
a
man
and
as
a
clergyman
.
<EOS>
He
is
,
however
,
full
of
years
,
and
his
life
could
not
under
any
circumstances
have
been
much
longer
spared
.
<EOS>
You
may
probably
have
known
him
.
  
<EOS>
There
is
,
it
appears
,
no
probable
chance
of
his
recovery
.
<EOS>
Sir
Omicron
Pie
is
,
I
believe
,
at
present
with
him
.
<EOS>
At
any
rate
the
medical
men
here
have
declared
that
one
or
two
days
more
must
limit
the
tether
of
his
mortal
coil
.
<EOS>
I
sincerely
trust
that
his
soul
may
wing
its
flight
to
that
haven
where
it
may
forever
be
at
rest
and
forever
be
happy
.
  
<EOS>
The
bishop
has
been
speaking
to
me
about
the
preferment
,
and
he
is
anxious
that
it
should
be
conferred
on
me
.
<EOS>
I
confess
that
I
can
hardly
venture
,
at
my
age
,
to
look
for
such
advancement
,
but
I
am
so
far
encouraged
by
his
lordship
that
I
believe
I
shall
be
induced
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
His
lordship
goes
to
 
---
to
-
morrow
and
is
intent
on
mentioning
the
subject
to
the
archbishop
.
  
<EOS>
I
know
well
how
deservedly
great
is
your
weight
with
the
present
government
.
<EOS>
In
any
matter
touching
church
preferment
you
would
of
course
be
listened
to
.
<EOS>
Now
that
the
matter
has
been
put
into
my
head
,
I
am
of
course
anxious
to
be
successful
.
<EOS>
If
you
can
assist
me
by
your
good
word
,
you
will
confer
on
me
one
additional
favour
.
  
<EOS>
I
had
better
add
,
that
Lord
 
---
can
not
as
yet
know
of
this

of

having

in
,
or
rather
of
its
certainty
of

(
for
poor
dear
<EOS>
Dr.
Trefoil
is
past
hope
)
.
<EOS>
Should
Lord
 
---
first
hear
it
from
you
,
that
might
probably
be
thought
to
give
you

fair

.
  
<EOS>
Of
course

grand
object
is
that
we

all
be

one

church

.
<EOS>
This

most

at
Barchester
;
it
is
this
that

.
<EOS>
You

Lord
 
---

<EOS>
Believe

,
My

Nicholas
,
Your

,
  
OBADIAH
SLOPE
  
<EOS>
His
letter
to
Mr.
Towers
was
written
in
quite
a
different
strain
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
conceived
that
he
completely
understood
the
difference
in
character
and
position
of
the
two
men
whom
he
addressed
.
<EOS>
He
knew
that
for
such
a
man
as
Sir
Nicholas
Fitzwhiggin
a
little
flummery
was
necessary
,
and
that
it
might
be
of
the
easy
,
everyday
description
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
his
letter
to
Sir
Nicholas
was
written
,
_
currente
calamo
_
,
with
very
little
trouble
.
<EOS>
But
to
such
a
man
as
Mr.
Towers
it
was
not
so
easy
to
write
a
letter
that
should
be
effective
and
yet
not
offensive
,
that
should
carry
its
point
without
undue
interference
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
difficult
to
flatter
Dr.
Proudie
or
Sir
Nicholas
Fitzwhiggin
,
but
very
difficult
to
flatter
Mr.
Towers
without
letting
the
flattery
declare
itself
.
<EOS>
This
,
however
,
had
to
be
done
.
<EOS>
Moreover
,
this
letter
must
,
in
appearance
at
least
,
be
written
without
effort
,
and
be
fluent
,
unconstrained
,
and
demonstrative
of
no
doubt
or
fear
on
the
part
of
the
writer
.
<EOS>
Therefore
the
epistle
to
Mr.
Towers
was
studied
,
and
re
-
copied
,
and
elaborated
at
the
cost
of
so
many
minutes
that
Mr.
Slope
had
hardly
time
to
dress
himself
and
reach
Dr.
Stanhope
's
that

.
  
<EOS>
When
dispatched
,
it
ran
as
follows
:
    
(
Private
.
)
<EOS>
Barchester
.
<EOS>
Sept.
185
    
(
He
purposely
omitted
any
allusion
to
the
"
palace
,
"
thinking
that
Mr.
Towers
might

.
<EOS>
A
great
man
,
he
remembered
,
had
been
once
much

for
dating

from
Windsor

.

<EOS>
MY
DEAR
SIR
,
  
<EOS>
We
were
all
a
good
deal
shocked
here
this
morning
by
hearing
that
poor
old
Dean
Trefoil
had
been
stricken
with
apoplexy
.
<EOS>
The
fit
took
him
about
9
A.M.
I
am
writing
now
to
save
the
post
,
and
he
is
still
alive
,
but
past
all
hope
or
possibility
,
I
believe
,
of
living
.
<EOS>
Sir
Omicron
Pie
is
here
,
or
will
be
very
shortly
,
but
all
that
even
Sir
Omicron
can
do
is
to
ratify
the
sentence
of
his
less
distinguished
brethren
that
nothing
can
be
done
.
<EOS>
Poor
Dr.
Trefoil
's
race
on
this
side
the
grave
is
run
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
know
whether
you
knew
him
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
good
,
quiet
,
charitable
man
,
of
the
old
school
,
of
course
,
as
any
clergyman
over
seventy
years
of
age
must
necessarily
be
.
  
<EOS>
But
I
do
not
write
merely
with
the
object
of
sending
you
such
news
as
this
:
<EOS>
doubtless
someone
of
your
Mercuries
will
have
seen
and
heard
and
reported
so
much
;
I
write
,
as
you
usually
do
yourself
,
rather
with
a
view
to
the
future
than
to
the
past
.
  
<EOS>
Rumour
is
already
rife
here
as
to
Dr.
Trefoil
's
successor
,
and
among
those
named
as
possible
future
deans
your
humble
servant
is
,
I
believe
,
not
the
least
frequently
spoken
of
;
in
short
,
I
am
looking
for
the
preferment
.
<EOS>
You
may
probably
know
that
since
Bishop
Proudie
came
to
the
diocese
I
have
exerted
myself
here
a
good
deal
<EOS>
and
,
I
may
certainly
say
,
not
without
some
success
.
<EOS>
He
and
I
are
nearly
always
of
the
same
opinion
on
points
of
doctrine
as
well
as
church
discipline
,
and
therefore
I
have
had
,
as
his
confidential
chaplain
,
very
much
in
my
own
hands
;
but
I
confess
to
you
that
I
have
a
higher
ambition
than
to
remain
the
chaplain
of
any
bishop
.
  
<EOS>
There
are
no
positions
in
which
more
energy
is
now
needed
than
those
of
our
deans
.
<EOS>
The
whole
of
our
enormous
cathedral
establishments
have
been
allowed
to
go
to
sleep
 
<EOS>
nay
,
they
are
all
but
dead
and
ready
for
the
sepulchre
!
<EOS>
And
yet
of
what
prodigious
moment
they
might
be
made
if
,
as
was
intended
,
they
were
so
managed
as
to
lead
the
way
and
show
an
example
for
all
our
parochial
clergy
!
  
<EOS>
The
bishop
here
is
most
anxious
for
my
success
;
indeed
,
he
goes
to
-
morrow
to
press
the
matter
on
the
archbishop
.
<EOS>
I
believe
also
I
may
count
on
the
support
of
at
least
one
most
effective
member
of
the
government
.
<EOS>
But
I
confess
that
the
support
of
"
The
Jupiter
,
"
if
I
be
thought
worthy
of
it
,
would
be
more
gratifying
to
me
than
any
other
;
more
gratifying
if
by
it
I
should
be
successful
,
and
more
gratifying
also
<EOS>
if
,
although
so
supported
,
I
should
be
unsuccessful
.
  
<EOS>
The
time
has
,
in
fact
,
come
in
which
no
government
can
venture
to
fill
up
the
high
places
of
the
Church
in
defiance
of
the
public
press
.
<EOS>
The
age
of
honourable
bishops
and
noble
deans
has
gone
by
,
and
any
clergyman
however
humbly
born
<EOS>
can
now
hope
for
success
if
his
industry
,
talent
,
and
character
be
sufficient
to
call
forth
the
manifest
opinion
of
the
public
in
his
favour
.
  
<EOS>
At
the
present
moment
we
all
feel
that
any
counsel
given
in
such
matters
by
"
The
Jupiter
"
has
the
greatest
weight
 
is
,
indeed
,
generally
followed
;
and
we
feel
also
 
I
am
speaking
of
clergymen
of
my
own
age
and
standing
 
that
it
should
be
so
.
<EOS>
There
can
be
no
patron
less
interested
than
"
The
Jupiter
,
"
and
none
that
more
thoroughly
understands
the
wants
of
the
people
.
  
<EOS>
I
am
sure
you
will
not
suspect
me
of
asking
from
you
any
support
which
the
paper
with
which
you
are
connected
can
not
conscientiously
give
me
.
<EOS>
My
object
in
writing
is
to
let
you
know
that
I
am
a
candidate
for
the
appointment
.
<EOS>
It
is
for
you
to
judge
whether
or
no
you
can
assist
my
views
.
<EOS>
I
should
not
,
of
course
,
have
written
to
you
on
such
a
matter
<EOS>
had
I
not
believed
(
and
I
have
had
good
reason
so
to
believe
)
that
"
The
Jupiter
"
approves
of
my
views
on
ecclesiastical
polity
.
  
<EOS>
The
bishop
expresses
a
fear
that
I
may
be
considered
too
young
for
such
a
station
,
my
age
being
thirty
-
six
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
think
that
at
the
present
day
any
hesitation
need
be
felt
on
such
a
point
.
<EOS>
The
public
has
lost
its
love
for
antiquated
servants
.
<EOS>
If
a
man
will
ever
be
fit
to
do
good
work
,
he
will
be
fit
at
thirty
-
six
years
of
age
.
  
<EOS>
Believe
me
very
faithfully
yours
,
OBADIAH
SLOPE
  
<EOS>
T.
TOWERS
,
ESQ
.
<EOS>
,
 
---
Court
,
Middle

.
  
<EOS>
Having
thus
exerted
himself
,
Mr.
Slope
posted
his
letters
and
passed
the
remainder
of
the
evening
at
the
feet
of
his
mistress
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
will
be
accused
of
deceit
in
his
mode
of
canvassing
.
<EOS>
It
will
be
said
that
he
lied
in
the
application
he
made
to
each
of
his
three
patrons
.
<EOS>
I
believe
it
must
be
owned
that
he
did
so
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
hesitate
on
account
of
his
youth
and
yet
be
quite
assured
that
he
was
not
too
young
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
count
chiefly
on
the
bishop
's
support
and
chiefly
also
on
that
of
the
newspaper
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
think
that
the
bishop
was
going
to
 
---
to
press
the
matter
on
the
archbishop
.
<EOS>
It
must
be
owned
that
in
his
canvassing
Mr.
Slope
was
as
false
as
he
well
could
be
.
  
<EOS>
Let
it
,
however
,
be
asked
of
those
who
are
conversant
with
such
matters
,
whether
he
was
more
false
than
men
usually
are
on
such
occasions
.
<EOS>
We
English
gentlemen
hate
the
name
of
a
lie
,
but
how
often
do
we
find
public
men
who
believe
each
other
's
words
?
   
<EOS>
Mrs.
Proudie
Victrix
 
<EOS>
The
next
week
passed
over
at
Barchester
with
much
apparent
tranquillity
.
<EOS>
The
hearts
,
however
,
of
some
of
the
inhabitants
were
not
so
tranquil
as
the
streets
of
the
city
.
<EOS>
The
poor
old
dean
still
continued
to
live
,
just
as
Sir
Omicron
Pie
had
prophesied
that
he
would
do
,
much
to
the
amazement
,
and
some
thought
disgust
,
of
Dr.
Fillgrave
.
<EOS>
The
bishop
still
remained
away
.
<EOS>
He
had
stayed
a
day
or
two
in
town
and
had
also
remained
longer
at
the
archbishop
's
than
he
had
intended
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
had
as
yet
received
no
line
in
answer
to
either
of
his
letters
,
but
he
had
learnt
the
cause
of
this
.
<EOS>
Sir
Nicholas
was
stalking
a
deer
,
or
attending
the
Queen
,
in
the
Highlands
,
and
even
the
indefatigable
Mr.
Towers
had
stolen
an
autumn
holiday
,
and
had
made
one
of
the
yearly
tribe
who
now
ascend
Mont
Blanc
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
learnt
that
he
was
not
expected
back
till
the
last
day
of
September
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Bold
was
thrown
much
with
the
Stanhopes
,
of
whom
she
became
fonder
and
fonder
.
<EOS>
If
asked
,
she
would
have
said
that
Charlotte
Stanhope
was
her
especial
friend
,
and
so
she
would
have
thought
.
<EOS>
But
,
to
tell
the
truth
,
she
liked
Bertie
nearly
as
well
;
she
had
no
more
idea
of
regarding
him
as
a
lover
than
she
would
have
had
of
looking
at
a
big
tame
dog
in
such
a
light
.
<EOS>
Bertie
had
become
very
intimate
with
her
,
and
made
little
speeches
to
her
,
and
said
little
things
of
a
sort
very
different
from
the
speeches
and
sayings
of
other
men
.
<EOS>
But
then
this
was
almost
always
done
before
his
sisters
;
and
he
,
with
his
long
silken
beard
,
his
light
blue
eyes
,
and
strange
dress
,
was
so
unlike
other
men
.
<EOS>
She
admitted
him
to
a
kind
of
familiarity
which
she
had
never
known
with
anyone
else
,
and
of
which
she
by
no
means
understood
the
danger
.
<EOS>
She
blushed
once
at
finding
that
she
had
called
him
Bertie
and
,
on
the
same
day
,
only
barely
remembered
her
position
in
time
to
check
herself
from
playing
upon
him
some
personal
practical
joke
to
which
she
was
instigated
by
Charlotte
.
  
<EOS>
In
all
this
Eleanor
was
perfectly
innocent
,
and
Bertie
Stanhope
could
hardly
be
called
guilty
.
<EOS>
But
every
familiarity
into
which
Eleanor
was
entrapped
was
deliberately
planned
by
his
sister
.
<EOS>
She
knew
well
how
to
play
her
game
,
and
played
it
without
mercy
;
she
knew
,
none
<EOS>
so
well
,
what
was
her
brother
's
character
,
and
she
would
have
handed
over
to
him
the
young
widow
,
and
the
young
widow
's
money
,
and
the
money
of
the
widow
's
child
,
without
remorse
.
<EOS>
With
her
pretended
friendship
and
warm
cordiality
,
she
strove
to
connect
Eleanor
so
closely
with
her
brother
as
to
make
it
impossible
that
she
should
go
back
even
if
she
wished
it
.
<EOS>
But
Charlotte
Stanhope
knew
really
nothing
of
Eleanor
's
character
,
did
not
even
understand
that
there
were
such
characters
.
<EOS>
She
did
not
comprehend
that
a
young
and
pretty
woman
could
be
playful
and
familiar
with
a
man
such
as
Bertie
Stanhope
and
yet
have
no
idea
in
her
head
,
<EOS>
no
feeling
in
her
heart
,
that
she
would
have
been
ashamed
to
own
to
all
the
world
.
<EOS>
Charlotte
Stanhope
did
not
in
the
least
conceive
that
her
new
friend
was
a
woman
whom
nothing
could
entrap
into
an
inconsiderate
marriage
,
whose
mind
would
have
revolted
from
the
slightest
impropriety
<EOS>
had
she
been
aware
that
any
impropriety
existed
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Stanhope
,
however
,
had
tact
enough
to
make
herself
and
her
father
's
house
very
agreeable
to
Mrs.
Bold
.
<EOS>
There
was
with
them
all
an
absence
of
stiffness
and
formality
which
was
peculiarly
agreeable
to
Eleanor
after
the
great
dose
of
clerical
arrogance
which
she
had
lately
been
constrained
to
take
.
<EOS>
She
played
chess
with
them
,
walked
with
them
,
and
drank
tea
with
them
;
studied
or
pretended
to
study
astronomy
;
assisted
them
in
writing
stories
in
rhyme
,
in
turning
prose
tragedy
into
comic
verse
,
or
comic
stories
into
would
-
be
tragic
poetry
.
<EOS>
She
had
no
idea
before
that
she
had
any
such
talents
.
<EOS>
She
had
not
conceived
the
possibility
of
her
doing
such
things
as
she
now
did
.
<EOS>
She
found
with
the
Stanhopes
new
amusements
and
employments
,
new
pursuits
,
which
in
themselves
could
not
be
wrong
,
and
which
were
exceedingly
alluring
.
  
<EOS>
Is
it
not
a
pity
that
people
who
are
bright
and
clever
should
so
often
be
exceedingly
improper
,
and
that
those
who
are
never
improper
should
so
often
be
dull
and
heavy
?
<EOS>
Now
Charlotte
Stanhope
was
always
bright
and
never
heavy
,
but
then
her
propriety
was
doubtful
.
  
<EOS>
But
during
all
this
time
Eleanor
by
no
means
forgot
Mr.
Arabin
,
nor
did
she
forget
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
She
had
parted
from
Mr.
Arabin
in
her
anger
.
<EOS>
She
was
still
angry
at
what
she
regarded
as
his
impertinent
interference
,
but
nevertheless
she
looked
forward
to
meeting
him
again
,
and
also
looked
forward
to
forgiving
him
.
<EOS>
The
words
that
Mr.
Arabin
had
uttered
still
sounded
in
her
ears
.
<EOS>
She
knew
that
if
not
intended
for
a
declaration
of
love
,
they
did
signify
that
he
loved
her
,
and
she
felt
also
that
if
he
ever
did
make
such
a
declaration
,
it
might
be
that
she
should
not
receive
it
unkindly
.
<EOS>
She
was
still
angry
with
him
,
very
angry
with
him
;
so
angry
that
she
would
bite
her
lip
and
stamp
her
foot
as
she
thought
of
what
he
had
said
and
done
.
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,
she
yearned
to
let
him
know
that
he
was
forgiven
;
all
that
she
required
was
that
he
should
own
that
he
had
sinned
.
  
<EOS>
She
was
to
meet
him
at
Ullathorne
on
the
last
day
of
the
present
month
.
<EOS>
Miss
Thorne
had
invited
all
the
country
round
to
a
breakfast
on
the
lawn
.
<EOS>
There
were
to
be
tents
,
and
archery
,
and
dancing
for
the
ladies
on
the
lawn
and
for
the
swains
and
girls
in
the
paddock
.
<EOS>
There
were
to
be
fiddlers
and
fifers
,
races
for
the
boys
,
poles
to
be
climbed
,
ditches
full
of
water
to
be
jumped
over
,
horse
-
collars
to
be
grinned
through
(
this
latter
amusement
was
an
addition
of
the
stewards
,
and
not
arranged
by
Miss
Thorne
in
the
original
programme
)
,
and
every
game
to
be
played
which
,
in
a
long
course
of
reading
,
Miss
Thorne
could
ascertain
to
have
been
played
in
the
good
days
of
Queen
Elizabeth
.
<EOS>
Everything
of
more
modern
growth
was
to
be
tabooed
,
if
possible
.
<EOS>
On
one
subject
Miss
Thorne
was
very
unhappy
.
<EOS>
She
had
been
turning
in
her
mind
the
matter
of
a
bull
-
ring
,
but
could
not
succeed
in
making
anything
of
it
.
<EOS>
She
would
not
for
the
world
have
done
,
or
allowed
to
be
done
,
anything
that
was
cruel
;
as
to
the
promoting
the
torture
of
a
bull
for
the
amusement
of
her
young
neighbours
,
it
need
hardly
be
said
that
Miss
Thorne
would
be
the
last
to
think
of
it
.
<EOS>
And
yet
there
was
something
so
charming
in
the
name
.
<EOS>
A
bull
-
ring
,
however
,
without
a
bull
would
only
be
a
memento
of
the
decadence
of
the
times
,
and
she
felt
herself
constrained
to
abandon
the
idea
.
<EOS>
Quintains
,
however
,
she
was
determined
to
have
,
and
had
poles
and
swivels
and
bags
of
flour
prepared
accordingly
.
<EOS>
She
would
no
doubt
have
been
anxious
for
something
small
in
the
way
of
a
tournament
,
but
,
as
she
said
to
her
brother
,
that
had
been
tried
,
and
the
age
had
proved
itself
too
decidedly
inferior
to
its
forerunners
to
admit
of
such
a
pastime
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Thorne
did
not
seem
to
participate
much
in
her
regret
,
feeling
perhaps
that
a
full
suit
of
chain
-
armour
would
have
added
but
little
to
his
own
personal
comfort
.
  
<EOS>
This
party
at
Ullathorne
had
been
planned
in
the
first
place
as
a
sort
of
welcoming
to
Mr.
Arabin
on
his
entrance
into
St.
Ewold
's
parsonage
;
an
intended
harvest
-
home
gala
for
the
labourers
and
their
wives
and
children
had
subsequently
been
amalgamated
with
it
,
and
thus
it
had
grown
to
its
present
dimensions
.
<EOS>
All
the
Plumstead
party
had
of
course
been
asked
,
and
at
the
time
of
the
invitation
Eleanor
had
intended
to
have
gone
with
her
sister
.
<EOS>
Now
her
plans
were
altered
,
and
she
was
going
with
the
Stanhopes
.
<EOS>
The
Proudies
were
also
to
be
there
,
and
,
as
Mr.
Slope
had
not
been
included
in
the
invitation
to
the
palace
,
the
signora
,
whose
impudence
never
deserted
her
,
asked
permission
of
Miss
Thorne
to
bring
him
.
  
<EOS>
This
permission
Miss
Thorne
gave
,
having
no
other
alternative
;
but
she
did
so
with
a
trembling
heart
,
fearing
Mr.
Arabin
would
be
offended
.
<EOS>
Immediately
on
his
return
she
apologized
,
almost
with
tears
,
so
dire
an
enmity
was
presumed
to
rage
between
the
two
gentlemen
.
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Arabin
comforted
her
by
an
assurance
that
he
should
meet
Mr.
Slope
with
the
greatest
pleasure
imaginable
and
made
her
promise
that
she
would
introduce
them
to
each
other
.
  
<EOS>
But
this
triumph
of
Mr.
Slope
's
was
not
so
agreeable
to
Eleanor
,
who
since
her
return
to
Barchester
had
done
her
best
to
avoid
him
.
<EOS>
She
would
not
give
way
to
the
Plumstead
folk
when
they
so
ungenerously
accused
her
of
being
in
love
with
this
odious
man
;
but
,
nevertheless
,
knowing
that
she
was
so
accused
,
she
was
fully
alive
to
the
expediency
of
keeping
out
of
his
way
and
dropping
him
by
degrees
.
<EOS>
She
had
seen
very
little
of
him
since
her
return
.
<EOS>
Her
servant
had
been
instructed
to
say
to
all
visitors
that
she
was
out
.
<EOS>
She
could
not
bring
herself
to
specify
Mr.
Slope
particularly
,
and
in
order
to
avoid
him
she
had
thus
debarred
herself
from
all
her
friends
.
<EOS>
She
had
excepted
Charlotte
Stanhope
and
,
by
degrees
,
a
few
others
also
.
<EOS>
Once
she
had
met
him
at
the
Stanhopes
"
,
but
as
a
rule
,
Mr.
Slope
's
visits
there
were
made
in
the
morning
and
hers
in
the
evening
.
<EOS>
On
that
one
occasion
Charlotte
had
managed
to
preserve
her
from
any
annoyance
.
<EOS>
This
was
very
good
-
natured
on
the
part
of
Charlotte
,
as
Eleanor
thought
,
and
also
very
sharp
-
witted
,
as
Eleanor
had
told
her
friend
nothing
of
her
reasons
for
wishing
to
avoid
that
gentleman
.
<EOS>
The
fact
,
however
,
was
that
Charlotte
had
learnt
from
her
sister
that
Mr.
Slope
would
probably
put
himself
forward
as
a
suitor
for
the
widow
's
hand
,
and
she
was
consequently
sufficiently
alive
to
the
expediency
of
guarding
Bertie
's
future
wife
from
any
danger
in
that
quarter
.
  
<EOS>
Nevertheless
the
Stanhopes
were
pledged
to
take
Mr.
Slope
with
them
to
Ullathorne
.
<EOS>
An
arrangement
was
therefore
necessarily
made
,
which
was
very
disagreeable
to
Eleanor
.
<EOS>
Dr.
Stanhope
,
with
herself
,
Charlotte
,
and
Mr.
Slope
,
were
to
go
together
,
and
Bertie
was
to
follow
with
his
sister
Madeline
.
<EOS>
It
was
clearly
visible
by
Eleanor
's
face
that
this
assortment
was
very
disagreeable
to
her
,
and
Charlotte
,
who
was
much
encouraged
thereby
in
her
own
little
plan
,
made
a
thousand
apologies
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
see
you
do
n't
like
it
,
my
dear
,
"
said
she
,
"
but
we
could
not
manage
otherwise
.
<EOS>
Bertie
would
give
his
eyes
to
go
with
you
,
but
Madeline
can
not
possibly
go
without
him
.
<EOS>
Nor
could
we
possibly
put
Mr.
Slope
and
Madeline
in
the
same
carriage
without
anyone
else
.
<EOS>
They
'd
both
be
ruined
forever
,
you
know
,
and
not
admitted
inside
Ullathorne
gates
,
I
should
imagine
,
after
such
an
impropriety
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
that
would
n't
do
,
"
said
Eleanor
,
"
but
could
n't
I
go
in
the
carriage
with
the
signora
and
your
brother
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Impossible
!
"
said
Charlotte
.
<EOS>
"
When
she
is
there
,
there
is
only
room
for
two
.
"
<EOS>
The
Signora
,
in
truth
,
did
not
care
to
do
her
travelling
in
the
presence
of
strangers
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
then
,
"
said
Eleanor
,
"
you
are
all
so
kind
,
Charlotte
,
and
so
good
to
me
that
I
am
sure
you
wo
n't
be
offended
,
<EOS>
but
I
think
I
'll
not
go
at
all
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Not
go
at
all
!
 
<EOS>
what
nonsense
!
 
<EOS>
indeed
you
shall
.
<EOS>
"
It
had
been
absolutely
determined
in
family
counsel
that
Bertie
should
propose
on
that
very
occasion
.
  
<EOS>
"
Or
I
can
take
a
fly
,
"
said
Eleanor
.
<EOS>
"
You
know
I
am
not
embarrassed
by
so
many
difficulties
as
you
young
ladies
;
I
can
go
alone
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nonsense
,
my
dear
!
<EOS>
Do
n't
think
of
such
a
thing
;
after
all
,
it
is
only
for
an
hour
or
so
;
and
,
to
tell
the
truth
,
I
do
n't
know
what
it
is
you
dislike
so
.
<EOS>
I
thought
you
and
Mr.
Slope
were
great
friends
.
<EOS>
What
is
it
you
dislike
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
nothing
particular
,
"
said
Eleanor
;
"
only
I
thought
it
would
be
a
family
party
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
it
would
be
much
nicer
,
much
more
snug
,
if
Bertie
could
go
with
us
.
<EOS>
It
is
he
that
is
badly
treated
.
<EOS>
I
can
assure
you
he
is
much
more
afraid
of
Mr.
Slope
than
you
are
.
<EOS>
But
you
see
Madeline
can
not
go
out
without
him
 
and
she
,
poor
creature
,
goes
out
so
seldom
!
<EOS>
I
am
sure
you
do
n't
begrudge
her
this
,
though
her
vagary
does
knock
about
our
own
party
a
little
.
"
  
<EOS>
Of
course
Eleanor
made
a
thousand
protestations
and
uttered
a
thousand
hopes
that
Madeline
would
enjoy
herself
.
<EOS>
And
of
course
she
had
to
give

and
undertake
to

in
the

Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
In

,
she

either
to

or

not

.
<EOS>
Now
she
could
not

to

all

passed

Plumstead
.
  
<EOS>
But
it
was
to
her
a
sore

.
<EOS>
She

of
a

for

;
she

not

;

to
go
,
although

,
and

;
anything
,

,

,

Arabin

Slope
.
<EOS>
However
,

,

no

,

Slope

,

.
  
<EOS>
The
bishop
returned
on
the
eve
of
the
Ullathorne
party
,
and
was

.
<EOS>
On

with

of

;
he
had

,
and

.
<EOS>
Nothing
,

,

;

;
and

,
"

,
"

her

,

,
good
,
<EOS>
pet
,
little

.
<EOS>
All

.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Proudie
had
somewhat

;

,

.
<EOS>
She

<EOS>
Mr.

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
But
,

,
 
!

,

"
We

"
<EOS>

Mrs.

a
false
,
designing
,
mean
,
intriguing
man
.
<EOS>
I
have
my
eye
on
him
;
he
little
knows
what
I
see
.
<EOS>
He
is
misconducting
himself
in
the
most
disgraceful
way
with
that
lame
Italian
woman
.
<EOS>
That
family
is
a
disgrace
to
Barchester
,
and
Mr.
Slope
is
a
disgrace
to
Barchester
.
<EOS>
If
he
does
n't
look
well
to
it
,
he
'll
have
his
gown
stripped
off
his
back
instead
of
having
a
dean
's
hat
on
his
head
.
<EOS>
Dean
,
indeed
!
<EOS>
The
man
has
gone
mad
with
arrogance
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
bishop
said
nothing
further
to
excuse
either
himself
or
his
chaplain
,
and
having
shown
himself
passive
and
docile
,
was
again
taken
into
favour
.
<EOS>
They
soon
went
to
dinner
,
and
he
spent
the
pleasantest
evening
he
had
had
in
his
own
house
for
a
long
time
.
<EOS>
His
daughter
played
and
sang
to
him
as
he
sipped
his
coffee
and
read
his
newspaper
,
and
Mrs.
Proudie
asked
good
-
natured
little
questions
about
the
archbishop
;
and
then
he
went
happily
to
bed
and
slept
as
quietly
as
though
Mrs.
Proudie
had
been
Griselda
herself
.
<EOS>
While
shaving
himself
in
the
morning
and
preparing
for
the
festivities
of
Ullathorne
,
he
fully
resolved
to
run
no
more
tilts
against
a
warrior
so
fully
armed
at
all
points
as
was
Mrs.
Proudie
.
   
<EOS>
Oxford
 
<EOS>
The
Master
and
Tutor
of
Lazarus
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
,
as
we
have
said
,
had
but
a
sad
walk
of
it
under
the
trees
of
Plumstead
churchyard
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
appear
to
any
of
the
family
till
dinner
-
time
,
and
then
he
seemed
,
as
far
as
their
judgement
went
,
to
be
quite
himself
.
<EOS>
He
had
,
as
was
his
wo
nt
,
asked
himself
a
great
many
questions
and
given
himself
a
great
many
answers
;
and
the
upshot
of
this
was
that
he
had
sent
himself
down
for
an
ass
.
<EOS>
He
had
determined
that
he
was
much
too
old
and
much
too
rusty
to
commence
the
manoeuvres
of
love
-
making
;
that
he
had
let
the
time
slip
through
his
hands
which
should
have
been
used
for
such
purposes
;
and
that
now
he
must
lie
on
his
bed
as
he
had
made
it
.
<EOS>
Then
he
asked
himself
whether
in
truth
he
did
love
this
woman
;
and
he
answered
himself
,
not
without
a
long
struggle
,
but
at
last
honestly
,
that
he
certainly
did
love
her
.
<EOS>
He
then
asked
himself
whether
he
did
not
also
love
her
money
,
and
he
again
answered
himself
that
he
did
so
.
<EOS>
But
here
he
did
not
answer
honestly
.
<EOS>
It
was
and
ever
had
been
his
weakness
to
look
for
impure
motives
for
his
own
conduct
.
<EOS>
No
doubt
,
circumstanced
as
he
was
,
with
a
small
living
and
a
fellowship
,
accustomed
as
he
had
been
to
collegiate
luxuries
and
expensive
comforts
,
he
might
have
hesitated
to
marry
a
penniless
woman
<EOS>
had
he
felt
ever
so
strong
a
predilection
for
the
woman
herself
;
<EOS>
no
doubt
Eleanor
's
fortune
put
all
such
difficulties
out
of
the
question
;
but
it
was
equally
without
doubt
that
his
love
for
her
had
crept
upon
him
without
the
slightest
idea
on
his
part
that
he
could
ever
benefit
his
own
condition
by
sharing
her
wealth
.
  
<EOS>
When
he
had
stood
on
the
hearth
-
rug
,
counting
the
pattern
and
counting
also
the
future
chances
of
his
own
life
,
the
remembrances
of
Mrs.
Bold
's
comfortable
income
had
certainly
not
damped
his
first
assured
feeling
of
love
for
her
.
<EOS>
And
why
should
it
have
done
so
?
<EOS>
Need
it
have
done
so
with
the
purest
of
men
?
<EOS>
Be
that
as
it
may
<EOS>
,
Mr.
Arabin
decided
against
himself
;
he
decided
that
it
had
done
so
in
his
case
,
and
that
he
was
not
the
purest
of
men
.
  
<EOS>
He
also
decided
,
which
was
more
to
his
purpose
,
that
Eleanor
did
not
care
a
straw
for
him
,
and
that
very
probably
she
did
care
a
straw
for
his
rival
.
<EOS>
Then
he
made
up
his
mind
not
to
think
of
her
any
more
,
and
went
on
thinking
of
her
till
he
was
almost
in
a
state
to
drown
himself
in
the
little
brook
which
ran
at
the
bottom
of
the
archdeacon
's
grounds
.
  
<EOS>
And
ever
and
again
his
mind
would
revert
to
the
Signora
Neroni
,
and
he
would
make
comparisons
between
her
and
Eleanor
Bold
,
not
always
in
favour
of
the
latter
.
<EOS>
The
signora
had
listened
to
him
,
and
flattered
him
,
and
believed
in
him
;
at
least
she
had
told
him
so
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Bold
had
also
listened
to
him
,
but
had
never
flattered
him
;
had
not
always
believed
in
him
;
and
now
had
broken
from
him
in
violent
rage
.
<EOS>
The
signora
,
too
,
was
the
more
lovely
woman
of
the
two
,
and
had
also
the
additional
attraction
of
her
affliction
 
for
to
him
it
was
an
attraction
.
  
<EOS>
But
he
never
could
have
loved
the
Signora
Neroni
as
he
felt
that
he
now
loved
Eleanor
;
and
so
he
flung
stones
into
the
brook
,
instead
of
flinging
in
himself
,
and
sat
down
on
its
margin
as
sad
a
gentleman
as
you
shall
meet
in
a
summer
's
day
.
  
<EOS>
He
heard
the
dinner
-
bell
ring
from
the
churchyard
,
and
he
knew
that
it
was
time
to
recover
his
self
-
possession
.
<EOS>
He
felt
that
he
was
disgracing
himself
in
his
own
eyes
,
that
he
had
been
idling
his
time
and
neglecting
the
high
duties
which
he
had
taken
upon
himself
to
perform
.
<EOS>
He
should
have
spent
this
afternoon
among
the
poor
at
St.
Ewold
's
,
instead
of
wandering
about
at
Plumstead
,
an
ancient
,
love
-
lorn
swain
,
dejected
and
sighing
,
full
of
imaginary
sorrows
and
Wertherian
grief
.
<EOS>
He
was
thoroughly
ashamed
of
himself
,
and
determined
to
lose
no
time
in
retrieving
his
character
,
so
damaged
in
his
own
eyes
.
  
<EOS>
Thus
when
he
appeared
at
dinner
he
was
as
animated
as
ever
and
was
the
author
of
most
of
the
conversation
which
graced
the
archdeacon
's
board
on
that
evening
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
was
ill
at
ease
and
sick
at
heart
,
and
did
not
care
to
appear
more
comfortable
than
he
really
was
;
what
little
he
did
say
was
said
to
his
daughter
.
<EOS>
He
thought
that
the
archdeacon
and
Mr.
Arabin
had
leagued
together
against
Eleanor
's
comfort
,
and
his
wish
now
was
to
break
away
from
the
pair
and
undergo
in
his
Barchester
lodgings
whatever
Fate
had
in
store
for
him
.
<EOS>
He
hated
the
name
of
the
hospital
;
his
attempt
to
regain
his
lost
inheritance
there
had
brought
upon
him
so
much
suffering
.
<EOS>
As
far
as
he
was
concerned
,
Mr.
Quiverful
was
now
welcome
to
the
place
.
  
<EOS>
And
the
archdeacon
was
not
very
lively
.
<EOS>
The
poor
dean
's
illness
was
of
course
discussed
in
the
first
place
.
<EOS>
Dr.
Grantly
did
not
mention
Mr.
Slope
's
name
in
connexion
with
the
expected
event
of
Dr.
Trefoil
's
death
;
he
did
not
wish
to
say
anything
about
Mr.
Slope
just
at
present
,
nor
did
he
wish
to
make
known
his
sad
surmises
;
but
the
idea
that
his
enemy
might
possibly
become
Dean
of
Barchester
made
him
very
gloomy
.
<EOS>
Should
such
an
event
take
place
,
such
a
dire
catastrophe
come
about
,
there
would
be
an
end
to
his
life
as
far
as
his
life
was
connected
with
the
city
of
Barchester
.
<EOS>
He
must
give
up
all
his
old
haunts
,
all
his
old
habits
,
and
live
quietly
as
a
retired
rector
at
Plumstead
.
<EOS>
It
had
been
a
severe
trial
for
him
to
have
Dr.
Proudie
in
the
palace
,
but
with
Mr.
Slope
also
in
the
deanery
<EOS>
he
felt
that
he
should
be
unable
to
draw
his
breath
in
Barchester
close
.
  
<EOS>
Thus
it
came
to
pass
that
in
spite
of
the
sorrow
at
his
heart
,
Mr.
Arabin
was
apparently
the
gayest
of
the
party
.
<EOS>
Both
Mr.
Harding
and
Mrs.
Grantly
were
in
a
slight
degree
angry
with
him
on

of
his
want
of

.
<EOS>
To
the
one
it
appeared
as

he

's

,
and
to

all

sad

day
 
Eleanor
's

,
Mr.
Slope
's

,

the

's

.
<EOS>
And
so

were
all
at
cross
-

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
left
the
room
almost
together
with
the
ladies
,
and
then
the
archdeacon
opened
his
heart
to
Mr.
Arabin
.
<EOS>
He
still
harped
upon
the
hospital
.
<EOS>
"
What
did
that
fellow
mean
,
"
said

,
"
by

Mrs.
Bold
that

Mr.
Harding
would
call

,

?
<EOS>
Of

,

well

.
<EOS>
It

because
Mrs.
Bold
is

.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
hinted
that
he
was

Mrs.
Bold
would

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
The

questioned

cross
-

,
but
elicited

,
and
at

,
_

_
,

Slope
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
strongly

Mr.

the
hospital
in

,
or

,
Mr.
Slope
's

.
<EOS>
"
If

really

Harding
,
"

,
"
he

other

.
<EOS>
Were

Harding
to
present

,
he

merely
be
playing
Mr.
Slope
's
game
;
"
and
thus

was
settled
that
nothing
should

done
till
the
great
Dr.
Gwynne
's
arrival
,
or
at
any
rate
without
that
potentate
's
