.
  
<EOS>
It
was
droll
to
observe
how
these
men
talked
of
Mr.
Harding
as
though
he
were
a
puppet
,
and
planned
their
intrigues
and
small
ecclesiastical
manoeuvres
in
reference
to
Mr.
Harding
's
future
position
without
dreaming
of
taking
him
into
their
confidence
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
comfortable
house
and
income
in
question
,
and
it
was
very
desirable
,
and
certainly
very
just
,
that
Mr.
Harding
should
have
them
;
but
that
at
present
was
not
the
main
point
;
it
was
expedient
to
beat
the
bishop
and
,
if
possible
,
to
smash
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
had
set
up
,
or
was
supposed
to
have
set
up
,
a
rival
candidate
.
<EOS>
Of
all
things
the
most
desirable
would
have
been
to
have
had
Mr.
Quiverful
's
appointment
published
to
the
public
and
then
annulled
by
the
clamour
of
an
indignant
world
,
loud
in
the
defence
of
Mr.
Harding
's
rights
.
<EOS>
But
of
such
an
event
the
chance
was
small
;
a
slight
fraction
only
of
the
world
would
be
indignant
,
and
that
fraction
would
be
one
not
accustomed
to
loud
speaking
.
<EOS>
And
then
the
preferment
had
,
in
a
sort
of
way
,
been
offered
to
Mr.
Harding
and
had
,
in
a
sort
of
way
,
been
refused
by
him
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
's
wicked
,
cunning
hand
had
been
peculiarly
conspicuous
in
the
way
in
which
this
had
been
brought
to
pass
,
and
it
was
the
success
of
Mr.
Slope
's
cunning
which
was
so
painfully
grating
to
the
feelings
of
the
archdeacon
.
<EOS>
That
which
of
all
things
he
most
dreaded
was
that
he
should
be
outgeneralled
by
Mr.
Slope
;
and
just
at
present
it
appeared
probable
that
Mr.
Slope
would
turn
his
flank
,
steal
a
march
on
him
,
cut
off
his
provisions
,
carry
his
strong
town
by
a
_
coup
de
main
_
,
and
at
last
beat
him
thoroughly
in
a
regular
pitched
battle
.
<EOS>
The
archdeacon
felt
that
his
flank
had
been
turned
when
desired
to
wait
on
Mr.
Slope
instead
of
the
bishop
,
that
a
march
had
been
stolen
when
Mr.
Harding
was
induced
to
refuse
the
bishop
's
offer
,
that
his
provisions
would
be
cut
off
when
Mr.
Quiverful
got
the
hospital
,
that
Eleanor
was
the
strong
town
doomed
to
be
taken
,
and
that
Mr.
Slope
,
as
Dean
of
Barchester
,
would
be
regarded
by
all
the
world
as
conqueror
in
the
final
conflict
.
  
<EOS>
Dr.
Gwynne
was
the
_
Deus
ex
machina
_
who
was
to
come
down
upon
the
Barchester
stage
and
bring
about
deliverance
from
these
terrible
evils
.
<EOS>
But
how
can
melodramatic
_
dénouements
_
be
properly
brought
about
,
how
can
vice
and
Mr.
Slope
be
punished
,
and
virtue
and
the
archdeacon
be
rewarded
,
while
the
avenging
god
is
laid
up
with
the
gout
?
<EOS>
In
the
mean
time
evil
may
be
triumphant
,
and
poor
innocence
,
transfixed
to
the
earth
by
an
arrow
from
Dr.
Proudie
's
quiver
,
may
lie
dead
upon
the
ground
,
not
to
be
resuscitated
even
by
Dr.
Gwynne
.
  
<EOS>
Two
or
three
days
after
Eleanor
's
departure
,
Mr.
Arabin
went
to
Oxford
and
soon
found
himself
closeted
with
the
august
head
of
his
college
.
<EOS>
It
was
quite
clear
that
Dr.
Gwynne
was
not
very
sanguine
as
to
the
effects
of
his
journey
to
Barchester
,
and
not
over
-
anxious
to
interfere
with
the
bishop
.
<EOS>
He
had
had
the
gout
,
but
was
very
nearly
convalescent
,
and
Mr.
Arabin
at
once
saw
that
had
the
mission
been
one
of
which
the
master
thoroughly
approved
,
he
would
before
this
have
been
at
Plumstead
.
  
<EOS>
As
it
was
,
Dr.
Gwynne
was
resolved
on
visiting
his
friend
,
and
willingly
promised
to
return
to
Barchester
with
Mr.
Arabin
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
bring
himself
to
believe
that
there
was
any
probability
that
Mr.
Slope
would
be
made
Dean
of
Barchester
.
<EOS>
Rumour
,
he
said
,
had
reached
even
his
ears
,
not
at
all
favourable
to
that
gentleman
's
character
,
and
he
expressed
himself
strongly
of
opinion
that
any
such
appointment
was
quite
out
of
the
question
.
<EOS>
At
this
stage
of
the
proceedings
,
the
master
's
right
-
hand
man
,
Tom
Staple
,
was
called
in
to
assist
at
the
conference
.
<EOS>
Tom
Staple
was
the
Tutor
of
Lazarus
and
,
moreover
,
a
great
man
at
Oxford
.
<EOS>
Though
universally
known
by
a
species
of
nomenclature
so
very
undignified
,
Tom
Staple
was
one
who
maintained
a
high
dignity
in
the
university
.
<EOS>
He
was
,
as
it
were
,
the
leader
of
the
Oxford
tutors
,
a
body
of
men
who
consider
themselves
collectively
as
being
by
very
little
,
if
at
all
,
second
in
importance
to
the
heads
themselves
.
<EOS>
It
is
not
always
the
case
that
the
master
,
or
warden
,
or
provost
,
or
principal
can
hit
it
off
exactly
with
his
tutor
.
<EOS>
A
tutor
is
by
no
means
indisposed
to
have
a
will
of
his
own
.
<EOS>
But
at
Lazarus
they
were
great
friends
and
firm
allies
at
the
time
of
which
we
are
writing
.
  
<EOS>
Tom
Staple
was
a
hale
,
strong
man
of
about
forty
-
five
,
short
in
stature
,
swarthy
in
face
,
<EOS>
with
strong
,
sturdy
black
hair
and
crisp
black
beard
of
which
very
little
was
allowed
to
show
itself
in
shape
of
whiskers
.
<EOS>
He
always
wore
a
white
neckcloth
,
clean
indeed
,
but
not
tied
with
that
scrupulous
care
which
now
distinguishes
some
of
our
younger
clergy
.
<EOS>
He
was
,
of
course
,
always
clothed
in
a
seemly
suit
of
solemn
black
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Staple
was
a
decent
cleanly
liver
,
not
over
-
addicted
to
any
sensuality
;
but
nevertheless
a
somewhat
warmish
hue
was
beginning
to
adorn
his
nose
,
the
peculiar
effect
,
as
his
friends
averred
,
of
a
certain
pipe
of
port
introduced
into
the
cellars
of
Lazarus
the
very
same
year
in
which
the
tutor
entered
it
as
a
freshman
.
<EOS>
There
was
also
,
perhaps
,
a
little
redolence
of
port
wine
,
as
it
were
the
slightest
possible
twang
,
in
Mr.
Staple
's
voice
.
  
<EOS>
In
these
latter
days
Tom
Staple
was
not
a
happy
man
;
university
reform
had
long
been
his
bugbear
,
and
now
was
his
bane
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
with
him
,
as
with
most
others
,
an
affair
of
politics
,
respecting
which
,
when
the
need
existed
,
he
could
,
for
parties
<EOS>
"
sake
or
on
behalf
of
principle
,
maintain
a
certain
amount
of
necessary
zeal
;
it
was
not
with
him
a
subject
for
dilettante
warfare
and
courteous
,
commonplace
opposition
.
<EOS>
To
him
it
was
life
and
death
.
<EOS>
The
_
status
quo
_
of
the
university
was
his
only
idea
of
life
,
and
any
reformation
was
as
bad
to
him
as
death
.
<EOS>
He
would
willingly
have
been
a
martyr
in
the
cause
,
had
the
cause
admitted
of
martyrdom
.
  
<EOS>
At
the
present
day
,
unfortunately
,
public
affairs
will
allow
of
no
martyrs
,
and
therefore
it
is
that
there
is
such
a
deficiency
of
zeal
.
<EOS>
Could
gentlemen
of
£
10,000
a
year
have
died
on
their
own
door
-
steps
in
defence
of
protection
,
no
doubt
some
half
-
dozen
glorious
old

would
have
so
fallen
,
and
the
school
of
protection
would
at
this
day
have
been
crowded
with
scholars
.
<EOS>
Who
can
fight
strenuously
in
any
combat
in
which
there
is
no
danger
?
<EOS>
Tom
Staple
would
have
willingly
been
impaled
before
a
Committee
of
the
House
,
could
he
by
such
self
-
sacrifice
have
infused
his
own

into
the
component
members
of
the
hebdomadal

.
  
<EOS>
Tom
Staple
was
one
of
those
who
in
his
heart
approved
of
the
credit
system
which
had
of
old
been
in
vogue
between
the
students
and

of

.
<EOS>
He
knew
and
acknowledged

that
it
was
useless
in
these
degenerate
days

to

"
The

"
on

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
Jupiter
"
had

,
and
Tom
Staple
was
well

that
"
The
Jupiter
"
was

.
<EOS>
But

,

,

that

of
credit
was
an
ordeal

for

.
  
<EOS>
The
bad
men
,
said
he
,
the
weak
and

,
blunder
into

and
burn
their

;
but
the

,
they
who

,
they

have
that

which
can
reflect

on

alma

,
they
come
through
scatheless
.
<EOS>
What

will

to
a

to
get
through
safely
,
if

be
guarded
and
protected
and

?
<EOS>
By

,
the
period
of
the
ordeal
is
only

,
and
the
manhood
of
the
man
will
be

from
the
age

twenty
to
that
of
twenty
-
four
.
<EOS>
If
you
bind
him
with
leading
-
strings
at

,
he
will
break

while
eating
for
the
bar
in
London
;
bind

,
and
he
will
break

,
when
he

.
<EOS>
The
wild

must
be
sown
somewhere
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Twas
thus
that
Tom
Staple
would
argue
of
young
men
,
not
,

,
with
much
consistency
,
but
still
with
some

of
the
subject

.
  
<EOS>
And

Tom
Staple
proffered
such

as

Dr.
Gwynne

.
  
<EOS>
"
Quite
out

,
"

,
arguing

Mr.
Slope

not

.
  
<EOS>
"
So

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"

"

,
"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
"

.

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

"

.

.
  
<EOS>

,
"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

rock
<EOS>
:

.

,
"

.
  
<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>
"

,

,

.
<EOS>

"

,

"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Dr.
Gwynne

,

,

,

,

,

,

therefrom

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

"

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
They

.
"
  
<EOS>
Dr.

,

not
the
less

.
<EOS>
If
Mr.
Harding
could
not

,
why

Barchester
?
  
<EOS>
And

ended
without

,
and

and

prepared
for

to

on

.
   
<EOS>
Miss
Thorne
's
Fête
Champêtre
 
<EOS>
The
day
of
the
Ullathorne
party
arrived
,
and
all
the
world
were
there
 
or
at
least
so
much
of
the
world
as
had
been
included
in
Miss
Thorne
's
invitation
.
<EOS>
As
we
have
said
,
the
bishop
returned
home
on
the
previous
evening
,
and
on
the
same
evening
and
by
the
same
train
came
Dr.
Gwynne
and
Mr.
Arabin
from
Oxford
.
<EOS>
The
archdeacon
with
his
brougham
was
in
waiting
for
the
Master
of
Lazarus
,
so
that
there
was
a
goodly
show
of
church
dignitaries
on
the
platform
of
the
railway
.
  
<EOS>
The
Stanhope
party
was
finally
arranged
in
the
odious
manner
already
described
,
and
Eleanor
got
into
the
doctor
's
carriage
full
of
apprehension
and
presentiment
of
further
misfortune
,
whereas
Mr.
Slope
entered
the
vehicle
elate
with
triumph
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
received
that
morning
a
very
civil
note
from
Sir
Nicholas
Fitzwhiggin
,
not
promising
much
,
indeed
,
but
then
Mr.
Slope
knew
,
or
fancied
that
he
knew
,
that
it
was
not
etiquette
for
government
officers
to
make
promises
.
<EOS>
Though
Sir
Nicholas
promised
nothing
he
implied
a
good
deal
,
declared
his
conviction
that
Mr.
Slope
would
make
an
excellent
dean
,
and
wished
him
every
kind
of
success
.
<EOS>
To
be
sure
he
added
that
,
not
being
in
the
cabinet
,
he
was
never
consulted
on
such
matters
,
and
that
even
if
he
spoke
on
the
subject
,
his
voice
would
go
for
nothing
.
<EOS>
But
all
this
Mr.
Slope
took
for
the
prudent
reserve
of
official
life
.
<EOS>
To
complete
his
anticipated
triumphs
,
another
letter
was
brought
to
him
just
as
he
was
about
to
start
to
Ullathorne
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
also
enjoyed
the
idea
of
handing
Mrs.
Bold
out
of
Dr.
Stanhope
's
carriage
before
the
multitude
at
Ullathorne
gate
as
much
as
Eleanor
dreaded
the
same
ceremony
.
<EOS>
He
had
fully
made
up
his
mind
to
throw
himself
and
his
fortune
at
the
widow
's
feet
,
and
had
almost
determined
to
select
the
present
propitious
morning
for
doing
so
.
<EOS>
The
signora
had
of
late
been
less
than
civil
to
him
.
<EOS>
She
had
indeed
admitted
his
visits
and
listened
,
at
any
rate
without
anger
,
to
his
love
,
but
she
had
tortured
him
and
reviled
him
,
jeered
at
him
and
ridiculed
him
,
while
she
allowed
him
to
call
her
the
most
beautiful
of
living
women
,
to
kiss
her
hand
,
and
to
proclaim
himself
with
reiterated
oaths
her
adorer
,
her
slave
and
worshipper
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Thorne
was
in
great
perturbation
,
yet
in
great
glory
,
on
the
morning
of
the
gala
day
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Thorne
also
,
though
the
party
was
none
of
his
giving
,
had
much
heavy
work
on
his
hands
.
<EOS>
But
perhaps
the
most
overtasked
,
the
most
anxious
,
and
the
most
effective
of
all
the
Ullathorne
household
was
Mr.
Plomacy
,
the
steward
.
<EOS>
This
last
personage
had
,
in
the
time
of
Mr.
Thorne
's
father
,
when
the
Directory
held
dominion
in
France
,
gone
over
to
Paris
with
letters
in
his
boot
-
heel
for
some
of
the
royal
party
,
and
such
had
been
his
good
luck
that
he
had
returned
safe
.
<EOS>
He
had
then
been
very
young
and
was
now
very
old
,
but
the
exploit
gave
him
a
character
for
political
enterprise
and
secret
discretion
which
still
availed
him
as
thoroughly
as
it
had
done
in
its
freshest
gloss
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Plomacy
had
been
steward
of
Ullathorne
for
more
than
fifty
years
,
and
a
very
easy
life
he
had
had
of
it
.
<EOS>
Who
could
require
much
absolute
work
from
a
man
who
had
carried
safely
at
his
heel
that
which
,
if
discovered
,
would
have
cost
him
his
head
?
<EOS>
Consequently
Mr.
Plomacy
had
never
worked
hard
,
and
of
latter
years
had
never
worked
at
all
.
<EOS>
He
had
a
taste
for
timber
,
and
therefore
he
marked
the
trees
that
were
to
be
cut
down
;
he
had
a
taste
for
gardening
,
and
would
therefore
allow
no
shrub
to
be
planted
or
bed
to
be
made
without
his
express
sanction
.
<EOS>
In
these
matters
he
was
sometimes
driven
to
run
counter
to
his
mistress
,
but
he
rarely
allowed
his
mistress
to
carry
the
point
against
him
.
  
<EOS>
But
on
occasions
such
as
the
present
Mr.
Plomacy
came
out
strong
.
<EOS>
He
had
the
honour
of
the
family
at
heart
;
he
thoroughly
appreciated
the
duties
of
hospitality
;
and
therefore
,
when
gala
doings
were
going
on
,
he
always
took
the
management
into
his
own
hands
and
reigned
supreme
over
master
and
mistress
.
  
<EOS>
To
give
Mr.
Plomacy
his
due
,
old
as
he
was
,
he
thoroughly
understood
such
work
as
he
had
in
hand
,
and
did
it
well
.
  
<EOS>
The
order
of
the
day
was
to
be
as
follows
.
<EOS>
The
quality
,
as
the
upper
classes
in
rural
districts
are
designated
by
the
lower
with
so
much
true
discrimination
,
were
to
eat
a
breakfast
,
and
the
non
-
quality
were
to
eat
a
dinner
.
<EOS>
Two
marquees
had
been
erected
for
these
two
banquets
:
that
for
the
quality
on
the
esoteric
or
garden
side
of
a
certain
deep
ha
-
ha
;
and
that
for
the
non
-
quality
on
the
exoteric
or
paddock
side
of
the
same
.
<EOS>
Both
were
of
huge
dimensions
 
that
on
the
outer
side
was
,
one
may
say
,
on
an
egregious
scale
 
but
Mr.
Plomacy
declared
that
neither
would
be
sufficient
.
<EOS>
To
remedy
this
,
an
auxiliary
banquet
was
prepared
in
the
dining
-
room
,
and
a
subsidiary
board
was
to
be
spread
_
sub
dio
_
for
the
accommodation
of
the
lower
class
of
yokels
on
the
Ullathorne
property
.
  
<EOS>
No
one
who
has
not
had
a
hand
in
the
preparation
of
such
an
affair
can
understand
the
manifold
difficulties
which
Miss
Thorne
encountered
in
her
project
.
<EOS>
Had
she
not
been
made
throughout
of
the
very
finest
whalebone
,
riveted
with
the
best
Yorkshire
steel
,
she
must
have
sunk
under
them
.
<EOS>
Had
not
Mr.
Plomacy
felt
how
much
was
justly
expected
from
a
man
who
at
one
time
carried
the
destinies
of
Europe
in
his
boot
,
he
would
have
given
way
,
and
his
mistress
,
so
deserted
,
must
have
perished
among
her
poles
and
canvas
.
  
<EOS>
In
the
first
place
there
was
a
dreadful
line
to
be
drawn
.
<EOS>
Who
were
to
dispose
themselves
within
the
ha
-
ha
,
and
who
without
?
<EOS>
To
this
the
unthinking
will
give
an
off
-
hand
answer
,
as
they
will
to
every
ponderous
question
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
the
bishop
and
such
-
like
within
the
ha
-
ha
,
and
Farmer
Greenacre
and
such
-
like
without
.
<EOS>
True
,
my
unthinking
friend
,
but
who
shall
define
these
such
-
likes
?
<EOS>
It
is
in
such
definitions
that
the
whole
difficulty
of
society
consists
.
<EOS>
To
seat
the
bishop
on
an
arm
-
chair
on
the
lawn
and
place
Farmer
Greenacre
at
the
end
of
a
long
table
in
the
paddock
is
easy
enough
,
but
where
will
you
put
Mrs.
Lookaloft
,
whose
husband
,
though
a
tenant
on
the
estate
,
hunts
in
a
red
coat
,
whose
daughters
go
to
a
fashionable
seminary
in
Barchester
,
who
calls
her
farm
-
house
Rosebank
,
and
who
has
a
pianoforte
in
her
drawing
-
room
?
<EOS>
The
Misses
Lookaloft
,
as
they
call
themselves
,
wo
n't
sit
contented
among
the
bumpkins
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Lookaloft
wo
n't
squeeze
her
fine
clothes
on
a
bench
and
talk
familiarly
about
cream
and
ducklings
to
good
Mrs.
Greenacre
.
<EOS>
And
yet
Mrs.
Lookaloft
is
no
fit
companion
and
never
has
been
the
associate
of
the
Thornes
and
the
Grantlys
.
<EOS>
And
if
Mrs.
Lookaloft
be
admitted
within
the
sanctum
of
fashionable
life
,
if
she
be
allowed
with
her
three
daughters
to
leap
the
ha
-
ha
,
why
not
the
wives
and
daughters
of
other
families
also
?
<EOS>
Mrs.
Greenacre
is
at
present
well
contented
with
the
paddock
,
but
she
might
cease
to
be
so
if
she
saw
Mrs.
Lookaloft
on
the
lawn
.
<EOS>
And
thus
poor
Miss
Thorne
had
a
hard
time
of
it
.
  
<EOS>
And
how
was
she
to
divide
her
guests
between
the
marquee
and
the
parlour
?
<EOS>
She
had
a
countess
coming
,
an
Honourable
John
and
an
Honourable
George
,
and
a
whole
bevy
of
Ladies
Amelia
,
Rosina
,
Margaretta
,
&
c
;
she
had
a
leash
of
baronets
with
their
baronettes
;
and
,
as
we
all
know
,
she
had
a
bishop
.
<EOS>
If
she
put
them
on
the
lawn
,
no
one
would
go
into
the
parlour
;
if
she
put
them
into
the
parlour
,
no
one
would
go
into
the
tent
.
<EOS>
She
thought
of
keeping
the
old
people
in
the
house
and
leaving
the
lawn
to
the
lovers
.
<EOS>
She
might
as
well
have
seated
herself
at
once
in
a
hornet
's
nest
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Plomacy
knew
better
than
this
.
"
<EOS>
Bless
your
soul
,
ma'am
,
"
said
he
,
"
there
wo
n't
be
no
old
ladies
 
not
one
,
barring
yourself
and
old
Mrs.
Clantantram
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Personally
Miss
Thorne
accepted
this
distinction
in
her
favour
as
a
compliment
to
her
good
sense
,
but
nevertheless
she
had
no
desire
to
be
closeted
on
the
coming
occasion
with
Mrs.
Clantantram
.
<EOS>
She
gave
up
all
idea
of
any
arbitrary
division
of
her
guests
and
determined
if
possible
to
put
the
bishop
on
the
lawn
and
the
countess
in
the
house
,
to
sprinkle
the
baronets
,
and
thus
divide
the
attractions
.
<EOS>
What
to
do
with
the
Lookalofts
even
Mr.
Plomacy
could
not
decide
.
<EOS>
They
must
take
their
chance
.
<EOS>
They
had
been
specially
told
in
the
invitation
that
all
the
tenants
had
been
invited
,
and
they
might
probably
have
the
good
sense
to
stay
away
if
they
objected
to
mix
with
the
rest
of
the
tenantry
.
  
<EOS>
Then
Mr.
Plomacy
declared
his
apprehension
that
the
Honourable
Johns
and
Honourable
Georges
would
come
in
a
sort
of
amphibious
costume
,
half
-
morning
,
half
-
evening
,
satin
neck
-
handkerchiefs
,
frock
-
coats
,
primrose
gloves
,
and
polished
boots
;
and
that
,
being
so
dressed
,
they
would
decline
riding
at
the
quintain
,
or
taking
part
in
any
of
the
athletic
games
which
Miss
Thorne
had
prepared
with
so
much
fond
care
.
<EOS>
If
the
Lord
Johns
and
Lord
Georges
did
n't
ride
at
the
quintain
,
Miss
Thorne
might
be
sure
that
nobody
else
would
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
,
"
said
she
in
dolorous
voice
,
all
but
overcome
by
her
cares
,
"
it
was
specially
signified
that
there
were
to
be
sports
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
so
there
will
be
,
of
course
,
"
said
Mr.
Plomacy
.
<EOS>
"
They
'll
all
be
sporting
with
the
young
ladies
in
the
laurel
walks
.
<EOS>
Them
's
the
sports
they
care
most
about
now
-
a
-
days
.
<EOS>
If
you
gets
the
young
men
at
the
quintain
,
you
'll
have
all
the
young
women
in
the
pouts
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Ca
n't
they
look
on
as
their
great
grandmothers
did
before
them
?
"
said
Miss
Thorne
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
seems
to
me
that
the
ladies
ai
n't
contented
with
looking
now
-
a
-
days
.
<EOS>
Whatever
the
men
do
they
'll
do
.
<EOS>
If
you
'll
have
side
-
saddles
on
the
nags
;
and
let
them
go
at
the
quintain
too
,
it
'll
answer
capital
,
no
doubt
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Miss
Thorne
made
no
reply
.
<EOS>
She
felt
that
she
had
no
good
ground
on
which
to
defend
her
sex
of
the
present
generation
from
the
sarcasm
of
Mr.
Plomacy
.
<EOS>
She
had
once
declared
,
in
one
of
her
warmer
moments
,
"
that
now
-
a
-
days
the
gentlemen
were
all
women
,
and
the
ladies
all
men
.
<EOS>
"
She
could
not
alter
the
debased
character
of
the
age
.
<EOS>
But
,
such
being
the
case
,
why
should
she
take
on
herself
to
cater
for
the
amusement
of
people
of
such
degraded
tastes
?
<EOS>
This
question
she
asked
herself
more
than
once
,
and
she
could
only
answer
herself
with
a
sigh
.
<EOS>
There
was
her
own
brother
Wilfred
,
on
whose
shoulders
rested
all
the
ancient
honours
of
Ullathorne
house
;
it
was
very
doubtful
whether
even
he
would
consent
to
"
go
at
the
quintain
,
"
as
Mr.
Plomacy
not
injudiciously
expressed
it
.
  
<EOS>
And
now
the
morning
arrived
.
<EOS>
The
Ullathorne
household
was
early
on
the
move
.
<EOS>
Cooks
were
cooking
in
the
kitchen
long
before
daylight
,
and
men
were
dragging
out
tables
and
hammering
red
baize
on
to
benches
at
the
earliest
dawn
.
<EOS>
With
what
dread
eagerness
did
Miss
Thorne
look
out
at
the
weather
as
soon
as
the
parting
veil
of
night
permitted
her
to
look
at
all
!
<EOS>
In
this
respect
,
at
any
rate
,
there
was
nothing
to
grieve
her
.
<EOS>
The
glass
had
been
rising
for
the
last
three
days
,
and
the
morning
broke
with
that
dull
,
chill
,
steady
,
grey
haze
which
in
autumn
generally
presages
a
clear
and
dry
day
.
<EOS>
By
seven
she
was
dressed
and
down
.
<EOS>
Miss
Thorne
knew
nothing
of
the
modern
luxury
of
_
déshabilles
_
.
<EOS>
She
would
as
soon
have
thought
of
appearing
before
her
brother
without
her
stockings
as
without
her
stays
 
and
Miss
Thorne
's
stays
were
no
trifle
.
  
<EOS>
And
yet
there
was
nothing
for
her
to
do
when
down
.
<EOS>
She
fidgeted
out
to
the
lawn
and
then
back
into
the
kitchen
.
<EOS>
She
put
on
her
high
-
heeled
clogs
and
fidgeted
out
into
the
paddock
.
<EOS>
Then
she
went
into
the
small
home
park
where
the
quintain
was
erected
.
<EOS>
The
pole
and
cross
-
bar
and
the
swivel
and
the
target
and
the
bag
of
flour
were
all
complete
.
<EOS>
She
got
up
on
a
carpenter
's
bench
and
touched
the
target
with
her
hand
;
it
went
round
with
beautiful
ease
;
the
swivel
had
been
oiled
to
perfection
.
<EOS>
She
almost
wished
to
take
old
Plomacy
at
his
word
,
to
get
on
a
side
-
saddle
and
have
a
tilt
at
it
herself
.
<EOS>
What
must
a
young
man
be
,
thought
she
,
who
could
prefer
maundering
among
laurel
trees
with
a
wishy
-
washy
school
-
girl
to
such
fun
as
this
?
"
<EOS>
Well
,
"
said
she
aloud
to
herself
,
"
one
man
can
take
a
horse
to
water
,
but
a
thousand
ca
n't
make
him
drink
.
<EOS>
There
it
is
.
<EOS>
If
they
have
n't
the
spirit
to
enjoy
it
,
the
fault
sha
n't
be
mine
;
"
and
so
she
returned
to
the
house
.
  
<EOS>
At
a
little
after
eight
her
brother
came
down
,
and
they
had
a
sort
of
scrap
breakfast
in
his
study
.
<EOS>
The
tea
was
made
without
the
customary
urn
,
and
they
dispensed
with
the
usual
rolls
and
toast
.
<EOS>
Eggs
also
were
missing
,
for
every
egg
in
the
parish
had
been
whipped
into
custards
,
baked
into
pies
,
or
boiled
into
lobster
salad
.
<EOS>
The
allowance
of
fresh
butter
was
short
,
and
Mr.
Thorne
was
obliged
to
eat
the
leg
of
a
fowl
without
having
it
devilled
in
the
manner
he
loved
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
looking
at
the
quintain
,
Wilfred
,
"
said
she
,
"
and
it
appears
to
be
quite
right
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
 
ah
,
yes
,
"
said
he
.
<EOS>
"
It
seemed
to
be
so
yesterday
when
I
saw
it
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Thorne
was
beginning
to
be
rather
bored
by
his
sister
's
love
of
sports
,
and
had
especially
no
affection
for
this
quintain
post
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
wish
you
'd
just
try
it
after
breakfast
,
"
said
she
.
<EOS>
"
You
could
have
the
saddle
put
on
Mark
Antony
,
and
the
pole
is
there
all
handy
.
<EOS>
You
can
take
the
flour
bag
off
,
you
know
,
if
you
think
Mark
Antony
wo
n't
be
quick
enough
,
"
added
Miss
Thorne
,
seeing
that
her
brother
's
countenance
was
not
indicative
of
complete
accordance
with
her
little
proposition
.
  
<EOS>
Now
Mark
Antony
was
a
valuable
old
hunter
,
excellently
suited
to
Mr.
Thorne
's
usual
requirements
,
steady
indeed
at
his
fences
,
but
extremely
sure
,
very
good
in
deep
ground
,
and
safe
on
the
roads
.
<EOS>
But
he
had
never
yet
been
ridden
at
a
quintain
,
and
Mr.
Thorne
was
not
inclined
to
put
him
to
the
trial
,
either
with
or
without
the
bag
of
flour
.
<EOS>
He
hummed
and
hawed
and
finally
declared
that
he
was
afraid
Mark
Antony
would
shy
.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
try
the
cob
,
"
said
the
indefatigable
Miss
Thorne
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
's
in
physic
,
"
said
Wilfred
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
's
the
Beelzebub
colt
,
"
said
his
sister
.
<EOS>
"
I
know
he
's
in
the
stable
because
I
saw
Peter
exercising
him
just
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Monica
,
he
's
so
wild
that
it
's
as
much
as
I
can
do
to
manage
him
at
all
.
<EOS>
He
'd
destroy
himself
and
me
,
too
,
if
I
attempted
to
ride
him
at
such
a
rattletrap
as
that
.
"
  
<EOS>
A
rattletrap
!
<EOS>
The
quintain
that
she
had
put
up
with
so
much
anxious
care
;
the
game
that
she
had
prepared
for
the
amusement
of
the
stalwart
yeomen
of
the
country
;
the
sport
that
had
been
honoured
by
the
affection
of
so
many
of
their
ancestors
!
<EOS>
It
cut
her
to
the
heart
to
hear
it
so
denominated
by
her
own
brother
.
<EOS>
There
were
but
the
two
of
them
left
together
in
the
world
,
and
it
had
ever
been
one
of
the
rules
by
which
Miss
Thorne
had
regulated
her
conduct
through
life
to
say
nothing
that
could
provoke
her
brother
.
<EOS>
She
had
often
had
to
suffer
from
his
indifference
to
time
-
honoured
British
customs
,
but
she
had
always
suffered
in
silence
.
<EOS>
It
was
part
of
her
creed
that
the
head
of
the
family
should
never
be
upbraided
in
his
own
house
,
and
Miss
Thorne
had
lived
up
to
her
creed
.
<EOS>
Now
,
however
,
she
was
greatly
tried
.
<EOS>
The
colour
mounted
to
her
ancient
cheek
,
and
the
fire
blazed
in
her
still
bright
eyes
;
but
yet
she
said
nothing
.
<EOS>
She
resolved
that
,
at
any
rate
,
to
him
nothing
more
should
be
said
about
the
quintain
that
day
.
  
<EOS>
She
sipped
her
tea
in
silent
sorrow
and
thought
with
painful
regret
of
the
glorious
days
when
her
great
ancestor
Ealfried
had
successfully
held
Ullathorne
against
a
Norman
invader
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
such
spirit
now
left
in
her
family
except
that
small
useless
spark
which
burnt
in
her
own
bosom
.
<EOS>
And
she
herself
,
was
not
she
at
this
moment
intent
on
entertaining
a
descendant
of
those
very
Normans
,
a
vain
proud
countess
with
a
Frenchified
name
who
would
only
think
that
she
graced
Ullathorne
too
highly
by
entering
its
portals
?
<EOS>
Was
it
likely
that
an
Honourable
John
,
the
son
of
an
Earl
De
Courcy
,
should
ride
at
a
quintain
in
company
with
Saxon
yeomen
?
<EOS>
And
why
should
she
expect
her
brother
to
do
that
which
her
brother
's
guests
would
decline
to
do
?
  
<EOS>
Some
dim
faint
idea
of
the
impracticability
of
her
own
views
flitted
across
her
brain
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
it
was
necessary
that
races
doomed
to
live
on
the
same
soil
should
give
way
to
each
other
and
adopt
each
other
's
pursuits
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
it
was
impossible
that
after
more
than
five
centuries
of
close
intercourse
,
Normans
should
remain
Normans
,
and
Saxons
,
Saxons
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
,
after
all
,
her
neighbours
were
wiser
than
herself
.
<EOS>
Such
ideas
did
occasionally
present
themselves
to
Miss
Thorne
's
mind
and
make
her
sad
enough
.
<EOS>
But
it
never
occurred
to
her
that
her
favourite
quintain
was
but
a
modern
copy
of
a
Norman
knight
's
amusement
,
an
adaptation
of
the
noble
tourney
to
the
tastes
and
habits
of
the
Saxon
yeomen
.
<EOS>
Of
this
she
was
ignorant
,
and
it
would
have
been
cruelty
to
instruct
her
.
  
<EOS>
When
Mr.
Thorne
saw
the
tear
in
her
eye
,
he
repented
himself
of
his
contemptuous
expression
.
<EOS>
By
him
also
it
was
recognized
as
a
binding
law
that
every
whim
of
his
sister
was
to
be
respected
.
<EOS>
He
was
not
perhaps
so
firm
in
his
observances
to
her
as
she
was
in
hers
to
him
.
<EOS>
But
his
intentions
were
equally
good
,
and
whenever
he
found
that
he
had
forgotten
them
,
it
was
matter
of
grief
to
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Monica
,
"
said
he
,
"
I
beg
your
pardon
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
in
the
least
mean
to
speak
ill
of
the
game
.
<EOS>
When
I
called
it
a
rattletrap
,
I
merely
meant
that
it
was
so
for
a
man
of
my
age
.
<EOS>
You
know
you
always
forget
that
I
an't
a
young
man
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
quite
sure
you
are
not
an
old
man
,
Wilfred
,
"
said
she
,
accepting
the
apology
in

and

.
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
was
five
-
and
-
twenty
,
or
thirty
,
"
continued

,
"
I
should
like

better
than
riding

the
quintain
all

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
are
not
too
old
to
hunt
or

shoot
,
"
said
she
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
can
jump
over
a

and

,
I
am
sure
you
could
turn
the
quintain

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
when
I
ride
over
the
hedges
,
my
dear
 
<EOS>
and
it
is
n't
very
often
<EOS>
I
do
that
 
<EOS>
but
when
I
do
ride
over
the
hedges
,
there
is
n't
any
bag
of
flour
coming
after

.
<EOS>
Think
how
I
'd
look
taking
the
countess
out
to
breakfast
with
the
back
of
my
head
all
covered

meal
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Miss
,
Thorne
said
nothing
further
.
<EOS>
She
did
n't
like
the
allusion
to
the
countess
.
<EOS>
She
could
n't
be
satisfied
with
the
reflection
that
the
sports
at
Ullathorne
should
be
interfered

by
the
personal
attentions
necessary
for
a
Lady
De
Courcy
.
<EOS>
But
she
saw
that
it
was
useless
for
her
to
push
the
matter
further
.
<EOS>
It
was
conceded
that
Mr.
Thorne
was
to
be
spared
the
quintain
,
and
Miss
Thorne
determined
to
trust
wholly
to
a
youthful
knight
of
hers
,
an
immense
favourite
,
who
,
as
she
often
declared
,
was
a
pattern
to
the
young
men
of
the
age
and
an
excellent

of
an
English

.
  
<EOS>
This
was
Farmer
Greenacre
's
eldest
son
,
who
,
to
tell

truth
,
had
from
his
earliest
years
taken
the
exact
measure
of
Miss
Thorne
's
foot
.
<EOS>
In
his
boyhood
he
had
never
failed
to
obtain
from
her
apples
,
pocket
-
money
,
and
forgiveness
for
his
numerous
trespasses
;
and
now
in
his
early
manhood
he
got
privileges
and
immunities
which
were
equally
valuable
.
<EOS>
He
was
allowed
a
day
or
two
's
shooting
in
September
;
he
schooled
the
squire
's

;
got
slips
of
trees
out
of
the
orchard
and
roots
of
flowers
out
of
the
garden
;
and
had
the
fishing
of
the
little
river
altogether
in
his
own
hands
.
<EOS>
He
had
undertaken
to
come
mounted
on
a
nag
of
his
father
's
and
show
the
way
at
the
quintain
post
.
<EOS>
Whatever
young
Greenacre
did
the
others
would
do
after
him
.
<EOS>
The
juvenile
Lookalofts
might
stand
aloof
,
but
the
rest
of
the
youth
of
Ullathorne
would
be
sure
to
venture
if
Harry
Greenacre
showed
the
way
.
<EOS>
And
so
Miss
Thorne
made
up
her
mind
to
dispense
with
the
noble
Johns
and
Georges
and
trust
,
as
her
ancestors
had
done
before
her
,
to
the
thews
and

of
native
Ullathorne
growth
.
  
<EOS>
At
about
nine
the
lower
orders
began
to
congregate
in
the
paddock
and
park
,
under
the
surveillance
of
Mr.
Plomacy
and
the
head

and
head

,
who
were
sworn
in
as
his
deputies
and
were
to
assist
him
in
keeping
the
peace
and
promoting
the
sports
.
<EOS>
Many
of
the
younger
inhabitants
of
the
neighbourhood
,
thinking
that
they
could
not
have
too
much
of
a
good
thing
,
had
come
at
a
very
early
hour
,
and
the
road
between
the
house
and
the
church
had
been
thronged
for
some
time
before
the
gates
were
thrown
open
.
  
<EOS>
And
then
another
difficulty
of
huge
dimensions
arose
,
a
difficulty
which
Mr.
Plomacy
had
indeed
foreseen
and
for
which
he
was
in
some
sort
provided
.
<EOS>
Some
of
those
who
wished
to
share
Miss
Thorne
's
hospitality
were
not
so
particular
as
they
should
have
been
as
to
the
preliminary
ceremony
of
an
invitation
.
<EOS>
They
doubtless
conceived
that
they
had
been
overlooked
by
accident
,
and
instead
of
taking
this
in
dudgeon
,
as
their
betters
would
have
done
,
they
good
-
naturedly
put
up
with
the
slight
,
and
showed
that
they
did
so
by
presenting
themselves
at
the
gate
in
their
Sunday
best
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Plomacy
,
however
,
well
-
knew
who
were
welcome
and
who
were
not
.
<EOS>
To
some
,
even
though
uninvited
,
he
allowed
ingress
.
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
be
too
particular
,
Plomacy
,
"
his
mistress
had
said
,
"
especially
with
the
children
.
<EOS>
If
they
live
anywhere
near
,
let
them
in
.
"
  
<EOS>
Acting
on
this
hint
,
Mr.
Plomacy
did
let
in
many
an
eager
urchin
and
a
few
tidily
dressed
girls
with
their
swains
who
in
no
way
belonged
to
the
property
.
<EOS>
But
to
the
denizens
of
the
city
he
was
inexorable
.
<EOS>
Many
a
Barchester
apprentice
made
his
appearance
there
that
day
and
urged
with
piteous
supplication
that
he
had
been
working
all
the
week
in
making
saddles
and
boots
for
the
use
of
Ullathorne
,
in
compounding
doses
for
the
horses
,
or
cutting
up
carcasses
for
the
kitchen
.
<EOS>
No
such
claim
was
allowed
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Plomacy
knew
nothing
about
the
city
apprentices
;
he
was
to
admit
the
tenants
and
labourers
on
the
estate
;
Miss
Thorne
was
n't
going
to
take
in
the
whole
city
of
Barchester
;
and
so
on
.
  
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,
before
the
day
was
half
over
,
all
this
was
found
to
be
useless
.
<EOS>
Almost
anybody
who
chose
to
come
made
his
way
into
the
park
,
and
the
care
of
the
guardians
was
transferred
to
the

on
which
the

was
spread
.
<EOS>
Even
here
there
was
many
an
unauthorised
claimant
for
a
place
,
of
whom
it
was
impossible
to
get

without
more
commotion
than
the
place
and

.
   
<EOS>
Ullathorne
Sports
 
<EOS>
Act
<EOS>
I
 
<EOS>
The
trouble
in
civilized
life
of
entertaining
company
,
as
it
is
called
too
generally
without
much
regard
to
strict
veracity
,
is
so
great
that
it
can
not
but
be
matter
of
wonder
that
people
are
so
fond
of
attempting
it
.
<EOS>
It
is
difficult
to
ascertain
what
is
the
_
quid
pro
quo
_
.
<EOS>
If
they
who
give
such
laborious
parties
,
and
who
endure
such
toil
and
turmoil
in
the
vain
hope
of
giving
them
successfully
,
really
enjoyed
the
parties
given
by
others
,
the
matter
could
be
understood
.
<EOS>
A
sense
of
justice
would
induce
men
and
women
to
undergo
,
in
behalf
of
others
,
those
miseries
which
others
had
undergone
in
their
behalf
.
<EOS>
But
they
all
profess
that
going
out
is
as
great
a
bore
as
receiving
,
and
to
look
at
them
when
they
are
out
,
one
can
not
but
believe
them
.
  
<EOS>
Entertain
!
<EOS>
Who
shall
have
sufficient
self
-
assurance
,
who
shall
feel
sufficient
confidence
in
his
own
powers
to
dare
to
boast
that
he
can
entertain
his
company
?
<EOS>
A
clown
can
sometimes
do
so
,
and
sometimes
a
dancer
in
short
petticoats
and
stuffed
pink
legs
;
occasionally
,
perhaps
,
a
singer
.
<EOS>
But
beyond
these
,
success
in
this
art
of
entertaining
is
not
often
achieved
.
<EOS>
Young
men
and
girls
linking
themselves
kind
with
kind
,
pairing
like
birds
in
spring
because
nature
wills
it
<EOS>
,
they
,
after
a
simple
fashion
,
do
entertain
each
other
.
<EOS>
Few
others
even
try
.
  
<EOS>
Ladies
,
when
they
open
their
houses
,
modestly
confessing
,
it
may
be
presumed
,
their
own
incapacity
,
mainly
trust
to
wax
candles
and
upholstery
.
<EOS>
Gentlemen
seem
to
rely
on
their
white
waistcoats
.
<EOS>
To
these
are
added
,
for
the
delight
of
the
more
sensual
,
champagne
and
such
good
things
of
the
table
as
fashion
allows
to
be
still
considered
as
comestible
.
<EOS>
Even
in
this
respect
the
world
is
deteriorating
.
<EOS>
All
the
good
soups
are
now
tabooed
,
and
at
the
houses
of
one
's
accustomed
friends
 
small
barristers
,
doctors
,
government
clerks
,
and
such
-
like
(
for
we
can
not
all
of
us
always
live
as
grandees
,
surrounded
by
an
elysium
of
livery
servants
)
 
<EOS>
one
gets
a
cold
potato
handed
to
one
as
a
sort
of
finale
to
one
's
slice
of
mutton
.
<EOS>
Alas
for
those
happy
days
when
one
could
say
to
one
's
neighbour
,
"
Jones
,
shall
I
give
you
some
mashed
turnip
?
<EOS>
May
I
trouble
you
for
a
little
cabbage
?
"
<EOS>
And
then
the
pleasure
of
drinking
wine
with
Mrs.
Jones
and
Miss
Smith
 
with
all
the
Joneses
and
all
the
Smiths
!
<EOS>
These
latter
-
day
habits
are
certainly
more
economical
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Thorne
,
however
,
boldly
attempted
to
leave
the
modern
,
beaten
track
,
and
made
a
positive
effort
to
entertain
her
guests
.
<EOS>
Alas
!
<EOS>
She
did
so
with
but
moderate
success
.
<EOS>
They
had
all
their
own
way
of
going
,
and
would
not
go
her
way
.
<EOS>
She
piped
to
them
,
but
they
would
not
dance
.
<EOS>
She
offered
to
them
good
,
honest
household
cake
made
of
currants
and
flour
and
eggs
and
sweetmeat
,
but
they
would
feed
themselves
on
trashy
wafers
from
the
shop
of
the
Barchester
pastry
-
cook
,
on
chalk
and
gum
and
adulterated
sugar
.
<EOS>
Poor
Miss
Thorne
!
<EOS>
Yours
is
not
the
first
honest
soul
that
has
vainly
striven
to
recall
the
glories
of
happy
days
gone
by
!
<EOS>
If
fashion
suggests
to
a
Lady
De
Courcy
that
,
when
invited
to
a
_
déjeuner
_
at
twelve
she
ought
to
come
at
three
,
no
eloquence
of
thine
will
teach
her
the
advantage
of
a
nearer
approach
to
punctuality
.
  
<EOS>
She
had
fondly
thought
that
when
she
called
on
her
friends
to
come
at
twelve
,
and
specially
begged
them
to
believe
that
she
meant
it
,
she
would
be
able
to
see
them
comfortably
seated
in
their
tents
at
two
.
<EOS>
Vain
woman
 
or
rather
ignorant
woman
 
ignorant
of
the
advances
of
that
civilization
which
the
world
had
witnessed
while
she
was
growing
old
.
<EOS>
At
twelve
she
found
herself
alone
,
dressed
in
all
the
glory
of
the
newest
of
her
many
suits
of
raiment
 
with
strong
shoes
however
,
and
a
serviceable
bonnet
on
her
head
,
and
a
warm
,
rich
shawl
on
her

.
<EOS>
Thus
clad
,
she
peered
out
into
the
tent
,
went
to
the
ha
-
ha
,
and
satisfied
herself
that
at
any
rate
the
youngsters
were
amusing
themselves
,
spoke
a
word
to
Mrs.
Greenacre
over
the
ditch
,
and
took
one
look
at
the
quintain
.
<EOS>
Three
or
four
young
farmers
were
turning
the
machine
round
and
round
and
poking
at
the
bag
of
flour
in
a
manner
not
at
all
intended
by
the
inventor
of
the
game
;
but
no
mounted
sportsmen
were
there
.
<EOS>
Miss
Thorne
looked
at
her
watch
.
<EOS>
It
was
only
fifteen
minutes
past
twelve
,
and
it
was
understood
that
Harry
Greenacre
was
not
to
begin
till
the
half
-
hour
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Thorne
returned
to
her
drawing
-
room
rather
quicker
than
was
her
wo
nt
,
fearing
that
the
countess
might
come
and
find
none
to

.
<EOS>
She
need
not
have
hurried
,
for
no
one
was
there
.
<EOS>
At
half
-
past
twelve
she
peeped
into
the

;
at
a
quarter
to
one
she
was

by

brother
;
and
just
then
the
first
fashionable
arrival
took

.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Clantantram
was
announced
.
  
<EOS>
No

was
necessary
,
indeed
,
for
the
good

's

was

to

,

who

from
Barchester
.
<EOS>
At

Thorne
could
not

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Miss
Thorne
,
look
here
!
"
said

as

in

;
"
do
look
at
my
roque
-

.
<EOS>
It
's
clean

,
and
forever
.
<EOS>
I
would
n't
but
wear
it
because
I
knew
you
wished
us
all
to
be
grand
to
-
day
,
and
yet
I
had
my
misgivings
.
<EOS>
Oh
dear
,
oh
dear
!
<EOS>
It
was
five
-
and
-
twenty
shillings
a
yard
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
Barchester
post
-
horses
had
misbehaved
in
some

just
as
Mrs.
Clantantram
was
getting
out
of
the

and
had

.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Clantantram
belonged
to
other
days
,
and
therefore
,

she
had
but
little
else
to

,

was

.
<EOS>
She

-

away

,
and
lent

one

.
  
<EOS>
The
next
comer
was
Mr.
Arabin
,
who
was

Clantantram
's

and

to

,

,

.
<EOS>
Then

was

sort

that
was
used
for
the
ladies
"
outside
cloaks
,
and
the
door

,
the

announced
,
not

,
Mrs.
Lookaloft
,
and
the
Miss
Lookalofts
,
and
Mr.
Augustus
Lookaloft
.
  
<EOS>
Poor
man
!
 
<EOS>
we
mean
the
footman
.
<EOS>
He
knew
,
none
better
,
that
Mrs.
Lookaloft
had
no
business
there
,
that
she
was
not

,
and
would

.
<EOS>
But
he
had
not
the

to
tell
a
stout
lady
with
a
low

,
short

,
and
satin
at
eight
shillings
a
yard
that
she
had
come
to
the
wrong

;
he
had
not

hint

young

with

that
there

place
ready

in

.
<EOS>
And
thus
Mrs.
Lookaloft
carried
her

,
broke
through

guards
,
and
made
her

into
the

.
<EOS>
That
she
would
have
to

there
<EOS>
she
had
surmised
before
.
<EOS>
But

now

of

that

consorted

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
It

Lookaloft
,

that

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Lookaloft
's
pluck
carried
her
through

,
and
she

into
the
Ullathorne

-

;
but

did

.
<EOS>
It
was
not

Thorne
's

to

,

to

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

Lookaloft
,

?
"

.
"
<EOS>
And

?
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
Could

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

,

,
"

;
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

?
"

shuddering
 
but

.
  
<EOS>
"
And
where
's
Lookaloft
?
"
said

house
,

's

.
<EOS>
Let

of

family
be

,

not

that
their
rent

;

.
  
<EOS>
"
Such

,

Thorne
!
"

.
<EOS>
"
In

n't

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Dear

,
"

<EOS>
"

,

.
"
  
"
<EOS>
Not

!
"

.
<EOS>
"
Not

,

.
<EOS>
It

bilious

,

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
The

,

.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.

<EOS>
Then

<EOS>
As

-

,

.
<EOS>
As

,

-

-
law
helping

,

.
<EOS>
She
had
had
an

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
's

had
been
more
than

;
and

,

had

which

,

.
<EOS>
Was

she
had

justified

in

?
<EOS>
After

,

,

?
<EOS>
Charlotte
Stanhope
had
also

Slope

it
behoved

to

,

.
<EOS>
She

.
  
<EOS>
Dr.

not

-

Slope
,

.
<EOS>
Mr.

,

.
<EOS>
Eleanor

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Mr.

,

,

.
<EOS>
Having

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
Eleanor

,

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
They

into

,
and
from

the

,
when
,

as

are

,
the
Proudies
drove
up
.
<EOS>
It
was
soon
apparent
that
no

was

.
<EOS>
One

to
another
that
it
was
the
bishop
,
and
the

soon
ran
through
all
the

-
on
and

.
<EOS>
There

"
lady
"

,

Ewold
's
.
  
<EOS>
And

fast

,

,

the

to

.
<EOS>
Voices

,

rustled
against

,
and

against
muslin
.
<EOS>
Miss
Thorne
became
more
happy
than
she
had

,
and
again

.
<EOS>
There

.
<EOS>
Here

.
<EOS>
Miss

.
<EOS>
There

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"
The
quintain
?
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Is
it
a
sort
of
gate
,
Miss
Thorne
?
"
  
<EOS>
Miss
Thorne
had
to
explain
the
noble
game
she
spoke
of
,
and
Frank
Foster
had
to
own
that
he
never
had
ridden
at
the
quintain
.
  
<EOS>
"
Would
you
like
to
come
and
see
?
"
said
Miss
Thorne
.
<EOS>
"
There
'll
be
plenty
here
you
know
without
you
,
if
you
like
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
do
n't
mind
,
"
said
Frank
.
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
the
ladies
can
come
too
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
yes
,
"
said
Miss
Thorne
;
"
those
who
like
it
.
<EOS>
I
have
no
doubt
they
'll
go
to
see
your
prowess
<EOS>
,
if
you
'll
ride
,
Mr.
Foster
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Foster
looked
down
at
a
most
unexceptionable
pair
of
pantaloons
,
which
had
arrived
from
London
only
the
day
before
.
<EOS>
They
were
the
very
things
,
at
least
he
thought
so
,
for
a
picnic
or
fête
champêtre
,
but
he
was
not
prepared
to
ride
in
them
.
<EOS>
Nor
was
he
more
encouraged
than
had
been
Mr.
Thorne
by
the
idea
of
being
attacked
from
behind
by
the
bag
of
flour
,
which
Miss
Thorne
had
graphically
described
to
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
do
n't
know
about
riding
,
Miss
Thorne
,
"
said
he
<EOS>
;
"
I
fear
I
'm
not
quite
prepared
.
"
  
Miss
Thorne
sighed
but
said
nothing
further
.
<EOS>
She
left
the
toxophilites
to
their
bows
and
arrows
and
returned
towards
the
house
.
<EOS>
But
as
she
passed
by
the
entrance
to
the
small
park
,
she
thought
that
she
might
at
any
rate
encourage
the
yeomen
by
her
presence
,
as
she
could
not
induce
her
more
fashionable

to
mix
with
them
in
their
manly
amusements
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
she
once
more
betook
herself
to
the
quintain
post
.
  
<EOS>
Here
to
her
great
delight
she
found
Harry
Greenacre
ready
mounted
,
with
his
pole
in
his
hand
,
and
a
lot
of
comrades
standing
round
him
,
encouraging
him
to
the
assault
.
<EOS>
She
stood
at
a
little
distance
and
nodded
to
him
in
token
of
her
good
pleasure
.
  
<EOS>
"
Shall
I
begin
,
ma'am
?
"
said
Harry
,
fingering
his
long
staff
in
a
rather
awkward
way
,
while
his
horse
moved
uneasily
beneath
him
,
not
accustomed
to
a
rider
armed
with
such
a
weapon
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
yes
,
"
said
Miss
Thorne
,
standing
triumphant
as
the
queen
of
beauty
on
an
inverted
tub
which
some
chance
had
brought
thither
from
the
farmyard
.
  
<EOS>
"
Here
goes
then
,
"
said
Harry
as
he
wheeled
his
horse
round
to
get
the
necessary
momentum
of
a
sharp
gallop
.
<EOS>
The
quintain
post
stood
right
before
him
,
and
the
square
board
at
which
he
was
to
tilt
was
fairly
in
his
way
.
<EOS>
If
he
hit
that
duly
in
the
middle
,
and
maintained
his
pace
as
he
did
so
,
it
was
calculated
that
he
would
be
carried
out
of
reach
of
the
flour
bag
,
which
,
suspended
at
the
other
end
of
the
cross
-
bar
on
the
post
,
would
swing
round
when
the
board
was
struck
.
<EOS>
It
was
also
calculated
that
if
the
rider
did
not
maintain
his
pace
,
he
would
get
a
blow
from
the
flour
bag
just
at
the
back
of
his
head
,
and
bear
about
him
the
signs
of
his
awkwardness
to
the
great
amusement
of
the
lookers
-
on
.
  
<EOS>
Harry
Greenacre
did
not
object
to
being
powdered
with
flour
in
the
service
of
his
mistress
and
therefore
gallantly
touched
his
steed
with
his
spur
,
having
laid
his
lance
in
rest
to
the
best
of
his
ability
.
<EOS>
But
his
ability
in
this
respect
was
not
great
,
and
his
appurtenances
probably
not
very
good
;
consequently
,
he
struck
his
horse
with
his
pole
unintentionally
on
the
side
of
the
head
as
he
started
.
<EOS>
The
animal
swerved
and
shied
and
galloped
off
wide
of
the
quintain
.
<EOS>
Harry
,
well
-
accustomed
to
manage
a
horse
,
but
not
to
do
so
with
a
twelve
-
foot
rod
on
his
arm
,
lowered
his
right
hand
to
the
bridle
,
and
thus
the
end
of
the
lance
came
to
the
ground
and
got
between
the
legs
of
the
steed
.
<EOS>
Down
came
rider
and
steed
and
staff
.
<EOS>
Young
Greenacre
was
thrown
some
six
feet
over
the
horse
's
head
,
and
poor
Miss
Thorne
almost
fell
off
her
tub
in
a
swoon
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
gracious
,
he
's
killed
,
"
shrieked
a
woman
who
was
near
him
when
he
fell
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
Lord
be
good
to
him
!
<EOS>
His
poor
mother
,
his
poor
mother
!
"
said
another
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
drat
them
dangerous
plays
all
the
world
over
,
"
said
an
old
crone
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
has
broke
his
neck
sure
enough
,
if
ever
man
did
,
"
said
a
fourth
.
  
<EOS>
Poor
Miss
Thorne
.
<EOS>
She
heard
all
this
and
yet
did
not
quite
swoon
.
<EOS>
She
made
her
way
through
the
crowd
as
best
she
could
,
sick
herself
almost
to
death
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
his
mother
 
his
poor
mother
!
<EOS>
How
could
she
ever
forgive
herself
.
<EOS>
The
agony
of
that
moment
was
terrific
.
<EOS>
She
could
hardly
get
to
the
place
where
the
poor
lad
was
lying
,
as
three
or
four
men
in
front
were
about
the
horse
,
which
had
risen
with
some
difficulty
,
but
at
last
she
found
herself
close
to
the
young
farmer
.
  
<EOS>
"
Has
he
marked
himself
?
<EOS>
For
heaven
's
sake
tell
me
that
:
has
he
marked
his
knees
?
"
said
Harry
,
slowly
rising
and
rubbing
his
left
shoulder
with
his
right
hand
and
thinking
only
of
his
horse
's
legs
.
<EOS>
Miss
Thorne
soon
found
that
he
had
not
broken
his
neck
,
nor
any
of
his
bones
,
nor
been
injured
in
any
essential
way
.
<EOS>
But
from
that
time
forth
she
never
instigated
anyone
to
ride
at
a
quintain
.
  
<EOS>
Eleanor
left
Dr.
Stanhope
as
soon
as
she
could
do
so
civilly
and
went
in
quest
of
her
father
,
whom
she
found
on
the
lawn
in
company
with
Mr.
Arabin
.
<EOS>
She
was
not
sorry
to
find
them
together
.
<EOS>
She
was
anxious
to
disabuse
at
any
rate
her
father
's
mind
as
to
this
report
which
had
got
abroad
respecting
her
,
and
would
have
been
well
pleased
to
have
been
able
to
do
the
same
with
regard
to
Mr.
Arabin
.
<EOS>
She
put
her
own
through
her
father
's
arm
,
coming
up
behind
his
back
,
and
then
tendered
her
hand
also
to
the
vicar
of
St.
Ewold
's
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
how
did
you
come
?
"
said
Mr.
Harding
,
when
the
first
greeting
was
over
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
Stanhopes
brought
me
,
"
said
she
;
"
their
carriage
was
obliged
to
come
twice
,
and
has
now
gone
back
for
the
signora
.
<EOS>
"
As
she
spoke
she
caught
Mr.
Arabin
's
eye
and
saw
that
he
was
looking
pointedly
at
her
with
a
severe
expression
.
<EOS>
She
understood
at
once
the
accusation
contained
in
his

.
<EOS>
It
said
as
plainly
as
an
eye
could
speak
,
"
Yes
,
you
came
with
the
Stanhopes
,
but
you
did
so
in
order
that
you
might
be
in
company
with
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Our
party
,
"
said
she
,
still
addressing
her
father
,
"
consisted
of
the
doctor
and
Charlotte
Stanhope
,
myself
,
and
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
"
As
she
mentioned
the
last
name
she
felt
her
father
's
arm
quiver
slightly
beneath
her
touch
.
<EOS>
At
the
same
moment
Mr.
Arabin
turned
away
from
them
and
,
joining
his
hands
behind
his
back
,
strolled
slowly
away
by
one
of

paths
.
  
<EOS>
"
Papa
,
"
said
she
,
"
it
was
impossible
to
help
coming
in
the
same
carriage
with
Mr.
Slope
;
it
was
quite
impossible
.
<EOS>
I
had
promised
to
come
with
them
before
I
dreamt
of
his
coming
,
and
afterwards
I
could
not
get
out
of
it
without
explaining
and
giving
rise
to
talk
.
<EOS>
You
were
n't
at
home
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
I
could
n't
possibly
help
it
.
"
<EOS>
She
said
all
this
so
quickly
that
by
the
time
her
apology
was
spoken
she
was
quite
out
of

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
why
you
should
have
wished
to
help
it
,
my
dear
,
"
said
her
father
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Papa
,
you
do
.
<EOS>
You
must
know
,
you
do
know
all
the
things
they
said
at
Plumstead
.
<EOS>
I
am
sure
you
do
.
<EOS>
You
know
all
the
archdeacon
said
.
<EOS>
How
unjust
he
was
;
and
Mr.
Arabin
too
.
<EOS>
He
's
a
horrid
man
,
a
horrid
odious
man
,
but
 
"
  
"
Who
is
an
odious
man
,
my
dear
?
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
but
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
You
know
I
mean
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
He
's
the
most
odious
man
I
ever
met
in
my
life
,
and
it
was
most
unfortunate
<EOS>
my
having
to
come
here
in
the
same
carriage
with
him
.
<EOS>
But
how
could
I
help
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
A
great
weight
began
to
move
itself
off
Mr.
Harding
's
mind
.
<EOS>
So
,
after
all
,
the
archdeacon
with
all
his
wisdom
,
and
Mrs.
Grantly
with
all
her
tact
,
and
Mr.
Arabin
with
all
his
talent
,
were
in
the
wrong
.
<EOS>
His
own
child
,
his
Eleanor
,
the
daughter
of
whom
he
was
so
proud
,
was
not
to
become
the
wife
of
a
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
about
to
give
his
sanction
to
the

,
so
certified
had
he
been
of
the
fact
,
and
now
he
learnt
that
this
imputed
lover
of
Eleanor
's
was
at
any
rate
as
much
disliked
by
her
as
by
any
one
of
the
family
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
,
however
,
was
by
no
means
sufficiently
a
man
of
the
world
to
conceal
the
blunder
he
had
made
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
pretend
that
he
had
entertained
no
suspicion
;
he
could
not
make
believe
that
he
had
never
joined
the
archdeacon
in
his
surmises
.
<EOS>
He
was
greatly
surprised
,
and
gratified
beyond
measure
,
and
he
could
not
help
showing
that
such
was
the
case
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
darling
girl
,
"
said
he
,
"
I
am
so

,
so
overjoyed
.
<EOS>
My
own
child
;
you
have
taken
such
a
weight
off
my

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
surely
,
Papa
,
_
you
_
did
n't
think
 
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't
know
what
to
think
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
The
archdeacon
told
me
that
 
"
  
"
The
archdeacon
!
"
<EOS>
said
Eleanor
,
her
face
lighting
up
with

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
man
like
the
archdeacon
might
,
one
would

,

than
in
traducing
his

-
in
-
law
and
creating

between

father
and
his
daughter
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
did
n't
mean

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
did
he
mean
then
?
<EOS>
Why
did

me
and

your

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Never

now
,

;
never

.
<EOS>
We
shall
all

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Papa
,
that
you
should

!
<EOS>
That
you

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do

what
you
mean
by

,
Eleanor
.
<EOS>
There
would
be
nothing

,

.
<EOS>
Nothing
that
could
have
justified
my

as
your
father
.
"
<EOS>
And
Mr.
Harding
would
have
proceeded

to

Mr.
Slope
after

was
a

,

by
Eleanor
's
greater

.
  
<EOS>
"
It
would
be
disgraceful
,
"
said
she
;
"
it
would
be
wrong
;
it
would
be
abominable
.
<EOS>
Could
I
do
such
a
horrid
thing
,
I
should
expect
no
one
to
speak

.
<EOS>
Ugh
 
"
and
she
shuddered
as
she
thought
of
the
matrimonial
torch
which
her
friends
had
been
so
ready
to
light
on
her
behalf
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
wonder
at
Dr.
Grantly
;
I
do
n't
wonder
at
Susan
;
but
,
oh
,
Papa
,
I
do
wonder
at
you
.
<EOS>
How
could
you
,
how
could
you
believe
it
?
"
<EOS>
Poor
Eleanor
,
as
she
thought
of
her
father
's
defalcation
,
could
resist
her
tears
no
longer
,
and
was
forced
to
cover
her
face
with
her
handkerchief
.
  
<EOS>
The
place
was
not
very
opportune
for
her
grief
.
<EOS>
They
were
walking
through
the
shrubberies
,
and
there
were
many
people
near
them
.
<EOS>
Poor
Mr.
Harding
stammered
out
his
excuse
as
best
he
could
,
and
Eleanor
with
an
effort
controlled
her
tears
and
returned
her
handkerchief
to
her
pocket
.
<EOS>
She
did
not
find
it
difficult
to
forgive
her
father
,
nor
could
she
altogether
refuse
to
join
him
in
the
returning
gaiety
of
spirit
to
which
her
present
avowal
gave
rise
.
<EOS>
It
was
such
a
load
off
his
heart
to
think
that
he
should
not
be
called
on
to
welcome
Mr.
Slope
as
his
son
-
in
-
law
.
<EOS>
It
was
such

to
him
to
find
that
his
daughter
's
feelings
and
his
own
were
now
,
as
they
ever
had
been
,
in
unison
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
so
unhappy
for
the
last

weeks
about
this
wretched
Mr.
Slope
!
<EOS>
He
was
so

as

the

,
so

daughter
,
that
,
strong

Eleanor
's
anger
<EOS>
,

could
not

.
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
Papa
,
"

,

,
"
never

:

never

.
<EOS>
Whatever
I
do
you
may
be
sure
I
shall

;
you

sure
I
shall

.
"
  
<EOS>
And
Mr.
Harding
did

,
and
owned
his

,
and

again
.
<EOS>
And
so
,
while
he

she
uttered

,

the

.
  
<EOS>
And
what
had

that
_
whatever

did
_
,

tell

father

?
<EOS>
What
was

doing
?
  
<EOS>
So

.
   
<EOS>
The
Signora
Neroni
,

,

Meet

<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
Just

Eleanor
reached
the

room
the

.
<EOS>
She
had

into

and
there

,
and

.
<EOS>
She
was
all
in

,
and

,

,

and

.
  
<EOS>
Miss

.
<EOS>
In

,
the
signora
was
a

;
and

.
<EOS>
The

,

<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Miss
Thorne
;

?
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
How

?
<EOS>

.
"
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"
We

"

<EOS>
do

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

Thorne

<EOS>
Mr.

<EOS>
But

<EOS>
Miss

,

<EOS>
She

<EOS>
The

<EOS>
I

.

<EOS>
The

,

<EOS>
"
George

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Upon

I
do

,
"
said

Lady

,
"
for

.
<EOS>
But
I
do

that
I
was
called
some
time
in
the
middle

the
night
and
was
dressing
myself
before

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Wise
people
,
when
they
are
in
the
wrong
,
always
put
themselves
right
by
finding
fault
with
the
people
against
whom
they
have
sinned
.
<EOS>
Lady
De
Courcy
was
a
wise
woman
,
and
therefore
,
having
treated
Miss
Thorne
very
badly
by
staying
away
till
three
o'clock
,
she
assumed
the
offensive
and
attacked
Mr.
Thorne
's
roads
.
<EOS>
Her
daughter
,
not
less
wise
,
attacked
Miss
Thorne
's
early
hours
.
<EOS>
The
art
of
doing
this
is
among
the
most
precious
of
those
usually
cultivated
by
persons
who
know
how
to
live
.
<EOS>
There
is
no
withstanding
it
.
<EOS>
Who
can
go
systematically
to
work
and
,
having
done
battle
with
the
primary
accusation
and
settled
that
,
then
bring
forward
a
countercharge
and
support
that
also
?
<EOS>
Life
is
not
long
enough
for
such
labours
.
<EOS>
A
man
in
the
right
relies
easily
on
his
rectitude
and
therefore
goes
about
unarmed
.
<EOS>
His
very
strength
is
his
weakness
.
<EOS>
A
man
in
the
wrong
knows
that
he
must
look
to
his
weapons
;
his
very
weakness
is
his
strength
.
<EOS>
The
one
is
never
prepared
for
combat
,
the
other
is
always
ready
.
<EOS>
Therefore
it
is
that
in
this
world
the
man
that
is
in
the
wrong
almost
invariably
conquers
the
man
that
is
in
the
right
,
and
invariably
despises
him
.
  
<EOS>
A
man
must
be
an
idiot
or
else
an
angel
who
,
after
the
age
of
forty
,
shall
attempt
to
be
just
to
his
neighbours
.
<EOS>
Many
like
the
Lady
Margaretta
have
learnt
their
lesson
at
a
much
earlier
age
.
<EOS>
But
this
of
course
depends
on
the
school
in
which
they
have
been
taught
.
  
<EOS>
Poor
Miss
Thorne
was
altogether
overcome
.
<EOS>
She
knew
very
well
that
she
had
been
ill
-
treated
,
and
yet
she
found
herself
making
apologies
to
Lady
De
Courcy
.
<EOS>
To
do
her
ladyship
justice
,
she
received
them
very

,
and
allowed
herself
,
with
her
train
of
daughters
,
to
be
led
towards
the
lawn
.
  
<EOS>
There
were
two
windows
in

drawing
-
room
wide

for
the
countess
to
pass
through
,
but
she
saw
that

was
a
woman
on
a
sofa
,
at
the
third
window
,
and
that
that
woman
had
,
as
it
were
,
a
following
attached
to

.
<EOS>
Her
ladyship
therefore
determined
to
investigate
the
woman
.
<EOS>
The
De
Courcy
's
were
hereditarily
shortsighted
,
and
had
been
so
for
thirty
centuries
at
least
.
<EOS>
So
Lady
De
Courcy
,
who
when

the
family

,

,

glass
to

,
pressed
in
among

who
surrounded

,
and
bowed

to
those
whom
she
chose

honour

.
  
<EOS>
In
order
to
get
to
the
window
she
had
to
pass
close
to
the
front
of
the
couch
,
and
as

did

she
stared
hard
at
the

.
<EOS>
The

,
in

,

hard
at
the
countess
.
<EOS>
The
countess
,
who
,
since
her

-

,
had
been

see
all

not
royal
,

,
or

fall
before

own
,
paused

,

,
and
stared

than
before
.
<EOS>
But
she
had
now
to
do
with
one
who
cared
little
for
countesses
.
<EOS>
It
was
,
one

say
,
impossible
for
mortal
man
or

abash
Madeline
Neroni
.
<EOS>
She
opened
her
large
,
bright
,

wider
and

,
till
she
seemed

be

.
<EOS>
She

up

the

's

,
not
as

,
but
as

she
delighted
in

.
<EOS>
She
used
no

to

,
and

.
<EOS>
The
faintest
possible

of

played
round
her
mouth
,
and
her

were
slightly
dilated
,
as
if
in
sure

of
her

.
<EOS>
And
it
was
sure
.
<EOS>
The
Countess
De
Courcy
,
in

her

and
De

,

Lord

,

with

.
<EOS>
At
first

little

of
gold
wavered
in
the
countess
's
hand
,
then
the
hand
shook
,
then

,
the

's

itself
into

,
and
the
countess
's
feet

.
<EOS>
She
did
not
,

,
go
so
fast
but
what

signora
's
voice
,
asking
:
  
"
Who
on

that
woman
,
Mr.
Slope
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
Lady
De
Courcy
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
ah
.
<EOS>
I
might
have
supposed

.
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
,
ha
.
<EOS>
Well
,
that
's
as
good
as

play
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
as
good
as
a
play
to
any
there
who
had
eyes
to
observe

and
wit
to
comment
on
what
they
observed
.
  
<EOS>
But
the
Lady
De
Courcy
soon
found
a
congenial
spirit
on
the

.
<EOS>
There
she
encountered
Mrs.
Proudie
,
and
as
Mrs.
Proudie
was
not
only
the
wife
of
a
bishop
but
was
also
the
cousin
of
an
earl
,
Lady
De
Courcy
considered
her
to
be
the
fittest
companion
she
was
likely
to
meet
in
that
assemblage
.
<EOS>
They
were
accordingly
delighted
to
see
each
other
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Proudie
by
no
means
despised
a
countess
,
and
as
this
countess
lived
in
the
county
and
within
a
sort
of
extensive
visiting
distance
of
Barchester
,
she
was
glad
to
have
this
opportunity
of
ingratiating
herself
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Lady
De
Courcy
,
I
am
so
delighted
,
"
said
she
,
looking
as
little

as
it
was
in
her
nature
to
do
.
<EOS>
"
I
hardly
expected
to
see
you
here
.
<EOS>
It
is
such
a
distance
,
and
then
,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
such
roads
,
Mrs.
Proudie
!
<EOS>
I
really
wonder
how
the
people
ever
get
about
.
<EOS>
But
I
do
n't
suppose
they
ever
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
really
do
n't
know
,
but
I
suppose
not
.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
No

.
  
<EOS>

Bold
.
<EOS>
Men

,

the
strong

of

.
<EOS>
They

,

,

.
<EOS>
The

by

women
instinctively
,

,

the

;

,

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Thorne

<EOS>
His

as
a
lover
he
was
very
second
-
rate
.
<EOS>
We
may
say
that
she
regarded
him
somewhat
as
a
sportsman
does
a
pheasant
.
<EOS>
The
bird
is
so
easily
shot
that
he
would
not
be
worth
the
shooting
were
it
not
for
the
very
respectable
appearance
that
he
makes
in
a
larder
.
<EOS>
The
signora
would
not
waste
much
time
in
shooting
Mr.
Thorne
,
but
still
he
was
worth
bagging
for
family
uses
.
  
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Arabin
was
game
of
another
sort
.
<EOS>
The
signora
was
herself
possessed
of
quite
sufficient
intelligence
to
know
that
Mr.
Arabin
was
a
man
more
than
usually
intellectual
.
<EOS>
She
knew
also
that
,
as
a
clergyman
,
he
was
of
a
much
higher
stamp
than
Mr.
Slope
and
that
,
as
a
gentleman
,
he
was
better
educated
than
Mr.
Thorne
.
<EOS>
She
would
never
have
attempted
to
drive
Mr.
Arabin
into
ridiculous
misery
as
she
did
Mr.
Slope
,
nor
would
she
think
it
possible
to
dispose
of
him
in
ten
minutes
as
she
had
done
with
Mr.
Thorne
.
  
<EOS>
Such
were
her
reflexions
about
Mr.
Arabin
.
<EOS>
As
to
Mr.
Arabin
,
it
can
not
be
said
that
he
reflected
at
all
about
the
signora
.
<EOS>
He
knew
that
she
was
beautiful
,
and
he
felt
that
she
was
able
to
charm
him
.
<EOS>
He
required
charming
in
his
present
misery
,
and
therefore
he
went
and
stood
at
the
head
of
her
couch
.
<EOS>
She
knew
all
about
it
.
<EOS>
Such
were
her
peculiar
gifts
.
<EOS>
It
was
her
nature
to
see
that
he
required
charming
,
and
it
was
her
province
to
charm
him
.
<EOS>
As
the
Eastern
idler
swallows
his
dose
of
opium
,
as
the
London
reprobate
swallows
his
dose
of
gin
,
so
with
similar
desires
and
for
similar
reasons
did
Mr.
Arabin
prepare
to
swallow
the
charms
of
the
Signora
Neroni
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
an't
you
shooting
with
bows
and
arrows
,
Mr.
Arabin
?
<EOS>
"
said
she
,
when
they
were
nearly
alone
together
in
the
drawing
-
room
,
"
or
talking
with
young
ladies
in
shady
bowers
,
or
turning
your
talents
to
account
in
some
way
?
<EOS>
What
was
a
bachelor
like
you
asked
here
for
?
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
mean
to
earn
your
cold
chicken
and
champagne
?
<EOS>
Were
I
you
,
<EOS>
I
should
be
ashamed
to
be
so
idle
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
murmured
some
sort
of
answer
.
<EOS>
Though
he
wished
to
be
charmed
,
he
was
hardly
yet
in
a
mood
to
be
playful
in
return
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
what
ails
you
,
Mr.
Arabin
?
"
said
she
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Here
you
are
in
your
own
parish
 
Miss
Thorne
tells
me
that
her
party
is
given
expressly
in
your
honour
 
and
yet
you
are
the
only
dull
man
at
it
.
<EOS>
Your
friend
Mr.
Slope
was
with
me
a
few
minutes
since
,
full
of
life
and
spirits
;
why
do
n't
you
rival
him
?
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
not
difficult
for
so
acute
an
observer
as
Madeline
Neroni
to
see
that
she
had
hit
the
nail
on
the
head
and
driven
the
bolt
home
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
winced
visibly
before
her
attack
,
and
she
knew
at
once
that
he
was
jealous
of
Mr.
Slope
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
look
on
you
and
Mr.
Slope
as
the
very
antipodes
of
men
,
"
said
she
.
<EOS>
"
There
is
nothing
in
which
you
are
not
each
the
reverse
of
the
other
,
except
in
belonging
to
the
same
profession
 
and
even
in
that
you
are
so
unlike
as
perfectly
to
maintain
the
rule
.
<EOS>
He
is
gregarious
;
you
are
given
to
solitude
.
<EOS>
He
is
active
;
you
are
passive
.
<EOS>
He
works
;
you
think
.
<EOS>
He
likes
women
;
you
despise
them
.
<EOS>
He
is
fond
of
position
and
power
;
and
so
are
you
,
but
for
directly
different
reasons
.
<EOS>
He
loves
to
be
praised
;
you
very
foolishly
abhor
it
.
<EOS>
He
will
gain
his
rewards
,
which
will
be
an
insipid
,
useful
wife
,
a
comfortable
income
,
and
a
reputation
for
sanctimony
;
you
will
also
gain
yours
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Well
,
and
what
will
they
be
?
"
said
Mr.
Arabin
,
who
knew
that
he
was
being
flattered
and
yet
suffered
himself
to
put
up
with
it
.
<EOS>
"
What
will
be
my
rewards
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
heart
of
some
woman
whom
you
will
be
too
austere
to
own
that
you
love
,
and
the
respect
of
some
few
friends
which
you
will
be
too
proud
to
own
that
you
value
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Rich
rewards
,
"
said
he
;
"
but
of
little
worth
,
if
they
are
to
be
so
treated
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
you
are
not
to
look
for
such
success
as
awaits
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
He
is
born
to
be
a
successful
man
.
<EOS>
He
suggests
to
himself
an
object
and
then
starts
for
it
with
eager
intention
.
<EOS>
Nothing
will
deter
him
from
his
pursuit
.
<EOS>
He
will
have
no
scruples
,
no
fears
,
no
hesitation
.
<EOS>
His
desire
is
to
be
a
bishop
with
a
rising
family
 
<EOS>
the
wife
will
come
first
,
and
in
due
time
the
apron
.
<EOS>
You
will
see
all
this
,
and
then
 
"
  
"
Well
,
and
what
then
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
you
will
begin
to
wish
that
you
had
done
the
same
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
looked
placidly
out
at
the
lawn
and
,
resting
his
shoulder
on
the
head
of
the
sofa
,
rubbed
his
chin
with
his
hand
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
trick
he
had
when
he
was
thinking
deeply
,
and
what
the
signora
said
made
him
think
.
<EOS>
Was
it
not
all
true
?
<EOS>
Would
he
not
hereafter
look
back
,
if
not
at
Mr.
Slope
,
at
some
others
,
perhaps
not
equally
gifted
with
himself
,
who
had
risen
in
the
world
while
he
had
lagged
behind
,
and
then
wish
that
he
had
done
the
same
?
  
<EOS>
"
Is
not
such
the
doom
of
all
speculative
men
of
talent
?
"
said
she
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
they
not
all
sit
wrapt
as
you
now
are
,
cutting
imaginary
silken
cords
with
their
fine
edges
,
while
those
not
so
highly
tempered
sever
the
everyday
Gordian
knots
of
the
world
's
struggle
and
win
wealth
and
renown
?
<EOS>
Steel
too
highly
polished
,
edges
too
sharp
,
do
not
do
for
this
world
's
work
,
Mr.
Arabin
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Who
was
this
woman
that
thus
read
the
secrets
of
his
heart
and
re
-
uttered
to
him
the
unwelcome

of
his
own

?
<EOS>
He
looked
full
into
her
face
when
she
had
done
speaking
and
said
,
"
Am
I
one
of
those
foolish
blades
,
too
sharp
and
too
fine
to
do
a
useful
day
's
work
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
do
you
let
the
Slopes
of
the
world
outdistance
you
?
"
said
she
.
<EOS>
"
Is
not
the
blood
in
your
veins
as
warm
as
his
?
<EOS>
Does
not
your
pulse
beat
as
fast
?
<EOS>
Has
not
God
made
you
a
man
and
intended
you
to
do
a
man
's
work
here
,
ay
,
and
to
take
a
man
's
wages
also
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
sat
ruminating
,
rubbing
his
face
,
and
wondering
why
these
things
were
said
to
him
,
but
he
replied
nothing
.
<EOS>
The
signora
went
on
:
  
"
<EOS>
The
greatest
mistake
any
man
ever
made
is
to
suppose
that
the
good
things
of
the
world
are
not
worth
the
winning
.
<EOS>
And
it
is
a
mistake
so
opposed
to
the
religion
which
you
preach
!
<EOS>
Why
does
God
permit
his
bishops
one
after
another
to
have
their
five
thousands
and
ten
thousands
a
year
if
such
wealth
be
bad
and
not
worth
having
?
<EOS>
Why
are
beautiful
things
given
to
us
,
and
luxuries
and
pleasant
enjoyments
,
if
they
be
not
intended
to
be
used
?
<EOS>
They
must
be
meant
for
someone
,
and
what
is
good
for
a
layman
surely
can
not
be
bad
for
a
clerk
.
<EOS>
You
try
to
despise
these
good
things
,
but
you
only
try
 
you
do
n't
succeed
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
n't
I
?
"
said
Mr.
Arabin
,
still
musing
,
not
knowing
what
he
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
ask
you
the
question
:
do
you
succeed
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
looked
at
her
piteously
.
<EOS>
It
seemed
to
him
as
though
he
were
being
interrogated
by
some
inner
spirit
of
his
own
,
to

he
could
not
refuse
an

,
and
to
whom
he
did
not

.
  
<EOS>
"
Come
,
Mr.
Arabin
,
confess
;
do
you
succeed
?
<EOS>
Is
money
so
contemptible
?
<EOS>
Is
worldly
power
so

?
<EOS>
Is
feminine
beauty
a
trifle
to

so

by

wise

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Feminine
beauty
!
"
said
he
,
gazing
into
her

,
as
though
all

in
the
world
were
concentrated
there
.
<EOS>
"
Why
do
you
say
I
do
not

it
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
look
at
me
like

,
Mr.
Arabin
,
I
shall
alter
my
opinion
 
or
should
do
so
,
were
I
not
of
course
<EOS>
aware
that
I
have
no
beauty
of
my
own

.
"
  
<EOS>
The
gentleman
blushed
crimson
,
but
the
lady
did
not
blush
at
all
.
<EOS>
A
slightly
increased
colour
animated
her
face
,
just
so
much
so
as
to
give
her
an
air
of
special
interest
.
<EOS>
She
expected
a
compliment
from
her
admirer
,
but
she
was
rather
gratified
than
otherwise
by
finding
that
he
did
not
pay

to
her
.
<EOS>
Messrs.
Slope
and
Thorne
,
Messrs.
Brown
,
Jones
,
and
Robinson
,
they
all
paid
her
compliments
.
<EOS>
She
was
rather
in
hopes
that
she
would
ultimately
succeed
in
inducing
Mr.
Arabin
to
abuse
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
your
gaze
,
"
said
she
,
"
is
one
of
wonder
,
not
of
admiration
.
<EOS>
You
wonder
at
my
audacity
in
asking
you
such
questions
about
yourself
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
do
rather
,
"
said
he
.
  
<EOS>
"
Nevertheless
,
I
expect
an

,
Mr.
Arabin
.
<EOS>
Why
were
women
made
beautiful
if
men
are
not
to

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
men
do
regard

,
"
he

.
  
<EOS>
"
And
why
not
you
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
begging
the
question
,
Madame
Neroni
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
I
shall
beg
nothing
,
Mr.
Arabin
,
which
you
will
not
grant
,
and
I
do
beg
for
an

.
<EOS>
Do
you
not
as
a
rule
think
women
below
your
notice
as

?
<EOS>
Let
us
see
.
<EOS>
There
is
the
Widow
Bold
looking
round
at
you
from
her
chair
this
minute
.
<EOS>
What
would
you
say
to
her
as
a
companion
for
life
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
,
rising
from
his
position
,
leaned
over
the
sofa
and
looked
through
the
drawing
-
room
door
to
the
place
where
Eleanor
was
seated
between
Bertie
Stanhope
and
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
She
at
once
caught
his
glance
and
averted
her
own
.
<EOS>
She
was
not
pleasantly
placed
in
her
present
position
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
was
doing
his
best
to
attract
her
attention
,
and
she
was
striving
to
prevent
his
doing
so
by
talking
to
Mr.
Stanhope
,
while
her
mind
was
intently
fixed
on
Mr.
Arabin
and
Madame
Neroni
.
<EOS>
Bertie
Stanhope
endeavoured
to
take
advantage
of
her
favours
,
but
he
was
thinking
more
of
the
manner
in
which
he
would
by
and
by
throw
himself
at
her
feet
than
of
amusing
her
at
the
present
moment
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
,
"
said
the
signora
.
<EOS>
"
She
was
stretching
her
beautiful
neck
to
look
at
you
,
and
now
you
have
disturbed
her
.
<EOS>
Well
,
I
declare
I
believe
I
am
wrong
about
you
;
I
believe
that
you
do
think
Mrs.
Bold
a
charming
woman
.
<EOS>
Your
looks
seem
to
say
so
,
and
by
her
looks
I
should
say
that
she
is
jealous
of
me
.
<EOS>
Come
,
Mr.
Arabin
,
confide
in
me
,
and
if
it
is
so
,
I
'll
do
all
in
my
power
to
make
up
the
match
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
is
needless
to
say
that
the
signora
was
not
very
sincere
in
her
offer
.
<EOS>
She
was
never
sincere
on
such
subjects
.
<EOS>
She
never
expected
others
to
be
so
,
nor
did
she
expect
others
to
think
her
<EOS>
so
.
<EOS>
Such
matters
were
her
playthings
,
her
billiard
table
,
her
hounds
and
hunters
,
her
waltzes
and
polkas
,
her
picnics
and
summer
-
day
excursions
.
<EOS>
She
had
little
else
to
amuse
her
,
and
therefore
played
at
love
-
making
in
all
its
forms
.
<EOS>
She
was
now
playing
at
it
with
Mr.
Arabin
,
and
did
not
at
all
expect
the
earnestness
and
truth
of
his
answer
.
  
<EOS>
"
All
in
your
power
would
be
nothing
,
"
said
he
,
"
for
Mrs.
Bold
is
,
I
imagine
,
already
engaged
to
another
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
you
own
the
impeachment
yourself
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
cross
-
question
me
rather
unfairly
,
"
he
replied
,
"
and
I
do
not
know

at

.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Bold

,

.
<EOS>
It

.
"
  
<EOS>
"

a

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
  
"

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
As

,

.
<EOS>
Mr.

,

.
<EOS>
His

to

,
that

.
<EOS>
Bertie

;
the
evil

was
near

;

no

why

.
<EOS>
He
had

Eleanor
Bold
if

,
and
was

to
-
day
to

.
<EOS>
But
there
was
time
enough
before

.
<EOS>
He

over

.
<EOS>
Having

good

,

future
Mrs.
Stanhope
as

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
,
having

,

.
<EOS>
He
was
full
of
thought
,

ate

.
  
<EOS>
But

Eleanor
was
the

to

.
<EOS>
The

she

rely

Bertie

,
and
he
,

,
was

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
did
not

.
<EOS>
She

then
,

too

,

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
followed
her
,
and
young
Stanhope
lost
the
occasion
.
  
<EOS>
Madeline
Neroni
,
when
she
was
left
alone
,
could
not
help
pondering
much
on
the
singular
interview
she
had
had
with
this
singular
man
.
<EOS>
Not
a
word
that
she
had
spoken
to
him
had
been
intended
by
her
to
be
received
as
true
,
and
yet
he
had
answered
her
in
the
very
spirit
of
truth
.
<EOS>
He
had
done
so
,
and
she
had
been
aware
that
he
had
so
done
.
<EOS>
She
had
wormed
from
him
his
secret
,
and
he
,
debarred
as
it
would
seem
from
man
's
usual

of
lying
,
had
innocently
laid
bare
his
whole

to
her
.
<EOS>
He
loved
Eleanor
Bold
,
but
Eleanor
was
not
in
his
eye
so
beautiful
as
herself
.
<EOS>
He
would
fain
have
Eleanor
for
his
wife
,
but
yet
he
had
acknowledged
that
she
was
the
less
gifted
of
the
two
.
<EOS>
The
man
had
literally
been
unable
to
falsify
his
thoughts
when
questioned
,
and
had
been
compelled
to
be
true
_
malgré
lui
_
,
even
when
truth
must
have
been
so
disagreeable
to

.
  
<EOS>
This
teacher
of
men
,
this
Oxford
pundit
,
this
double
-

of
university

,
this

,
this

,
had
been
like
a
little
child
in
her

;
she
had
turned
him
inside
out
and
read
his
very
heart
as
she

of
a

.
<EOS>
She
could
not
but
despise
him
for
his
facile

,
and
yet
she
liked
him
for
it
,
too
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
novelty
to
her
,
a
new
trait
in
a
man
's
character
.
<EOS>
She
felt
also
that
she
could
never
so
completely
make
a

of
him
as
she
did
of
the
Slopes
and
Thornes
.
<EOS>
She
felt
that
she
never
could
induce
Mr.
Arabin
to
make
protestations
to
her
that
were
not
true
,
or
to
listen
to
nonsense
<EOS>
that
was
mere
nonsense
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
quite
clear
that
Mr.
Arabin
was
heartily
in

with
Mrs.
Bold
;
and
the
signora
,
with
very

nature
,
began
to
turn

over
in
her
mind
whether
she
could
not
do

.
<EOS>
Of
course
Bertie
was
to
have
the
first

.
<EOS>
It
was
an
understood
family
arrangement
that
her
brother
was
,
if
possible
,
to
marry
the
Widow
Bold
.
<EOS>
Madeline
knew
too
well
his

and
what
was
due
to

to

so

,

.
<EOS>
But

strong

that

.
<EOS>
She

not

Mrs.
Bold
would
accept

man

's

,
and

.
<EOS>
She

Mr.
Slope

more

,
and
with

of

.
  
<EOS>
And

,

,

Arabin
to

.
   
<EOS>
The
Lookalofts
and
the
Greenacres
 
<EOS>
On
the
whole
,
Miss
Thorne
's
provision
for
the
amusement
and
feeding
of
the
outer
classes
in
the
exoteric
paddock
was
not
unsuccessful
.
  
<EOS>
Two
little
drawbacks
to
the
general
happiness
did
take
place
,
but
they
were
of
a
temporary
nature
,
and
apparent
rather
than
real
.
<EOS>
The
first
was
the
downfall
of
young
Harry
Greenacre
,
and
the
other
the
uprise
of
Mrs.
Lookaloft
and
her
family
.
  
<EOS>
As
to
the
quintain
,
it
became
more
popular
among
the
boys
on
foot
than
it
would
ever
have
been
among
the
men
on
horseback
,
even
had
young
Greenacre
been
more
successful
.
<EOS>
It
was
twirled
round
and
round
till
it
was
nearly
twirled
out
of
the
ground
,
and
the
bag
of
flour
was
used
with
great
gusto
in
powdering
the
backs
and
heads
of
all
who
could
be
coaxed
within
its
vicinity
.
  
<EOS>
Of
course
it
was
reported
all
through
the
assemblage
that
Harry
was
dead
,
and
there
was
a
pathetic
scene
between
him
and
his
mother
when
it
was
found
that
he
had
escaped
scatheless
from
the
fall
.
<EOS>
A
good
deal
of
beer
was
drunk
on
the
occasion
,
and
the
quintain
was
"
dratted
"
and
"
bothered
,
"
and
very
generally
anathematized
by
all
the
mothers
who
had
young
sons
likely
to
be
placed
in
similar
jeopardy
.
<EOS>
But
the
affair
of
Mrs.
Lookaloft
was
of
a
more
serious
nature
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
tell
"
ee
plainly
 
face
to
face
 
<EOS>
she
be
there
in
madam
's
drawing
-
room
;
herself
and
Gussy
,
and
them
two
walloping
gals
,
dressed
up
to
their
very
eyeses
.
<EOS>
"
This
was
said
by
a
very
positive
,
very
indignant
,
and
very
fat
farmer
's
wife
,
who
was
sitting
on
the
end
of
a
bench
leaning
on
the
handle
of
a
huge
,
cotton

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
:
you
did
n't
zee
her
,
Dame
Guffern
?
<EOS>
"
said
Mrs.
Greenacre
,
whom
this
information
,
joined
to
the
recent
peril
undergone
by
her
son
,
almost
overpowered
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Greenacre
held
just
as
much
land
as
Mr.
Lookaloft
,
paid
his
rent
quite
as
punctually
,
and
his
opinion
in
the
vestry
room
was
reckoned
to
be
every
whit
as
good
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Lookaloft
's
rise
in
the
world
had
been
wormwood
to
Mrs.
Greenacre
.
<EOS>
She
had
no
taste
herself
for
the
sort
of
finery
which
had
converted
Barleystubb
farm
into
Rosebank
and
which
had
occasionally
graced
Mr.
Lookaloft
's
letters
with
the
dignity
of
esquirehood
.
<EOS>
She
had
no
wish
to
convert
her
own
homestead
into
Violet
Villa
,
or
to
see
her
goodman
go
about
with
a
new
-
fangled
handle
to
his
name
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
a
mortal
injury
to
her
that
Mrs.
Lookaloft
should
be
successful
in
her
hunt
after
such
honours
.
<EOS>
She
had
abused
and
ridiculed
Mrs.
Lookaloft
to
the
extent
of
her
little
power
.
<EOS>
She
had
pushed
against
her
going
out
of
church
,
and
had
excused
herself
with
all
the
easiness
of
equality
.
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
dame
,
I
axes
pardon
,
but
you
be
grown
so
mortal
stout
these
times
.
<EOS>
"
She
had
inquired
with
apparent
cordiality
of
Mr.
Lookaloft
after
"
the
woman
that
owned
him
,
"
and
had
,
as
she
thought
,
been
on
the
whole
able
to
hold
her
own
pretty
well
against
her
aspiring
neighbour
.
<EOS>
Now
,
however
,
she
found
herself
distinctly
put
into
a
separate
and
inferior
class
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Lookaloft
was
asked
into
the
Ullathorne
drawing
-
room
merely
because
she
called
her
house
Rosebank
and
had
talked
over
her
husband
into
buying
pianos
and
silk

instead
of
putting
his
money
by
to
stock

for
his
sons
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Greenacre
,
much
as
she
reverenced
Miss
Thorne
,
and
highly
as
she
respected
her
husband
's
landlord
,
could
not
but
look
on
this
as
an
act
of
injustice
done
to
her
and
hers
.
<EOS>
Hitherto
the
Lookalofts
had
never
been
recognized
as
being
of
a
different
class
from
the
Greenacres
.
<EOS>
Their
pretensions
were
all
self
-
pretensions
,
their
finery
was
all
paid
for
by
themselves
and
not
granted
to
them
by
others
.
<EOS>
The
local
sovereigns
of
the
vicinity
,
the
district
fountains
of
honour
,
had
hitherto
conferred
on
them
the
stamp
of
no
rank
.
<EOS>
Hitherto
their
crinoline
petticoats
,
late
hours
,
and
mincing
gait
had
been
a
fair
subject
of
Mrs.
Greenacre
's
raillery
,
and
this
raillery
had
been
a
safety
-
valve
for
her
envy
.
<EOS>
Now
,
however
,
and
from
henceforward
,
the
case
would
be
very
different
.
<EOS>
Now
the
Lookalofts
would
boast
that
their

had
been
sanctioned
by
the
gentry

the
country
;
now
they
would
declare

that
their

.
<EOS>
They

sat

;

;
they
were
about
to
sit

to
table
in
company

!
<EOS>
Bab
Lookaloft
,
as

,

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Stubbs

.
<EOS>
He

,

plasterer

.
<EOS>
It

Barchester

just

.
<EOS>
He

what

would

,
but

great

.
<EOS>
Not
only

Mr.
Plomacy
order

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
The
goddess
Mercy
,

,
the

that
ever

,
and

,
frail
,
erring
man
,
appeared
on
the
field
in
the
person
of
Mr.
Greenacre
.
<EOS>
Never
was
interceding
goddess
more
welcome
.
  
<EOS>
"
Come
,
man
,
"
said
Mr.
Greenacre
,
"
never
stick
at
trifles
such
a
day
as
this
.
<EOS>
I
know
the
lad
well
.
<EOS>
Let
him
bide
at
my
axing
.
<EOS>
Madam
wo
n't
miss
what
he
can
eat
and
drink
,
I
know
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Now
Mr.
Plomacy
and
Mr.
Greenacre
were
sworn
friends
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Plomacy
had
at
his
own
disposal
as
comfortable
a
room
as
there
was
in
Ullathorne
House
,
but
he
was
a
bachelor
,
and
alone
there
,
and
,
moreover
,
smoking
in
the
house
was
not
allowed
even
to
Mr.
Plomacy
.
<EOS>
His
moments
of
truest
happiness
were
spent
in
a
huge
armchair
in
the
warmest
corner
of
Mrs.
Greenacre
's
beautifully
clean
front
kitchen
.
<EOS>
"
Twas
there
that
the
inner
man
dissolved
itself
and
poured
itself
out
in
streams
of
pleasant
chat
;
"
twas
there
that
he
was
respected
and
yet
at
his
ease
;
"
twas
there
,
and
perhaps
there
only
,
that
he
could
unburden

from
the
ceremonies
of
life
without
offending
the
dignity
of
those
above

,
or
incurring

of
those

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Twas
there
that
his
long
pipe
was
always
to
be
found
on
the
accustomed
chimney
-
board
,
not
only
permitted
but
encouraged
.
  
<EOS>
Such
being

state

case
,
it
was
not

Mr.
Plomacy

Mr.
Greenacre
;
but

.
  
<EOS>
"
Eat
and

,
Mr.
Greenacre
!
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
It

he

,

<EOS>
He

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Plasterer
!
<EOS>
I

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
He

,

,

Plomacy
.
<EOS>
And

,
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
You

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

;

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
And

shock

.
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
Which

it

.
  
<EOS>
But

was
not

,

<EOS>
This

<EOS>

<EOS>
All

swimmingly
 
that

,
if

.
<EOS>
Sir
Harkaway
Gorse
proposed

,

a
blood

-

,
always

and
not

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Thorne
returned
thanks
,

he
hoped

always

run
when

and
then

health

of
the

.
<EOS>
His

was
very
much

by
seeing
so
many

at
her
poor
board
.
<EOS>
They
were
all
aware
that
important

made

.
<EOS>
As

,

,

<EOS>
an
opinion
<EOS>
,

<EOS>
And

,

.
  
<EOS>
And
then

Honourable
George
returned

.
<EOS>
We
will
not

him
through
the
different

of
his
somewhat

.
<EOS>
Those
immediately
in
his

found
it
at
first

to
get

on
his
legs
,
but
much
greater

was
soon

in

to

.
<EOS>
One
of
two
arrangements
should
certainly

in
these
days
:
either
let
all
speech
-
making

;

.
<EOS>
As

,

do

.
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
He

,

.
<EOS>
The

,
a

.
<EOS>
But
what

.
  
<EOS>
And
so

passed

.
   
<EOS>
Ullathorne
Sports
 
<EOS>
Act
II
 
"
<EOS>
That
which
has
made
them
drunk
has
made
me
bold
.
"
<EOS>
"
Twas
thus
that
Mr.
Slope
encouraged
himself
,
as
he
left
the
dining
-
room
in

of
Eleanor
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
indeed
seen
in
that
room
any
person
really
intoxicated
,
but
there
had
been
a
good
deal
of
wine
drunk
,
and
Mr.
Slope
had
not
hesitated
to
take
his
share
,
in
order
to
screw
himself
up
to
the
undertaking
which
he
had
in
hand
.
<EOS>
He
is
not
the
first
man
who
has
thought
it
expedient
to
call
in
the
assistance
of
Bacchus
on
such

occasion
.
  
<EOS>
Eleanor
was
out
through
the
window
and
on
the
grass
before
she
perceived
that
she
was
followed
.
<EOS>
Just
at
that
moment
the
guests
were
nearly
all
occupied
at
the
tables
.
<EOS>
Here
and
there
were
to
be
seen
a
constant
couple
or

,
who
preferred
their
own
sweet
discourse
to
the

or
the

which
fell
from
the

of
the
Honourable
George
and

of
Barchester
;
but
the
grounds
were
as
nearly
vacant
as
Mr.
Slope
could
wish

to
be
.
  
<EOS>
Eleanor
saw
that
she
was
pursued
,
and
as

,
when

is
no
longer

,
will
turn
to

and
attack

,
so
did

turn
upon
Mr.
Slope
.
  
<EOS>
"
Pray
do
n't
let
me
take
you
from
the
room
,
"
said
she
,
speaking
with
all

which
she

.
<EOS>
"
I
have
come
out
to
look
for

friend
.
<EOS>
I
must
beg

,
Mr.
Slope
,
to
