.
"
  
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Slope
would
not
be
thus
entreated
.
<EOS>
He
had
observed
all
day
that
Mrs.
Bold
was
not
cordial
to
him
,
and
this
had
to
a
certain
extent
oppressed
him
.
<EOS>
But
he
did
not
deduce
from
this
any
assurance
that
his
aspirations
were
in
vain
.
<EOS>
He
saw
that
she
was
angry
with
him
.
<EOS>
Might
she
not
be
so
because
he
had
so
long
tampered
with
her
feelings
 
<EOS>
might
it
not
arise
from
his
having
,
as
he
knew
was
the
case
,
caused
her
name
to
be
bruited
about
in

own
without

of
confessing
to
the
world
that
henceforth
their
names
were
to
be
one
and
the
same
?
<EOS>
Poor
lady
.
<EOS>
He
had
within
him
a
certain
Christian
conscience
-
stricken
feeling
of
remorse
on
this
head
.
<EOS>
It
might
be
that
he
had
wronged
her
by
his

.
<EOS>
He
had
,
however
,
at
the
present
moment
imbibed
too
much
of
Mr.
Thorne
's
champagne
to
have
any
inward
misgivings
.
<EOS>
He
was
right
in
repeating
the
boast
of
Lady
Macbeth
:
he
was
not
drunk
,
but
he
was
bold
enough
for
anything
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
pity
that
in
such
a
state
he
could
not
have
encountered
Mrs.
Proudie
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
must
permit
me
to
attend
you
,
"
said
he
;
"
I
could
not

of

you

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Indeed
you
must
,
Mr.
Slope
,
"
said
Eleanor
still
very
stiffly
,
"
<EOS>
for
it
is
my
special
wish
to
be
alone
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
time
for
letting
the
great
secret
escape
him
had
already
come
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
saw
that
it
must
be
now
or
never
,
and
he
was
determined
that
it
should
be
now
.
<EOS>
This
was
not
his
first
attempt
at
winning
a
fair
lady
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
on
his
knees
,
looked
unutterable
things
with
his

,
and
whispered
honeyed
words
before
this
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
he
was
somewhat
an
adept
at
these
things
,
and
had
only
to
adapt
to
the
perhaps
different
taste
of
Mrs.
Bold
the
well
-
remembered
rhapsodies
which
had
once
so
much

Olivia
Proudie
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
not

me
to

you
,
Mrs.
Bold
,
"
said

with
an
impassioned

,
impassioned
and
sanctified
as
well
,
with
that
sort

look
which
is
not
uncommon
with
gentlemen
of
Mr.
Slope
's
school
and
which
may
perhaps
be
called
the
tender
-
pious
.
<EOS>
"
Do
not
ask
me
to
leave
you
till
I
have
spoken
a
few
words
with
which
my
heart
is
full
 
which
I
have
come
hither
purposely
to
say
.
"
  
<EOS>
Eleanor
saw
how
it
was
now
.
<EOS>
She
knew
directly
what
it
was
she
was
about
to
go
through
,
and
very
miserable
the
knowledge
made
her
.
<EOS>
Of
course
she
could
refuse
Mr.
Slope
,
and
there
would
be
an
end
of
that
,
one
might
say
.
<EOS>
But
there
would
not
be
an
end
of
it
,
as
far
as
Eleanor
was
concerned
.
<EOS>
The
very

of
Mr.
Slope
's
making

offer
to

would

to
the

and
,

,
a

of
Mr.
Arabin
's

.
<EOS>
The
widow
could
not
bring
herself
to
endure
with
patience
the
idea
that
she
had
been
in
the
wrong
.
<EOS>
She
had
defended
Mr.
Slope
,
she
had
declared
herself
quite
justified
in
admitting
him
among
her

,
had
ridiculed

idea
of
his

,
and
had

's
caution

:
now

was
about
to

proved
to
her
in
a

that
the

had
been

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't

what

can

,

,

;
"
and
she

,

,
and
looked

in
a
manner
that
ought
to
have
frozen
him
.
  
<EOS>
But
gentlemen
are
not
easily
frozen
when
they
are
full
of
champagne
,
and
it
would
not
at
any
time
have
been
easy
to
freeze
Mr.
Slope
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
are
things
,
Mrs.
Bold
,
which
a
man
can
not
well
say
before
a
crowd
;
which
perhaps

well

at
any
time
;
which
indeed
he
may
most
fervently
desire
to
get
spoken
,
and
which
he
may
yet
find

almost
impossible
to
utter
.
<EOS>
It
is
such
things
as
these
that
I
now
wish
to
say
to
you
;
"
and
then
the
tender
-
pious
look
was
repeated
,
with
a
little
more
emphasis
even
than
before
.
  
<EOS>
Eleanor
had
not
found
it
practicable
to
stand
stock
still
before
the
dining
-
room
window
,
there
receive
his
offer
in
full
view
of
Miss
Thorne
's
guests
.
<EOS>
She
had
therefore
in
self
-
defence
walked
on
,
and
thus
Mr.
Slope
had
gained
his
object
of
walking
with
her
.
<EOS>
He
now
offered

his
arm
.
  
<EOS>
"

,
Mr.
Slope
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
must

be
so

?
"

.
<EOS>
"
Must
it
be
 
"
  
"
Yes
,
"

,

,
"
as

as

,
if
you

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
had
hoped
,
Mrs.
Bold
 
I
had
hoped
 
"
  
"
Pray

nothing
,
Mr.
Slope
,
as
far

I

;

;

.
<EOS>
Our

.
<EOS>
Pray
,

;

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Bold
was
certainly
treating
Mr.
Slope
rather

,
and
he

so
.
<EOS>
She
was
rejecting
him
before

had
offered

,
and
informing

at

that

was

a

much
on

to

.
<EOS>
She

not

attempt
  
From
such

as
"
no
"
To

.
  
<EOS>
He
was
still

very

,

that
,

Mrs.

;

.
<EOS>
The

was
bearing

,

,
with
too

,

.
<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
would
be
tender
as

,

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
could
undoubtedly

,

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
That

,
"

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
What

pass

<EOS>
so

?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

<EOS>
"
Beautiful

,
"

"

.
<EOS>
Yes

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Next

.
"
<EOS>
(
Mr.
Slope
's

,

.
)
<EOS>
"
How

.
<EOS>
Say
,
Eleanor
,

,

"
  
<EOS>
Eleanor

<EOS>
"
Ah
,
Eleanor
,
"

"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
,
Eleanor
 
"
  
"
My

Slope
,

Bold
,
"

,
who
,

<EOS>
"
Sweetest

,

,
"

,

the
champagne
broke

,
and

pass

.
<EOS>
He

,
for
up

.
<EOS>
They

,
and
Mr.
Slope
therefore
no

that

.
<EOS>
It
may

of
measures
had

Olivia
Proudie
.
<EOS>
Be

,

.
  
<EOS>
She

far
 
not
,

,
beyond
arm
's
length
 
and
then
,
quick

thought
<EOS>
,

little

a
box
on
the
ear
with

right

that

.
  
<EOS>
And
now
it
is
to

will
lay

,

,

.
<EOS>
She

,

.
<EOS>
At

,

.
<EOS>
I
have
suspected
her
all

,
a
third

;
she
has
no

of
the

of
a

,

.
<EOS>
At
one

is

Stanhope
;
then

is

Arabin
;
anon
she
comes

lover
 
and
all
before

yet
a
widow
of
two
years
"

.
  
<EOS>
She

,
and

averred
that

is
not

,
not

nor

.
<EOS>
It
were
to

that

Mr.
Slope
in

.
<EOS>
In
doing

she
derogated
from

and

.
<EOS>
Had

Belgravia
,

that

,

<EOS>
,

,

,

.
<EOS>
As

,

too

,

too

.
<EOS>
She
was
too
keen
in
the
feeling

,
a

for
a

,
but
one
in

.
<EOS>
And

Mr.
Slope
's

,

than

by

had

,

,
seemed

.
<EOS>
She
had
,

,
a
true
instinct
as
to
the
man
;
he
was
capable

in

.
<EOS>
To

from

.
<EOS>
It
went
directly
to
his

.
<EOS>
He
conceived
himself
lowered
in
his
dignity
and
personally
outraged
.
<EOS>
He
could
almost
have
struck
at
her
again
in
his
rage
.
<EOS>
Even
the
pain
was
a
great
annoyance
to
him
,
and
the
feeling
that
his
clerical
character
had
been
wholly

sorely

.
  
<EOS>
There
are
such
men
:
men
who
can
endure
no
taint
on
their
personal
self
-
respect
,
even
from

woman
;
men
whose

are
to

such
sacred

that
a
joke
against
them
is

,
and
a
rough
touch
downright

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
was
such
a
man
,
and
therefore
the
slap
on
the
face
that
he
got
from
Eleanor
was
,
as
far
as
he
was
concerned
,
the
fittest

which
could
have
been
administered
to
him
.
  
<EOS>
But
nevertheless
,
she
should
not
have
raised
her
hand
against
the
man
.
<EOS>
Ladies
"
hands
,
so
soft
,
so
sweet
,
so
delicious
to
the

,
so

to

eye
,
so

in

,
were
not
made
to

's

.
<EOS>
The
moment
the
deed
was
done
Eleanor
felt
that
she
had
sinned
against
all
propriety
,
and
would

given
little
worlds
to
recall

.
<EOS>
In

first

all

man
's

.
<EOS>
Her

,
however
,
and

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
never
,
never

,
"
she

,

,
and
so

she
put
foot
to

and
ran
quickly

along
the
path
to

house
.
  
<EOS>
But
how
shall
I
sing
the
divine
wrath
of
Mr.
Slope
,
or
how
invoke
the
tragic
muse
to
describe
the
rage
which
swelled
the
celestial

of
the
bishop
's
chaplain
?
<EOS>
Such
an
undertaking
by
no
means
befits
the
low
-
heeled
buskin
of
modern
fiction
.
<EOS>
The
painter
put
a
veil
over
Agamemnon
's
face
when
called
on
to
depict
the
father
's
grief
at
the
early

of
his
devoted
daughter
.
<EOS>
The
god
,
when
he
resolved
to
punish
the
rebellious
winds
,
abstained
from
mouthing
empty
threats
.
<EOS>
We
will
not
attempt
to
tell
with
what
mighty
surgings
of
the
inner
heart
Mr.
Slope
swore
to
revenge
himself
on
the
woman
who
had
disgraced
him
,
nor
will
we
vainly
strive
to
depict
his
deep
agony
of
soul
.
  
<EOS>
There
he
is
,
however
,
alone
in
the
garden
walk
,
and
we
must
contrive
to
bring
him
out
of
it
.
<EOS>
He
was
not
willing
to
come
forth
quite
at
once
.
<EOS>
His
cheek
was
stinging
with
the
weight
of
Eleanor
's
fingers
,
and
he
fancied
that
everyone
who
looked
at
him
would
be
able
to
see
on
his
face
the
traces
of
what
he
had
endured
.
<EOS>
He
stood
awhile
,
becoming
redder
and
redder
with
rage
.
<EOS>
He
stood
motionless
,
undecided
,
glaring
with
his
eyes
,
thinking
of
the
pains
and
penalties
of
Hades
,
and
meditating
how
he
might
best
devote
his
enemy
to
the
infernal
gods
with
all
the
passion
of
his
accustomed
eloquence
.
<EOS>
He
longed
in
his
heart
to
be
preaching
at
her
.
"
<EOS>
Twas
thus
that
he
was
ordinarily
avenged
of
sinning
mortal
men
and
women
.
<EOS>
Could
he
at
once
have
ascended
his
Sunday
rostrum
and
fulminated
at
her
such
denunciations
as
his
spirit
delighted
in
,
his
bosom
would
have
been
greatly
eased
.
  
<EOS>
But
how
preach
to
Mr.
Thorne
's
laurels
,
or
how
preach
indeed
at
all
in
such
a
vanity
fair
as
this
now
going
on
at
Ullathorne
?
<EOS>
And
then
he
began
to
feel
a
righteous
disgust
at
the
wickedness
of
the
doings
around
him
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
justly
chastised
for
lending
,
by
his
presence
,
a
sanction
to
such
worldly
lures
.
<EOS>
The
gaiety
of
society
,
the
mirth
of
banquets
,
the
laughter
of
the
young
,
and
the
eating
and
drinking
of
the
elders
were
,
for
awhile
,
without
excuse
in
his
sight
.
<EOS>
What
had
he
now
brought
down
upon
himself
by
sojourning
thus
in
the
tents
of
the
heathen
?
<EOS>
He
had
consorted
with
idolaters
round
the
altars
of
Baal
,
and
therefore
a
sore
punishment
had
come
upon
him
.
<EOS>
He
then
thought
of
the
Signora
Neroni
,
and
his
soul
within
him
was
full
of
sorrow
.
<EOS>
He
had
an
inkling
 
a
true
inkling
 
that
he
was
a
wicked
,
sinful
man
,
but
it
led
him
in
no
right
direction
;
he
could
admit
no
charity
in
his
heart
.
<EOS>
He
felt
debasement
coming
on
him
,
and
he
longed
to
shake
it
off
,
to
rise
up
in
his
stirrup
,
to
mount
to
high
places
and
great
power
,
that
he
might
get
up
into
a
mighty
pulpit
and
preach
to
the
world
a
loud
sermon
against
Mrs.
Bold
.
  
<EOS>
There
he
stood
fixed
to
the
gravel
for
about
ten
minutes
.
<EOS>
Fortune
favoured
him
so
far
that
no
prying
eyes
came
to
look
upon
him
in
his
misery
.
<EOS>
Then
a
shudder
passed
over
his
whole
frame
;
he
collected
himself
and
slowly
wound
his
way
round
to
the
lawn
,
advancing
along
the
path
and
not
returning
in
the
direction
which
Eleanor
had
taken
.
<EOS>
When
he
reached
the
tent
,
he
found
the
bishop
standing
there
in
conversation
with
the
Master
of
Lazarus
.
<EOS>
His
lordship
had
come
out
to
air
himself
after
the
exertion
of
his
speech
.
  
<EOS>
"
This
is
very
pleasant
 
very
pleasant
,
my
lord
,
is
it
not
?
"
said
Mr.
Slope
with
his
most
gracious

,
pointing
to
the
tent
;
"
very
pleasant
.
<EOS>
It
is
delightful
to
see
so
many
persons
enjoying
themselves
so
thoroughly
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
thought
he
might
force
the
bishop
to
introduce
him
to
Dr.
Gwynne
.
<EOS>
A
very
great
example
had
declared
and
practised
the
wisdom
of
being
everything
to
everybody
,
and
Mr.
Slope
was
desirous
of
following
it
.
<EOS>
His
maxim
was
never
to
lose
a
chance
.
<EOS>
The
bishop
,
however
,
at
the
present
moment
was
not
very

to
increase
Mr.
Slope
's
circle
of
acquaintance
among
his
clerical
brethren
.
<EOS>
He
had
his
own
reasons
for
dropping
any
marked
allusion
to
his
domestic
chaplain
,
and
he
therefore
made
his
shoulder
rather
cold
for
the
occasion
.
  
<EOS>
"
Very
,
very
,
"
said
he
without

,

Slope
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
therefore
,

.
<EOS>
I
,

,
Dr.
Gwynne
 
"
  
"
Dr.
Gwynne
,
"

as

Barchester
.
  
<EOS>
The
Master
of
Lazarus
also
raised
his
hat
and
bowed

Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
There
is
not
a
more

in

Master
of
Lazarus
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
lord
,
"

Slope

"
pray

Gwynne
.
<EOS>
The
opportunity
is
too
much
in
my

be
lost
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
bishop
had
no
help
for

.
<EOS>
"
My
chaplain
,
Dr.
Gwynne
,
"
said
he
,
"
my
present

,
Mr.
Slope
.
"
<EOS>
He
certainly
made

as

by

"

Mr.

.
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Slope
cared
nothing

.
<EOS>
He

,
and

.
<EOS>
It
might
probably

to
pass
that

would

.
<EOS>
What

future

,

?
<EOS>
Had

-

"

"
?
<EOS>
Had

this

?
  
<EOS>
So

the
bishop
,

.
  
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
One

<EOS>
"
What

,

?
"

<EOS>
"
The

,

;

.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.

no

with
the
Master
of
Lazarus
,
and

.
  
<EOS>
Eleanor
,
as
we
have
said
,

never

communication

,

.
<EOS>
The

,

,
of
what
she
had
done

,

she

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Twas
<EOS>
thus
she
played
the
second

in
that
day
's

.
   
<EOS>
Mrs.
Bold
Confides
Her
Sorrow
to
Her
Friend
Miss
Stanhope
 
<EOS>
When
Mrs.
Bold
came
to
the
end
of
the
walk
and
faced
the
lawn
,
she
began
to
bethink
herself
what
she
should
do
.
<EOS>
Was
she
to
wait
there
till
Mr.
Slope
caught
her
,
or
was
she
to
go
in
among
the
crowd
with
tears
in
her
eyes
and
passion
in
her
face
?
<EOS>
She
might
in
truth
have
stood
there
long
enough
without
any
reasonable
fear
of
further
immediate
persecution
from
Mr.
Slope
,
but
we
are
all
inclined
to
magnify
the
bugbears
which
frighten
us
.
<EOS>
In
her
present
state
of
dread
she
did
not
know
of
what
atrocity
he
might
venture
to
be
guilty
.
<EOS>
Had
anyone
told
her
a
week
ago
that
he
would
have
put
his
arm
round
her
waist
at
this
party
of
Miss
Thorne
's
,
she
would
have
been
utterly

.
<EOS>
Had
she
been
informed
that
he
would
be
seen
on
the
following
Sunday
walking
down
the
High
Street
in
a
scarlet
coat
and
top
boots
<EOS>
,
she
would
not
have
thought
such
a

more
improbable
.
  
<EOS>
But
this
improbable
iniquity
he
had
committed
,
and
now
there
was
nothing
she
could
not
believe
of
him
.
<EOS>
In
the
first
place
it
was
quite
manifest
that
he
was
tipsy
;
in
the
next
place
it
was
to
be
taken
as
proved
that
all
his
religion
was
sheer
hypocrisy
;
and
finally
the
man
was
utterly
shameless
.
<EOS>
She
therefore
stood
watching
for
the
sound
of
his
footfall
,
not
without
some
fear
that
he
might
creep
out
at
her
suddenly
from
among
the
bushes
.
  
<EOS>
As
she
thus
stood
she
saw
Charlotte
Stanhope
at
a
little
distance
from
her
,
walking
quickly
across
the
grass
.
<EOS>
Eleanor
's
handkerchief
was
in
her
hand
,
and
putting
it
to
her
face
so
as
to
conceal
her

,
she
ran
across
the
lawn
and
joined
her
friend
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Charlotte
,
"
she
said
,
almost

much

to

;
"
I
am
so

I

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Glad

have
found
me
!
"
<EOS>
said
Charlotte
,

;
<EOS>
"
that
's
a
good
joke
.
<EOS>
Why
Bertie

.
<EOS>
He

you
have
gone

Slope
,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

,

,
"

.
  
<EOS>

Why

?
"

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
What

?
"
  
<EOS>
Eleanor

.
<EOS>
She
was
a
good

,
as

,

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

?

,

<EOS>
Only

man
 
"
  
"
<EOS>
What

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
There
are
some

in
which
both
men

women
feel
themselves
imperatively
called
on
to

confidence
,

.
<EOS>
There
are

who
never

,

,
but

generally
dull
,
close
,

,
"
gloomy

,

live
in

.
<EOS>
"
There

nothing
of
the
gnome
about
Eleanor
,
and
she
therefore

to
tell
Charlotte
Stanhope
the
whole
story
about
Mr.
Slope
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
horrid
man
;
that
Mr.
Slope
,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Did

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
But

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

I

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
But

"
  
<EOS>
"
But

<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"
Nice
!
"

.
<EOS>
"
He

most
fulsome
,

.
<EOS>
What

to

to

?
 
<EOS>
I
<EOS>
that
never

I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That

.
<EOS>
He

that

.
"
  
<EOS>
This

.
<EOS>
It

all

month
past
 
and
which
experience
now

.
<EOS>
Eleanor
resolved

.
<EOS>
The

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
But

,
my

?
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
He
 
he
 
he
 
"
  
"
Well
 
come
,

ca

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

"

.
<EOS>
"
I

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

But

"
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>

:

,

<EOS>
Oh

<EOS>
"

"
I

?

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
  
"

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ha
,
ha
,
ha
!
"
Charlotte
Stanhope
laughed
heartily
at
the
finale
to
the
tragedy
.
<EOS>
It
was
delightful
to
her
to
think
that
Mr.
Slope
had
had
his
ears
boxed
.
<EOS>
She
did
not
quite
appreciate
the
feeling
which
made
her
friend
so
unhappy
at
the
result
of
the
interview
.
<EOS>
To
her
thinking
the
matter
had
ended
happily
enough
as
regarded
the
widow
,
who
indeed
was
entitled
to
some
sort
of
triumph
among
her
friends
.
<EOS>
Whereas
to
Mr.
Slope
would
be
due
all
those
gibes
and
jeers
which
would
naturally
follow
such
an
affair
.
<EOS>
His
friends
would
ask
him
whether
his
ears
tingled
whenever
he
saw
a
widow
,
and
he
would
be
cautioned
that
beautiful
things
were
made
to
be
looked
at
and
not
to
be
touched
.
  
<EOS>
Such
were
Charlotte
Stanhope
's
views
on
such
matters
,
but
she
did
not
at
the
present
moment
clearly
explain
them
to
Mrs.
Bold
.
<EOS>
Her
object
was
to
endear
herself
to
her
friend
,
and
therefore
,
having
had
her
laugh
,
she
was
ready
enough
to
offer
sympathy
.
<EOS>
Could
Bertie
do
anything
?
<EOS>
Should
Bertie
speak
to
the
man
and
warn
him
that
in
future
he
must
behave
with
more
decorum
?
<EOS>
Bertie
indeed
,
she
declared
,
would

<EOS>
Ullathorne
Sports
 
<EOS>
Act
III
 
<EOS>
And
now
Miss
Thorne
's
guests
were
beginning
to
take
their
departure
,
and
the
amusement
of
those
who
remained
was
becoming
slack
.
<EOS>
It
was
getting
dark
,
and
ladies
in
morning
costumes
were
thinking
that
,
if
they
were
to
appear
by
candlelight
,
they
ought
to
readjust
themselves
.
<EOS>
Some
young
gentlemen
had
been
heard
to
talk
so
loud
that
prudent
mammas
determined
to
retire
judiciously
,
and
the
more
discreet
of
the
male
sex
,
whose
libations
had
been
moderate
,
felt
that
there
was
not
much
more
left
for
them
to
do
.
  
<EOS>
Morning
parties
,
as
a
rule
,
are
failures
.
<EOS>
People
never
know
how
to
get
away
from
them
gracefully
.
<EOS>
A
picnic
on
an
island
or
a
mountain
or
in
a
wood
may
perhaps
be
permitted
.
<EOS>
There
is
no
master
of
the
mountain
bound
by
courtesy
to
bid
you
stay
while
in
his
heart
he
is
longing
for
your
departure
.
<EOS>
But
in
a
private
house
or
in
private
grounds
a
morning
party
is
a
bore
.
<EOS>
One
is
called
on
to
eat
and
drink
at
unnatural
hours
.
<EOS>
One
is
obliged
to
give
up
the
day
,
which
is
useful
,
and
is
then
left
without
resource
for
the
evening
,
which
is
useless
.
<EOS>
One
gets
home
fagged
and
_
désoeuvré
_
,
and
yet
at
an
hour
too
early
for
bed
.
<EOS>
There
is
no
comfortable
resource
left
.
<EOS>
Cards
in
these
genteel
days
are
among
the
things
tabooed
,
and
a
rubber
of
whist
is
impracticable
.
  
<EOS>
All
this
began
now
to
be
felt
.
<EOS>
Some
young
people
had
come
with
some
amount
of
hope
that
they
might
get
up
a
dance
in
the
evening
,
and
were
unwilling
to
leave
till
<EOS>
all
such
hope
was
at
an
end
.
<EOS>
Others
,
fearful
of
staying
longer
than
was
expected
,
had
ordered
their
carriages
early
,
and
were
doing
their
best
to
go
,
solicitous
for
their
servants
and
horses
.
<EOS>
The
countess
and
her
noble
brood
were
among
the
first
to
leave
,
and
as
regarded
the
Hon
.
<EOS>
George
,
it
was
certainly
time
that
he
did
so
.
<EOS>
Her
ladyship
was
in
a
great
fret
and
fume
.
<EOS>
Those
horrid
roads
would
,
she
was
sure
,
be
the
death
of
her
if
unhappily
she
were
caught
in
them
by
the
dark
night
.
<EOS>
The
lamps
she
was
assured
were
good
,
but
no
lamp
could
withstand
the
jolting
of
the
roads
of
East
Barsetshire
.
<EOS>
The
De
Courcy
property
lay
in
the
western
division
of
the
county
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Proudie
could
not
stay
when
the
countess
was
gone
.
<EOS>
So
the
bishop
was
searched
for
by
the
Revs
.
<EOS>
Messrs.
Grey
and
Green
and
found
in
one
corner
of
the
tent
enjoying
himself
thoroughly
in
a

on
the
hebdomadal
board
.
<EOS>
He
obeyed
,
however
,
the
behests
of
his
lady
without
finishing
the
sentence
in
which
he
was
promising
to
Dr.
Gwynne
that
his
authority
at
Oxford
should
remain
unimpaired
,
and
the
episcopal

turned

towards
the

.
<EOS>
Then
the
Grantlys
went
.
<EOS>
Before
they
did
so
,
Mr.
Harding
managed
to
whisper
a
word
into
his
daughter
's
ear
.
<EOS>
Of
course
,
he
said
,
he
would
undeceive
the
Grantlys
as
to
that
foolish

about
Mr.
Slope
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
no
,
"
said
Eleanor
;
"
pray
<EOS>
do
not
 
pray
wait
till
I
see
you
.
<EOS>
You
will
be
home
in
a

or

,
and
then
I
will

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
home
to
-
morrow
,
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
so

,
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
You
will
come
and

me
,
and
then
we
shall
be
so

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
promised
.
<EOS>
He
did
not

what
there

to
be

,
or
why
Dr.
Grantly
's

,
but

.
<EOS>
He
owed
some

to
his
daughter
,
and
he
thought
that
he
might
best
make

by

.
  
<EOS>
And
thus
the
people
were
thinning
off
by

as
Charlotte

about
in

Bertie
.
<EOS>
Their

might
have
been
long
had

.
<EOS>
He
was
comfortably

in
the
ha
-
ha
,
with
his
back
to
the
sloping
side
,
smoking
a

,
and
eagerly
engaged
in

with
some

from

of

county
,
whom

had

before
,

was
also

under

's

and

with

to
an
account
given
by

of

of
Eastern

.
  
<EOS>
"
Bertie
,
I
am
seeking
you
everywhere
,
"
said
Charlotte
.
<EOS>
"
Come
up
here
at
once
.
"
  
<EOS>
Bertie
looked
up
out
of
the
ha
-
ha
and
saw
the
two
ladies
before
him
.
<EOS>
As
there
was
nothing
for
him
but
to
obey
,
he
got
up
and
threw
away
his
cigar
.
<EOS>
From
the
first
moment
of
his
acquaintance
with
her
<EOS>
he
had
liked
Eleanor
Bold
.
<EOS>
Had
he
been
left
to
his
own
devices
,
had
she
been

,
and
had
it
then

quite
out

that
he
should

her
,
he
would
most
probably
have
fallen
violently
in

with
her
.
<EOS>
But
now
he
could
not
help
regarding
her
somewhat
as
he
did
the
marble

at
Carrara
,
as
he
had
done
his
easel
and
palette
,
as
he
had
done
the
lawyer
's
chambers
in
London
 
in
fact
,
as
he
had
invariably
regarded
everything
by
which
it
had
been
proposed
to
him
to
obtain
the
means
of
living
.
<EOS>
Eleanor
Bold
appeared
before
him
,
no
longer
as
a
beautiful
woman
,
but
as
a
new
profession
called
matrimony
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
profession
indeed
requiring
but
little
labour
,
and
one
in
which
an
income
was
insured
to
him
.
<EOS>
But
nevertheless
he
had
been
as
it
were
goaded
on
to
it
;
his
sister
had
talked
to
him
of
Eleanor
,
just
as
she
had
talked
of
busts
and

.
<EOS>
Bertie
did
not
dislike
money
,
but
he
hated
the
very
thought
of
earning
it
.
<EOS>
He
was
now
called
away
from
his
pleasant
cigar
to
earn
it
,
by
offering
himself
as
a
husband
to
Mrs.
Bold
.
<EOS>
The
work
indeed
was
made
easy
enough
,
for
in
lieu
of
his
having
to
seek
the
widow
,
the

had
apparently

to

.
  
<EOS>
He
made
some

absurd
excuse
to
his

and
then
,
throwing
away
his

,
climbed
up
the
wall

the
ha
-
ha
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
Come

Bold
an

,
"

,
"

,

_

_
,

.
<EOS>
Your

,

,

,

is

.
"
  
<EOS>
Bertie
immediately
gave
his
arm
to
Eleanor
,
walking
between
her
and
his
sister
.
<EOS>
He
had
lived
too
long
abroad
to
fall
into
the
Englishman
's
habit
of
offering
each
an
arm
to
two
ladies
at
the
same
time
 
a
habit
,
by

by
,
which
foreigners
regard
as
an

to
bigamy
,
or
a
sort

.
  
<EOS>
The
little
history
of
Mr.
Slope
's
misconduct
was
then
told
to
Bertie
by
his
sister
,
Eleanor
's
ears
tingling
the
while
.
<EOS>
And
well
they
might
tingle
.
<EOS>
If
it
were
necessary
to
speak
of
the
outrage
at
all
,
why
should

be
spoken
of
to
such

as
Mr.
Stanhope
,
and
why
in
her
own

?
<EOS>
She
knew
she
was
wrong
,
and
was
unhappy
and

,
yet
she
could
think
of
no
way
to
extricate

,
no

to
set
herself

.
<EOS>
Charlotte
spared
her
as
much
as
she
possibly

,
spoke
of
the
whole

as

Mr.
Slope
had
taken

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Mrs.
Bold

,
"

,
"
for

Slope

.
<EOS>
He

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
He

,

,

what

fault
,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,

,

.
<EOS>
Now
I
'll

with

.
<EOS>
The

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's

.
<EOS>
Good

.
<EOS>
Of

.
<EOS>
I

,

,

.
"
<EOS>
And

,
Charlotte

,

alone

.
  
<EOS>
As
Miss
Stanhope
went
off
,
Eleanor
bethought
herself
that
,
as
Mr.
Slope
had
taken
his

,
there
no

any

for
separating
Mr.
Stanhope
from
his

,
who
so

.
<EOS>
It
had
been
arranged
that
he
should
remain
so
as

Mr.
Slope
's

in
the

,
and
act

that

.
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Slope
had
effected
his
own

,
and
there
was
no
possible
reason
now
why
Bertie
should
not
go
with
his
sister
 
<EOS>
at
least
Eleanor
saw
none
,
and
she

much
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
let
Charlotte
have
her
own

,
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
She
has
arranged

,
and
there
will
be
no
end

if
we
make
another

.
<EOS>
Charlotte
always
arranges
everything
in
our
house
and
rules
us
like
a
despot
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
But
the
signora
?
"
said
Eleanor
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
the
signora
can
do
very
well
without
me
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
she
will
have
to
do
without
me
,
"
he
added
,
thinking
rather
of
his
studies
in
Carrara
than
of
his
Barchester
hymeneals
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
you
are
not
going
to
leave
us
?
"
asked
Eleanor
.
  
<EOS>
It
has
been
said
that
Bertie
Stanhope
was
a
man
without
principle
.
<EOS>
He
certainly
was
so
.
<EOS>
He
had
no
power
of
using
active
mental
exertion
to
keep
himself
from
doing
evil
.
<EOS>
Evil
had
no
ugliness
in
his
eyes
;
virtue
no
beauty
.
<EOS>
He
was
void
of
any
of
these
feelings
which
actuate
men
to
do
good
.
<EOS>
But
he
was
perhaps
equally
void
of
those
which
actuate
men
to
do
evil
.
<EOS>
He
got
into
debt
with
utter
recklessness
,
thinking
nothing
as
to
whether
the
tradesmen
would
ever
be
paid
or
not
.
<EOS>
But
he
did
not
invent
active
schemes
of
deceit
for
the
sake
of
extracting
the
goods
of
others
.
<EOS>
If
a
man
gave
him
credit
,
that
was
the
man
's
look
-
out
;
Bertie
Stanhope
troubled
himself
nothing
further
.
<EOS>
In
borrowing
money
he
did
the
same
;
he
gave
people
references
to
"
his
governor
;
"
told
them
that
the
"
old
chap
"
had
a
good
income
;
and
agreed
to
pay
sixty
per
cent
for
the
accommodation
.
<EOS>
All
this
he
did
without
a
scruple
of
conscience
;
but
then
he
never
contrived
active
villainy
.
  
<EOS>
In
this
affair
of
his
marriage
it
had
been
represented
to
him
as
a
matter
of
duty
that
he
ought
to
put
himself
in
possession
of
Mrs.
Bold
's
hand
and
fortune
,
and
at
first
he
had
so
regarded
it
.
<EOS>
About
her
he
had
thought
but
little
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
customary
thing
for
men
situated
as
he
was
to
marry
for
money
,
and
there
was
no
reason
why
he
should
not
do
what
others
around
him
did
.
<EOS>
And
so
he
consented
.
<EOS>
But
now
he
began
to
see
the
matter
in
another
light
.
<EOS>
He
was
setting
himself
down
to
catch
this
woman
,
as
a
cat
sits
to
catch
a
mouse
.
<EOS>
He
was
to
catch
her
,
and
swallow
her
up
,
her
and
her
child
,
and
her
houses
and
land
,
in
order
that
he
might
live
on
her
instead
of
on
his
father
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
cold
,
calculating
,
cautious
cunning
about
this
quite
at
variance
with
Bertie
's
character
.
<EOS>
The
prudence
of
the
measure
was
quite
as
antagonistic
to
his
feelings
as
the
iniquity
.
  
<EOS>
And
then
,
should
he
be
successful
<EOS>
,
what
would
be
the
reward
?
<EOS>
Having
satisfied
his
creditors
with
half
of
the
widow
's
fortune
,
he
would
be
allowed
to
sit
down
quietly
at
Barchester
,
keeping
economical
house
with
the
remainder
.
<EOS>
His
duty
would
be
to
rock
the
cradle
of
the
late
Mr.
Bold
's
child
,
and
his
highest
excitement
a
demure
party
at
Plumstead
Rectory
,
<EOS>
should
it
ultimately
turn
out
that
the
archdeacon
would
be
sufficiently
reconciled
to
receive
him
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
very
little
in
the
programme
to
allure
such
a
man
as
Bertie
Stanhope
.
<EOS>
Would
not
the
Carrara
workshop
,
or
whatever
worldly
career
fortune
might
have
in
store
for
him
,
would
not
almost
anything
be
better
than
this
?
<EOS>
The
lady
herself
was
undoubtedly
all
that
was
desirable
,
but
the
most
desirable
lady
becomes
nauseous
when
she
has
to
be
taken
as
a
pill
.
<EOS>
He
was
pledged
to
his
sister
,
however
,
and
let
him
quarrel
with
whom
he
would
,
it
behoved
him
not
to
quarrel
with
her
.
<EOS>
If
she
were
lost
to
him
,
all
would
be
lost
that
he
could
ever
hope
to
derive
henceforward
from
the
paternal
roof
-
tree
.
<EOS>
His
mother
was
apparently
indifferent
to
his
weal
or
woe
,
to
his
wants
or
his
warfare
.
<EOS>
His
father
's
brow
got
blacker
and
blacker
from
day
to
day
,
as
the
old
man
looked
at
his
hopeless
son
.
<EOS>
And
as
for
Madeline
 
poor
Madeline
,
whom
of
all
of
them
he
liked
the
best
 
<EOS>
she
had
enough
to
do
to
shift
for
herself
.
<EOS>
No
;
come
what
might
,
he
must
cling
to
his
sister
and
obey
her
behests
,
let
them
be
ever
<EOS>
so
stern
 
or
at
the
very
least
seem
to
obey
them
.
<EOS>
Could
not
some
happy
deceit
bring
him
through
in
this
matter
,
so
that
he
might
save
appearances
with
his
sister
and
yet
not
betray
the
widow
to
her
ruin
?
<EOS>
What
if
he
made
a
confederate
of
Eleanor
?
<EOS>
"
Twas
in
this
spirit
that
Bertie
Stanhope
set
about
his
wooing
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
are
not
going
to
leave
Barchester
?
"
asked
Eleanor
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
know
,
"
he
replied
;
"
I

know

what
I
am
going
to
do
.
<EOS>
But
it
is
at
any
rate
certain
that
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
mean

?
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
about
my

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

not

?
"

.
<EOS>
"
Were

a
man
<EOS>
,
I

none
I

to
it
,
except

.
<EOS>
And
I
believe
the
one

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,

,
"

Bertie
with

.
<EOS>
He
knew
in
his

that
he

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
often

,
"

Eleanor
,
who

for
the

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Impertinent
!
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Not

,

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
And

,

,
"
she

.
"
<EOS>
And

,

.
<EOS>
Why
ca

?
"
  
"
<EOS>
And

,

,

?
<EOS>
Or

,

,

,

,

;

death
will
be

out
and
poking

with

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Eleanor

,
but
<EOS>
yet

,
the

of
the
artist
as

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

's

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"

,

.
"
  
"
Yes

.
<EOS>
Do

,

Stanhope
,

will

.
<EOS>
Come

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

,

on

.
<EOS>
Only

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
My

are
too

,

,

's

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

Bold
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,

;
"
I

be

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Wholly

?
"
said
Eleanor
,

,
and
not

,
his

.
  
<EOS>
"
Wholly
by
you
,
"
said
Bertie
,
dropping
his
companion
's

and
standing
before
her
on
the

.
<EOS>
In
their
walk
they
had
come
exactly
to
the
spot
in
which
Eleanor
had
been
provoked
into
slapping
Mr.
Slope
's
face
.
<EOS>
Could
it
be
possible
that
this
place
was
peculiarly
unpropitious
to
her
comfort
?
<EOS>
Could
it
be
possible
that
she
should
here

to
encounter
yet
another
amorous

?
  
<EOS>
"
If

will

,

Stanhope
,

,
and

as

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing

,

.
<EOS>
But

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Will

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
really
do
not
know
what
you
can

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
you
can
not

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
But

,
Mrs.
Bold
,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

,
"
said

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
were

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There

;
I
do

's

<EOS>
and

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
do

,
"
said

,
"

I

,
"
and

,
hardly

that

.
  
<EOS>
And
it
was
no

that

.
<EOS>
He
had
to

his

the

had

to
rob

,

her

,
or

he

her
without

;

,

,
and

Bold
to

Charlotte
that

.
  
<EOS>
Bertie
Stanhope
was
not

be

of
his
own

,
but
it
did

to

that

.
<EOS>
He

,

.
  
<EOS>
By

,
not

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

,

,

<EOS>
"

"

.
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
You

.
"
  
<EOS>
Eleanor

.
  
<EOS>
"

;

.
<EOS>
You

?
"
  
<EOS>
Eleanor

,

the

Miss
Stanhope
.
  
<EOS>
"
I

her

,
Mrs.
Bold
,

.
<EOS>
But

Charlotte
 
<EOS>
you

entirely
the

.
<EOS>
Without

,

.
<EOS>
You

.
"
  
<EOS>

;
she

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

should

.
"
  
<EOS>
Eleanor

.
  
<EOS>
"
And
she
has
had
a

,
Mrs.
Bold
 
a
very
difficult
game
.
<EOS>
Poor
Madeline
's
unfortunate

and

,
my
mother
's
ill
-
health
<EOS>
,
my

's

,

,

,

,

have

.
<EOS>
You
can
not
wonder
if
among
all
her
cares
one

the

is
to
see
me
settled
in
the
world
.
"
  
<EOS>
Eleanor
on
this
occasion
expressed
no
acquiescence
.
<EOS>
She
certainly
supposed
that
a
formal
offer
was
to
be
made
and
could
not
but
think
that
so
singular
<EOS>
an
exordium
was
never
before
made
by
a
gentleman
in
a
similar
position
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
had
annoyed
her
by
the
excess
of
his
ardour
.
<EOS>
It
was
quite
clear
that
no
such
danger
was
to
be
feared
from
Mr.
Stanhope
.
<EOS>
Prudential
motives
alone
actuated
him
.
<EOS>
Not
only
was
he
about
to
make
love
because
his
sister
told
him
,
but
he
also
took
the

of
explaining
all
this
before
he

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Twas
thus
,
we
may
presume
,
that
the
matter
presented
itself
to
Mrs.
Bold
.
  
<EOS>
When
he
had
got
so
far
,
Bertie
began
poking
the
gravel
with
a
little
cane
which
he
carried
.
<EOS>
He
still
kept
moving
on
,
but
very
slowly
,
and
his
companion
moved
slowly
by
his
side
,
not
inclined
to
assist
him
in
the
task
the
performance
of
which
appeared
to
be
difficult
to
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Knowing
how
fond
she
is
of
yourself
,
Mrs.
Bold
,
can
not
you
imagine
what
scheme
should
have

to

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
imagine
no
better
scheme
,
Mr.
Stanhope
,
than
the
one
I
proposed
to
you
just
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
he
somewhat

;
"
I
suppose
that
would
be
the
best
,
but
Charlotte
thinks
another
plan
might
be
joined
with
it
.
<EOS>
She
wants
me
to
marry
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
A
thousand
remembrances
flashed
across
Eleanor
's
mind
all
in
a
moment
 
<EOS>
how
Charlotte
had
talked
about
and
praised
her
brother
,
how
she
had
continually
contrived
to
throw
the
two
of
them
together
,
how
she
had
encouraged
all
manner
of
little
intimacies
,
how
she
had
with
singular
cordiality
persisted
in
treating
Eleanor
as
one
of
the
family
.
<EOS>
All
this
had
been
done
to
secure
her
comfortable
income
for
the
benefit
of
one
of
the
family
!
  
<EOS>
Such
a
feeling
as
this
is
very
bitter
when
it
first
impresses
itself
on
a
young
mind
.
<EOS>
To
the
old
,
such
plots
and
plans
,
such
matured
schemes
for
obtaining
the
goods
of
this
world
without
the
trouble
of
earning
them
,
such
long
-
headed
attempts
to
convert
"
tuum
"
into
"
meum
"
are
the
ways
of
life
to
which
they
are
accustomed
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Tis
thus
that
many
live
,
and
it
therefore
behoves
all
those
who
are
well
-
to
-
do
in
the
world
to
be
on
their
guard
against
those
who
are
not
.
<EOS>
With
them
it
is
the
success
that
disgusts
,
not
the
attempt
.
<EOS>
But
Eleanor
had
not
yet
learnt
to
look
on
her
money
as
a
source
of
danger
;
she
had
not
begun
to
regard
herself
as
fair
game
to
be
hunted
down
by
hungry
gentlemen
.
<EOS>
She
had
enjoyed
the
society
of
the
Stanhopes
,
she
had
greatly
liked
the
cordiality
of
Charlotte
,
and
had
been
happy
in
her
new
friends
.
<EOS>
Now
she
saw
the
cause
of
all
this
kindness
,
and
her
mind
was
opened
to
a
new
phase
of
human
life
.
  
<EOS>
"
Miss
Stanhope
,
"
said
she
haughtily
,
"
has
been
contriving
for
me
a
great
deal
of
honour
,
but
she
might
have
saved
herself
the
trouble
.
<EOS>
I
am
not
sufficiently
ambitious
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Pray
do
n't
be
angry
with
her
,
Mrs.
Bold
,
"
said
he
,
"
or
with
me
either
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Certainly
not
with
you
,
Mr.
Stanhope
,
"
said
she
with
considerable
sarcasm
in
her
tone
.
"
<EOS>
Certainly
not
with
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
 
nor
with
her
,
"
said
he
imploringly
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
why
,
may
I
ask
you
,
Mr.
Stanhope
,

?
<EOS>
For

that
 
that
 
that
you

not

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
we

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

,
"

Bold
,
who
was

.
"
<EOS>
And

,
why

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
once
think
,
Mrs.
Bold
 
that
you
 
that
you
 
"
  
<EOS>
The
widow
now
again

entirely

,
and
would

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
once
think
that
you
perhaps
might

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Never
!
"

,
"

.
<EOS>

,

been
very

blame
 
very
much

blame

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
never
have
,
"
said
Bertie
,
who
really
had
a
good
-
natured

to

said

little

as

.
<EOS>
"
You
never
have
,
and
I
have
seen
for
some

that
I
had
no
chance
 
<EOS>
but
my
sister
's
hopes
ran
higher
.
<EOS>
I

not
mistaken
you
,
Mrs.
Bold
,
though
perhaps
she

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
why
have

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Because
I
must
not

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
will
not
this
anger

?
<EOS>
Upon

,
Mr.
Stanhope
,
I

not
understand
the
policy
of
your
family
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
how
I
wish
I
was
at
home
!
"
<EOS>
And
as
she
expressed
the
wish
she
could
restrain
herself
no
longer
and
burst
out
into
a
flood
of
tears
.
  
<EOS>
Poor
Bertie
was
greatly
moved
.
<EOS>
"
You
shall
have
the
carriage
to
yourself
going
home
,
"
said
he
;
"
at
least
you
and
my
father
.
<EOS>
As

me
,
I
can
walk
,
or
for

matter
of
that
it
does
not
much
signify

I
do
.
"
<EOS>
He
perfectly
understood
that
part
of
Eleanor
's
grief
arose
from
the
apparent
necessity
of
her
going
back
to
Barchester
in
the
carriage
with
her
second
suitor
.
  
<EOS>
This
somewhat
mollified
her
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
Mr.
Stanhope
,
"
said
she
,
"
why
should
you
have
made
me
so
miserable
?
<EOS>
What
will
you
have
gained
by
telling
me

?
"
  
<EOS>
He
had
not
even
yet
explained
to
her
the
most
difficult
part
of
his

;
he
had
not

that
she
was
to
be
a
party
to
the
little
deception
which
he
intended
to
play
off
upon
his
sister
.
<EOS>
This
suggestion
had
still
to
be
made
,
and
as
it
was
absolutely
necessary
,
he
proceeded
to
make

.
  
<EOS>
We
need
not
follow
him
through
the
whole
of
his
statement
.
<EOS>
At
last
,
and
not
without
considerable

,
he
made

understand
why

had
let
her
into
his
confidence
,
seeing
that
he
no
longer

the

of
a

.
<EOS>
At
last
he
made
her
comprehend
the
part
which
she
was

to
play
in
this
little
family
comedy
.
  
<EOS>
But
when
she
did
understand
it
,
she
was
only
more

with

than
ever
;
more
angry
,
not
only
with
him
,
but
with
Charlotte
also
.
<EOS>
Her
fair
name
was
to
be
bandied
about
between
them
in
different
senses
,
and
each
sense
false
.
<EOS>
She
was
to
be
played
off
by
the
sister
against
the
father
,
and
then
by
the
brother
against
the
sister
.
<EOS>
Her
dear
friend
Charlotte
,
with
all
her
agreeable
sympathy
and
affection
,
was
striving
to
sacrifice
her
for
the
Stanhope
family
welfare
;
and
Bertie
,
who
,
as
he
now
proclaimed
himself
,
was
over
head
and
ears
in
debt
,
completed
the
compliment
of
owning
that
he
did
not
care
to
have
his
debts
paid
at
so
great
a
sacrifice
of
himself
.
<EOS>
Then
she
was
asked
to
conspire
together
with
this
unwilling
suitor
for
the
sake
of
making
the
family
believe
that
he
had
in
obedience
to
their
commands
done
his
best
to
throw
himself
thus
away
!
  
<EOS>
She
lifted
up
her
face
when
he
had
finished
,
and
looking
at
him
with
much
dignity
,
even
through
her

,

said
:
  
"
I
regret

,
Mr.
Stanhope
,
but
after
what

passed
I
believe
that
all
intercourse
between
your

and

had

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,

,
"

naïvely
;
"
perhaps
that
will
be
better
at
any

for
a

;
and
then
Charlotte

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

"

.
<EOS>
"
I
can

,

:
after
what

passed
,
"

"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
must
find

,

;

,

again

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
There

a
truth

,

in

for

,

's

.
<EOS>
So
she
suffered

to
walk
by

side
over
the
now

,
till
they
came
to
the

room
window
.
<EOS>
There
was
something
about
Bertie
Stanhope
which
gave
him
,
in
the

of
everyone
,
a
different

from
that
which

man
would

.
<EOS>
Angry

Eleanor
was
,
and
great

her

for

,
she
was
not
half
as
angry
with

as

would

been

anyone
else
.
<EOS>
He
was
apparently
so
simple
,
so
good
-

,
so

,
<EOS>
that
she
had
already
half
-
forgiven

.
  
<EOS>
When
they

,
Dr.
Stanhope
was

Mr.
and
Miss

;
one

other

were
there
,
who
from
one
cause
or
another
were
still
delayed
in
getting
away
,
but
they
were
every

getting
fewer
in
number
.
  
<EOS>
As

had
handed
Eleanor
over
to

,
Bertie
started
off

the
front

in
search
of
the
carriage
,
and
there
he
waited
leaning

against

front
wall
,
comfortably

,
till
it
came
up
.
<EOS>
When
he
returned
to

room
,

Stanhope
and

were
alone
with

hosts
.
  
<EOS>
"
At
last
,
Miss
Thorne
,
"
said

,
"
I
have
come
to

.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Bold
and
my
father
are
the
last
roses
of
the
very

summer
you
have
given

,
and
desirable
as
Mrs.
Bold
's

always
is
,
now
at
least
you
must

last

.
"
  
<EOS>
Miss
Thorne
declared
that

was

to
have
Mrs.
Bold
and
Dr.
Stanhope
still
with
her
,
and
Mr.
Thorne
would
have
said

,
had

checked

,
which
he

.
  
<EOS>
"
Father
,

you
give
your
arm
to
Mrs.
Bold
?
"
said
Bertie
:
<EOS>
and
so
the
last
adieux
were
made
,
and
the
prebendary
led
out
Mrs.
Bold
,
followed
by

son
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
home
soon
after

,
"
said
he
as

into

carriage
.
  
<EOS>
"
Are
you
not

in
the
carriage
?
"
said

father
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
;
I
have
someone
to
see

road
,
and
shall
walk
.
<EOS>
John
,
mind

to
Mrs.
Bold
's

first
.
"
  
<EOS>
Eleanor
,
looking
out
of
the
window
,
saw
him
with
his
hat
in

hand
,
bowing
to
her
with
his
usual
gay

,
as

nothing
had
happened
to
mar
the

of
the
day
.
<EOS>
It
was
many
a
long
year
before
she
saw
him
again
.
<EOS>
Dr.
Stanhope
hardly
spoke
to
her
on
her
way
home
,
and
she
was
safely
deposited
by
John
at
her
own
hall
-
door
before
the
carriage
drove
into
the
close
.
  
<EOS>
And
thus
our
heroine
played
the
last
act
of
that
day
's
melodrama
.
   
<EOS>
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Quiverful
Are
Made
Happy
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
is
Encouraged
by
the
Press
 
<EOS>
Before
she
started
for
Ullathorne
,
Mrs.
Proudie
,
careful
soul
,
caused
two
letters
to
be
written
,
one
by
herself
and
one
by
her
lord
,
to
the
inhabitants
of
Puddingdale
vicarage
,
which
made
happy
the
hearth
of
those
within
it
.
  
<EOS>
As
soon
as
the
departure
of
the
horses
left
the
bishop
's
stable
-
groom
free
for
other
services
,
that
humble
denizen
of
the
diocese
started
on
the
bishop
's
own
pony
with
the
two
dispatches
.
<EOS>
We
have
had
so
many
letters
lately
that
we
will
spare
ourselves
these
.
<EOS>
That
from
the
bishop
was
simply
a
request
that
Mr.
Quiverful
would
wait
upon
his
lordship
the
next
morning
at
11
A.M.
;
that
from
the
lady
was
as
simply
a
request
that
Mrs.
Quiverful
would
do
the
same
by
her
,
though
it
was
couched
in
somewhat
longer
and
more
grandiloquent
phraseology
.
  
<EOS>
It
had
become
a
point
of
conscience
with
Mrs.
Proudie
to
urge
the
settlement
of
this
great
hospital
question
.
<EOS>
She
was
resolved
that
Mr.
Quiverful
should
have
it
.
<EOS>
She
was
resolved
that
there
should
be
no
more
doubt
or
delay
,
no
more
refusals
and
resignations
,
no
more
secret
negotiations
carried
on
by
Mr.
Slope
on
his
own
account
in
opposition
to
her
behests
.
  
<EOS>
"
Bishop
,
"
she
said
immediately
after
breakfast
on
the
morning
of
that
eventful
day
,
"
have
you
signed
the
appointment
yet
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
my
dear
,
not
yet
;
it
is
not
exactly
signed
as
yet
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Then
do
it
,
"
said
the
lady
.
  
<EOS>
The
bishop
did
it
,
and
a
very
pleasant
day
indeed
he
spent
at
Ullathorne
.
<EOS>
And
when
he
got
home
,
he
had
a
glass
of
hot
negus
in
his
wife
's
sitting
-
room
,
and
read
the
last
number
of
the
Little
Dorrit
of
the
day
with
great
inward
satisfaction
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
husbands
,
oh
,
my
marital
friends
,
what
great
comfort
is
there
to
be
derived
from
a
wife
well
obeyed
!
  
<EOS>
Much
perturbation
and
flutter
,
high
expectation
and
renewed
hopes
,
were
occasioned
at
Puddingdale
,
by
the
receipt
of
these
episcopal
dispatches
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Quiverful
,
whose
careful
ear
caught
the
sound
of
the
pony
's
feet
as
he
trotted
up
to
the
vicarage
kitchen
door
,
brought
them
in
hurriedly
to
her
husband
.
<EOS>
She
was
at
the
moment
concocting
the
Irish
stew
destined
to
satisfy
the
noonday
<EOS>
wants
of
fourteen
young
birds
,
let
alone
the
parent
couple
.
<EOS>
She
had
taken
the
letters
from
the
man
's
hands
between
the
folds
of
her
capacious
apron
so
as
to
save
them
from
the
contamination
of
the
stew
,
and
in
this
guise
she
brought
them
to
her
husband
's
desk
.
  
<EOS>
They
at
once
divided
the
spoil
,
each
taking
that
addressed
to
the
other
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Quiverful
,
"
said
she
with
impressive
voice
,
"
you
are
to
be
at
the
palace
at
eleven
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
so
are
you
,
my
dear
,
"
said
he
,
almost
gasping
with
the
importance
of
the
tidings
 
<EOS>
and
then
they
exchanged
letters
.
  
<EOS>
"
She
'd
never
have
sent
for
me
again
,
"
said
the
lady
,
"
if
it
was
n't
all
right
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
my
dear
,
do
n't
be
too
certain
,
"
said
the
gentleman
,
"
Only
think
if
it
should
be
wrong
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
'd
never
have
sent
for
me
,
Q.
,
if
it
was
n't
all
right
,
"
again
argued
the
lady
.
<EOS>
"
She
's
stiff
and
hard
and
proud
as
piecrust
,
but
I
think
she
's
right
at
bottom
.
<EOS>
"
Such
was
Mrs.
Quiverful
's
verdict
about
Mrs.
Proudie
,
to
which
in
after
times
she
always
adhered
.
<EOS>
People
when
they
get
their
income
doubled
usually
think
that
those
through
whose
instrumentality
this
little
ceremony
is
performed
are
right
at
bottom
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Letty
!
"
said
Mr.
Quiverful
,
rising

his
well

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Q.
!
"

,
and

of

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

's

,
do

,
"

wife
.
  
<EOS>
"
Let

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

will

?
"
<EOS>
said

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
wo
n't
say
too
much
,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
cup
has

,

,
but

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
You

will
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Heaven
send

may
,
"

Quiverful

.
<EOS>
And
who
that

weight

on
this
man
's

will

that
the

an

?
<EOS>
There
were
fourteen
of
them
 
<EOS>
fourteen
of

living
 
as

Quiverful
had

in

.
<EOS>
As

<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
And
"
the

"

"

<EOS>
Poor

!
<EOS>
Good

<EOS>
There

<EOS>
The

,

,

<EOS>
With

"

<EOS>

.

.
<EOS>
The

.
  
<EOS>
Then

<EOS>
The

<EOS>
But

<EOS>

,

.

Oh

!
<EOS>
It

.
  
<EOS>
Going

,

<EOS>
"

.
"
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

"

"

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
It

-

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"

.
"
<EOS>

;

;

<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>
Everybody

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
My

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Twas

the

Mrs.
Grantly
.
  
<EOS>
And
now
we
may

bishop
's

.
  
<EOS>
Dr.
Gwynne
had
certainly

which
here

.
<EOS>
He
 
together
with
all
the
clerical
world
of
England
 
had
heard

rumoured
about
that
Mrs.
Proudie
did

,
still
-
rooms
,
and

;
but
yet
it

,

;

,

.
<EOS>
It
appeared
,
however
,
as
though

the
present

Mrs.
Proudie
had
no

.
  
<EOS>
The
bishop
had

very

with
Dr.
Gwynne
on
the
preceding

,
and
of
course

that
Dr.
Gwynne
had

.
<EOS>
He
attributed
the
visit
solely

,
and

gracious

for
the
Master

to

from
Plumstead
specially
to
call
at
the
palace
so
soon
after
his
arrival
in
the
country
.
<EOS>
The
fact
that
they
were
not
on
the
same
side
either
in
politics
or
doctrines
made
the
compliment
the
greater
.
<EOS>
The
bishop
,
therefore
,
was
all
smiles
.
<EOS>
And
Mrs.
Proudie
,

<EOS>
There
was
more
in
this
than
in
all
Sir
Nicholas
Fitzwhiggin
's
flummery
;
more
than
in
all
the
bishop
's
promises
,
even
had
they
been
ever
so
sincere
;
more
than
in
any
archbishop
's
good
word
,
even
had
it
been
possible
to
obtain
it
.
<EOS>
Tom
Towers
would
do
for
him
what
he
could
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
had
from
his
youth
upwards
been
a
firm
believer
in
the
public
press
.
<EOS>
He
had
dabbled
in
it
himself
ever
since
he
had
taken
his
degree
,
and
he
regarded
it
as
the
great
arranger
and
distributor
of
all
future
British
terrestrial
affairs
whatever
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
yet
arrived
at
the
age
,
an
age
which
sooner
or
later
comes
to
most
of
us
,
which
dissipates
the
golden
dreams
of
youth
.
<EOS>
He
delighted
in
the
idea
of
wresting
power
from
the
hands
of
his
country
's
magnates
and
placing
it
in
a
custody
which
was
at
any
rate
nearer
to
his
own
reach
.
<EOS>
Sixty
thousand
broadsheets
dispersing
themselves
daily
among
his
reading
fellow
citizens
formed
in
his
eyes
a
better
depot
for
supremacy
than
a
throne
at
Windsor
,
a
cabinet
in
Downing
Street
,
or
even
an
assembly
at
Westminster
.
<EOS>
And
on
this
subject
we
must
not
quarrel
with
Mr.
Slope
,
for
the
feeling
is
too
general
to
be
met
with
disrespect
.
  
<EOS>
Tom
Towers
was
as
good
,
if
not
better
,
than
his
promise
.
<EOS>
On
the
following
morning
"
The
Jupiter
,
"
spouting
forth
public
opinion
with
sixty
thousand
loud
clarions
,
did
proclaim
to
the
world
that
Mr.
Slope
was
the
fitting
man
for
the
vacant
post
.
<EOS>
It
was
pleasant
for
Mr.
Slope
to
read
the
following
lines
in
the
Barchester
news
-
room
,
which
he
did
within
thirty
minutes
after
the
morning
train
from
London
had
reached
the
city
.
  
<EOS>
It
is
just
now
five
years
since
we
called
the
attention
of
our
readers
to
the
quiet
city
of
Barchester
.
<EOS>
From
that
day
to
this
,
we
have
in
no
way
meddled
with
the
affairs
of
that
happy
ecclesiastical
community
.
<EOS>
Since
then
,
an
old
bishop
has
died
there
,
and
a
young
bishop
has
been
installed
;
but
we
believe
we
did
not
do
more
than
give
some
customary
record
of
the
interesting
event
.
<EOS>
Nor
are
we
now
about
to
meddle
very
deeply
in
the
affairs
of
the
diocese
.
<EOS>
If
any
of
the
chapter
feel
a
qualm
of
conscience
on
reading
thus
far
,
let
it
be
quieted
.
<EOS>
Above
all
,
let
the
mind
of
the
new
bishop
be
at
rest
.
<EOS>
We
are
now
not
armed
for
war
,
but
approach
the
reverend
towers
of
the
old
cathedral
with
an
olive
branch
in
our
hands
.
  
<EOS>
It
will
be
remembered
that
at
the
time
alluded
to
,
now
five
years
past
,
we
had
occasion
to
remark
on
the
state
of
a
charity
in
Barchester
called
Hiram
's
Hospital
.
<EOS>
We
thought
that
it
was
maladministered
,
and
that
the
very
estimable
and
reverend
gentleman
who
held
the
office
of
warden
was
somewhat
too
highly
paid
for
duties
which
were
somewhat
too
easily
performed
.
<EOS>
This
gentleman
 
<EOS>
and
we
say
it
in
all
sincerity
and
with
no
touch
of
sarcasm
 
<EOS>
had
never
looked
on
the
matter
in
this
light
before
.
<EOS>
We
do
not
wish
to
take
praise
to
ourselves
whether
praise
be
due
to
us
or
not
.
<EOS>
But
the
consequence
of
our
remark
was
that
the
warden
did
look
into
the
matter
,
and
finding
on
so
doing
that
he
himself
could
come
to
no
other
opinion
than
that
expressed
by
us
,
he
very
creditably
threw
up
the
appointment
.
<EOS>
The
then
bishop
as
creditably
declined
to
fill
the
vacancy
till
the
affair
was
put
on
a
better
footing
.
<EOS>
Parliament
then
took
it
up
,
and
we
have
now
the
satisfaction
of
informing
our
readers
that
Hiram
's
Hospital
will
be
immediately
reopened
under
new
auspices
.
<EOS>
Heretofore
,
provision
was
made
for
the
maintenance
of
twelve
old
men
.
<EOS>
This
will
now
be
extended
to
the
fair
sex
,
and
twelve
elderly
women
,
if
any
such
can
be
found
in
Barchester
,
will
be
added
to
the
establishment
.
<EOS>
There
will
be
a
matron
;
there
will
,
it
is
hoped
,
be
schools
attached
for
the
poorest
of
the
children
of
the
poor
,
and
there
will
be
a
steward
.
<EOS>
The
warden
,
for
there
will
still
be
a
warden
,
will
receive
an
income
more
in
keeping
with
the
extent
of
the
charity
than
that
heretofore
paid
.
<EOS>
The
stipend
we
believe
will
be
£
450
.
<EOS>
We
may
add
that
the
excellent
house
which
the
former
warden
inhabited
will
still
be
attached
to
the
situation
.
  
<EOS>
Barchester
Hospital
can
not
perhaps
boast
a
world
-
wide
reputation
,
but
as
we
adverted
to
its
state
of
decadence
,
we
think
it
right
also
to
advert
to
its
renaissance
.
<EOS>
May
it
go
on
and
prosper
.
<EOS>
Whether
the
salutary
reform
which
has
been
introduced
within

has

far
as
could
have

desired
may
be

.
<EOS>
The
important
question
of
the
school
appears
to
be
somewhat
left
to
the
discretion
of
the
new
warden
.
<EOS>
This
might
have
been
made
the
most
important

of

establishment
,
and
the
new

,
whom
we

,
might
have

with

view

.
<EOS>
But
we
will
not
now
look
a
gift
-
horse
in
the
mouth
.
<EOS>
May
the
hospital
go
on
and
prosper
!
<EOS>
The
situation
of
warden
has
of
course
been
offered
to
the
gentleman
who
so
honourably
vacated
it
five
years
since
,
but
we
are
given
to

that
he
has

.
<EOS>
Whether

ladies
who
have

be

,
whether

to

old
place
,
or

in

clerical

,

not

.
<EOS>
We
are
,
however
,
informed
that
he
has
refused
the
offer
and
that
the
situation
has
been
accepted
by
Mr.
Quiverful
,
the
vicar
of
Puddingdale
.
  
<EOS>
So
much
we
think
is
due
to
Hiram
redivivus
.
<EOS>
But
while
we
are
on
the
subject
of
Barchester
,
we
will
venture
with
all
respectful
humility
to
express
our
opinion
on
another
matter
connected
with
the
ecclesiastical
polity
of
that
ancient
city
.
<EOS>
Dr.
Trefoil
,
the
dean
,
died
yesterday
.
<EOS>
A
short
record
of
his
death
,
giving
his
age
and
the
various
pieces
of
preferment
which
he
has
at
different
times
held
,
will
be
found
in
another
column
of
this
paper
.
<EOS>
The
only
fault
we
knew
in
him
was
his
age
,
and
as
that
is
a
crime
of
which
we
all
hope
to
be
guilty
,
we
will
not
bear
heavily
on
it
.
<EOS>
May
he
rest
in
peace
!
<EOS>
But
though
the
great
age
of
an
expiring
dean
can
not
be
made
matter
of
reproach
,
we
are
not
inclined
to
look
on
such
a
fault
as
at
all
pardonable
in
a
dean
just
brought
to
the
birth
.
<EOS>
We
do
hope
that
the
days
of
sexagenarian
appointments
are
past
.
<EOS>
If
we
want
deans
,
we
must
want
them
for
some
purpose
.
<EOS>
That
purpose
will
necessarily
be
better
fulfilled
by
a
man
of
forty
than
by
a
man
of
sixty
.
<EOS>
If
we
are
to
pay
deans
at
all
,
we
are
to

for
some
sort
of
work
.
<EOS>
That
work
,
be
it
what
it
may
,
will
be
best
performed
by
a
workman
in
the
prime
of
life
.
<EOS>
Dr.
Trefoil
,
we
see
,
was
eighty
when
he
died
.
<EOS>
As
we
have
as
yet
completed
no
plan
for
pensioning
superannuated
clergymen
,
we
do
not
wish

get
rid

any
existing
deans
of
that
age
.
<EOS>
But
we
prefer
having
as
few

as

.
<EOS>
If
a
man
of
seventy
be
now
appointed
,
we
beg
to
point
out
to
Lord
 
---
that
he
will
be
past
all
use
in
a
year
or
two
,
if
indeed
he
be
not
so
at
the
present

.
<EOS>
His
lordship
will
allow
us
to
remind
him
that
all
men
are
not
evergreens
like
himself
.
  
<EOS>
We
hear
that
Mr.
Slope
's
name
has
been
mentioned
for
this
preferment
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
is
at
present
chaplain
to
the
bishop
.
<EOS>
A
better
man
could
hardly
be
selected
.
<EOS>
He
is
a
man
of
talent
,
young
,
active
,
and

with
the

of
the
cathedral
;
he
is
moreover
,

,
a

.
<EOS>
We
know
that
his
services
in
the
city
of
Barchester
have
been

.
<EOS>
He
is
an
eloquent
preacher
and
a
ripe
scholar
.
<EOS>
Such
a
selection
as
this
would
go
far
to
raise
the
confidence
of
the
public
in
the
present
administration
of
church
patronage
and
would
teach

to
believe
that
from
henceforth
the
establishment
of
our
church
will
not

to
worn
-
out

voluptuaries
.
  
<EOS>
Standing
at
a

-

in
the
Barchester
news
-
room
,
Mr.
Slope
digested
this
article
with
considerable

.
<EOS>
What
was
therein
said
as
to
the
hospital
was
now
comparatively
a
matter
of
indifference
to

.
<EOS>
He
was
certainly

that

had
not

in

to
the
place
the
father
of
that
virago
who
had
so

in

,
and
was

far

.
<EOS>
But
Mrs.
Proudie
's
nominee
was
appointed
,
and
he
was
so
far

.
<EOS>
His

,

,
was
now

above
Mrs.
Bold
or
Mrs.
Proudie
.
<EOS>
He
was
sufficiently
conversant
with
the

of
"
The
Jupiter
"
to
know
that
the
pith
of
the
article
would
lie
in

last

.
<EOS>
The
place
of
honour
was
given
to
him
,
and
it
was
indeed
as
honourable
as
even
he
could
have

.
<EOS>
He
was
very
grateful
to
his
friend
Mr.
Towers
,
and
with
full
heart
looked
forward
to
the
day
when
he
might

him
in
princely
style
at
his
own
full
-

in
the
deanery
dining
-
room
.
  
<EOS>
It
had
been
well
for
Mr.
Slope
that
Dr.
Trefoil
had
died
in
the
autumn
.
<EOS>
Those
caterers
for
our
morning
repast
,
the
staff
of
"
The
Jupiter
,
"
had
been
sorely
put
to
it
for
the
last
month
to
find
a
sufficiency
of
proper
pabulum
.
<EOS>
Just
then
there
was
no
talk
of
a
new
American
president
.
<EOS>
No
wonderful
tragedies
had
occurred
on
railway
trains
in
Georgia
,
or
elsewhere
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
dearth
of
broken
banks
,
and
a
dead
dean
with
the
necessity
for
a
live
one
was
a
godsend
.
<EOS>
Had
Dr.
Trefoil
died
in
June
,
Mr.
Towers
would
probably
not
have
known
so
much
about
the
piety
of
Mr.
Slope
.
  
<EOS>
And
here

will
leave
Mr.
Slope
for
awhile
in
his
triumph
,
explaining
,
however
,
that
his
feelings
were
not

.
<EOS>
His

by
the
widow
,
or
rather

of
his

,
galled

terribly
.
<EOS>
For

to
come
he
positively
felt
the
sting
upon
his
cheek
whenever
he
thought
of
what
had
been
done
to

.
<EOS>
He
could
not

from
calling
her
by

,
speaking
to

as

walked
through

of
Barchester
.
<EOS>
When
he
said
his
prayers
,
he
could
not
bring
himself
to
forgive
her
.
<EOS>
When

do

,
his

from

,
and
in

of

ran
off
in
a

,
dwelling
on
the

of
the
injury
he
had
received
.
<EOS>
And
so
his
prayers
dropped
senseless
from

.
  
<EOS>
And
then
the
signora
 
<EOS>
what
would
he
not
have
given
to
be
able

hate
her
also
?
<EOS>
As
it
was
,
he
worshipped
the
very
sofa
on
which
she
was
ever
lying
.
  
<EOS>
And
thus
it
was
not
all
rose
colour
with
Mr.
Slope
,
although
his
hopes
ran
high
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs.
Bold
at
Home
 
<EOS>
Poor
Mrs.
Bold
,
when
she
got
home
from
Ullathorne
on
the
evening
of
Miss
Thorne
's
party
,
was
very
unhappy
and
,
moreover
,
very
tired
.
<EOS>
Nothing
fatigues
the
body
so
much
as
weariness
of
spirit
,
and
Eleanor
's
spirit
was
indeed
weary
.
  
<EOS>
Dr.
Stanhope
had
civilly
<EOS>
but
not
very
cordially
asked
her
in
to
tea
,
and
her
manner
of
refusal
convinced
the
worthy
doctor
that
he
need
not
repeat
the
invitation
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
exactly
made
himself
a
party
to
the
intrigue
which
was
to
convert
the
late
Mr.
Bold
's
patrimony
into
an
income
for
his
hopeful
son
,
but
he
had
been
well
aware
what
was
going
on
.
<EOS>
And
he
was
well
aware
also
,
when
he
perceived
that
Bertie
declined
accompanying
them
home
in
the
carriage
,
that
the
affair
had
gone
off
.
  
<EOS>
Eleanor
was
very
much
afraid
that
Charlotte
would
have
darted
out
upon
her
,
as
the
prebendary
got
out
at
his
own
door
,
but
Bertie
had
thoughtfully
saved
her
from
this
by
causing
the
carriage
to
go
round
by
her
own
house
.
<EOS>
This
also
Dr.
Stanhope
understood
and
allowed
to
pass
by
without
remark
.
  
<EOS>
When
she
got
home
,
she
found
Mary
Bold
in
the
drawing
-
room
with
the
child
in

lap
.
<EOS>
She
rushed
forward
and
,
throwing
herself
on
her

,
kissed
the
little
fellow
till
she
almost
frightened
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Mary
,
I
am
so
glad
you
did
not
go
.
<EOS>
It
was
an
odious
party
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Now
the
question
of
Mary
's
going
had
been
one
greatly
mooted
between
them
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Bold
,
when
invited
,
had
been
the
guest
of
the
Grantlys
,
and
Miss
Thorne
,
who
had
chiefly
known
Eleanor
at
the
hospital
or
at
Plumstead

,
had
forgotten
all
about
Mary
Bold
.
<EOS>
Her
sister
-
in
-
law
had
implored

to
go
under
her
wing
and
had
offered
to
write
to
Miss
Thorne
,
or
to
call

.
<EOS>
But
Miss
Bold
had
declined
.
<EOS>
In
fact
,
Mr.
Bold
had
not

popular
with
such
people
as
the
Thornes
,
and
his
sister
would
not
go
among

unless
she

specially

to
do

.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
then
,
"
said
Mary
cheerfully
,
"
I
have
the
less
to
regret
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
nothing
to
regret
;
but
oh
!
<EOS>
Mary
,
I
have
 
so
much
 
so
much
;
"
and
then
she
began

her
boy
,
whom
her
caresses
had
roused
from
his

.
<EOS>
When
she
raised
her
head
,
Mary
saw
that

were

.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
heavens
,
Eleanor
<EOS>
,

?
<EOS>
What

Eleanor
 
<EOS>
dearest
Eleanor
 
<EOS>
what
is
the
matter
?
"
<EOS>
and
Mary
got

with

boy

.
  
<EOS>
"
Give
him
to
me
 
give
him
to

,
"
said

young

.
<EOS>
"
Give

to
me
,
Mary
,
"
and
she

child

's

.
<EOS>
The
poor

fellow
murmured
somewhat

but
nevertheless

close
into

's

.
  
<EOS>
"
Here
,

,
take

.
<EOS>
My
own
own

,
darling
,

.
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
Everybody

;

.
<EOS>

nobody
,
nobody
,
nobody
,

her
own
,
own
,
own

man
;
"
and

again

and
pressed

and
cried
till
the

ran
down
over

child
's

.
  
<EOS>
"
Who
has
been
cruel
to
you
,
Eleanor
?
"
said
Mary
.
<EOS>
"
I
hope
I
have
not
.
"
  
<EOS>
Now
in
this
matter
Eleanor
had
great
cause
for
mental
uneasiness
.
<EOS>
She
could
not
certainly
accuse
her
loving
sister
-
in
-
law
of
cruelty
;
but
she
had
to
do
that
which
was
more
galling
:
she
had
to
accuse
herself
of
imprudence
against
which
her
sister
-
in
-
law
had
warned
her
.
<EOS>
Miss
Bold
had
never
encouraged
Eleanor
's
acquaintance
with
Mr.
Slope
,
and
she
had
positively
discouraged
the
friendship
of
the
Stanhopes
,
as
far
as
her
usual
gentle
mode
of
speaking
had
permitted
.
<EOS>
Eleanor
had
only
laughed
at
her
,
however
,
when
she
said
that
she
disapproved
of
married
women
who
lived
apart
from
their
husbands
and
suggested
that
Charlotte
Stanhope
never
went
to
church
.
<EOS>
Now
,
however
,
Eleanor
must
either
hold
her
tongue
,
which
was
quite
impossible
,
or
confess
herself
to
have
been
utterly
wrong
,
which
was
nearly
equally
so
.
<EOS>
So
she
staved
off
the
evil
day
by
more
tears
,
and
consoled
herself
by
inducing
little
Johnny
to
rouse
himself
sufficiently
to
return
her
caresses
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
a
darling
 
as
true
as
gold
.
<EOS>
What
would
mamma
do
without
him
?
<EOS>
Mamma
would
lie
down
and
die
if
she
had
not
her
own
Johnny
Bold
to
give
her
comfort
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
This
and
much
more
she
said
of
the
same
kind
,
and
for
a
time
made
no
other
answer
to
Mary
's
inquiries
.
  
<EOS>
This
kind
of
consolation
from
the
world
's
deceit
is
very
common
.
<EOS>
Mothers
obtain
it
from
their
children
,
and
men
from
their
dogs
.
<EOS>
Some
men
even
do
so
from
their
walking
-
sticks
,
which
is
just
as
rational
.
<EOS>
How
is
it
that
we
can
take
joy
to
ourselves
in
that
we
are
not
deceived
by
those
who
have
not
attained
the
art
to
deceive

?
<EOS>
In
a
true
man
,
if
such
can

found
,
or
a
true
woman
,
much
consolation
may
indeed
be
taken
.
  
<EOS>
In
the
caresses
of
her
child
,
however
,
Eleanor
did
receive
consolation
,
and
may
ill
befall
the
man
who
would

it
to
her
.
<EOS>
The
evil
day
,
however
,
was
only

.
<EOS>
She
had
to
tell
her

tale
to
Mary
,
and
she

to
tell

to

.
<EOS>
Must

,

,

before

stand
all

with

?
<EOS>
At
the
present

there
was
no
one
to

could
turn
for
comfort
.
<EOS>
She
hated
Mr.
Slope
;
that
was
a
matter

;
in

she
revelled
.
<EOS>
She

;

.
<EOS>
She
had
,

,

this

;

?
<EOS>
She

,

had
believed
ill
of

.
<EOS>
Mary
Bold
had
turned
Mentor
.
<EOS>
That

,
but

.
<EOS>
She

,

,

.
<EOS>
She

,

.
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
He

,

hers

.
<EOS>
And

Slope
!
<EOS>
She

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Mary
,

-

"

<EOS>
"

"

,

.
  
<EOS>
Mary

,

<EOS>
"
He

,
"

"

take
him
up
to
bed
.
"
  
<EOS>
But
Eleanor
would
not

her

.
<EOS>
She

the

,

.
<EOS>
She
was

that

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
Nelly
,
"

,
"
do

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
an't
cross
,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Are
you
angry

?
<EOS>
Surely
you
ca

be

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
an't
angry
 
at

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
I

.
"
  
<EOS>
Eleanor
did

,
and
allowed

.
<EOS>
She
ate

,
and

she

.
<EOS>
At

,

,

;
of

Arabin
<EOS>
she

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,

;
"
<EOS>
but

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"

!
"
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,
"

<EOS>
Eleanor

to

that

.
  
<EOS>
There

no

than
Mary

.
<EOS>
There

a

.
<EOS>
"
I
told

so
,

!
<EOS>
"
is

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
On

.
<EOS>
Barchester
<EOS>
she

;

.
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
In

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
He

.
  
<EOS>

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"

.

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
With

.
  
<EOS>

"

"

.
  
<EOS>

Or

?
"

.
<EOS>
"

;

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
"

?

.

<EOS>
"

"

"

<EOS>

If

"
  
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"
Terms
!

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

;

.
<EOS>
But

<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

"

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
But

"

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
,

,

_

.
<EOS>
He

daughter
,
and

,
and

,
and
do

.
<EOS>
It
did
not
suit
the
peculiar

of
the
man
to
tell

daughter
that
though
she
had
rejected
Mr.
Slope
,
and

Stanhope
,
some

would

,

that

the

might

.
<EOS>
But
doubtless

idea
crossed
his

,
and

to

other

which
made
him
decide
on
still
keeping
the
close
,
odious
little
room
in
High
Street
.
  
<EOS>
The
evening
passed
over
quietly
and
in
comfort
.
<EOS>
Eleanor
was
always
happier
with
her
father
than
with
anyone
else
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
,
perhaps
,
any
natural
taste
for
baby
-
worship
,
but
he
was
always
ready
to
sacrifice
himself
,
and
therefore
made
an
excellent
third
in
a
trio
with
his
daughter
and
Mary
Bold
in
singing
the
praises
of
the
wonderful
child
.
  
<EOS>
They
were
standing
together
over
their
music
in
the
evening
,
the
baby
having
again
been
put
to
bed
upon
the
sofa
,
when
the
servant
brought
in
a
very
small
note
in
a
beautiful
pink
envelope
.
<EOS>
It
quite
filled
the
room
with
perfume
as
it
lay
upon
the
small
salver
.
<EOS>
Mary
Bold
and
Mrs.
Bold
were
both
at
the
piano
,
and
Mr.
Harding
was
sitting
close
to
them
,
with
the
violoncello
between
his
legs
,
so
that
the
elegancy
of
the
epistle
was
visible
to
them
all
.
  
<EOS>
"
Please
ma'am
,
Dr.
Stanhope
's
coachman
says
he
is
to
wait
for
an
answer
,
"
said
the
servant
.
  
<EOS>
Eleanor
got
very
red
in
the
face
as
she
took
the
note
in
her
hand
.
<EOS>
She
had
never
seen
the
writing
before
.
<EOS>
Charlotte
's
epistles
,
to
which
she
was
well
accustomed
,
were
of
a
very
different
style
and
kind
.
<EOS>
She
generally
wrote
on
large
note
-
paper
;
she
twisted
up
her
letters
into
the
shape
and
sometimes
into
the
size
of
cocked
hats
;
she
addressed
them
in
a
sprawling
,
manly
hand
,
and
not
unusually
added
a
blot
or
a
smudge
,
as
though
such
were
her
own
peculiar
sign
-
manual
.
<EOS>
The
address
of
this
note
was
written
in
a
beautiful
female
hand
,
and
the
gummed
wafer
bore
on
it
an
impress
of
a
gilt
coronet
.
<EOS>
Though
Eleanor
had
never
seen
such
a
one
before
,
she
guessed
that
it
came
from
the
signora
.
<EOS>
Such
epistles
were
very
numerously
sent
out
from
any
house
in
which
the
signora
might
happen
to
be
dwelling
,
but
they
were
rarely
addressed
to
ladies
.
<EOS>
When
the
coachman
was
told
by
the
lady
's
maid
to
take
the
letter
to
Mrs.
Bold
,
he
openly
expressed
his
opinion
that
there
was
some
mistake
about
it
.
<EOS>
Whereupon
the
lady
's
maid
boxed
the
coachman
's
ears
.
<EOS>
Had
Mr.
Slope
seen
in
how
meek
a
spirit
the
coachman
took
the
rebuke
,
he
might
have
learnt
a
useful
lesson
,
both
in
philosophy
and
religion
.
  
<EOS>
The
note
was
as
follows
.
<EOS>
It
may
be
taken
as
a
faithful
promise
that
no
further
letter
whatever
shall
be
transcribed
at
length
in
these
pages
.
  
<EOS>
MY
DEAR
MRS
.
<EOS>
BOLD
,
  
<EOS>
May
I
ask
you
,
as
a
great
favour
,
to
call
on
me
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
You
can
say
what
hour
will
best
suit
you
,
but
quite
early
,
if
you
can
.
<EOS>
I
need
hardly
say
that
if
I
could
call
upon
you
,
I
should
not
take
this
liberty
with
you
.
  
<EOS>
I
partly
know
what
occurred
the
other
day
,
and
I
promise
you
that
you
shall
meet
with
no
annoyance
if
you
will
come
to
me
.
<EOS>
My
brother
leaves
us
for
London
to
-
day
;
from
thence
he
goes
to
Italy
.
  
<EOS>
It
will
probably
occur
to
you
that
I
should
not
thus
intrude
on
you
,
unless
I
had
that
to
say
to
you
which
may
be
of
considerable
moment
.
<EOS>
Pray
therefore
excuse
me
,
even
if
you
do
not
grant
my
request
.
  
<EOS>
And
believe
me
,
Very
sincerely
yours
,
  
M.
VESEY
NERONI
  
<EOS>
Thursday
Evening
  
<EOS>
The
three
of
them
sat
in
consultation
on
this
epistle
for
some
ten
or
fifteen
minutes
,
and
then
decided
that
Eleanor
should
write
a
line
saying
that
she
would
see
the
signora
the
next
morning
at
twelve
o'clock
.
   
<EOS>
The
Stanhopes
at
Home
 
<EOS>
We
must
now
return
to
the
Stanhopes
and
see
how
they
behaved
themselves
on
their
return
from
Ullathorne
.
  
<EOS>
Charlotte
,
who
came
back
in
the
first
homeward
journey
with
her
sister
,
waited
in
palpitating
expectation
till
the
carriage
drove
up
to
the
door
a
second
time
.
<EOS>
She
did
not
run
down
,
or
stand
at
the
window
,
or
show
in
any
outward
manner
that
she
looked
for
anything
wonderful
to
occur
;
but
when
she
heard
the
carriage
wheels
,
she
stood
up
with
erect
ears
,
listening
for
Eleanor
's
footfall
on
the
pavement
,
or
the
cheery
sound
of
Bertie
's
voice
welcoming
her
in
.
<EOS>
Had
she
heard
either
,
she
would
have
felt
that
all
was
right
;
but
neither
sound
was
there
for
her
to
hear
.
<EOS>
She
heard
only
her
father
's
slow
step
as
he
ponderously
let
himself
down
from
the
carriage
and
slowly
walked
along
the
hall
,
till
he
got
into
his
own
private
room
on
the
ground
floor
.
"
<EOS>
Send
Miss
Stanhope
to
me
,
"
he
said
to
the
servant
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
's
something
wrong
now
,
"
said
Madeline
,
who
was
lying
on
her
sofa
in
the
back
drawing
-
room
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
all
up
with
Bertie
,
"
replied
Charlotte
.
<EOS>
"
I
know
,
I
know
,
"
she
said
to
the
servant
as
he
brought
up
the
message
.
"
<EOS>
Tell
my
father
I
will
be
with
him
immediately
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Bertie
's
wooing
has
gone
astray
,
"
said
Madeline
.
<EOS>
"
I
knew
it
would
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
has
been
his
own
fault
then
.
<EOS>
She
was
ready
enough
,
I
am
quite
sure
,
"
said
Charlotte
with
that
sort
of
ill
-
nature
which
is
not
uncommon
when
one
woman
speaks
of
another
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
will
you
say
to
him
now
?
"
<EOS>
By
"
him
,
"
the
signora
meant
their
father
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
will
be
as
I
find
him
.
<EOS>
He
was
ready
to
pay
two
hundred
pounds
for
Bertie
to
stave
off
the
worst
of
his
creditors
,
if
this
marriage
had
gone
on
.
<EOS>
Bertie
must
now
have
the
money
instead
and
go
and
take
his
chance
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Where
is
he
now
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Heaven
knows
!
<EOS>
Smoking
in
the
bottom
of
Mr.
Thorne
's
ha
-
ha
,
or
philandering
with
some
of
those
Miss
Chadwicks
.
<EOS>
Nothing
will
ever
make
an

on

.
<EOS>
But
he
'll
be
furious
if
I
do

go
down
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
nothing
ever
will
.
<EOS>
But
do
n't
be
long
,
Charlotte
,
for
I
want
my
tea
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
And
so
Charlotte
went
down
to
her
father
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
very
black
cloud
on
the
old
man
's
brow
 
blacker
than
his
daughter
could
ever
yet
remember
to
have
seen
there
.
<EOS>
He
was
sitting
in
his
own
armchair
,
not
comfortably
over
the
fire
,
but
in
the
middle
of
the
room
,
waiting
till
she
should
come
and
listen
to
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
has
become
of
your
brother
?
"
<EOS>
he
said
as
soon
as
the
door
was
shut
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
rather
ask
you
,
"
said
Charlotte
.
<EOS>
"
I
left
you
both
at
Ullathorne
when
I
came
away
.
<EOS>
What
have
you
done
with
Mrs.
Bold
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mrs.
Bold
!
<EOS>
Nonsense
.
<EOS>
The
woman
has
gone
home
as
she
ought
to
do
.
<EOS>
And
heartily
glad
I
am
that
she
should
not
be
sacrificed
to
so
heartless
a
reprobate
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Papa
!
"
  
"
A
heartless
reprobate
!
<EOS>
Tell
me
now
where
he
is
and
what
he
is
going
to
do
.
<EOS>
I
have
allowed
myself
to
be
fooled
between
you
.
<EOS>
Marriage
,
indeed
!
<EOS>
Who
on
earth
that
has
money
,
or

,
or
respect
in
the
world
to
lose
would
marry
him
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
no
use
your
scolding
me
,
Papa
.
<EOS>
I
have
done
the
best
I
could
for
him
and
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
Madeline
is
nearly
as
bad
,
"
said
the
prebendary
,
who
was
in
truth
very
,
very
angry
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
I
suppose
we
are
all
bad
,
"
replied
Charlotte
.
  
<EOS>
The
old
man
emitted
a
huge
,
leonine
sigh
.
<EOS>
If
they
were
all
bad
,
who
had
made
them
so
?
<EOS>
If
they
were
unprincipled
,
selfish
,
and
disreputable
,
who
was
to
be
blamed
for
the
education
which
had
had
so
injurious
an
effect
?
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
you
'll
ruin
me
among
you
,
"
said
he
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
Papa
,
what
nonsense
that
is
.
<EOS>
You
are
living
within
your
income
this
minute
,
and
if
there
are
any
new
debts
,
I
do
n't
know
of
them
.
<EOS>
I
am
sure
there
ought
to
be
none
,
for
we
are
dull
enough
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Are
those
bills
of
Madeline
's
paid
?
"
  
"
No
,
they
are
not
.
<EOS>
Who
was
to
pay

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Her
husband
may
pay

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Her
husband
!
<EOS>
Would
you

tell

you
say

?
<EOS>
Do

wish

turn

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
what
on
earth
has

?
<EOS>
Poor
Madeline
!
<EOS>
To
-
day
is
only
the
second

she
has
gone
out
since
we
came
to
this

.
"
  
<EOS>
He
then

,

what

would

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
Papa
,
"
said

,
"
shall
I
stay
here
,
or

I
go

and
give

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
in
your
brother
's
confidence
.
<EOS>
Tell

what
he
is
going

do
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
that
I
am

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
 
nothing
!
<EOS>
Nothing
but
eat
and

and
spend

he

.
<EOS>
I

,
Charlotte
.
<EOS>
He
shall
eat

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Very
well
.
<EOS>
Then
I
suppose

must
go
back
to
Italy
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That

,
Papa
,

<EOS>
what

?
<EOS>
You
ca
n't
let
him
 
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

?
"
said

doctor
,
speaking
more

was
his
wo
nt
and

;
"
that
as
sure

God
rules
in

I
will
not

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
ruling
in

!
"
said
Charlotte
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
no
use

.
<EOS>
You
must
rule
him
here

;
and

,

.
<EOS>
You
ca
n't
turn
him
out
of
the
house
penniless
,
to
beg
about

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
may

where

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
must
go
back

Carrara
.
<EOS>
That

the
cheapest

he
can
live

,

.
<EOS>
But

must

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
As
sure
as
 
"
  
"
Oh
,
Papa
,

.
<EOS>
You
know

must
do
it
.
<EOS>
You
were

two

pounds
for
him
if
this

came
off
.
<EOS>
Half
that
will
start

to
Carrara
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
?
<EOS>
Give

a
hundred

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
know
we
are
all
in
the
dark
,
Papa
,
"
said

,

.
<EOS>
"
For

he
may

Mrs.
Bold
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Fiddlestick
,
"
said
the
father
,
who
had
seen
the
way
in
which
Mrs.
Bold
had
got
into
the
carriage
while
his
son
stood
apart
without
even
