her
his
hand
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
then
,
he
must
go
to
Carrara
,
"
said
Charlotte
.
  
<EOS>
Just
at
this
moment
the
lock
of
the
front
door
was
heard
,
and
Charlotte
's
quick
ears
detected
her
brother
's
catlike
step
in
the
hall
.
<EOS>
She
said
nothing
,
feeling
that
for
the
present
Bertie
had
better
keep
out
of
her
father
's
way
.
<EOS>
But
Dr.
Stanhope
also
heard
the
sound
of
the
lock
.
  
<EOS>
"
Who
's
that
?
"
<EOS>
he
demanded
.
<EOS>
Charlotte
made
no
reply
,
and
he
asked
again
,
"
Who
is
that
that
has
just
come
in
?
<EOS>
Open
the
door
.
<EOS>
Who
is
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
it
is
Bertie
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Bid
him
come
here
,
"
said
the
father
.
<EOS>
But
Bertie
,
who
was
close
to
the
door
and
heard
the
call
,
required
no
further
bidding
,
but
walked
in
with
a
perfectly
unconcerned
and
cheerful
air
.
<EOS>
It
was
this
peculiar
_
insouciance
_
which
angered
Dr.
Stanhope
,
even
more
than
his
son
's
extravagance
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
?
"
said
the
doctor
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
how
did
you
get
home
,
sir
,
with
your
fair
companion
?
"
said
Bertie
.
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
she
is
not
upstairs
,
Charlotte
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Bertie
,
"
said
Charlotte
,
"
Papa
is
in
no
humour
for
joking
.
<EOS>
He
is
very
angry
with
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Angry
!
"
said
Bertie
,
raising
his
eyebrows
as
though
he
had
never
yet
given
his
parent
cause
for
a
single
moment
's
uneasiness
.
  
<EOS>
"
Sit
down
,
if
you
please
,
sir
,
"
said
Dr.
Stanhope
very
sternly
but
not
now
very
loudly
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
I
'll
trouble
you
to
sit
down
,
too
,
Charlotte
.
<EOS>
Your
mother
can
wait
for
her
tea
a
few
minutes
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Charlotte
sat
down
on
the
chair
nearest
to
the
door
in
somewhat
of
a
perverse
sort
of
manner
,
as
much
as
though
she
would
say
 
"
Well
,
here
I
am
;
you
sha
n't
say
I
do
n't
do
what
I
am
bid
;
but
I
'll
be
whipped
if
I
give
way
to
you
.
"
<EOS>
And
she
was
determined
not
to
give
way
.
<EOS>
She
too
was
angry
with
Bertie
,
but
she
was
not
the
less
ready
on
that
account
to
defend
him
from
his
father
.
<EOS>
Bertie
also
sat
down
.
<EOS>
He
drew
his
chair
close
to
the
library
-
table
,
upon
which
he
put
his
elbow
,
and
then
resting
his
face
comfortably
on
one
hand
,
he
began
drawing
little
pictures
on
a
sheet
of
paper
with
the
other
.
<EOS>
Before
the
scene
was
over
he
had
completed
admirable
figures
of
Miss
Thorne
,
Mrs.
Proudie
,
and
Lady
De
Courcy
,
and
begun
a
family
piece
to
comprise
the
whole
set
of
the
Lookalofts
.
  
<EOS>
"
Would
it
suit
you
,
sir
,
"
said
the
father
,
"
to
give
me
some
idea
as
to
what
your
present
intentions
are
?
<EOS>
What
way
of
living
you
propose
to
yourself
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
do
anything
you
can
suggest
,
sir
,
"
replied
Bertie
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
shall
suggest
nothing
further
.
<EOS>
My
time
for
suggesting
has
gone
by
.
<EOS>
I
have
only
one
order
to
give
,
and
that
is
that
you
leave
my
house
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
To
-
night
?
"
said
Bertie
,
and
the
simple
tone
of
the
question
left
the
doctor
without
any
adequately
dignified
method
of
reply
.
  
<EOS>
"
Papa
does
not
quite
mean
to
-
night
,
"
said
Charlotte
;
"
at
least
I
suppose
not
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
To
-
morrow
,
perhaps
,
"
suggested
Bertie
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
to
-
morrow
,
"
said
the
doctor
.
<EOS>
"
You
shall
leave
this
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Very
well
,
sir
.
<EOS>
Will
the
4.30
P.M.
train
be
soon
enough
?
"
<EOS>
and
Bertie
,
as
he
asked
,
put
the
finishing
touch
to
Miss
Thorne
's
high
-
heeled
boots
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
may
go
how
and
when
and
where
you
please
,
so
that
you
leave
my
house
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
You
have
disgraced
me
,
sir
;
you
have
disgraced
yourself
,
and
me
,
and
your
sisters
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
at
least
,
sir
,
that
I
have
not
disgraced
my
mother
,
"
said
Bertie
.
  
<EOS>
Charlotte
could
hardly
keep
her
countenance
,
but
the
doctor
's
brow
grew
still
blacker
than
ever
.
<EOS>
Bertie
was
executing
his
_
chef
d'oeuvre
_
in
the
delineation
of
Mrs.
Proudie
's
nose
and
mouth
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
a
heartless
reprobate
,
sir
;
a
heartless
,
thankless
,
good
-
for
-
nothing
reprobate
.
<EOS>
I
have
done
with
you
.
<EOS>
You
are
my
son
 
that
I
can
not
help
 
<EOS>
but
you
shall
have
no
more
part
or
parcel
in
me
as
my
child
,
nor
I
in
you
as
your
father
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Papa
,
Papa
!
<EOS>
You
must
not
,
shall
not
say
so
,
"
said
Charlotte
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
say
so
,
and
do
say
so
,
"
said
the
father
,
rising
from
his
chair
.
"
<EOS>
And
now
leave
the
room
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Stop
,
stop
,
"
said
Charlotte
.
<EOS>
"
Why
do
n't
you
speak
,
Bertie
?
<EOS>
Why
do
n't
you
look
up
and
speak
?
<EOS>
It
is
your
manner
that
makes
Papa
so
angry
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
perfectly
indifferent
to
all
decency
,
to
all
propriety
,
"
said
the
doctor
;
then
he
shouted
out
,
"
Leave
the
room
,
sir
!
<EOS>
Do
you
hear
what
I
say
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Papa
,
Papa
,
I
will
not
let
you
part
so
.
<EOS>
I
know
you
will
be
sorry
for
it
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
then
she
added
,
getting
up
and
whispering
into
his
ear
,
"
Is
he
only
to
blame
?
<EOS>
Think
of
that
.
<EOS>
We
have
made
our
own
bed
,
and
,
such
as
it
is
,
we
must
lie
on
it
.
<EOS>
It
is
no
use
for
us
to
quarrel
among
ourselves
,
"
and
as
she
finished
her
whisper
,
Bertie
finished
off
the
countess
's
bustle
,
which
was
so
well
done
that
it
absolutely
seemed
to
be
swaying
to
and
fro
on
the
paper
with
its
usual
lateral
motion
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
father
is
angry
at
the
present
time
,
"
said
Bertie
,
looking
up
for
a
moment
from
his
sketches
,
"
because
I
am
not
going
to
marry
Mrs.
Bold
.
<EOS>
What
can
I
say
on
the
matter
?
<EOS>
It
is
true
that
I
am
not
going
to
marry
her
.
<EOS>
In
the
first
place
 
"
  
"
That
is
not
true
,
sir
,
"
said
Dr.
Stanhope
,
"
but
I
will
not
argue
with
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
were
angry
just
this
moment
because
I
would
not
speak
,
"
said
Bertie
,
going
on
with
a
young
Lookaloft
.
  
<EOS>
"
Give
over
drawing
,
"
said
Charlotte
,
going
up
to
him
and
taking
the
paper
from
under
his
hand
.
<EOS>
The
caricatures
,
however
,
she
preserved
and
showed
them
afterwards
to
the
friends
of
the
Thornes
,
the
Proudies
,
and
De
Courcys
.
<EOS>
Bertie
,
deprived
of
his
occupation
,
threw
himself
back
in
his
chair
and
waited
further
orders
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
it
will
certainly
be
for
the
best
that
Bertie
should
leave
this
at
once
;
perhaps
to
-
morrow
,
"
said
Charlotte
;
"
but
pray
,
Papa
,
let
us
arrange
some
scheme
together
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
he
will
leave
this
to
-
morrow
,
I
will
give
him
£
10
,
and
he
shall
be
paid
£
5
a
month
by
the
banker
at
Carrara
as
long
as
he
stays
permanently
in
that
place
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
,
it
wo
n't
be
long
,
"
said
Bertie
,
"
for
I
shall
be
starved
to
death
in
about
three
months
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
He
must
have
marble
to
work
with
,
"
said
Charlotte
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
plenty
there
in
the
studio
to
last
me
three
months
,
"
said
Bertie
.
<EOS>
"
It
will
be
no
use
attempting
anything
large
in
so
limited
a
time
 
unless
I
do
my
own
tombstone
.
"
  
<EOS>
Terms
,
however
,
were
ultimately
come
to
somewhat
more
liberal
than
those
proposed
,
and
the
doctor
was
induced
to
shake
hands
with
his
son
and
bid
him
good
night
.
<EOS>
Dr.
Stanhope
would
not
go
up
to
tea
,
but
had
it
brought
to
him
in
his
study
by
his
daughter
.
  
<EOS>
But
Bertie
went
upstairs
and
spent
a
pleasant
evening
.
<EOS>
He
finished
the
Lookalofts
,
greatly
to
the
delight
of
his
sisters
,
though
the
manner
of
portraying
their
_
décolleté
_
dresses
was
not
the
most
refined
.
<EOS>
Finding
how
matters
were
going
,
he
by
degrees
allowed
it
to
escape
from
him
that
he
had
not
pressed
his
suit
upon
the
widow
in
a
very
urgent
way
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
,
in
point
of
fact
,
you
never
proposed
at
all
?
"
said
Charlotte
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
she
understood
that
she
might
have
me
if
she
wished
,
"
said
he
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
she
did
n't
wish
,
"
said
the
Signora
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
thrown
me
over
in
the
most
shameful
manner
,
"
said
Charlotte
.
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
you
told
her
all
about
my
little
plan
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
it
came
out
somehow
 
at
least
the
most
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
's
an
end
of
that
alliance
,
"
said
Charlotte
,
"
but
it
does
n't
matter
much
.
<EOS>
I
suppose
we
shall
all
be
back
at
Como
soon
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
I
hope
so
,
"
said
the
signora
.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
sick
of
the
sight
of
black
coats
.
<EOS>
If
that
Mr.
Slope
comes
here
any
more
,
he
'll
be
the
death
of
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
've
been
the
ruin
of
him
,
I
think
,
"
said
Charlotte
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
as
for
a
second
black
-
coated
lover
of
mine
,
I
am
going
to
make
a
present
of
him
to
another
lady
with
most
singular
disinterestedness
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
next
day
,
true
to
his
promise
,
Bertie
packed
up
and
went
off
by
the
4.30
P.M.
train
,
with
£
20
in
his
pocket
,
bound
for
the
marble
quarries
of
Carrara
.
<EOS>
And
so
he
disappears
from
our
scene
.
  
<EOS>
At
twelve
o'clock
on
the
day
following
that
on
which
Bertie
went
,
Mrs.
Bold
,
true
also
to
her
word
,
knocked
at
Dr.
Stanhope
's
door
with
a
timid
hand
and
palpitating
heart
.
<EOS>
She
was
at
once
shown
up
to
the
back
drawing
-
room
,
the
folding
doors
of
which
were
closed
,
so
that
in
visiting
the
signora
Eleanor
was
not
necessarily
thrown
into
any
communion
with
those
in
the
front
room
.
<EOS>
As
she
went
up
the
stairs
,
she
saw
none
of
the
family
and
was
so
far
saved
much
of
the
annoyance
which
she
had
dreaded
.
  
<EOS>
"
This
is
very
kind
of
you
,
Mrs.
Bold
;
very
kind
,
after
what
has
happened
,
"
said
the
lady
on
the
sofa
with
her
sweetest
smile
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
wrote
in
such
a
strain
that
I
could
not
but
come
to
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
,
I
did
;
I
wanted
to
force
you
to
see
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
signora
,
I
am
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
cold
you
are
to
me
.
<EOS>
But
I
suppose
I
must
put
up
with
that
.
<EOS>
I
know
you
think
you
have
reason
to
be
displeased
with
us
all
.
<EOS>
Poor
Bertie
;
if
you
knew
all
,
you
would
not
be
angry
with
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
angry
with
your
brother
 
not
in
the
least
.
<EOS>
But
I
hope
you
did
not
send
for
me
here
to
talk
about
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
are
angry
with
Charlotte
,
that
is
worse
,
for
you
have
no
warmer
friend
in
all
Barchester
.
<EOS>
But
I
did
not
send
for
you
to
talk
about
this
 
pray
<EOS>
bring
your
chair
nearer
,
Mrs.
Bold
,
so
that
I
may
look
at
you
.
<EOS>
It
is
so
unnatural
to
see
you
keeping
so
far
off
from
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
Eleanor
did
as
she
was
bid
and
brought
her
chair
close
to
the
sofa
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
now
,
Mrs.
Bold
,
I
am
going
to
tell
you
something
which
you
may
perhaps
think
indelicate
,
but
yet
I
know
that
I
am
right
in
doing
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Hereupon
Mrs.
Bold
said
nothing
but
felt
inclined
to
shake
in
her
chair
.
<EOS>
The
signora
,
she
knew
,
was
not
very
particular
,
and
that
which
to
her
appeared
to
be
indelicate
might
to
<EOS>
Mrs.
Bold
appear
to
be
extremely
indecent
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
believe
you
know
Mr.
Arabin
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Bold
would
have
given
the
world
not
to
blush
,
but
her
blood
was
not
at
her
own
command
.
<EOS>
She
did
blush
up
to
her
forehead
,
and
the
signora
,
who
had
made
her
sit
in
a
special
light
in
order
that
she
might
watch
her
,
saw
that
she
did
so
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
am
acquainted
with
him
.
<EOS>
That
is
,
slightly
.
<EOS>
He
is
an
intimate
friend
of
Dr.
Grantly
,
and
Dr.
Grantly
is
my
brother
-
in
-
law
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
if
you
know
Mr.
Arabin
,
I
am
sure
you
must
like
him
.
<EOS>
I
know
<EOS>
and
like
him
much
.
<EOS>
Everybody
that
knows
him
must
like
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Bold
felt
it
quite
impossible
to
say
anything
in
reply
to
this
.
<EOS>
Her
blood
was
rushing
about
her
body
<EOS>
she
knew
not
how
or
why
.
<EOS>
She
felt
as
though
she
were
swinging
in
her
chair
,
and
she
knew
that
she
was
not
only
red
in
the
face
but
also
almost
suffocated
with
heat
.
<EOS>
However
,
she
sat
still
and
said
nothing
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
stiff
you
are
with
me
,
Mrs.
Bold
,
"
said
the
signora
;
"
and
I
the
while
am
doing
for
you
all
that
one
woman
can
do
to
serve
another
.
"
  
<EOS>
A
kind
of
thought
came
over
the
widow
's
mind
that
perhaps
the
signora
's
friendship
was
real
,
and
that
at
any
rate
it
could
not
hurt
her
;
and
another
kind
of
thought
,
a
glimmering
of
a
thought
,
came
to
her
also
 
that
Mr.
Arabin
was
too
precious
to
be
lost
.
<EOS>
She
despised
the
signora
,
but
might
she
not
stoop
to
conquer
?
<EOS>
It
should
be
but
the
smallest
fraction
of
a
stoop
!
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
want
to
be
stiff
,
"
she
said
,
"
but
your
questions
are
so
very
singular
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
then
,
I
will
ask
you
one
more
singular
still
,
"
said
Madeline
Neroni
,
raising
herself
on
her
elbow
and
turning
her
own
face
full
upon
her
companion
's
.
<EOS>
"
Do
you
love
him
,
love
him
with
all
your
heart
and
soul
,
with
all
the
love
your
bosom
can
feel
?
<EOS>
For
I
can
tell
you
that
he
loves
you
,
adores
you
,
worships
you
,
thinks
of
you
and
nothing
else
,
is
now
thinking
of
you
as
he
attempts
to
write
his
sermon
for
next
Sunday
's
preaching
.
<EOS>
What
would
I
not
give
to
be
loved
in
such
a
way
by
such
a
man
,
that
is
,
if
I
were
an
object
fit
for
any
man
to
love
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Bold
got
up
from
her
seat
and
stood
speechless
before
the
woman
who
was
now
addressing
her
in
this
impassioned
way
.
<EOS>
When
the
signora
thus
alluded
to
herself
,
the
widow
's
heart
was
softened
,
and
she
put
her
own
hand
,
as
though
caressingly
,
on
that
of
her
companion
,
which
was
resting
on
the
table
.
<EOS>
The
signora
grasped
it
and
went
on
speaking
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
I
tell
you
is
God
's
own
truth
;
and
it
is
for
you
to
use
it
as
may
be
best
for
your
own
happiness
.
<EOS>
But
you
must
not
betray
me
.
<EOS>
He
knows
nothing
of
this
.
<EOS>
He
knows
nothing
of
my
knowing
his
inmost
heart
.
<EOS>
He
is
simple
as
a
child
in
these
matters
.
<EOS>
He
told
me
his
secret
in
a
thousand
ways
because
he
could
not
dissemble
,
but
he
does
not
dream
that
he
has
told
it
.
<EOS>
You
know
it
now
,
and
I
advise
you
to
use
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Eleanor
returned
the
pressure
of
the
other
's
hand
with
an
infinitesimal
_
soupçon
_
of
a
squeeze
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
remember
,
"
continued
the
signora
,
"
he
is
not
like
other
men
.
<EOS>
You
must
not
expect
him
to
come
to
you
with
vows
and
oaths
and
pretty
presents
,
to
kneel
at
your
feet
,
and
kiss
your
shoe
-
strings
.
<EOS>
If
you
want
that
,
there
are
plenty
to
do
it
,
but
he
wo
n't
be
one
of
them
.
<EOS>
"
Eleanor
's
bosom
nearly
burst
with
a
sigh
,
but
Madeline
,
not
heeding
her
,
went
on
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
With
him
,
yea
will
stand
for
yea
,
and
nay
for
nay
.
<EOS>
Though
his
heart
should
break
for
it
,
the
woman
who
shall
reject
him
once
will
have
rejected
him
once
and
for
all
.
<EOS>
Remember
that
.
<EOS>
And
now
,
Mrs.
Bold
,
I
will
not
keep
you
,
for
you
are
fluttered
.
<EOS>
I
partly
guess
what
use
you
will
make
of
what
I
have
said
to
you
.
<EOS>
If
ever
you
are
a
happy
wife
in
that
man
's
house
,
we
shall
be
far
away
,
but
I
shall
expect
you
to
write
me
one
line
to
say
that
you
have
forgiven
the
sins
of
the
family
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Eleanor
half
-
whispered
that
she
would
,
and
then
,
without
uttering
another
word
,
crept
out
of
the
room
and
down
the
stairs
,
opened
the
front
door
for
herself
without
hearing
or
seeing
anyone
,
and
found
herself
in
the
close
.
  
<EOS>
It
would
be
difficult
to
analyse
Eleanor
's
feelings
as
she
walked
home
.
<EOS>
She
was
nearly
stupefied
by
the
things
that
had
been
said
to
her
.
<EOS>
She
felt
sore
that
her
heart
should
have
been
so
searched
and
riddled
by
a
comparative
stranger
,
by
a
woman
whom
she
had
never
liked
and
never
could
like
.
<EOS>
She
was
mortified
that
the
man
whom
she
owned
to
herself
that
she
loved
should
have
concealed
his
love
from
her
and
shown
it
to
another
.
<EOS>
There
was
much
to
vex
her
proud
spirit
.
<EOS>
But
there
was
,
nevertheless
,
an
under
stratum
of
joy
in
all
this
which
buoyed
her
up
wondrously
.
<EOS>
She
tried
if
she
could
disbelieve
what
Madame
Neroni
had
said
to
her
,
but
she
found
that
she
could
not
.
<EOS>
It
was
true
;
it
must
be
true
.
<EOS>
She
could
not
,
would
not
,
did
not
doubt
it
.
  
<EOS>
On
one
point
she
fully
resolved
to
follow
the
advice
given
her
.
<EOS>
If
it
should
ever
please
Mr.
Arabin
to
put
such
a
question
to
her
as
that
suggested
,
her
"
yea
"
should
be
"
yea
.
"
<EOS>
Would
not
all
her
miseries
be
at
an
end
if
she
could
talk
of
them
to
him
openly
,
with
her
head
resting
on
his
shoulder
?
   
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
's
Parting
Interview
with
the
Signora
 
<EOS>
On
the
following
day
the
signora
was
in
her
pride
.
<EOS>
She
was
dressed
in
her
brightest
of
morning
dresses
,
and
had
quite
a
levée
round
her
couch
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
beautifully
bright
October
afternoon
;
all
the
gentlemen
of
the
neighbourhood
were
in
Barchester
,
and
those
who
had
the
entry
of
Dr.
Stanhope
's
house
were
in
the
signora
's
back
drawing
-
room
.
<EOS>
Charlotte
and
Mrs.
Stanhope
were
in
the
front
room
,
and
such
of
the
lady
's
squires
as
could
not
for
the
moment
get
near
the
centre
of
attraction
had
to
waste
their
fragrance
on
the
mother
and
sister
.
  
<EOS>
The
first
who
came
and
the
last
to
leave
was
Mr.
Arabin
.
<EOS>
This
was
the
second
visit
he
had
paid
to
Madame
Neroni
since
he
had
met
her
at
Ullathorne
.
<EOS>
He
came
,
he
knew
not
why
,
to
talk
about
,
he
knew
not
what
.
<EOS>
But
,
in
truth
,
the
feelings
which
now
troubled
him
were
new
to
him
,
and
he
could
not
analyse
them
.
<EOS>
It
may
seem
strange
that
he
should
thus
come
dangling
about
Madame
Neroni
because
he
was
in
love
with
Mrs.
Bold
;
but
it
was
nevertheless
the
fact
;
and
though
he
could
not
understand
why
he
did
so
,
Madame
Neroni
understood
it
well
enough
.
  
<EOS>
She
had
been
gentle
and
kind
to
him
and
had
encouraged
his
staying
.
<EOS>
Therefore
he
stayed
on
.
<EOS>
She
pressed
his
hand
when
he
first
greeted
her
;
she
made
him
remain
near
her
and
whispered
to
him
little
nothings
.
<EOS>
And
then
her
eye
,
brilliant
and
bright
,
now
mirthful
,
now
melancholy
,
and
invincible
in
either
way
!
<EOS>
What
man
with
warm
feelings
,
blood
unchilled
,
and
a
heart
not
guarded
by
a
triple
steel
of
experience
could
have
withstood
those
eyes
!
<EOS>
The
lady
,
it
is
true
,
intended
to
do
him
no
mortal
injury
;
she
merely
chose
to
inhale
a
slight
breath
of
incense
before
she
handed
the
casket
over
to
another
.
<EOS>
Whether
Mrs.
Bold
would
willingly
have
spared
even
so
much
is
another
question
.
  
<EOS>
And
then
came
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
All
the
world
now
knew
that
Mr.
Slope
was
a
candidate
for
the
deanery
and
that
he
was
generally
considered
to
be
the
favourite
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
,
therefore
,
walked
rather
largely
upon
the
earth
.
<EOS>
He
gave
to
himself
a
portly
air
,
such
as
might
become
a
dean
,
spoke
but
little
to
other
clergymen
,
and
shunned
the
bishop
as
much
as
possible
.
<EOS>
How
the
meagre
little
prebendary
,
and
the
burly
chancellor
,
and
all
the
minor
canons
and
vicars
choral
,
ay
,
and
all
the
choristers
,
too
,
cowered
and
shook
and
walked
about
with
long
faces
when
they
read
or
heard
of
that
article
in
"
The
Jupiter
.
<EOS>
"
Now
were
coming
the
days
when
nothing
would
avail
to
keep
the
impure
spirit
from
the
cathedral
pulpit
.
<EOS>
That
pulpit
would
indeed
be
his
own
.
<EOS>
Precentors
,
vicars
,
and
choristers
might
hang
up
their
harps
on
the
willows
.
<EOS>
Ichabod
!
<EOS>
Ichabod
!
<EOS>
The
glory
of
their
house
was
departing
from
them
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
,
great
as
he
was
with
embryo
grandeur
,
still
came
to
see
the
signora
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
he
could
not
keep
himself
away
.
<EOS>
He
dreamed
of
that
soft
hand
which
he
had
kissed
so
often
,
and
of
that
imperial
brow
which
his
lips
had
once
pressed
;
and
he
then
dreamed
also
of
further
favours
.
  
<EOS>
And
Mr.
Thorne
was
there
also
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
first
visit
he
had
ever
paid
to
the
signora
,
and
he
made
it
not
without
due
preparation
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Thorne
was
a
gentleman
usually
precise
in
his
dress
and
prone
to
make
the
most
of
himself
in
an
unpretending
way
.
<EOS>
The
grey
hairs
in
his
whiskers
were
eliminated
perhaps
once
a
month
;
those
on
his
head
were
softened
by
a
mixture
which
we
will
not
call
a
dye
 
<EOS>
it
was
only
a
wash
.
<EOS>
His
tailor
lived
in
St.
James
's
Street
,
and
his
bootmaker
at
the
corner
of
that
street
and
Piccadilly
.
<EOS>
He
was
particular
in
the
article
of
gloves
,
and
the
getting
up
of
his
shirts
was
a
matter
not
lightly
thought
of
in
the
Ullathorne
laundry
.
<EOS>
On
the
occasion
of
the
present
visit
he
had
rather
overdone
his
usual
efforts
,
and
caused
some
little
uneasiness
to
his
sister
,
who
had
not
hitherto
received
very
cordially
the
proposition
for
a
lengthened
visit
from
the
signora
at
Ullathorne
.
  
<EOS>
There
were
others
also
there
 
young
men
about
the
city
who
had
not
much
to
do
and
who
were
induced
by
the
lady
's
charms
to
neglect
that
little
 
but
all
gave
way
to
Mr.
Thorne
,
who
was
somewhat
of
a
grand
signor
,
as
a
country
gentleman
always
is
in
a
provincial
city
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Mr.
Thorne
,
this

kind

!
"
said

signora
.
<EOS>
"
You
promised
to
come
,
but
I
really
did
not

.
<EOS>
I
thought
you
country

never
kept
your
pledges
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
yes
,
sometimes
,
"
said

Thorne
,
looking
rather

and
making
his

a
little
too
much
in
the
style
of
the
last
century
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
deceive
none
but
your
consti
 
stit
 
stit
 
<EOS>
what
do
you
call
the
people
that
carry
you
about
in
chairs
and
pelt
you
with
eggs
and
apples
when
they
make
you
a
member
of
Parliament
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
One
another
also
,
sometimes
,
signora
,
"
said

Slope
,
with
a
very
deanish

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Country
gentlemen
do
deceive
one
another
sometimes
,
do

,
Mr.
Thorne
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Thorne
gave
him
a
look
which
undeaned
him
completely
for
the
moment
,
but
he
soon
remembered
his
high
hopes
and
,
recovering
himself
quickly
,
sustained
his
probable
coming
dignity
by
a
laugh
at
Mr.
Thorne
's
expense
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
never
deceive
a
lady
,
at

rate
,
"
said
Mr.
Thorne
,
"
especially
when
the
gratification
of
my
own

is
so
strong
an
inducement
to
keep
me
true
,
as
it
now
is
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Thorne
went
on
thus
awhile
with
antediluvian
grimaces
and
compliments
which
he
had
picked
up
from
Sir
Charles
Grandison
,
and
the
signora
at
every

and
at
every
bow
smiled

little

and

little

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Thorne
,
however
,
was
kept
standing
at
the
foot
of
the
couch
,
for
the
new
dean
sat
in
the
seat
of
honour
near
the
table
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
the
while
was
standing
with
his
back
to
the
fire
,
his
coat
-
tails
under
his
arms
,
gazing

her
with
all

not
quite
in

,
for
every

again
<EOS>
a

came

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Mr.
Thorne
,

girl

.
<EOS>
Can
you
spare
a
moment
 
<EOS>
will

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Thorne
assured

that

and

young
lady
with

.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
,

?
"
<EOS>
said
she
,
and
when
Mr.
Slope
got

,
she

at

Thorne
and

to

chair
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Thorne
,
however
,
was
much
too
slow
to
understand

,
and
Mr.
Slope
would
have
recovered

had
not
the
signora
,
who
never
chose
to
be

,
somewhat

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Mr.
Slope
,
I

Mr.
Thorne

here

.
<EOS>
I
am
sure
you

.
<EOS>
We
can

.
<EOS>
Next

,
you
know
,
when
you
move

the
dean
's
house
,
we
shall
all
be

.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
,
with
an
air
of
much
indifference
,
rose
from
his
seat
and
,
walking
into
the
next
room
,
became
greatly
interested
in
Mrs.
Stanhope
's
worsted
work
.
  
<EOS>
And
then
the
child
was
brought
in
.
<EOS>
She
was
a
little
girl
,
about
eight
years
of
age
,
like
her
mother
,
only
that
her
enormous
eyes
were
black
,
and
her
hair
quite
jet
.
<EOS>
Her
complexion
,
too
,
was
very
dark
and
bespoke
her
foreign
blood
.
<EOS>
She
was
dressed
in
the
most
outlandish
and
extravagant
way
in
which
clothes
could
be
put
on
a
child
's
back
.
<EOS>
She
had
great
bracelets
on
her
naked
little
arms
,
a
crimson
fillet
braided
with
gold
round
her
head
,
and
scarlet
shoes
with
high
heels
.
<EOS>
Her
dress
was
all
flounces
and
stuck
out
from
her
as
though
the
object
were
to
make
it
lie
off
horizontally
from
her
little
hips
.
<EOS>
It
did
not
nearly
cover
her
knees
,
but
this
was
atoned
for
by
a
loose
pair
of
drawers
,
which
seemed
made
throughout
of
lace
;
then
she
had
on
pink
silk
stockings
.
<EOS>
It
was
thus
that
the
last
of
the
Neros
was
habitually
dressed
at
the
hour
when
visitors
were
wo
nt
to
call
.
  
<EOS>
"
Julia
,
my
love
,
"
said
the
mother
 
Julia
was
ever
a
favourite
name
with
the
ladies
of
that
family
.
<EOS>
"
Julia
,
my
love
,
come
here
.
<EOS>
I
was
telling

about
the
beautiful
party
poor
Mamma
<EOS>
went
to
.
<EOS>
This
is
Mr.
Thorne
;
will

a

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
Julia
put
up
her
face
to
be
kissed
,
as
she
did
to
all
her
mother
's
visitors
,
and
then
Mr.
Thorne
found
that
he
had
got
her
and
,
what
was
much
more
terrific
to
him
,
all
her
finery
,
into
his
arms
.
<EOS>
The
lace
and
starch
crumpled
against
his
waistcoat
and
trousers
,
the
greasy
black
curls
hung
upon
his
cheek
,
and
one
of
the
bracelet
clasps
scratched
his
ear
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
at
all
know
how
to
hold
so
magnificent
a
lady
,
nor
holding
her
what
to
do
with
her
.
<EOS>
However
,
he
had
on
other
occasions
been
compelled
to
fondle
little
nieces
and
nephews
,
and
now
set
about
the
task
in
the
mode
he
always
had
used
.
  
<EOS>
"
Diddle
,
diddle
,
diddle
,
diddle
,
"
said
he
,
putting
the
child
on
one
knee
and
working
away
with
it
as
though
he
were
turning
a
knife
-
grinder
's
wheel
with
his
foot
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mamma
,
Mamma
,
"
said
Julia
crossly
,
"
I
do
n't
want
to
be
diddle
diddled
.
<EOS>
Let
me
go
,
you
naughty
old
man
,
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
Poor
Mr.
Thorne
put
the
child
down
quietly
on
the
ground
and
drew
back
his
chair
;
Mr.
Slope
,
who
had
returned
to
the
pole
star
that
attracted
him
,
laughed
aloud
;
Mr.
Arabin
winced
and
shut
his
eyes
;
and
the
signora
pretended
not
to
hear
her
daughter
.
  
<EOS>
"
Go
to
Aunt
Charlotte
,
lovey
,
"
said
the
mamma
,
"
and
ask
her
if
it
is
not
time
for
you
to
go
out
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But
little
Miss
Julia
,
though
she
had
not
exactly
liked
the
nature
of
Mr.
Thorne
's
attention
,
was
accustomed
to
be
played
with
by
gentlemen
,
and
did
not
relish
the
idea
of
being
sent
so
soon
to
her
aunt
.
  
<EOS>
"
Julia
,
go
when
I
tell
you
,
my
dear
.
"
<EOS>
But
Julia
still
went
pouting
about
the
room
.
<EOS>
"
Charlotte
,
do
come
and
take
her
,
"
said
the
signora
.
<EOS>
"
She
must
go
out
,
and
the
days
get
so
short
now
.
"
<EOS>
And
thus
ended
the
much
-
talked
-
of
interview
between
Mr.
Thorne
and
the
last
of
the
Neros
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Thorne
recovered
from
the
child
's
crossness
sooner
than
from
Mr.
Slope
's
laughter
.
<EOS>
He
could
put
up
with
being
called
an
old
man
by
an
infant
,
but
he
did
not
like
to
be
laughed
at
by
the
bishop
's
chaplain
,
even
though
that
chaplain
was
about
to
become
a
dean
.
<EOS>
He
said
nothing
,
but
he
showed
plainly
enough
that
he
was
angry
.
  
<EOS>
The
signora
was
ready
enough
to
avenge
him
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
,
"
said
she
,
"
I
hear
that
you
are
triumphing
on
all
sides
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
so
?
<EOS>
"
said
he
,
smiling
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
dislike
being
talked
to
about
the
deanery
,
though
,
of
course
,
he
strongly
denied
the
imputation
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
carry
the
day
both
in
love
and
war
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
hereupon
did
not
look
quite
so
satisfied
as
he
had
done
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Arabin
,
"
continued
the
signora
,
"
do
n't
you
think
Mr.
Slope
is
a
very
lucky
man
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Not
more
so
than
he
deserves
,
I

,
"
said

Arabin
.
  
<EOS>
"
Only
think
,
Mr.
Thorne
,
he
is
to
be
our

;

.
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

Slope
,
"
we
all
know

about

.
<EOS>
I
can

I
myself
 
<EOS>
"
  
"
He
is
to
be
the
new
dean
 
<EOS>
there
is
no
manner
of

of

,
Mr.
Thorne
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Hum
!
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Passing

old

my

and
Archdeacon
Grantly
 
<EOS>
"
  
"
Oh
 
oh
!
"

Slope
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
archdeacon
would
not

,
"

,
whereupon

,
that

.
  
<EOS>
"
Going

,
"
continued

signora
,
"
for

.
<EOS>
"
  
"

,
"

,
"

,

to

<EOS>
,

glory

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Mr.
Slope
,

;
I

.
<EOS>
There

glory

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
is
not

to

but
a
wife
to

.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
again

.
  
<EOS>
"
A
wife
with

large

,
too
.
<EOS>
It
never
rains
but
it
pours
,

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
No
,

,
"
said

Thorne
,
who
did
not
quite

talking
about
Mr.
Slope
and
his

.
  
<EOS>
"
When
will
it
be
,
Mr.
Slope
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
When
will
what
be
?
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
we
know
when
the

of
the

will

:
a

will
settle

.
<EOS>
The

,
I

,

.
<EOS>
But

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
mean

Arabin
's
?
"
said

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
just
then
I
meant
yours
,
though
,
perhaps
,
after

,
Mr.
Arabin
's
may

first
.
<EOS>
But
we

nothing
of

.
<EOS>
He
is
too
close

any
of

.
<EOS>
Now
all

open

above
board
with
you
 
<EOS>
which
,
by
the
by
,
Mr.
Arabin
,
I
beg

I
like

the
best
.
<EOS>
He
who
runs
can
read
that
Mr.
Slope
is
a

.
<EOS>
Come
,
Mr.
Slope
,
when

the

to

Mrs.
Dean
?
"
  
<EOS>
To
Mr.
Arabin
<EOS>
this
badinage
was
peculiarly
painful
,
and
yet
he
could
not
tear
himself
away
and
leave
it
.
<EOS>
He
believed
,
still
believed
with
that
sort
of
belief
which
the
fear
of
a
thing
engenders
,
that
Mrs.
Bold
would
probably
become
the
wife
of
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
Of
Mr.
Slope
's
little
adventure
in
the
garden
he
knew
nothing
.
<EOS>
For
aught
he
knew
,
Mr.
Slope
might
have
had
an
adventure
of
quite
a
different
character
.
<EOS>
He
might
have
thrown
himself
at
the
widow
's
feet
,
been
accepted
,
and
then
returned
to
town
a
jolly
,
thriving
wooer
.
<EOS>
The
signora
's
jokes
were
bitter
enough
to
Mr.
Slope
,
but
they
were
quite
as
bitter
to
Mr.
Arabin
.
<EOS>
He
still
stood
leaning
against
the
fire
-
place
,
fumbling
with
his
hands
in
his
trousers
pockets
.
  
<EOS>
"
Come
,
come
,
Mr.
Slope
,
do
n't
be
so
bashful
,
"
continued
the
signora
.
<EOS>
"
We
all
know
that
you
proposed
to
the
lady
the
other
day
at
Ullathorne
.
<EOS>
Tell
us
with
what
words
she
accepted
you
.
<EOS>
Was
it
with
a
simple
"
yes
,
"
or
with
the
two
"
<EOS>
no
<EOS>
no
's
"
which
make
an
affirmative
?
<EOS>
Or
did
silence
give
consent
?
<EOS>
Or
did
she
speak
out
with
that
spirit
which
so
well
becomes

widow
and
say

,
"
By
my
troth
,
sir
,
you
shall
make
me
Mrs.
Slope
as
soon
as
it
is
your
pleasure
to
do

.
"
<EOS>
"
  
Mr.
Slope
had
seldom
in
his
life
felt
himself
less
at
his
ease
.
<EOS>
There
sat
Mr.
Thorne
,
laughing
silently
.
<EOS>
There
stood
his
old
antagonist
,
Mr.
Arabin
,
gazing
at
him
with
all
his
eyes
.
<EOS>
There
round
the
door
between
the
two
rooms
<EOS>
were
clustered
a
little
group
of
people
,
including
Miss
Stanhope
and
the
Revs
.
<EOS>
Messrs.
Grey
and
Green
,
all
listening
to
his
discomfiture
.
<EOS>
He
knew
that
it
depended
solely
on
his
own
wit
whether
or
no
he
could
throw
the
joke
back
upon
the
lady
.
<EOS>
He
knew
that
it
stood
him
to
do
so
if
he
possibly
could
,
but
he
had
not
a
word
.
"
<EOS>
'
tis
conscience
that
makes
cowards
of
us
all
.
"
<EOS>
He
felt
on
his
cheek
the
sharp
points
of
Eleanor
's
fingers
,
and
did
not
know
who
might
have
seen
the
blow
,
who
might
have
told
the
tale
to
this
pestilent
woman
who
took
such
delight
in
jeering
him
.
<EOS>
He
stood
there
,
therefore
,
red
as
a
carbuncle
and
mute
as
a
fish
;
grinning
sufficiently
to
show
his
teeth
;
an
object
of
pity
.
  
<EOS>
But
the
signora
had
no
pity
;
she
knew
nothing
of
mercy
.
<EOS>
Her
present
object
was
to
put
Mr.
Slope
down
,
and
she
was
determined
to
do
it
thoroughly
,
now
that
she
had
him
in
her
power
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
,
Mr.
Slope
,
no
answer
?
<EOS>
Why
it
ca
n't
possibly
be
that
the
woman
has
been
fool
enough
to
refuse
you
?
<EOS>
She
ca
n't
surely
be
looking
out
after
a
bishop
.
<EOS>
But
I
see
how
it
is
,
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
Widows
are
proverbially
cautious
.
<EOS>
You
should
have
let
her
alone
till
the
new
hat
was
on
your

,
till
you
could
show

of

deanery
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Signora
,
"
said

at

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Solemn
subjects
 
what
solemn

?
<EOS>
Surely

dean
's

is
not

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have

.
<EOS>
Perhaps

will

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

,
Mr.
Slope
;
but
one

.
<EOS>
Go
to

again
with

's

.
<EOS>
I
'll

shawl
to

she
does

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

,
that
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

,

;
I
'll
only

;
"
and
then
she
commenced
singing
    
<EOS>
"
It
's
gude
to
be
merry
and
wise
,
Mr.
Slope
;
It
's
gude
to

;
It
's
gude
to
be
off
with
the
old
love
 
Mr.
Slope
,
Before
you
are
on
with
the
new
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ha
,
ha
,
ha
!
"
  
<EOS>
And
the
signora
,
throwing
herself
back
on
her
sofa
,
laughed
merrily
.
<EOS>
She
little
recked
how
those
who
heard
her
would
,
in
their
own
imaginations
,
fill
up
the
little
history
of
Mr.
Slope
's
first
love
.
<EOS>
She
little
cared
that
some
among
them
might
attribute
to
her
the
honour
of
his
earlier
admiration
.
<EOS>
She
was
tired
of
Mr.
Slope
and
wanted
to
get
rid
of
him
;
she
had
ground
for
anger
with
him
,
and
she
chose
to
be
revenged
.
  
<EOS>
How
Mr.
Slope
got
out
of
that
room
he
never
himself
knew
.
<EOS>
He
did
succeed
ultimately
,
and
probably
with
some
assistance
,
in
getting
his
hat
and
escaping
into
the
air
.
<EOS>
At
last
his
love
for
the
signora
was
cured
.
<EOS>
Whenever
he
again
thought
of
her
in
his
dreams
,
it
was
not
as
of
an
angel
with
azure
wings
.
<EOS>
He
connected
her
rather
with
fire
and
brimstone
,
and
though
he
could
still
believe
her
to
be
a
spirit
,
he
banished
her
entirely
out
of
heaven
and
found
a
place
for
her
among
the
infernal
gods
.
<EOS>
When
he
weighed
in
the
balance
,
as
he
not
seldom
did
,
the
two
women
to
whom
he
had
attached
himself
in
Barchester
,
the
pre
-
eminent
place
in
his
soul
's
hatred
was
usually
allotted
to
the
signora
.
   
<EOS>
The
Dean
Elect
 
<EOS>
During
the
entire
next
week
Barchester
was
ignorant
who
was
to
be
its
new
dean
.
<EOS>
On
Sunday
morning
Mr.
Slope
was
decidedly
the
favourite
,
but
he
did
not
show
himself
in
the
cathedral
,
and
then
he
sank
a
point
or
two
in
the
betting
.
<EOS>
On
Monday
he
got
a
scolding
from
the
bishop
in
the
hearing
of
the
servants
,
and
down
he
went
till
nobody
would
have
him
at
any
price
;
but
on
Tuesday
he
received
a
letter
,
in
an
official
cover
,
marked
private
,
by
which
he
fully
recovered
his
place
in
the
public
favour
.
<EOS>
On
Wednesday
he
was
said
to
be
ill
,
and
that
did
not
look
well
;
but
on
Thursday
morning
he
went
down
to
the
railway
station
with
a
very
jaunty
air
;
and
when
it
was
ascertained
that
he
had
taken
a
first
-
class
ticket
for
London
,
there
was
no
longer
any
room
for
doubt
on
the
matter
.
  
<EOS>
While
matters
were
in
this
state
of
ferment
at
Barchester
,
there
was
not
much
mental
comfort
at
Plumstead
.
<EOS>
Our
friend
the
archdeacon
had
many
grounds
for
inward
grief
.
<EOS>
He
was
much
displeased
at
the
result
of
Dr.
Gwynne
's
diplomatic
mission
to
the
palace
,
and
did
not
even
scruple
to
say
to
his
wife
that
had
he
gone
himself
,
he
would
have
managed
the
affair
much
better
.
<EOS>
His
wife
did
not
agree
with
him
,
but
that
did
not
mend
the
matter
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Quiverful
's
appointment
to
the
hospital
was
,
however
,
a
_
fait
accompli
_
,
and
Mr.
Harding
's
acquiescence
in
that
appointment
was
not
less
so
.
<EOS>
Nothing
would
induce
Mr.
Harding
to
make
a
public
appeal
against
the
bishop
,
and
the
Master
of
Lazarus
quite
approved
of
his
not
doing
so
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
what
has
come
to
the
master
,
"
said
the
archdeacon
over
and
over
again
.
"
<EOS>
He
used
to
be
ready
enough
to
stand
up
for
his
order
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Archdeacon
,
"
Mrs.
Grantly
would
say
in
reply
,
"
what
is
the
use
of
always
fighting
?
<EOS>
I
really
think
the
master
is
right
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
master
,
however
,
had
taken
steps
of
his
own
of
which
neither
the
archdeacon
nor
his
wife
knew
anything
.
  
<EOS>
Then
Mr.
Slope
's
successes
were
henbane
to
Dr.
Grantly
,
and
Mrs.
Bold
's
improprieties
were
as
bad
.
<EOS>
What
would
be
all
the
world
to
Archdeacon
Grantly
if
Mr.
Slope
should
become
Dean
of
Barchester
and
marry
his
wife
's
sister
!
<EOS>
He
talked
of
it
and
talked
of
it
till
he
was
nearly
ill
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Grantly
almost
wished
that
the
marriage
were
done
and
over
,
so
that
she
might
hear
no
more
about
it
.
  
<EOS>
And
there
was
yet
another
ground
of
misery
which
cut
him
to
the
quick
nearly
as
closely
as
either
of
the
others
.
<EOS>
That
paragon
of
a
clergyman
whom
he
had
bestowed
upon
St.
Ewold
's
,
that
college
friend
of
whom
he
had
boasted
so
loudly
,
that
ecclesiastical
knight
before
whose
lance
Mr.
Slope
was
to
fall
and
bite
the
dust
,
that
worthy
bulwark
of
the
church
as
it
should
be
,
that
honoured
representative
of
Oxford
's
best
spirit
,
was
 
so
at
least
his
wife
had
told
him
half
a
dozen
times
 
misconducting
himself
!
  
<EOS>
Nothing
had
been
seen
of
Mr.
Arabin
at
Plumstead
for
the
last
week
,
but
a
good
deal
had
,
unfortunately
,
been
heard
of
him
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
Mrs.
Grantly
had
found
herself
alone
with
the
archdeacon
,
on
the
evening
of
the
Ullathorne
party
,
she
had
expressed
herself
very
forcibly
as
to
Mr.
Arabin
's
conduct
on
that
occasion
.
<EOS>
He
had
,
she
declared
,
looked
and
acted
and
talked
very
unlike
a
decent
parish
clergyman
.
<EOS>
At
first
the
archdeacon
had
laughed
at
this
,
and
assured
her
that
she
need
not
trouble
herself
 
that
Mr.
Arabin
would
be
found
to
be
quite
safe
.
<EOS>
But
by
degrees
he
began
to
find
that
his
wife
's
eyes
had
been
sharper
than
his
own
.
<EOS>
Other
people
coupled
the
signora
's
name
with
that
of
Mr.
Arabin
.
<EOS>
The
meagre
little
prebendary
who
lived
in
the
close
told
him
to
a
nicety
how
often
Mr.
Arabin
had
visited
at
Dr.
Stanhope
's
,
and
how
long
he
had
remained
on
the
occasion
of
each
visit
.
<EOS>
He
had
asked
after
Mr.
Arabin
at
the
cathedral
library
,
and
an
officious
little
vicar
choral
had
offered
to
go
and
see
whether
he
could
be
found
at
Dr.
Stanhope
's
.
<EOS>
Rumour
,
when
she
has
contrived
to
sound
the
first
note
on
her
trumpet
,
soon
makes
a
loud
peal
audible
enough
.
<EOS>
It
was
too
clear
that
Mr.
Arabin
had
succumbed
to
the
Italian
woman
,
and
that
the
archdeacon
's
credit
would
suffer
fearfully
if
something
were
not
done
to
rescue
the
brand
from
the
burning
.
<EOS>
Besides
,
to
give
the
archdeacon
his
due
,
he
was
really
attached
to
Mr.
Arabin
,
and
grieved
greatly
at
his
backsliding
.
  
<EOS>
They
were
sitting
,
talking
over
their
sorrows
,
in
the
drawing
-
room
before
dinner
on
the
day
after
Mr.
Slope
's
departure
for
London
,
and
<EOS>
on
this
occasion
Mrs.
Grantly
spoke
out
her
mind
freely
.
<EOS>
She
had
opinions
of
her
own
about
parish
clergymen
,
and
now
thought
it
right
to
give
vent
to
them
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
would
have
been
led
by
me
,
Archdeacon
,
you
would
never
have
put
a
bachelor
into

Ewold
's
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
my
dear
,
you
do
n't
meant
to
say
that
all
bachelor
clergymen
misbehave
themselves
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
that
clergymen
are
so
much
better
than
other
men
,
"
said
Mrs.
Grantly
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
all
very
well
with
a
curate
,
whom
you
have
under
your
own
eye
and
whom
you
can
get
rid

if
he

in

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
Mr.
Arabin
was
a
fellow
,
and
could
n't
have
had
a
wife
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
I
would
have
found
someone
who
could
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
,
my
dear
,
are
fellows
never
to
get
livings
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
to
be
sure
they
are
,
when
they
get
engaged
.
<EOS>
I
never
would
put
a
young
man
into
a
living
unless
he
were
married
,
or
engaged
to
be
married
.
<EOS>
Now
,
here
is
Mr.
Arabin
.
<EOS>
The
whole
responsibility
lies
upon
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
is
not
at
this
moment
a
clergyman
in
all
Oxford
more
respected
for
morals
and
conduct
than
Arabin
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Oxford
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
lady
,
with
a
sneer
.
<EOS>
"
What
men
choose
to
do
at
Oxford
nobody
ever
hears
of
.
<EOS>
A
man
may
do
very
well
at
Oxford
who
would
bring
disgrace
on
a
parish
;
and
to
tell
you
the
truth
,
it
seems
to
me
that
Mr.
Arabin
is
just
such
a
man
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
archdeacon
groaned
deeply
,
but
he
had
no
further
answer
to
make
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
really
must
speak
to
him
,
Archdeacon
.
<EOS>
Only
think
what
the
Thornes
will
say
if
they
hear
that
their
parish
clergyman
spends
his
whole
time
philandering
with
this
woman
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
archdeacon
groaned
again
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
courageous
man
,
and
knew
well
enough
how
to
rebuke
the
younger
clergymen
of
the
diocese
,
when
necessary
.
<EOS>
But
there
was
that
about
Mr.
Arabin
which
made
the
doctor
feel
that
it
would
be
very
difficult
to
rebuke
him
with
good
effect
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
can
advise
him
to
find
a
wife
for
himself
,
and
he
will
understand
well
enough
<EOS>
what
that
means
,
"
said
Mrs.
Grantly
.
  
<EOS>
The
archdeacon
had
nothing
for
it
but
groaning
.
<EOS>
There
was
Mr.
Slope
:
he
was
going
to
be
made
dean
;
he
was
going
to
take
a
wife
;
he
was
about
to
achieve
respectability
and
wealth
,
an
excellent
family
mansion
,
and
a
family
carriage
;
he
would
soon
be
among
the
comfortable
_
élite
_
of
the
ecclesiastical
world
of
Barchester
;
whereas
his
own
_
protégé
_
,
<EOS>
the
true
scion
of
the
true
church
,
by
whom
he
had
sworn
,
would
be
still
but
a
poor
vicar
,
and
that
with
a
very
indifferent
character
for
moral
conduct
!
<EOS>
It
might
be
all
very
well
recommending
Mr.
Arabin
to
marry
,
but
how
would
Mr.
Arabin
,
when
married
,
support
a
wife
?
  
<EOS>
Things
were
ordering
themselves
thus
in
Plumstead
drawing
-
room
when
Dr.
and
Mrs.
Grantly
were
disturbed
in
their
sweet
discourse
by
the
quick
rattle
of
a
carriage
and
pair
of
horses
on
the
gravel
sweep
.
<EOS>
The
sound
was
not
that
of
visitors
,
whose
private
carriages
are
generally
brought
up
to
country
-
house
doors
with
demure
propriety
,
but
betokened
rather
the
advent
of
some
person
or
persons
who
were
in
a
hurry
to
reach
the
house
,
and
had
no
intention
of
immediately
leaving
it
.
<EOS>
Guests
invited
to
stay
a
week
,
and
who
were
conscious
of
arriving
after
the
first
dinner
-
bell
,
would
probably
approach
in
such
a
manner
.
<EOS>
So
might
arrive
an
attorney
with
the
news
of
a
granduncle
's
death
,
or
a
son
from
college
with
all
the
fresh
honours
of
a
double
first
.
<EOS>
No
one
would
have
had
himself
driven
up
to
the
door
of
a
country
-
house
in
such
a
manner
who
had
the
slightest
doubt
of
his
own
right
to
force
an
entry
.
  
<EOS>
"
Who
is
it
?
"
said
Mrs.
Grantly
,
looking
at
her
husband
.
  
<EOS>
"
Who
on
earth
can
it
be
?
"
said
the
archdeacon
to
his
wife
.
<EOS>
He
then
quietly
got
up
and
stood
with
the
drawing
-
room
door
open
in
his
hand
.
<EOS>
"
Why
,
it
's
your
father
!
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
indeed
Mr.
Harding
,
and
Mr.
Harding
alone
.
<EOS>
He
had
come
by
himself
in
a
post
-
chaise
with
a
couple
of
horses
from
Barchester
,
arriving
almost
after
dark
,
and
evidently
full
of
news
.
<EOS>
His
visits
had
usually
been
made
in
the
quietest
manner
;
he
had
rarely
presumed
to
come
without
notice
,
and
had
always
been
driven
up
in
a
modest
old
green
fly
,
with
one
horse
,
that
hardly
made
itself
heard
as
it
crawled
up
to
the
hall
-
door
.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
gracious
,
Warden
,
is
it
you
?
"
said
the
archdeacon
,
forgetting
in

the
events
of
the

.
<EOS>
"
But
come
in
;
nothing
the
matter
,
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
are

are

,
Papa
,
"

daughter
.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
go
and

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
an't
warden
,

,
"
said
Mr.
Harding
;
"
Mr.
Quiverful
is
warden
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
I
know
,
I
know
,
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
I

at

.
<EOS>
Is
anything
the

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do

,
Susan
,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
The

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Will

?
"

Harding
.
<EOS>
"
Then

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
was
big
with
news
which
he
had
come
to

,
but

.
<EOS>
He

as

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
No
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Has

?
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,

,

"

But

"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
They
have
 
"
  
"
They

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
They

,

,

<EOS>

Good

!
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
"
My

,

,
"

,

<EOS>
"
So

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Consult
!
"

.
"
<EOS>
But
,

,

with

;

.
<EOS>

;
"

,

"

<EOS>
"
But
 
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
But

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

Lord
 
---

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That

's

,

,
"

,

Lazarus
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

,

!
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
But
,
my
dear
,
"
said

Harding
.
<EOS>
It
was
all

vain
that
he
strove
to
speak
;
nobody
would
listen
to
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Mr.
Dean
,
"
said
the
archdeacon
,
triumphing
,
"
the
deanery
gardens
will
be
some
consolation
for
the
hospital
elms
.
<EOS>
Well
,
poor
Quiverful
!
<EOS>
I
wo
n't
begrudge
him
his
good
fortune
any
longer
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
indeed
,
"
said
Mrs.
Grantly
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Poor
woman
,
she
has
fourteen
children
.
<EOS>
I
am
sure
I
am
very
glad
they
have
got
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
So
am
I
,
"
said
Mr.
Harding
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
would
give
twenty
pounds
,
"
said
the
archdeacon
,
"
to
see
how
Mr.
Slope
will
look
when
he
hears

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
idea
of
Mr.
Slope
's
discomfiture
formed
no
small
part
of
the
archdeacon
's
pleasure
.
  
<EOS>
At
last
Mr.
Harding
was
allowed
to
go
upstairs
and
wash
his
hands
,
having
,
in
fact
,
said
very
little
of
all
that
he
had
come
out
to
Plumstead
on
purpose
to
say
.
<EOS>
Nor
could
anything
more
be
said
till
the
servants
were
gone
after

.
<EOS>
The
joy
of
Dr.
Grantly
was
so
uncontrollable
that
he
could
not

from
calling
his
father
-
in
-
law
Mr.
Dean
before
the
men
,
and
therefore
it
was
soon
matter
of
discussion
in
the
lower
regions
how
Mr.
Harding
,
instead
of
his
daughter
's
future
husband
,
was
to
be
the
new
dean
,
and
various
were
the
opinions
on
the
matter
.
<EOS>
The
cook
and
butler
,
who
were
advanced
in
years
,
thought
that
it
was
just
as
it
should
be
;
but
the
footman
and
lady
's
maid
,
who
were
younger
,
thought
it
was
a
great
shame
that
Mr.
Slope
should
lose
his
chance
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
's
a
mean
chap
all
the
same
,
"
said
the
footman
,
"
and
it
an't
along
of
him
that
I
says
so
.
<EOS>
But
I
always
did
admire
the
missus
's
sister
;
and
she
'd
well
become
the
situation
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
While
these
were
the
ideas
downstairs
,
a
very
great
difference
of
opinion
existed
above
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
the
cloth
was
drawn
and
the
wine
on
the
table
,
Mr.
Harding
made
for
himself
an
opportunity
of
speaking
.
<EOS>
It
was
,
however
,
with
much
inward
troubling
that
he
said
:
  
"
It
's
very
kind
of
Lord
 
---
,
very
kind
,
and
I
feel
it
deeply
,
most
deeply
.
<EOS>
I
am
,
I
must
confess
,
gratified
by
the
offer
 
<EOS>
"
  
"
I
should
think
so
,
"
said
the
archdeacon
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
all
the
same
I
am
afraid
that
I
ca
n't
accept
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
decanter
almost
fell
from
the
archdeacon
's
hand
upon
the
table
,
and
the
start
he
made
was
so
great
as
to
make
his
wife
jump
up
from
her
chair
.
<EOS>
Not
accept
the
deanship
!
<EOS>
If
it
really
ended
in
this
,
there
would
be
no
longer
any
doubt
that
his
father
-
in
-
law
was
demented
.
<EOS>
The
question
now
was
whether
a
clergyman
with
low
rank
and

amounting
to
less
than
£
200
a
year
should
accept
high
rank
,
£
1,200
a
year
,
and
one
of
the
most
desirable
positions
which
his

had
to

!
  
<EOS>
"
What
!
"
said

archdeacon
,

for

and

as

the

of

had

.
<EOS>
"
What
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
find
myself
fit
for
new
duties
,
"
urged
Mr.
Harding
.
  
<EOS>
"
New
duties
!
<EOS>
What
duties
?
<EOS>
"
said
the
archdeacon
with

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Papa
,
"
said
Mrs.
Grantly
,
"
nothing

than
what
a

has

.
<EOS>
Surely

more

Trefoil
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
wo

<EOS>
as

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Did

"
The
Jupiter
"
said

about

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
and
I

that
"
The
Jupiter
"
said

Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
Perhaps

Slope

.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
made
no
reply
to

,
though
he
felt
it
strongly
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
come
over
to
Plumstead
to
have

with

son
-
in
-
law
about
Mr.
Slope
,
so
he
allowed

to
pass
by
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
I
can
not
make
you
understand
my
feeling
,
"
he
said
,
"
for
we
have
been
cast
in

.
<EOS>
I
may
wish
that
I
had
your
spirit
and
energy
and

;
but
I
have
not
.
<EOS>
Every
day
that
is
added
to

life
increases
my
wish
for
peace
and
rest
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
where
on
earth
can

rest
if

deanery
!
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
"
People
will

that
I
am

old
for

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Good
heavens
!
<EOS>
People
!
<EOS>
What
people
?
<EOS>
What
need
you
care
for
any
people
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
think
myself
I
am
too
old
for
any
new
place
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
Papa
,
"
said
Mrs.
Grantly
,
"
men
ten
years
older
than
you
are
appointed
to
new
situations
day
after

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
,
"
said
he
,
"
it
is
impossible
that
I
should
make
you
understand
my
feelings
,
nor
do
I
pretend

any
great

in

.
<EOS>
The
truth
is
,
I
want
the
force
of
character
which
might
enable
me
to
stand
against
the
spirit
of
the
times
.
<EOS>
The
call
on
all
sides
now
is
for
young
men
,
and
I
have
not
the
nerve
to
put
myself
in
opposition
to
the
demand
.
<EOS>
Were
"
The
Jupiter
,
"
<EOS>
when
it
hears
of
my
appointment
,
to
write
article
after
article
setting
forth
my

,
I
am
sure
it
would
cost
me
my
reason
.
<EOS>
I
ought
to
be
able
to
bear

such

,

will

.
<EOS>
Well
,
my

,
I
own

ought
.
<EOS>
But
I
feel
my
weakness
,
and
I
know
that
I
ca
n't
.
<EOS>
And
to
tell

,
I
know
no
more
than
a
child
what
the
dean
has
to
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Pshaw
!
"
exclaimed
the
archdeacon
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
be
angry
with
me
,
Archdeacon
<EOS>
:
do
n't
let
us
quarrel
about
it
,
Susan
.
<EOS>
If
you
knew
how
keenly
I
feel
the

of
having
to

you
in
this
matter
,
you
would
not
be
angry
with
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
This
was
a
dreadful
blow
to
Dr.
Grantly
.
<EOS>
Nothing
could
possibly
have
suited
him
better
than
having
Mr.
Harding
in
the
deanery
.
<EOS>
Though
he
had
never
looked
down
on
Mr.
Harding
on
account
of
his
recent
poverty
,
he
did
fully
recognize
the
satisfaction
of
having
those
belonging
to
him
in
comfortable
positions
.
<EOS>
It
would
be
much
more
suitable
that
Mr.
Harding
should
be
Dean
of
Barchester
than
vicar
of
St.
Cuthbert
's
and
precentor
to
boot
.
<EOS>
And
then
the
great
discomfiture
of
that
arch
-
enemy
of
all
that
was
respectable
in
Barchester
,
of
that
new
Low
Church
clerical
parvenu
that
had
fallen
amongst
them
,
that
alone
would
be
worth
more
,
almost
,
than
the
situation
itself
.
<EOS>
It
was
frightful
to
think
that
such
unhoped
-
for
good
fortune
should
be
marred
by
the
absurd
crotchets
and
unwholesome
hallucinations
by
which
Mr.
Harding
allowed
himself
to
be
led
astray
.
<EOS>
To
have
the
cup
so
near
his
lips
and
then
to
lose
the
drinking
of
it
was
more
than
Dr.
Grantly
could
endure
.
  
<EOS>
And
yet
it
appeared
as
though
he
would
have
to
endure
it
.
<EOS>
In
vain
he
threatened
and
in
vain
he
coaxed
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
did
not
indeed
speak
with
perfect
decision
of
refusing
the
proffered
glory
,
but
he
would
not
speak
with
anything
like
decision
of
accepting
it
.
<EOS>
When
pressed
again
and
again
,
he
would
again
and
again
allege
that
he
was
wholly
unfitted
to
new
duties
.
<EOS>
It
was
in
vain
that
the
archdeacon
tried
to
insinuate
,
though
he
could
not
plainly
declare
,
that
there
were
no
new
duties
to
perform
.
<EOS>
It
was
in
vain
he
hinted
that
in
all
cases
of
difficulty
he
,
he
the
archdeacon
,
was
willing
and
able
to
guide
a
weak
-
minded
dean
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
seemed
to
have
a
foolish
idea
,
not
only
that
there
were
new
duties
to
do
,
but
that
no
one
should
accept
the
place
who
was
not
himself
prepared
to
do
them
.
  
<EOS>
The
conference
ended
in
an
understanding
that
Mr.
Harding
should
at
once
acknowledge
the
letter
he
had
received
from
the
minister
's
private
secretary
,
and
should
beg
that
he
might
be
allowed
two
days
to
make
up
his
mind
;
and
that
during
those
two
days
the
matter
should
be
considered
.
  
<EOS>
On
the
following
morning
the
archdeacon
was
to
drive
Mr.
Harding
back
to
Barchester
.
   
<EOS>
Miss
Thorne
Shows
Her
Talent
at
Match
-
Making
 
<EOS>
On
Mr.
Harding
's
return
to
Barchester
from
Plumstead
,
which
was
effected
by
him
in
due
course
in
company
with
the
archdeacon
,
more
tidings
of
a
surprising
nature
met
him
.
<EOS>
He
was
,
during
the
journey
,
subjected
to
such
a
weight
of
unanswerable
argument
,
all
of
which
went
to
prove
that
it
was
his
bounden
duty
not
to
interfere
with
the
paternal
Government
that
was
so
anxious
to
make
him
a
dean
,
that
when
he
arrived
at
the
chemist
's
door
in
High
Street
,
he
hardly
knew
which
way
to
turn
himself
in
the
matter
.
<EOS>
But
,
perplexed
as
he
was
,
he
was
doomed
to
further
perplexity
.
<EOS>
He
found
a
note
there
from
his
daughter
begging
him
most
urgently
to
come
to
her
immediately
.
<EOS>
But
we
must
again
go
back
a
little
in
our
story
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Thorne
had
not
been
slow
to
hear
the
rumours
respecting
Mr.
Arabin
which
had
so
much
disturbed
the
happiness
of
Mrs.
Grantly
.
<EOS>
And
she
,
also
,
was
unhappy
to
think
that
her
parish
clergyman
should
be
accused
of
worshipping
a
strange
goddess
.
<EOS>
She
,
also
,
was
of
opinion
that
rectors
and
vicars
should
all
be
married
,
and
with
that
good
-
natured
energy
which
was
characteristic
of
her
,
she
put
her
wits
to
work
to
find
a
fitting
match
for
Mr.
Arabin
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Grantly
,
in
this
difficulty
,
could
think
of
no
better
remedy
than
a
lecture
from
the
archdeacon
.
<EOS>
Miss
Thorne
thought
that
a
young
lady
,
marriageable
and
with
a
dowry
,
might
be
of
more
efficacy
.
<EOS>
In
looking
through
the
catalogue
of
her
unmarried
friends
who
might
possibly
be
in
want
of
a
husband
,
and
might
also
be
fit
for
such
promotion
as
a
country
parsonage
affords
,
she
could
think
of
no
one
more
eligible
than
Mrs.
Bold
;
consequently
,
losing
no
time
,
she
went
into
Barchester
on
the
day
of
Mr.
Slope
's
discomfiture
,
the
same
day
that
her
brother
had
had
his
interesting
interview
with
the
last
of
the
Neros
,
and
invited
Mrs.
Bold
to
bring
her
nurse
and
baby
to
Ullathorne
and
make
them
a
protracted
visit
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Thorne
suggested
a
month
or
two
,
intending
to
use
her
influence
afterwards
in
prolonging
it
so
as
to
last
out
the
winter
,
in
order
that
Mr.
Arabin
might
have
an
opportunity
of
becoming
fairly
intimate
with
his
intended
bride
.
<EOS>
"
We
'll
have
Mr.
Arabin
,
too
,
"
said
Miss
Thorne
to
herself
;
"
and
before
the
spring
they
'll
know
each
other
;
and
in
twelve
or
eighteen
months
"
time
,
if
all
goes
well
,
Mrs.
Bold
will
be
domiciled
at
St.
Ewold
's
;
"
and
then
the
kind
-
hearted
lady
gave
herself
some
not
undeserved
praise
for
her
match
-
making
genius
.
  
<EOS>
Eleanor
was
taken
a
little
by
surprise
,
but
the
matter
ended
in
her
promising
to
go
to
Ullathorne
for
at
any
rate
a
week
or
two
;
on
the
day
previous
to
that
on
which
her
father
drove
out
to
Plumstead
,
she
had
had
herself
driven
out
to
Ullathorne
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Thorne
would
not
perplex
her
with
her
embryo
lord
on
that
same
evening
,
thinking
that
she
would
allow
her
a
few
hours
to
make
herself
at
home
;
but
on
the
following
morning
Mr.
Arabin
arrived
.
<EOS>
"
And
now
,
"
said
Miss
Thorne
to
herself
,
"
I
must
contrive
to
throw
them
in
each
other
's
way
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
That
same
day
,
after
dinner
,
Eleanor
,
with
an
assumed
air
of
dignity
which
she
could
not
maintain
,
with
tears
which
she
could
not
suppress
,
with
a
flutter
which
she
could
not
conquer
,
and
a
joy
which
she
could
not
hide
,
told
Miss
Thorne
that
she
was
engaged
to
marry
Mr.
Arabin
and
that
it
behoved
her
to
get
back
home
to
Barchester
as
quick
as
she
could
.
  
<EOS>
To
say
simply
that
Miss
Thorne
was
rejoiced
at
the
success
of
the
scheme
would
give
a
very
faint
idea
of
her
feelings
on
the
occasion
.
<EOS>
My
readers
may
probably
have
dreamt
before
now
that
they
have
had
before
them
some
terribly
long
walk
to
accomplish
,
some
journey
of
twenty
or
thirty
miles
,
an
amount
of
labour
frightful
to
anticipate
,
and
that
immediately
on
starting
they
have
ingeniously
found
some
accommodating
short
cut
which
has
brought
them
without
fatigue
to
their
work
's
end
in
five
minutes
.
<EOS>
Miss
Thorne
's
waking
feelings
were
somewhat
of
the
same
nature
.
<EOS>
My
readers
may
perhaps
have
had
to
do
with
children
,
and
may
on
some
occasion
have
promised
to
their
young
charges
some
great
gratification
intended
to
come
off
,
perhaps
at
the
end
of
the
winter
,
or
at
the
beginning
of
summer
.
<EOS>
The
impatient
juveniles
,
however
,
will
not
wait
,
and
clamorously
demand
their
treat
before
they
go
to
bed
.
<EOS>
Miss
Thorne
had
a
sort
of
feeling
that
her
children
were
equally
unreasonable
.
<EOS>
She
was
like
an
inexperienced
gunner
,
who
has
ill
-
calculated
the
length
of
the
train
that
he
has
laid
.
<EOS>
The
gun
-
powder
exploded
much
too
soon
,
and
poor
Miss
Thorne
felt
that
she
was
blown
up
by
the
strength
of
her
own
petard
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Thorne
had
had
lovers
of
her
own
,
but
they
had
been
gentlemen
of
old
-
fashioned
and
deliberate
habits
.
<EOS>
Miss
Thorne
's
heart
also
had
not
always
been
hard
,
though
she
was
still
a
virgin
spinster
;
but
it
had
never
yielded
in
this
way
at
the
first
assault
.
<EOS>
She
had
intended
to
bring
together
a
middle
-
aged
,
studious
clergyman
and
a
discreet
matron
who
might
possibly
be
induced
to
marry
again
,
and
in
doing
so
she
had
thrown
fire
among
tinder
.
<EOS>
Well
,
it
was
all
as
it
should
be
,
but
she
did
feel
perhaps
a
little
put
out
by
the
precipitancy
of
her
own
success
,
and
perhaps
a
little
vexed
at
the
readiness
of
Mrs.
Bold
to
be
wooed
.
  
<EOS>
She
said
,
however
,
nothing
about
it
to
anyone
,
and
ascribed
it
all
to
the
altered
manners
of
the
new
age
.
<EOS>
Their
mothers
and
grandmothers
were
perhaps
a
little
more
deliberate
,
but
it
was
admitted
on
all
sides
that
things
were
conducted
very
differently
now
than
in
former
times
.
<EOS>
For
aught
Miss
Thorne
knew
of
the
matter
,
a
couple
of
hours
might
be
quite
sufficient
under
the
new
régime
to
complete
that
for
which
she
in
her
ignorance
had
allotted
twelve
months
.
  
<EOS>
But
we
must
not
pass
over
the
wooing
so
cavalierly
.
<EOS>
It
has
been
told
,
with
perhaps
tedious
accuracy
,
how
Eleanor
disposed
of
two
of
her
lovers
at
Ullathorne
;
and
it
must
also
be
told
with
equal
accuracy
,
and
if
possible
with
less

,
how
she
encountered
Mr.
Arabin
.
  
<EOS>
It
can
not
be
denied
that
when
Eleanor
accepted
Miss
Thorne
's
invitation
she
remembered
that
Ullathorne
was
in
the
parish
of
St.
Ewold
's
.
<EOS>
Since
her

with
the
signora
she
had
done
little
else
than
think
about
Mr.
Arabin
and
the
appeal
that
had
been
made
to

.
<EOS>
She
could
not
bring
herself
to
believe
,
or
try
to
bring

to
believe
,
that
what
she
had
been
told
was
untrue
.
<EOS>
Think
of
it
how
she
would
,
she

not
but

that
Mr.
Arabin
was

of
her
;
and
then

,

also
that
she

.
<EOS>
If

were

to

,

Thorne
?
<EOS>
This

was
like
an

the

of

,
and

Mr.
Arabin

at

on

,
it

.
<EOS>
Well
,

not

?
<EOS>
In
that

of
Mr.
Slope
had
not

?
  
<EOS>
She
could
not
,
however
,
make
herself
easy
and
at
home
.
<EOS>
When
,
in
the

,

Arabin
's

,

that
any
little
rumour
which
might
be
ill
-
naturedly
spread
abroad
concerning
him
really
meant
nothing
,
Mrs.
Bold
found
herself
unable
to
answer
.
<EOS>
When

Thorne
went
a
little

and

that
she
did
not
know
a
prettier
vicarage
-
house
in
the
county
than
St.
Ewold
's
,
Mrs.
Bold
,
remembering
the
projected
bow
-

,
still
held
her

,
though
her
ears
tingled
with
the

that
all
the
world

Arabin
.
<EOS>
Well
,
what
would

matter
if
they
could
only
meet
and
tell

each
now
longed
to

?
  
<EOS>
And
they
did
meet
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
came
early
in
the
day
and
found
the
two
ladies
together
at
work
in
the
drawing
-
room
.
<EOS>
Miss
Thorne
,
who
,
had
she
known
all

truth
,
would
have
vanished
into
air
at
once
,
had
no

that
her

would
be
a

,
and
remained
chatting
with

till

-

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
could
talk
about
nothing
but
the
Signora
Neroni
's
beauty
,
would
discuss
no
people
but
the
Stanhopes
.
<EOS>
This
was
very
distressing
to
Eleanor
and
not

to
Miss
Thorne
.
<EOS>
But
yet
there
was
evidence
of
innocence
in
his
open
avowal
of

.
  
<EOS>
And
then
they
had
lunch
,
and
then
Mr.
Arabin
went
out
on

,
and
Eleanor
and
Miss
Thorne
were
left
to
take

.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
the
Signora
Neroni
is
so
lovely
as
people
say
?
"
<EOS>
Eleanor
asked
as
they
were

home
.
  
<EOS>
"
She
is
very
beautiful
,
certainly
,
very
beautiful
,
"
Miss
Thorne
answered
;
"
but
I
do
not
know
that
anyone
considers
her

.
<EOS>
She
is
a
woman
all
men
would
like
to
look

,
but
few
,
I

,
would

her
to

hearths
,
<EOS>
even

unmarried
and
not
afflicted
as
she
is
.
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
some
little
comfort
in
this
.
<EOS>
Eleanor
made
the
most
of
it
till
she
got
back
to
the
house
.
<EOS>
She
was
then
left
alone
in
the
drawing
-
room
,
and
just
as
it
was
getting
dark
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
came
in
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
beautiful
afternoon
in
the
beginning
of
October
,
and
Eleanor
was
sitting
in
the
window
to
get
the
advantage
of
the
last
daylight
for
her
novel
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
fire
in
the
comfortable
room
,
but
the
weather
was
not
cold
enough
to
make
it
attractive
;
and
as
she
could
see
the
sun
set
from
where
she
sat
,
she
was
not
very
attentive
to
her
book
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
,
when
he
entered
,
stood
awhile
with
his
back
to
the
fire
in
his
usual
way
,
merely
uttering
a
few
commonplace
remarks
about
the
beauty
of
the
weather
,
while
he
plucked
up
courage
for
more
interesting
converse
.
<EOS>
It
can
not
probably
be
said
that
he
had
resolved
then
and
there
to
make
an
offer
to
Eleanor
.
<EOS>
Men
,
we
believe
,
seldom
make
such
resolves
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
and
Mr.
Stanhope
had
done
so
,
it
is
true
,
but
gentlemen
generally
propose
without
any

as
to

doing

.
<EOS>
Such
was
now
the

with
Mr.
Arabin
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
lovely
sunset
,
"
said
Eleanor
,
answering
him
on
the
dreadfully
trite

which
he
had
chosen
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
could
not
see
the
sunset
from
the
hearth
-
rug
,
so
he
had
to
go
close
to
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
Very
lovely
,
"
said
he
,
standing
modestly
so
far
away
from
her
as
to
avoid
touching
the

of
her
dress
.
<EOS>
Then

that

had
nothing

;
so
,

for

at

of

,

to

.
  
<EOS>
Eleanor
found
that
it
was
quite
impossible
for
herself
to
commence
a
conversation
.
<EOS>
In
the
first
place
she
could
find
nothing
to
say
;
words
,
which
were
generally
plenty
enough
with
her
,
would
not
come
to
her
relief
.
<EOS>
And
moreover
,
do
what
she
would
,
she
could
hardly
prevent
herself
from
crying
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
like
Ullathorne
?
"
said
Mr.
Arabin
,
speaking
from
the
safely

position
which
he
had
assumed
on
the
hearth
-
rug
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
indeed
,
very
much
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
mean
Mr.
and
Miss
Thorne
 
<EOS>
I
know
you
like
them
 
<EOS>
but
the
style
of
the
house
.
<EOS>
There
is
something
about
old
-
fashioned
mansions
,
built
as
this
is
,
and
old
-
fashioned
gardens
,
that
to
me
is
especially
delightful
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
like
everything
old
-
fashioned
,
"
said
Eleanor
;
<EOS>
"
old
-
fashioned
things
are
so
much
the

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
about
that
,
"
said
Mr.
Arabin
,
gently
laughing
.
<EOS>
"
That
is
an
opinion
on
which
very
much
may
be
said
on
either
side
.
<EOS>
It
is
strange
how
widely
the
world
is
divided
on
a
subject
which
so
nearly
concerns
us
all
,
and
which
is
so
close
beneath
our
eyes
.
<EOS>
Some
think
that
we
are
quickly
progressing
towards
perfection
,
while
others
imagine
that
virtue
is
disappearing
from

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
,
Mr.
Arabin
,

?
"
said

.
<EOS>
She
felt
somewhat
surprised
at
the
tone
which
his
conversation
was
taking
,
and
yet
she
was
relieved
at
his
saying
something
which
enabled
herself
to

without

.
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
I
think
,
Mrs.
Bold
?
"
<EOS>
and
then
he
rumbled
his
money
with
his
hands
in
his
trousers
pockets
,
and
looked
and
spoke
very
little
like

.
<EOS>
"
It
is
the
bane
of
my
life
that
on
important

I
acquire
no
fixed

.
<EOS>
I
think
,
and
think
,
and
go
on
thinking
,
<EOS>
and
yet
my
thoughts
are
running
ever
in
different
directions
.
<EOS>
I
hardly
know
whether
or
no
we
do
lean
more
confidently
than
our
fathers
did
on
those
high
hopes
to
which
we
profess

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
the
world
grows
more
worldly
every
day
,
"
said
Eleanor
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
because
you
see
more
of
it
than
when
you

younger
.
<EOS>
But
we
should
hardly
judge

what

see
 
<EOS>
we
see
so
very
,

little
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
There

,

Mr.
Arabin
continued
to
turn

.
<EOS>
"
If

believe
in
Scripture
,

mankind

now

.
"
  
<EOS>
Eleanor
,
whose
mind
was
certainly
engaged
otherwise
than
on
the

state
of
mankind
,
made
no
answer
to
this
.
<EOS>
She
felt
thoroughly
dissatisfied
with

.
<EOS>
She
could
not

her

away
from
the
topic

which
the
signora
had
spoken

her
in
so

,
and

Arabin
in

tone
till

.
<EOS>
She
was
most

any

,
and
yet
she
felt
that
if

,
he

that
she
was
not
at

.
  
<EOS>
But
he
did
not
look
at

.
<EOS>
Instead

doing
so
,
he
left
the
fire
-

and
began

up
and
down

room
.
<EOS>
Eleanor
took
up
her
book
resolutely
,
but
she
could
not
read
,
for
there
was
a
tear
in
her
eye
,
and
do
what
she
would
,
it
fell
on

.
<EOS>
When
Mr.
Arabin
's

was
turned

her
,
she

away
;
but
another
was
soon
coursing
down
her
face
in

.
<EOS>
They
would
come
 
not
a
deluge
of
tears
that
would
have
betrayed
her
at
once
,
but
one
by
one
,
single
monitors
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
did
not
observe
her
closely
,
and
they
passed

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
,
thus
pacing
up
and
down
the
room
,
took
four
or
five

before
he
spoke
another

,
and
Eleanor
sat
equally

with
her
face

over

.
<EOS>
She
was
afraid
that
her
tears
would
get
the
better

her
,
and
was
preparing
for
an
escape
from
the

,
when
Mr.
Arabin
in

.
<EOS>
He
did
not
come
close
up
but
stood

the

which
his

brought

,
and
then
,
with

,
thus

.
  
<EOS>
"
Mrs.
Bold
,
"
said
he
,
"
I
owe
you
retribution
for
a
great

of
which
I
have
been
guilty
towards
you
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Eleanor
's
heart
beat
so
that
she
could
not
trust
herself
to
say
that
he
had
never
been
guilty
of
any
offence
.
<EOS>
So
Mr.
Arabin
thus
went
on
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
thought
much
of
it
since
,
and
I
am
now
aware
that
I
was
wholly

in

to
you
a
question

I
once

.
<EOS>
It

,
and

.
<EOS>
No

which
may

,

,

.
<EOS>
Nor

.
<EOS>
"
This
word
acquaintance
struck

's
heart
.
<EOS>
Was
this

her
doom

?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
I

,
and
I
now

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
What
was
Eleanor
to
say
to
him
?
<EOS>
She
could
not
say
much
because
she
was
crying
,
and
yet
she
must

something
.
<EOS>
She
was
most

that
something
graciously
,

,
and
yet

.
<EOS>
She

never

.
  
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,
I

,

Arabin
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,

!
<EOS>
And

,

.
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
I

,
but
I

.
"
  
<EOS>
She
was
now
past

,

still

to

;
and

,

,

the

.
<EOS>
She
felt
that

could
not

unanswered
without

all

;
so
,

,

said
,
"
Oh
,
Mr.
Arabin
,

!
<EOS>
I
do
forgive

.
<EOS>
You
know
that

.
"
  
<EOS>
He
took

that
had
so
gently

his
arm
and
then
gazed
into

as

would
peruse
there
,
as

,

;

found

.
<EOS>
She
could

,

her

as

would
,
and
leave
her

within

.
  
<EOS>
It
was
but
for
a
minute

,
but
the

was

.
<EOS>
Eleanor
was
sure
now
that
she
was

.
<EOS>
No

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
Why
did

so
into

?
<EOS>
Why

not

?
<EOS>
Could

?
  
<EOS>
And

,

.
<EOS>
He

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
He

to

.
<EOS>
Ah

<EOS>
Did

<EOS>
Nay

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mrs.
Bold
 
<EOS>
"

.
  
<EOS>
If

,

<EOS>
He

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Eleanor
!
"
<EOS>
he

,

She

<EOS>
There

<EOS>
"
Eleanor
!
"
<EOS>
he

,

<EOS>
How

.
<EOS>
There

.
<EOS>
They

one
flesh
 
<EOS>
one

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

own

,

"

.
  
<EOS>
She

,

,

<EOS>
She

"

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>

"
<EOS>

<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
Oh

<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
!
<EOS>
That
anyone

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
The

At

<EOS>
The
Beelzebub
Colt
 
<EOS>
When

.
<EOS>
Eleanor

but

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
Whereupon

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
Miss

,
"

,
"

:

.
"
  
<EOS>
Now

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
But

,

.
  
<EOS>
Eleanor

no

,
except

as

;

,

,
were

.
<EOS>
Miss

,
but
Mr.
Thorne
,
who

nothing
of

had
occurred
,
and
another

,

,

.
<EOS>
So

Eleanor
had
to

.
<EOS>
Her
state
,
nevertheless
,

not

.
  
<EOS>
The
next
morning
she
was
up
early
.
<EOS>
It
was
probable
,
she
thought
,
that
by
going
down
a

before
the
usual

she
might

Arabin
alone
in

-

.
<EOS>
Might

he

thus

?
<EOS>
Thus

,
Eleanor
was
dressed
a

the

fixed
in
the
Ullathorne

for

.
<EOS>
She
did
not

.
<EOS>
She
was
afraid
to
seem

too

to
meet

lover
,
though

her

was
intense
enough
.
<EOS>
She
therefore
sat

down
at
her
window
,
and
repeatedly
looking
at
her
watch
,
nursed
her
child
till
she
thought
she
might
venture
forth
.
  
<EOS>
When
she
found

at
the
dining
-
room
door
,
she
stood
a
moment
,
hesitating
to
turn

handle
;
but
when
she
heard

Thorne
's
voice
inside
she
hesitated
no
longer
.
<EOS>
Her
object
was
defeated
,
and
she
might
now
go
in
as
soon
as
she
liked
without
the
slightest
imputation
on
her

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Thorne
and
Mr.
Arabin
were
standing
on
the
hearth

rug
,
discussing

of
the
Beelzebub
colt
;
or
rather
,
Mr.
Thorne
was

,
and
Mr.

was

.
<EOS>
That
interesting
animal
had
rubbed

against

wall

and

.
<EOS>
Had

but

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.

,

,

.
<EOS>
The
Beelzebub
colt
must
do
without

.
<EOS>
And

,

,

.
<EOS>
As

shut
the
door
behind
him
<EOS>
Eleanor
almost
wished
that
he
had
remained
.
<EOS>
It

that

was

Mr.
Arabin
,

.
  
<EOS>
He
,

,
soon

.
<EOS>
He

,
"
So
,

,
you

.
<EOS>
Is

?
"
  
<EOS>
She

,
and
her

into
a
single

.
<EOS>
She

,
but
he
could

.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is

great

,
"

"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
 
it
is
,
"

,

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
And

,

and

,
well

with

.
<EOS>
They
neither
of
them
spoke
,
or
found

of

.
<EOS>
All
that
was
needful
for

to
say
had
been

.
<EOS>
The
yea
,
yea
,
had
been
spoken
by
Eleanor
in
her
own
way
 
and
that

had
been

Arabin
.
  
<EOS>
And
now
it
remained
to
them
each
to
enjoy
the
assurance
of
the
other
's
love
.
<EOS>
And
how
great
that
luxury
is
!
<EOS>
How
far
it
surpasses
any
other
pleasure
which
God
has
allowed
to
his
creatures
!
<EOS>
And
to
a
woman
's
heart
how
doubly
delightful
!
  
<EOS>
When
the
ivy
has
found
its
tower
,
when
the
delicate
creeper
has
found
its
strong
wall
,
we
know
how
the
parasite
plants
grow
and
prosper
.
<EOS>
They
were
not
created
to
stretch
forth
their
branches
alone
,
and
endure
without
protection
the
summer
's
sun
and
the
winter
's

.
<EOS>
Alone
<EOS>
they
but
spread
themselves
on
the
ground
and
cower
unseen
in
the
dingy

.
<EOS>
But
when
they
have
found
their
firm
supporters
,
how
wonderful
is
their
beauty
;
how
all
-

!
<EOS>
What
is
the
turret
without
its
ivy
,
or
the
high

without
the
jasmine
which
gives

its

and

?
<EOS>
The

without
the

is
but
a

.
  
<EOS>
There
is
a
feeling
still
half
-
existing
,
but
now
half
-
conquered
by
the
force
of
human
nature
,
that
a
woman
should
be
ashamed
of
her
love
till
the

's
right
to
her
compels

.
<EOS>
We
would
fain

a
different

.
<EOS>
A

should
glory
in
her

,
but
on
that

let
her
take
the
more
care
that
it
be
such
as
to

.
  
<EOS>
Eleanor
did
glory
in
hers
,
and
she
felt
,
and
had

to

,
that
it

held

.
<EOS>
She
could

,
had
fate
and

Thorne

.
<EOS>
Each

crept
nearer
to

and

more

more

that
there
was
her

.
<EOS>
What
now
to

the

's

,

?
<EOS>
What

?
<EOS>
She
had
found

strong

,

that

.
<EOS>
She

heavy

,
and

the

of

woman

.
  
<EOS>
And
he
,
too
,

there

.
<EOS>
They

looking

as

,

.

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
How

,

"
  
<EOS>

,
"

"
no
,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Her

,

.
<EOS>
The

demure

of

Arabin
,
and

.
  
<EOS>
Immediately

Thorne

.
  
<EOS>

;

<EOS>
As

.
  
<EOS>
How

<EOS>
Then

<EOS>

<EOS>

Mr.

!
"

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
oh
,

!

"

Fickle

<EOS>
By

<EOS>

The

<EOS>
The

had

.
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
These

,

,

.
<EOS>
The

,

.

,

_

.

,

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
The

,

<EOS>

.

.
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>

hostility
from
Dr.
Grantly
;
they
knew
his
anxiety
that
Mr.
Harding
should
return
to
his
old
home
at
the
hospital
,
and
they
did
not
know
that
a
new
home
had
been
offered
to
him
at
the
deanery
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Quiverful
was
therefore
not
a
little
surprised
,
and
not
a
little

also
,
at
the
tone
in
which

was

.
  
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
do
,
Mrs.
Quiverful
,
how
do
you
do
?
<EOS>
"
said
he
,
stretching
his
left
hand
out
of
the
gig
as
he
spoke
to
her
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
glad
to
see
you
employed
in
so
pleasant
and
useful

;
very

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Quiverful
thanked

,
and
shook
hands
with

,
and
looked
into
his
face
suspiciously
.
<EOS>
She
was
not
sure
whether
the
congratulations
and

were
or
were
not
ironical
.
  
<EOS>
"
Pray
tell
Mr.
Quiverful
from
me
,
"
he

,
"
that
I
am
rejoiced
at
his
appointment
.
<EOS>
It
's
a
comfortable
place
,
Mrs.
Quiverful
,
and
a
comfortable
house
,
and
I
am
very
glad
to
see
you
in
it
.
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
 
good
-
bye
.
<EOS>
"
And
he
drove
on
,
leaving
the
lady
well
pleased
and
astonished
at
his
good
nature
.
<EOS>
On
the
whole
things
were
going
well
with
the
archdeacon
,
and
he
could
afford
to
be
charitable
to
Mrs.
Quiverful
.
<EOS>
He
looked
forth
from
his
gig
smilingly
on
all
the
world
,
and
forgave
everyone
in
Barchester
their
sins
,
excepting
only
Mrs.
Proudie
and
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
Had
he
seen
the
bishop
,
he
would
have
felt
inclined
to
pat
even
him
kindly
on
the
head
.
  
<EOS>
He
determined
to
go
home
by
St.
Ewold
's
.
<EOS>
This
would
take
him
some
three
miles
out
of
his
way
,
but
he
felt
that
he
could
not
leave
Plumstead
comfortably
without
saying
one
word
of
good
-
fellowship
to
Mr.
Arabin
.
<EOS>
When

the
parsonage
,
the

was
still
out
,
but
from
what

had
heard
,
he
did
not

but
that
he
would
meet

on

.
<EOS>
He
was
right
in
this
,
for
about

home
,

a

,

Arabin
,
who

.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
,
well
,
well
,
"
said

archdeacon

,

,

;
"
well
,
well
,
well
,
well
;
so
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

Grantly
that

to

Harding
,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Slope
has
lost

deanery
I

,
"
and

.
<EOS>
"
Come
,

,
Arabin
,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
Archdeacon
,
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
None

all
 
not

a

.
<EOS>
It

that
I
knew

,

<EOS>

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
With

,

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
It
's

I

.
<EOS>
She

;

;

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
And

's

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
warmly

's

,
but
he
said

.
<EOS>
His

was
too
full
for

,
and

.
<EOS>
Dr.
Grantly

.
  
<EOS>
"
And

,

"

.
<EOS>
We

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Harding

.
<EOS>
But

dress

.
"
<EOS>
And

.
  
<EOS>
On

the
archdeacon
occupied

with

for

.
<EOS>
He

that

atone

injury

done

by

.
<EOS>
He
would
show

what
was
the
difference

between

.
<EOS>
On

:

's

.
  
<EOS>
"
So

're
sold
after

,
Sue
,
"

to

,

.
<EOS>
He
did
not
call
his
wife
Sue
above
twice
or

in

,
and
these

were
great
high
days
.
  
<EOS>
"
Eleanor
has
had
more

than

gave

,
"
said
Mrs.
Grantly
.
  
<EOS>
And
there

great

in
Plumstead
Rectory
that

.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Grantly
promised
her

that
she
would
now
open

heart
and
take

Arabin
into

.
<EOS>
Hitherto

had

to
do

.
   
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
Bids
Farewell
to
the
Palace
and
Its
Inhabitants
 
<EOS>
We
must
now
take
leave
of
Mr.
Slope
,
and
of
the
bishop
also
,
and
of
Mrs.
Proudie
.
<EOS>
These
leave
-
takings
in
novels
are
as
disagreeable
as
they
are
in
real
life
;
not
so
sad
,
indeed
,
for
they
want
the
reality
of
sadness
;
but
quite
as
perplexing
,
and
generally
less
satisfactory
.
<EOS>
What
novelist
,
what
Fielding
,
what
Scott
,
what
George
Sand
,
or
Sue
,
or
Dumas
,
can
impart
an
interest
to
the
last
chapter
of
his
fictitious
history
?
<EOS>
Promises
of
two
children
and
superhuman
happiness
are
of
no
avail
,
nor
assurance
of
extreme
respectability
carried
to
an
age
far
exceeding
that
usually
allotted
to
mortals
.
<EOS>
The
sorrows
of
our
heroes
and
heroines
<EOS>
,
they
are
your
delight
,
oh
public
!
 
<EOS>
their
sorrows
,
or
their
sins
,
or
their
absurdities
;
not
their
virtues
,
good
sense
,
and
consequent
rewards
.
<EOS>
When
we
begin
to
tint
our
final
pages
with
_
couleur
de
rose
_
,
as
in
accordance
with
fixed
rule
we
must
do
,
we
altogether
extinguish
our
own
powers
of
pleasing
.
<EOS>
When
we
become
dull
,
we
offend
your
intellect
;
and
we
must
become
dull
or
we
should
offend
your
taste
.
<EOS>
A
late
writer
,
wishing
to
sustain
his
interest
to
the
last
page
,
hung
his
hero
at
the
end
of
the
third
volume
.
<EOS>
The
consequence
was
that
no
one
would
read
his
novel
.
<EOS>
And
who
can
apportion
out
and
dovetail
his
incidents
,
dialogues
,
characters
,
and
descriptive
morsels
so
as
to
fit
them
all
exactly
into
930
pages
,
without
either
compressing
them
unnaturally
,
or
extending
them
artificially
at
the
end
of
his
labour
?
<EOS>
Do
I
not
myself
know
that
I
am
at
this
moment
in
want
of
a
dozen
pages
,
and
that
I
am
sick
with
cudgelling
my
brains
to
find
them
?
<EOS>
And
then
,
when
everything
is
done
,
the
kindest
-
hearted
critic
of
them
all
invariably
twits
us
with
the
incompetency
and
lameness
of
our
conclusion
.
<EOS>
We
have
either
become
idle
and
neglected
it
,
or
tedious
and
overlaboured
it
.
<EOS>
It
is
insipid
or
unnatural
,
overstrained
or
imbecile
.
<EOS>
It
means
nothing
,
or
attempts
too
much
.
<EOS>
The
last
scene
of
all
,
as
all
last
scenes
we
fear
must
be
,
  
Is
second
childishness
,
and
mere
oblivion
,
Sans
teeth
,
sans
eyes
,
sans
taste
,
sans
everything
.
  
<EOS>
I
can
only
say
that
if
some
critic
who
thoroughly
knows
his
work
,
and
has
laboured
on
it
till
experience
has
made
him
perfect
,
will
write
the
last
fifty
pages
of
a
novel
in
the
way
they
should
be
written
,
<EOS>
I
,
for
one
,
will
in
future
do
my
best
to
copy
the
example
.
<EOS>
Guided
by
my
own
lights
only
,
I
confess
that
I
despair
of
success
.
  
<EOS>
For
the
last
week
or
ten
days
Mr.
Slope
had
seen
nothing
of
Mrs.
Proudie
,
and
very
little
of
the
bishop
.
<EOS>
He
still
lived
in
the
palace
,
and
still
went
through
his
usual
routine
work
;
but
the
confidential
doings
of
the
diocese
had
passed
into
other
hands
.
<EOS>
He
had
seen
this
clearly
and
marked
it
well
,
but
it
had
not
much
disturbed
him
.
<EOS>
He
had
indulged
in
other
hopes
till
the
bishop
's
affairs
had
become
dull
to
him
,
and
he
was
moreover
aware
that
,
as
regarded
the
diocese
,
Mrs.
Proudie
had
checkmated
him
.
<EOS>
It
has
been

,
in
the

these
pages
,
how
three

four
were

,

.
<EOS>
Each

had
now

(
or

)
that
Mrs.
Proudie
was
victorious
in

.
<EOS>
They
had
gone
through
a
competitive
examination
of
considerable
severity
,
and
she
had
come
forth
the
winner
,
_
facile
<EOS>
princeps
_
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
had
for
a
moment
run
her
hard
,
but
it
was
only

a
moment
.
<EOS>
It
had
become
,
as
it
were
,
acknowledged
that
Hiram
's
Hospital
should
be
the
testing
-

between

,
and
now

Quiverful
was
already
in
the
hospital
,
the
proof
of
Mrs.
Proudie
's
skill
and

.
  
<EOS>
All

did
not
break
down
Mr.
Slope
's
spirit
,
because
he
had
other
hopes
.
<EOS>
But
,
alas
,
at
last
there
came
to
him
a
note
from
his
friend
Sir
Nicholas
,
informing
him
that
the
deanship
was
disposed

.
<EOS>
Let
us
give
Mr.
Slope
his
due
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
lie
prostrate
under
this
blow
,
or
give
himself
up
to
vain

;
he
did
not
henceforward
despair
of
life
and
call
upon
gods
above
and
gods

to
carry

off
.
<EOS>
He
sat
himself
down
in
his

,
counted

what

had

for

and
what
others
were
coming
in
to

,
bethought

as
to
the
best
sphere
for
his
future

,
and
at
once
wrote
off
a
letter
to
a
rich
sugar
-
refiner
's
wife
in
Baker
Street
,
who
,
as
he
well
knew
,
was
much

to
the

and
encouragement
of
serious
young

.
<EOS>
He
was
again
,
he
said
,
"
upon
the
world
,
having
found
the
air
of
a
cathedral
town
,
and
the
very
nature
of
cathedral

,
uncongenial
to
his
spirit
;
"
and
then
he
sat

,
making
firm

as
to

of
parting
from
the
bishop
,
and
also

to

future

.
  
<EOS>
At
last
he
rose
,
and
twitched
his
mantle
blue
(
black
)
,
To
-
morrow
to
fresh
woods
and
pastures
new
.
  
<EOS>
Having
received
a
formal
command
to
wait
upon
the
bishop
,
he
rose
and
proceeded
to

.
<EOS>
He
rang

bell
and

to

,
if

lordship
,
he
,

Slope
,

.
<EOS>
The

,
who
well

that

Slope

,

that
"
his

.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope

to

,
and
then

went
into

bishop
's

.
<EOS>
There
,

,

Proudie
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Hum
,
ha
 
Mr.
Slope
,
pray

a

,
"
said

bishop
.
  
<EOS>
"
Pray

,
Mr.
Slope
,
"
said

bishop
.
  
<EOS>
"
Thank
ye
,
thank
ye
,
"
said
Mr.
Slope
,
and
walking
round
to
the
fire
,
he
threw
himself
into
one
of
the
armchairs
that
graced
the
hearth
-
rug
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Slope
,
"
said
the
bishop
,
"
it
has
become
necessary
that
I
should
speak
to
you
definitively
on
a
matter
that
has
for
some
time
been
pressing
itself
on
my
attention
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
May
I
ask
whether
the
subject
is
in
any
way
connected
with
myself
?
"
said
Mr.
Slope
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
<EOS>
so
 
certainly
 
yes
,
it
certainly
is
connected
with
yourself
,

Slope
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"

,
"

,
"
no

.
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
merely

,
Mr.
Slope
,
to
express
my
own
wishes
 
<EOS>
no

will
be

all

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
That

,

,

"

;
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

It

's

,

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Slope

"

,
"
it

.
<EOS>
It

to

but

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,

,

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
What

amiss
,
Mr.
Slope
?
"
said
Mrs.
Proudie
,
standing
erect

the

and

.
<EOS>
"
Do
you
dare
to

bishop
what

?
<EOS>
Does
not
your
conscience
 
"
  
"

,

,

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,

,

,
"

;
"

.
<EOS>

?
<EOS>

,
you

,

,

as
that
 
with

woman
 
with

's

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
At
any
rate
I

in

-

,
"
retorted
