Slope
.
  
<EOS>
"
And

,
"

Proudie
;
"
most

.
<EOS>
I
was

to

house
a

what

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
!
"

.
<EOS>
"
I

not

who

!
<EOS>
I

!
<EOS>
I

!
<EOS>
I
will

,
Mr.
Slope
,
whether

.
<EOS>
You

no

bishop
,

,

.

<EOS>

,
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

,

"

.
<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

Mrs.
Proudie
<EOS>

.

"

"

;
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,

!
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Thus
ended
the
intimacy
of
the
Bishop
of
Barchester
with
his
first
confidential
chaplain
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Proudie
was
right
in
this
;
namely
,
that
Mr.
Slope
was
not
insane
enough
to
publish
to
the
world
any
of
his
doings
in
Barchester
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
trouble
his
friend
Mr.
Towers
with
any
written
statement
of
the
iniquity
of
Mrs.
Proudie
,
or
the
imbecility
of
her
husband
.
<EOS>
He
was
aware
that
it
would
be
wise
in
him
to
drop
for
the
future
all
allusion
to
his
doings
in
the
cathedral
city
.
<EOS>
Soon
after
the
interview
just
recorded
he
left
Barchester
,
shaking
the
dust
off
his
feet
as
he
entered
the
railway
carriage
;
and
he
gave
no
longing
,
lingering
look
after
the
cathedral
towers
as
the
train
hurried
him
quickly
out
of
their
sight
.
  
<EOS>
It
is
well
known
that
the
family
of
the
Slopes
never
starve
:
they
always
fall
on
their
feet
,
like
cats
;
and
let
them
fall
where
they
will
,
they
live
on
the
fat
of
the
land
.
<EOS>
Our
Mr.
Slope
did
so
.
<EOS>
On
his
return
to
town
he
found
that
the
sugar
-
refiner
had
died
and
that
his
widow
was
inconsolable
 
in
other
words
,
in
want
of
consolation
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
consoled
her
,
and
soon
found
himself
settled
with
much
comfort
in
the
house
in
Baker
Street
.
<EOS>
He
possessed
himself
,
also
,
before
long
,
of
a
church
in
the
vicinity
of
the
Red
Road
,
and
became
known
to
fame
as
one
of
the
most
eloquent
preachers
and
pious
clergymen
in
that
part
of
the
metropolis
.
<EOS>
There
let
us
leave
him
.
  
<EOS>
Of
the
bishop
and
his
wife
very
little
further
need
be
said
.
<EOS>
From
that
time
forth
nothing
material
occurred
to
interrupt
the
even
course
of
their
domestic
harmony
.
<EOS>
Very
speedily
,
a
further
vacancy
on
the
bench
of
bishops
gave
to
Dr.
Proudie
the
seat
in
the
House
of
Lords
,
which
he
at
first
so
anxiously
longed
for
.
<EOS>
But
by
this
time
he
had
become
a
wiser
man
.
<EOS>
He
did
certainly
take
his
seat
,
and
occasionally
registered
a
vote
in
favour
of
Government
views
on
ecclesiastical
matters
.
<EOS>
But
he
had
thoroughly
learnt
that
his
proper
sphere
of
action
lay
in
close
contiguity
with
Mrs.
Proudie
's
wardrobe
.
<EOS>
He
never
again
aspired
to
disobey
,
or
seemed
even
to
wish
for
autocratic
diocesan
authority
.
<EOS>
If
ever
he
thought
of
freedom
,
he
did
so
as
men
think
of
the
millennium
,
as
of
a
good
time
which
may
be
coming
,
but
which
nobody
expects
to
come
in
their
day
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Proudie
might
be
said
still
to
bloom
,
and
was
,
at
any
rate
,
strong
,
and
the
bishop
had
no
reason
to
apprehend
that
he
would
be
speedily
visited
with
the
sorrows
of
a
widower
's
life
.
  
<EOS>
He
is
still
Bishop
of
Barchester
.
<EOS>
He
has
so
graced
that
throne
that
the
Government
has
been
averse
to
translate
him
,
even
to
higher
dignities
.
<EOS>
There
may
he
remain
,
under
safe
pupilage
,
till
the
newfangled
manners
of
the
age
have
discovered
him
to
be
superannuated
and
bestowed
on
him
a
pension
.
<EOS>
As
for
Mrs.
Proudie
,
our
prayers
for
her
are
that
she
may
live
forever
.
   
<EOS>
The
New
Dean
Takes
Possession
of
the
Deanery
,
and
the
New
Warden
of
the
Hospital
 
Mr.
Harding
and
the
archdeacon
together
made
their
way
to
Oxford
,
and
there
,
by
dint
of
cunning
argument
,
they
induced
the
Master
of
Lazarus
also
to
ask
himself
this
momentous
question
:
"
Why
should
not
Mr.
Arabin
be
Dean
of
Barchester
?
<EOS>
"
He
,
of
course
,
for
awhile
tried
his
hand
at
persuading
Mr.
Harding
that
he
was
foolish
,
overscrupulous
,
self
-
willed
,
and
weak
-
minded
;
but
he
tried
in
vain
.
<EOS>
If
Mr.
Harding
would
not
give
way
to
Dr.
Grantly
,
it
was
not
likely
that
he
would
give
way
to
Dr.
Gwynne
,
more
especially
now
that
so
admirable
a
scheme
as
that
of
inducting
Mr.
Arabin
into
the
deanery
had
been
set
on
foot
.
<EOS>
When
the
master
found
that
his
eloquence
was
vain
,
and
heard
also
that
Mr.
Arabin
was
about
to
become
Mr.
Harding
's
son
-
in
-
law
,
he
confessed
that
he
also
would
,
under
such
circumstances
,
be
glad
to
see
his
old
friend
and
protégé
,
the
fellow
of
his
college
,
placed
in
the
comfortable
position
that
was
going
a
-
begging
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
might
be
the
means
you
know
,
Master
,
of
keeping
Mr.
Slope
out
,
"
said
the
archdeacon
with
grave
caution
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
has
no
more
chance
of
it
,
"
said
the
master
,
"
than
our
college
chaplain
.
<EOS>
I
know
more
about
it
than
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Grantly
had
been
right
in
her
surmise
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
Master
of
Lazarus
who
had
been
instrumental
in
representing
in
high
places
the
claims
which
Mr.
Harding
had
upon
the
Government
,
and
he
now
consented
to
use
his
best
endeavours
towards
getting
the
offer
transferred
to
Mr.
Arabin
.
<EOS>
The
three
of
them
went
on
to
London
together
,
and
there
they
remained
a
week
,
to
the
great
disgust
of
Mrs.
Grantly
,
and
most
probably
also
of
Mrs.
Gwynne
.
<EOS>
The
minister
was
out
of
town
in
one
direction
,
and
his
private
secretary
in
another
.
<EOS>
The
clerks
who
remained
could
do
nothing
in
such
a
matter
as
this
,
and
all
was
difficulty
and
confusion
.
<EOS>
The
two
doctors
seemed
to
have
plenty
to
do
;
they
bustled
here
<EOS>
and
they
bustled
there
,
and
complained
at
their
club
in
the
evenings
that
they
had
been
driven
off
their
legs
;
but
Mr.
Harding
had
no
occupation
.
<EOS>
Once
or
twice
he
suggested
that
he
might
perhaps
return
to
Barchester
.
<EOS>
His
request
,
however
,
was
peremptorily
refused
,
and
he
had
nothing
for
it
but
to
while
away
his
time
in
Westminster
Abbey
.
  
<EOS>
At
length
an
answer
from
the
great
man
came
.
<EOS>
The
Master
of
Lazarus
had
made
his
proposition
through
the
Bishop
of
Belgravia
.
<EOS>
Now
this
bishop
,
though
but
newly
gifted
with
his
diocesan
honours
,
was
a
man
of
much
weight
in
the
clerico
-
political
world
.
<EOS>
He
was
,
if
not
as
pious
,
at
any
rate
as
wise
as
St.
Paul
,
and
had
been
with
so
much
effect
all
things
to
all
men
that
,
though
he
was
great
among
the
dons
of
Oxford
,
he
had
been
selected
for
the
most
favourite
seat
on
the
bench
by
a
Whig
prime
minister
.
<EOS>
To
him
Dr.
Gwynne
had
made
known
his
wishes
and
his
arguments
,
and
the
bishop
had
made
them
known
to
the
Marquis
of
Kensington
-
Gore
.
<EOS>
The
marquis
,
who
was
Lord
High
Steward
of
the
Pantry
Board
,
and
who
by
most
men
was
supposed
to
hold
the
highest
office
out
of
the
cabinet
,
trafficked
much
in
affairs
of
this
kind
.
<EOS>
He
not
only
suggested
the
arrangement
to
the
minister
over
a
cup
of
coffee
,
standing
on
a
drawing
-
room
rug
in
Windsor
Castle
,
but
he
also
favourably
mentioned
Mr.
Arabin
's
name
in
the
ear
of
a
distinguished
person
.
  
<EOS>
And
so
the
matter
was
arranged
.
<EOS>
The
answer
of
the
great
man
came
,
and
Mr.
Arabin
was
made
Dean
of
Barchester
.
<EOS>
The
three
clergymen
who
had
come
up
to
town
on
this
important
mission
dined
together
with
great
glee
on
the
day
on
which
the
news
reached
them
.
<EOS>
In
a
silent
,
decent
,
clerical
manner
they
toasted
Mr.
Arabin
with
full
bumpers
of
claret
.
<EOS>
The
satisfaction
of
all
of
them
was
supreme
.
<EOS>
The
Master
of
Lazarus
had
been
successful
in
his
attempt
,
and
success
is
dear
to
us
all
.
<EOS>
The
archdeacon
had
trampled
upon
Mr.
Slope
,
and
had
lifted
to
high
honours
the
young
clergyman
whom
he
had
induced
to
quit
the
retirement
and
comfort
of
the
university
.
<EOS>
So
at
least
the
archdeacon
thought
;
though
,
to
speak
sooth
,
not
he
,
but
circumstances
,
had
trampled
on
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
But
the
satisfaction
of
Mr.
Harding
was
,
of
all
,
perhaps
,
the
most
complete
.
<EOS>
He
laid
aside
his
usual
melancholy
manner
and
brought
forth
little
quiet
jokes
from
the
inmost
mirth
of
his
heart
;
he
poked
his
fun
at
the
archdeacon
about
Mr.
Slope
's
marriage
and
quizzed
him
for
his
improper
love
for
Mrs.
Proudie
.
<EOS>
On
the
following
day
they
all
returned
to
Barchester
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
arranged
that
Mr.
Arabin
should
know
nothing
of
what
had
been
done
till
he
received
the
minister
's
letter
from
the
hands
of
his
embryo
father
-
in
-
law
.
<EOS>
In
order
that
no
time
might
be
lost
,
a
message
had
been
sent
to
him
by
the
preceding
night
's
post
,
begging
him
to
be
at
the
deanery
at
the
hour
that
the
train
from
London
arrived
.
<EOS>
There
was
nothing
in
this
which
surprised
Mr.
Arabin
.
<EOS>
It
had
somehow
got
about
through
all
Barchester
that
Mr.
Harding
was
the
new
dean
,
and
all
Barchester
was
prepared
to
welcome
him
with
pealing
bells
and
full
hearts
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
had
certainly
had
a
party
;
there
had
certainly
been
those
in
Barchester
who
were
prepared
to
congratulate
him
on
his
promotion
with
assumed
sincerity
,
but
even
his
own
party
was
not
broken
-
hearted
by
his
failure
.
<EOS>
The
inhabitants
of
the
city
,
even
the
high
-
souled
,
ecstatic
young
ladies
of
thirty
-
five
,
had
begun
to
comprehend
that
their
welfare
,
and
the
welfare
of
the
place
,
was
connected
in
some
mysterious

with
daily

and
bi
-
weekly

.
<EOS>
The
expenditure
of
the
palace
had
not
added
much
to
the
popularity
of
the
bishop
's
side
of
the
question
;
and
,
on
the
whole
,
there
was
a
strong
reaction
.
<EOS>
When
it
became
known
to
all
the
world
that
Mr.
Harding
was
to
be
the
new
dean
,
all
the
world
rejoiced

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
,
we
have
said
,
was
not
surprised
at
the
summons
which
called
him
to
the
deanery
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
as
yet
seen
Mr.
Harding
since
Eleanor
had
accepted

,
nor
had
he
seen
him
since
he
had
learnt
his
future
father
-
in
-
law
's
preferment
.
<EOS>
There
was
nothing
more
natural
,
more

,
than
that

should
meet
each

the
earliest

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
was
waiting
in
the
deanery
parlour
when
Mr.
Harding
and
Dr.
Grantly
were

.
  
<EOS>
There
was
some

in

bosoms
of
them
all
,

met
and

hands
;
by
far
too
much
to
enable

them
to
begin

and
tell

in
a
proper
equable
style

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
was
some
minutes
quite
dumbfounded
,
and
Mr.
Arabin
could
only
talk
in
short
,
spasmodic

about
his
love

.
<EOS>
He
slipped
in
,
as

,
some
sort

congratulation
about
the
deanship
,
and
then
went
on
with
his
hopes
and
fears
 
hopes
that
he
might
be
received
as
a
son
,
and
fears
that
he
hardly
deserved
such
good

.
<EOS>
Then
he
went
back
to
the
dean
;
it
was
the
most
thoroughly
satisfactory
appointment
,
he
said
,
of

had
ever

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
!
<EOS>
But
!
<EOS>
But
 
"
said
Mr.
Harding
,
and
then
,
failing
to
get
any

,
he
looked

.
  
<EOS>
"
The
truth

,
Arabin
,
"

,
"
that
,

all

are
not

to

son
-
in
-
law
to
a
dean
.
<EOS>
Nor
am
I
either
:
more
's
the
pity
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
looked
at
him
for
explanation
.
<EOS>
"
Is
not
Mr.
Harding
to
be
the
new
dean
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
appears
not
,
"
said
the
archdeacon
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
's
face
fell
a
little
,
and
he
looked
from
one
to
the
other
.
<EOS>
It
was
plainly
to
be
seen
from
them
both
that
there
was
no
cause
of
unhappiness
in
the
matter
,
at
least

of

to

;
but

was
as
yet

of

.
  
<EOS>
"
Think
how
old
I
am
,
"
said
Mr.
Harding
imploringly
.
  
<EOS>
"
Fiddlestick
!
"
said
the
archdeacon
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
all
very
well
,
but
it
wo
n't
make
a
young
man

me
,
"

Harding
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
who
is

?
"

Mr.
Arabin
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
that
's

,
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
Come
,
Mr.
Precentor
,

,

is

man
.
<EOS>
He
has
got
the
nomination
in

.
"
  
<EOS>
With
eyes
brim
full
of

,
Mr.
Harding
pulled

letter
and
handed
it
to
his
future
son
-
in
-
law
.
<EOS>
He
tried
to
make
a
little
speech
but
failed
altogether
.
<EOS>
Having
given
up
the
document
,
he
turned
round
to
the
wall
,
feigning
to
blow
his
nose
,
and
then
sat
himself
down
on
the
old
dean
's
dingy
horsehair
sofa
.
<EOS>
And
here
we
find
it
necessary
to
bring
our
account
of
the
interview
to
an
end
.
  
<EOS>
Nor
can
we
pretend
to
describe
the

with
which
Mr.
Harding
was
received
by
his
daughter
.
<EOS>
She
wept
with
grief
and
wept
with
joy
 
with
grief
that
her
father
should
,
in
his
old
age
,
still
be
without
that
rank
and
worldly
position
which
,
according

her

,
he
had
so
well
earned
;
and
with
joy
in
that
he
,
her
darling
father
,
should
have
bestowed
on
that
other
dear
one
the
good
things
of
which
he
himself
would
not
open
his
hand
to
take
possession
.
<EOS>
And
here
Mr.
Harding
again
showed
his
weakness
.
<EOS>
In
the
_
mêlée
_
of
this
exposal
of
their
loves
and
reciprocal

,
he
found
himself
unable
to
resist
the
entreaties
of
all
parties
that
the
lodgings
in
the
High
Street
should
be
given
up
.
<EOS>
Eleanor
would
not
live
in
the
deanery
,
she
said
,
unless
her
father
lived
there
also
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
would
not
be
dean
,
unless
Mr.
Harding
would
be
co
-
dean
with
him
.
<EOS>
The
archdeacon
declared
that
his
father
-
in
-
law
should
not
have
his
own
way
in
everything
,
and
Mrs.
Grantly
carried
him
off
to
Plumstead
,
that
he
might
remain
there
till
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Arabin
were
in
a
state
to
receive
him
in
their
own
mansion
.
  
<EOS>
Pressed
by
such
arguments
as
these
,
what
could
a
weak
old
man
do
but
yield
?
  
<EOS>
But
there
was
yet
another
task
which
it
behoved
Mr.
Harding
to
do
before
he
could
allow
himself
to
be
at
rest
.
<EOS>
Little
has
been
said
in
these
pages
of
the
state
of
those
remaining
old
men
who
had
lived
under
his
sway
at
the
hospital
.
<EOS>
But
not
on
this
account
must
it
be
presumed
that
he
had
forgotten
them
,
or
that
in
their
state
of
anarchy
and
in
their
want
of
due
government
he
had
omitted
to
visit
them
.
<EOS>
He
visited
them
constantly
,
and
had
latterly
given
them
to
understand
that
they
would
soon
be
required
to
subscribe
their
adherence
to
a
new
master
.
<EOS>
There
were
now
but
five
of
them
,
one
of
them
having
been
but
quite
lately
carried
to
his
rest
 
but
five
of
the
full
number
,
which
had
hitherto
been
twelve
,
and
which
was
now
to
be
raised
to
twenty
-
four
,
including
women
.
<EOS>
Of
these
,
old
Bunce
,
who
for
many
years
had
been
the
favourite
of
the
late
warden
,
was
one
;
and
Abel
Handy
,
who
had
been
the
humble
means
of
driving
that
warden
from
his
home
,
was
another
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
now
resolved
that
he
himself
would
introduce
the
new
warden
to
the
hospital
.
<EOS>
He
felt
that
many
circumstances
might
conspire
to
make
the
men
receive
Mr.
Quiverful
with
aversion
and

;
he
felt
also
that
Mr.
Quiverful
might
himself

some

if
he
entered

hospital
with
an
idea
that
he
did
so
in

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
therefore
determined
to
walk
in
,
arm
in
arm
with
Mr.
Quiverful
,
and
to
ask
from
these
men
their
respectful

to
their
new
master
.
  
<EOS>
On
returning
to
Barchester
,
he
found
that
Mr.
Quiverful
had
not
yet
slept
in
the
hospital
house
,
or
entered
on

new

.
<EOS>
He
accordingly
made
known
to
that
gentleman
his
wishes
,
and
his
proposition
was
not
rejected
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
bright
,
clear
morning
,
though
in
November
,
that
Mr.
Harding
and
Mr.
Quiverful
,
arm
in

,
walked
through
the
hospital
gate
.
<EOS>
It
was
one
trait
in
our
old
friend
's
character
that
he
did
nothing
with
parade
.
<EOS>
He
omitted
,
even
in
the
more
important
doings
of
his
life
,
that
sort
of
parade
by
which
most
of
us
deem
it
necessary
to
grace
our
important
doings
.
<EOS>
We
have
house
-
warmings
,
christenings
,
and
gala
days
;
we
keep
,
if
not
our
own
birthdays
,
those
of
our
children
;
we
are
apt
to
fuss
ourselves
if
called
upon
to
change
our
residences
and
have
,
almost
all
of
us
,
our
little
state
occasions
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
had
no
state
occasions
.
<EOS>
When
he
left
his
old
house
,
he
went
forth
from
it
with
the
same
quiet
composure
as
though
he
were
merely

his
daily

;
now
that
he
re
-
entered
it
with
another
warden
under
his
wing
,
he
did
so
with
the
same
quiet
step
and
calm
demeanour
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
little
less
upright
than
he
had
been
five
years
<EOS>
,
nay
,
it
was
now
nearly
six
years
ago
;
he
walked
perhaps
a
little
slower
;
his
footfall
was
perhaps
a
thought
less
firm
;
otherwise
one
might
have
said
that
he
was
merely
returning
with
a
friend
under
his
arm
.
  
<EOS>
This
friendliness
was
everything
to
Mr.
Quiverful
.
<EOS>
To
him
,
even
in
his
poverty
,
the
thought
that
he
was
supplanting
a
brother
clergyman
so
kind
and
courteous
as
Mr.
Harding
had
been
very
bitter
.
<EOS>
Under
his
circumstances
it
had
been
impossible
for
him
to
refuse
the
proffered
boon
;
he
could
not
reject
the
bread
that
was
offered
to
his
children
,
or
refuse
to
ease
the
heavy
burden
that
had
so
long
oppressed
that
poor
wife
of
his
;
nevertheless
,
it
had
been
very
grievous
to
him
to
think
that
in
going
to
the
hospital
he
might
encounter
the
ill
-
will
of
his
brethren
in
the
diocese
.
<EOS>
All
this
Mr.
Harding
had
fully
comprehended
.
<EOS>
It
was
for
such
feelings
as
these
,
for
the
nice
comprehension
of
such
motives
,
that
his
heart
and
intellect
were
peculiarly
fitted
.
<EOS>
In
most
matters
of
worldly
import
the
archdeacon
set
down
his
father
-
in
-
law
as
little
better
than
a
fool
.
<EOS>
And
perhaps
he
was
right
.
<EOS>
But
in
some
other
matters
,
equally
important
if
they
be
rightly
judged
,
Mr.
Harding
,
had
he
been
so
minded
,
might
with
as
much
propriety
have
set
down
his
son
-
in
-
law
for
a
fool
.
<EOS>
Few
men
,
however
,
are
constituted
as
was
Mr.
Harding
.
<EOS>
He
had
that
nice
appreciation
of
the
feelings
of
others
which
belongs
of
right
exclusively
to
women
.
  
<EOS>
Arm
in
arm
they
walked
into
the
inner
quadrangle
of
the
building
,
and
there
the
five
old
men
met
them
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
shook
hands
with
them
all
,
and
then
Mr.
Quiverful
did
the
same
.
<EOS>
With
Bunce
Mr.
Harding
shook
hands
twice
,
and
Mr.
Quiverful
was
about
to
repeat
the
same
ceremony
,
but
the
old
man
gave
him
no
encouragement
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
glad
to
know
that
at
last
you
have
a
new
warden
,
"
said
Mr.
Harding
in
a
very
cheery
voice
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
be
very
old
for
any
change
,
"
said
one
of
them
,
"
but
we
do
suppose
it
be
all
for
the
best
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Certainly
 
certainly
it
is
for
the
best
,
"
said
Mr.
Harding
.
<EOS>
"
You
will
again
have
a
clergyman
of
your
own
church
under
the
same
roof
with
you
,
and
a
very
excellent
clergyman
you
will
have
.
<EOS>
It
is
a
great
satisfaction
to
me
to
know
that
so
good
a
man
is
coming
to
take
care
of
you
,
and
that
it
is
no
stranger
,
but
a
friend
of
my
own
who
will
allow
me
from
time
to

to
come
in
and
see

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
be
very
thankful
to
your
Reverence
,
"
said
another

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
need
not
tell
you
,
my
good

,
"
said
Mr.
Quiverful
,
"
how
extremely
grateful
I
am
to
Mr.
Harding
for
his
kindness
to
me
 
<EOS>
I
must
say
his
uncalled
-
for
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
be
always
very
kind
,
"
said
a
third
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
I
can
do
to
fill
the
void
which
he
left
here
<EOS>
I
will
do
.
<EOS>
For
your
sake
and
my
own
I
will
do
so
,
and
especially
for
his
sake
.
<EOS>
But
to
you
who
have
known
him
,
I
can
never
be
the
same
well
-
loved
friend
and
father
that
he
has
been
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
,
no
,
"
said
old
Bunce
,
who
hitherto
had
held
his
peace
;
"
no
one
can
be
that
.
<EOS>
Not
if
the
new
bishop
sent
a
hangel
to
us
out
of

.
<EOS>
We
does
n't
doubt
you
'll
do
your
best
,
sir
,
but
you
'll
not
be
like
the
old
master
 
not
to
us
old
ones
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Fie
,
Bunce
,
fie
;
how
dare
you
talk
in
that
way
?
"
said
Mr.
Harding
;
but
as
he
scolded
the
old
man
he
still
held
him
by
his
arm
and
pressed
it
with
warm
affection
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
no
getting
up
any
enthusiasm
in
the
matter
.
<EOS>
How
could
five
old
men
tottering
away
to
their
final
resting
place
be
enthusiastic
on
the
reception
of
a
stranger
?
<EOS>
What
could
Mr.
Quiverful
be
to
them
,
or
they
to
Mr.
Quiverful
?
<EOS>
Had
Mr.
Harding
indeed
come
back
to
them
,
some
last
flicker
of
joyous
light
might
have
shone
forth
on
their
aged
cheeks
;
but
it
was
in
vain
to
bid
them
rejoice
because
Mr.
Quiverful
was
about
to
move
his
fourteen
children
from
Puddingdale
into
the
hospital
house
.
<EOS>
In
reality
they
did
no
doubt
receive
advantage
,
spiritual
as
well
as
corporal
,
but
this
they
could
neither
anticipate
nor
acknowledge
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
dull
affair
enough
,
this
introduction
of
Mr.
Quiverful
,
but
still
it
had
its
effect
.
<EOS>
The
good
which
Mr.
Harding
intended
did
not
fall
to
the
ground
.
<EOS>
All
the
Barchester
world
,
including
the
five
old
bedesmen
,
treated
Mr.
Quiverful
with
the
more
respect
because
Mr.
Harding
had
thus
walked
in
,
arm
in
arm
with
him
,
on
his
first
entrance
to
his
duties
.
  
<EOS>
And
here
in
their
new
abode
we
will
leave
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Quiverful
and
their
fourteen
children
.
<EOS>
May
they
enjoy
the
good
things
which
Providence
has
at
length
given
to
them
!
    
<EOS>
Conclusion
  
<EOS>
The
end
of
a
novel
,
like
the
end
of
a
children
's
dinner
party
,
must
be
made
up
of
sweetmeats
and
sugar
-
plums
.
<EOS>
There
is
now
nothing
else
to
be
told
but
the
gala
doings
of
Mr.
Arabin
's
marriage
,
nothing
more
to
be
described
than
the
wedding
-
dresses
,
no
further
dialogue
to
be
recorded
than
that
which
took
place
between
the
archdeacon
,
who
married
them
,
and
Mr.
Arabin
and
Eleanor
,
who
were
married
.
  
<EOS>
"
Wilt
thou
have
this
woman
to
thy
wedded
wife
,
"
and
"
wilt
thou
have
this
man
to
thy
wedded
husband
,
to
live
together
according
to
God
's
ordinance
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Arabin
and
Eleanor
each
answered
,
"
I
will
.
"
  
<EOS>
We
have
no
doubt
that
they
will
keep
their
promises
,
the
more
especially
as
the
Signora
Neroni
had
left
Barchester
before
the
ceremony
was
performed
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Bold
had
been
somewhat
more
than
two
years
a
widow
before
she
was
married
to
her
second
husband
,
and
little
Johnny
was
then
able
with
due
assistance
to
walk
on
his
own
legs
into
the
drawing
-
room
to
receive
the
salutations
of
the
assembled
guests
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Harding
gave
away
the
bride
,
the
archdeacon
performed
the
service
,
and
the
two
Miss
Grantlys
,
who
were
joined
in
their
labours
by
other
young
ladies
of
the
neighbourhood
,
performed
the
duties
of
bridesmaids
with
equal
diligence
and
grace
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Grantly
superintended
the
breakfast
and
bouquets
,
and
Mary
Bold
distributed
the
cards
and
cake
.
<EOS>
The
archdeacon
's
three
sons
had
also
come
home
for
the
occasion
.
<EOS>
The
elder
was
great
with
learning
,
being
regarded
by
all
who
knew
him
as
a
certain
future
double
first
.
<EOS>
The
second
,
however
,
bore
the
palm
on
this
occasion
,
being
resplendent
in
a
new
uniform
.
<EOS>
The
third
was
just
entering
the
university
,
and
was
probably
the
proudest
of
the
three
.
  
<EOS>
But
the
most
remarkable
feature
in
the
whole
occasion
was
the
excessive
liberality
of
the
archdeacon
.
<EOS>
He
literally
made
presents
to
everybody
.
<EOS>
As
Mr.
Arabin
had
already
moved
out
of
the
parsonage
of
St.
Ewold
's
,
that
scheme
of
elongating
the
dining
-
room
was
of
course
abandoned
;
but
he
would
have
refurnished
the
whole
deanery
had
he
been
allowed
.
<EOS>
He
sent
down
a
magnificent
piano
by
Erard
,
gave
Mr.
Arabin
a
cob
which
any
dean
in
the
land
might
have
been
proud
to
bestride
,
and
made
a
special
present
to
Eleanor
of
a
new
pony
chair
that
had
gained
a
prize
in
the
Exhibition
.
<EOS>
Nor
did
he
even
stay
his
hand
here
;
he
bought
a
set
of
cameos
for
his
wife
and
a
sapphire
bracelet
for
Miss
Bold
;
showered
pearls
and
work
-
boxes
on
his
daughters
;
and
to
each
of
his
sons
he
presented
a
check
for
£
20
.
<EOS>
On
Mr.
Harding
he
bestowed
a
magnificent
violoncello
with
all
the
new
-
fashioned
arrangements
and
expensive
additions
,
which
on
account
of
these
novelties
that
gentleman
could
never
use
with
satisfaction
to
his
audience
or
pleasure
to
himself
.
  
<EOS>
Those
who
knew
the
archdeacon
well
perfectly
understood
the
causes
of
his
extravagance
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Twas
thus
that
he
sang
his
song
of
triumph
over
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
This
was
his
pæan
,
his
hymn
of
thanksgiving
,
his
loud
oration
.
<EOS>
He
had
girded
himself
with
his
sword
and
gone
forth
to
the
war
;
now
he
was
returning
from
the
field
laden
with
the
spoils
of
the
foe
.
<EOS>
The
cob
and
the
cameos
,
the
violoncello
and
the
pianoforte
,
were
all
as
it
were
trophies
reft
from
the
tent
of
his
now
-
conquered
enemy
.
  
<EOS>
The
Arabins
after
their
marriage
went
abroad
for
a
couple
of
months
,
according
to
the
custom
in
such
matters
now
duly
established
,
and
then
commenced
their
deanery
life
under
good
auspices
.
<EOS>
And
nothing
can
be
more
pleasant
than
the
present
arrangement
of
ecclesiastical
affairs
in
Barchester
.
<EOS>
The
titular
bishop
never
interfered
,
and
Mrs.
Proudie
not
often
.
<EOS>
Her
sphere
is
more
extended
,
more
noble
,
and
more
suited
to
her
ambition
than
that
of
a
cathedral
city
.
<EOS>
As
long
as
she
can
do
what
she
pleases
with
the
diocese
,
she
is
willing
to
leave
the
dean
and
chapter
to
themselves
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slope
tried
his
hand
at
subverting
the
old
-
established
customs
of
the
close
,
and
from
his
failure
she
had
learnt
experience
.
<EOS>
The
burly
chancellor
and
the
meagre
little
prebendary
are
not
teased
by
any
application
respecting
Sabbath
-
day
schools
,
the
dean
is
left
to
his
own
dominions
,
and
the
intercourse
between
Mrs.
Proudie
and
Mrs.
Arabin
is
confined
to
a
yearly
dinner
given
by
each
to
the
other
.
<EOS>
At
these
dinners
Dr.
Grantly
will
not
take
a
part
,
but
he
never
fails
to
ask
for
and
receive
a
full
account
of
all
that
Mrs.
Proudie
either
does
or
says
.
  
<EOS>
His
ecclesiastical
authority
has
been
greatly
shorn
since
the
palmy
days
in
which
he
reigned
supreme
as
mayor
of
the
palace
to
his
father
,
but
nevertheless
such
authority
as
is
now
left
to
him
he
can
enjoy
without
interference
.
<EOS>
He
can
walk
down
the
High
Street
of
Barchester
without
feeling
that
those
who
see
him
are
comparing
his
claims
with
those
of
Mr.
Slope
.
<EOS>
The
intercourse
between
Plumstead
and
the
deanery
is
of
the
most
constant
and
familiar
description
.
<EOS>
Since
Eleanor
has
been
married
to
a
clergyman
,
and
especially
to
a
dignitary
of
the
church
,
Mrs.
Grantly
has
found
many
more
points
of
sympathy
with
her
sister
;
and
on
a
coming
occasion
,
which
is
much
looked
forward
to
by
all
parties
,
she
intends
to
spend
a
month
or
two
at
the
deanery
.
<EOS>
She
never
thought
of
spending
a
month
in
Barchester
when
little
Johnny
Bold
was
born
!
  
<EOS>
The
two
sisters
do
not
quite
agree
on
matters
of
church
doctrine
,
though
their
differences
are
of
the
most
amicable
description
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Arabin
's
church
is
two
degrees
higher
than
that
of
Mrs.
<EOS>
Grantly
.
<EOS>
This
may
seem
strange
to
those
who
will
remember
that
Eleanor
was
once
accused
of
partiality
to
Mr.
Slope
,
but
it
is
no
less
the
fact
.
<EOS>
She
likes
her
husband
's
silken
vest
,
she
likes
his
adherence
to
the
rubric
,
she
specially
likes
the
eloquent
philosophy
of
his
sermons
,
and
she
likes
the
red
letters
in
her
own
prayer
-
book
.
<EOS>
It
must
not
be
presumed
that
she
has
a
taste
for
candles
,
or
that
she
is
at
all
astray
about
the
real
presence
,
but
she
has
an
inkling
that
way
.
<EOS>
She
sent
a
handsome
subscription
towards
certain
very
heavy
ecclesiastical
legal
expenses
which
have
lately
been
incurred
in
Bath
,
her
name
of
course
not
appearing
;
she
assumes
a
smile
of
gentle
ridicule
when
the
Archbishop
of
Canterbury
is
named
;
and
she
has
put
up
a
memorial
window
in
the
cathedral
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Grantly
,
who
belongs
to
the
high
and
dry
church
,
the
High
Church
as
it
was
some
fifty
years
since
,
before
tracts
were
written
and
young
clergymen
took
upon
themselves
the
highly
meritorious
duty
of
cleaning
churches
,
rather
laughs
at
her
sister
.
<EOS>
She
shrugs
her
shoulders
and
tells
Miss
Thorne
that
she
supposes
Eleanor
will
have
an
oratory
in
the
deanery
before
she
has
done
.
<EOS>
But
she
is
not
on
that
account
a
whit
displeased
.
<EOS>
A
few
High
Church
vagaries
do
not
,
she
thinks
,
sit
amiss
on
the
shoulders
of
a
young
dean
's
wife
.
<EOS>
It
shows
at
any
rate
that
her
heart
is
in
the
subject
,
and
it
shows
moreover
that
she
is
removed
,
wide
as
the
poles
asunder
,
from
that
cesspool
of
abomination
in
which
it
was
once
suspected
that
she
would
wallow
and
grovel
.
<EOS>
Anathema
maranatha
!
<EOS>
Let
anything
else
be
held
as
blessed
,
so
that
that
be
well
cursed
.
<EOS>
Welcome
kneelings
and
bowings
,
welcome
matins
and
complines
,
welcome
bell
,
book
,
and
candle
,
so
that
Mr.
Slope
's
dirty
surplices
and
ceremonial
Sabbaths
be
held
in
due
execration
!
  
<EOS>
If
it
be
essentially
and
absolutely
necessary
to
choose
between
the
two
,
we
are
inclined
to
agree
with
Mrs.
Grantly
that
the
bell
,
book
,
and
candle
are
the
lesser
evil
of
the
two
.
<EOS>
Let
it
however
be
understood
that
no
such
necessity
is
admitted
in
these
pages
.
  
<EOS>
Dr.
Arabin
(
we
suppose
he
must
have
become
a
doctor
when
he
became
a
dean
)
is
more
moderate
and
less
outspoken
on
doctrinal
points
than
his
wife
,
as
indeed
in
his
station
it
behoves
him
to
be
.
<EOS>
He
is
a
studious
,
thoughtful
,
hard
-
working
man
.
<EOS>
He
lives
constantly
at
the
deanery
and
preaches
nearly
every
Sunday
.
<EOS>
His
time
is
spent
in
sifting
and
editing
old
ecclesiastical
literature
and
in
producing
the
same
articles
new
.
<EOS>
At
Oxford
he
is
generally
regarded
as
the
most
promising
clerical
ornament
of
the
age
.
<EOS>
He
and
his
wife
live
together
in
perfect
mutual
confidence
.
<EOS>
There
is
but
one
secret
in
her
bosom
which
he
has
not
shared
.
<EOS>
He
has
never
yet
learned
how
Mr.
Slope
had
his
ears
boxed
.
  
<EOS>
The
Stanhopes
soon
found
that
Mr.
Slope
's
power
need
no
longer
operate
to
keep
them
from
the
delight
of
their
Italian
villa
.
<EOS>
Before
Eleanor
's
marriage
they
had
all
migrated
back
to
the
shores
of
Como
.
<EOS>
They
had
not
been
resettled
long
before
the
signora
received
from
Mrs.
Arabin
a
very
pretty
though
very
short
epistle
,
in
which
she
was
informed
of
the
fate
of
the
writer
.
<EOS>
This
letter
was
answered
by
another
 
bright
,
charming
,
and
witty
,
as
the
signora
's
letters
always
were
 
and
so
ended
the
friendship
between
Eleanor
and
the
Stanhopes
.
  
<EOS>
One
word
of
Mr.
Harding
,
and
we
have
done
.
<EOS>
He
is
still
precentor
of
Barchester
and
still
pastor
of
the
little
church
of
St.
Cuthbert
's
.
<EOS>
In
spite
of
what
he
has
so
often
said
himself
,
he
is
not
even
yet
an
old
man
.
<EOS>
He
does
such
duties
as
fall
to
his
lot
well
and
conscientiously
,
and
is
thankful
that
he
has
never
been
tempted
to
assume
others
for
which
he
might
be
less
fitted
.
  
<EOS>
The
author
now
leaves
him
in
the
hands
of
his
readers
:
not
as
a
hero
,
not
as
a
man
to
be
admired
and
talked
of
,
not
as
a
man
who
should
be
toasted
at
public
dinners
and
spoken
of
with
conventional
absurdity
as
a
perfect
divine
,
but
as
a
good
man
,
without
guile
,
believing
humbly
in
the
religion
which
he
has
striven
to
teach
,
and
guided
by
the
precepts
which
he
has
striven
to
learn
.
  
<EOS>
